                         Selected Books by the Author
1. 3D Unconditional Security—graphical overview of principle perspectives regarding unconditional security.
2. 4D Forgiveness—examines four levels of biblical forgiveness and explains how it is possible for God to
    forgive and forget our sin in one stratum while not forgiving or forgetting our sin in another stratum.
3. Breaking the Rocking Horse—introductory book regarding the distinction between having eternal life as a
    gift versus obtaining it as a reward in relation to the outer darkness and the parable of the soils.
4. Carnal Corinth—an affirmation of the categorical existence of carnal Corinthian Christians.
5. Destined for Salvation—evaluates five major models for interpreting 1Thess 5:9-10 and takes the passage
    as promising an unconditional rapture (and thus unconditional security) to all believers in Christ, even to
    those who are morally asleep. However, an incentive for being morally awake is provided by making
    salvation (in the form of millennial and eternal rulership) contingent upon being morally alert.
6. Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection—an advanced defense of unconditional security which affirms
    that believers can fall from grace but not fall from perfection.
7. Is God a Communist?—by comparing Paul’s teaching of the workmen with Jesus’ parable of the laborers,
    this book refutes communistic views of Heaven which think that Jesus is building heavenly mansions in
    New Jerusalem for all believers regardless of the way they live.
8. John in Living Color—a color-coded translation and reference manual of the Gospel of John that focuses
    on the grammatical and aspectual indications of unconditional security.
9. Like a Tree Planted by the Water—expounds upon the OT background for the outer darkness by examining
    the precursor texts in Psalms, especially Ps 1-2.
10. Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity—a more comprehensive discussion regarding perseverance (and
    other performance-related themes) as being needed for rewards in Heaven rather than for entrance into
    Heaven. This book provides both introductory material and advanced treatments.
11. Monogamous Sex in Heaven!—at the same time in which the present author was reading books by Marrow
    and Kreeft posing that sexual intimacy continues in Heaven, he discovered that his wife had stage-3 breast
    cancer. As a therapy to help him deal with this news, he poured himself into research to see if Marrow and
    Kreeft might be correct, thereby enabling him to believe that no matter what happened, the best was yet to
    come. This is the conclusion and comfort of this book.
12. New Birth by the Sovereign Wind—refutes the Calvinistic interpretation of Jn 3:16 that limits God’s love
    to the elect. An excursus deals with the Calvinistic claim from Jn 3:3 that one must be born again before
    one can see (i.e., believe) the gospel. An additional excursus entertains a possible duality to what it means
    to see the kingdom.
13. Predestination and the Open View—a discussion of predestination that focuses on free will and the book
    of life from an open view.
14. Rewards are Eternal—is a defense of the eternal nature of biblical rewards against the proposition that
    Rev 22:5 indicates that all believers will rule in the eternal state and against the premise that Rev 21:4
    proves that misthological death will no longer exist in the eternal state.
15. Sealed and Secure—a thorough defense of a popular argument for unconditional security that also defends
    the premise of unconditional promises.
16. The Race of Grace—introductory book in which performance-related themes (such as perseverance) are
    considered essential for rewards in Heaven. Entrance into Heaven, in contrast, is regarded as free. A strong
    defense of unconditional security derived from believers being given to Jesus is a strength of this book.
17. The Outer Darkness—a magnum opus that ties together the author’s arguments for unconditional security
    and conditional rewards.
18. Woolly Wolves and Woolless Sheep—a rejection of the notion that profession of salvation is proven genuine
    by the way a person lives. This book focuses on the parable of the sheep and the goats and shows the
    inadequacy of conditional security in interpreting this parable.

             For these and other books by the author, see http://misthology.org/?page_id=35.
                      For additional material, see www.UnconditionalSecurity.org.

                                                 Acknowledgments
       Keith Call had requested that I do a book dedicated to New Jerusalem. So, when our mutual friend, Scott
Crawford, asked me to teach a series of Sunday School lessons on New Jerusalem, I put material in a book format
to facilitate both requests. Keith also provided multiple references to books for me to consider in my research and
did the initial proofreading of this book. Consequently, the impetus for this present book is largely attributable to
him. As always, I am thankful for my mother, Gladys J. Cauley, for assisting in the proofreading. Likewise, I
appreciate my wife, Dianne Cauley, for assisting as well.
              Chapter 1. New Jerusalem in the Historical Past
                                                      Introduction
       As explained earlier in this misthological series,1 my friend Scott Crawford and I had differences of opinion
over where believers go when they die. I believed they went to New Jerusalem. He believed they went elsewhere
in Heaven. After all, Heaven is a big place, a big country, perhaps even including other planets. Why posit that
believers are currently living in New Jerusalem? Being unable to answer the question definitively from Scripture
at the time, I finally resorted to reading a lot of books on near-death experiences to determine where believers are
claiming to be taken during these experiences. Were they claiming to be taken inside New Jerusalem or outside of
New Jerusalem? At the conclusion of that analysis, I discovered that Scripture already had provided a critical clue
cryptically in the book of Hebrews. Indeed, Hebrews has some other tantalizing information about the Heavenly
City as well.
                                                Looking for the City
        One fascinating piece of information provided by Hebrews is that many OT believers were looking forward
to this Heavenly City. The first reference to this City tells us that Abraham was looking for this City:

      8
        By faith Abraham, when he was called, obeyed by going out to a place which he was to receive for
      an inheritance; and he went out, not knowing where he was going. 9 By faith he lived as an alien in
      the land of promise, as in a foreign land, dwelling in tents with Isaac and Jacob, fellow heirs of the
      same promise; 10 for he was looking for the city which has foundations, whose architect and builder is
      God. (Heb 11:8-10)

     Despite the misgivings of some commentators who follow Philo in treating this City as allegorical (ICC-
Moffatt, NICNT-Bruce)2 or who believe that Abraham “may not have clearly understood this” City (GNTC-
Tanner), many commentators readily take the text at face value and believe that Abraham was indeed looking for a
Heavenly City. Baker is representative of those writers who take such texts at face value:

              All of God’s people who have died since the days of Adam are now happy inhabitants of the
      New Jerusalem. This is the teaching of the Bible, for when we come to the New Jerusalem we are
      come to “Mount Zion and unto the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem—and to the spirits
      of just men made perfect.” (Heb.12:22,23).
              Jesus said to the repentant thief on the cross, “Today shalt thou be with me in Paradise” (Luke
      23:43). That day the dead body of the thief was on the cross. His soul was in Paradise, the Garden of
      God, the Eden of the Lord. This was not soul-sleeping, soul-unconsciousness. It was entrance into an
      enlarged life in the abundance of God’s glory. It was entrance into the conscious life of eternal peace
      by still waters and green pastures.
              In the heavenly city then are the spirits of “just men made perfect”, the saved of God from the
      beginning of God’s saving grace. Here the saints of both Old and New Testament, and the saints of all

1
  Soteriology is based on two biblical Greek words, soteria (salvation) and logos (teaching) and correspondingly
refers to the biblical teaching about salvation. Although the biblical concept of salvation includes many dimensions
other than deliverance from Hell, it is this aspect of salvation to which writers frequently refer when they use the
word soteriology. Thus, salvation from Hell (or, more specifically, from eternal damnation in the Lake of Fire) will
be referred to as soteriological salvation. In contrast, misthology is a coined term derived from the Greek word
misthos (reward) and logos (teaching) and refers to the doctrine of temporal and eternal rewards but is used
primarily in reference to eternal rewards. Misthological themes pertain to eternal rewards.
2
  The position taken herein is opposed to that taken by the likes of EBD: “The new Jerusalem pictured at Rev. 21–
22 is a not a new theme, but one borrowed from the Old Testament and later Jewish literature (Isa. 54:11–14; 60:15-
22; Ezek. 40–48). The new Jerusalem in Revelation, however, figuratively represents the body of Christ.” If it were
borrowed from later resources and represented the body of Christ, then Abraham could not have been looking for
it. A similar objection should be made to DNTB attributing the NT discussion to “a strain of apocalyptic thinking
in Second Temple Judaism.”
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                       Page 2
      succeeding centuries unite in heaven’s ways on the plains of this city of the Third Heaven. Abraham,
      when on earth, “sojourned in the land of promise as in a strange country, dwelling in tabernacles—for
      he looked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God.” (Heb. 11:9,10).
      Although the Lord had promised earthly possession of the land of Canaan to Abraham and his seed,
      he well knew that his real Canaan was the heavenly Jerusalem and that, in fact, he was but a
      stranger and a pilgrim on any earthly soil. Not only Abraham, but all those Old Testament saints, as
      well, knew that their ultimate goal, their real abiding country was the heavenly land. It was because of
      this revelation given by God that they had faith to persevere through privations and persecutions as
      strangers and pilgrims in the present world, bound for the heavenly Jerusalem. These Old Testament
      saints “all died in faith, (not having received the promise in the heavenly city), but having seen them
      afar off and were persuaded of them (the certainty of the heavenly life in the New Jerusalem), and
      confessed that they were strangers and pilgrims on earth.” (Heb. 8:11, 13). All these saints knew,
      therefore, that their promises were heavenly, not earthly. “For they that say such things declare plainly
      that they seek a country” (not on earth). “They desire a better country, that is a heavenly, wherefore
      God is not ashamed to be called their God: For He hath prepared for them a city.” (Heb. 11:13,14,16).
      Hence, God prepared a city, the New Jerusalem, for all the saints of Old Testament days.3

       Some scholars recognize both the literal and misthological nature of this Reward City. Yates, for example,
in an excellent article about the description of this City in Revelation, affirms both its literality and misthology:

             The principle of progressive revelation supports the view that the rewards predicted in [Rev]
      7:15b-17 will be bestowed in the eternal state (21:1-7). Progressive revelation affirms that later
      revelation clarifies earlier revelation. Thus it is suggested that the time of these rewards is not clarified
      until John’s revelation is finished and all has been recorded.
             After John viewed the heavenly scene of the great multitude (7:9-17), he was shown scenes of
      the coming Tribulation period (chaps. 8–18), the return of Christ in judgment (chap. 19), the millennial
      reign of Christ (20:1-9), and the final judgments (vv. 10-15). Then subsequent to these visions he was
      shown the final state of the new heavens and the new earth, which included the New Jerusalem (21:1-
      22:5). It is in the context of this later description of the New Jerusalem that the rewards predicted in
      7:15b-17 will be fulfilled. The rewards predicted in [Rev] 7:15b-17 are clarified in 21:1-4 as
      descriptive of the holy city in the final state. In that context (v. 7), John was told that these eternal
      rewards are for ὁ νικῶν (“the one who overcomes”).4

       True. The progressive nature of revelation clarifies the misthological nature of previously promised heavenly
rewards as finding fulfillment in this Reward City, such as: serving God in His temple, having Him spread His
tabernacle over you, having Him guide you to the very springs where the water of life originates, having Him wipe
away your tears and remove all sorrow. As rewards, such benefits are limited to those believers who overcome, but
they are not limited to believers within the church age but include tribulational overcomers as well. Yates notes that
the erroneous discounting of the literal nature of the City and confusing its misthological nature with soteriology
goes back to Origen:

             Some writers hold that the blessings promised in [Rev] 7:15b-17 are metaphors of salvation that
      portray what all people receive when they turn to God. They view Christ feeding them “by his word,”
      and God Himself being the fountain of life. This interpretation follows Origen, who taught that the
      saints’ reward would not be a literal, fleshly kingdom of eating and marrying. He insisted that the
      kingdom would be spiritual, for they will “drink from the cup of divine wisdom.” Yet, as will be
      argued, these descriptions refer to physical as well as spiritual blessings in the eternal state. (Italics
      his.)5

      Contrary to the allegation and allegorization of Origen, this City is not a soteriological metaphor for aspects

  H. A. Baker, Heaven and The Angels, Kindle Edition (Lawton, OK: Great Plains Press, 2012), 61-62.

of salvation shared by all believers. Rather, it refers to a reward associated with a variety of other rewards that are
limited to those believers who experientially overcome. This Reward City houses and is associated with a variety
of rewards and is the home of rewarded overcomers, as John affirms in Revelation. This is the City for which
Abraham was seeking, as affirmed by Hebrews. Continuing then with comments regarding this City in Hebrews:
“This God-established ‘City’ is a true ‘place’ (v. 8). It is, in fact, identical to the ‘rest’ that God has prepared for his
people (4:1)” (NICNT-Cockerill). “Abraham and the other patriarchs were seeking a city which, because it was in
heaven, was not yet (v. 7; cf. v. 3) visible to them, but which (like God’s “resting-place” in 3:7–4:11) has existed
from the beginning of creation” (NIGTC- Ellingworth). As Fruchtenbaum correctly deduces from the discussion in
Hebrews, Abraham was looking for two things: “It was the Heavenly Jerusalem, which Abraham believed was his
ultimate Promised Land. This was in addition to and not in place of the Land of Canaan” (ABC). Abraham was
looking for the Promised City in addition to, not in place of, the Promised Land. Pentecost integrates the discussion
of Hebrews and Revelation:

              Of Abraham it was said that his hope centered in life in a city, “For he looked for a city
       which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God” (Heb. 11:10). That this was the
       expectation, not only of Abraham, but also of other Old Testament saints is seen in Hebrews
       11:16, where it is stated: “But now they desire a better country, that is, an heavenly: wherefore God is
       not ashamed to be called their God: for he hath prepared for them a city.” It is observed that the hope
       of these heroes of faith, according to this verse, was a heavenly city.
              This same heavenly city is further described in Hebrews 12:22-24, where it is called the
       heavenly Jerusalem. In Galatians 4:26, it is called “Jerusalem which is above,” in Revelation 3:12, it
       is called “The city of my [Christ’s] God,” and “new Jerusalem,” in Revelation 21:2, it is called “the
       holy city, new Jerusalem,” and in Revelation 21:10, it is called “that great city, the holy Jerusalem.”
       In these passages it is clearly seen to be the place where all the hopes of the church saints will be
       realized. Without doubt this is the “place” our Lord promised He would go to prepare and to which He
       would come and take us in John 14:2. It is no real problem, then, to identify the “church of the
       firstborn” who occupy this heavenly Jerusalem according to Hebrews 12:23. There can be no doubt
       that this heavenly city will be comprised, in part, of the church, the body of Christ, from this present
       age.
              Hebrews 12:22-24 gives us a word that leads us to expect other redeemed men to be in that
       heavenly city in addition to the saints of this age. The term general assembly [panēquris] implies not
       merely a great, but the full number. And this circumstance, that all the members are collected, gives
       the assembly a character of solemn and joyous festivity. The question is: “Who joins with the
       unfallen angels and the church saints to make up the full complement of the inhabitants of that
       heavenly city?” The answer is in the phrase “the spirits of just men made perfect,” who are
       evidently the Old Testament saints. It would seem, then, that the writer to the Hebrews is giving
       us a picture of the heavenly city, in which place there will be gathered together with Christ the
       unfallen angels, the resurrected and translated saints of the church age, and all resurrected Old
       Testament saints.
              This interpretation finds support in Revelation 21:12-14, where the walls of the “holy
       Jerusalem” are described. Here the same threefold occupancy is indicated, for in verse 12 there is a
       reference to the angels and the twelve tribes of the children of Israel and in verse 14 reference to the
       names of the twelve apostles of the Lamb. Thus the angels, saints of Israel and the Old Testament, and
       the saints of the church are included within the wall.
              It would thus be concluded that it is the consistent teaching of Scripture that the Lord will gather
       unto Himself in the eternal city the unfallen angels, the Old Testament saints, and the New Testament
       believers, where they, in resurrected glorified bodies, will share in the literal city and its glory, into
       which place they can only enter by resurrection. It should be noted that this heavenly Jerusalem is
       not the sphere of the living saved who go into the millennium, for they will look to the rebuilt
       earthly Jerusalem as their capital city, but rather the dwelling place of the resurrected saints
       during the millennium. The living will realize the fulfillment of the national promises of the Old
       Testament in the millennium, while the resurrected will realize the fulfillment of the expectation of a
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                     Page 4
                                                                 6
      “city which hath foundations” during the millennial age. (Italics his.)

       Although this Promised City will be home to all the heroes of the faith from all dispensations, not all believers
will live in this Promised City. Believers who enter the millennial kingdom in physical bodies will live on Earth
and have the Earthly Jerusalem as their capital. Resurrected saints (i.e., experiential holy ones) will live in the
Promised City—this Heavenly City. Naturally, resurrected believers who do not qualify for this Reward City will
be excluded from it. The City would not be a reward if it were given freely to all believers regardless of whether
they overcome. The writer of Hebrews (hereafter WH) shows the reasonableness of making natural deductions
derived from the biblical text:

      13
        All these died in faith, without receiving the promises, but having seen them and having welcomed
      them from a distance, and having confessed that they were strangers and exiles on the earth. 14 For
      those who say such things make it clear that they are seeking a country of their own. 15 And indeed if
      they had been thinking of that country from which they went out, they would have had opportunity to
      return. 16 But as it is, they desire a better country, that is a heavenly one. Therefore God is not ashamed
      to be called their God; for He has prepared a city for them. (Heb 11:13-16)

       Indeed, Tanner (GNTC) gives reason to believe that Abraham did not regard the Promised Land to be his
real home: “Though Abraham by his own confession was a stranger and pilgrim even after reaching Canaan
(Gen 23:4), he certainly did not regard Ur (or Haran) [the land from which he came] as his true homeland.” And
Tanner (GNTC) concedes, regarding Heb 11:17-19, that “Abraham and the patriarchs were people who lived life
in light of their ultimate destiny in the eternal city of God.” Walvoord concurs:

             From these passages it is evident that the millennial reign of Christ on earth as such is not the
      ultimate hope of the resurrected saints, but rather of the saints who enter the millennium in their natural
      bodies and who are fitted for the earthly scene.
             This conclusion seems to be confirmed by the New Testament revelation concerning the
      heavenly city. In stating the faith of Abraham in Hebrews 11 it is stated: “For he looked for the city
      which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God” (Heb. 11:10). It is further stated of
      Abraham and his descendants who died in the Old Testament that they did not receive the
      promises, and in fact were seeking a heavenly city: “These all died in faith, not having received the
      promises, but having seen them and greeted them from afar, and having confessed that they were
      strangers and pilgrims on the earth. For they that say such things make it manifest that they are seeking
      after a country of their own. And if indeed they had been mindful of that country from which they
      went out, they would have had opportunity to return. But now they desire a better country, that is, a
      heavenly: wherefore God is not ashamed of them, to be called their God; for he hath prepared for them
      a city” (Heb. 11:13-16). It is evident from these verses that the hope which was Abraham’s in
      resurrection had to do with a heavenly city rather than an earthly kingdom.7

        The most reasonable conclusion, then, is that these OT believers knew about this Heavenly City and wanted
to live in such a way that would qualify them to live in it. Abraham confessed his true feelings about the Promised
Land while buying a burial place for his wife Sarah in this land, when he said, “I am a stranger and a sojourner
among you” (Gen 23:4). Additionally, just a few verses earlier, WH reminded us: “By faith Enoch was taken up so
that he should not see death, and he was not found, because God had taken him” (Heb 11:5). Where was Enoch
taken? The most intuitive answer would be that he was taken up to live with God somewhere in Heaven. Moses
summarized the background story in Genesis: “And Enoch walked with God; and he was not, for God took him”
(Gen 5:24). Strictly following WH’s logic, we would infer that Abraham was hoping to achieve the same outcome,
that is, to go live with God in His heavenly country. In that case, why not just infer a heavenly country home rather
than living in a heavenly city? It sounds like WH has insider information. He affirms that Abraham was not merely

looking for a heavenly country but a heavenly city. Did he get this additional information from Enoch? There is a

      28. And I stood up to see till they folded up that old house; and carried off all the pillars, and all the

      laid it in a place in the south of the land. 29. And I saw till the Lord of the sheep brought a new house
      greater and loftier than that first, and set it up in the place of the first which had been folded up: all
      its pillars were new, and its ornaments were new and larger than those of the first, the old one which
      He had taken away, and all the sheep were within it.8 (1Enoch 90:28-29)

On the other hand, Johnson regards this as a reference to the Millennial Temple instead of New Jerusalem.9 In any
case, no mention of foundations is made, so this Enochian document will not suffice as a source for WH’s inference
that Abraham was looking for a heavenly city, much less the Heavenly City specifically described by John. Of
course, the foundation of New Jerusalem, as described by John, is certainly an outstanding feature of that City
(Rev 21:4,19). But proposing that WH had access to Revelation is very problematic. Revelation may have been
written decades later. Other sources were available for WH, however. Paul had been to Heaven in an out-of-body
experience, perhaps a near-death experience (2Cor 12:2-4). Surely, he would have seen New Jerusalem. If Paul is
WH or an associate of WH, this might explain where WH got his insider information about the foundations. Still,
how would Abraham have known to look for a city, much less a city characterized by such a foundation? Where
did Abraham and the other OT saints gain their misthological knowledge of the Heavenly City built by God?
                                                     The City
        The KJV translates Heb 11:10 as, “For he looked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker
is God.” However, the Greek text has a definite article, so the verse should be translated as: “For he was looking
forward to the city that has foundations, whose designer and builder is God” (ESV). Moreover, “the Greek is
literally ‘which has the foundations,’ indicating not just any city but one specifically characterized by its
foundations” (EBC-Garland).10
                                               Jewish Literature
       Perry Stone makes a key observation: “Some may assume that God simply spoke the Holy City, the New
Jerusalem, into existence. The New Jerusalem was not spoken into being, however, but was built and made under
God’s supervision” (emphasis his).11 This City was a common feature in Jewish apocalyptic thought, as shown by
the following frequently cited text:
      1
        And the Lord said to me:
      This city will be delivered up for a time,
      And the people will be chastened for a time,
      And the world will not be forgotten.
      2
        Or do you think that this is the city of which I said: On the palms of my hands I have carved you? 3 It
      is not this building that is in your midst now; it is that which will be revealed, with me, that was
      already prepared from the moment that I decided to create Paradise. And I showed it to Adam
      before he sinned. But when he transgressed the commandment, it was taken away from him—
      as also Paradise. 4 After these things I showed it to my servant Abraham in the night between the
      portions of the victims [see Gen 15:7-21]. 5 And again I showed it also to Moses on Mount Sinai
      when I showed him the likeness of the tabernacle and all its vessels.12 (2 Baruch 4:1-4; Italics his)

       In this Jewish document (probably written after Hebrews), the City was: created before God created Paradise,

also have been aware of traditions in which God shows heavenly Jerusalem to Abraham (as in 2 Bar. 4:1–7), making
this the real goal of his pilgrimage” (BKBC). If so, then WH has confirmed this Jewish tradition to a considerable
extent! Then again, Lane (WBC) is rather turned off about the prospect of influence or confirmation:

      The biblical concept that God laid the foundations of the city of Jerusalem (Ps 86[MT 87]:1, 5 LXX)
      was extended to the foundations of the glorified, heavenly city as well (Isa 28:16; 54:11 LXX), and
      this motif is echoed in later Jewish and Christian apocalyptic literature (e.g., 4 Ezra 10:27; Rev 21:10–
      14, 19–20). The well-founded city of God furnishes a fixed metaphor for the kingdom of God or the
      reign of God in its totality (e.g., Ezek 48:35; Tob 13:7–8; Heb 12:22; 13:14; Rev 3:12; 4 Ezra 7:26;
      8:52; see Comment on Heb 11:16; 12:22; 13:14). An interesting strand of the tradition in post-
      biblical Jewish apocalyptic affirms that God had shown the pre-existent heavenly city to
      Abraham during the incident reported in Gen 15:9–21 (2 ApocBar 4:2–5; cf. 4 Ezra 3:13–14; T.
      Abr. 2:6 [Recension A]). There is no influence from this tradition on the formulation of v 10, or
      elsewhere in Hebrews.

DeSilva (BKBC) shares this assessment of Heb 11:10:

      The author points to the fact that Abraham chose to live “in tents” and to call himself a “sojourner”
      even after he entered Canaan (Gen. 12:8; 13:18; 17:8; 23:4) as “proof” that Abraham knew he was
      looking not for any earthly region as his abiding dwelling place, but rather for the heavenly homeland
      (Heb. 11:13–16). This is in keeping with his argument in Heb. 4:1–11 that “Canaan” was not the “rest”
      that God promised to God’s people. The author uses the language of a “city with foundations,”
      recalling the Zion traditions of LXX Ps. 48:9, Ps. 87:5 [cp. v. 1], and Isa. 14:32, all of which speak of
      God’s laying the “foundations” of Jerusalem “forever.” The author associates these traditions,
      however, with a heavenly city, since earthly Jerusalem had been subject to the ravages of conquest
      and war throughout its history.

       Really? Is WH merely gathering inferences from post-Abrahamic OT texts and attributing them to Abraham?
Frankly, the more reasonable supposition is that Abraham had seen the City, at least “from a distance” (Heb 11:13),
perhaps in a vision, or had heard of the City from other sources, such as Shem. Stedman affirms that Abraham saw
the City:

      It is amazing how far Abraham saw by faith. He lived two thousand years before Christ, and we live
      two thousand years after him. Yet Abraham, believing that what God had said would take place, looked
      across forty centuries of time and beyond to the day when God would bring to earth a city with eternal
      foundations. Abraham saw what John saw in Revelation: a city coming down from heaven onto
      earth (Rev 21). That is what Abraham longed for; an earth run after God’s order, where people would
      dwell together in peace, harmony, blessing, beauty and liberty. (IVPNTCS)

      Zev Vilnay records Jewish legends reporting that God showed Moses the Reward City just before he died:
“On the same day when Moses was to die, the Almighty, blessed be He, lifted him up to the skies, and He showed
him what reward awaited him therein…the Temple of heaven out of precious stones and pearls….the house which
the Lord buildeth with his own hands in the heavens, out of precious stones” (pp. 130-131). Whether Moses actually
saw the City before his death, we know that he knew about the City before he left the land of Egypt (Heb 11:26).
Vilnay commences his section entitled Celestial Jerusalem by saying, “Not only on the face of this earth is there a
Jerusalem, called in Hebrew Yerushalaim Shel Matt (the Lower) but also in heaven is there such a city Yerushalaim
Shel Maalah—Jerusalem the Upper.” He concludes this section by noting that early church fathers believed the
Jewish legends that the Jewish people had been able to see the City in the sky:

            In the second century the church father Tertullian writes about the divinely built city of the
      Jerusalem which is in heaven: “It is evident from the testimony of even heathen witnesses that in Judea
Chapter 1. New Jerusalem in the Historic Past                                                                   Page 7
      there was a city suspended in the sky early every morning…As the day advanced, the entire figure
      of the walls would wane gradually, and sometimes it would vanish instantly.”13

Such extrabiblical texts and traditions appear to be reasonably grounded to some degree in historical reality.
According to the extrabiblical text cited above and believed by many early Christians to be true, the City was shown
to Adam while he was in Paradise and was removed from him along with Paradise, but it was then shown to
Abraham and Moses. This extrabiblical text bears repeating:
             2
               Dost you think that this is that city of which I said: “On the palms of My hands have I graven
             3
      you”? This building now built in your midst is not that which is revealed with Me, that which prepared
      beforehand here from the time when I took counsel to make Paradise, and showed Adam before he
      sinned, but when he transgressed the commandment it was removed from him, as also Paradise. 4 And
      after these things I showed it to My servant Abraham by night among the portions of the victims.
      5
        And again also I showed it to Moses on Mount Sinai when I showed to the likeness of the tabernacle
      and all its vessels. 6 And now, behold, it is preserved with Me, as Paradise. 7 Go, therefore, and do as
      I command you.’ (2Bar 4:2-7)
                                                   Working Premise
       Whether Abraham literally saw the City at a distance or just saw it through the eyes of faith based on the
testimony of others is impossible to determine with dogmatic certainty. Even so, we can affirm with Stedman that
Abraham did see the City, in one capacity or the other. Abraham knew what he was looking for. For that matter, so
did Moses. He was looking for the reward, “considering the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of
Egypt; for he was looking to the reward” (Heb 11:26). According to Jewish legend, Moses saw this Reward City
just before he died. According to Jewish texts, he saw it even earlier at Mount Sinai. I believe that he and the elders
ate there at that time (Ex 24:9-11). The Jewish people knew about the City. Frankly, since the pyramids were
probably based on this Heavenly City, the entire world evidently knew about this Heavenly City.14 In that case, it
was no more necessary for Moses to comment on the Heavenly City in his writing than for him to comment on the
Great Pyramid. As sojourners in the land of Egypt, he and his readers were well acquainted with both the Great
Pyramid and its heavenly pyramidal archetype.
       As discussed in “Pyramidal City” (MMP2), extrabiblical texts confirm that the pyramids were patterned after
celestial “buildings in the sky,” which were believed to have been in existence before the Earth was created. Enoch,
Job, or Seth are the top candidates for the brains behind the construction of the Great Pyramid. Surely all three knew
about the Heavenly City. And in all probability Abraham was acquainted with Shem (as affirmed by Jasher.) The
working premise herein, accordingly, will be that commentators such as Stedman are correct in presuming that, in
one capacity or another, Abraham had the seen the New Jerusalem described by John in Revelation and that the
affirmation by WH can be taken at face value. Consequently, the presumption herein will be inverse to those
commentators who assume that WH pieced together inferences from the OT to some heavenly city of which
Abraham knew nothing and then attributed a desire to reach this city to Abraham. On the contrary, the more
reasonable postulation is to proceed from the premise that Abraham was actually looking for the Heavenly City,
which we know by the name New Jerusalem, and then follow the implications of that premise to their logical
conclusions with the reasonable expectation that hints about this City might be garnered from some OT texts.

                                               Nimrod’s Counterattack
       Circumstantially, although Isaiah and Jeremiah would later refer to the Great Pyramid (cf. Is 19:19-21;
Jer 32:17,20), Moses had no need to report on the presence of the pyramids or the presence of Heavenly City, after
which the pyramids were fashioned. These were ancient news. Everybody in Egypt knew about these. And the
children of Israel had just spent hundreds of years in the land of those pyramids. What was new was that God was
calling out a special people to inherit the Promised Land on Earth. The Sky God was going to create His own earthly
kingdom. He was not going to stay hidden away in His Sky City (a.k.a., Heavenly City). This Sky God had
previously divided the Earth among seventy angelic rulers in the table of the nations (Gen 10). This Sky God
intended for the nations to disperse throughout the world. However, under the leadership of Nimrod, they gathered
to build a tower to Heaven (Gen 11)—the Tower of Babel.
                                         Illustration 1. Nimrod’s Stargate




       Babel literally means gate of God in its Babylonian form. But Moses uses verbal wordplay and irony to
denote confusion in Hebrew. “The ‘Tower of Babel’ was an ancient construction called a ziggurat—a step-pyramid
building with a shrine at the top reserved for a divine being” (LBD). Thomas Horn pictures a stargate atop a ziggurat
for the cover of his book: Nephilim Stargates. This imagery is fitting. Whether the stargate was visible to the naked
eye is a matter of conjecture. Even so, this dimensional portal may have been visible to Nimrod’s Nephilim eyes.15
Seemingly, one reason for building this tower was to create a portal to Heaven whereby they might launch an attack
against the Sky God who had sent the flood (Gen 6-9). They might also try to bring forth the fallen forces that this
Sky God had banished to another realm to aid them in their fight against the Sky God. The earthly pyramids were
fashioned after the Sky God’s Heavenly City. He had destroyed their earthly pyramids with the flood. Now they
would launch a counterattack against His Heavenly Pyramid. The Jews, among others, had legends to this effect:

           But Nimrod was uneasy in his mind, and he feared lest someone should arise who would be

       Flynn provides legends that “the Tower of Babel was a tower to Mars” (p. 325). The Great Pyramid of Giza
would be “The Mound of Mars” (p. 336). He believes the Tower of Babel had a prehistoric background going back
to buildings on Mars. If so, naturally, we would ask, Who built these structures on Mars? Flynn acknowledges that
Hoagland believes pre-Adamic proto-humans constructed buildings on Mars before they were destroyed.
However, Flynn posits an alternate theory in which the aliens are angels (p. 352). Planet Krypton is the missing
planet that exploded between Mars and Jupiter, where some of its remnants form the asteroid belt (p. 359). It is also
known as the “Planet of the Angels” (p. 362) or “planet Rahab/Aster” (p. 368). It was “the center of the angelic
kingdom” (p. 445). The angels built the physical structures on Mars before their rebellion (pp. 446-447). The angels,
including Satan, existed in the physical realm and were the physical beings who built the physical structures
(p. 449). The extraterrestrials are angels (p. 458). God designed the mirror of heaven on these physical planets in
accordance with His as-above-so-below theme. Satan and his angels were to build these structures to God’s glory.
But Satan perverted them to glorify himself (p. 472). When God destroyed this angelic watery planet, the blast from
it wiped out the angelic buildings on Mars and resulted in the Luciferian flood on Earth (p. 445). Flynn prefers the
old-Earth gap model: “The age of the dinosaurs lasted from about 248 million years ago to 65 million years ago.
That entire world came to an end. God shattered Satan’s crown jewel, the fifth terrestrial planet, and the rebels were
stoned, their creation wiped out” (p. 477). So why build pyramids on Earth? “The Edfu Texts had described the
significance of the ‘mounds’ of the divine builder gods—the rebel angels. The correct building of mounds according
to the template disclosed by the builder gods would bring about a ‘resurrection of the destroyed world of the gods”
(p. 450).17

       How much truth may be in such legends is open to speculation. However, a kernel of truth is reasonably
supposed. The basic premise of such legends has been adopted within this misthological series: The Tower of Babel
was a rebel attempt to reach Heaven and counter God’s rule by attacking His Heavenly Pyramidal City.
       For myself, I would agree with those like Hoagland, whom Flynn cited, in allowing the possibility that pre-
Adamic proto-humans were involved in the original buildings on Mars in prehistoric times. Moreover, I reject the
native mortal-angel theory in favor of the pre-Adamic humanoid theory. Quayle reasonably postulates that the
pre-Adamic race was composed of humanoids who were genetically compromised by copulation with fallen
angels (as in the days of Noah), but this entire pre-Adamic human race was wiped out because none were left
genetically pure (unlike the case of Noah and his family).19 Horn believes that the Tower of Babel was to be
a stargate portal to reach Mars, the prison planet, for a jailbreak to release the fallen Nephilim spirits.20 The
postulation of prehistoric Nephilim naturally entails the proposition of pre-Adamic humanoids. Immortal fallen
angels would have had to assume a mortal form to procreate with mortal pre-Adamic humanoids in the prehistoric
past to produce prehistoric Nephilim before the Luciferian flood, just as immortal angels would have had to assume
a mortal form to procreate with mortal Adamites in the historical past to produce Nephilim before the Noachian
flood. Thus, we have biblical inferences for Luciferian Nephilim followed by Noachian Nephilim.

       In any event, the Tower of Babel was to use fallen angel technology to re-establish a connection with Mars
and fallen angels. Wayne poses: “Nimrod was easily capable of painting God as one of the more powerful gods but
also one of the more iniquitous and violent gods. God was framed as a most powerful God, but no more powerful
than the pantheon of gods worshipped by Nimrod and his followers” (Conspiracy, 288). These people were familiar
with gods who came into their human realm and took on mortal forms which could be killed. For instance, the 200
fallen angels who descended to mate with human women in Gen 6:1-4 took a physical form capable of sexual
copulation. Presumably, this physical form was mortal. Conversely, Nimrod reasoned that he could go into the
divine realm and kill such gods. He considered God to be one of these gods and was preparing to attack His City—
a proposition made all the more plausible if Nimrod planned on using fallen angel technology and gaining fallen
angel support, enlisting one group of gods to fight another group of gods and take the Mountain City.
       At any rate, Abraham was seeking this City, described in more detail by John in Revelation. Moses repeatedly
points out that Abraham considered himself a sojourner even in the midst of the Promised Land, which WH naturally
and correctly affirms (by these repeated affirmations of sojourning) as being indications that Abraham was seeking
the Heavenly City, which was widely known among the Jewish people of both the OT and NT era. What Abraham
and Moses had was insider information on how to reach this Heavenly City. It was not through building a tower
and trying to take it by force (Gen 11:5-9; cp. Mt 11:12).21 It was through faith in the Promised Redeemer, whom
they knew personally as the Angel of the Lord.
                                                    Gag Order
       Abraham and Moses were apparently under a gag order not to report details about the Heavenly City.
Concerning Abraham, the Jewish tradition affirms: “You [God] loved him [Abraham] and to him only you revealed
the end of times, secretly by night” (4 Ezra 3:13). According to Jewish tradition, the apocalyptic revelations given
to Abraham by God were secret. Likewise, we know from the OT Jewish Scripture that Daniel was permitted to
reveal certain end-time events but told to seal up other aspects: “But as for you, Daniel, conceal these words and
seal up the book until the end of time; many will go back and forth, and knowledge will increase” (Dan 12:4). We
also know from the NT era that Paul was caught up to Paradise, thus to New Jerusalem, but he was not permitted
to share the details at the time (2Cor 12:4). It was not until the end of the cannon that God chose to provide the
details about the Heavenly City via Revelation, and John was told, “Do not seal up the words of the prophecy of
this book” (Rev 22:10). After this unsealing, and especially in these latter days, many believers have had near-death
experiences and have been permitted to share many other details about the Heavenly City.
       How else will one reasonably explain the fact that Moses and seventy elders went up on the mountain and
not only saw God but had supper with Him, and all we get from Moses about this stupendous event is three verses?!?
      11
        Then Moses went up with Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel, 10 and they
      saw the God of Israel; and under His feet there appeared to be a pavement of sapphire, as clear as the
      sky itself. 11 Yet He did not stretch out His hand against the nobles of the sons of Israel; and they
      beheld God, and they ate and drank. (Ex 24:9-11)

       What did they talk about? What did they eat? What did God look like? If the pavement was like sapphire,
what were the surroundings like? Were they in a room? Were they in the Heavenly City? When the prophets are
caught up to the throne room later, presumably in the Heavenly City, they give us details. But we don’t get a peep
out of Moses about any such details. All we get from Moses about this dinner with God is a description of the floor!
The only way that I would not have blabbed away about the event, especially in the very book in which I was
writing about the event no less, was if the Lord had given me a gag order. Moses left Egypt for the sake of acquiring
the Reward City, yet he gives us no information about it, other than hinting that the edifice he was building was
patterned after a heavenly building (Ex 25:8-40), leaving the Jewish people and us to speculate that God showed
him the Heavenly City.22
       God, as a master strategist, had very good reasons for giving a gag order about the Heavenly City after which
Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, and OT heroes of the faith were seeking. One reason would be for the sake of
progressive revelation. The kingdom is the primary theme of the Bible. Yet this kingdom has both an earthly

21
   Gilbert says that the building of the Tower of Babel “was humanity’s attempt to force its way back into the divine

dimension and a heavenly dimension. By focusing the written revelation on the earthly dimension in the OT and
leaving the heavenly dimension to be transmitted through oral tradition (and perhaps also through nonconical
written patriarchal records), God did not preserve the oral tradition of the heavenly dimension with anywhere near
the same degree of fidelity. Consequently, during the silent years between the OT and NT, the oral tradition
regarding the heavenly dimension could slip out of sight from among the general populace and religious leaders so
that the tension between their focus on the earthly dimension and Jesus’ focus on the heavenly dimension would
result in His crucifixion. When Jesus came preaching about the kingdom of heaven being at hand, they expected an
earthly kingdom and thus misconstrued His offer of a heavenly kingdom. Their lack of understanding played into
God’s strategy, for otherwise, “if they had understood it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory”
(1Cor 2:8). The NT is a tale of two cities, not just one. By focusing exclusively on the Earthly Jerusalem, the general
populace and leadership, by and large, failed to perceive the significance of Jesus’ heavenly message, which was
tied to the Heavenly City. This resulted in a division among Jesus’ hearers, leading to His crucifixion.
                                        Two Progenies and Two Cities
      Lascelle, a Messianic Jew, commences her book, Heavenly Jerusalem, with an affirmation of Abraham’s two
progenies and their corresponding two cities. She concludes the first section of her book, The Two Peoples of
Abraham, by quoting the promise that God made to Abraham to make his descendants as the dust of the earth
(Gen 13:16) and the stars of heaven (Gen 15:5) and asserting:
            There are two peoples represented. The word sands points to earth, the word stars points
      to heaven. Both the earthly (dust) and heavenly (stars) people come from Abraham! As we study
      the Scriptures we find that for these two peoples there will be two Jerusalems, two Thrones, two
      Temples, one on earth for the earthly people and one in heaven for the heavenly people.23 (Italics hers.)
     She then begins her next section, Two Jerusalems, by reaffirming: “We repeat: There will be two Jerusalems,
one on earth for the earthly (mortal) people and one in heaven for the heavenly (immortal) people. Even Jewish
writings imply this” (p. 5). She then cites Legends of Jerusalem by Zev Vilnay, affirming Jerusalem the Lower on
Earth and Jerusalem the Upper in Heaven. Basically, the terrestrial and celestial versions of the City require that
Abraham understood the nature of the two progenies.
       Dolphin (JAJB) likewise links the Heavenly City with a separate progeny so as to pose two progenies.
Moreover, he suggests a plausible connection between the two cities and makes the Heavenly City the gateway
to the rest of the universe:
              Abraham’s dream impelling him onward in his long journey of faith was for a city to dwell in:
      By faith Abraham obeyed when he was called to go out to a place which he was to receive as an
      inheritance; and he went out, not knowing where he was to go.
              By faith he sojourned in the land of promise, as in a foreign land, living in tents with Isaac and
      Jacob, heirs with him of the same promise. For he looked forward to the city which has foundations,
      whose builder and maker is God. (Hebrews 11:8-11)
              Was Abraham looking only for an earthly city of God or did he envision a City of God in
      the heavens? Perhaps he was able to foresee both! Very often Biblical truth is not “either/or”
      but “both/and!”….
              In summary then the Bible speaks of two Jerusalems, not merely one. As Abraham was
      promised a heavenly family, as numerous as the stars of the heavens, and also an earthly family,
      a numerous as the grains of sand on the seas shore, so the coming time of redemption will feature
      a restored earthly Jerusalem, capital city of the Planet Earth, capital city of Israel.
              But there is also a great space city, a magnificent gateway city to the rest of the universe,
      Jerusalem Above, the mother of us all.
              Are the two Jerusalems connected? Probably yes. The Temple in Jerusalem on earth may
      well prove to be the “gateway” for “travel” to and from the orbiting space city New Jerusalem.24

Multiple points of interest are proposed in Dolphin’s analysis:
    1.    Abraham foresaw both the terrestrial Jerusalem and the celestial Jerusalem.
    2.    Abraham was promised both a terrestrial progeny and a celestial progeny.
    3.    The temple in the Earthly Jerusalem will be a gateway to the orbiting Space City.
    4.    The orbiting Space City is the Gateway City to the rest of the universe.
Each of these points is adopted herein with further advances suggested as well, such as: Not only did Abraham
foresee that his earthly progeny would dwell in the Earthly Jerusalem, where the Garden of Eden was originally
located, but he actually saw Heavenly Jerusalem up in the sky from a distance, as it was in stationary orbit above
that location. He knew that he would have offspring in both locations. A ziggurat in Earthly Jerusalem will be a
stargate portal to the Heavenly Jerusalem in stationary orbit above it, just as it was in the Garden of Eden. Pyramidal
heavenly 3D Jerusalem will be the stargate portal not only to other planets throughout this universe and the
multiverse but also be the portal to the Heavenly 4D Jerusalem and probably located in numerous locations at once
by means of its own teleportal sphere. These expansions on Dolphin’s summation serve as a demonstration that he
just surmised the tip of the iceberg. The present book will explore the submerged deeper depths of that iceberg.
       As various writers have deduced, two progenies go hand-in-hand with two very different types of cities. If
there is a terrestrial city and a celestial city and if Abraham knew that he would have descendants in both locations,
then it stands to reason that he could reason that he would have at least two different types of descendants: one who
lived in one city, the other who lived in the other city. Exploring the reasonableness of this deduction will serve as
a suitable introduction to a deeper exploration.

                God used “heaven and earth” to declare not only His creation of the universe but to provide a
         template of salvation for two distinctive entities: Israel and the Church (the body of Christ). To Israel,
         God made earthly promises. To the Church, He made heavenly promises. Both sets of promises
         originate in Abraham. God promised Abraham earthly, “dust of the earth,” “sand on the

      Testament (YHVH, ‫)יהוה‬. The heavenly descendants are both Jews and Gentiles (but primarily
      Gentiles) who have believed Paul’s gospel of grace (Acts 20.24; 1 Corinthians 15.1-4).25

Chitwood expounds upon the two progenies at length:

              Further, many Old Testament saints, beginning with Abraham, looked beyond the
      earthly inheritance to the heavenly. As seen in Heb. 11:10, 12, 16, with reference to both the
      heavenly and the earthly seed of Abraham from Gen. 22:17, 18, Abraham looked beyond the
      earthly land to a heavenly land. And as seen in Matt. 8:11, 12 and Luke 13:28, 29, such an outlook
      was shared by Isaac, Jacob, all the prophets, and undoubtedly countless numbers of other Jewish
      people over the centuries as well (cf. Heb. 11:32-40).
              And though this aspect of the kingdom was taken from Israel at the time of Christ’s first
      coming, with the one new man “in Christ” then called into existence to be the recipient of the heavenly
      part of the kingdom (the present abode of Satan and his angels, who, in a regal capacity, are to be
      replaced by Christ and His co-heirs), those Old Testament saints who looked beyond the earthly to
      the heavenly will not be denied a part in the heavenly. Though the nation at large has forfeited
      the right to rule from the heavenly sphere of the kingdom during the coming age, those Old
      Testament saints who aspired to occupy these positions will not be denied their right to do so.
              In fact, they will evidently occupy regal positions from the heavens over the restored nation of
      Israel on earth. Note that Christians (aside from the twelve apostles), the present recipients of that
      which was taken from Israel, have been promised regal power over the nations alone, never over
      Israel, which is not to be reckoned among the nations (cf. Num. 23:9; Deut. 14:2; Matt. 19:27, 28;
      Rev. 2:26, 27).26 (Italics his.)

Like Chitwood, Stedman appeals to Gen 13:16 and 15:5 to defend this distinction:

             It is highly unlikely, given our author’s precise use of language, that these two phrases
      should both describe the same descendants of Abraham, whether they are physical or spiritual.
      Abraham was first promised seed “like the dust of the earth” (Gen 13:16). Then some thirteen
      years later, when God announced the birth of Isaac within a year, Abraham was shown the stars
      and the promise was given, “Look up at the heavens and count the stars—if indeed you can count
      them….So shall your offspring be” (Gen 15:5). This widely separated revelation suggests the
      phrases should be understood as a reference to two lines of posterity: a heavenly seed (as
      numerous as the stars in the sky) which would embrace all who fit Paul’s description: “If you
      belong to Christ, then you are Abraham’s seed, and heirs according to the promise” (Gal 3:29);
      and an earthly line (as countless as the sand on the seashore), which includes all the physical
      descendants of the twelve sons of Jacob. This would agree with Paul’s statements in Romans
      11:11–12 that despite the formation of the church (the heavenly seed), God has not yet finished with
      his people Israel (the earthly seed). As the writer of Hebrews has intimated, the time will come when
      God will fulfill the new covenant of grace to “the house of Israel and the house of Jacob.” The blending
      of these two lines will be found in the city for which Abraham looked, on whose gates is written the
      names of the twelve tribes of Israel and on its foundations the names of the twelve apostles of the
      Lamb (Rev 21:12–14). (IVPNTCS)

Lee also defends this interpretation of Gen 22:17 by appealing to these two previous passages in Genesis:

             Abraham was blessed with two categories of people, one likened to the stars of the heaven

      you will see that they are of two categories, one heavenly and the other earthly. We, the
      Christians, are the stars, the heavenly descendants of Abraham; and the genuine Jews, God’s
      earthly people, are the sand, the dust. Eventually, the Jewish people will be God’s priests on earth
      and will teach all the nations. This is prophesied clearly in Zechariah 8:20-23. Why are the Jews
      described both as the sand and as the dust? The sea signifies the world corrupted by Satan, and the
      dust is of the earth created by God. The Jews have been restored to God’s creation. Hence, they are
      signified by the sand which is the dust beside the sea. Although they are an earthly people, they are
      not the dust under the sea, but the dust, the sand, by the seashore. They are separated from the corrupted
      sea, Satan’s corrupted world. However, the stars are not only separated from the corrupted world but
      are also heavenly.
             According to Revelation 20:8 and 9, at the end of the millennium Gog and Magog will fight
      against the camp of the saints and the beloved city. The camp of the saints is the camp of all the
      heavenly stars, and the beloved city, Jerusalem, is the city of the separated sand. The two
      categories of Abraham’s descendants, who at that time will be caring for God’s interests in the
      universe, will be attacked by Gog and Magog under Satan’s instigation. That will be the last war
      in the universe, a war between the devilish people and Abraham’s descendants.27

logic. When Abraham offered up Isaac, WH infers that Abraham “considered that God is able to raise men even

deduce that Abraham was able to conclude that God would raise Isaac from the dead because God had promised
Abraham a progeny through Isaac. Dead men do not have children. Thus, Abraham could deduce that God would
have to raise Isaac from the dead if that is what it took for God to fulfill His promise to him. From God’s promises,
Abraham could have deduced that God would raise Isaac from the dead. In a similar fashion, Abraham could have
deduced that he would have descendants in a heavenly location, thus a heavenly city. At a minimum, WH credits
Abraham with being able to make these deductions regarding his physical progeny. Seemingly, WH expects us to
reach the same conclusion about Abraham’s spiritual progeny. Abraham should have been able to deduce that he
would have both heavenly and earthly progeny since he was looking to inherit both the Promised Land and the
Heavenly City. Since Paul was able to make this deduction, what was to prevent Abraham from doing the same?29

the beginning and showed it to Adam before he fell and later showed it to Abraham and Moses. Such inferences are
entirely reasonable, and WH apparently accepts the reasonableness of such Jewish traditions and affirms them by
writing in this manner to these Jewish believers who, like him, were probably familiar with such Jewish traditions.
                                                    Human Aliens
       The NAS translates the verb paroikeo as live as an alien in Heb 11:9. It means to live as a resident alien.
Translations also render it as to live as a stranger or to sojourn. A stigma is associated with the term. “Wherever
he went he incurred the stigma of a stranger and a foreigner….In the LXX the verb παροικεῖν and its cognates are
used to characterize Abraham’s status and experience as an alien who resides in a foreign country without native
and civil rights” (WBC-Lane). Relative to the Promised Land, when Abram when down to Egypt, he was an alien:
“Now there was a famine in the land; so Abram went down to Egypt to live as an alien there, for the famine was
severe in the land” (TM). Relative to the Promised City, dwelling in the Promised Land was to live as a resident
alien. Relative to the Promised City, Gentiles are aliens. When Gentiles believe, however, they become “fellow
citizens” of the Heavenly City (Eph 2:19).31 “Proleptically [presumptively] Christians are already fellow citizens
even while they are still resident aliens, but only because one day they will be citizens in the full sense” (TDNTA;
emphasis original). Lane (WBC) says that WH’s “account of the story differs sharply from the version in Acts 7:2–
5.” True, Stephen’s focus is on the Promised Land, and he poses this as the reason that Abraham left for that land,
while the focus of WH is on the Promised City and provides this as the reason that Abraham lived as an alien in the
Promised Land. However, there is no reason to suppose a tension between the two biblical accounts.
                                                Prepared Perfection
       What was promised to these OT saints must have been the Heavenly City, as Cockerill surmises: “The
supposed ‘land of promise’ was no more than the place of Abraham’s earthly sojourn as he awaited his true
home….They are aliens here because they have affirmed their faith in God, chosen to obey his heavenly calling,
identified with his people, and committed themselves to live for the heavenly ‘City’” (NICNT). Phillips concurs:
“Abraham’s horizons were not dominated by the land of Canaan or by earthly things. He thoroughly understood
that God was calling him to a heavenly country and to the coming age when the material promises would all have
their ultimate fulfillment in heaven’s spiritual realities.” Moreover, “the word prepared is in the aorist tense,
meaning that it has already been done” (JPCS; emphasis his). The Heavenly City was already a reality. “To our
author’s mind Moses, as truly as the patriarchs, looked for his perfect recompense [reward] in the well-
founded city of God” (NICNT-Bruce). Commenting on Moses from Heb 11:26, Cockerill affirms: “Like Noah, he
lived in pursuit of ‘things not yet seen’ (v. 7). Like Abraham, he ‘saw’ God’s promised City (v. 13). He had his
parents’ vision into the things of God (v. 23)” (NICNT).

                                              A City Versus the City
       As to Heb 11:16, Fruchtenbaum (ABC) affirms that the patriarchs “knew that one day they would be in the
Heavenly Jerusalem, which is going to be far better than anything found on earth. Therefore, they stayed put, were
willing to wait, and not go back to where they came from.” DeSilva (BKBC) provides plausible background for his
summation quoted earlier:

             The author makes an important modification to the story of Abraham, so as to shape it more
      strategically to the audience’s situation. He takes Abraham’s focus off the land of Canaan as the
      “promised land” (despite Gen. 12:7; 15:7; 17:8), and raises it to the unshakable city that God has
      prepared in heaven. The author points to the fact that Abraham chose to live “in tents” and to call
      himself a “sojourner” even after he entered Canaan (Gen. 12:8; 13:18; 17:8; 23:4) as “proof” that
      Abraham knew he was looking not for any earthly region as his abiding dwelling place, but rather for
      the heavenly homeland (Heb 11:13–16). This is in keeping with his argument in Heb. 4:1–11 that
      “Canaan” was not the “rest” that God promised to God’s people. The author uses the language of a
      “city with foundations,” recalling the Zion traditions of LXX Ps. 48:9, Ps. 87:5, and Isa. 14:32, all of
      which speak of God’s laying the “foundations” of Jerusalem “forever.” The author associates these
      traditions, however, with a heavenly city, since earthly Jerusalem had been subject to the ravages of
      conquest and war throughout its history. Unlike the terrestrial Jerusalem, destroyed by
      Nebuchadnezzar in 587 B.C., profaned by Antiochus IV in 167–164 B.C. and Pompey in 63 B.C., soon
      to be ground under the heels of the Roman legions i A.D. n 70, the heavenly city truly does “have
      foundations” that will not be shaken. Indeed, God’s heavenly city alone will withstand the
      eschatological “shaking” that will destroy every earthly city along with the removal of the visible
      cosmos itself (12:26–28; 13:14). The author may also have been aware of traditions in which God
      shows heavenly Jerusalem to Abraham (as in 2 Bar. 4:1–7), making this the real goal of his
      pilgrimage.

would seem to imply at first glance. They were not just looking for a city—that is, any city built by God—but this
particular City built by God. The most reasonable deduction is that WH is using the OT inferences to affirm the

       Since this Heavenly City existed since the beginning of creation, it stands to reason that the Earthly Jerusalem
was only an earthly shadow of that Heavenly Jerusalem. WH’s proof is too weak to stand by itself as being logically
derived from OT texts, but if it is taken in conjunction with Jewish tradition, it is a logically justified inference.
However, according to WH, they were looking for two heavenly things not of this Earth: a country (patris) in 11:13-
16a and a city (polis). A city is not a country. This country is our fatherland. Bruce (NICNT), contrariwise, says,
“There is, of course, no difference between the heavenly country and the city of God.” Really? Naturally, those
who fail to see the City as being literal are subject to making such completely erroneous statements. Those who
take the text at face value, on the other hand, should be able to readily affirm the opposite: There is, of course, a
big difference between the heavenly country and the City of God. Nevertheless, though affirming the literality of

appears to be in order. This heavenly realm is (1) a country with (2) a city. Granted, there may be more than one
city. But the City in question in the book of Hebrews is the Reward City prepared for those believers who walk by
faith just as Abraham did. France correctly notes, “Their faith is to be rewarded by a ‘city’ (see on v. 10), and
the City the author has in mind is here, as in 12:22–24, the heavenly Zion. It is there rather than in the earthly
Canaan that they will ultimately be at home—and with them all those who share their faith and their looking
forward” (EBC). This particular City is to be their home with which they are rewarded. To be sure, the Promised
Land is also a reward. Therefore, at the misthological level, Stedman is correct to associate the land of Canaan with

the Heavenly City. Nevertheless, a heavenly country is broader than a heavenly city.
        To integrate Pauline terminology, this heavenly country is our fatherland, and that Heavenly City is our

Rest. On the other hand, the land of Canaan, as used topologically for soteriology versus misthology, may be used

        As defended in much more detail in TOD, the City of Zion is part of God’s eternal rest. “For the Lord has
chosen Zion; He has desired it for His habitation. This is My resting place forever; here I will dwell” (Ps 132:13-

will never enter God’s rest (Num 14:23; Ps 95:11; Heb 3:11), which is Zion, the New Jerusalem. This resting place
is contextually associated with His holy mountain (Is 11:9) and even with being an inhabitant of Zion (Is 12:6,
cp. Is 4:3-5). This Reward City is the misthological mountain home of those who qualify to live there. Passages
such as Num 14:21-23; Dt 3:18-20; 12:8-10; and Josh 1:13 convincingly show that the rest is a literal place,
specifically the land of Canaan. The City Zion, which is the central city of Canaan, is the resting place (Ps 132:13-
14). Subcomers will not be able to enter the Promised Land of Canaan on Earth or the Reward City in Heaven. They
will live in the land outside of the Heavenly City in the Celestial Outer Darkness and outside the Promised Land in
the Terrestrial Outer Darkness.
        This Heavenly City is not just a city in that country, but a city prepared for them (Heb 11:16b): the city which
has foundations (11:10). Some think that the reason the City has foundations is because it will come down to rest
on the Earth in the eternal state in the future. Whether it will be on Earth during the eternal state is debatable. Along
with other writers such as Becker, I am inclined to think that New Jerusalem will be in a geosynchronous orbit
above the Earth in the eternal state. A better postulation is that the City already has foundations because it is already
resting on solid ground now—in the heavenly country. As noted in MMP4, those who have had near-death
experiences affirm this to be the case. Presently, the Heavenly City is in resting on solid ground in the heavenly
country. Accepting this postulation is prudent because it rests upon the inference given to us by WH.

                                                      Conclusion
       Hebrews explicitly affirms that Abraham was looking for the Heavenly City that has foundations, identifies
it as Heavenly Jerusalem, and adds that other OT saints also were seeking to gain this City as their reward. Faithful
believers of all ages from the beginning of the human race until the return of the Lord will dwell in this Reward
City. Thus, OT saints are included. Moreover, Hebrews affirms that the City resides in a heavenly country. Various
interpreters, both ancient and modern, take these affirmations literally. God resides in Heaven (1Kgs 8:30,49;
Is 14:12-14). The literal approach reasonably infers that God resides in this Heavenly City on a heavenly planet—
Planet Heaven. Or one might refer to it as Planet Paradise. NDErs have provided eyewitness confirmation that these
biblical deductions are correct. The possible discrepancy in exegetical considerations and eyewitness accounts as
to the cubical versus pyramidal nature of the City might be best explained by posing that its multidimensional nature
allows both possibilities: a pyramidal 3D City that is a 4D cubical City. Seemingly, this Pyramidal City is accessible
through 3D pyramidal portals, and these portals might not be limited to this planet. Some pose that they were also
built as stargates by angels or pre-Adamic humanoids on other planets, such as Mars. Abraham was promised both
this Celestial City and terrestrial land on Planet Earth. Abraham could deduce that he would have heirs occupying
both realms. Over the course of time, the focus shifted from the celestial promise to the terrestrial promise, leading
to a conflict when Jesus came preaching that the kingdom of heaven was near to earthly-minded people.
       Since the Reward City is limited to those believers who overcome, questions naturally arise as to what will
be the fate of subcomers and Planet Heaven. If the Heavenly City is moved from Planet Heaven to Planet Earth at
the beginning of the millennial kingdom, what will become of Planet Heaven at that time? Would unfaithful
believers be consigned to live on Planet Heaven or Planet Earth or somewhere else? Do unfaithful believers now
live on Planet Heaven outside of the Heavenly City? Other questions about the Heavenly City also come into play:
When was it created? Why was it created? Where was it created? Plausible answers to such latter questions can be
gleaned by digging further into its past in the next chapter before proceeding to its future for the former questions.

                                                     Introduction
       As noted in MMP4, a disagreement between my friend Scott Crawford and me regarding the location of
believers during the present intermediate state led to my investigation in that book. Scott posed that no believers
currently reside in New Jerusalem. Contrariwise, I thought that all believers currently reside within New Jerusalem.
Not being able to derive an answer exegetically at the time, I opened my investigation in MMP4 to include near-
death experiences and visions of Heaven. What were believers purporting to see New Jerusalem saying about it?
Were all, some, or no believers currently living in it? As a result of that research, I derived a mediating position and
then came to find that the answer had already been provided in the Scripture. I was just blind to it until I was open
to seeing it by the results of that study. The present chapter will extract some of the most pertinent material from
that discussion in MMP4 since it answers the question regarding the present habitation and location of New
Jerusalem and confirms the conclusion of the previous chapter. After this review, we can then advance to new
material in the next chapter.

the central city of the infant paradise.”37 Infant Paradise is located in the lowest level of the Heavenly City. Just as
Paradise is composed of many paradises, so the Heavenly City is composed of many cities. Lindsay makes an

a considerable time, [sic] have now reached a state of perfection. Hebrews 12:22-23 indicates that they live
in their heavenly Jerusalem and that their spirits have been made perfect” (p. 23). Baker concurs from his
