Grammars
       As to the spirits of righteousness having been made perfect in Heb 12:23, let us hear a brief word from our
grammarians. What does this perfect participle about having been made perfect mean? Wallace (GGBB) notes that
“the perfect participle is almost always antecedent with reference to the main verb. When it is contemporaneous,
such is due to either an intensive use of the perfect or to a present force of the perfect in its lexical nuance.”
Robertson (GGNT) likewise says that the perfect participle “either represents a state (intensive) or a completed act
(extensive)” and “may be represented as completed before that of the principle verb and so antecedent action.”
Fanning (VANT) similarly states, “The perfect participle preserves the basic sense of the other perfect forms in
denoting a state or condition resulting from an anterior occurrence...it often emphasizes the resulting state and only
implies the anterior occurrence” (p. 416). The “temporal meaning,” that is, the anterior occurrence, is “in relation
to some reference-point, usually the action of the main verb” (p. 408). “The perfect participle’s normal temporal
relation to the main verb is that the resulting state is contemporaneous with the main verbal occurrence, and the
action which produced it is thus antecedent to the main verb” (p. 416, n. 23).39 They are each saying the same thing;
namely, the perfect participle acts perfectly normal, just the way you would expect a perfect aspect to act in Greek.
So, there is no excuse for commentators or biblical expositors to miss its significance in Heb 12:23.40
       22
         But you have come (proserchomai) to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God, the Heavenly
       Jerusalem, and to thousands of angels, 23 to the general assembly and church of the firstborn who are
       enrolled in Heaven, and to God, the Judge of all, and to the spirits of the righteous men having been
       made perfect (teleioo). (Heb 12:2-23; TM)

       The main verb in Heb 12:22-23 is proserchomai (you have come), used in the perfect tense in v. 22. When
these believers first became believers within this NT era, they personally and presumptively came immediately to
the potential realization of misthological perfection being described in this context, and they were still in that
potential state. However, something else already had happened before they came to this potential state. The spirits
of the righteous already had become perfect.
       The perfect participle of teleioo (having been made perfect) in v. 23 indicates that this teleological perfection
occurred antecedent to (i.e., before) they came to this potential state described in v. 22. What was a potential
misthological realization for these Hebrew believers in v.22 was already a realized misthology for the spirits of
these righteous departed spirits in v. 23.41 From Heb 11:40, we can pinpoint when they became perfect: not until
the advent of the NT era. Therefore, since these righteous spirits did not become perfect until the NT period and
since they became righteous before these Hebrew believers came to faith, the natural conclusion is that this perfect
translation in the spiritual arena by these righteous spirits was reached at the dispensational transition to the NT era.
Because WH associates this perfection with the Reward City in this context, we can safely deduce that their realized
misthology in the spiritual dimension involved a transition to the Heavenly City. Their spiritual perfection is
centered around a realized misthopology.42 We need to pay close attention to the tense used in the verse:

       In Heb 11:40, WH is talking generically about NT believers from a dispensational perspective, thinking in
terms of the entire NT era. (WH stresses the dispensational transition in his epistle.) From a dispensational
perspective, the us in 11:40 is only inclusive of the Hebrew believers being addressed in the epistle. These NT
believers are part of the new inaugurated era. Yet, in Heb 12:22, the writer is talking specifically about the Hebrew
believers whom he is warning about the danger of not finishing the race they have begun. He is not talking about
the whole NT era but that part of the NT era comprised of believers who had come to faith after that era had started.
These NT believers, as part of the new dispensation, had come to the potential realization of misthological perfection
in the intermediate state when they first believed. But the new dispensation, as a whole, did not occur before the
transition to intermediate misthological perfection. The beginning of the NT dispensation marked the beginning of
such metaphysical perfection. Put simply, NT believers now have come to the place in time, dispensationally
speaking, where the spirits of the righteous already have been made perfect in association with their having
entered the Heavenly City, something that did not occur until the start of the new dispensation. So, what
exactly happened? These righteous spirits were translated to the Heavenly City at the transition to the new
dispensation. Now, will the commentators and interpreters reach this proper conclusion? Lindsay did.43

who have waited eagerly for the Lord” (p. 108), that Zion in Is 62:11 is associated with a reward foreshadowing
New Jerusalem being associated with a reward (p. 113). Janet Willis, What on Earth is Heaven Like? A Look at
God’s City: New Jerusalem, second revised edition (Ashland, TN: Khesed Publications, 2015). She completely
misses the point that in the OT background in Exodus, which foreshadows the NT counterpart, it is the children of
God who are excluded from this mountain and that WH strongly associates access to Mount Zion with reward,
limiting access to God’s children who are faithful. The differentiation in access is not merely mortal versus immortal
but faithful versus unfaithful. Unfaithful immortal believers will not have access to this Reward City. Moses has
pictured the misthological outer darkness with this misthopological typology.
Chapter 2. New Jerusalem in the Present                                                                          Page 27
Whereas Greene advocates a realized soteriology, Lang insists upon an unrealized misthology. Lang is correct in
that the passages are misthological; Greene is correct in that the promise has been realized. Lang points out the
perfect tense in Heb 12:22 but completely fails to note the perfect participle in 12:23, resulting in a highly imperfect
argument. Heb 12:23 affirms that these select OT believers already have been perfected spiritually in the manner
anticipated in Heb 11:40, namely misthopologically. Misthopological perfection, insofar as it pertains to the
departed spirits of the righteous, is already a reality. At present, to be sure, it is only partially realized since it is
only realized spiritually. Two different stages of misthopological perfection must therefore be hypothesized.
         Intermediate misthological perfection allows an inaugurated realized metaphysical misthology regarding
the spirits of righteous believers in certain aspects: being clothed in white garments, eating the Tree of Life, and
inhabiting the Heavenly City. Ultimate misthological perfection requires the joining of the metaphysical spirit-soul
body with the physical body in order to rule over physical creation in a glorified resurrected body.
         The perfect participle in Heb 12:23 demonstrates that an intermediate form of misthological perfection must
be allowed regarding righteous spirits, as is explicitly confirmed by the biblical text. Lang missed this crucial
observation in Heb 12:23.
Govett
       Like Lang, Govett insists that the perfection in question in Heb 11:40 and 12:23 requires a physical
resurrection. Commenting on 11:40, Govett (GOH) postulates that those raised from the dead in Mt 27:52-53 at
Christ’s resurrection have entered the Heavenly City:

               Moreover, we have, at the close of our Lord’s life, a notice of “the spirits of just men made
         perfect,” and of entry into the eternal city, in those words of Matthew: ‘And the tombs were opened
         and many bodies of the saints which slept arose, and came out of the tombs after His resurrection, and
         went into the Holy City, and appeared unto many.46 (Italics his.)

       In this theory, Jesus only led some of the captives captive into the eternal City—those who were raised from
the tombs. The major problem with this proposal is, of course, that the perfection in Heb 12:23 is applied to
disembodied spirits. When he gets to Heb 12:23, Govett attempts to dispute this common understanding, saying
that in this verse, “‘perfected’ belongs grammatically not to ‘spirits;’ they are not perfected as ‘spirits,’ but as
righteous men’” (p. 453). His argument, then, is that having been made righteous modifies just the word righteous,
not the entire phrase the spirits of the righteous. This novel grammatical appeal fails on multiple accounts, however.
       First, in the sentence immediately preceding, Govett claimed, “They are ‘perfected,’ inasmuch as they are
accepted by God, and have run through their mortal course” (p. 453). No, this would describe why these OT
believers are righteous, not what it means to be perfected in this verse. Perfection in both this verse and in the
preceding reference has, as he himself admitted in regard to the previous reference, a view to “entry into the eternal
city.” This perfection pertains to entrance into the Reward City.
       Second, the biblical writer already has said that they could not obtain this type of perfection—entry into the
Heavenly City—apart from us NT believers, that is, apart from Jesus’ resurrection and the NT covenant it
inaugurated. These OT believers were, however, able to run their mortal course and become misthologically
acceptable to God apart from us and Christ’s resurrection. Therefore, contrary to Govett, WH is not posing non-
dispensational righteousness in 12:23. Govett is correct that we have drawn near dispensationally, but he is wrong
to say that “the word ‘just,’ or ‘righteous,’ describes them dispensationally” (p. 452). On the contrary,
dispensationally describes their perfection. A dispensational shift has occurred, and these OT believers are now, in
the time period of the new dispensation, something they were not before—misthologically perfect in spirit. They
were righteous before the NT dispensation, of course, but not perfect in spirit in the manner being described in this
context, that is, misthologically, or more specifically, misthopologically.
       Third, Govett contradicts himself. On the same page, talking about the same verse no less, he refutes himself.
On the one hand, he says, “‘Perfected’ belongs grammatically not to ‘spirits;’ they are not perfected as ‘spirits.”
Then, evidently without realizing his self-contradiction, he acknowledges, “They are ‘perfected, now as far as
regards their spirits” (p. 453). They are not perfect as spirits....they are perfected, now as...spirits. They are
perfected as spirits after all! What does that mean? He does not attempt to answer; he only makes a claim as to what
it does not mean.

46
     Robert Govett, Govett on Hebrews (Miami Springs, FL: Conley & Schoettle Publishing Co., 1981), 448.

        Yet, if we take our clue from his earlier comments regarding Heb 11:40, their being perfect in spirit would
mean that, now, in the new dispensation, they have entered the Eternal City in their spirits. Strangely, Govett asserts
the exact opposite, “They are ‘perfected, now as far as regards their spirits; they are awaiting the perfecting of their
bodies, as necessary to their living with God in His city. For no ‘glorified spirits’ of men will enter there” (pp. 453-
454). According to this so-called explanation, being perfected in spirit oddly means nothing more than waiting for
a perfection of your body. Govett trips all over himself in trying to deny the obvious: These disembodied righteous
spirits have now, in the new dispensation, entered into the Holy City.
        The dispensational transition that took place in Heb 10:14 took the spirits of all these subterranean believers
and made them soteriologically perfect. This dispensational transaction paid their redemption, taking them off
layaway, as it were. Nonetheless, the writer’s words in Heb 12:23 cannot refer to that soteriological perfection, as
the writer has placed the perfection within the latter verse in a misthological setting replete with misthological
warnings, applying only to the misthological righteous. Soteriological perfection is not an option for Govett in this
passage. Indeed, he acknowledges that moral righteousness is in view. He also recognizes that they are disembodied
spirits. Misthopological perfection of morally righteous disembodied spirits is the natural conclusion to which his
own analysis leads.
Tanner
        Although soteriological perfection was affirmed earlier in Heb 10:14, WH moved on to misthological
perfection in Heb 11:40: “God had provided something better for us, so that apart from us they should not be made
perfect.” Tanner (GNTC) correctly suggests that the church of the firstborn in Heb 12:22 is misthological in nature
and that the corresponding perfection in Heb 11:40 is misthological as well, in contradistinction to the soteriological
perfection found in Heb 10:14. However, Tanner’s rationale probably needs refinement. He assumes that because
the perfection in Heb 10:14 already has been accomplished, the perfection in 11:40 is more encompassing,
anticipating the future realization of the full Messianic scope of salvation. He is on the right track, noting the
misthological nature of the context in chapter 11 of Hebrews, but in his discussion of 11:40, he has failed to observe
that the perfect participle in Heb 12:23 indicates that they already have obtained the perfection in question insofar
as it pertains to their spirits. This aspect of their misthological perfection is not future.
        The reward for which God was preparing Abraham was the Heavenly City (Heb 11:8-19). After establishing
this fact in ch. 11, WH then proceeds in ch. 12 to say that the spirits of these ethically righteous believers have now
been perfected. The deduction is simple. These OT heroes of the faith now have joined the faithful believers of
the church age in the church of the firstborn in Heavenly Jerusalem. They already have been granted this
part of their reward via inaugurated misthopology. The OT faithful obtained the misthological promises (Heb
11:33), but those promises remained unfilled in the OT era (Heb 11:13,39). Not until the NT era were these promises
fulfilled and the spirits of the faithful perfected (Heb 11:40; 12:23).
        Not all believers qualify for this misthological perfection, of course. Only the faithful believers within either
the OT or NT dispensations qualify. The spirits of the faithful OT and NT believers, even now, during the
church age, while awaiting their physical resurrection, already have experienced the misthological spiritual
perfection by qualifying misthologically to dwell in the Heavenly City. The full realization, complete with their
physical resurrection and rulership, awaits the future, naturally, as pointed out by WH. Nonetheless, WH is urging
believers to be faithful, not only because eschatological misthological concerns are at stake, but because inaugurated
misthological benefits are at stake as well, already being experienced presently by a cloud of witnesses in the
Heavenly City.
        FG commentators such as Constable, Hodges, Tanner, and Yates perceive the rest being entered within
Hebrews to be a futuristic inheritance of the kingdom as a reward.47 In Fallen from Grace, I adopted this perspective

also and still do. Misthological rest is in view. However, they nor I had entertained the possibility of a partially

a present tense verb to assert that those believers who have that kind of faith “are entering” (GWN, NJB) this place
of rest, evidently right now. The use of the present tense in the verse has caused many exchanged-life trichotomists
(ELTs) to assume that a present temporal experience of peace and victory is entailed, espoused by the let-go-let-
God mentality. Tanner rightly shows the shortcomings of such a present-rather-than-future perspective. For one
thing, believers must exercise due diligence (Heb 4:11) to enter this rest, which would necessarily entail works. Yet
the context asserts, “For the one who has entered His rest has himself also rested from his works, as God did from
His” (Heb 4:10). Living believers cannot rest from their works because they must work in order to enter this rest.
Also, the passage is concerned with the possibility of failing to enter this promised rest rather than losing a temporal
rest that is being experienced already. A postmortem rest or an eschatological rest—or both—must be entailed.
        Aspectually, a punctiliar entrance () is suggested amidst a linear entrance: An aorist infinitive, suggesting
a punctiliar entrance, is used to state, “A [futuristic] promise remains of entering () His rest” (Heb 4:1), while a
present indicative is used to suggest linear entrance. “For we who believed are [currently] entering [ £] that rest”
(Heb 4:3; TM). Yet the present entrance would not be experienced in the present, on Earth, by those believers
striving to live for the Lord.
        Both the tension of the punctiliar-linear action and the present-future time are resolvable by enjoining realized
and eschatological misthology. The two verses (Heb 4:1,3) combine to indicate that the liner action may be pictured
as the outer shell and the aoristic action as the inner with a distributive aspectual symbol: “For we who have believed
 are entering  that rest” (TM). At the point of death, those soteriological believers who qualify as
misthological believers are considered those who have believed. Their misthological faith  at the end of their lives
qualifies  them for this misthological rest. Their perseverance in faith throughout the course of their lives
qualifies them to be considered misthological believers at the end of their lives. At that point, they enter into their
misthological rest, the City of Rest, as their heavenly reward. They join the company of “the spirits of righteous
having been made perfect” (Heb 12:23; TM). Spiritually, they are already experiencing this aspect of their
misthological inheritance. Physically, though, their inheritance (Heb 1:14) of “the world to come” (Heb 2:5),
associated with “the city which is to come” (Heb 13:14), has not yet been realized. Obviously, this City already
exists. The writer is not saying that the City is to become, that is, come into existence. Rather, this City, which
already exists in the heavenly dimension and which is currently housing the spirits of the righteous, is to come into
our physical dimension at a future time. We do not have a “lasting city” here, that is, on Earth. But we do have such
a City there, and it will come here, to Earth, when we inherit the Earth.
        In short, those righteous spirits, who already have entered this City of Rest, are already enjoying the fruit of
their labors. They already have entered His rest (Heb 4:10). Their works have followed with them (Rev 14:13), and
they are eating the fruit of the Tree of Life, evidently even now, within the City (Rev 2:7). They already are (not
merely will be) a part of Christ’s misthological household (Heb 3:6). They are living with Christ in His misthological
City. Such NT believers who endure until the end of their lives are, even now at the end of their lives, becoming
partakers with Christ in His City during the current dispensation. They already “have become partakers” with Christ
in this City of Rest (Heb 3:14). This City is their residency. They are already Christ’s partners in this City. As NT
believers, what is ours provisionally, principally, and presumptively is becoming ours experientially, even now at
the point of death, if we qualify misthologically.
        As a result of Christ’s sufferings, He became perfect in the sense of reaching His goal of winning an eternal
misthological resting-place, as a man, in the City of Rest, which He can share with the believing remnant of
humanity who live obediently just as He did:

        Jesus was perfected through His sufferings in the sense that He became (ginomai) something He was not
before: “the author of their salvation.” He became an author. When I wrote my first book, I became something I
was not before—an author. Likewise, when Jesus took captivity captive and led the faithful believers to their
heavenly rest inside the City of Rest (Ps 68:18; Eph 4:7-10), He became something He was not before—the author
of their misthopological salvation. At that point, He brought many sons to glory, that is, to their heavenly home in
glory. As a result of His ascension, “He became the author of eternal salvation to all those who obey Him.” The
aorist tense is used, not the future tense. He became—not will become—the author of this experience at that point
in time. He already has written His book, so to speak. He already has become the author of the firstborn enrolled in
Heaven (Heb 12:23) in that those firstborn saints (i.e., the spirits of righteous believers) are living already in the
Heavenly City as citizens of that City. Christ already has become the author of misthopological salvation, providing
this misthopological experience, ever since His ascension, to faithful believers during the intermediate state.
        Jesus reached His goal of becoming such an author by learning obedience. In the same manner, believers
must learn to “obey Him” if they are to win this eternal salvation. This eternal salvation in Heb 5:9 is not merely a
millennial salvation that awaits future realization but a salvation that the spirits of the righteous made perfect already
have been enjoying for two millennia. Those misthologists who claim that rewards only last a thousand years are
refuted by the realization that the faithful are being rewarded already in the intermediate state and will continue to
be rewarded in the millennial kingdom and beyond. Rewards cannot possibly be limited to a future thousand years
when the spirits of the faithful have been enjoying their heavenly rewards for two thousand years!
        At the point of their physical death, those believers who have obeyed Him during the course of their earthly
lives are being taken to the Heavenly City and literally seated with Christ in the heavenly places (cp. Eph 2:6).
Being seated with Him is not merely a positional truth but a literal experience on the part of those faithful believers
who have crossed over to the other side. The Lord won the right to be exalted as a faithful human being and to share
this exaltation with other faithful human beings who would believe in Him and then follow His example. The right
He won was to sit down “at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens” (Heb 8:1) as a victorious
man and share this right with victorious human believers. He already has taken His seat in the Heavenly City. He
became the author/source of this same experience to believers who obey Him. Those believers who follow Him
obediently are taking their seats with Him as they pass over to the other side.
        What happened when Enoch was taken to the other side, that is, when he was translated (KJV) or taken up
(NAS)? “By faith Enoch was taken up so that he should not see death; and he was not found because God took him
up; for he obtained the witness that before his being taken up he was pleasing to God” (Heb 11:5). The OT
background for this text is Gen 5:24, of course: “And Enoch walked with God; and he was not, for God took him.”
The popular theory adopted herein is that God took Enoch to Heaven. A popular counter-argument is that Enoch
could not have been taken to Heaven because, many years later, Jesus said that no one but Him had ascended to

for men to die once and after this comes judgment” (Heb 9:27), yet we know that there are exceptions, like Lazarus,
to this general rule. Exceptionality apparently applies to Enoch on both accounts: He did not die, and he did ascend
to Heaven. Notwithstanding, he did not ascend to the Holy Hill, to New Jerusalem.48 The same chapter of Hebrews,

Lane
    Although not grasping the full misthological-versus-soteriological implications of what he is saying, Lane
(WBC) rightly acknowledges the basic dichotomy in his comments on Heb 12:23:

       the heavenly city that is the goal of the pilgrimage of godly men and women under both covenants
       (11:10, 13–16; 13:14). The choice of this designation for those righteous persons who have died and

       πατὴρ τῶν πνευμάτων, “the Father of spirits,” in 12:9.

       Precisely! The spirits of these godly, righteous believers now inhabit the Heavenly City, which was the
(preliminary and primary) goal of their misthological pilgrimage. A major part of their realized misthology is that
they are now allowed to live in the Reward City as an inaugurated foretaste of the full misthology yet to come. This
part Lane got right.
       Lane allows two options for the perfect participle in Heb 12:23: “The participle can be understood
eschatologically, [1] in reference to those who have already passed through judgment (cf. 9:27) and have obtained
the verdict that they are righteous, or [2] soteriologically, in reference to those who have been decisively purged
and consecrated to God by the sacrificial death of Jesus.” In other words, it can be used misthologically or
soteriologically.
       With his death-then-judgment affirmation, WH already has hinted in Heb 9:27 that a preliminary pre-
Bema judgment occurs immediately after death, not having to await the resurrection. WH does not postpone
judgment by saying resurrection then judgment. Rather, he acknowledges death then judgment. Logistically, a
soteriological sorting between unbelievers and believers must occur immediately after death. WH is laying the
foundation for concluding that a preliminary sorting occurs regarding the spirits of believers at the point of
death. At the point of death, the spirits of righteous believers are perfected in the intermediate state (so Heb 12:23;
cp. 9:27), now that the church age has come (so Heb 11:40), by a maturation that allows them to enter the Heavenly
City and advance to the upper levels (so Heb 12:23). To be consistent with the biblical context and his own

ascended back to His unseen native 7D realm far above all heavens and also took His seat at the throne in the lower
heavenly 4D realm where He could be seen. See 7D Ultraspace, 282. He can be in both places at once.
         Indeed, Nicodemus should have been able to acknowledge the plausibility of each of these explanations.
He would have been aware that Elijah and Enoch were taken into Heaven, per the OT. Equally obviously, according
to the OT, they did not ascend by their own power or with the authority anticipated by Psalms. Nicodemus
presumably would be aware of the tradition that Enoch was taken to the lower part of Heaven, and thus one logically
could deduce that Enoch could not speak with authority regarding the higher heavenly truths concerning where God
lives.

        The first option posed by Lane is the correct one. The perfection of ch. 12 is separated from the soteriological
perfection of ch. 10 by the misthological perfection of ch. 11. After laying the soteriological foundation of perfection
in Heb 10:14, the context advances to a higher level of perfection in ch. 11—misthological perfection—from which
WH derives his misthological conclusion in ch. 12. These spirits in Heb 12:23 are righteous because their lives
reflected the faith of which God approves.” The righteousness in question is ethical, not imputational. Their
persevering faith expresses itself in their lives by the way they live and thus qualifies for a reward. Misthological
righteousness, not soteriological righteousness, is clearly entailed. Under the old covenant, they had to wait for their
transfer to the Heavenly City (Heb 11:40). Yet what WH is strongly asserting is that the wait is over! With the dawn
of the new covenant, these faithful believers are even now, during the intermediate state, in the Heavenly City.
        Granted, they still await the better resurrection of Heb 11:35, when the physical bodies of misthological
perfect spirits will be raised and transformed into co-glorified bodies to rule physically over the physical Earth and
universe. Apart from us, those OT believers would still be in subterranean Paradise. Yet, as attested by both
Scripture and NDE data, the spirits of these faithful believers are now in the Heavenly City, appropriately clothed,
as overcomers, in the white garments of victory (cp. Rev 6:11). They already have been judged. Their postmortem
inhabitation of this City proves realized misthology.
        In some way, these faithful OT believers have now entered their rest and reward in an inaugurated
misthological manner consistent with their present capacity, in the immediate presence of God, in a manner that
they did not before the advent of the NT era. Dispensationalism makes a consistent answer possible. The OT
believers were in a subterranean Paradise, in a parallel dimension, overlapping the heart of the Earth during the OT
era. At the time of Christ’s resurrection, however, they and Paradise were moved to the immediate presence of God
in Heaven. Thus, faithful OT believers, having undergone the preliminary judgment, are today, after Christ’s
resurrection, in the Heavenly City, also known in my research and in accord with the context as the City of Rest and
Reward City. They have now, after Christ’s resurrection, come to “the city which is to come” (Heb 13:14). This
City has not yet come to Earth, but the faithful dead already have come to the City, now that the NT era has
commenced. The physical aspect of their holistic misthological perfection awaits the future, admittedly, but their
spirits now enjoy the Heavenly City. These spirits of faithful OT believers now join faithful NT believers in the
Heavenly City. They have been perfected in the sense of having reached their appointed goal, the Reward City. The
OT believers had to await the NT era to reach this goal. Yet now, with the advent of the NT era, the OT faithful
reside with the NT faithful in the Heavenly City.
        What about the unfaithful during the intermediate state? Lindsay did not really say. He skipped ahead to the
eternal state. Notwithstanding, he did supply us with the framework to make a straightforward affirmation from
Hebrews regarding such misthopology even during the intermediate state. The implication of Heb 12:23 is that
ethically righteous believers, who were trying to qualify for living in the Reward City, already have obtained their
goal in relation to that City, insofar as their spirits are able to realize that misthological teleiology—subsequent to
Christ’s resurrection, per Heb 11:40—so that they, and they alone, now inhabit that Reward City. In accord with
the generic nature of rewards and the specific misthological promises and warnings in the book of Hebrews,
unfaithful believers would be excluded from living in this Heavenly City. In fact, WH practically says as much.
This Reward City can be appropriately called the City of Rest. WH repeatedly warns believers that they will not
enter this rest if they give up the race (Heb 3:11-4:11). Dillow translates Heb 3:11 as saying that they will never
enter My Rest.51 Does never not mean forever? BDAG (ei, 4) likewise calls this grammatical construction a “marker
of strong or solemn assertion,” in this case, a negation that should be translated strongly as “they shall certainly not
enter.” This is an emphatic negation in the Greek text. The unfaithful elect will never ever enter the rest.
        Given that WH affirms that (1) faithful believers already have entered into the initial phase of this rest, by
entering into the City of Rest, and (2) that unfaithful believers never will enter this rest, we are left with the
straightforward deduction that (3) unfaithful believers are not now living in the City of Rest, nor will they ever in
the future inhabit this City. The never includes now. Unfaithful believers reside outside the City; faithful believers
reside inside the City.

                                                      Testifiers
      The comments of the above interpreters were augmented in MMP4 by the testimonies of various people
claiming to have experienced heaven. To briefly recap the highlights of one of those testimonies, in Carol Hooley’s
booklet, Caught Up to Heaven, she testifies that after being taken through our universe, she came (1) to the third
heaven, then (2) to the Heavenly City located in a portion of the third heaven, then (3) to a mansion located in a
portion of the Heavenly City. In a section entitled, “A Shocking Experience,” Hooley relates the following:

                The Lord revealed a scene to me which I shall never forget. I saw a large host of saints, and I
         began to recognize some of the faces as I was taken near. I knew these people to be believers in the
         Lord Jesus. Then, suddenly, I spotted the familiar face of an uncle who had died only a short time
         prior. I was shocked, because as far as I knew, he hadn’t served God. My Lord brought me to even
         a closer view, and I asked, “Did he make it?” My Lord answered in the affirmative, but He also said,
         “Carol, don’t ever forget what you are seeing.”
                For some reason I wanted to turn my face, for my uncle was not robed like the others about
         him. It wasn’t the feeling of embarrassment from looking on one who is naked, but my Lord was
         impressing a great and important truth in my heart. He talked to me very sincerely and in a way which
         I could understand, and I was made to know [by her conversation with Jesus] that my uncle had
         just barely made it into heaven. When I returned, I learned from my aunt, who lived in another state,
         that my uncle had accepted Jesus Christ as his personal Saviour just prior to his death.
                This experience has taught me the importance of living daily a victorious life in Christ. My
         uncle received the gift of eternal life the same as any other believer, because salvation is by grace,
         not works. Yet, he did not live a victorious life in Christ here on earth; he did not build upon the
         foundation of faith in Christ. He waited until the very end of his life to commit himself to Jesus
         Christ. I saw a definite distinction between my uncle and those who had lived a consecrated
         Christian life.52 (Underline hers.)

        Per the understanding imparted to her by Jesus and per the details of her own testimony, her uncle just barely
making it into Heaven would have to mean that her uncle only made it into the outskirts of Heaven. Recall the
sequence. She first entered the “realm of the third heaven.” Then, subsequently, the angels took her to the Heavenly
City. If her uncle had just barely made it into the third heaven, he could not have made it into the Heavenly City,
which, according to her own testimony, was a particular location further inside the heavenly realm.
        The logical conclusion is that the angels who brought him to the heavenly realm must have left him at the
outer rim of that realm. If there are planets in this outer rim, this would have to be his habitation. Jesus did not make
it that hard to figure out. Jesus caused her to understand that her black-sheep uncle had just barely made it into
heaven—not into the City! Jesus did not want her to think that her uncle had just barely made it into the City.
Rather, the Lord wanted her to perceive that her uncle merely made it into heaven. This is the distinct impression
that the Lord gave her. Similar testimonies by others would lead us to similar conclusions. And we will include
some review material and new material in that regard as we proceed.53
                                                     Conclusion
       Exegetically, we have concluded that the Heavenly City presently resides in a heavenly country in a higher
dimension. Therefore, both this City and this land can be described as 4D as compared to our 3D shadowy reality.
Exegesis also leads us to conclude that the spirits of OT and NT believers who qualify to live in the Heavenly City
are now doing so, having been made perfect at the time of Christ’s ascension and thus living there as a preliminary
part of their reward, which includes being able to eat the fruit of the Tree of Life. The spirits of unfaithful believers
are not allowed into this Reward City nor allowed to eat the fruit of the Tree of Life. The experiences of some of
those who claim to have been to Heaven supply confirmatory testimony.

                   Chapter 3. New Jerusalem in Transition
                                                    Introduction
      One proposition being explored herein is that the Heavenly City is migratory. It moves from one location to
another. This transition may be from one planet to another, such as from Planet Rahab to Planet Earth, or it may be
from one galaxy to another, or it may be from one universe to another, or it may be from one dimension to another.
Michell notes sightings of it above our planet in the past.

             The records of folklore and mystical experience contain many accounts of an ethereal city
      viewed in the sky, variously explained as an effect of light on clouds, a mirage reflecting an actual
      city on earth, or a vision of paradise. In Celtic lands, where, perhaps because of the misty
      atmosphere, such phenomena are most commonly reported, the ghostly city in the air is said to
      be the habitation of the saintly dead. It has been claimed that St. John was a Celt; but whether or
      not he ever personally saw such a thing, his poetic instinct caused him to adopt the legendary city in
      the sky as the external image of that cosmological city, or ideal order of the universe, revealed to him
      in the course of his studies.
             The traditional code of cosmology, for which Plato’s symbol was a political city-state, is
      represented by St. John in the form of a familiar type of vision. As proof that the New Jerusalem was
      no mere illusion or imaginative fancy, St. John gives its actual measured dimensions.54

      Sightings of the aerial New Jerusalem, as described by St. John the Divine in Revelation at the
      beginning of the Christian era, have been reported on many subsequent occasions, often at
      moments of millenarian excitement. Many Christians early in the third century believed that
      they would live to witness the descent of the New Jerusalem, and their hopes were raised when
      a beautiful walled city became apparent in the skies over Judaea. According to Tertullian, it was
      seen every morning for forty days, fading away as the dawn lightened. Some eight hundred years
      later, bands of poor pilgrims, struggling across Europe toward Jerusalem during the People’s
      Crusade, were sustained by visions of a glorious city in the air above them to which ghostly
      crowds were flocking. The traditional interpretation of such visions is that they presage the coming
      of a new dispensation that will reproduce on earth the harmonious order of the heavens.55

        From time to time, even after being moved away from Planet Earth after the flood, the Heavenly City has
seemingly been seen, at least partially decloaked, in our dimension above our planet. Presently, New Jerusalem is
presumably in the outer sphere of the multiverse. That is, unless it has already started its migration to Earth for the
purpose of the rapture. The perception that I have shared in POV is that New Jerusalem will return to Earth at the
time of the rapture and remain cloaked here, above Earth, in a sphere until the time end of the tribulation. We will
begin this chapter by retracing those steps from POV.
        To trace the migration of the Heavenly City, (1) it is currently beyond the northern stars. (2) At the rapture,
it will be surrounded by an invisible time dilation bubble and descend to Earth’s atmosphere as believers are raptured
up to meet the Lord in the air and join Him in this heavenly home which He has prepared for them. (3) After the
tribulation, the bubble will become visible so that the City can be seen from Earth, and the time can be synchronized
so that time in the Heavenly Jerusalem will match that on Earth. Overcomers will then rule Earth from their heavenly
residence. (4) After the millennium, the Heavenly Jerusalem might land on the New Earth and be called the New
Jerusalem.56

       When the Lord returns, it is not for the purpose of taking us back to Heaven far beyond the stars. Rather, He
will receive us to Himself in the clouds of Earth and judge us there to determine which believers are worthy to rule
on Earth. This Bema evaluation will take a considerable amount of metaphysical time, so Heavenly Jerusalem (in
the skies above the Earth) will be surrounded by a time bubble to allow for this extension in metaphysical time
while events on Earth continue on their prophetic course. At the completion of the physical seven-year tribulation
on Earth (during which the unspecified metaphysical time necessary to complete the Bema judgment in the
Heavenly Jerusalem above Earth will also be completed), the Lord will then continue and complete His descent to
Earth so that His Bride can rule with Him on Earth. He, as the Bridegroom, will clean up the situation on Earth and
then rule Earth with His Bride from the Heavenly Jerusalem suspended in Earth’s atmosphere above Earthly
Jerusalem. Afterward, when the Earth has been remade into the New Earth, the Heavenly City will probably remain
above Earth and be called the New Jerusalem.
       To be caught up into the clouds of the Earth at the time of the rapture will be to be caught up to Heaven since
the initial migration of the Heavenly City from the stars to the Earth’s atmosphere will be completed at this time.
Heaven will no longer be off beyond the stars. Jesus brings the house that He has been preparing for us with Him
(Jn 14:2-3). In other words, the Lord brings Heavenly Jerusalem with Him when He comes for us. Our earthly sky
will become its new location.
Apokalupsis
       This scenario is probable in view of the Pauline clarification. In 1Thessalonians (4:17), Paul leaves us with
Christ in the clouds after the rapture. No mention is made of our going elsewhere. It is not until 2Thessalonians that
we have any indication from Paul that we leave those clouds at the end of the tribulation. Since we will always be
with the Lord after the rapture (so Paul in 1Thess 4:17), it is reasonable to pose that we will also be with Christ at
the second phase (or continuation) of the parousia, “when the Lord Jesus will be revealed [apokalupsis] from
Heaven with His mighty angels in flaming fire” to repay rest to afflicted believers (2Thess 1:7).57 If fact, it is
probable that the very first taste of rest/rulership that some of these heavenly believers (i.e., sky dwellers) will
experience is in riding the white horses as they descend with Christ to exercise judgment on Earth dwellers
(Rev 19:14).
       Therefore, in conjunction with OT predictions,58 we will most likely be hidden with Christ in the clouds of
Heaven while the events of the tribulation are taking place on Earth below. L-N (28.38) states that the nominal form
(apokalupsis) means: “to uncover, to take out of hiding,’ not occurring in the NT.” But its claim that this meaning
does not occur in the NT is suspect. Paul speaks of the revelation of the mystery which has been kept secret
(Rom 16:25). And concerning this verse, L-N states that it refers: “to the disclosure of the secret truth which was
hidden for long ages in the past.” Yet this is the same usage that we find in its verbal cognate (apokalupto). Paul
interchangeably uses the nominal and verbal forms to convey this usage in Eph 3:3-5. Thus, FB defines it in this
verse as “generally, of what God discloses or makes known revelation, disclosure, e.g., his plan of redemption.”
God’s plan was already in existence, but it is just now being disclosed, that is, taken out of hiding. It would appear
that TY is closer to the mark in acknowledging that the nominal usage can be equivalent to “to apokaluptesthai [the
verbal infinitive] as used of events by which things or states or persons hitherto withdrawn from view are made
visible to all.” Therefore, the most plausible proposition is that we will be hidden in the clouds with the Lord but
hidden from view of those on Earth until we are revealed with Him at the end of the tribulation.
Apokalupto
       As noted above, the verbal form (apokalupto) can be used of revealing something that is secret or hidden. It
is so used in 1Cor 2:10 (cp. v 7) and Eph 3:5. It is likewise used of revealing something that is covered (Mt 10:26;
Lk 12:2). Something may be present but covered, concealed, or cloaked from public view. Does this revelation of

Christ from Heaven in 2Thess 1:7 necessarily mean that He was not already present in the clouds of Earth? No.

arrival. They will already be here before their being present is made publicly apparent.
Ouranos
       The fact that Christ will be revealed from Heaven (ouranos) poses no insurmountable problem for this model.
This word for Heaven (ouranos) is sometimes translated as sky. So Christ being present in the clouds would be
compatible with this understanding of Heaven as meaning sky. For example, in Lk 17:29, Paul’s traveling
companion, from whose gospel Paul quotes as Scripture, writes: “But on the day that Lot went out from Sodom it
rained fire and brimstone from Heaven and destroyed them all.” Certainly, we are to understand this fire from
Heaven as meaning from the sky in this Lukan parallel. Interestingly, both texts link this flaming fire from Heaven
with the revelation (apokalupto) of Christ at the conclusion of the tribulation (Lk 17:29-30; 2Thess 1:7-8).
       But even if Heaven is understood to be the transcendent abode of God, this is certainly no problem if my
hypothesis is accepted that the Heavenly City will be located in the sky above Earth during the tribulation. In fact,
John tells us that at the end of the millennium, this Heavenly City will come done out of Heaven.59 Certainly, he
does not mean that the City from which we will be ruling the Earth during the millennium is far off from Earth in
outer space among the stars during the millennium! No. The Heavenly City comes down out of Heaven at the end
of the millennium because it is already there—in the skies above Earth. During the millennium the Heavenly
Jerusalem will be a satellite city above Earth. This Heavenly City is called the tabernacle (i.e., traveling-tent) of
God in Rev 21:2-3 and is appropriately translatable as either tent or dwelling place of God. Home is where you
pitch your tent. During the tribulation and millennium, God’s home will be our sky.

lots of very nice places to live elsewhere in the spirit realm within the Kingdom. Having an outside or country

discussion confirms that there will be ample space inside the City (as calculated in MMP1) and personalized
universes inside the City (as illustrated in MMP2).

       The following illustrations in this section are from POV, and brief parts of that discussion have been adapted

       Ashtar is an alternate spelling for Athtar, which is also known as Venus and Day Star. The Hebrew word
Isaiah uses is Helel (shining one, star) and is rendered as Lucifer in various translations. According to Ashtar
Command, Jesus was taken to Heaven by one of their spaceships and will return with a fleet of spaceships. Their

who are beamed aboard the spaceships would pose a threat to the harmony and evolution being brought by the

false explanation anticipates a real event and, consequently, lends support to the anticipation that the genuine rapture
will be carried out visibly via spaceships. The event is not false, only the explanation. Believers will be caught up
to spaceships at the rapture, but they will not be the spaceships of Ashtar Command.
                                                        Gap
        In TOD (2012), various GAP models were considered, including a YEC (Young-Earth Creationist) model.
At the time, I preferred a YEC model. However, a weakness in that preference is that I did not adequately consider
the destruction of Planet Rahab. A Planet X was considered, but not a Planet X associated with our galaxy. Planet
X in TOD would have been better called Planet L (aka, Planet Lucifer). But such a planet in another galaxy as
fitting the biblical data was deemed unlikely. A much better contender for the title Planet L (aka, Planet Lucifer),
however, would be either Planet Rahab or Planet X (both within our solar system). My subsequent discussion in
MMP2 (2018) discussed Planet Rahab and Planet X and posed that Planet Rahab was Planet Lucifer (which is a
common perception) and posed that Planet Rahab may have been destroyed by Planet X (which is one popular
option). The present study will entertain an alternative possibility, namely, that Planet Rahab was destroyed in a
war (which is another very popular option). This proposal would also favor a classical GAP, that is, the RET (Ruined
Earth Theory). Thus, the discussion of that GAP/RET model from TOD will be quickly reviewed below and then
challenged.62

        In both Is 14:12 and Eze 28:17, Satan was cast to the ground/earth (Heb. eretes, Gr. ge). The most pressing
question now to be considered is, “To the ground of which planet?” These are the same Hebrew and Greek words
used respectively in Gen 1:1 for the creation of Earth. Therefore, advocates of the falling-to-Earth hypothesis
seemingly are on firm ground in posing that Lucifer’s fall took place to this planet. Additional support might be
derivable from Rev 12:4, the Dragon (Satan) with “his tail swept down a third of the stars of heaven and cast them
to the earth [ge].” The context describes a war that took place in Heaven (Rev 12:7-9). If this casting down to Earth
is a recapitulation of what happened in the past, then the case for this model is strengthened.
        Since Satan is called the god of this world (aion) in 2Cor 4:4 and the ruler of this world (kosmos) in Jn 12:31,
presumably this planet is supposed. Unger advocates this traditional understanding: “Intimations are not lacking in
Scripture that the highest of all God’s created angels, ‘the day star, son of the morning,’ was placed in charge of the
earth when this planet was originally created.”63 Satan’s fall occurred after creation and resulted in chaos on Earth
in which this planet became formless and void:

             Satan’s defection and fall occurred after the creation of the earth (Job 38:7) and apparently in
      connection with it. Although the subject is to a large extent wrapped in mystery, there are not lacking
      Scriptural intimations that suggest that Satan and certain angelic spirits were given suzerainty over the
      earth when it was primevally created and that it was in that high position of trust that “the day-star, son
      of the morning” planned his far-sweeping insurrection to usurp authority over the heavenly spheres and
      the earth that rightfully belonged only to “the Most High” as Creator and, therefore, “possessor of
      heaven and earth” (Gen 14:19, 22).
             If this interpretation is true, it would explain the cause of the fearful cataclysmic judgment that
      engulfed the pristine globe, reducing it to a chaotic ruin (Gen 1:2). It would also give meaning to Satan’s
      specific use of the divine title “the Most High,” which is descriptive of ownership by virtue of creation,
      in his original revolt against divine authority, when he cried: “I will make myself like the Most High”
      (Is 14:14).64

       Yet weaknesses for even this streamlined version of this GAP theory are well known. At the conclusion of
the creation week, God said that creation was very good, so there could not have been a fall before that point in time
(Gen 1:31).65 Young-Earth creationists insist that a planet full of dead dinosaur bones buried under the ground
would have been an unclean planet. Moreover, Scripture attributes the entrance of death into the world through
Adam’s sin (Rom 5:12). Obviously, Lucifer fell (Is 14:12-14) before he induced Eve to fall, but there is no room
for a gap in the creation account (Ex 20:11).
       So, the above is a quick recap of my objections to GAP from TOD. However, as the present study and
subsequent studies demonstrate, these objections are not insurmountable. For example, in RAE (2015), I proved

that death was indeed present before Adam fell. As to Gen 1:31, the text actually says, “God saw all that He had

(Gen 1:26). God did not create man from nothing. He made man from the dust (cp. Gen 5:1; 6:6-7; 9:6) by forming
(yatsar) him from the dust of the ground (Gen 2:7; 3:19). The pronouncement of good on everything that He had
just formed from the formless Earth of Gen 1:2 is not on everything He had ever created in Gen 1:1. Satan would
not snicker because he would realize that God excluded him from the pronouncement of good. As to Ex 20:11, the
same argument applies: “For in six days the Lord made [asah] the heaven [singular] and the earth” (ESV).66 Lucifer

reformation of the Earth rather than the recreation of the universe.67

      Toop is a YEC who believes the Earth is about ten thousand years old. He rejects the GAP theory (KL 3337-

was on Planet Rahab, which was destroyed. Though he rejects the RET, his discussion is very commendable and
very compatible with RET. As to Lucifer having walked up and down in the midst of the stones of fire in Eze 28:14
(KJV), Toop points out that the expression walked up and down also occurs in Job 1:7 and 2:2.

      The passages in Job refer to Satan’s travels to and upon Earth. This observation is part of Toop’s argument
that Earth is one of the stones of fire (firestones), that is, one of the planets that Satan was visiting in our solar
system (KL 2762-2826). He argues at length that Planet Rahab was the planet in the midst of the solar system where
Lucifer had his throne until God destroyed that planet, resulting in devastation to surrounding planets. His book is
highly recommended, and the basic thesis of Toop’s extended discussion is adopted regarding the destruction of
Planet Rahab:

      In this narrative, false gods and goddesses were not involved in its destruction. In this narrative, it is
      the almighty God, the true Creator of the Universe, who reduced this planet to rubble. This planet’s
      name, in the Hebrew language, is known as Rahab. (KL 3112)

      The Hebrew word chatsab also chetseb [2672] is only found exclusively pertaining to Isaiah 51:9. It
      is not found anywhere else in the Old Testament. This Hebrew word chatseb means to “cut or divide
      stone or other material.” This is exactly what God did to the planet Rahab; He cut and divided the
      various materials of Rahab, namely stone, into billions of fragmented pieces, leaving them adrift to
      become the Main Asteroid Belt we know today. (KL 3144)

       Yet Toop’s timing is problematic since he rejects RET, even though RET makes some of these very claims.68
As Toop acknowledges, Lucifer did not become Satan until his fall (or, more specifically, until his expulsion). Yet,
if one accepts the Planet Rahab hypothesis, it seems that this planet was destroyed when Satan was cast out of the
Third Heaven (or Heavenly City). Toop must place Satan’s expulsion before the temptation of Adam and Eve, for
Lucifer already had become Satan by then. But since Toop delayed the destruction of Planet Rahab until the time
of the flood (at least 1656 years later, per his own timeline), he has posed a very unlikely YEC GAP theory, placing
a gap of at least 1656 years between Satan’s expulsion and the destruction of his planet. I am inclined to a young-
Earth view as well, yet from a RET perspective. One would be better advised to adopt the RET if one is going to
adopt the Planet Rahab theory. One way or another, a gap must be posed in that case, and the RET gap is much
more intuitive than a YEC gap. Toop writes as if Satan’s expulsion, punishment, and the destruction of his planet
happened in quick succession:

      Psalm 89:10 describes the scattering of “thine enemies” (plural) in relation to the destruction of Rahab.
      This is not speaking of a singular nation or entity. I submit that this is a reference to the other fallen
      angels (former stewards) caught up in this cataclysmic event and scattered throughout Second Heaven.
      Not only is this action clearly defined in Isaiah 51:9, it is also clearly linked with the wounding of the
      dragon. Lucifer, as Satan (the dragon), was wounded in the exchange of his banishment from the
      Kingdom of Heaven and the destruction of his throne on the ancient planet Rahab. (KL 3159-3172)

       Toop’s assessment here is intuitive.69 There was no significant YEC gap between Satan’s expulsion and
Rahab’s explosion. Therefore, his rejection of the RET GAP theory is counterintuitive. The destruction of Planet
Rahab must have occurred in connection with the Luciferian flood, not the Noachian flood. Langford, who has
written a highly commendable book in defense of RET, believes that Earth was the planet to which Satan was cast,
which is an extremely popular view among Ruined Earth Theorists (RETs).70 He would regard Rahab as another
name for Satan. Whether Rahab refers to Lucifer or his planet or a combination of the two, Langford’s comments
regarding Job 9:4-13 are worth considering:

             The last passage we will look at is connected with a catastrophic destruction upon the earth,

         even involving the starry heavens. We also know this destruction is not a reflection upon God’s later
         battles with the Egyptians, nor does it have anything to do with the blood in Noah’s day. It is rather at
         a time of direct conflict with Lucifer and his minions. The passage is Job 9:4-13:

               “(God is) wise in heart and mighty in strength, who has defied Him without harm? It
               is God Who removes the mountains, they know nor how, when He overturns them in
               His anger: Who shakes the earth out of its place, and its pillars tremble; Who
               commands the sun not to shine, and sets a seal upon the stars; Who alone stretches
               out the heavens, and tramples down the waves of the sea; Who makes the Bear, Orion,
               and the Pleiades, and the chambers of the south; Who docs great things, unfathomable,
               and wondrous works without number . . . God will not turn back His anger; beneath Him
               crouch the helpers of Rahab.”

                 This is an amazing passage from several respects. It first of all associates a tremendous
         destruction of the earth and even the heavens within the context of a rebellion against God—“who has
         defied Him (God) without harm?” It even suggests that the associates of such a rebellion now have
         experienced God’s “anger,” and “beneath Him (God) crouch the helpers (angels) of Rahab (Satan).”
         Of course, by now we can piece together the (acts that the Scriptures are revealing to us. Namely, at
         some distant time in the past there was a rebellion against God. In particular, Satan, also known as
         Rahab, “defied” God along with “helpers,” meaning other angelic beings. This rebellion was met with
         an outpouring of God’s anger and wrath. This wrath meant cataclysmic convulsions not only upon the
         earth, but also in the starry heavens.
                 Now this Biblical description of destruction upon the earth is very revealing. The magnitude of
         this destruction cannot fit into any other time period other than that designated by the second verse of
         Genesis 1. If taken literally, this is not describing rain clouds that come between man on earth and the
         sun, such as might have happened in Noah’s day at the time of the flood. The statement is “Who (God)
         commands the sun not to shine.” This means the source of light itself had been directly affected. There
         would be darkness. Furthermore, it clearly specifics God setting a “seal upon the stars.” The function
         of the stars in relationship to the earth is stopped and “sealed.” Furthermore, there was most certainly
         no mention in the flood account of violent earthquakes, but here on this occasion the earth is literally
         “shaken out of its place.” Most dramatic of all, as far as the surface of the earth is concerned, the very
         mountains are either “removed” or else convoluted so as to be “overturned.” Again, there is no remote
         action like this that was taken in the days of Noah’s flood, nor in the days afterward. (Bold emphasis
         his.)71

       In short, this rebellion was an interplanetary/interstellar war involving the Earth but not limited to the Earth.
Other starry helpers (planets and the angels who inhabited and ruled them) were also involved in the conflict. And
both—the other planets and the angels who inhabited and ruled them—experienced God’s wrath, not at a remote
distance but beneath Him. If God was in the Heavenly City when He expressed this wrath, which is a reasonable
hypothesis, then His wrath was expressed from this City to the rebellious angelic planets below. Given the other
passages describing this destructive wrath, the supposition necessarily follows that the principal culprit—Rahab
(both the planet and angelic ruler of that planet, namely, Lucifer)—experienced the severest expression of that
wrath, resulting in the complete destruction of Planet Rahab, aka, Planet Lucifer. They were destroyed by the
Heavenly City as an act of war. This City is a warship. War City would be another appropriate name.
                                                   Lucifer’s Fall
       In TOD, the timing of the Luciferian fall in the YEC model was thought superior because TOD placed the
fall after the creation week was completed. But if what is being described is a restoration week, then RET is
superior. The RET model will be adopted in the present book for consideration. The primary reason for adopting
RET as the working model herein is to make better sense of texts pertaining to angelic fall, rebellion, and war.72

RET Model
        What impact does adopting the RET model have regarding the spatial location of Lucifer’s fall? Modification
of the following discussion from TOD will favor a RET answer. From where did Lucifer fall, and to where did he
fall? Isaiah uses the king of Babylon to symbolize the fall of Satan, as Ron Rhodes notes, “We find a dual reference
that includes not just the king of Babylon but a typological description of Lucifer as well” (italics his).73 While
some scholars might object to considering this imagery an example of typology, it is more reasonably taken as a
duality rather than mere apostrophe and thus best fits the picture of typology.74 Indeed, when typology is understood
as the intentional shadowing of some metaphysical reality (antitype) by some physical entity (type), then this
depiction of Lucifer’s fall qualifies as an example of typology.75 The type does not necessarily have to precede its
antitype in time but would be expected to exceed its antitype in significance.

   Terry takes Is 14:12-15 as an example of apostrophe. Milton S. Terry, Biblical Hermeneutics: A Treatise on the
Interpretation of the Old and New Testaments, second edition (Grand Rapids: Zondervan, n.d.), 252. Technically,
it would not be considered an example of typology when types are narrowly defined to be OT inferior objects that
are intended by God to represent (foreshadow) some future (i.e., NT) superior antitypes with a notable point of
resemblance amidst dissimilarities (pp. 334-346). Virkler takes much the same perspective as Terry and gives this
exercise: “Isaiah 14:12-15 has often been interpreted as a typological allusion to Satan. Discuss the hermeneutical
pros and cons of such an interpretation. Henry A. Virkler, Hermeneutics: Principles and Processes of Biblical
Interpretation (Grand Rapids: Baker Book House, 1981), 209. Two notable cons are readily apparent: (1) The
allusion moves from present to past (instead of from past to future), and (2) the scope of the allusion is within the
OT (instead of between the testaments). Therefore, given the restrictive definition posed by both Terry and Virkler,
one may object to considering Is 14:12-15 a type.
     On the other hand, the type (tupos) in Heb 8:5 indicates that typology should not be viewed in such a narrow
fashion. The tabernacle is a shadowy type of the heavenly sanctuary. If this heavenly sanctuary is understood as
representing the Heavenly City (the true tabernacle of Heb 8:2), that already was in existence at the time that the
earthly tabernacle was prepared, then a broader typology is understood than that allowed by Terry and Virkler. The
antitype can come after the type in time. A more feasible approach would be to broaden typology more inclusively
when a physical entity is used to picture a metaphysical reality. Normally the predictive element of typology is
claimed to set it aside from being a symbol. However, the fall of Lucifer is not merely symbolized, but typified, by
the passage in question.

capital planet. Lucifer and his associated planet, Planet Lucifer (Rahab), were in the middle of the firestones when

system. Other angels could have overseen the other planets in our solar system and been subservient to Lucifer.

throughout the universe.81 We know from Scripture that “the love of money is a root of all sorts of evil, and some

are the ways of everyone who is greedy for unjust gain; it takes away the life of its possessors” (Prov 1:19). The

Other angels could have overseen the other planets, and the planetary angelic overseers in our solar system could
have been subservient to Lucifer. When Lucifer fell, they might have fallen along with him, or some of them might
have resisted, resulting in an interplanetary war and perhaps interstellar or even intergalactic wars, with wars against
angelic rulers with whom they were trading in other solar systems. Various scenarios are advocated by various
interpreters of the Scripture, science, and ancient texts that indicate such wars. These options were not explored in
TOD. Only the bottom line was provided in TOD, which remains plausible.
Two Edens
       As Dill and Langford explain, the Eden in which Lucifer walked before his fall in Eze 28:13, and over which
he had kingly authority, could not possibly be the same Eden in which Adam was given authority.84 They believe
this Luciferian pre-Adamic Eden was on Earth. DeHaan likewise makes this assumption:
             That is the record God gives of Lucifer. God placed him in Eden, the prehistoric Eden [on Earth]
      which geology has now uncovered. Then he sinned and fell. He was banished from the earth and cast
      out of Heaven and consigned to the atmosphere between Heaven and earth and thus has become the
      “prince of the power of the air.” He has access to Heaven under limitations and also to the earth, but
      his abode is the “atmosphere above the earth.”85

       This assessment is counter-intuitive. If Eden was on Earth and Satan was then consigned to the atmosphere
on Earth, he rose rather than fell! He may not have succeeded in ascending above the clouds, but he at least
succeeded in ascending to the clouds! God cast him down to the ground, not up into the sky (Eze 28:17).86 A fall
from a stellar rather than earthly Eden would be more intuitive. Moving in the right direction, Langford perceives
a duality to Lucifer’s dominion and functions. While Eze 28:13 refers to his functions on Earth, the reference to
God’s holy mountain in Eze 28:14 refers to God’s heavenly realm:

       Most likely, Lucifer had an Eden on Earth and/or Rahab that was only a replica of the Heavenly Eden on the
holy mountain of God. Perhaps other planets ruled by other angels throughout the universe had other replicas as
well. Multiple replicas would make sense. In any case, Lucifer’s planetary Eden was a replica of the Heavenly
Eden. Lucifer aspired to trade his replica for the real thing, his planetary Eden for God’s heavenly Eden, his earthly
throne for God’s heavenly throne. Commenting on Eze 28:16, Langford says, “Lucifer was immediately ‘cast as
profane from the mountain of God’” (p. 170). Per his own analysis, this would be from God’s heavenly dwelling.
Surely, Lucifer was not cast out of God’s throne room back down to Eden! Satan was not cast into Eden. Like
Adam, he would have been cast out of Eden! He must have been in the Heavenly Eden and cast out from it.
       McGee (TTBC) concurs: “Satan was the ‘anointed cherub that covereth’—that is, he protected the throne of
God. This is not the Eden that was on earth, but apparently is a picture [replica] of heaven itself. Satan had access
to heaven, of course.” Some of those who propose the single Eden hypothesis even go so far as to suggest that Satan
was the cherub in charge of guarding the Tree of Life when he tempted Adam and Eve to eat from it! Such bizarre
notions can be avoided with the dual Eden deduction.
       In conjunction with other Scripture, combining the fall from Heaven (so Isaiah) with the fall from the
mountain of God (so Ezekiel) so as to derive a fall from the Heavenly Mountain Eden is the most reasonable
explanation. Apparently, Satan was cast from the Heavenly Eden (which was a satellite mountain residence above
the clouds to the north of some planet) to the ground/earth of some planet below it. TOD posed that it was Planet
Earth. Dake, a RET advocate, likewise poses that “according to Isa. 14:12-14, Lucifer actually invaded heaven from
earth hoping to defeat God and usurp heaven from earth.”88 However, the more likely scenario is that Lucifer’s
residence was on Planet Rahab, where his throne was in the midst of the other planets in our solar system. Lucifer
led an assault against Heaven (a ground attack against the Heavenly City), but he and his forces were defeated, and
he was cast down from Heaven (i.e., from the heavenly throne room of Heavenly Jerusalem) to the planet below.
       The residence from which Lucifer was cast resembled a heavenly mountain in size and shape and was located
above the clouds. This would be Satellite Jerusalem above the clouds where God’s throne was. Since man was
created to be the ruler of the planet upon which he was placed, and yet initially was created lower than the angels
(Heb 1:7), it stands to reason that Lucifer was the planetary ruler (or at least caretaker) of the planet that hosted this
mountain-shaped Emerald Eden on or above the planet over which he had dominion. If an Emerald Eden on (or
above) a planet in the first galaxy to emerge from the white hole is envisioned, so that this is when all these precious
gems were first prepared as a covering for Lucifer (who was created and coroneted on the same day Outlying
Galaxies Time (O.G.T.), then this neo-creational model is a reasonable understanding of the text.
       Obviously, this description of Lucifer in Eden does not match that of Adam in Eden. Two different pictures
of Eden are pictured because two different Edens are involved. In commenting on Eze 28:13-14, Whitcomb (a
young-earth creationist) provides the following explanation:

      It seems clear from a comparison with Daniel 2:45 and Isaiah 14:13 that “the holy mountain of God“

What mountain could this be? What mountain would qualify as a heavenly one hosting an Emerald Eden like the
Holy City of Revelation? Such clues are more than sufficient to make more than an educated guess. Yet the Scripture
supplies another clue to seal the inference. Hebrews informs us that Abraham “was looking for the city which has
foundations, whose architect and builder is God” (Heb 11:10). The Greek definite article informs us that Abraham
was not merely looking for some heavenly city or a heavenly city. He was not merely looking for something—that
just so happens to be a heavenly city. His aspirations were high, and they were definite. He definitely was looking
for the Holy City described in Revelation. Therefore, Whitcomb’s statement must be amended. Lucifer did not fall
from a heavenly emerald city; he fell from the Heavenly Emerald City. Lucifer fell from it; Abraham was seeking
to rise to it. Abraham intended to fill the vacancy and everything that went with it.
        Lucifer was in the Heavenly City. He was cast from this Heavenly City to the ground below. God cast Lucifer
from this Heavenly Eden to the ground of the planet below that satellite City. Just as a correlation is made between
the king of Tyre and Satan, a connection should be supposed between the Emerald Eden of that mountain and the
Eden of Earth. Now the key question is, “Where was this Emerald Eden located in relation to Earth’s Eden?”

        The first location of the Heavenly City (i.e., the Emerald Eden) considered in TOD was in hyperspace outside
the sphere of our material universe. The conjecture was that perhaps the City was located in hyperspace, and Lucifer
fell from hyperspace to space. Although the above diagram from TOD in Illustration 10 pictures this location as
being to the north of the universe, it must be remembered that this location is in hyperspace. Therefore, it is not
truly north. This location does not actually make sense if north means north and clouds mean clouds in the passage
from Isaiah. Literal interpretation is to be preferred over symbolic interpretation when literal interpretation makes
sense. Therefore, this first option was rejected in TOD as being in discord with Isaiah (Is 14:12-15) as well as with
other possible references.
        At that juncture, third heaven was perceived in TOD as being limited to New Jerusalem floating in hyperspace
outside our universe. The present misthological series, however, has been refined to note that third heaven is a
spacious extradimensional realm outside our universe (outside the multiverse actually) that encompasses many
places where a heavenly being might reside. New Jerusalem is not the third heaven; rather, New Jerusalem is a City
within the third heaven. Thieme is astute in suggesting that New Jerusalem is the Garden of Eden/Mountain of God
in which Lucifer resided and from which he was cast in the prehistoric past and that this City was in the third
heaven.91

       In Greek mythology, the gods lived on Mount Olympus and drank nectar and ate ambrosia, and doing so
would confer immortality to any mortal who partook of it, though sometimes ambrosia was thought to be a drink.
Perhaps this echoes the fact that angelic sons of God eat and drink in this Heavenly Mountain. The reference to the
bread of angels in Ps 78:25 is thought by many to refer to angels’ food. Tate (WBC): “LXX has ‘angels’
(cf. Ps 103:20) and this is widely adopted. The meaning is that of strong ones of the heavenly host of God; even
possibly ‘the mighty gods.’” And Zeph 2:11 is thought to refer to God withholding such food from disobedient,
fallen, angelic gods of the Earth: “The Lord will be terrifying to them, for He will starve all the gods of the earth;
and all the coastlands.” As intrinsically immortal beings (which is the opinion of some such as myself), angels
would not die if deprived of such food, yet their strength might diminish. One possibility is that now, as a result of
the fall, they are deprived of heavenly manna and live off the worship and sacrifices made to them, and without
such worship and sacrifices, they wither, are made lean (NICOT), grow thin (NAC), and are weakened (WBC). Gill
poses something along this line, that the curse of eating dust in Gen 3:14, as it applied to Satan, meant that he would
now live off the base desires of humanity: “This is applicable to Satan…the sordid food he lives upon; no more on
angels’ food and joys of heaven, but on the base, mean, earthly, and impure lusts of men; and this will be his case,
condition, and circumstances, for ever” (GEEB). Gallups concurs.92 Lamont portrays this withering and dependency
of these (intrinsically) immortals on such substances in splendid detail via her fictional format.93
       Alberino takes this proposition a step further. In his opinion, angels are not intrinsically immortal but
extrinsically immortal: “Having chosen to betray the King of heaven and abandon paradise, the watchers likely
forfeited their extrinsic immortality and became subject to entropy” (BR, 145). According to him, all angels are
mortal: “All life, terrestrial and otherwise, is subject to death and unless supplemented by the rejuvenating stimulant
available exclusively in the paradise of God” (BR, 110). The “take also” of Gen 3:22 implies that the angels were
also partaking of the Tree of Life so that they could live forever (BR, 110).94 Because the fallen angels are now
barred from the Tree of Life, they must, like vampires, feed off the lifeforce of animals and humans.95 Although
they have advanced biology that enables them to age more slowly than humans, Ps 82:6-7 shows that they eventually
will die like humans (BR, 111). He acknowledges that this hypothetical proposition is speculative and “should be
taken with a grain of salt” (BR, 112).96

      then cast into the lake of fire which is the second death. Several writers have espoused this view, like
      Pember, Ottman and Pardington.
