    Quarterman (Watchers, 57-61) poses that the Nachash (serpent) was a morally intelligent being that God created
just below Adam and Eve and was jealous of Eve for not having been chosen to be Adam’s mate. If so, I would
pose that Satan placed this jealous notion into the Nachash’s mind and used the Nachash to deceive Eve. Also, if a
female Nachash was jealous of Eve (compare the legends of Lilith mating with Adam), then certainly the female
Nachash would have had a male counterpart who would have been jealous of Adam (compare the legends of Lucifer
mating with Eve). Such illicit mating legends would be a little more plausible, perhaps, if the male and female
Nachashs involved were beautiful, moral, intelligent, subordinate creatures. Satan may have possessed them or
simply put them up to the task. However, sexual interaction between Adam and Eve with a Nachash would not be
expected to produce offspring since it is a different kind of being. For instance, the mating of a human with an ape
would not result in a human-ape offspring. To be sexually reproductive with human or animal species, fallen angels
must take a form that is more closely compatible than those forms natively created by God since forms natively
created by God are not able to crossbreed across species. In any case, Satan was the instigator behind the temptation,
and God cursed the Nachash(s). This Nachash—and perhaps his or her mate (depending on whether the seduction
was sexual or not)—was/were reduced from a high serpentine form to a low serpentine form. Possibly, God changed
the form of these two Nachashs to the form of lower pre-existing nonintelligent serpents. Myths of witches turning
people into toads might be a vague recall of God turning these Nachashs into snakes. If so, just as in such myths
not all toads are transformed people nor are all people transformed into toads, we need not suppose in the biblical
factual account that all Nachashs were turned into snakes or that all snakes are offspring of these Nachashs.

        The existence of pre-Adamic humanoids on Earth before Lucifer’s fall practically necessitates the affirmation

intergalactic trade with angelic rulers of other planets and their humanoid populations before his rebellion. The ETIs
on the planets in our solar system were part of the Luciferian confederation and perished in his destruction.
However, ETIs on other planets surely still exist.
        Nephilim hybrids probably existed in both the pre-Adamic and pre-Noachian eras. Plausibly, demons are the
disembodied spirits of Nephilim from both time periods. Demons are not redeemable. For that matter, fallen angels
and fallen pre-Adamites are not redeemable either. Redemption is limited to Adamites. Just as Lucifer’s fall would
not have automatically resulted in the fall of all angels, Adam’s fall would not have automatically resulted in the
fall of all humanoids. Unfallen humanoids do not need redemption. Lucifer was a murderer from the beginning and
would have killed any humanoids under his command who did not submit to his rebellion. The Christian gospel is
good news for any such humanoids. Despite the belief of some in the RET camp who pose that pre-Adamic
humanoids were not fully sentient or were not created in the image of God, the more likely inference is that unfallen
humanoids, whether dead or alive, will have cause to rejoice in the victory Christ has won. The good news of the

these unfallen humanoids. They are morally accountable. As morally unfallen creatures, they will be able to
participate in the joy of an unfallen creation when Christ fully enacts His victory won on the cross and frees the

Introduction
       The association of New Jerusalem with Mount Zion is rather obvious. For example, WH makes the link
explicit: “You have come to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem” (Heb 12:22).
Yet some of the implications regarding this association are not so obvious and bear searching out.
Location
       The significance of Heavenly Jerusalem being to the north was discussed in LTPW. We will recap part of
that discussion here and tie it in with this discussion of Planet Rahab.180 The heavenly Mount Zion was occupied
originally by Lucifer in the far north (Is 14:13) and will be there again (Ps 48:1-2). Psalm 48 is not merely using
hyperbole when it pictures God’s City as the joy of the whole earth; rather, it is looking forward, typologically and
prophetically, to a point in time when Mount Zion will indeed be the joy of the whole Earth literally.
       1
        Great is the Lord, and greatly to be praised, in the city of our God, His holy mountain. 2 Beautiful
      in elevation, the joy of the whole earth, is Mount Zion in the far north, the city of the great King.
      3
        God, in her palaces, has made Himself known as a stronghold. 4 For, lo, the kings assembled
      themselves, they passed by together. 5 They saw it, then they were amazed; they were terrified, they
      fled in alarm. 6 Panic seized them there, anguish, as of a woman in childbirth. 7 With the east wind
      Thou dost break the ships of Tarshish. 8 As we have heard, so have we seen in the city of the Lord
      of hosts, in the city of our God; God will establish her forever. (Ps 48:1-8)

        A unique detail is added in this Psalm. Mount Zion is in the far north. This detail is unique in this capacity
except for the fact that Isaiah appears to use practically the same phraseology and imagery to describe when Lucifer
fell from Heaven because Lucifer said, “I will ascend to heaven; I will raise my throne above the stars of God, I
will set my throne on high; I will sit on the mount of assembly in the far reaches of the north” (Is 14:13). Where
could the mount of assembly be but Mount Zion? Lucifer, of course, was not aspiring to ascend to the Earthly
Jerusalem. Lucifer was seeking to set up his throne in Heavenly Jerusalem, “above the heights of the clouds”
(Is 14:14) on the “holy mountain of God” (Eze 28:14).181 This Heavenly City is the misthological reality to which

        Phillips (JPCS) commences his explanation of the phrase in Psalms, “The expression ‘the sides of the north’

abode of Baal was Mount Zaphon. In fact, Mount Zaphon is known as the Mountain of Baal. God was enthroned
there.185 Isaiah uses this word for north (Zaphon) in 14:13, along with other parts of the Canaanite imagery, as a
taunt to the king of Babylon.186 In doing so, Isaiah adapts and modifies Canaanite poetry, applies it to a historical
situation, and merges it with a description of Lucifer’s fall. As Athtar,187 the son of the Morning (i.e., son of
Shachar),188 was unable to ascend successfully to Mount Zaphon and rule in Baal’s place (and had to rule on Earth
instead), so the king of Babylon will fail (as Lucifer fell), and the Israelites will be freed from his rule.189
        Liberals will suggest that Isaiah’s theology was developed from Canaanite sources. Some conservatives
object and seek to find other explanations, such as attributing such sayings to Jerusalem’s geographical or
topological location, both of which are dismissed, and rightly so, by Lange. While such factors may have inspired
Isaiah’s imagination and suggested the application he makes, such conservative estimations fail to account for the
full impact of the material. Lange dismisses the comments by those who would pose parallelism with the pagan
sources: “Now Mount Zion is not here compared to the supposed mountain homes of the gods of the Asiatic nations
in the far north, nor is it presented as realizing that of which the heathen dreamed.”190 On the other hand, other
conservatives, such as myself, believe that Isaiah indeed has adapted the Canaanite material to fit his literary
and prophetic purposes. Lange failed to consider a typological usage that drew upon geographical, typological,
mythological, and historical sources. I will only summarize my approach here since I have explained it more
thoroughly in TOD. I pose typology, as opposed to mere poetical hyperbole, as the literary genre. Even Lange
appears open to the possibility that Is 14:13 is indeed using pagan ideas of the northern mountain to present the
biblical picture. Once again, he acknowledges that earthly Mount Zion hardly fits the bill: “Here the Babylonian
expresses his purpose of assuming the highest place, not simply on earth among the lords of the world, but in heaven
itself, and that above the stars, which seem here to be conceived of as the residences of the spirits of God....Zion
lay neither to the north of Palestine nor to the north of Jerusalem, nor does the mention of Zion in this sense become
the lips of the possessor of the world-power.” What mountain is this? Lange answers: “The pinnacle of the sacred
mountain of the gods, about which the constellations circle, and which the heathen notions of the Orient represent
as in the North. This mountain is variously named by the different nations. It is called Meru...by those in India,
Alburg by the others; nor does the Olympus of the Greeks stand wholly disconnected herewith.”191 Acknowledging
that they are not disconnected from this mountain begs the question of how they are connected. How is the mountain
home of the gods in the farthest recesses of the north connected with earthly Mount Zion?
        My answer is that these mountains are certainly connected historically (in the pre-Adamic and Adamic distant
past and Isaiah’s present), to a limited extent geographically and topologically, obviously poetically, and to a fuller
extent prophetically and typologically. The historical, geographical, and topological parallels are the seedbed for
the poetical, prophetical, and typological connections. Both Isaiah and the Canaanites, and by implication David
also, are drawing upon a historical reality that predates the flood, when the heavenly mountain City of God

(known as Mount Zion, Zaphon, Olympus, Meru, Alburg, etc.) was indeed to the north of this planet. My

the eyes of David as well, is that many years before these images were committed to Scripture, the people of this
planet were aware of this Mountain City and probably even saw it. Abraham endured many trials and the testing of
his faith, for he was looking for this Reward City (Heb 11:8). How could he look for it if he knew nothing about it?
In NT times, this City is called various names: Heavenly City, Heavenly Jerusalem, New Jerusalem, and Mount
Zion. In deference to the NT teaching and imagery, one might also call it the Bridal City—a reward for bridal saints.
Isaiah also describes this City in bridal terms. So this perspective is not unique to the NT. Because Abraham was
looking for this Heavenly City as his reward and because David talks about the possibility of earning the right to
ascend to this City, the probability should be granted that Abraham and David share a similar perspective about the
City—a perspective grounded in factual history, not pagan mythology.
        Admittedly, to some extent, this biblical perspective was shared by pagans. Though the historical
background had been distorted by pagan myths, the biblical record suggests a common heritage. One need
not pose that the biblical record has been contaminated by pagan mythology, although it is expressed in part by
pagan imagery. Just as the event of the Noachian flood can be found preserved in primitive accounts from various
people groups around the world, the recollection of an earlier time when this City was stationed to the north of this
planet is preserved in various stories as well. The heavenly Mount Zion of the Bible is the Mount Olympus of the
Greek myths. Yet the Greek myths are but a distorted picture of the reality to which the Bible accurately points.
        The similarities between the earthly Mount Zion and the Heavenly City inspired the imaginations of David
and Isaiah (under the superintendence and inspiration of the Holy Spirit, of course) to see parallels with the heavenly
Mount Zion (known from times past). The current historical events going on in David’s life and Isaiah’s life
triggered a recollection of previous historical accounts and a projection of future historical outcomes surrounding
this thematic mountain. These OT prophets clearly foresaw the possibility of earning the right to ascend to this
Heavenly City that was shaped like a mountain. A Greek would have described it as becoming one of the gods
living on Mount Olympus.
        Moving beyond the above discussion in LTPW, I would pose that whether the City was visible above Earth
from the time of the Luciferian flood until the time of the Noachian flood, the stories about it originally being above
Planet Rahab could have been passed down from Adam and Eve to their descendants. Alternatively/additionally,
when the 200 Watchers came to Earth in Gen 6:1-4, they would have told their version of the story. Most likely,
Adam and Eve gave the true version of the story to their descendants as related to them by God. Then the Watchers
gave their version when they came down and mingled with human women. As a result, various pagan versions of
this northern location have survived. Job and Psalms confirm the destruction of Planet Rahab, a destruction
told in pagan versions. Psalms also shares the pagan perspective that this celestial City will be located to the
north in the future because that is where it was located in the distant past—above Planet Rahab.

                                                     Mount Zion
       To recap some of the historical and typographical information from LTPW, Mount Zion was not a gift to be
received but a prize to be won. This Mountain City is a Reward City. Originally, this mountain near Jerusalem was
the home of a Jebusite fortress. After David captured Zion by overcoming its previous inhabitants, he named it the
City of David (2Sam 5:8-9), which is where he lived (1Chron 11:7). Typologically, one would expect overcomers
to be the inhabitants of Zion. They, too, must overcome its previous inhabitants to inhabit it misthologically. As
noted above, the heavenly Mount Zion counterpart was occupied originally by Lucifer in the far north, as indicated
in Is 14:13: “You said in your heart, ‘I will ascend to heaven; above the stars of God I will set my throne on high; I
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 114
will sit on the mount of assembly in the far reaches of the north” (ESV). Moreover, this heavenly Mount Zion
will be located to the north yet again: “Great is the Lord, and greatly to be praised, in the city of our God, His holy
mountain. Beautiful in elevation, the joy of the whole earth, is Mount Zion in the far north, the city of the great
King” (Ps 48:1-2). If we wish to occupy the thrones from which Lucifer and his followers have fallen, we must
overcome Satan and his forces in spiritual warfare.
        Exegetically, one may derive the same conclusion. Zion is also where the Lord is to dwell forever: “Sing
praises to the Lord, who dwells in Zion (Ps 9:11). “For the Lord has chosen Zion; He has desired it for His
habitation. This is My resting place forever; here I will dwell, for I have desired it” (Ps 132:13-14).192 Mount Zion
is God’s resting place. It is the City of Rest. Of course, the Lord Jesus is to be installed as King there because He
overcame. Jesus attributes His own misthological rulership to His overcoming, and He promises that those believers
who likewise overcome will also rule with Him from the same throne: “He who overcomes, I will grant to him to
sit down with Me on My throne, as I also overcame and sat down with My Father on His throne” (Rev 3:21). Where
is that throne? Zion. Accordingly, Zion will be populated by overcoming rulers, an overcoming monarchy. Mount
Zion is to be the location of the blessing—life forever (Ps 133:2). The blessing of having eternal life on this mountain
is misthological. Believers can/must earn it.
        David asks this question: “O Lord, who may abide in Thy tent? Who may dwell on Thy holy hill?”
(Ps 15:1) The Hebrew word for hill here is har. The same Hebrew word is used for the mountain in Ps 2:6. Some
translations render it as Zion My holy hill, some as Zion My holy mountain. Regardless of the preference, the
reference is the same. David is comparing dwelling on Mount Zion to living in God’s house. But who gets to live
there? David answers that question immediately by providing a list of qualifications. The first verse of that list
suffices for our purposes: “He who walks with integrity, and works righteousness, and speaks truth in his
heart” (Ps 15:2). Living in God’s house on Mount Zion is a reward conditioned on your performing righteous
works.
        The same theme is repeated in Psalm 24: “Who may ascend into the hill [har] of the Lord? And who may
stand in His holy place?” (Ps 24:3) Given the focus on abiding and dwelling on this holy mountain in Ps 15:1,
Barnes comments, regarding ascending and standing to it in Ps 24:3, that the questions are asking: “Who shall
ascend there with a view of abiding there? Who is worthy to dwell there?” In response to David’s question as to
who can stand on this holy mountain/hill, Barnes refers back to the fact that the wicked cannot stand in the judgment
in Ps 1:5. The thought is, “Who is worthy to stand before God? Who has the qualifications requisite to constitute
the evidence of his friendship?” This evidence is requisite and prescriptive, not merely descriptive. So what
qualifications must you possess to dwell there? David again provides a similar list of necessary quality traits: “He
who has clean hands and a pure heart, who has not lifted up his soul to falsehood, and has not sworn
deceitfully. He shall receive a blessing from the Lord and righteousness from the God of his salvation”
(Ps 24:4-5). If you live righteously, you will be rewarded with this misthological righteousness as your blessing.
The NT imagery of being rewarded with a crown of righteousness would be fitting (2Tim 4:8). After all, living on
this mountain and co-ruling with Christ are reserved for royalty. More than mere faith is necessary to reside on
Mount Zion. Rewards are conditioned on works, and these passages deal with rewards. The earthly Mount Zion
does not typologically picture Heaven. Instead, it pictures the heavenly Mount Zion, just as in David’s descriptions,
Mount Zion is not the entire planet. Phillips (JPCS) is perceptive in his assessment of Ps 24:

            The Lord now throws down the challenge! “Who wants to ascend to the hill of the Lord?
      Who wants a lofty place in the kingdom? Who wants a share in all that is going to be controlled
      from Mount Zion? Who wants a share in the dynamics of secular power during the coming
      kingdom? Who wants to stand in the holy place?” In David’s day only the high priest of Israel
      could stand in the holy place and then only briefly once a year. The Lord, however, throws wide the
      temple gates and rends the veil: “Who wants a share in all that goes on in the holy place?”
            What a call! It was to try to attain just such a dual thrown of power that Lucifer fell....
            Such positions of eminence during the coming golden age are not for everyone, just for
      those who earn them. The essential qualifications will be Christlikeness!

      Paradise for sweethearts. (Pp. 34-35)

Hetrick and I concur that reproductive sex is ruled out for those resurrected from the dead while
monogamous sexual companionship continues. We differ, at least in specifics, regarding the presence of
reproductive organs, however. He affirms that resurrected women and men still look like males and females. Would
this not entail resurrected women having feminine breasts and males having male breasts? Would this distinction
between the sexes not also apply to other sexual genitalia? Logical consistency dictates that they retain these
external genitalia but that the functions of these genitalia are transformed in the resurrected state so that they no
longer serve to promote sexual reproduction but exclusively promote sexual companionship via sexual pleasure.
MSIH explorers this superior proposal at length. Indeed, Hetrick’s statements here seem to necessitate my
conclusions, though he will formulate his own answers to support various levels of sexual pleasure for heavenly
soulmates.195

        Hetrick correctly implies that entrance into the Heavenly City is a reward. He expounds in the next chapter:
“The angel who keeps the gate has on record the name, the spiritual status and the works of every saint of God. In
this hallway we are greeted by the angel of the gate with a joyful welcome because he knows who we are and
because the angels bring only those who are worthy to enter this City” (p. 44). Not everyone in Heaven will be

itself, though, is free:

             Everyone who enters Heaven has the same eternal life, but everyone does not have the
      same reward. In the resurrection we are changed in substance from physical to spiritual, but we
      are not changed in character. All that is required to enter Heaven and obtain eternal life is to

             If you want rewards and spiritual character, in Heaven, you must while on earth add to your

Not all believers who are judged in Heaven do well. Hetrick describes seeing the judgment of believers hearing the
joyous, “Well done,” versus those who did not:

      absolutely no works at all for which to be rewarded. All the works that they had done were for
      themselves, or done with selfish motives, for they did not do unto others as they would have others do
      unto them, therefore they had no works recorded, and they suffered by reason of their loss. The Judge
      also suffered with them for He was touched by the feeling of their sorrows, but there was nothing He
      could do, for they had chosen to live as they had lived. These sorrows so affected us that we asked to
      be dismissed and were allowed to join those who were rejoicing in their post-judgment joys. (P. 76)

Unfortunately, Hetrick did not want to see the outcome for those believers who succumb rather than overcome, so
we are left to biblical extrapolation. My assessment is that these unfaithful believers are sent to the outer courts of
the City, that is, to the outer realm of the heavenly dimension. Hetrick’s testimony and his limited citations suggest
this conclusion. My more thorough analysis demands it.
       Returning now to Star, Hetrick’s daughter, she attests that the outer court around the City is the size of a
planet (p. 29). She confirms something I have proven in various places in my writings: “If we are not learning to
be in harmony/obedience to the Spirit on earth, we will not be happy and fulfilled in Heaven because everyone
and everything there is Spirit-controlled” (p. 81). Not everyone in Heaven will have a cup full of joy. Some will
experience sorrow. Why? She proceeds to answer that there will be different degrees of rewards in Heaven. Only
those believers who are holy in their behavior will be near to the Lord. She cites Ps 4:3 and Ps 65:4 (p. 106).
Holy believers live in God’s courts. Unholy believers do not. At best, her statements give the impression that
unfaithful believers would have to live in a lower level of the City. However, since she, like her father, divides

you are now one with God’s Spirit, and as Adam and Eve were originally together as one, so companions here
can unite together, masculine and feminine as one person. After the resurrection, your glorified bodies will
be able to unite in the same way” (p. 70).

believers into three groups, she seems to leave open the possibility that some believers might dwell in the courts

done” (Lk 19:17), and gets to rule 10 cities. The second slave does not do as well and does not hear, “Well done”

amply justified, on the basis of OT misthopology, to identify the heavenly Mount Zion with the Heavenly Jerusalem
and regard it as a reward (Heb 12:22), a Reward City.

Primary Pauline Zionistic Texts

                                                      Rom 11:26
       For a reverse of the direction of Illustration 18, an abbreviated extract from LTPW will suffice. Paul links
the salvation of which he speaks in Romans with what is written in the OT text: “All Israel will be saved; just as it
is written, ‘The Deliverer will come from Zion’” (Rom 11:26). Yet the Hebrew text says that He will come to
Zion (Is 59:20). The LXX translates this verse into Greek as stating that He will come for the sake of Zion. Paul
changed the wording of the OT text he is citing in Rom 11:26. In the Pauline context, the salvation from which the
legalistic Jews were cut off and from which believers in the present dispensation are in danger of being cut off
is one that comes from Zion.198 God’s chosen people can lose this salvation. Believers can lose misthological

end of the tribulation (which would be the time period in view here in Romans), Paul actually specifies that Jesus
will be revealed from Heaven (2Thess 1:7). Technically, Jesus will already be present in the clouds and come from
Heavenly Mount Zion at that time. Zionistic salvation is a reward in both Psalms and Isaiah (see LTPW). Paul
certainly has this OT background in mind in Rom 11:26. Therefore, the most reasonable deduction is that Paul is,
in fact, referring to a reward in connection with Zion that is granted when the Lord returns.
        Paul probably changed the preposition intentionally to from in Rom 11:26 in accordance with Ps 14:7: “Oh,
that the salvation of Israel would come out of Zion! When the Lord restores His captive people” (repeated in Ps
53:6). This salvation will come from Zion. The riddle as to how the Lord and such salvation can come to Zion by
coming from Zion is easily answered once it is acknowledged that two different Zions are in view, yet they are
linked typologically by the same salvation. When the Lord comes from Heavenly Zion, He will accomplish
misthological salvation for earthly Zion. In Paul’s context, being cut off from this misthopological salvation is what
is at stake for God’s children.
        Paul would be familiar with OT misthopology from both Psalms and Isaiah, and he most likely invokes that
OT imagery intentionally in Rom 11:26. Isaiah proceeds to say, shortly after the verse that Paul has quoted and
adapted in Rom 11:26, that at that future time period (which Paul is talking about): “Then all your people will be
righteous; they will inherit [kleronomeo] the land forever” (Is 60:21). All your people (who are righteous in their
behavior) will inherit the Promised Land of Zion as their reward. All faithful believers will be saved in terms of
inheriting the promised reward. Unfaithful believers will be cut off from the land and city of Zion, just as David
confirms:
      5
        Whoever secretly slanders his neighbor, him I will destroy; no one who has a haughty look and an
      arrogant heart will I endure. 6 My eyes shall be upon the faithful of the land, that they may dwell with
      me; he who walks in a blameless way is the one who will minister to me. 7 He who practices deceit
      shall not dwell within my house; he who speaks falsehood shall not maintain his position before me.
      8
        Every morning I will destroy all the wicked of the land, so as to cut off from the city of the Lord all
      those who do iniquity. (Ps 101:5-8)
       Surely, this picture of how David will conduct his house on earthly Mount Zion mirrors how he believes God
will conduct His house in the heavenly counterpart in an as-above-so-below model. Given Paul’s familiarity with
OT misthopology, being cut off in Romans from Zionistic salvation assuredly has misthopological overtones. Being
cut off from the salvation/inheritance associated with the Heavenly City is at stake in both David’s psalms and
Paul’s epistle. This danger in relation to Zion is in Paul’s mind, as proven from his context when he says, “Behold
then the kindness and severity of God; to those who fell, severity, but to you, God’s kindness, if you continue in
His kindness; otherwise you also will be cut off” (Rom 11:22). Paul’s statement, like that of David, is anticipatory
of the reward described by John. McLaughlin is an FG proponent of the misthopological nature of the Reward City.

        Winner believers is McLaughlin’s term for overcomer believers. He is correct to state that not all believers
are overcomers. In his bracketed insert in the above quote, he is justified to interject that only overcomer believers
will enter New Jerusalem. He is insightful to suggest that unfaithful believers will never see the inside of this
Heavenly City! His position is entirely plausible, indeed acceptable. If the Bema is at the top of New Jerusalem,
then all believers will be summoned to the top of the City to be judged at the Judgment Seat of Christ.
Unfaithful believers, however, will not be allowed to enter the City and thus never allowed inside the City to
see it for themselves. They will only see it from the outside. They will never see inside the City because they
will never enter it. McLaughlin’s conclusion is logically and biblically consistent.
        Additionally, McLaughlin’s deduction that loser believers (which would be a corresponding term for
subcomer believers) will not enter the Heavenly City and see certain things within it provides an explanation for
WH’s exhortation-warning: “Pursue peace with all men, and the sanctification without which no one will see the
Lord” (Heb 12:14). Practical sanctification is necessary to see the Lord misthologically. The Lord will be seated at
the Lord’s right hand in the Heavenly City. David refers to this Zionistic location of where they will be seated in
Ps 110:1-2: “The Lord says to my Lord: ‘Sit at My right hand, until I make Thine enemies a footstool for Thy
feet. The Lord will stretch forth Thy strong scepter from Zion, saying, ‘Rule in the midst of Thine enemies’”
(Ps 110:1-2). WH quotes from this passage in Heb 1:13 and alludes to it in Heb 1:3; 8:1; 10:12; 12:2. This location
of their seating is very much in WH’s mind. Therefore, when in this same chapter WH alludes to it and refers to the
Heavenly Jerusalem as Mount Zion (Heb 12:22), we may safely deduce that unfaithful believers will never see the
Lord Jesus seated at the right hand of the Father inside the Heavenly City. Additionally, we may reasonably infer
that since WH says that such believers will never see the Lord, he is talking about seeing the Father, who will be
in the Heavenly City.
        Commentators on Heb 12:14 tend to be very disappointing. Some see it as proof of conditional security.
Others think that it makes imparted sanctification a necessary proof of imputed sanctification. Some think that it
simply refers to imputed sanctification. Such soteriological interpretations falter badly because they fail to perceive
the misthological nature of the verse.

favorably acknowledges: “Hodges did not limit the passage to the eschatological future.” Fine. The verse has a

Still, such an interpretation fails to deal with the contextual focus and the theological elephant in the room. Even
though the verse may have a present application, what are its eschatological implications? Hodges (BKC) states,
“One’s perception of God even now is conditioned by his real measure of holiness (cf. Matt 5:8).” Ok, but what
about one’s perception of God even then—in the eschatological future? Surely Mt 5:8, for instance, has
eschatological implications and thus misthological ramifications. Tanner (GNTC) acknowledges: “‘Seeing the
Lord’ probably looks forward to that future moment that completes the sanctification process when each believer
will see the Lord face to face and be like Him (cf. 1 John 3:2).” Yes, Heb 12:14 looks to the future, but the remainder
of Tanner’s interpretation falls flat. If the verse is merely promising that every believer will see the Lord, then it
makes no sense for it to enjoin us to pursue peace and sanctification if we are going to see the Lord and receive
complete sanctification in the future even if we fail to pursue it in the present. WH urges: “Pursue peace with all
men, and the sanctification without which no one will see the Lord” (Heb 12:14). You must pursue peace and
sanctification if you hope to see the Lord in the manner being described by WH. Hodges correctly infers the
conditional nature of the verse. Tanner correctly observes the future nature of the verse. Yet Tanner assumes the
verse applies to all believers to some degree because “just as all true sons partake of God’s discipline (Heb 12:8),
so also enter the sanctification process, progress to some degree, and ultimately see the Lord” (GNTC). Not so! I
call Hodges as a witness to the fact that some believers refuse to submit to God’s discipline and thus become
misthologically illegitimate, as Hodges’ (BKC) comments on Heb 12:8 make clear. Such believers lose the reward
of their inheritance. The implication should be, then, that just as they lose their reward of the inheritance in Heb 12:8,
they lose their reward of seeing God in the manner described in Heb 12:14. Even Tanner’s (GNTC) statements on
Heb 12:8 are pointing in the right direction: “If we are to be metochoi [partners/partakers] with Jesus on the
pilgrimage to the heavenly Jerusalem, then we must also willingly become metochoi of God’s disciple that helps us
successfully arrive there.” Precisely! We must be willing to submit to God’s discipline if we are going to be able to
enter the Reward City. To see God inside the Heavenly City is a reward. This view of God is not for each believer,
only for obedient believers.
        Govett (GOH) is on the right track when he comments on Heb 12:14: “The ‘seeing the Lord,’ to which we
are called, is that of reward in the glory of the kingdom.” The problem with his comment is that as a kingdom-
exclusionist, it might be taken to mean nothing more than faithful believers are allowed to enter the millennial
kingdom and see God therein. Thus, his statement is too generic and leaves the question unanswered as to what
happens at the end of the millennial kingdom when, according to kingdom-exclusion misthology, unfaithful
believers are allowed into the eternal kingdom. Do they see the Lord then? If so, does seeing the Lord cease to be a
reward limited to faithful believers at that time? However, this would not be possible since rewards and the lack
thereof are eternal. Koester (AYBC) is better in his comments on the verse: “Seeing God was an eschatological
hope (Matt 5:8; 1 Cor 13:12; 1 John 3:2; Rev 22:4) that Hebrews depicts as entry into the heavenly city (Heb 12:22–
24) and sanctuary (10:19), where God is present.” Likewise, Rhee rightfully associates this seeing with the
contextual reference to the Heavenly Jerusalem: “In 12:14–29 the author gave further insight on the heavenly city.
It is Mount Zion, the city of the living God, that is, the heavenly Jerusalem (v. 22). Believers in the New Covenant
have already entered this heavenly city, as indicated by the perfect tense (προσεληλύθατε, ‘have come to’).”201 The
misthopological implications of a number of Psalms were demonstrated in LTPW. Although Ps 27:4 was briefly
noted in that capacity, more could be said regarding its implication for the City. Obviously, the one thing that David
seeks in this verse has serval components since he says: “One thing I have asked from the Lord, that I shall seek:
[1] that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life, [2] to behold the beauty of the Lord, [3] and to
meditate in His temple.” These three components are not mere anticipations but aspirations. They must be sought.
Believers are to seek them through holy obedience to the Lord. To dwell in the City and behold the Lord are rewards
to be sought. The one entails the other. Seeing God’s face is the principal reward to be sought, as David goes on to
indicate a few verses later: “When Thou didst say, ‘Seek My face,’ my heart said to Thee, ‘Thy face, O Lord, I shall
seek” (Ps 27:8; cp. Ps 105:4). Govett’s statement needs to be amended to affirm that seeing the Lord is a reward in
the glory of the Heavenly City.
        Even so, an additional deduction must be made. Commenting on Heb 12:14, Lang (TETTH) draws the
necessary inferences:

             That the holiness here in view is not that righteousness which is imputed to the ungodly
      when he first places faith in Christ is clear from the very fact that the already justified are here
      exhorted to pursue it. That they had received as a free gift (Rom. 3: 24); this they are to pursue.
             iii. The Goal of the Race—Seeing the Lord (ver. 14). Two questions arise: (1) Who is “the
      Lord”? and (2) What is meant by “seeing” Him?
             Concerning the Lord Jesus Christ it is written that before Him “every knee shall bow” (Rom.
      14:11; Phil. 2:10,11) and that “every eye shall see Him,” including those who pierced Him (Rev. 1:7).
      Therefore holiness is no prerequisite for seeing Christ.
             But the title “the Lord” is definitely applied to God the Father. This usage follows the Old
      Testament. In Ps. 2:2 “the Lord [Jehovah]” is distinguished from “His Anointed,” which passage is
      quoted in Acts 4: 26, followed in vers. 29, 30 by " And now Lord . . . grant . . . that signs and wonders
      may be done through the name of Thy holy Servant Jesus.” The same distinction is made in Paul’s
      words: “the grace of our Lord abounded exceedingly with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus”
      (I Tim. 1: 14). Christ Himself had addressed His Father as “Lord of heaven and earth” (Matt. 11: 25);
      and James echoes this by speaking of “the Lord and Father” (Jas. 3:9).
             It would therefore seem that our passage it must be the Father for the sight of Whom
      practical holiness is essential….
             …there is yet another statement even more completely parallel to our present passage. It is
             (l) Matt. 5:8: “Blessed are the pure in heart; for they shall see God”; and, as in Hebrews, this is
      immediately associated with peaceableness by the directly following words: “Blessed are the
      peacemakers; for they shall be called sons of God.” The mention of sons of God shows that “God”
      here is the Father, and thus the Son pointed forward to a sight of the Father.
             (m) This is the evident sense of the sublime doxology in Jude 24,25: “Now unto Him that is able
      to guard you from stumbling, and to set you before the presence of His glory without blemish in
      exceeding joy, to the only God our Saviour, through Jesus Christ our Lord, be glory, etc.” “God our
      Saviour” must here mean the Father, for the glory is rendered to Him "through Jesus Christ our
      Lord”; and the prospect opened is of a permanent position (“set” you) before the very personal glory
      of God.
             It is essential to this that there be conferred a body of glory, spiritual and of heaven, which can
      endure the blaze of that uncreated light. The natural, earthly body cannot do this: “Man shall not see
      Me and live” (Exod. 33:20); for “the blessed and only Potentate,” the Father, is “dwelling in light
      unapproachable; Whom no man hath seen, nor is able to see” (I Tim. 6: 15,16). The heirs of glory must
      be “clothed upon with our habitation which is from heaven” (II Cor. 5:2), at the coming of the Lord
      (I Cor. 15: 35-38).
             iv. The Prize of the Course is Conditional (ver. 14)….
             But the attaining of this high dignity is conditional upon development of godliness. “Pursue the
      sanctification apart from which [hou chõris] no one shall see the Lord.” [Seeing the Father]…is
      conditional upon the justified giving diligence to advance in personal holiness….
             ….A king has million of subjects, most of whom never see him in his palace. It is the few who
…
      are counted worthy of this honor.202 (Italics his.)

       The Lord’s face, which must be sought exclusively as a reward, is that of the Father. Everyone will see Jesus’
face. Only faithful believers will see the Father’s face. Why? Because the Father will be seated on His throne in the
Reward City, and unfaithful believers will not be allowed into the City. The misthological nature of such verses
supports the misthopological interpretation of the City. In commenting on Mt 5:8, France (NICNT) correctly
connects the dots when he says,

            The vision of God which is the goal of the pure in heart (Ps 24:6; cf. Pss 11:7; 17:15; 27:5;
      42:2 for this aspiration), and which is here promised to them, is sometimes in the OT expressed in


202
  G. H. Lang, The Epistle to the Hebrews: A Practical Treatise for Plan and Serious Readers (Miami Springs, FL:
Conley & Schoettle Publishing Co., 1985), 244-248.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                     Page 122
         terms of an actual “seeing” (Exod 24:10; Isa 6:1) though these are clearly marked out as exceptional.
         More often it is the invisibility of God which is stressed (Exod 33:18–23) and this is strongly reinforced
         in the NT (John 1:18; 1 Tim 1:17; 6:16). There may be visionary experiences in this world which
         include a “seeing” of God, as for John on Patmos, but “seeing God’s face” is a privilege reserved
         for the new Jerusalem (Rev 22:4; cf. 1 Cor 13:12; 1 John 3:2).

       This privilege of seeing God’s face has a rich OT background, going back to the Psalms, especially, as France
(NICNT) notes, “Psalm 24, on which this beatitude is based.” About the only thing missing in France’s affirmation
is the explicit acknowledgment that this beatitude in Mt 5:8 is a reward. This missing detail is supplied by Hagner
(WBC):
                The sixth beatitude bears strong similarity to the thought of Ps 24[LXX: 23]:3–4, where the
         LXX refers, as does the present text, to the καθαρὸς τῇ καρδία, “the pure in heart” (cf. Pss 51:10; 73:1;
         linked here with “guiltless hands”), who will go up to the mountain of the Lord and stand in his
         holy place. “Pure in heart” refers to the condition of the inner core of a person, that is, to thoughts and
         motivation, and hence anticipates the internalizing of the commandments by Jesus in the material that
         follows in the sermon. It takes for granted right actions but asks for integrity in the doing of those
         actions, i.e., a consistency between the inner springs of one’s conduct and the conduct itself. Another
         way of putting this is in terms of “single-mindedness” (cf. Jas 4:8, where it is the “double-minded”
         who are exhorted to “purify [their] hearts”). Purity of heart and purity of conscience are closely related
         in the pastoral Epistles (cf. 1 Tim 1:5; 3:9; 2 Tim 1:3; 2:22; cf. 1 Pet 1:22). The reference to seeing
         God in the present passage is again eschatological in tone. In contrast to the strong OT statement that
         no one can see the face of God and live (e.g., Exod 33:20), the righteous in the eschatological age will
         experience the beatific vision; they will see the face of God (cf. too Rev 22:4). Although one might
         have expected in the second clause something more in line with the first, such as “for they will be
         granted peace,” Matthew describes the greatest possible eschatological reward, one that by its
         nature includes all else. This beatitude is the most difficult to relate to the others.
        Well said. Seeing God’s face is the greatest possible eschatological reward and includes everything else. It
is conditioned on inner experiential purity and associated with being able to ascend God’s holy mountain and stand
in His Holy City, which was David’s aspiration. Since it is a reward, it is not freely given to all believers, only to
those believers who purify their hearts. Therefore, Yates’ statement needs clarification when he says, “His throne
will be located where His servants will serve Him ([Rev] 22:3), and the residents of the New Jerusalem “will see
His face” ([Re 22] v. 4). This sacred fellowship is not unique to Tribulation saints; it is a promised reward for all
believers (Matt. 5:8; 1 Cor. 13:12; 1 John 3:2).”203 If by “all believers” Yates means faithful believers of all
dispensations up through the tribulation, then he is correct (all without distinction does not mean all without
exception). If he means that all believers get this reward regardless of the way they live, then he is mistaken. The
latter possibility is logically ruled out by noting that it is a reward. Hence, the former statement stands, and the
clarification should be made that this promised reward will not be obtained by all believers, only by faithful
believers of the various dispensations.
        Judging from such texts and from the fact that the Father “has given all judgment to the Son” (Jn 5:22), we
must infer that the Father remains seated inside the City, with the result that unfaithful believers will not see the
Father. Possibly, they are judged by the Lord Jesus at the Bema atop the City. The Father told Moses: “You cannot
see My face, for no man can see Me and live!” (Ex 33:20) Presumably, even those believers who visit inside the
Heavenly City in the eternal state in sinless flesh and blood bodies will not be able to come into the throne room
and see the Father since they do not have transformed bodies. They will only have semi-transformed bodies that are
sinless but not immortal. Apparently, WH is asserting more, namely, that unfaithful believers, even though having
fully transformed immortal bodies, will not be able to enter the City and thus will not be able to see the Father. In
fact, they will never see the Father. Heb 12:14 may be the saddest verse in the Bible for unfaithful believers,
indicating that they will never be able to see their Daddy’s face. If there was no other reason to be faithful
than to have this one reward, to see your Daddy’s face, it would suffice as sufficient grounds to be faithful.
The reward of seeing Daddy’s face is apparently limited to overcomers. Like Ps 110:1-2, the dual reference to
“throne of God and of the Lamb” in Rev 22:1,3 locates their thrones in New Jerusalem, where the promise to

203
      R. S. Yates, “The Rewards of the Tribulation Saints,” BibSac 163 (2006): 327.
Chapter 4. New Jerusalem as Mount Zion                                                                        Page 123
overcomers is that “they shall see His face” (Rev 22:4). Seeing the Father’s face is a reward limited to overcomers.
       Notwithstanding the persuasiveness of the above writers regarding the misthological nature of seeing God’s
face in a variety of texts, I must part company with them when they simplistically place 1Jn 3:2 in this same
category. For instance, the citations by France and Yates include 1Jn 3:2. Lang lumps 1Jn 3:2 in with these purely
misthological references to seeing God’s face.204 Evidently, from Lang’s perspective, the misthological privilege of
seeing God just as He is in 1Jn 3:2 is apparently talking about the Father (cp. 1Jn 3:1), whose children we are, as
underscored in 1Jn 3:2. The problem with such a simplistic assumption is that John uses phaneroo (appear) in both
1Jn 2:28 and 1Jn 3:2 in reference to when He appears, apparently talking about Christ. Therefore, trying to read the
verse in the manner indicated by the context yet inferred by Lang’s presumption yields a rather strained limitation:
      2
       Beloved, now we are children of God [the Father], and it has not appeared as yet what we shall be.
      We know that, when He [the Son] appears, we shall be like Him [who: Father, Son, both?], because
      we shall see Him [who: Father, Son, both?] just as He [who: Father, Son, both?] is. (1Jn 3:2)
        Some scholars believe that like Him refers to the Father, while others believe that it refers to the Son. The
same is true of see Him. Smalley (WBC) provides discussion for both sides of the argument and yet states: “The
writer’s Christology is such that he does not make sharp distinctions between the persons of God and Jesus.” If this
is an unconditional promise that applies indiscriminately to all believers, then 1Jn 3:3 should be treated in the same
manner. On the other hand, if it is a conditional promise that applies only to faithful believers, then 1Jn 3:2 should
likewise be treated as an imperative that makes a hortatory condition. Yarbough (BECNT) says that 1Jn 3:2 is
tantamount to an imperative. Concurring with Bultmann, Smalley (WBC) says that its hortatory overtones are
obvious. Citing Mt 5:8, Marshall (NICNT) says, “The condition for seeing Jesus is that we should be morally fit to
come into his presence.” Eaton likewise gives grounds for concluding that “1 John 3:3 is not referring to what
irresistibly and inevitably happens to each Christian.”205
        In contrast, Hodges (GNTC) states that in 1Jn 3:2, “seeing Jesus in His glory will be automatically
transforming for each child of God.” So in 1Jn 3:3, to hope in Him is equivalent to believe in Him and results in
soteriological ontological purity.206 Anderson concurs that “all believers will be like Him when He appears” so that
the verse is an eschatological affirmation of perfective sanctification.207 NIBC likewise surmises: “Believers will
put on immortality and become free from the sin nature that presently plagues us.” In TOD, I also took 1Jn 3:2 as
affirming the unconditional, perfect sanctification of all believers. At that time, I was inclined to think that all
believers will get a glorified body at that point, which is an affirmation that Anderson also makes. But this leaves a
contextual question unanswered: Why would unfaithful believers be shamefully put away from the Lord if they are
glorious like the Lord? If, however, the verse is only referring eschatologically to being ontologically and
experientially sinless, which is a strong theme in the ensuing context (1Jn 3:6-9), the verse need not be taken as
indicating that all believers will be glorious, which, in turn, would explain why some experience shame at that time.
        In 4DF, additional notation was made of misthological sanctification, and RBVGB limited glorification to
faithful believers. Given the scholarly division on the passage, the ambiguity of the text, and the soteric-mistholic
implications of the context, the proposition herein is that John purposefully invokes ambiguity here in accord with
his duality stated just a few verses earlier in seeing things from opposing vantage points (cp. 1Jn 2:7-8). John expects
us to see both points of view as contextually valid. All believers will see Jesus and be like Jesus in terms of being
sinless. Only morally pure believers will see Jesus and be like Jesus in terms of being glorious and thus able to stand
before the Father and see the Father’s face.
        Unfaithful believers will shrink away from Jesus at the Bema (1Jn 2:28) and thus not be able to enter the City

or see the Father’s face. As noted in TOD, LS draws erroneous soteriological conclusions in making practical

the Father is a reward limited to winner believers. Loser believers will be cut off from the possibility of seeing
the Father. Paul’s warning in Rom 11:22 has profound misthological implications, nor is this the only Pauline text
leading to such a conclusion.
                                  Illustration 19. Pauline View of Mount Zion




      Given Pauline misthopology, as gleaned from the OT background and his contemporary Jewish background
and his own writings, we are justified in advancing the hypothesis that Pauline misthopology is more prevalent than
generally perceived.208 Several additional Pauline texts suggesting misthopological overtones are worthy of
consideration.


208
   McLaughlin does well to credit Paul with such insights. However, he could have strengthened his association of
these insights with Paul, but he simply closes with a quote from Eph 3:16-19. Granted, this Pauline text has a
reference to God’s 4D breath-length-height-depth blessing (which could be a veiled reference to the 4D City), but
Pauline misthopology is more readily discerned in texts such as Rom 11:26.

                                                       Phil 3:20
       Paul affirms that our “citizenship [politeuma] is in heaven, from which also we eagerly wait for a Savior, the
Lord Jesus Christ” (Phil 3:20).209 Because which is singular and grammatically denotes coming from a singular
location associated with citizenship in the plural heavens, a reasonable gloss for its translation would be: “For our
citizenship is in the heavens, from which City also we eagerly wait for a Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ” (Phil 3:20;
TM). Putting City in italics in the translation denotes that it is implied by the context and grammar. Johnson says
that politeuma “really means ‘seat of citizenship.’”210 Another good gloss would be: “The seat of our citizenship is
in the heavens, from which also we eagerly wait for a Savior” (Phil 3:20; TM). Citizenship, though, suggests
membership in a city. And the seat of our citizenship is the City. McGee (TTBC) would translate it as: “For our city
home is in heaven.” Govett would translate politeuma as City in Phil 3:20 and, like many others, believes Paul is
describing the Lord as coming from this Heavenly City.211 The seat of our heavenly citizenship is the Heavenly
City. The best gloss may be: “Our City citizenship is in the heavens, from which City also we eagerly wait for a
Savior.” After all, the Greek word for city is polis, from which the word citizenship (politeuma) is derived.
209
    WH presents this same truth in Heb 12:23 when he refers to the “church of the first-born who are enrolled
[apographo] in heaven” (Heb 12:23). In Lk 2:3, we read, “And all were proceeding to register [apographo] for the
census, everyone to his own city.” To be enrolled in Heaven is to have one’s name registered as a citizen of the
Heavenly City mentioned in the previous verse (Heb 12:22). As noted in MMP2, WH explains that the purpose of
this shaking of the Earth and Heaven in Heb 12:26-27 is to remove those things from them that will not be eternally
within them. Lucifer and his forces will be forcefully removed from Heaven to Earth (Rev 12:4). However, one
might also add that the names of those believers who are found unfaithful at the Bema may have their names
removed from the City’s role. As noted in MMP3, Rev 3:5 and 21:27 indicate that our names cannot be erased
soteriologically, but they can be erased misthologically. Having one’s name recorded misthologically is the new
name (Rev 2:17) necessary for regal entrance into the Heavenly Jerusalem (cp. Rev 3:12).
210
    S. L. Johnson, Jr., “The Out-Resurrection from the Dead,” BibSac 110 (1953): 145.
211
    Govett, Romans, 472. In a footnote on that page, Govett says that city gives the best sense of politeuma, rather
than citizenship. Granted, on that page, he asserts that the Heavenly City sits on a heavenly Mount Zion, thus making
a distinction between the City and Mount Zion. Nevertheless, in Hebrews, he clarifies, “It is a real mountain, on
which the New Jerusalem, is set.” Nevertheless, “Mount Zion at length develops into Jerusalem, the heavenly city”
(Hebrews, 440). Rather than perceiving New Jerusalem as sitting on a celestial mountain initially, as Govett does,
I perceive New Jerusalem as being the celestial mountain conceptually. The literal city, New Jerusalem, is the
heavenly Mount Zion.
        Hawthorne (WBC) acknowledges that which in Phil 3:20 formally refers to citizenship but asserts that the
sense refers to Heaven. He says that commonwealth is a more accurate translation than citizenship but quotes Caird
as saying, “Each local church is a colony of heaven, its members enjoying full citizenship of the heavenly city (cf.
Gal 4:26; Eph 2:19).” Caird is better than Hawthorne. Lange asserts that which is adverbial and refers to Heaven.
BaNTC asserts that the singular which can refer to the plural heavens because the connotation is reputed to be
singular. Lenski, in contrast, says that which is best taken as referring to the singular citizenship, not to the heavens.
BECNT says that it formally agrees with homeland as a concrete place but still sees no strong objection to seeing
the plural heavens as the real antecedent (p. 189). Bockmuehl suggests that the expression may “be comparable to
the apocalyptic belief in a future descent to earth of the new Jerusalem” (BLNTC). ACC believes that it refers to a
city, specifically, “a heavenly city, the New Jerusalem.” The gloss I personally suggest takes these various factors
into consideration. Although the plural en ouranios (in the heavens) is a plural common and frequently translated
as singular, using the plural form here is advantageous because it performs double duty, which is probably intended
by Paul. The City is in Heaven and will be in the heavens at the time of the rapture. The plural translation is common
in Ps 2:4. The NAS, for instance, translates it as the Lord “who sits in the heavens.” The LXE renders it from the
LXX as, “For our God whom we serve is in the heavens.” Rendering it as singular is common in the NT. Paul
enjoins both. Another case in point would be 1Thess 1:10, where Paul says that we wait for the Lord to return from
Heaven/from the heavens (ek ton ouranon). The expression en tois ouranios is commonly translated as in the
heavens in Eph 1:10. Hendricksen comments on Phil 3:20: “Their heavenly mansions are being prepared. See such
passages as John 3:3; 14:1–4; Rom. 8:17; Eph 2:6; Col 3:1–3; Heb 4:14–16; 6:19, 20; 7:25; 12:22–24; 1 Peter 1:4,
5; Rev 7:9–17” (BaNTC). The Pauline texts included as cross-references are particularly interesting for our present
purposes. If taken at face value, which the present book is inclined to do, Hendricksen is acknowledging that Paul
is alluding to the fact that we are seated with Christ in the Heavenly City.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 126
      A verbal form is found in Phil 1:27. The NAS translates (politeuo) as conduct: “Only conduct yourselves in
a manner worthy of the gospel of Christ” (Phil 1:27). But this translation fails to convey the fact that politeuo is
verbally related to the noun city (polis). Witmer’s quote of Moule below is on target regarding Phil 3:20, but
Witmer’s translation of Phil 1:27 could use improvement.

      Moule wisely comments, “The Apostle means that Christians are citizens of the heavenly City [City
      is Moule’s superior rendering for Phil 3:20] as to their status, and are therefore ‘obliged by their
      nobility’ to live, however far from their home, as those who belong to it, and represent it.” The veiled
      exhortation of this verse to live in the light of the reality of our heavenly citizenship is presented as a
      direct command in an accurate translation of Philippians 1:27: “But under all circumstances do your
      duty as good citizens of a heavenly kingdom [kingdom is Witmer’s inferior rendering for Phil 1:27];
      act worthily of the Gospel of Christ.” (Italics his.)212

       As Witmer admits, Moule wisely translates the citizenship in Phil 3:20 in terms of belonging to a City, thus
my gloss City citizenship. Witmer, on the other hand, translates citizenship in Phil 1:27 in terms of belonging to a
kingdom. As Witmer goes on to explain, Paul valued his citizenship as a citizen of Rome (Acts 22:25-28; 25:10-
12). However, Rome was an earthly city from which its kingdom was ruled. We should not equate Rome with its
kingdom. Paul was grateful for his citizenship associated with that city. Likewise, we should not equate the
Heavenly City with its heavenly kingdom. New Jerusalem is the Heavenly City from which its heavenly kingdom
is ruled. The kingdom is much larger than the City. GWN translates Phil 1:27 as, “Live as citizens.” NLT provides
this gloss: “Live as citizens of heaven.” But considering what Paul clarifies in Phil 3:20, a better gloss for Phil 1:27
would be: “Live as citizens of the heavenly City.” A suitable translation would be: “Only, as citizens of the
Heavenly City, live in a manner worthy of the gospel of Christ” (Phil 1:27; TM). A misthopological gospel is in
view.213 In Phil 1:27 and 3:20, respectively, Paul exhorts us to live as citizens of this Heavenly City (politeuo) in
view of our citizenship in that Heavenly City (politeuma). This Heavenly City is the literal city of New Jerusalem,
explicitly described time and again in Revelation as a reward given to those who overcome (e.g., Rev 3:12;
Rev 22:19). McLaughlin was on target in this aspect of his assessment.
       Why live appropriately as citizens of this City, though? What difference does it make? How does this
citizenship fit into the context? The citizenship within the Heavenly City affirmed in Phil 3:20 probably includes
the eschatological destruction of unfaithful believers, alluded to in Phil 3:18-19: “For many walk, of whom I often
told you, and now tell you even weeping, that they are enemies of the cross of Christ, whose end is destruction,
whose god is their appetite, and whose glory is in their shame, who set their minds on earthly things.”
       This impression is reinforced from Paul’s previous statements in this epistle: “Some, to be sure, are preaching
Christ even from envy and strife, but some also from good will; the latter do it out of love, knowing that I am
appointed for the defense of the gospel; the former proclaim Christ out of selfish ambition, rather than from pure
motives, thinking to cause me distress in my imprisonment” (Phil 1:15-17). “But I hope in the Lord Jesus to send
Timothy to you shortly, so that I also may be encouraged when I learn of your condition. For I have no one else of
kindred spirit who will genuinely be concerned for your welfare. For they all seek after their own interests, not those
of Christ Jesus” (Phil 2:19-21). Sapaugh (GNTC) is certainly justified in applying Phil 3:17-19 to such believers:

             Unfortunately some believers are not good examples to follow. It distresses Paul greatly that
      there are believers who live their lives in opposition to the cross of Christ. These believers pursue
      their own self-interest and pleasure and disregard His call to bear the cross of discipleship. With their
      mind set on the things of the world, their pursuit of what is shameful will eventually result in their
      deaths. Here selfishness and selflessness are clearly contrasted. These libertines selfishly live for their
      own self-gratification. Paul selflessly lives for Christ. The libertines set their mind (phroneō) on
      earthly things. Paul, on the other hand, has the eternal perspective of Christ’s reward. (Emphasis his.)

      Fee (NICNT) likewise believes that Paul “is probably describing some itinerants, whose view of the faith is
such that it allows them a great deal of undisciplined self-indulgence.” After all, Paul is criticizing their walk, not
212
  J. A. Witmer, “Christian Civic Responsibility,” BibSac 111 (1954): 347–348.
213
   Similarly, a misthological gospel is in view in several Pauline passages. As noted in TOD, Paul teaches a
misthological gospel (Rom 2:16; Col 1:5,23; 2Thess 2:14). See DFS for an extended discussion of 2Thess 2:14.
Chapter 4. New Jerusalem as Mount Zion                                                                        Page 127
their doctrine. Perceiving Paul as weeping over errant libertine believers is more believable than thinking that he is
weeping over legalistic unbelievers. These are “anti-nomian libertines who were in some way connected with the
church. They misinterpreted Christian liberty as freedom from all moral restraint” (WCBCNT). “The description
applies far more aptly to professing Christians who allowed their liberty to degenerate into license (Gal. 5:13)”
(EGTC). Just as believers can be enemies of God via their friendship with the world (Jam 4:4), so they can be
enemies of the cross via worldly desires. Paul is not weeping over false brethren, but antinomian brethren.214
        On the other hand, given Phil 3:2-3, Hawthorne (WBC) thinks that unbelieving and/or believing Jewish
legalists are in view, though he ends his discussion of Phil 3:19 with the alternative possibility that Paul is dealing
with antinomians, which is the view adopted herein. In any case, his comments regarding the grammar of Phil 3:20
are insightful but involve an unnecessary assumption: “The pronoun ἡμῶν, ‘our,’ stands first in this new section. It
has the emphatic position (as in v 3) in order again to draw a sharp contrast between ‘them’ and ‘us,’ between Jews
or Jewish Christians and Pauline Christians. Their citizenship is on earth (v 19); ours is in heaven” (emphasis his).
His grammatical analysis is correct, but his soteriological interpretation is unnecessary. To be sure, Paul’s emphatic
pronominal position in v. 20 provides a contrast so that the citizenship being ascribed to those believers who follow
Paul’s example in Phil 3:17 is being denied to those who do not follow it in Phil 3:18-29. But Paul does not say that
the citizenship of those being described in vv. 17-18 is on Earth. This is a pure assumption on Hawthorne’s part.
Much more reasonable is the proposition that Paul is making a misthopological contrast. Faithful believers retain
their citizenship in the Heavenly City since citizenship in this City is a reward; indeed, it is the prize of the upward
call in Phil 3:14. Unfaithful believers forfeit their citizenship in this City.
        In Phil 3:19, Paul says that the end (telos) of such believers would be destruction (apoleia).215 Placing the
misthological destruction of such believers within the scope of possibilities described in Phil 3:20 provides the
impetus for the moral exhortation for believers to stand firm in the Lord in Phil 4:1. An exclusively soteric
citizenship makes little sense as grounds for appealing for moral performance in a context of misthological
destruction. What would be the misthological end of such believers? The telic (telos) destruction of these particular
heavenly citizens in Philippians gives grounds for concluding that their names will be erased from the heavenly
registry pertaining to this City. They will reap misthological destruction. Misthopologically, they will be in the
outer darkness.
        The passage is dealing with brethren, as interjecting two additional references as an interpretive gloss
clarifies:
             17
                Brethren, join in following my example, and observe those brethren who walk according to
      the pattern you have in us.
             18
                For many brethren walk, of whom I often told you, and now tell you even weeping, that they
      are enemies of the cross of Christ, 19 whose end is destruction, whose god is their appetite, and whose
      glory is in their shame, who set their minds on earthly things.
             20
                For our citizenship is in heaven, from which also we eagerly wait for a Savior, the Lord Jesus
      Christ; 21 who will transform the body of our humble state into conformity with the body of His glory,
      by the exertion of the power that He has even to subject all things to Himself. 1 Therefore, my beloved
      brethren whom I long to see, my joy and crown, so stand firm in the Lord, my beloved. (Phil 3:17-
      4:1).

The our of v. 20 jumps back to the brethren described in v. 17 who walk worthily and who are called beloved
brethren in 4:1. It excludes the enemy brethren who walk licentiously in vv. 18-19. Paul’s point in Phil 3:18-20 is
that enemy brethren reap misthological destruction in the form of misthopological exclusion. Therefore, we are
enjoined to walk in a manner worthy of our misthological citizenship since, otherwise, it can be forfeited.

   Thomas Finley, Philippians: Pursuing Christ to Know Him (N.P., 2015), 76-82.

   Whether the destruction (apoleia) of Phil 3:18 alludes back to that of Phil 1:28 is questionable. If so, the enemies

(apoleia) in 1Tim 6:9 certainly applies to believers, but it may apply to the regenerate or unregenerate alike. It is

                                                    2Cor 5:1
      The third most probable text describing Mount Zion from a misthopological perspective may be 2Cor 5:1.
Heron connects the dots. Before hearing from him, though, it might be best to clear the way of objections so that he
can be given a fair hearing. Consider the context:
      1
       For we know that if the earthly tent which is our house is torn down, we have a building from God,
      a house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens. 2 For indeed in this house we groan, longing to
      be clothed with our dwelling from heaven; 3 inasmuch as we, having put it on, shall not be found
      naked….8 we are of good courage, I say, and prefer rather to be absent from the body and to be at
      home with the Lord. (2Cor 5:1-3,8)

        Thrall (ICC) discusses nine different interpretations as to what building from God means in 1Cor 5:1. The
first he lists is his preference—a resurrection body. This is by far the most popular opinion. However, Paul is talking
about a building we currently have that is eternal in the heavens. We do not currently have resurrection bodies.
Thus, the second interpretation provided by ICC is much more plausible. ICC simply mentions this interpretation
but then provides two objections:

      [It] is not a heavenly body, but rather a heavenly habitation [i.e., Heavenly City] in the sense of the
      dwellings mentioned in Jn 14:2. The objection to this is precisely the main argument advanced in
      favour of (i), i.e., the logical requirement that οἰκία must have the same type of reference in both halves
      of the verse, coupled with the very high probability that in v. 1a the οἰκία is the body in the ordinary
      sense of the word. It is hazardous, moreover, to use the Johannine ‘many mansions’ to interpret Paul.216

      If the concept of this City was limited to John, then the thrust of the latter part of ICC’s objection would carry
more force. However, since the concept was found in the OT, shared by contemporaneous Jewish tradition, and
found in other NT literature, it seems rather shortsighted to rule it out so quickly.217 Moreover, having this eternal

building in the heavens when we die in 2Cor 5:1 is equated with being home with the Lord in 2Cor 5:8. The standard

      Why does Paul write the present tense (“we have”)? The answer is that New Testament writers
      frequently penned a present tense with a future meaning that is determined by the context. One example
      is in the Gethsemane narrative, where prior to his arrest Jesus says, “The Son of Man is betrayed in

       As to the first part of ICC’s objection, it too hastily overlooks the fact that New Jerusalem is described as a
tent not made with hands (Heb 9:11; TM), which correlates well with Paul’s description of this building as not made
with hands in 2Cor 5:1. To underscore the permanency of this heavenly tent, Paul describes it as a building. Yet
Hebrews also describes this tent in such terms, stating that the City was built by God (Heb 11:10). Conceptually,
Paul and WH seem to be on the same page and describing the same building. This City is God’s traveling tent, just
as our bodies are our traveling tents. As a tent, it moves. As a City, it has foundations.
       Still, rather than be content with my counter to Thrall’s (ICC) objections. I will allow his fellow ICC

which, like the Apocalypse of John, were written after the destruction of Jerusalem in 70 A. D.) doubtless furnished
the apostle with the basis of his conception here expressed.” According to the ICC (Burton), Paul was doubtlessly
thinking of New Jerusalem in Gal 4:26. Yet, according to the ICC (Thrall), Paul was not thinking of New Jerusalem
in 2Cor 5:1, even though Paul uses the present tense in 2Cor 5:1, which would normally indicate that he is thinking
of New Jerusalem. After all, Hansen says, “But Paul does not put the heavenly Jerusalem in the future. His use of
present tense indicates that the Galatian believers are already citizens of the heavenly Jerusalem” (IVPNTCS).
Granted, Hansen is probably thinking in some mystical sense rather than the literal sense of the City since he
immediately adds this rationale: “Since they are already experiencing the Spirit of God, they are already enjoying
the fulfillment of the promises of God. This means that they have already entered the heavenly Jerusalem. They can
shout with joy, She is our mother!” (IVPNTCS, emphasis his). Notwithstanding, if the present tense indicates
present experience, which is the most natural indication, and if Paul is thinking in terms of New Jerusalem, which
is the most logical deduction given the conceptual basis that was widely circulating in Paul’s day,218 then there is
no reason to think that Paul is not talking about believers entering the literal New Jerusalem in the present time
period as they die to depart and be with the Lord in 2Cor 5:1.
       Pfeiffer’s spiritualizing comments on Gal 4:26 to the contrary backfire: “This is a reference not to the future
New Jerusalem of the Apocalypse but to a present spiritual reality, the home of believers. This home answers to the

by commentators, then TWBCNT has short-circuited its own objection as to the present reference to New Jerusalem

              In these legends the Heavenly Jerusalem is the archetype of the good to come, which will be

       The objection posed by Gaebelein for interpreting 2Cor 5:1 in terms of New Jerusalem is based on the from
