       Heron’s assessment that Paul is referring to New Jerusalem in 2Cor 5:1 is adopted herein as a working
premise. His locating this City to the North is somewhat problematic. If the City is truly in another dimension, how
can it be located to the North of a planet in our dimension, especially if that City is in a dimension outside our solar
system? While I share Heron’s belief that the City is located to the North of our planet, I am not inclined to his
simplistic explanation. First, the North Star moves the least of the stars because it is almost directly in line with
Earth’s North Pole. However, if Earth’s axis was altered because of a cataclysmic event, then the North Star was
not in this relative position before that event. Even if that is not the case, Polaris has not always been at this location
due to the progression cycle of the Earth’s axis. Even worse, “The star Polaris, also known as the North Star and
the brightest star in Ursa Minor, happens to be the same Greek word Polaris, which also translates to Satan” (Toop,
KL 2232). Even so, for those acquainted with the prophecy in the stars and who believe that it pictures where the
Shepherd keeps His sheep, I will give a sympathetic ear. In any event, I do believe that the City was to the North of
Planet Rahab when Lucifer planned to ascend to it and set up his throne. My hypothesis, however, is that the 3D
pyramidal form of the City was in satellite position to the North of the Planet Rahab, while the 4D cubical shape of
the City was sitting on the solid ground atop (i.e., the north of) Planet Paradise. The City is a transdimensional
portal and quite capable of being in two places at the same time. Even in the 4D position outside our universe, I
would conjecture that it might be North of Planet Earth (being reached through that direction, cp. NDEs).
       Even if Paul is thinking about the Heavenly City, is there any reason to believe that he is thinking about it as
a reward in this context, thus a Reward City? Well, he is certainly thinking about rewards since he immediately
proceeds to say that our ambition should be to be pleasing to the Lord because of the Judgment Seat of Christ, which
is a potentially fearful event (2Cor 5:9-11), and he urges these believers to be reconciled to God as a result
(2Cor 5:20). Thus, given his misthopological views elsewhere, it would be out of character for him not to have
misthopological implications in mind here as well. In conclusion, Paul’s point is that the eternal building that we
faithful believers have from God as our home in the heavens when we die is New Jerusalem (2Cor 5:1-3,8).

                                                        Gal 4:26
       Although Gal 4:26 was addressed in part in the foregoing discussion, further background information will be
provided at this juncture to solidify the conclusion herein that Paul is referring to Heavenly Jerusalem in his writings.
In Gal 4:26, he refers to the Jerusalem above as being our mother. Willis states that “according to the Jewish
Talmud, the heavenly city is positioned directly above the earthly Jerusalem” (emphasis hers, 110). Dunn provides
background information from Jewish Scripture and Jewish apocalyptic writings and confirms that Paul jointly has
this biblical and extrabiblical background in mind regarding the Jerusalem above in Gal 4:26:

                 Here Paul clearly had in mind the strand of Jewish apocalyptic thought which presumed
         that there was a heavenly Jerusalem, that is, an ideal form of Jerusalem in the purpose of God,
         waiting, as it were, in heaven to be revealed at the end time, when God’s purpose would be completely
         fulfilled. This was obviously based on Exod. 25:9, 40 (cf. Wisd. Sol. 9:8), where Moses was told to
         construct the tabernacle in accordance with the pattern shown him on the mountain. Hence
         subsequently the explicit denial of 2 Baruch that Isa. 49:16 refers to the earthly Jerusalem:

               2 Bar. iv.2–6—Or do you think that this is the city of which I said: ‘On the palms of my
               hands I have carved you?’ (Isa. 49:16). It is not this building that is in your midst now;
               it is that which will be revealed, with me, that was already prepared from the
               moment that I decided to create Paradise. And I showed it to Adam before he sinned
               … After these things I showed it to my servant Abraham in the night between the
               portions of the victims. And again I showed it also to Moses on Mount Sinai when I
               showed him the likeness of the tabernacle and all its vessels. Behold, now it is preserved
               with me—as also Paradise (Charlesworth).



219
      Patrick Heron, The Nephilim and the Pyramid of the Apocalypse (New York, NY: Citadel Press, 2004), 200-202.

             Likewise 4 Ezra promises that ‘the city which now is not seen shall appear’ (7:26); ‘and Zion
      will come and be made manifest to all people, prepared and built, as you saw the mountain carved out
      without hands’ (13:36; cf. 8:52; 10:25–59). And Enoch speaks of his going ‘up to the highest heaven,

      vii.325–7; Schlier 222–3; Longenecker 214). The same apocalyptic schema is presupposed elsewhere
      in the NT, particularly in Hebrews (Heb. 8–10–8:5 explicitly citing Exod. 25:40; 11:10, 16; 12:22–3;
      13:10–14; cf. Philo, Som. ii.250) and Revelation (Rev. 3:12 [see on 2:9]; 21:1–3, 10–11, 22–7). The
      corollary of such a schema, particularly in apocalyptic thought, is that the present equivalent is an
      inadequate copy, provisional, awaiting eschatological transfiguration into or replacement by the
      intended ideal. Hebrews draws out that corollary at considerable length, and Paul does so here too in
      his own way. (Dunn, BNTC)

Longenecker likewise cites such sources and provides some additional OT references regarding the OT scriptural
background from which Paul had to draw:

              The idea of a “heavenly Jerusalem” (“the Jerusalem that is above”) has a rich Jewish
      background. The concept has to do with the culmination of God’s redemptive purposes in human
      history, the realization of God’s reign in its totality. As such, it is an eschatological concept that
      describes Jerusalem as it will be at the end of time, often in contrast to what the city is at present.
      References to a “heavenly Jerusalem” are to be found in embryonic form in the Jewish Scriptures (e.g.,
      Ps 87:3; Isa 54 [the opening verse of which Paul quotes in 4:27]; Ezek 40–48), in Jewish wisdom
      literature (e.g., Sir 36:13ff.; Tob 13), and in more developed form in the apocalyptic writings of Second
      Temple Judaism (cf. 1 Enoch 53.6; 90.28–29; 2 Enoch 55.2; Pss. Sol. 17:33; 4 Ezra 7:26; 8:52; 10:25–
      28; 2 Apoc. Bar. 4.2–6; 32.2; 59.4; also of relevance here are 1QM 12.1–2 and 4QShirShab, which
      speak of angelic ministry in a heavenly temple). The idea of a “heavenly Jerusalem” in contrast to the
      present Jerusalem appears a number of times in rabbinic literature as well (e.g., b. Ta˓an. 5a; b.Ḥag.
      12b; Gen. Rab. 55.7; 69.7; Num. Rab. 4.13; Midr. Pss. 30.1; 122.4; Cant. Rab. 3.10; 4.4; Pesiq. R.
      40.6), though without reflecting negatively on Judaism itself. This concept of a “heavenly” or “new”
      Jerusalem also epitomized the hopes of Jewish Christians, as in Heb 11:10, 14–16; 12:22; 13:14; and
      Rev 3:12; 21:2, where the full realization of God’s kingdom and Christ’s reign is set out in terms of a
      “heavenly” or “new” Jerusalem that was looked forward to by the patriarchs and is now experienced
      by Christians in inaugurated fashion. (Longenecker, WBC. Emphasis and insert his.)

George makes the astonishing claim that this rich Jewish background regarding New Jerusalem forms the outlook
for Paul’s entire theology:

             The concept of the heavenly Jerusalem, or the New Jerusalem, is deeply rooted in the Jewish
      apocalyptic tradition that forms the background of Paul’s entire theological outlook. After the
      Babylonians had destroyed the first temple in 586 B.C., the prophet Ezekiel envisioned the building of
      a new temple on a grand scale in the renovated city of Jerusalem (cf. Ezek 40–48). The New Testament
      also looks forward to the coming age in which the New Jerusalem will come down out of heaven from
      God, “prepared as a bride beautifully dressed for her husband” (Rev 21:2). (George, NAC)

Highlights from the cross-references provided from Dunn (BNTC) above include the Jewish belief that: (1) visual
appearances of New Jerusalem were made to Adam, Abraham, and Moses, (2) Earthly Jerusalem is a type
of the Heavenly Jerusalem; (3) this Heavenly City is now in existence and will appear eschatologically,
(4) Zion is built and yet represented by a mountain, (5) Moses wrote about this Heavenly City in the pattern
provided for the earthly tabernacle, (6) the Psalms refer to this Heavenly City in Ps 87:3, (7) Isaiah refers to
this Heavenly Jerusalem in Is 49:16 and 54:1ff. If Pauline misthology is the outgrowth of his underlying
misthopology, then George may indeed be correct that New Jerusalem forms the background for Paul’s entire
theology. Certainly, given Paul’s discussion surrounding New Jerusalem in Gal 4:26 and its extending until the end
of ch. 4, it probably finds repercussion in his discussion in his ch. 5, which begins with this solemn warning: “Indeed
I, Paul, say to you that if you become circumcised, Christ will profit you nothing” (Gal 5:2; NKJ). Then he tells
Chapter 4. New Jerusalem as Mount Zion                                                                      Page 133
them that, even if they don’t go that far, they already have fallen from grace and have been severed from Christ
(Gal 5:4) because of their legalistic mindset, which he had just described in ch. 4.
       To this point in my writings, I have been content with experiential and misthological explanations for these
warnings, noting that these legalistic believers were experientially fallen from grace and experientially estranged
from Christ in the present, and, if they did not correct the situation, Christ would not benefit them misthologically:
They would fail to inherit the kingdom misthologically (Gal 5:21) and reap misthological destruction (Gal 6:8). Yet
one has to wonder, given the OT misthopology and his own misthopological insinuations in Rom 11:26 and
Phil 3:20 and possibly 2Cor 5:1, plus the arguments by Dunn and Longenecker above, if Paul does not mean to
insinuate that Christ would not profit them misthopologically if they continue to live legalistically. Just as in
Rom 11:22 he warned believers about the possibility of being cut off from Christ in Zion, so here in Gal 5:4 he
warns believers about the possibility of being cut off from Christ in the Jerusalem above. Conceptually, both texts
seem to extend the experiential and misthological severance to a misthopological severance that applies to both the
present and the future. Legalistic believers are excluded from the Heavenly City in the present when they die and
will be excluded from the inside of the City in the future when they are judged. NT misthopology leads to this
conclusion. Pauline misthopology alludes to this conclusion. Paul could not be any more explicit at the time because,
as he acknowledges in 2Cor 12:2-4, he was under a gag order about the details of his trip to Paradise when he was
caught up to the third heaven. Nevertheless, given the information we are able to put together from other biblical
and extrabiblical sources and from his own writings, we must infer that Paul was aware of the misthopological
nature of the City and that his biblical, extrabiblical, and experiential knowledge of this Holy City did frame his
theology and is found in various forms of allusions in his writings. In some texts, his Zionistic references to the
Heavenly City are explicit, but the misthopological implications are only implied. He gives his readers enough clues
to connect the dots, but because of the gag order, he leaves it up to them to draw the necessary misthopological
connections. These connections are rightly said to be necessary because biblical misthology as a whole makes
misthopology a necessary inference. For those who have eyes to see, the footprints of misthopology have not passed
without trace through the Pauline corpus.
Secondary Pauline Zionistic Texts
      As I mentioned in DSAS, my friend James Hollandsworth informed me that, in his series of sermons through
Ephesians, he had taken a more misthological orientation about Ephesians than I had in TOD.220 At that point, I
informed him that I had also migrated to a more misthological viewpoint in that, in conjunction with Joseph Dillow,
I now perceived a misthological dimension to Eph 1:13-14. As demonstrated in DSAS, a soteriological-
misthological dualism is discernible in that text. Consequently, I would now be open to considering the possibility
of dualism in other texts in Ephesians. Whereas Hollandsworth might be more inclined to a singular misthological
perspective, I would presently be more inclined to a dualistic perspective.

                                                      Eph 1:1
         •   “Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, to the saints who are at Ephesus, and who are
             faithful in Christ Jesus.” The epistle is addressed to faithful believers with the word saints thus be
             understood in its typical OT fashion.
     For example, for reasons explained in TOD, I treated Eph 1:1 as an exclusively soteriological text and
translated pistos as believer in that verse and defined saints of Eph 1:1,18 as believers (cp. Eph 1:19). A
misthological understanding, however, would embrace the typical translation of pistos as faithful and define saints
as faithful believers. The epistle would thus be focused primarily on faithful believers. Duality would embrace both
perspectives and perceive the epistle as dealing with privileges that are freely available to all believers and
conditionally available to faithful believers. Hollandsworth’s sermons are available online and highly
recommended. For present purposes, I will mention some misthological possibilities for a few texts in Ephesians,
with the understanding that a dualistic option might be preferable in some cases.

                                                     Eph 1:3
         •   “Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us with every spiritual
             blessing in the Heavenly City in Christ” (TM).

220
    See https://www.sermonaudio.com/search.asp?sourceonly=true&currSection=sermonssource&keyword=tri-
city&subsetcat=series&subsetitem=Studies+in+Ephesians.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 134

        Although normally translated as heavenly places, contextual clues suggest that the Heavenly Mount Zion is
particularly in view. As noted above regarding Pfeiffer’s comments on Gal 4:26: “This home answers to the
‘heavenlies’ of Eph 1:3 and ‘the city of the living God’ of Heb 12:22” (TWBCNT). Salmond (EGTC) observes that
“not a few interpreters” see a connection with Phil 3:20. Unfortunately, however, few see the spatial connection
with Heavenly Jerusalem, though acknowledging the general spatial intent is not uncommon. For instance, Barth
(AYBC) says, “Since elsewhere in Ephesians the phrase “in the heavenlies” always denotes a location, a place is
probably meant in 1:3, also.” Keener (IVPBBCNT) provides a postmortem spatial intent: “Almost everyone in the
ancient world believed that the heavens had numerous levels (often three or seven), that different spiritual beings
(various kinds of angels, demons, stars, etc.) lived in different levels and that God or the purest spiritual beings
lived in the highest heaven. In much Jewish teaching, the spirits of the righteous would live with God there after
death.” Where do faithful believers go when they die? To live with God in His Heavenly City. Paul may indeed be
implicitly answering that question with this affirmation since it was a common association. Various commentators
acknowledge that it has a local sense. Some seem to combine heavenly locality/spatially with earthly experientiality.
For example, Hoehner (CBC) states, “The heavenly realms (traditionally, ‘heavenlies’) in classical Greek can refer
to the place where the gods dwell and from which they come.…It has a local sense, denoting the place where the
exalted Christ is and the place from which believers derive their spiritual blessings.” Chrysostom (NPNF) asserts
that “it is not upon earth” but refers to our citizenship in Heaven (Phil 3:20). Muddiman (BNTC) sees it as a spatial
term with contextually mystical implementation. Moule (CBSC) is better than most and says, “See Heb. 11:16. The
form of the adjective suggests not only a heavenly origin, or nature, but a heavenly locality.” By citing Heb 11:6,
he has associated this heavenly locality with the Heavenly City. To speak idiomatically, such comments are
perceiving a different part of the elephant. Paul will go on to assert that Christ “hyperspaced above all the heavens”
(Eph 4:10; TM), thus describing Christ’s spatial postmortem experience and associating it with the spatial
postmortem experience of believers (Eph 4:8). However, Christ’s ascension to the highest heaven does not put
believers out of touch with Christ until their deaths! We not only have a legal and positional association with Him
before then, we also have a living mystical experience with Him in the interim.

                                                   Eph 1:4
         •   He chose us in Him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless before
             Him.
       Hollandsworth argues that Eph 1:4 pertains to what we should be, not necessarily what we would be—holy
and blameless.221 Thus, he states that a practical rather than positional holiness and blamelessness are in view. In
TOD, I discussed should versus would. I allowed soteric-mistholic duality (also see POV). Similarly, Bond (GNTC)
says the verse could be talking about either positional or experiential holiness and blamelessness. Furthermore,
Bond clarifies that if it is experiential, then “Paul is thinking of the Judgment Seat of Christ (cf. Col 1:21-23).” In
other words, if it is experiential, then it is also misthological. Like Hollandsworth, Dillow prefers an experiential
should is intended (and notes the OT background for experiential blamelessness), but Dillow also adds that this
preference harmonizes with his understanding of Col 1:22 (Destiny, 728). In this case, an experiential-misthological
duality would be entailed. In TOD, I stated that if my soteric-mistholic dualistic approach to Eph 1:4 is too difficult
to maintain, then one could drop the dualism and simply adopt the misthological position, in which case Paul simply
is saying that God misthologically has chosen believers contingently (who are in Christ positionally) to be holy and
blameless before Him. In other words, the election in this verse would be limited to God’s purpose and intention
that we should be misthologically blameless at the Bema (but God has left the deciding vote up to believers, so to
speak, as explained in POV and noted by the contingency in Col 1:21-23). In short, God has chosen faithful believers
to be misthologically holy and blameless at the Bema.
       As explained in 4DF, Paul teaches misthological sanctification in a number of passages (Eph 1:4; 5:27;
Col 1:22-23; 2Tim 2:20-21). He also describes the misthological sinlessness of Christ’s Bride as “having no spot
or wrinkle or any such thing; but that she should be holy and blameless” (Eph 5:27), and Paul clearly indicates that
being presented in this manner is conditional for believers and is based on their performance (Col 1:22-23). Being
misthologically blameless is possible but only if we diligently persevere (1Cor 1:8; Eph 1:4; Phil 1:10; 2:14-15;

221
    James Hollandsworth, Christ Magnified: Glorifying Jesus by Your Life (USA: Holly Publishing, 2016), 10. Also
listen to “Chosen to Holiness.” At https://www.sermonaudio.com/saplayer/playpopup.asp?SID=821181829454.
Accessed 2/6/2022.
Chapter 4. New Jerusalem as Mount Zion                                                                        Page 135
Col 1:22-23; 1Thess 3:12-13; 5:23; 2Pet 3:14; Jude 1:24; Rev 14:4-5).
       The discussion of Eph 1:4 by Beal and Radmacher, on the other hand, is thoroughly disappointing. They opt
for an exclusively positional understanding, rejecting both an experiential and misthological understanding: “The
words holy and blameless’ do not refer to the Christian’s character. They have to do with the Christian’s standing
(or position)….The question of character or practice cannot enter, because no one has an acceptable
character….Certainly every believer will be blameless when presented to the Father in Heaven.”222
       Nonsense. I have discussed such passages at length, and so has Dillow. In the midst of his excellent extended
discussion, Dillow surmises: “The notion of being ‘blameless’ in the sense of being experientially righteous is
grounded in the Old Testament.. ‘Blameless’ never means perfectly blameless in the Bible” (Destiny, 365). In short,
Dillow denies that this blamelessness refers to absolute positional soteriological justification, stressing its
experiential nature in both the OT and NT instead. He may be correct. Then again, I am willing to allow the
possibility of a secondary positional soteriological sense via duality or triality. As to the latter, Lazar poses that
Eph 1:4 has a trilateral application via positional, experiential, and misthological implications. Strangely, Lazar
gives positive citation from Beal and Radmacher as to the positional intent, even though they wrongly argued for
an exclusively positional sense, but Lazar does better and proceeds to say that the verse is calling for “ethical
righteousness” with a “purpose related to rewards in the kingdom,” thereby adding the experiential and
misthological intents.223 If a positional sense is intended, it is secondary to the experiential and misthological sense.
The misthological sense of being blameless is particularly apparent in Col 1:21-23. However, this misthological
sense from the opening chapter of Colossians certainly informs the sense in which it is intended in the opening
chapter of Ephesians in that Paul exhorts the Colossians to read his sister epistle of Ephesians and the Ephesians to
read his sister epistle of Colossians (Col 4:16).
       In their jointly authored book, Should Christians Fear Outer Darkness?, Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig argue
that regardless of how carnal believers may be, Paul promises them that they will be blameless at the Bema, citing
1Cor 1:8 as proof. They treat this as a soteriological promise of eternal security, citing 1Thess 3:13 and 5:23-24 in
supposed support. What do they do with Col 1:21-23? Like an ostrich burying its head in the sand, they ignore it.
As to 1Thess 3:13 and 5:23-24, these are invocations, not unconditional promises. In fact, the conditional nature of
verse 13 is made apparent in verse 12: “Now may our Lord direct our way to you; and may the Lord cause you to
increase and abound in love for one another, and for all men, just as we also do for you; so that He may establish
your hearts unblameable in holiness before our God and Father at the coming of our Lord Jesus with all His saints”
(1Thess 3:11-13). Being misthologically blameless is conditioned on being experientially loving. As to
1Thess 5:23-24, the verses proceeding in 1Thess 5:14-22 make it clear that the sanctification and corresponding
misthological blamelessness of these believers are not unconditional but require their cooperation. As to 1Cor 1:8,
I have dealt with it at length in my writings (see FFG and CC). Indeed, Appendix 3 of CC is dedicated to the verse.
Dealing with this passage in the present discussion requires little more than noting the inconsistencies in the trite
argument made by Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig:

      God will no longer remember the believer’s sins (Ps. 103:12; Isa. 38:17; Micah 7:19; Heb. 8:12;
      10:17). Of course God is omniscient and does not forget sin, but this figure of speech indicates that He
      will not hold the believer’s sins against him for the purpose of condemning or punishing him. This is
      why Paul could promise to the carnal Corinthians that Christ “will also confirm you to the end, that
      you may be blameless in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ” (1 Cor. 1:8; cf. 1 Thess. 3:13; 5:23-24).
      This passage promises the eternal security of the believer (“confirm you to the end”), but it also literally
      says that believers will be confirmed “to the end blameless.” The italicized words, “that you may be,”
      are not in the Greek text. But if Christ will judge, condemn, and punish believers for their sins at His
      coming, how will believers be “blameless”? Instead, they would be blamable! The word for
      “blameless,” anegklētos, also means being above or beyond reproach (1 Tim. 3:10; Titus 1:6-7,
      NASB). If Christ will rebuke and punish believers for their sins at the Bema, then they will not be
      beyond reproach; they will be blamable. (Emphasis theirs, 225-226.)

       I have already responded to such arguments regarding forgiveness in my book 4D Forgiveness. In the
introduction therein, I stated that an ostrich serves as a good mascot for the opposing position because many of
those holding the opposing point of view regarding the Bema understand the gospel of grace correctly.
Nevertheless, they tend not to fear the Bema because they bury their heads in the sand when regarding the Bema’s
logical and biblical implications regarding the gospel of the kingdom.
                                Illustration 20. Bad Reasons Not to Fear the Bema




       Not every ostrich will offer all these excuses not to fear the Bema. Some may only offer one or two such
explanations. Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig, for instance, hold the top three positions. Regardless, none of these
reasons are legitimate reasons not to fear the Bema. Nevertheless, there are various degrees of truth to each of these
misperceptions. The kernel of truth is wrapped in deception, nonetheless, when such positions are used to justify
the supposition that believers do not need to fear the Bema.
       As I proceeded to note in the introduction of 4DF, perhaps the most common objection to the assertion that
the Bema is punitive is derived from the nature of soteriological forgiveness. Hence this response is listed at the top
of the list of erroneous reasons provided by the ostrich for not fearing the Bema. Supposedly, this judicial
forgiveness level of sins is so complete that it renders judicial punishment of sin impossible. Some passages
commonly cited in this capacity include: Ps 103:12; Is 38:17; 44:22; Micah 7:19; Col 2:13; Heb 8:12. Since the
forgiveness that saves us from Hell is judicial in nature, those of the ostrich persuasion insist we cannot need that
same type of forgiveness in other areas, such as the Bema. Because God already has forgiven us judicially at the
cross, we cannot be judged judicially at the Bema. Otherwise, they assert, double jeopardy would be involved. So,
they argue that after Christ already has paid the price for our judicial forgiveness, a judicial view of the Bema
wrongly would have us pay for our sins in this same judicial capacity yet again. Thus, a judicial understanding of
the Bema is impossible, in their opinion. The judgment of the believer cannot include the judgment of his or her
sins. We cannot be punished for our sin, so we cannot be punished for our sinful works. Forgiveness and
chastisement are familial rather than judicial (cp. 1Jn 1:9; Heb 12:6). Judicial forgiveness must be limited to the
soteriological dimension. Furthermore, since our sin and sin nature are removed completely in heaven, no need for
forgiveness or chastisement remains at the Bema. Like the rewards dispensed at the Olympian Games, which
supplies the historical backdrop, the Bema must exclusively be an awards podium, not a judgment seat where
punishments are rendered. Thus, this position can be appropriately labeled the awards-podium (AP) position.
       The AP position taken by Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig is refuted, among other things, by the fact that
misthological forgiveness is entailed in many such passages. See my 4DF for a book-length exposition. For present
purposes, it suffices to note that Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig acknowledge that carnal works are flammable
(1Cor 3:15) and poor workers are shameable (1Jn 2:28). Therefore, they are blamable. The Bema is no mere awards
podium. Losers were not called up onto the awards podiums at the Olympic Games to be shamed. However, losers
will be shamed and ashamed at the Judgment Seat of Christ (Mk 8:38; Lk 9:26). Therefore, one cannot simplistically
equate the Bema with an awards podium or deny that negative consequences for reprehensible behavior are not
imposed.224

                                                      Eph 1:5
         •   He predestined us to adoption as sons.
        Lazar (pp. 208-211) notes that the adoption as sons in the Roman world was for the purpose of obtaining the
inheritance (cp. Eph 1:11). Hollandsworth concurs with Lazar and further observes the adoption as mature sons
(huiothesia = huios [sons] + thesis/tithemi [placement]), as opposed to birth as children (teknon).225 Wuest
(WSGNT), likewise, states: “God takes a believing sinner, regenerates him, and by means of this makes him His
child (teknon (τεκνον), a born one). [See Rom 8:16-17a.] Then He takes this child and places him in a legal position
as an adult son (huios (υἱος)). [See Rom 8:17b.] We thus become joint-heirs with Christ, having been raised to a
civil status as adult sons, in which we become heirs of God, inheriting jointly with Christ all that He possesses as
an heir of God the Father by virtue of His Sonship and work on the Cross.” Paul is not referring to what we have
become by virtue of regeneration but what we may become by virtue of adoption in Eph 1:5 (and Rom 8:15, etc.).
Christ won His heirship by virtue of what He did on the cross. We win our co-heirship with Him by taking up our
cross (cp. Rom 8:15-17).
        As noted in DSAS, though I prefer the complexity of duality, such arguments for the simplicity of misthology
are well received. For instance, the possibility of a misthological adoption was entertained for Rom 8:23 in TOD.
Hollandsworth advances the misthological perception by adopting an exclusively misthological view of adoption
in all relevant passages (i.e., Rom 8:15,23; 9:4; Gal 4:5; Eph 1:5). His proposal of an exclusively misthological
perception regarding mature sons (huios) is certainly plausible. Furthermore, as explained in RBVGB, I now concur
with Hollandsworth that the adoption/sonship (huiothesia) in Rom 8:23 is an acknowledgment of our status as
mature sons (huios). This legal status as adult sons will be necessary for rulership. The redemption of our body in
Rom 8:23 occurs in relation to our misthological adoption as sons, but this redemption is not a misthological
affirmation.226 Paul is affirming that at the time believers soteriologically receive redeemed bodies via the
resurrection, the sons of God will experience their misthological adoption as sons and their transformation into
glorified bodies. Those believers who fail to qualify for misthological adoption will simply have
redeemed/resurrected bodies. As heirs of God, their unglorified-redeemed bodies will qualify them to live in the
kingdom, not to inherit it. Mature believers will qualify for misthological adoption as sons and thus for glorified
bodies.

                                                      Eph 1:18
         •    “I pray that the eyes of your heart may be enlightened, so that you may know what is the hope of His
             calling, what are the riches of the glory of His inheritance in the saints.”
       A misthological hope, calling, and inheritance are available for faithful believers. In DSAS, I advocated a
duality for Eph 1:14, stating that Govett’s interpretation of Eph 1:14 is on target in that he explains it in terms of
the duality of the inheritance: “There are two parts in the heritage of the believer. (1) The gift of the inheritance,
which is certain, and which is eternal....(2) ‘The reward of the inheritance,’ or the prize of the millennial
kingdom....It is citizenship in the heavenly city” (GOE, emphasis his).228 Similar arguments could be made regarding
Eph 1:18, concerning which Govett calls attention to the OT background in Dt 4:20, 9:26; 32:9, and to which
1Pet 2:9 should be added in association with Eph 1:14. The soteric-mistholic duality of 1Pet 2:9 was also
acknowledged in DSAS, deferring to the more extensive treatment in MMP3. Misthologically, the Lord inherits a
glorious Bride. The Lord not only inherits a people He can rule over, but also whom He can rule with. God is
glorified by having such a glorious Bride! Just as “the woman is the glory of man” (1Cor 11:7), the Bride is the
glory of Christ. Unfaithful believers will not be glorious (see RBVGB). Faithful believers will be glorious
(2Cor 4:17). The riches of the glory of God’s grace will be most beautifully displayed in the glory of the Bride and
Her Bridal City. Turner (NBC) remarks: “(‘By his grace I’m to be a prince, not a frog’) will transform them with
joy and love.” Using misthological imagery, I would point out that the Bride is to be a butterfly, not a caterpillar.
Wuest (WSGNT) says, “God’s inheritance is within the sphere of the saints. That is, the phrase ‘in the sphere of the
saints’ is definitive of the word ‘inheritance.’” Fine. Yet, in conjunction with Heb 11:8-10, we should note that the
spatial sphere in which the saints will experience this inheritance is the Heavenly City, which we might dub
Inheritance City.

                                                  Eph 1:20
         •    “Which He brought about in Christ, when He raised Him from the dead, and seated Him at His right
             hand in the Heavenly City” (TM).
       My specificity of City poses much greater spatial literality than that of Foulkes (TNTC, 1989), who asserts:
“Inevitably as the ascension and exaltation of Christ are referred to we have spatial imagery, but as Calvin puts it,
when it is said that he is lifted up to the Father’s right hand, ‘It does not mean any particular place, but the power
which the Father hath bestowed on Christ, that he may administer in his name the government of heaven and earth.’”
No particular place! Hardly! Paul specifically says that Christ sat at His right hand. Little deduction is needed to
determine that location. Although the expression in the heavenly is normally followed with the spatial gloss places,
the specificity of City is suggested by the specification that He is seated at the right hand of the Father, which would
be understood in that cultural context to be in the Heavenly City. The Lord Jesus being seated at the right hand of
His Lord Father goes back to a well-known Psalm associated with Zion: “The Lord says to my Lord: ‘Sit at My
right hand, until I make Thine enemies a footstool for Thy feet. The Lord will stretch forth Thy strong scepter from
Zion, saying, ‘Rule in the midst of Thine enemies’” (Ps 110:1-2). This OT background gives strong grounds for
associating Christ being seated at the right hand of the Father in heavenly Mount Zion. Ps 110:1 is the most quoted

is the capital from which this heavenly war is currently directed. Moreover, it has been and will be again the
principal Mothership from which the war will actively engage. This City is the hub of this spiritual war. Trying to
picture God’s involvement in this war without thinking of the Heavenly City is like trying to discuss WWI or WWII
with no thought of the USA or Washington DC! Just think of the American soldiers, not the American country or

warriors have no association with the Heavenly City.

                                                    Eph 2:6
         •   “[God] raised us up with Him, and seated us with Him in the Heavenly City, in Christ Jesus” (TM).
       The heavenly place where believers are seated with Christ is the Heavenly City. At the point of new birth, all
believers are presumptively and positionally seated with Christ in the Heavenly City. The positional seating gives
all believers the basis and potential for temporal victory. The presumptive seating gives all believers the
misthological hope of eschatological seating. Got Questions appropriately links Eph 2:6 with New Jerusalem and
applies it to all believers:

      If you believe that Jesus, the Son of God, died and rose again and have asked God to save you by His
      grace, then you are a citizen of the New Jerusalem. “God raised [you] up with Christ and seated [you]
      with him in the heavenly realms in Christ Jesus” (Ephesians 2:6). You have “an inheritance that can
      never perish, spoil or fade” (1 Peter 1:4).229 (Insert theirs.)

       This heavenly seating took place even when we were dead in our sins but made alive in Christ (Eph 2:5). In
other words, it occurred at the point of new birth. Christians do not have to wait until they overcome and become
mature to be seated with Christ in New Jerusalem. On the contrary, appropriating these truths is a means to obtaining
spiritual maturity. The positional seating provides the means for victory. The presumptive seating supplies the
motivation for victory. During a Sunday School Class discussion of Rev 3:11 hosted by Scott Crawford, our friend,
Douglas Berner, posed the possibility that those believers who are being warned about the possibility of losing their
crown may have been granted those crowns presumptively.230 So, I am indebted to Berner for this terminology. In
that particular passage, I would be inclined to see the matter dualistically. The Philadelphian believers were very
much in the running to retain the crown that they had been granted presumptively and had probably added additional
degrees of glory to it by their subsequent perseverance (cp. Rev 3:8-10).231 However, in Eph 2:5-6, Paul underscores
the presumptive nature of this misthological seating by specifying that it occurs at the point of regeneration. The
same presumptive misthological proposition can be made regarding various other potential rewards: heavenly
blessings (Eph 1:3), predestination to adoption as sons (Eph 1:5), predestined for an inheritance (Eph 1:11), hope
(Eph 1:18), riches (Eph 2:7), and citizenship (Eph 2:19), etc.

       Of course, Paul clarifies that the eschatological realization of such rewards is contingent upon post-regenerate
performance (e.g., Eph 5:5). Likewise, John stipulates that our being seated eschatologically with Christ on His
throne in His Heavenly City is conditioned on our works (cp. Rev 3:21). Nevertheless, in conjunction with my
proposals of a misthological age of accountability and misthological grace, I can pose that those believers who die
before they have a chance to mature misthologically will qualify not only for entrance into the Reward City but also
for some basic degree of regality.232 In contrast, those believers who fail to overcome and mature, despite having
had sufficient time and opportunity to do so, will be disqualified from all forms of regality and from any entrance
into the City.
        The perspective advanced in MMP4 was that at the point of their physical death, those believers who have
obeyed the Lord during their earthly lives are being taken to the Heavenly City and literally seated with Christ in
the heavenly places (cp. Eph 2:6). Being seated with Him is not merely a positional or spiritual truth but a literal
experience on the part of those faithful believers who have crossed over to the other side. Namely, they are with
Christ in the Heavenly City. The same conclusion can be allowed for those who die below the misthological age of
accountability.
       The objections might be raised that the adjective heavenly (epouranios) does not necessarily denote the
Heavenly City, and the expression in the heavenly certainly does not denote the Heavenly City in Eph 6:12. Both
objections are valid. Nevertheless, as usual, both the word and expression must be interpreted in its context. And
the previous reference in Eph 1:20 certainly suggests that the place being alluded to is where Christ is seated at the
right hand of the Father in the Heavenly City. Moreover, this is the adjective used to describe Heavenly Jerusalem
in Heb 12:22. Furthermore, as suggested above regarding Eph 1:20, we must picture Christ as directing this war
from the Heavenly City. Revelation gives the impression that this Heavenly Warship is very much involved in the
232
    In my writings, I presuppose a soteriological age of accountability and propose a misthological age of
accountability. RBVGB proposed misthological neutrality for certain cases. 4DF briefly dealt with some
complexities in this regard. DOLF posed a misthological age of accountability. Briefly, without repeating those
discussions here, I am adding auxiliary supporting considerations in the present discussion.
       Typologically, even those Jewish children below the age of accountability of twenty years old were not
expected to fight, yet they were expected to participate in the Promised Land if\when their parents crossed in and
achieved the victory, which suggests a misthological age of accountability. Furthermore, even their parents were
not disqualified from entering the Promised Land until they had tried the Lord ten times (Num 14:22). Additionally,
Mephibosheth was lame in both feet but allowed to dine at the king’s table for the sake of his father (2Sam 9:13-
14), which typologically suggests that believers who are lame (practically since birth) will be able to do the same.
At a minimum, they would have low-wattage glorious bodies, dwell in the City, and be able to eat the Tree of Life—
privileges that would normally be reserved for mature believers who fought the good fight and overcame their
adversities. Of course, God will decide who genuinely qualifies, because of personal misthological lameness, to
have such basic rewards, which would normally be reserved for those who qualified because of personal
misthological merit.
       Parabolically, the Lord stresses that those believers who are handed over for severe misthological
consequences and cast into the outer darkness are those who had a “long time” to prepare (Mt 24:48; 25:19). The
Lord would not have entrusted them with the talents and expected a large return the very next day. In the Parable
of the Sower, if you allow for the first soil to be soteriological or at least have intended soteriological application,
then a passage of at least a brief period of time is expected before the negative inditement is passed on the two
misthological soil types (Mt 13:18-23). Three years plus the extension of one year are allowed in the Parable of the
Vineyard-Keeper (Lk 13:7-9).
       Exegetically, in Col 1:12, we find that believers are already qualified for a misthological inheritance.
Evidently, believers are contingently pre-qualified for this and other rewards. This inheritance can be lost, just as
Esau lost his presumptive inheritance—his birthright (Heb 12:16). Esau did not earn it and then lose it. Rather, it
was a misthologically presumptive birthright that he forfeited because of his subsequent performance. Similarly, in
Rev 3:11, believers are told to “hold fast what you have, in order that no one take your crown.” While the argument
could be made that you have to reach a stage of maturity before you qualify for any crown, one might allow the
possibility that all believers are presumptively qualified for a basic crown and remain qualified until they disqualify
themselves after the age of misthological accountability by not having pressed on to maturity. Accordingly,
overcomers in Rev 3:5 are promised that their names will not be erased misthologically from the Book of Life.
Misthologically, their names may have been written presumptively in this book.
Chapter 4. New Jerusalem as Mount Zion                                                                        Page 141
spiritual war going on Earth. Is Christ not currently directing the heavenly warriors from this Heavenly City?
       In any event, in seeking to find the background for Paul’s thought, commentators note the obvious parallels
with extrabiblical and biblical data. Lincoln (WBC), for example, states:
      Greater light is shed on this notion by the motif, which was fairly widespread in apocalyptic writings,
      of the righteous entering into eschatological life and dominion and sitting on heavenly thrones…. In
      the NT itself this tradition is reflected in passages such as Matt 19:28, 1 Cor 6:2, or especially Rev 3:21,
      “He who conquers, I will grant him to sit with me on my throne, as I myself conquered and sat down
      with my Father on his throne” (cf. also 20:4). This tradition of a future role for the righteous and
      particularly the Rev 3:21 reference, where this is expressed in terms of being seated with Christ, only
      serve to highlight by contrast the fact that Eph 2:6 claims that this has already been accomplished for
      believers.

       This present position on thrones is positional/legal truth made real by their spiritual union with Christ via
appropriation for present spiritual victory, thus for experiential realization in a realized nikology. Faithful believers
are not literally seated on these thrones until after the Bema. This misthological realization of being seated on
thrones is still in the future. The future throne promise of Rev 3:21 is linked with the future City-promise via
Rev 3:12. Literally sitting on these thrones is an eschatological reward to be granted in the Reward City.
Nevertheless, as proven in MMP4, as a preliminary reward, faithful believers are currently residing in New
Jerusalem. Being with Christ in the Heavenly City is already being realized by faithful postmortem believers. As
demonstrated herein, Paul was not ignorant of these facts. Although Revelation was not yet written, the
misthological affirmations made within Revelation regarding the thrones and the City were not made in a vacuum.
Extrabiblical and biblical data would lead to an association of these thrones with the City. The most reasonable
proposition is that Paul is affirming both positional and spatial truth.
       All living believers are positionally seated with Christ, while some postmortem believers are currently
residing spatially with Christ—in the Heavenly City. Not until the Bema will this partially realized misthology be
fully realized by overcomers. The connection between this enthronement and our present heavenly citizenship in
Phil 3:20 is commonly noted by commentators (e.g., Frank-BECNT, Francis-TNTC 1989, Constable-TCENB).
This heavenly enthronement will be in the same place where our heavenly citizenship resides—Heavenly Jerusalem.
Even now, faithful believers, as they die, are becoming residents in this Heavenly City. Thus, this heavenly
citizenship is not merely positional. It is a realized misthology for those postmortem faithful believers already
residing there.

                                                     Eph 2:7
         •   In order that in the ages to come He might show the surpassing riches of His grace in kindness toward
             us in Christ Jesus.
        Because Govett is a kingdom exclusionist who wrongly limits rewards to the millennial kingdom age, he,
unfortunately, assumes that if Paul were thinking misthologically, he would have had to refer to a singular age. As
it is, because Paul refers to multiple ages, Govett (GOE) assumes that Paul is thinking of soteriological riches
bestowed freely on all believers in eternity. Hollandsworth, on the other hand, after expositing Eph 2:8-10, comes
back to Eph 2:7 and asserts that v.7 is talking about rewards, contextually bestowed on those believers who are
soteriologically saved apart from works (vv. 8-9) but who nevertheless perform the good works that God prepared
beforehand (v. 10).233 Several points can be made to support Hollandsworth’s exposition.
        First, these works which God prepared beforehand in v. 10 would obviously have a misthological impact on
the riches of God’s grace that will be bestowed in the ages to come. Biblical misthology in general and Pauline
theology, in particular, require that any association of God’s surpassing grace associated with works must be
misthological.
        Second, God misthologically preparing works beforehand (proetoimazo) goes hand in hand, contextually,
with God misthologically predestining (proorizo) working believers for misthological adoption as sons (Eph 1:5)
and misthologically predestining (proorizo) them an allotted misthological inheritance, according to His purpose
(Eph 1:11).

        Third, misthological grace is a common enough biblical theme, discussed at some length in FFG, wherein I
note:

               In fact, the same Pauline epistle which contains one of the most beloved verses in all the Bible
        concerning unmerited grace, namely Eph 2:2-9, concludes with a reference to misthological grace:
        “Grace be with all those who love our Lord Jesus Christ with a love incorruptible” (Eph 6:24). Here
        Paul pronounces a special blessing of grace upon those believers who already have been saved by
        grace. However, this extra dimension of grace from God is invoked for believers who love the Lord
        Jesus with an incorruptible love.234

        Fourth, because misthological grace is a well-established biblical motif, one cannot reasonably suppose that
soteriological grace would be the epitome of God’s grace. Misthological grace presupposes soteriological grace and
moves on beyond it to higher dimensions to show the full range of God’s grace. Logically, one would conclude that
this is the spectrum Paul would have in mind.
        Fifth, the explanatory gar (for) of Eph 2:8 is exegetically followed with the explanatory gar (for) of Eph 2:10,
both under Eph 2:7, to demonstrate that the superlative grace (of v. 7) moves beyond soteriological grace (of v. 8)
by means of the good works (of v. 10), thus resulting in surpassing misthological riches of grace (of v. 7).
                                 Illustration 21. Simplified Phrasing of Eph 2:7-10
        7
          In order that in the ages to come He might show the surpassing riches of His grace in kindness
        toward us in Christ Jesus.
              • 8 For [gar] by grace you have been saved through faith; and that not of yourselves, it is
                  the gift of God; 9 not as a result of works, that no one should boast.
              •   10
                     For [gar] we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God
                  prepared beforehand, that we should walk in them.

To elaborate on this grammatical rationale, the first gar provides soteriological grace (in v. 8) as foundational for
the superlative grace (of v. 7), but this superlative grace (of v. 7) surpasses the foundational grace (of v. 8) by means
of the good works introduced by the second gar (in v. 10). An if-then equation can be used for summation:
                             Soteriological grace + subsequent works ¹ surpassing grace.

        Sixth, the identical phrase riches of grace is used in Eph 1:7 for soteriological redemption and forgiveness.
However, the phrase is proceeded by the superlative huperballo in Eph 2:7, which is translated as exceeding (KJV
and NKJ) and surpassing (NAS). Comparatively, the grace in Eph 2:7 exceeds and surpasses the soteriological
grace of Eph 1:7. Therefore, the most reasonable deduction is that the grace in 2:7 is misthological, which naturally
is built upon yet exceeds soteriological grace.
        Seventh, this exceeding grace (huperballo charis) of Eph 2:7 is conceptually comparable to the misthological
mega grace (megas charis) found in Jam 4:6, which is awarded to the humble (see FFG).
        Eighth, the heavenly seating with Christ in Eph 2:6 is reasonably deduced to be in the Heavenly City. The
riches of grace in Eph 2:7 are thus implicitly associated with the Heavenly City. In short, Eph 2:7 is another text
that should be added to the list of texts for misthological grace. In this context, there is ample reason to infer that
this misthological grace is a misthopological grace being partially realized in the present age and awaiting full
realization in the ages to come.

    Indeed, the first reference to grace in the Bible is, “Noah found grace” (Gen 6:8). As noted in the next verse, the

       The only other occurrence of politeia in the NT occurs in a well-known incident regarding Paul: “So the
tribune came and said to him, ‘Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?’ And he said, ‘Yes.’ The tribune answered, ‘I
bought this citizenship [politeia] for a large sum.’ Paul said, ‘But I am a citizen by birth.’ So those who were about
to examine him withdrew from him immediately, and the tribune also was afraid, for he realized that Paul was a
Roman citizen and that he had bound him” (Acts 22:27-29; ESV). Paul was a natural Roman citizen by birth;
the commander had to buy the privilege. Likewise, Jews were naturally entitled to Heavenly Citizenship by
birth (and would realize that misthological citizenship by faith and obedience). Gentiles, on the other hand,
in the previous dispensation of the law, had no hope of misthological citizenship without first becoming
Jewish proselytes. In view of the historical Pauline background and the Pauline context, which is discussing
citizenship (see Eph 2:19), politeia should be rendered citizenship in Eph 2:12, not merely commonwealth, so as to
more clearly convey the connection to the English reader.235 Wiersbe says that the Gentiles were “without
citizenship. God called the Jews and built them into a nation. He gave them His laws and blessings. A Gentile could
enter the nation as a proselyte, but he was not born into that very special nation” (TBEC; emphasis his). Similarly,

members of the nation of Israel, but as a whole, the Gentiles had no part in what God planned to do in and through
Israel” (TCENB). In the previous dispensation, one did not have to become a Jew to be born again (one had merely
to believe in the Promised Redeemer for eternal life), but one had to become a Jew to qualify for citizenship in the
Heavenly City. After stressing the now, Gaebelein states, “The poor, miserable, naked beggar upon the dunghill,
the Gentile, is taken up to sit among princes and inherit the throne of Glory” (TAB). This realized misthology could
be taken literally. Postmortem Jewish and Gentile believers are now united as monarchs in the Heavenly City.
The mystery now revealed is misthological in scope: Gentiles can now qualify as fellow citizens of the
Heavenly City.

City, namely, the Heavenly Jerusalem.237 As Constable states: “Christians are also fellow citizens of heaven with

       Paul was not permitted to speak in any detail regarding this experience. He was placed under a gag order.

taken into the Heavenly Jerusalem, while unfaithful believers were given abodes outside of this Reward City in the
heavenly realm. This thesis was developed and explained in depth in MMP4. The following illustrations will suffice

         •   “For He delivered us from the domain of darkness, and transferred us to the kingdom of His beloved

       Some of my fellow misthologists object to my taking this verse as inferring to some form of an inaugurated
kingdom that is presently experienced and into which believers are presently transferred. They may be pleased to
note that if they take this verse in an exclusively misthopological sense, they can sidestep my taking it in a mystical
sense. Believers are currently and literally being transferred from the domain of darkness to the kingdom as
they die, with faithful believers being transferred to the Heavenly City. Paul alludes to this transfer more fully
in the sister epistle of Ephesians, referring in Eph 4:7-10 back to Ps 68:18. Thus, Col 1:13 could merely be an
allusion to this literal transfer to the heavenly realm. “The hope laid up for you in heaven” (Col 1:5) is, more
specifically, in the Heavenly City. The heavenly places for believers are literal places in Heaven (Eph 1:3,20; 2:6).
In addition to believers being transferred spatially from the domain of darkness into the heavenly realm when they
terminate, they are also transferred positionally (legally), presumptively, and ontologically when they become
regenerate.

exhorts us to fix “our eyes on Jesus…who…has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God” (Heb 12:2). WH

writers, we are to fix our minds on Heavenly Jerusalem and all the misthopological implications of that City.
The purpose of the present book is to help facilitate compliance with this repeated biblical mandate. During
the course of proofreading this section, a missionary emailed me and asked why I was producing a book on New
Jerusalem. I responded, “The theme of the Bible is the kingdom. New Jerusalem is its capital and thus should be a
principal point of focus in obeying Col 3:2 and explaining the outer darkness.”240 The missionary responded that he
had not thought of that implication. However, if such implications are not carefully considered, one might wonder
how serious can one’s claim be to be taking Col 3:2 earnestly.

NDE Confirmation of Misthopological Outer Darkness
       While I was in the process of writing this book, I received an email from someone who had visited my website
because she had heard the NDE testimony of Betty Cone regarding the outer darkness. As a result of this inquiry, I
listened to Cone’s testimony, which is available online.244 Cone had an NDE while in a five-day coma. She
describes going to Heaven as going to another planet, which is attested by others as well. Some people call it Planet
Heaven. In my books, I call it Planet Paradise (MMP4, MMP5). Cone sees the skyline of the City in the distance
(10:57), which is also consistent with the testimony of others. Cone says that she had not lived for Jesus but was
able to approach Jesus after eating fruit, which is plausible since they were outside the Heavenly City (and is a
detail attested by other NDErs). She had a pre-Bema life review, which is a common experience also attested
by other NDErs. In Cone’s NDE, Jesus tells her that she has to stop at the City gate, which is one huge pearl.
He informs her that she needs to go back, but He will let her decide whether to stay or return. She wants to
stay. He warns her not to come any closer because if she does, she will not be able to go back. She persists in
her desire to stay (which is again common in NDEs). Jesus then finally warns her that if she stays, “‘It won’t
be like you think,’ and He stretched His arm to His left and said, ‘because over here you will be in outer
darkness.’” She immediately wondered what He meant. Did He mean Hell? In reflecting back, she does not believe
that He meant Hell because what He had pointed at looked like a dark opening to what appeared to be outer
space. Also, since that time, after a lot of praying and reflecting on what had been revealed to her, she realized
that Jesus was telling her that she was going to lose her reward and still be in Heaven but in a less glorious
portion of it. Still, in her mind at that time, she did not know what He meant. And she knew that He knew she did
not know what He meant. She decided not to take chances and chose to return to Earth. (21:00-25:20)
       Her analysis is spot on with my conclusions. The outer darkness is often misidentified and associated with
Hell. However, the biblical outer darkness is a reward issue dealing with eternally secure children of God who miss
out on heavenly rewards because of their unfaithfulness. Those in the biblical outer darkness are still children of
God and loved as such. They are also still in the heavenly realm. However, they are excluded from New Jerusalem.
They do not experience the same degree of loving intimacy with the Lord Jesus that faithful believers experience
with Him. In MMP4, I concluded, from biblical analysis and by examining NDEs, that unfaithful believers are cast
into the outer darkness in the outer realm of Heaven (on other nearby planets in the heavenly realm) and will be

    In MMP4, I noted that NDErs will sometimes voice their opinion about the outer darkness, and their opinion is

passed outer darkness does not mean that this is the outer darkness to which Jesus referred in either Scripture or in

I cannot, on the basis of her testimony alone, rule out the possibility of planets in our outer space being the reference.
Notwithstanding, by her own testimony, Jesus refers to the outer darkness to which He is referring as being located
over here rather than located out there. In English grammar, here is used to describe things in the immediate space
around the speaker, whereas there is the opposite and is used to describe spaces away from the speaker. They are
standing outside the gate of the Heavenly City on Planet Heaven/Paradise when He gives this warning.
Accordingly, Jesus is indicating that the outer darkness to which He refers is close to the Heavenly City but
not on the same planet since the outer darkness to which He refers is accessed through adjoining outer space.

darkness to which Jesus refers in her NDE is on nearby planet-sized pieces of land accessed through outer
space. Since they are in the 3rd Heaven, this would be the outer space of the 3rd Heaven, and these planets
would be nearby planets in the 3rd Heaven.

                                                       Conclusion
        The association of New Jerusalem with Mount Zion is one reason that some interpreters believe that the City
is pyramidal and thus shaped like a mountain. Exegetes are divided on the issue. Similarly, some people who claim
to have been to New Jerusalem say that it is pyramidal; some say that it is cubical. Consequently, some interpreters
believe that it is both and attribute the discrepancy to its multiple dimensions. This dualistic approach is adopted
herein and used to formulate a hypothesis as to how this difference could be most readily perceived as a cubical
4D City from 4DOS and as a 3D pyramid from 3DOS. This option will be further developed in the next chapter.248
        The working model adopted herein is that the 3D Pyramidal City is migratory. In prehistoric times, the
3D Mountain City was located above Planet Rahab. The OT affirms that it was in the far north at that time.
Additionally, the OT uses extrabiblical imagery as a literary menu by which to express the City’s typology. In both
extrabiblical and biblical narratives, this Olympian City is the dwelling place of gods and goddesses. According to
the biblical account, the angels were the gods and goddesses who originally lived in this celestial Mountain City.
When Lucifer rebelled against this Satellite City, which was located above his planet at that time, his planet was
destroyed by a blast from this City. This was the death blow to the rogue forces in this civil war among the gods.
        The rogue gods and goddesses were expelled from the Olympian City. Thousands of years later, the Heavenly
City was opened to receive human overcomers at the time of Christ’s ascension. These new human residents, who
currently reside within the City in spiritual bodies, are in the process of becoming the divine inhabitants of the City.
As discussed in my RBVGB, glorified bodies are limited to overcomers. When these glorified humans receive
resurrected glorified bodies, they will be its new gods and goddesses. As will be discussed further in the next
chapter, the process will be complete when the transformation of these overcoming humans as gods and goddesses
is finished.
        As demonstrated in MSIH and confirmed in the present chapter, both angelic and human gods and goddesses
live in monogamous nonreproductive relationships within the Heavenly City, but angels do not commingle with
humans in these sexual relations. Fallen angels had to leave their heavenly state and estate to have reproductive sex
via commingling with human women, resulting in Nephilim hybrids.
        Heavenly Jerusalem was stationed as a celestial 3D pyramidal city/mountain above the terrestrial Earthly
Jerusalem in the past and will be again in the future, at which time Earthly Jerusalem will also sit elevated on a
mountain which makes the typology complete. Moreover, the Satellite City was probably accessed through ziggurat
stargates in the past and will be again in the future.
        Unfaithful believers will be cut off from both Heavenly Jerusalem and Earthly Jerusalem. Unfaithful
believers who have celestial bodies will live in a Celestial Outer Darkness on other planets in the third heaven. This
will be true of them both in their intermediate state (while they are in spiritual bodies) and in the eternal state (when
they have resurrected bodies). Unfaithful believers who have terrestrial bodies will live in a Terrestrial Outer

248
      See Illustration 45. , 170.
Chapter 4. New Jerusalem as Mount Zion                                                                       Page 155
Darkness on Earth and other planets in its solar system and universe. Most regrettably, unfaithful believers may
never qualify to see their heavenly Father’s face in person. After all, unfaithful believers residing in the outer
darkness will not have direct access to the Father who resides in the City. They will have to live with the eternal
regret of not having earned this privilege.249 Paul is quite conversant with OT and Jewish material that would lead

overtly, apparently because of a gag order that was in effect at least until the completion of the cannon with

testimony.

   Of course, my posing that the Father remains inside the City in 4DOS and 3DOS has nothing to do with His

localized presence to the throne inside the City does not curtail the exercise of His omnipresence from 7D space.
Of course, my interpretation takes such passages literally. Dillow, in contrast, takes Heb 12:14 merely
metaphorically:
      Without this holiness “no man will see the Lord” (Hebrews 12:14). To see the Lord means to
      fellowship with Him. Job, for example, said, “But now my eyes have seen you. (Job 42:5). The parallel
      is precise. As a result of divine discipline, Job came to “see” the Lord. The writer to the Hebrews,
      steeped in the Old Testament as he was, apparently had this passage in mind. (Destiny, 534; emphasis
      his.)
Actually, the numerous OT passages I cited in conjunction with Mt 5:8 are much more likely the OT parallels.
Seeing God’s face, and thus God, is a reward in such passages. Fellowship with God is a reward. Yet, this fellowship
entails literally seeing God. Even Job’s experience of seeing God in Job 42:5 had a literal component, as Hartley
(NICOT) observes:

      Job had a direct encounter with the living God and heard him speak clearly. Yahweh veiled himself
      in a tempest [Job 38:1], which resembles in many respects his appearance at Sinai (Exod. 19), so
      that Job was not consumed by his holiness. His presence, however, was so unmistakably real that Job
      could say now my eyes have seen you. His deepest longing—to behold his Redeemer with his own
      eyes—has been fulfilled (19:25–27). (Italics his.)

“The Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind” (Job 38:1). Contextually, Job refers to seeing a visible manifestation
of a veiled appearance of the Lord. Even more importantly, he knowledges that eschatologically, he will literally
see the Lord: “And as for me, I know that my Redeemer lives, and at the last He will take His stand on the earth.
Even after my skin is destroyed, yet from my flesh I shall see God; whom I myself shall behold, and whom my eyes
shall see and not another” (Job 19:25-27). Heb 12:14 has an eschatological dimension in a context pertaining to the
Heavenly City. Seeing God in this City is a reward. Since Dillow does not believe the City is literal, it makes sense
that he seeks for a nonliteral interpretation. Surprisingly, as discussed in MMP1, Lang does not believe the City is
literal either. Yet, he gives a strong defense for taking Heb 12:14 as a literal misthological limitation of seeing the
Lord. My approach is much more consistent. Literally seeing the Lord in the literal Reward City is a reward.

                    Chapter 5. New Jerusalem in Typology
                                                   Introduction
       In the previous chapter, mention was made that Jewish sources considered Moses’ tabernacle to be a pattern
for New Jerusalem, which is certainly a reasonable inference from Ex 25:9, 40, where Moses was told to construct
the tabernacle in accordance with the pattern shown him on the mountain. The tabernacle foreshadowed Ezekiel’s
temple, but that temple typologically pictures New Jerusalem. This chapter will explore some typological images
of New Jerusalem, thus linking the past with the future. The tabernacle-temple typology is a suitable place to start.
                                               Three-Level Typology
Tabernacle Typology
       For present purposes, observing the three main selections of the tabernacle suffices. And a summation using
popular Mormon terms will serve simply because I like their terms, though their three-kingdoms definitions should
be rejected as distortions of the biblical records. Correcting blurred distortions rather than rejecting feasible terms
is preferable.
                                   Illustration 29. Three-Sectioned Tabernacle




We can acknowledge that the Outer Court is telestial in that it represents the lowest degree of glory. Obviously, the
Holy Place would be a higher degree of glory, an intermediate degree of glory compared to the Holy of Holies,
which would be the highest degree of glory. One might even allow that the Holy Place is terrestrial, depending on
one’s frame of reference, and that the Holy of Holies is celestial, adopting a similar frame of reference. Quite
possibly, the tabernacle is intended to represent more than one truth typologically, depending upon the frame of
reference being considered.
Temple Typology
        An abbreviated adaptation from TOD will serve as a launching point. In Illustration 35 (p. 161), the arrows
denote avenues of entry. Before proceeding with illustrations from TOD, however, some new illustrations will be
interjected below to expand the treatment from TOD. Some topologists have long recognized that the Holy of Holies
of the tabernacle represents Heaven (Heb 9:24-26), where Jesus entered through the veil of His flesh when He made
atonement for us (Heb 9:1-10:20). More specifically, the Holy of Holies symbolizes where God resides. The
typological correlation between the perfect cube of the Holy of Holies and New Jerusalem certainly has not gone
unnoticed (1Kgs 6:20; 2Chron 3:8). Since the outer walls of Ezekiel’s three-tiered temple (Eze 41:6) become
progressively tiered (inward) as one moves up the levels, with only the base of the “most holy place” (i.e., Holy of
Holies) being square (Eze 41:4), some believe that the pyramidal shape of New Jerusalem is suggested (Eze 41:1ff).
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 158
                            Illustration 30. Ezekiel’s Temple Walls Widening Outward




        On the other hand, a dissenting point of view not discussed in TOD is that some believe that inner walls
become progressively tiered outward to reach the outer wall. The above print screen was taken from “Ezekiel
Temple Vision (2012)” at https://bibliaprints.com/free-bible-animations.250 It pictures the inner walls in Eze 41:7
as being stationary, with the three tiers widening out to the outward wall. The fade they do in their video for the
transition from the inner composition of the wall to its external three-story provides a splendid visualization.
        Conversely, if you take the tiers as widening out from the stationary outer wall to the inner wall, which was
the preferred approach taken in TOD, then inside the Most Holy Place would be tiered inward as one proceeds
upward. For example, Leslie (WBC), commenting on Eze 41:7, perceives a narrowing design as one moves up: “As
in Solomon’s temple (1 Kgs 6:6, 10), they were structurally differentiated from the holy temple itself, by building
the temple wall in a vertically narrowing design so that wooden beams, resting on the resultant ledges, supported
the two upper stories.”
         In any event, the Most Holy Place is not cubical, and it has three tiers between the inner and outer walls. Yet
the inner sanctuary of Solomon’s temple was certainly cubical, though his temple was also built as three stories
(1Kgs 6:6). Why the typological discrepancy/ambiguity as to the cubical versus pyramidal nature of the Most Holy
Place? Block (NICOT) acknowledges that Eze 41:7 is “extremely difficult to interpret.”251 Cooke (ICC) says, “The
text is barely translatable, and can only be restored by conjecture, with more or less probability.” My own conjecture
is that the ambiguity is purposeful. The City is cubical on the inside but pyramidal on the outside. The inner and
outer walls are transitional because they reflect the teleportational nature of the walls of the City. The walls have
the potential to transfer one from the outer 3D Pyramidal City to the internal 4D Cubicle City when used in a
teleportational capacity. Logistical reasons for proposing this solution will be noted as we proceed. For now, the

is possible through the Gizrah—the separate space surrounding both the Holy of Holies and the Holy Place.252 One
must enter these holy places through the Inner Court (which would be the northern hemisphere of the planet).
Beyond the Inner Court lies the (3) Outer Court (the southern hemisphere). To enter the Outer Court, one must
enter through either the North Gate or South Gate, after the Eastern Gate is shut up because the Lord enters through
it (Eze 44:1-3). Just as the Outer Court is part of the temple complex, the outer darkness is part of the kingdom.
This kingdom is entered by the new birth. The temple typologically represents:

       1. New Jerusalem as the Holy of Holies

       In the end, the temple’s three major compartments foreshadow three major divisions of humanity among

Some precedence for this concept of limited misthological grace may be derived from the account of the prodigal
son who was given a robe and a ring although he forfeited his inheritance (Lk 15:21-24). Other misthologists opine
that infants and those who die below the age of accountability may live in the Heavenly City on a provisional basis
currently, be resurrected at the beginning of the millennium, live in the millennial kingdom, become believers, die,
be resurrected a second time to stand before the Great White Throne to be judged misthologically, and then be
allowed to live in New Jerusalem if they were faithful during the millennium. This proposal has the advantage of
misthological consistency: Only believers who qualify misthologically by their works will be able to live in the
Reward City. However, in my opinion, this misthological consistency is offset by excessive misthological
complexity. I find it hard to believe that the infants who are reported to be currently living and growing up in New
Jerusalem would be required to go through the above gambit in order to return to New Jerusalem.254
       Broadly speaking, the second-highest privilege will be to live on Earth, denoted by the Holy Place. This
privilege will be given to faithful believers who live until the end of the millennial kingdom. In my assessment,
being faithful during the millennial kingdom does not qualify one to live in New Jerusalem. Believers during that
time will be able to walk by sight rather than by faith, thus not qualifying to live in the Reward City. Other
misthologists mentioned above opine that those who live faithfully during the millennial kingdom will qualify to
live in the Heavenly City. This assessment allows them to be consistent with their proposal that those who died
before the age of accountability and who were resurrected into mortal bodies to live during the millennium are
subsequently judged as worthy of living in the City. In subsequent advanced discussions herein, the partial
concession will be granted in that, for logistical reasons, the allowance will be made for the possibility that those
smortals255 who are faithful in the eternal state might eventually qualify for lower-level positions of authority as
second-tier elohim in other renditions of the 3D City. For now, though, we will continue with our walk-through of
some previous material.
