        As noted in TOD and MMP1, Becker has posed that unfaithful believers will live inside the New Jerusalem:
“Those who are born again by the Spirit but fail to hear God and obey will live inside the heavenly city but receive
no reward.”256 In my reconstruction of her model, presuming that believers currently are in the city as they await
judgment, her model would divide the city into three sections and limit subcomers to the lower one. In my mind,
this would have been equivalent to saying that the outer darkness is within the lower level. Becker, however, did
not make this association since she mistook the outer darkness for a soteriological theme. Moreover, she mistakenly
(or at least inconsistently) thought that unfaithful believers would be able to eat of the Tree of Life.
        As this misthological series has progressed, so has my understanding of the outer darkness. While initially
exploring various models, I considered equating the outer court with the outer darkness initially, until such time
when the unfaithful were subsequently expelled. That model was greatly improved by MMP4, in which it postulated
that unfaithful believers never live inside the City, always outside the City. This more recent assessment requires a
tweak regarding the typological correspondence between the City and temple supplied in the above illustration.
Becker cited visions of Heaven seen by the children in the Adullam Orphanage in the early 1900s and by Marvin
Ford in the early 1970s in support of the three-level view of New Jerusalem.257 I have interacted with those visions
in MMP4 and found them plausible. That part of the model is still retained. Others claim to have seen the three
levels in the City as well. Some supplement this conclusion with typological biblical material. Joyful Star, for
example, surmises: “The ark [of Noah] and Solomon’s temple were built with instructions from God. It is our
understanding that the City has three levels like three stories. Because Amos 9:6 says ‘It is He (Jehovah) that builds
His stories in the heavens.’ My dad saw the three levels, and I have seen two of them” (p. 75).
        Later, she notes that Scripture divides believers into three different groups on a variety of occasions:

                 In 1 Corinthians 15[:41] the Bible says there is one glory of [1] the sun, another glory of [2] the
         moon, and another glory of [3] the stars. It is the same way after the resurrection, when we receive our

         They that be wise shall shine as the brightness of the firmament; and they that turn many to

       The earlier examination of this quote from Ps 24 herein noted that Jesus divides believers into three groups
in the parable of the minas and talents, with the unfaithful slave being cast into the outer darkness (Mt 25:30),

City, dwelling in those courts should be limited to those believers misthologically chosen for this blessing, as Star
deduces, in part, from her partial quote of Ps 65:4.
       Star is correct in her summation regarding Ps 65:4 and its related texts. Nonetheless, the significance of
Ps 65:4 deserves full quotation and further exploration. The context addresses, “O God, in Zion” (Ps 65:1). The
courts of Ps 65:4 are located in Zion. They are associated with God’s house and holy temple, as seen from the full

             In David’s day, the Temple was not yet built. But it would be! David had been shown the plans

       Typologically, David foresees more than just the millennial temple, however. He sees Mount Zion as being
a place where those who are faithful among redeemed humanity will be able to dwell in the house of the Lord, the
heavenly Mount Zion. David looked forward to dwelling in this “house of the Lord forever” (Ps 23:6). (See LTPW.)
In such cases, the courts equate to both the inner and outer courts of the temple as being misthopologically
approachable and livable, equatable with New Jerusalem. Like Abraham, David was looking forward to this Reward
City and referred to it using plural courts. Therefore, the outer darkness must be outside these courts. Ps 65:4 is a
strong typological indicator that the outer darkness is completely outside the City. In binary terms, either you have
access to the City, or you do not. The courts picture the City. The outer darkness cannot be in the lower court of the
City. When the temple is used typologically of the City, the outer court must be part of that City. If you do not have
access to the courts of the City, then you are in the relative darkness outside the City. Temple typology is a
kaleidoscope with multiple vantage points to view various aspects of its beauty, a multifaceted diamond showing
different facets of its sparkling light.261 When seen through the vantage point of Ps 65:4, the outer court refers to a
part of the City, not to the outer darkness outside the City. The area outside the temple would picture the outer
darkness. Gaebelein (ABC) expands upon the millennial temple motif:

             The four next Psalms unfold prophetically the times of restitution of all things as spoken by
      the mouth of His holy Prophets since the world began. Here we get the visions of Israel’s restoration,
      her spiritual blessings and her praise unto the Lord, and what will be the result for the nations and for
      all creation. We recommend a careful study in details by comparing Scripture with Scripture. In this

        Gaebelein calls attention to the broader context of this Psalm in relation to the next three Psalms that follow

that follows it:

       During the millennial kingdom, the nations throughout the entire Earth will worship the Lord. Yet, obviously,
not all the nations of the Earth will dwell in the courts of the Lord in Mount Zion. The blessing of the millennial
increase will apply to all the nations who submit to the Lord’s rod-of-iron rule during the millennium. Those nations
who do not submit will perish, as David noted in his opening Psalm (Ps 2:8-12). The Terrestrial Outer Darkness
will be in this outer realm, away from the terrestrial Mount Zion and its typological counterpart, the Heavenly
Mount Zion. Only those misthologically chosen in Ps 65:4 will dwell in the Promised Land and Promised City, as
even some commentators have discerned, albeit with their typical inconsistencies:
              The Lord hears particularly the prayers of those whom he has “chosen” (cf. Dt 7:6–7; 14:2) and
      whom he has brought “near” to enjoy his presence. Who are they? They could be God’s priests (Nu
      16:5; Jer 30:21), but equally well they could be his covenantal people, to whom he granted the status
      of a royal priesthood (Ex 19:6). The Lord has promised to reward those who are especially devoted
      to him (cf. Pss 15[:1-11]; 24:3-4; Isa 33:15–16). Whoever is loyal to the Lord is blessed (cf. [Ps]
      1:1) with “good things” (cf. 23:6). God’s gifts include spiritual benefits (forgiveness of sins, v. [Ps
      65:]3) and the joys of life (vv. [Ps 65:]9–13). The elect enjoy God’s goodness in this life and in the
      life to come (EBC-VanGemeren)
       VanGemeren correctly associates being chosen in Ps 65:4 with the reward of being chosen in Ex 19:5-6.
Peter also talks about being the blessing of being misthological chosen in connection with this text in 1Pet 2:9.
Since these texts have been explored in detail elsewhere in my writings, simply noting the association in the present
treatment should suffice. Into the strong misthological context dealing with rewards, VanGemeren interjects a
reference to gifts for Ps 65:3,9-13. If he means to make the reward out to be a gift, then he is blatantly mistaken.
Even if that is not the case, then his interjection of a gift perspective for even these parts of this Psalm is suspect.
While God does water the Earth in Ps 65:9, He withholds rain from those nations who do not submit to His rule of
iron during the millennium. Even forgiveness need not be assumed to be a gift. The forgiveness in Ps 103:12-18,
for example, is a reward. Yet, in commenting on this passage, VanGemeren asserts, “Forgiveness is a gift.” Not so!
Read the passage for yourself and see that VanGemeren is mistaken. The forgiveness in Ps 103:12-18 is a reward
for those of God’s children who fear Him by keeping His commandments. See 4DF for my misthological exposition.
Notwithstanding, since I hold a dual soteric-mistholic view regarding being chosen in 1Pet 2:9 (see DSAS), I would
allow the possibility of such a duality to forgiveness in Ps 64:3. Even if one insists on viewing forgiveness in this
verse as a gift, it lays the foundation for the reward in Ps 64:4. The gift lays the foundation for the reward but must
not be confused with the reward. Being chosen to dwell in the courts of God’s house in Zion is a reward limited to
those who have received the gift dimension of forgiveness and then have moved on to obtain the misthological
dimension of forgiveness. The foundation must not be confused with the building upon it, a biblical principle with
which we should all be familiar (1Cor 3:11-15). To use another metaphor, the Lord says, “Heaven is My throne,
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                 Page 168
and the earth is My footstool” (Is 66:1). Do not confuse the throne with the footstool. Do not confuse Heaven with
Earth. God’s heavenly throne will always be above Earth. Davidic temple typology clarifies that the soteric benefit
of being able to live on Earth in the outer darkness is not equated with dwelling with God on Mount Zion. As noted,
Gaebelein says that these four chapters in Psalm, chs. 65-69, deal prophetically with the times of restitution. Ps 68
proceeds to describe “God in His holy habitation” (Ps 68:2), which we know to be the heavenly Mount Zion, referred
to in Ps 68:16 as the mountain which God has desired for His abode where the Lord will dwell forever (cp. Ps 125:1;
146:10; Is 24:23; Micah 4:7). The fact that not everybody on Earth is going to dwell in this City was obvious to the
Psalmist.
              Illustration 40. Three-Sectioned Temple Dualistically Compared to Outer Darkness




       Considering the typological significance of texts such as Ps 65:4, when the outer court of the temple is
typologically associated with the outer darkness, the temple must not be limited typologically to the City. Rather,
in that case, in this zoomed-out view of the typology, the typological association should limit the association with
the City to the Holy of Holies. When the Holy of Holies is typologically equated with Jerusalem, it would
dualistically picture 3D Terrestrial Jerusalem (on the left) and 4D Celestial Jerusalem (on the right), probably tying
these together with my hypothesis that the 3D City suspended above the Earth serves as a portal to the 4D Celestial
City on Planet Paradise. The inner court would equate to the Promised Land on Earth (as pictured on the left) and
to Planet Paradise in the heavenly dimension (as pictured on the right). The outer court would picture the Terrestrial
Outer Darkness (as pictured on the left) and the Celestial Outer Darkness (on the right). In this correspondence, the
outer court pictures the outer darkness as being the nations of the Earth, thus the outer darkness as outside both the
Promised City and Promised Land.
Ark Typology
       Noah’s Ark also factors into a three-level typology. Noah found misthological grace in the sight of the Lord
(Gen 6:8) based on his practical righteousness (Gen 6:9; cp. 7:1). To draw upon a discussion from FFG, this popular
text clashes with the popular definition of grace as unmerited favor: “But Noah found favor [i.e., grace] in the eyes
of the Lord. These are the records of the generations of Noah. Noah was a righteous man, blameless in his time;
Noah walked with God” (Gen 6:8-9). The implication is that Noah found grace because he was righteous in his
walk with God. Likewise, Peter informs believers that they can find grace if they live right: “But if when you do
what is right and suffer for it you patiently endure it, this finds favor [= grace] with God” (1Pet 2:20). The OT
gives a similar pronouncement: “The Lord gives [didomi] grace and glory; no good thing does He withhold from
those who walk uprightly” (Ps 84:11). Those who walk uprightly are rewarded with grace and glory. They are given
grace as their payment:

       •   Grace is their reward.
       •   Grace is God’s favor.

      These two statements are not contradictory. Whether God’s grace/favor is earned or unearned is dependent
Chapter 5. New Jerusalem in the Typology                                                                      Page 169
on the context. The key is to note whether grace is the result that is given or the basis for what is given. In the
example provided by Peter, God’s favor is the reward for morally upright behavior. Peter informs us that believers
can still find grace today, just as Noah did in his day, by doing what is right, that is, as a result of practical
righteousness. Believers who are righteous in this manner find grace because they are righteous in their behavior.
The point in these texts is not that they were made righteous by grace, but rather they found grace by being righteous.
Practical righteousness rather than positional righteousness is in view. See FFG for more discussion along that line.
       The salvation in the Ark was misthological, not merely physical: “By faith Noah, being warned by God
concerning events as yet unseen, in reverent fear constructed an Ark for the saving of his household. By this he
condemned the world and became an heir of the righteousness that comes by faith” (Heb 11:7).262 His righteous
action, based on his faith in God’s misthological nature (Heb 11:6), resulted in him becoming a misthological heir
due to his practical righteousness. This passage is not referring to forensic righteousness.
       Noah’s works-based practical righteousness, coming from a faith-based misthology, resulted in his becoming
a misthological heir. In the very next verse, after using Noah as an illustration, WH uses Abraham to exemplify the
same truth, saying that Abraham also was qualified for an inheritance by his obedience in going out and doing the
Lord’s will in leaving Ur (Heb 11:8). Moreover, Abraham was looking for the Heavenly City (Heb 11:10).
       The entire Hall of Faith passage, concerning these OT believers and comprising Heb 11, is not presenting
faith as the means of escaping eternal damnation but of saving the soul. The chapter begins in Heb 11:1 with
reference to faith as being the assurance of things hoped for, which immediately takes the reader back to the last
verse of the previous chapter concerning the necessity of persevering faith for the preservation of the soul
(Heb 10:39). WH explicitly summarizes chapter eleven by saying, “And all these, having gained approval through
their faith, did not receive what was promised” (Heb 11:39). What was it that they were promised but had not yet
received at that time? The Reward City.
       Righteousness in Heb 11 is not given as a gift but earned by giving gifts/sacrifices to God (Heb 11:4). The
faith in this passage is explicitly one that believes God will reward those who seek Him (Heb 11:6). The chapter
specifically mentions rewards (Heb 11:6,26), heirship (Heb 11:7), inheritance (Heb 11:8), co-heirship (Heb 11:9),
and being tortured in order to attain a better resurrection (Heb 11:35). This chapter is misthological in scope. In
fact, Constable rightly observes, on the basis of Heb 11, that the misthological emphasis of this entire epistle is
eschatological: “This chapter is one of the strongest proofs that eschatological reward is the full inheritance (rest)
that the writer urged his readers not to sacrifice. The reward of these saints in the past lay beyond the grave.”263 The
rest introduced in Heb 3:11 is explained in ch. 11. It is an eschatological rest.
       Star is correct to associate the Ark with the City, noting that the Ark has three decks: “You shall make a
window for the ark, and finish it to a cubit from the top; and set the door of the ark in the side of it; you shall make
it with lower, second, and third decks” (Gen 6:16). Both the Ark and City have three levels, and both are
misthological. In my estimation, the City was suspended above the Earth, where Noah could see it until the end of
the Flood. Then God removed this heavenly warship and replaced it with a bow hung in such a way to denote peace.
Some theorists place the destruction of Planet Rahab at this time, while others place it earlier, at the Luciferian flood
when Lucifer was cast from the City, which is the model adopted in the present book.




262
    Noah physically saved his family by means of the Ark. Yet, in Heb 11:7, this physical salvation was a means to
a misthological end, to become a misthological heir. Therefore, the underlying type of salvation is physical, but it
is secondarily misthological. Similarly, in 1Pet 3:20-21, Noah worked to save his family physically, and this
typologically becomes a picture of being saved now, in the present, in progressive sanctification. Biblically, this
salvation is expected to be seen from multiple vantage points. In each of these cases, salvation by works is entailed.
Faith was working with his works to produce physical, temporal, and misthological salvation. Salvation by means
of the Ark was not intended to picture soteriological salvation. Noah built an ark to save his household. A whole lot
of work, his work, went into it. Noah’s work saved eight persons/souls (1Pet 3:20; KJV). This physical salvation
of eight persons (NAS) pictures the misthological salvation of eight souls (KJV). This salvation of the soul is
dualistically physical and misthological.

    Constable, Hebrews, 96.

       Some would take the misthological nature of the Ark and this salvation to be an argument for a partial rapture
in which only faithful believers are raptured. I do not. See my DFS for my argument for a full rapture. Nevertheless,
I would allow that there were other believers on Earth when God sent the Flood, and they were killed. This need
not be pressed to indicate a partial rapture. For one thing, the Flood killed everyone on Earth. Everyone on Earth
will not die at the rapture, regardless of whether the rapture is full or partial. The details need not be pressed that
far. The NAS translation might be misunderstood or misleading when it inserts alone in its translation, “Then the
Lord said to Noah, ‘Enter the ark, you and all your household; for you [singular] alone I have seen to be righteous
before Me in this time’” (Gen 7:1). This insertion might be taken to mean that Noah was the only righteous person
on Earth. But that does not compute either soteriologically or misthologically. Other members of his family enter
the Ark. Surely, they were righteous, to varying degrees. Other translations leave out alone and render it as talking
Chapter 5. New Jerusalem in the Typology                                                                      Page 171
about generation(s): “You are righteous before Me in this generation” (KJV), or even plural generations: “perfect
in his generations” (Gen 6:9; KJV). Some take this affirmation as a reference to the genetic purity of his DNA. I
share that perspective, but moral purity is also included. Nonetheless, one need not suppose that Noah was alone in
this state. Nor need one conclude that Ham’s wife was completely pure morally and genetically. The NAS probably
injects alone in Gen 6:9 to indicate that God uses the singular form of the verb. God did not include Noah’s family
in this statement. I suspect that Ham’s wife was morally and genetically compromised (see MSIH). She might be
taken as a picture of Lot’s wife. Typologically, she was saved soteriologically but not misthologically. Similarly,
at the rapture, all believers will be caught up to the Bema atop the Heavenly City. Yet only morally righteous
believers will pass the test and be able to reside in the City.
        Keith Call, a friend of mine, inquired: “Marty, do you think there are legitimate comparisons to be made
between Noah’s Ark and the New Jerusalem? Does Noah’s Ark typify or prefigure the Reward City? Both contain
a narrow selection of humans, and both are elevated above the earth.”264 I responded affirmatively. I had advocated
a misthological take on the Ark in my book Salvation, though that book was not yet published. Indeed, we could
dub the City—Ark City—to underscore the typological connection with Noah’s Ark. Keith’s points about selection
and elevation are plausible. If other believers on Earth were not taken into the Ark, as I believe is probable, then the
limited selection could indicate a misthological election. In that case, one could very well take elevation above the
Earth as typologically pointing to the City, which was likely stationed above the Earth at that time. The Earth below
would be a terrestrial picture of the outer darkness. Jointly, then, the City above the Earth would picture a three-
level typology of the City with a two-level typology compared to Earth. Revisiting Illustration 39. Three-Sectioned
Temple Compared to the City and Illustration 41. Three-Sectioned Temple Dualistically Compared to Outer
Darkness from this vantage point would yield a bird’s eye, two-level typology.

other more detailed typological vantage points. As seen from the temple typology, the implication of the typology
can vary according to the frame of reference and be intended to apply to multiple vantage points. Indeed, temple
typology is also applicable to human trichotomy. Temple typology is a kaleidoscope that allows one to see beauty
in multiple, colorful, three-level patterns and even in two-level patterns. The same is true of Ark typology.

                                              Typological Apposition
       Some typological illustrations focus on two levels to provide a sharp, simplified, binary typological contrast.
Mount Sinai is one such case in point. In a section entitled “The Mt. Sinai Connection,” Willis explains the
typological connection between the earthly Mount Sinai and the heavenly Mount Zion by means of Ezekiel’s Holy
Allotment and the location of Earthly Jerusalem in that allotment. She reduces the size of the heavenly New
Jerusalem so that she can place the City on Earth and equate it with Earthly Jerusalem in Ezekiel’s Holy Allotment.
Doing so enables her to make a direct connection between Mount Sinai and Mount Zion.265 One need not make this
reduction in size, however, to appreciate the obvious deduction of the connection between the earthly Mount Sinai
and heavenly Mount Zion. Typology allows the earthly Mount Sinai to be contrasted directly with the heavenly
Mount Zion without putting the latter on Earth and without equating the heavenly Mount Zion with Ezekiel’s
location of the Earthly Jerusalem. Even so, her discussion is especially commendable if her equation of John’s
vision of Heavenly City with the earthly city is removed:
               The case for a pyramid-shaped New Jerusalem gets even stronger when we look at a key
        prophecy in the book of Exodus. While the Israelites were rejoicing immediately after the Red Sea
        crossing, Moses foretold that God would bring them to a specially designated mountain.
               “You will bring them and plant them in the mountain of Your inheritance, the place, O
               LORD, which You have made for Your dwelling, the sanctuary, O Lord, which Your
               hands have established. The LORD shall reign forever and ever.” Exodus 15:17-18
                The reference to God’s permanent reign is a clue that this prophecy will have a near/far
        fulfillment. The Israelite encampment around Mount Sinai where Moses received the Ten
        Commandments would be just a first taste of the future. God’s presence was manifested by the cloud
        and fire at the top of Mount Sinai (Exodus 24:16-17). Only a chosen few were allowed to go up into
        His presence. Most were not even allowed to touch the mountain, for God had said, “Set bounds
        about the mountain and consecrate it” (Exodus 19:23). It is important to note the overall layout of
        Mount Sinai. The tent dwellings of the Israelites were at its base, and eventually the worship center or
        Tabernacle was in the midst of those dwellings. The tents of the Levites, the priestly tribe, had the
        privilege of being the closest, surrounding the Tabernacle. This entire configuration was a
        foreshadowing of the future. In other words, one unique mountain would be a picture of another
        unique mountain.
                Later on when the Israelites arrived in the Promised Land, their dwellings and their worship
        center, the temple, was located upon the natural heights of Jerusalem. However, the picture of Sinai
        pointed beyond this, toward something that has not yet been fulfilled.…Someday, God will dwell in
        the mountain of [His] inheritance where He will reign forever and ever (Exodus 15:17-18). God
        will live in that mountain and rule and reign from that location.
                When we add the details from John’s vision of the New Jerusalem, the harmony is amazing….
        access to it will be restricted to immortals, John tells us, “nothing unclean, and no one who practices
        abomination and lying, shall ever come into it, but only those whose names are written in the Lamb’s
        book of life” (Revelation 21:27). John even tells us that though the twelve gates are always open, an
        angel guards each gate (Revelation 21:12, 25)….
                The New Testament confirms this connection, making direct comparisons between Mount Sinai
        and the New Jerusalem both in Galatians 4:25 and in Hebrews 12:18-29. This later section discusses
        the similarities and differences in great detail, with the implication that the New Jerusalem will

       Willis does well to suggest that immortals live inside the City while mortals are excluded and live outside

Mount Sinai is juxtaposed directly with the heavenly Mount Zion in a black-and-white binary fashion. Paul uses a
binary juxtaposition when he contrasts the earthly Mount Sinai with the heavenly Mount Zion in his allegory
(Gal 4:24-26). Willis’ typology likewise would be better served by a binary juxtaposition. After all, she cites

City, John concludes: “Nothing unclean and no one who practices abomination and lying, shall ever come into it,

       10

The boundaries are set up to exclude God’s consecrated people from going up on the mountain. The boundaries
create a gap between them and the mountain. Their washing evidently prefigures a soteriological cleansing since it
results in them having clean garments but fails to qualify them for being worthy to touch the mountain.

      14

       The passage is a misthological warning to believers not to come short of God’s misthological grace, which
grants the reward of the inherited blessing to those believers who are not misthologically defiled. Soteriologically,
they already “have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all” (Heb 10:10). The
Lord “has perfected for all time those who are sanctified” (Heb 10:14). This soteriological sanctification is not at
stake. It is a finished fact with permanent results. The sanctification to be pursued in Heb 12:14, on the other hand,
is necessary to see God in His holy mountain. This privilege is limited to those believers who go beyond
soteriological sanctification and perfection (pertaining to the perfect cleansing by the Lamb’s blood) to attain the
misthological sanctification and perfection (regarding the Heavenly Jerusalem) by following the will of the Lord.

       Mount Sinai is used for a typological juxtaposition in relation to Mount Bashan. Heiser says, “Bashan is the

passage under discussion comes from that last Psalm in the group of four Psalms with which we have been
interacting above from Psalms 65-68.
      15 A mountain of gods and goddesses is the mountain of Bashan; a mountain of many peaks is the

not specified in Dt 33:2 and is debatable in Ps 68:17. Preferring a mediating translational option in Ps 68:17, I would

Christ’s descent and ascent—His burial, descent into Hades, resurrection, and ascension into Heaven. Heiser
believes v. 18 indicates that at that point in time, Christ led “a train of captives down from the mountain [Bashan]
(v. 18)” (p. 292). I believe that at His death, Christ descended and defeated satanic forces (or defeated and
descended) and then led forth the OT believers as the triumphant spoils out of Hades. A mediating view is possible,
even plausible.

pose that Moses was using some sort of unknown alchemical burning of the gold at some extreme heat beyond its

at face value: “The sequence of burn-grind-scatter-eat is also found in a Ugaritic text to indicate total destruction of

follow—‘grounded to powder’; the powder of malleable metals can be ground so fine as to resemble dust from the
wings of a moth or butterfly; and these dust particles will float in water for hours, and in a running stream for days.
These operations of grinding were intended to show contempt for such worthless gods” (JFBBC). “Burning,
grinding, and scattering were actions commonly employed in the ancient world to get rid of an idol permanently so
that it could never be reconstituted from its scavenged elements and be thought again worthy of worship” (EBC).

be unlikely to refer to the stone called sapphire in modern times, as sapphire had a different meaning, and wasn’t
even mined, before the Roman era” (MSBW). My supernatural explanation for God speaking from the mountain
and their eating with God on the mountain is better suited for taking the text at face value.

Eden

                                                  Deductive Typology
        The Garden of Eden is another example of binary misthopological typology. Certainly, one can easily see
that the Garden of Eden would represent the Heavenly City. Being cast out of the garden would represent being cast
out of the City. Just as Lucifer was cast out of the Heavenly City (i.e., the Emerald Eden, the Garden City) after his
fall, so Adam and Eve were cast from the Garden of Eden after their fall. A correlative connection exists, not a
soteric equation.
                              Illustration 46. Correlative Expulsion from the Garden




       The part of the above illustration on the left is adapted from my book, TOD. At that time, I posed that Lucifer

(MMP5), I pose that Lucifer was cast down to Planet Rahab, as his Terrestrial Outer Darkness (TOD). Regardless
of which model is preferred, the broad strokes of the picture painted by Scripture strongly suggest a correlation
between the three major locations.
       The fallen angelic sons of God were cast out of the Heavenly City to the planet below, representing expulsion
into their Terrestrial Outer Darkness (TOD). Whether that planet is Rahab or Earth is immaterial to the overall
typological correlation. Regenerate human sons of God who live until the end of the tribulation likewise could be
cast out of the Bema atop the Heavenly City to this Earth, representing expulsion into their Terrestrial Outer
Darkness (TOD).274 Eventually, the fallen angelic sons of God will be sent to the Lake of Fire, which is their
soteriological outer darkness (SOD). At the end of the millennium, unfaithful regenerate sons of God will be sent
to the Celestial Outer Darkness (COD).
       The soteric expulsion of angelic sons of God provides a prototype for the mistholic expulsion of regenerate
sons of God. Correlatively, what will happen to disobedient Christians shares a point of commonality with what has
happened, and will happen, to fallen angels. The fallen angels were cast out of the Heavenly City to the planet below
and eventually will be cast into the Lake of Fire. Fallen believers likewise will be cast out of the Heavenly City to

       For Lucifer, the Lake of Fire was prepared to be his dwelling as a result of his fall: “Then He will also say to
those on His left, ‘Depart from Me, accursed ones, into the eternal fire which has been prepared for the devil and
his angels” (Mt 25:41). Although unredeemed humanity will also be cast into this eternal fire, this is not applicable
to Adam and Eve. For the unredeemed, a soteriological exclusion is entailed. For Adam and Eve, a misthological
exclusion is detailed. The Garden of Eden is highly instructive in this regard.
                                 Illustration 47. Expulsion from Garden of Eden




       Many artistic representations of the expulsion of Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden wrongly show
them as naked or holding fig leaves. Others do better by showing them clothed, at least in cloth, but even this is a
misrepresentation. The biblical sequence and clothing are clear. They were clothed with animal skins before being
cast outside the garden:
      21
         And the Lord God made garments of skin for Adam and his wife, and clothed them. 22 Then
      the Lord God said, “Behold, the man has become like one of Us, knowing good and evil; and now, lest
      he stretch out his hand, and take also from the tree of life, and eat, and live forever”—23 therefore the
      Lord God sent him out from the garden of Eden, to cultivate the ground from which he was taken.
      24
         So He cast the man out; and at the east of the garden of Eden He stationed the cherubim, and the
      flaming sword which turned every direction, to guard the way to the tree of life.275 (Gen 3:21-24; TM)

275
   The LXX (OT Greek text) uses ekballo: “And he cast out Adam and caused him to dwell over against the garden
of Delight, and stationed the cherubs and the fiery sword that turns about to keep the way of the tree of life” (Gen
3:24; LXE). Adam and Eve were cast out of and away from the Garden of Eden. Their expulsion out of/from
prefigures the expulsion of unfaithful believers out of/from the Promised Land and New Jerusalem. The use of
ekballo here is typologically significant for its use in all three of Jesus’ references to being cast out of/from (the
Promised Land and Promised City) into the outer darkness (Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30). See RBVGB.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 182

       Being able to partake of the Tree of Life is not a gift. “For the gifts and the calling of God are irrevocable”
(Rom 11:29). God revoked the right of Adam and Eve to eat from the Tree of Life. Neither in Genesis nor in
Revelation is eating from this tree an unconditional gift. Rather, eating from the tree is a privilege limited to those
who are obedient (Rev 2:7; 22:14). This provisional privilege can be lost by those who previously had it.
Typologically, their losing their right to the Tree of Life in the opening pages of the Bible would entail losing their
misthological right to the Holy City in the closing pages of the Bible. Exegetically, the same misthological
association is made in the closing pages: “If anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God
shall take away his part from the tree of life and from the holy city, which are written in this book” (Rev 22:19).
Adam and Eve were clothed with animal skin before being expelled. This animal skin typologically portrays their
redemption, making this a misthological exclusion. They were not stripped of their animal skins when they were
expelled from the garden. On the contrary, they retained this clothing, representing their soteriological redemption.
Thus, their expulsion was misthological, not soteriological. Lucifer was not clothed with animal skins. God “does
not give [redemptive] help to angels” (Heb 2:16). The point is clear. Redeemed humanity can lose their participation
in the Tree of Life and thus from the Holy City. They can be driven from the Holy City to live in the comparative
darkness outside—the outer darkness. They do not lose their redemption as a result of this expulsion. This
typological and exegetical conclusion is deductively certain. What remains to be determined is if the connection
with New Jerusalem is only typological. Might it also have been historical?

                                               Inductive Typology
       Further extrapolations regarding Adam and Eve’s expulsion suggest an inductive plausibility for a more
direct connection with New Jerusalem. The hypothesis has been entertained herein that New Jerusalem was located
above the Garden of Eden where Adam could see it. Willis made a similar proposal. Jewish sources assert that God
showed New Jerusalem to Adam. Ancient traditions indicate a familiarity with the Heavenly City, describing it as
Mount Olympus, for example. Other points might be brought forward in favor of this proposal. Gallups has written
a book adopting the popular belief that the Garden of Eden is where Jerusalem now stands:

             A number of scholars believe they have narrowed down the location of the actual Garden of
      Eden even further. They insist it was originally located not only in Israel, but perhaps on Mt. Zion
      itself—in the very center of Jerusalem, the city of God.
             According to ancient Jewish tradition, the Temple Mount in Jerusalem is the location of the
      foundation stone upon which God created the world. In Hebrew, the stone is called the Even HaShtiya.
      The Jews claim this is the place of the original Garden of Eden, as well as the site of Abraham’s
      intended sacrifice of Isaac (Genesis 22). According to Scripture, this was also where Solomon built
      the Temple and where the “Lord appeared” to King David (2 Chronicles 3:1).
             The Hebrew word Even means “rock.” This is also the reason for the name “Dome of the Rock,”
      the Islamic Mosque now located on the site of the original temple.
             The western facade of the Dome of the Rock features the following Arabic inscription: “The
      Rock of the Temple from the Garden of Eden.”276 (Emphasis his.)

       This location for the Garden of Eden is reasonable and accepted as a working premise herein. In the next
chapter, Gallups explains that most scholars, such as Heiser, believe that Eden, the Garden of God, from which
Lucifer fell in Eze 28:13, was the same Eden in which Adam and Eve dwelt, which is his opinion since he does not
adopt the Gap Theory. Gallups’ proposition makes Lucifer the guardian of the Garden of Eden, and this opinion is
shared by others of that persuasion. However, he admits that in Jewish thought, there were two different Edens: one
terrestrial and the other celestial, though both were very intricately connected.277 The two-Eden hypothesis is the

       Adopting a single-Eden hypothesis, Alberino argues that “Adam was able not only to perceive the

from the Celestial Garden of Eden, which, if true, would, in my assessment, be the Heavenly City. However,
although I am adopting the dual-Eden hypothesis instead of the single-Eden hypothesis, I would agree that Adam
and Eve lost visual sight of the heavenly Garden City when they were cast out of the earthly Garden of Eden.
       In the dual-Eden hypothesis adopted herein, this Mountain City, New Jerusalem, was originally located in
the heavenly dimension above the lower site that would later become Earthly Jerusalem. Gallups and I concur that
Mount Moriah is where Abraham offered Isaac (Gen 22:2) and is the location of Solomon’s temple (2Chron 3:1)
and the location of Jesus’ crucifixion.280 Gallups speculates that the Garden of Gethsemane is the exact location in
the Garden of Eden where the fall took place.281 Perhaps, he is correct in that conjecture. In any case, the Garden of
Eden was in that location. Whereas he proposes a singular Eden, placing Lucifer and Adam there at the same time
so that they fell at the same time, I am placing a gap between the falls via the RET model and proposing two

attest that Satan had sex with Eve. If one wants to adopt this perspective, it does not necessarily require that one
adopt the singular Eden hypothesis. The argument that Eve’s fall was through her having sex with Lucifer is more
plausible if one augments it by affirming that Lucifer’s wife, Lilith, seduced Adam. Such possibilities are discussed
in MSIH and MMP4 but thus far have not been adopted in my models, though they are rather common persuasions.
In a similar manner, Fortson discusses the Lilith motif as a plausible opinion held by some biblical students, though
he does not hold it. Minister Dante Fortson, Beyond Flesh and Blood: The Ultimate Guide to Angels and Demons
(USA: Impact Media, 2012), 25-29. Though I do not adopt these suggestions, they would be less objectionable if
one were content to argue that Satan had nonproductive sex with Eve. Thus, he was not made mortal nor imprisoned
in Tartarus.

                               Illustration 48. Possible Three-Level Eden Typology




       The two-level typological connection between the Garden of Eden and the outer darkness is deductively
certain. Adam and Eve were cast out of the Garden of Eden (representing the Heavenly Eden) to perform laborious
work outside of it (picturing the outer darkness). This conclusion does not require that one place New Jerusalem in
the terrestrial Eden or even above it. Even if one does not accept the hypothesis that New Jerusalem was above the
Garden of Eden, the inductive probability of an indirect typological connection with New Jerusalem is exceedingly
high through the connection that the Garden of Eden has with Earthly Jerusalem and through that connection with
the Heavenly Jerusalem. On the other hand, if one accepts the proposition that New Jerusalem was above the Garden
of Eden, then the typological connection is direct. This proposition is certainly within reason. Thus, the proposed
three-level typological connection in the above illustration is entirely sensible.
       A speculative element has been added to the above illustration in placing a ziggurat in the Garden of Eden.
When were ziggurats first invented, and who invented them? The Tower of Babel was not the first ziggurat to
Heaven. Numerous pyramids have been found around the globe. Despite his focus on post-flood ziggurats, Toop
acknowledges pre-flood ziggurats as well:

      Besides the smooth-faced pyramids located at Giza, Egypt, the majority of these pyramid structures
      where built with central staircases leading to the top, known as stepped ziggurats. There are more than
      one hundred thousand pyramids discovered worldwide. Pyramids have been discovered at the
      bottom of various oceans and seas, such as off the coast of Japan, a site known as the Yonaguni
      Monument discovered in 1987 near the southern part of the Ryukyu Islands. Despite God’s direct
      intervention at the Tower of Babel to prevent further contact of the fallen angels in Second Heaven,
      the people defiantly carried on the “secret name” and the knowledge of pyramid building throughout
      the world. Wherever the people went, pyramid structures and various altars followed; wherever these
      are found, stories of giants are an integral part of the culture’s folklore. (KL 1484)

Some ziggurats are underwater. Surely, many of these ziggurats predate Noah’s Flood; as Toop explains: “Puma
Punku was built before the Great Flood. A flood explains why the structure is scattered and spread out in its ruinous
Chapter 5. New Jerusalem in the Typology                                                                    Page 185
state as well as its age” (KL 2064). Post-flood ziggurats were an attempt to regain “contact with fallen angels in
Second Heaven,” and they worked, as attested by the post-flood giants. The Tower of Babel likewise was an attempt
to regain what had existed before the Flood—a connection to Heaven, described as a “tower whose top will reach
into heaven” (Gen 11:4). It would have worked, as attested by Scripture: “And this is what they began to do, and
now nothing which they purpose to do will be impossible for them” (Gen 11:6).
       If such technology existed before the Noachian flood, could it have existed before the Luciferian flood? If
one accepts the fact that pyramids exist on Mars, then we have scientific evidence for such pyramids. Further,
Willis’ opinion, mentioned earlier, is that ziggurats were originally designed by God and subsequently perverted by
Satan. Her opinion that Satan does not have the ability to create, only pervert, is a common one. Toop holds it as
well: “Satan does not have the ability to create” (KL 1649). If this assessment is correct, then we have a theological
basis for believing God was the original designer of the technology employed by the ziggurats. God invented these
stargates. He had the angels use them for travel between terrestrial and celestial locations. He had the angels build
them as part of their intergalactic trade. These stargates could also have been used between terrestrial and celestial
locations.
                         Illustration 49. Expulsion from Ziggurat in the Garden of Eden




       If God had created ziggurats before He created the Garden of Eden, then proposing that God created a
ziggurat in the Garden of Eden is sensible. The Lord Jesus and angels could have used it to travel back and forth
between the Garden of Eden and the Heavenly City, which was suspended above it. Indeed, we may have a hint of
this in Gen 3:18: “And they heard the sound of the Lord God walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and the
man and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the Lord God among the trees of the garden.” If dry autumn
leaves were all over the ground, then one might understand how Adam and Eve could hear Jesus walking in the
garden. But how could they hear Him walking in a lush garden? Some believe that when celestial beings came down
from the heavenly realm to the portal atop the ziggurat, there was an electrical discharge that had to be dissipated
as they walked down the steps of the ziggurat. My conjecture is that when the Lord Jesus, probably in the form of
the Angel of the Lord and using God-created technology common to the angels, came down to the top of the ziggurat
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 186
in the Garden of Eden, it made a loud electrical noise. Each evening, in the cool of the day, He would come down
to visit with Adam and Eve through this means, so they could hear the sound of His coming and even His walking
down those steps of the ziggurat in the garden. Indeed, the cool of the day is taken by some to mean in the midst of
the electrical storm:

      Akkadian terminology has demonstrated that the word translated “day” also has the meaning “storm.”
      This meaning can be seen also for the Hebrew word in Zephaniah 2:2. It is often connected to the deity
      coming in a storm of judgment. If this is the correct rendering of the word in this passage, they heard
      the thunder (the word translated “sound” is often connected to thunder) of the Lord moving about in
      the garden in the wind of the storm. In this case it is quite understandable why they are hiding.
      (Chavalas, IVPBBCOT)

The sound of God walking can denote an electrical storm. JFBC notes that it

      is frequently used in Scripture to denote a storm—a war of the elements (Ps. 18:13; 29:5), and some
      think that, in addition to the moral tempest of conflicting thoughts that was raging in the breasts of the
      fallen pair, they were exposed to a new and sudden convulsion of the elements—some peals of rolling
      thunder—in which their guilty imaginations recognized the tokens of Divine wrath.

       Granted, JFBC believes this meaning is unlikely here because this meaning “occurs only in poetry” and
would be too violent an effect for Adam and Eve’s first disobedience. However, such objections lose much of their
force if this electrical discharge was a common occurrence and thus not associated with a storm of wrath. Stuart
commends a viewpoint close to that adopted herein: “Jeffrey Niehaus has proposed a different translation of the
verse, as follows: ‘Then the man and his wife heard the thunder of Yahweh God as he was going back and forth in
the garden in the wind of the storm and they hid from Yahweh God among the trees of the garden.’” 282 My
conjecture is that just as a ziggurat in the Garden of Eden (which was where the terrestrial Jerusalem is located) was
used to facilitate travel to and from the Heavenly Jerusalem in orbit above it, a ziggurat will be in Earthly Jerusalem
at the end of Revelation to do the very same thing. Many people believe that Eden was a legendary retelling of
Eridu, which is well known for its ziggurats, associated with the forbidden Sumerian paradise containing the Tree
of Life. Conversely, I pose that Eridu was an imitation of Eden. The biblical Garden of Eden was the original
gardened ziggurat encountered by humanity for accessing the Heavenly City, the pattern from which other human
copies were made. Such copies attest to the reasonableness of believing a ziggurat existed in the original Garden of
Eden. As to angelic gods and goddesses coming down to Earth via the ziggurat, picturing Jesus as coming down to
the top of the ziggurat in the Garden of Eden in the form of the Angel of the Lord, which was a form He often
assumed in the OT, is a rationale representation.

                               Illustration 50. Cauley-versus-Willis Eden Typology




       Placing a ziggurat in the terrestrial Eden, per my model, by which heavenly Eden was accessed, is more
probable than the similar model advanced by Willis. We concur that the heavenly Eden (i.e., Heavenly Jerusalem)
is a ziggurat-shaped City/Mountain. Where we primarily differ is that she believes the Heavenly Eden was the
Earthly Eden.283 My model poses two Gardens of Eden, one above the other. Her model poses a singular Garden of
Eden, placing the Heavenly City on Earth. Her model is consistent in placing the Heavenly City on Earth, both in
Genesis and Revelation. My model is also consistent in placing the Heavenly City above Earth, both in Genesis and
in Revelation. Regardless of which model is taken, a ziggurat is associated with the Garden of Eden. Her model
makes a ziggurat of the earthly Garden of Eden by equating it with the heavenly Garden of Eden, thus posing one
ziggurat. My model places a ziggurat in the earthly Garden of Eden, which accesses the heavenly Ziggurat City that
hovered above its earthly counterpart. I pose a three-level Eden typology. She poses a two-level Eden typology.
Both two-level and three-level misthological topologies are valid, as we have seen. Thus, one might find it difficult
to prove which model is superior through that means. Plus, scholars differ over whether New Jerusalem will be on
Earth or above Earth in the millennial and eternal states. Therefore, one might be hard-pressed to prove one’s point
by appealing to the saying that as it was in the beginning, so it will be in the ending. Both models make that
affirmation. Nevertheless, my model appears to have several typological advantages.284 Plus, my model also
explains another possible typological connection with the Heavenly City.

    Willis, 67-72.
284
    Typologically, my model has the greater probability in that, even in Willis’ model, the Holy City does not occupy
all of the Promised Land. For that matter, the Holy City only takes up a portion of the Holy Allotment, as Willis
demonstrates in her illustrations. Therefore, consistency would favor my model in that one would still have three-
level typology in the eternal state: (1) Holy City, (2) Promised Land, and (3) outer darkness outside the Promised
Land. Thus, one would anticipate a three-level typology in Genesis. Even if one proposes that the Luciferian Garden
of Eden was the Adamic Garden of Eden, as Willis does, one need not necessarily suppose that this Luciferian-
Adamic Garden was the Heavenly City. If the distinction between the Garden of Eden and the Heavenly City is
maintained, then three-level typology is retained. The heavenly Garden of Eden would still not be equated with the
earthly Garden of Eden. Thus, even this alternate model, which would be a mediating model between my model
and Willis’ model, would support my three-level typological model.

                                                Jacob’s Staircase
      The postulation made herein is that a ziggurat in Earthly Jerusalem will be the earthly portal to the Heavenly
Jerusalem in a stationary orbit above it. Justification for that inference comes, in part, from typology. Earlier
material quoted from Dolphin made this affirmation:

             In summary then the Bible speaks of two Jerusalems, not merely one. As Abraham was
      promised a heavenly family, as numerous as the stars of the heavens, and also an earthly family,
      as numerous as the grains of sand on the seas shore, so the coming time of redemption will feature
      a restored earthly Jerusalem, capital city of the Planet Earth, capital city of Israel.
             But there is also a great space city, a magnificent gateway city to the rest of the universe,
      Jerusalem Above, the mother of us all.
             Are the two Jerusalems connected? Probably yes. The Temple in Jerusalem on earth may
      well prove to be the “gateway” for “travel” to and from the orbiting space city New Jerusalem.
      (JAJB)

Amen! Space City is Gateway City to the rest of this universe and even the multiverse. Quoting Stedman, Dolphin
provides grounds for believing that access to the Heavenly City is through Israel:

            The gates of the Holy City are named for the tribes of Israel. It is a perpetual reminder
      that “salvation is of the Jews.” Access to the city is through Israel—not merely because it was
      the Jewish nation that gave us Jesus, but also because Israel gave us the Old Testament prophets
      and the godly traditions and practices of the Old Testament. (JAJB)

Surely, the Space City can be accessed through space, that is, through spaceships. How would such access be limited
through Israel, though? It would not be. Also, this Teleportal City can probably be accessed through teleportals
from numerous other planets. Dolphin, quoting Stedman, shares my belief that humanity will spread to these planets:

             The new universe will surely be as big or bigger than it is now---and its vastness is orders
      of magnitude beyond human comprehension as it is! Billions of galaxies, each containing billions
      of stars like our own sun, sprinkle the heavens for as far as our greatest telescopes can see. Each
      of those stars may be circled by planets—perhaps even many earthlike planets.
             These may be new limitless worlds for us to encounter, explore, develop, and experience.
      Every moment of eternity will be a new adventure of discovery. (JAJB)

He makes this quote just before his quote above about the access through the Israeli gates of the Heavenly City.
Likely, stargates from ziggurats on these other planets will provide additional means of personally reaching the
Heavenly City. What about the cargo? Kings of Planet Earth will be bringing their trading goods into the Heavenly
City (Rev 21:24-26). Of course, they will not be the only ones doing so. The other planets will certainly be doing
so as well. Transporting cargo for intergalactic trade to the Capital City from these remote locations could be
facilitated by transport spaceships passing through large stargates suspended in space to make the hyperjump from
one galaxy to another, even from one universe to another. With all this intergalactic beehive of trading activity
going on with the Heavenly City, why make a special association of its gates with Israel? Jacob was named Israel
because he overcame in his struggle with God (Gen 32:28). Typology suggests that entrance through the gates is
associated with being overcomers. After all, it is the City of the overcomers. We might call it Overcomer City since
it belongs to them (Rev 3:12). Even so, the deeper typological connection is even more suggestive, going back at
least as far as Jacob’s dream.
      12
        And he had a dream, and behold, a stairway was set on the Earth with its top reaching to Heaven;
      and behold, the angels of God were ascending and descending on it. 13 And behold, the Lord stood

realities in this dream, he may have actually seen the outline of the portal, thus a portal ring.

      Sitchin thinks this ladder was mechanical equipment used by the divine beings who hovered over the spot in
“some kind of craft.”287 Identifying this craft as New Jerusalem is more plausible than leaving it unidentified as a
UFO. As to the ladder, Sitchin allows that the ziggurats were raised to serve the spacecraft of the gods as a
connecting link (pp. 379-380). His own deductions should allow the plausibility that Jacob saw a ziggurat
connecting Earth and Heaven via this Heavenly Spaceship.
                                                   Jesus’ Staircase
       Jesus makes a very interesting allusion to Jacob’s dream when He tells Nathaniel: “Truly, truly, I say to you
[singular], hereafter you [plural] will see the heavens opened, and the angels of God ascending and descending on
the Son of Man” (Jn 1:51; TM). Jesus’ statement was addressed to Nathaniel, but the promise was made to all the
believers who were present. They would all see the fulfillment of this promise. Many translations and commentators
omit the word hereafter (ap arti) because it is omitted in the CT. Comfort is a case in point:

              The addition of απ αρτι (“hereafter”) was borrowed from Matt 26:64 (which reads, “Hereafter
      you will see the Son of Man sitting on the right hand of power and coming on the clouds of heaven”).
      Some commentators think the scribal addition of απ αρτι links 1:51 with Matt 26:64 exegetically, but
      this is not so. The promise in Matthew is eschatological; the promise in John was to be fulfilled in

287
  Zecharia Sitchin, The 12th Planet: The First Book of The Earth Chronicles, Kindel Edition (Rochester, VM: Bear
& Company, n.d.), 171.
Chapter 5. New Jerusalem in the Typology                                                                      Page 193
      Jesus’ lifetime. The prophetic promise in 1:51 is an allusion to Jacob’s vision of the ladder connecting
      heaven to earth (see Gen 28:12–21). Jesus, as the Son of Man, was the real vehicle of communication
      between heaven and earth, divinity and humanity. (NTTTC)

      Such scholastic preference for an exclusively realized eschatology assumes an unnecessary dichotomy. One
can affirm the typical realized metaphorical understanding of Jn 1:51 without ruling out an additional literal
eschatological meaning. Yes, Jesus is the gateway to Heaven (Jn 14:6). Such metaphorical understandings of this
passage can be fully affirmed. However, metaphorical propositions do not exhaust the meaning of this text. Toop
poses five possible levels of meaning. His statements elsewhere about the Son of Man are applicable here:

             This brings into focus one of the five distinct ways God presents His Word to the reader, which
      I call multi-level interpretation. This method is perhaps one of the least understood by studiers of the
      Word. The other four methods of conveyance being (1) the direct, literal sense, which is the most
      common; (2) the parable sense, simply telling a story to illustrate one or more lessons of truth and
      principle, a method Jesus used often; (3) the metaphoric sense, which is presenting something, usually
      a singular object or action, that is symbolically representing something else. This extends to the
      allegoric sense which presents multiple facets that symbolically represent a more complex theme based
      on moral or political issues and, (4) something which I call encoded revelation, which is Spiritual
      knowledge God has encoded within His Word (both ancient and modern languages) that have remained
      hidden and are locked until they are meant to be unlocked and understood at God’s prescribed time
      and by God’s anointed person(s). (Italics his, KL 2638-2651.)

Jesus did not intend for His Son-of-Man statement here in Jn 1:51 to be limited to the here-and-now. He prefaced
it with reference to the hereafter, as affirmed by MT, TR, various translators, and commentators. In its
eschatological fulfillment, this promise will find literal fulfillment. A link with Mt 26:64 is sustainable: “Hereafter
you shall see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of Power, and coming on the clouds of heaven.” These two
eschatological statements regarding the Son of Man are linked to the hereafter. Gaebelein is on the right track when
he affirms a literal eschatological fulfillment.
             The last two verses of this marvellous [sic.] chapter [Jn 1:50-51] will find their fulfillment in
      that day when heaven is opened. Then greater things will take place. The angels of God will be seen
      ascending and descending upon the Son of Man. It will take place when He comes the second time,
      when Israel acknowledges Him as their King and as the Son of God. (ABC)

Govett argues at length for an exclusively literal fulfillment. Only part of his excellent discussion will be cited here:
             When then is it to be accomplished?
             (1) It has been shown, that the promise cannot be fulfilled in our Gospel days of grace. For
      during these times heaven is not visibly open, angels are not objects of sight, and even if they were, it
      would not avail; for the promise is that they are to move up and down in connection with Christ as
      their centre, their Master and Governor, executing His errands.
             When then shall it be accomplished?
             (1) In millennial days. When the Kingdom is, as foretold, to be given into the hands of Christ
      Jesus, exalted as ‘the Son of Man.’ It is God’s counsel, that the Kingdom, lost by the first Adam, shall
      be manifested with additional glory in the hand of the second man. When He is a second time
      manifested in the habitable earth, all the angels of God are to worship Him (Heb. i. 6). He is to come
      with them when He takes His Kingdom of glory. They are to be the executioners of His wrath. This
      tells us too, that in the days of Christ’s rule over heaven and earth, they are to bring Him tidings, and
      to be dispatched on His errands. Then they are not only to be seen, but are to be in closest connection
      with His person.
             Then, too, the heaven is to be opened. As during the reign of Satan and his False King and
      Christ, heaven is shut and hell is opened: so during the reign of the true Christ, heaven is opened and
      hell (or the bottomless pit) is shut (Rev. xix. 11; xx. 1-3). John sees the heaven opened then and the
      inhabitants of it come forth. That can only take place in millennial days….
             Moreover, thus, as we have seen, we bring the matter into closest correspondence with the
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 194
      context. The thoughts of Nathanael probably turned on the future kingdom. He was informed that the
      Son of Man, the great centre of all the promises in Moses and the Prophets, was come. And our Lord
      confirms his thoughts. To Him, as Son of Man, all tllings, even the angels, shall be subordinate…..
             ….In the days of the Son of Man there shall be a visible way of access between heaven and
      earth. It is God s purpose as He has declared, to gather together in Christ, as the One Head, all things
      (Eph. i.).
             This dream, too, assures the land of promise to Christ, and to Jacob. Neither of these has as yet
      received the prize. The land belongs to Jacob and to Christ. Neither has as yet enjoyed the promise.
      All nations are to be blessed under Christ in those days.
             The final promise supposes resurrection. Not till then can Jacob possess the land of Palestine.
      Neither he, nor Christ, the seed of Jacob, has ever yet enjoyed the land promised them. Never yet have
      all the families of the earth been blessed in Christ ; nor will they be during the Gospel, though some
      of each family are being gathered out by the Gospel in order to have part in the resurrection-glory of
      those days.
             These words suppose the restoration of Israel to their own land and to the favour of God. The
      promises to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, embrace also the earthly seed of the patriarchs.288 (Emphasis
      his.)
Govett (GOJ) does well to call attention to both the OT and NT context. He concludes with the OT context. The
passage deals with the Promised Land:
      12
        And he dreamed, and behold, there was a ladder [stairway] set up on the earth, and the top of it
      reached to heaven. And behold, the angels of God were ascending and descending on it! 13 And behold,
      the Lord stood above it and said, “I am the Lord, the God of Abraham your father and the God of Isaac.
      The land on which you lie I will give to you and to your offspring. 14 Your offspring shall be like
      the dust of the earth, and you shall spread abroad to the west and to the east and to the north and to the
      south, and in you and your offspring shall all the families of the earth be blessed. 15 Behold, I am with
      you and will keep you wherever you go, and will bring you back to this land. For I will not leave
      you until I have done what I have promised you. (Gen 28:12-15)

        The fulfillment of this passage is undoubtedly literal and millennial in scope. This type of fulfillment is what
Nathaniel and the other believers were thinking about when they read about Jacob’s dream. If Jesus does not have
this literal millennial fulfillment exclusively in mind, He certainly has it inclusively in mind, probably even
preeminently in mind. With Govett’s thoughts on Jn 1:51 in mind, Keith Call makes a tantalizing suggestion:

             Since Christ will govern a dual reign between the heavenly New Jerusalem and the Jerusalem
      complex on earth, he will occasionally ascend or descend through the spatial distance between the two
      points, with his royal retinue of angels accompanying him from one “office” to the other, whether this
      happens daily, weekly, monthly or yearly. It will be a spectacular public event, like the changing of
      the guard in England, or watching the Queen of England and her entourage coming through town, or
      spying the presidential motorcade passing through.289

Our mutual friend, James Hollandsworth, has an excellent sermon available online entitled City of Reward, in which
he asserts that the ladder/portal Jacob saw was reaching to the Heavenly City and that Jesus is indicating that
Nathaniel will be misthologically qualified for this Reward City.290 The duality of Jerusalem is affirmed by its very

name. In Hebrew, its ending denotes a duality. Jewish Rabbis have perceived a corresponding spiritual duality,

one. Therefore, for Willis and others of that mindset to pose a merger of the earthly city and heavenly City into one

given at new birth. Misthological entrance into the misthopological kingdom is a reward attained by subsequent

Jn 3:3 is horao.) Jacob’s calling the place he saw the house of God makes sense if he saw the City of God. In

descending) are not angels but glorified saints who qualify to ascend/teleport into the City and thus qualify to
descend/teleport back down to Earth and rule over it in their service to Jesus.
     Additionally, Hollandsworth believes the kingdom of God (KOG) can be used comprehensively to refer to the
entirety of God’s kingdom, while the kingdom of heaven (KOH) is used more narrowly to refer to the Heavenly
City. I am not inclined to be as sharp in my delineation, particularly since I am inclined for duality at times. For
instance, I have entertained a secondary misthological possibility to Jn 3-5 above, whereas initially in my writings
I insisted upon an exclusively soteriological interpretation of that passage. Additionally, when Matthew says that
the kingdom of God is taken away from the Jews (Mt 21:43), he is not talking soteriologically about the universal
kingdom or millennially about their ancestral kingdom. Rather, he is talking about the misthopological kingdom.
Keys for Inheriting the Kingdom by Hollandsworth is an excellent book devoted to this thesis. Under the
Dispensation of Promise and the Dispensation of the Law, Gentiles would have to become Jewish proselytes to
qualify for the misthopological kingdom. Under the Dispensation of Grace, the exclusivity of the approach to the
City has been taken away from the Jews and given to a new nation comprised of faithful believers in Christ, putting
Jewish believers and Gentile believers on equal footing. Nevertheless, I concur with Hollandsworth that the City is
like the castle of the more comprehensive kingdom. Christ exclusively, rather than the Jews intermediately, is now
the drawbridge to that castle. For those who have eyes to see them, at least four primary spatial kingdoms are
perceivable: universal kingdom, terrestrial kingdom, ancestral kingdom, and misthopological kingdom (see
RBVGB). One can be excluded from more exclusive forms of the kingdom while not excluded from the more
comprehensive forms of the kingdom.
     Pearl has written a book that discusses eight kingdoms in Scripture, which includes a commendable discussion
of the kingdom from the perspective of RET. Also, he rightly acknowledges that Abraham was seeking the literal
Promised City rather than soteriological salvation. Still, the primary focus of Pearl’s discussion is to differentiate
the KOH from the KOG. Supposedly the KOG is spiritual, but the KOH is physical. However, even he must
acknowledge their similarities despite their differences. His overall misthology is very weak. For instance, he
interprets the outer darkness to be soteriological, arguing that the slothful servant in the parable of the pounds deals
with misthological issues because the phrase KOG is used, but he thinks that the slothful servant in the parable of
the talents is cast into Hell because it is dealing with the KOH. Supposedly, entrance into the KOG is soteriological,
thus by grace through faith, so that the KOG is limited to the regenerate; whereas, entrance into the KOH is
misthological, thus conditioned on personal worthiness, though presently both the unregenerate and the regenerate
are within it. He is forced to acknowledge that the KOH is present today “in a sense” (p. 103). Thoroughgoing
distinctions are strained in passages such as Mt 29:23-24 and Lk 19:11-27. In seeking to make Lk 9:62
soteriological, he interprets it to mean that the unfaithful are not fit to be workers for the KOG (p. 128); whereas,
the text simply says that they are not fit for the KOG, thus implying misthological considerations. The KOG also
encompasses misthological themes in Mk 10:28-31 and Lk 18:29-30, making his distinctions seem artificial at times
(pp. 129-130). He fails to acknowledge that being worthy of the KOG is a misthological theme in 2Thess 1:5 (p.
137). He acknowledges that the discussion of the kingdom is “beautifully complex” (p. 147). However, it does not
appear that he has succeeded in reducing that complexity to the simplicity he has sought to achieve. Michael Pearl,
Eight Kingdoms: Kingdom of God and Kingdom of Heaven (Pleasantville, TN: No Greater Joy Ministries, 2006).
Personally, I would be interested in seeing this thesis developed by a more astute misthologist who might be able
to achieve the desired simplicity for the phraseology. For now, though, I am content with my contextual complexity.

                                 Illustration 55. Angels Ascending and Descending




       Putting all these clues together yields a composite that posits that during the millennial state, Jesus’s statement
about the angels ascending and descending on Him in connection with the Promised Land will find literal
fulfillment. Just as Jacob saw a ziggurat linking Heaven with the Promised Land where he was laying, believers
during the millennial kingdom (and probably during the eternal state as well) will be able to see angels ascending
and descending on a ziggurat in the Promised Land. Jesus will go back and forth between the Earthly Jerusalem and
Heavenly Jerusalem via a ziggurat in the Promised Land when He desires great angelic fanfare. This ziggurat will
most likely be located where it was originally located, namely, in the Garden of Eden at Jerusalem, or it might be
located where Jacob anointed his rock at Bethel.
       Alternatively, heretofore, I have regarded Jesus as only being physically present in one location at a time and
having to split time in order to appear to be in multiple locations almost simultaneously. However, Lascelle
preferences her picture of Jacob’s ladder in her book with an alternate explanation:
             This “new heavens and new earth” will also have a “new city” called “New Jerusalem” which
      will be the location of the Throne occupied by God, the King of heaven and earth. He is omnipresent
      (everywhere present) therefore can appear in heaven, and on earth at His will. (See John 3:13 where,
      though the Son of Man was on earth, He said that He was in heaven.) Our Lord can sit on the Throne
      of His glory in heaven as King of Kings and at the same time be on earth to sit on the Throne of
      David as King of the Jews in Jerusalem!
             Another instance when the Lord was on earth and in heaven also is when, after conversing with
      Abraham He went to the area of Sodom-Gomorrah where He rained down fire and brimstone upon
      these cities. It is stated this way: “Then the LORD rained upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah [on earth]
      brimstone and fire from the LORD out of heaven” (Genesis 19:24). Here the Lord…is Omnipresent
      (Everywhere-Present), that is, He was earth and in heaven at the same time! (Font emphasis hers, 130-
      131.)

      As He sits upon David’s throne during the Millennial Kingdom on earth, He will be called “King of
      the Jews” as He rules over the Tribes of Israel located in the land of Israel. Being omnipresent He will
      also be reigning on His Throne in heaven at the same time as He rules over the Jews in the Kingdom
      on earth! (Emphasis hers, 161, n. 95.)

     Wilkin (GNTC) concurs on Jn 3:13: “The clause ‘who is in heaven’ is not found in some early Greek
manuscripts and so it is missing from some English versions. However, since it is found in the vast majority of
Chapter 5. New Jerusalem in the Typology                                                                    Page 197
manuscripts, this powerful statement is likely original. While on earth talking to Nicodemus, Jesus was also in
heaven (i.e., omnipresent).” Thiessen concurs: “He is omnipresent. He was in heaven while on earth (John 3:13)
and is on earth while he is in heaven (Matt. 18:20; 28:20).”291 Barnes (BNONT) similarly states:
             Which is in heaven. This is a very remarkable expression. Jesus, the Son of man, was then
      bodily on earth conversing with Nicodemus; yet he declares that he is at the same time in heaven.
      This can be understood only as referring to the fact that he had two natures—that his divine
      nature was in heaven, and his human nature on earth. Our Saviour is frequently spoken of in this
      manner. Comp. Jn. 6:62; 17:5; 2 Co. 8:9. As Jesus was in heaven—as his proper abode was there—he
      was fitted to speak of heavenly things, and to declare the will of God to man.…The Lord Jesus is
      divine. He was in heaven while on earth. He had, therefore, a nature far above the human, and is equal
      with the Father, ch. 1:1. (Italics his.)

Although skeptical that the MT words who is Heaven are a genuine part of the original text, Leon Morris (NICNT,
1995) affirms the point they make: “If they are included they will point to the eternal being of the Son of man. The
incarnation represents not a diminution of his functions, but an addition to them. Only a crassly literal
localization of heaven would require us to think that Jesus had to leave heaven to come to earth.” Indeed, one
reason that Morris can insist that Jesus did not have to abandon Heaven to come to Earth is that this would mean
that He would have had to abandon the Father. Yet both John and John the Baptist affirm that this was not the case:
“No man has seen God at any time; the only begotten God, who is in the bosom of the Father, He has explained
Him” (Jn 1:18). Concerning this verse, Morris affirms:

      The copula “is” expresses a continuing union. The only begotten is continually in the bosom8 of the
      Father. When the Word became flesh his cosmic activities did not remain in abeyance until the
      end of his earthly life. There are mysteries here that we cannot plumb, but we must surely hold that
      the incarnation meant the adding of something to what the Word was doing, rather than the
      cessation of most of his activities.292

    Henry Clarence Thiessen, Lectures in Systematic Theology, revised by Vernon D. Doerksen (Grand Rapids:

    Morris’ assessment of Jn 1:18 in the 1995 NICNT is vastly superior to that of Michaels in the 2010 NICNT, who

Only’ than on the time reference of the pronouncement.” On the contrary, the tensed now accentuates the nature of
God the One and Only. His nature is such that He can be on Earth and in Heaven at the same time. Klink (ZECNT)
is on the right track: “When the Word became flesh, he did not cease to perform his cosmic activities as if the

Lange and Vincent). Nor is it enough to say that it is a “timeless state, an eternal condition” (Phillips, JPCS). No!
