Walvoord explains at length regarding Christ’s omnipresence:

      That God is omnipresent is the clear teaching of Scripture (Dt. 4:39; Psa. 139:7–10; Prov. 15:3; Isa.
      66:1; Jer. 23:24; Acts 17:27). It is evident that Christ possessed the same attribute. His promises of
      abiding with His disciples forever (Mt. 28:20), and His promise to indwell the believer (John 14:18,
      20, 23) are impossible of any literal fulfillment unless Christ is also omnipresent. The experience of
      Nathaniel (John 1:48) would imply that Christ was spiritually omnipresent even during His life on
      earth. If the disputed passage of John 3:13, “which is in heaven,” be admitted as genuine, it would be
      explicit statement of this doctrine. Inasmuch as the deity of Christ can be sustained on other grounds,
      it would follow that Christ as God has the same omnipresence which is described so clearly in Psalm
      139:7–10. Whether in heaven or hell or in the uttermost parts of the sea, Christ is there.293

Ryrie makes this affirmation a matter of orthodoxy:

      If omnipresence was restored, then that means that it was relinquished while our Lord was on earth
      which idea of course is an improper doctrine of kenosis and actually a denial of the full deity of Christ
      during the period of humiliation. Such verses as John 1:48 and 3:13 make it clear that omnipresence
      was not relinquished while He was on earth.294

       Overstreet has an article dedicated to the discussion of Jn 3:13 and cites supporters of this position, some of
whom clarify that Christ was present in His deity in Heaven while limited in His humanity while on Earth. In
other words, although His deity was united with His humanity during the incarnation, His deity was not
limited to His humanity. Although Christ’s human body was limited to one place during that time, He was
simultaneously present with His Father in Heaven. As Overstreet notes, “asserting that Christ is omnipresent in
His deity does not therefore require that His human body must also be omnipresent.” In my opinion, that statement
could remain true after Christ’s ascension. Theoretically, Christ could appear in multiple places in an ethereal body
while limiting His appearance in His glorified human body to one place at a time even after His ascension. On the
other hand, since His emptying Himself of the full exercise of His attributes was limited to the incarnation (Phil 2:5-
11) and since multiple promises were made by the incarnate Christ in which the hypostatic union was being
manifested at the time (Mt 18:20; 28:20; Jn 14:3, 18, 23), I am skeptical that Christ would limit the physical
expression of His presence to one place at a time after His ascension. Overstreet goes on to conclude: “Even though
He took upon Himself human form and walked on this earth, He never ceased to be God; and as God He was in
heaven while He was also on earth. John 3:13 serves as direct evidence, therefore, of the doctrine of Christ’s
omnipresence and also assumes the doctrine of the hypostatic union.”295

Chapter 5. New Jerusalem in the Typology                                                                   Page 199
Global Impact Ministries provides an excellent video explaining that Trinitarian commentators tend to affirm the
phrase even the Son of man which is in heaven in Jn 3:13 (KJV), posing that the phrase was probably removed from
some early manuscripts by Arians and Semi-Arians who denied the full deity of Christ.296 Those opposed to
Trinitarian passages reject the proposition that Christ retained the full exercise of His attributes in Heaven while
limiting them in His incarnate state on Earth.
       Trying to downplay the textual support and theological implications, Robertson (WPNT) asserts that “if
genuine, [this wording who is in Heaven] would merely emphasize the timeless existence of God’s Son who is in
heaven even while on earth.” Robertson’s comments are partially flawed and much too reserved. For textual and
logistical considerations, the spatial proposition of Robertson’s position is acceptable, but the atemporal-
temporal juxtaposition is impossible. Jesus was not setting timelessly in Heaven while living and dying in time
on Earth. He was in two different places, each place with its own time, but time in one was related to the time
in the other. Christ was not impassive in Heaven while suffering on Earth. Mullins quotes Gregory of Nazianzus’
statement that Jesus was “on earth and at the same time in heaven.”297 Very good. However, Gregory made this
statement in the context of saying that Jesus was passible on Earth while being impassible in Heaven. Not so!
Gregory of Nazianzus’ affirmation same time should be applied to Christ in both heavenly and earthly dimensions,
not limited to the earthly dimension. Mullins demonstrates the fallacy of thinking that God is impassible and
timeless. God experiences change in emotions, and He experiences time. If Jesus were timeless, He could not
have become incarnate. We will return to that thought later, for now, though, because the textual evidence is so
strong, Lenski’s (LCNT) emphatic response suffices:

      Though he came down and now speaks to Nicodemus as the Son of man, he remains ὁ ὢν ἐν τῷ
      οὑρανῷ, “he who is in heaven.” He cannot change his divine nature, cannot lay it aside, cannot cancel
      even temporarily his divine Sonship, his unity of essence with the Father and the Spirit. This is
      unthinkable although men have tried to think it. To think such a thing is to make also “the Son of man”
      an illusion, to say nothing of undoing in thought the very Godhead itself and the Trinity of immutable
      Persons….
      ….he that came down is now here as the incarnate Son of man, and yet, having come down, does
      not mean leaving heaven—he is both here and is still in heaven. Impossible! is the reply. Why?
      This would destroy the unity of Christ’s person and the unity of his self-consciousness! In simple
      language this dogmatical objection declares: We do not see and understand how one can be in heaven
      and on earth at the same time, hence such a thing cannot be—Jesus must mean something else; and
      then the search begins for what he must mean. Thus the story of Nicodemus is here repeated when in
      v. 9 he asked, “How can these things be?” and was told that his question meant nothing but plain,
      persistent unbelief. Jesus is in heaven though as the Son of man he walks on earth—that fact stands
      whether it staggers our reason and powers of comprehension or not. Preconceived dogmatical
      considerations have always been the bane of exegesis. They have vitiated the plainest grammatical and
      linguistic facts. The plea about the unity of person and consciousness transfers what would be true of
      an ordinary human being with only one nature to Christ, the unique divine Being who after his
      incarnation has two natures. The further plea that from John’s prolog onward Christ’s being on earth
      or in the world and his being with God (1:1, 2, and 1:10) form an exclusive contrast, reveals how far
      back this dogmatical preconception reaches and how it misunderstands the prolog. It will do the same
      with other statements in our Gospel, such as 10:30; 17:11 and 22. When the Spirit in the form of a
      dove came down out of heaven upon Jesus, he did not thereby remove his person and presence
      from heaven, nor did he do this when he was poured out upon the disciples on Pentecost. The
      same is true of Jehovah when he appeared to Abraham, to Moses in the fiery bush, and when he
      descended on Sinai, to mention only these. (Emphasis his.).


with His finite-created-human mind. He could limit the latter without necessarily limiting the exercise of the former
(in all locations).

       For reasons to be explained later, extrapolations in the present book led me to deduce that the Lord, as a
higher-class dimensional being, can replicate Himself in an infinite number of lower-class dimensional
representations and be in as many lower dimensional locations as He desires.298 He has joined His infinite divine
nature with our finite human nature in such a way to be able to be in multiple locations at one time. Since I have
concluded that He is able to do this currently, it stands to reason that He was able to do so at the point of His
incarnation. Since He is a higher dimensional being than the Bride, He must be able to supersede Her ability, which
we will consider subsequently. Retrospectively, I perceive the truth conveyed by the majority text for Jn 3:13 as
being a logical necessity. The Lord could limit the exercise of His human consciousness to that of an infant in
His earthly form while simultaneously retaining the full exercise of His divine consciousness in His heavenly
form, thus holding the multiverse together from Heaven (Col 1:17) even while lying in a manger on Earth.
Even earlier, He could walk in the garden as the Angel of the Lord and limit His knowledge of Adam’s location
and legitimately ask, “Where are you?” (Gen 3:9), while simultaneously knowing in His heavenly form exactly
where Adam was. Our Trinitarian Lord can split His consciousness to be appropriate to the form and location
He desires. The Lord can do so not merely as a holistic function of the Trinity but also in the second person
of the Trinity. The Lord Jesus is not required to exercise the full range of His divine prerogatives in every
form, time, and location. He can lay aside their full exercise as desired or needed in certain forms and times
(Phil 2:6-8). Moreover, He can take multiple forms simultaneously.
       As for the Lord on Earth addressing the Lord in Heaven in Gen 19:24, Barnes states: “Here the Lord is
represented as present in the skies, whence the storm of desolation comes, and on the earth where it falls” (BNONT).
Fruchtenbaum (ABC) acknowledges the reality of the plurality:
         There are two Jehovahs in this passage: a Jehovah on earth and Jehovah in heaven, showing a plurality
         in the Godhead. The first Jehovah, on the earth, rained judgment from the second Jehovah, in heaven.
         Even the ancient rabbis recognized that there seem to be two Jehovahs, and they had to find a way
         around it. Some rabbis identified the first Jehovah as Gabriel and the second Jehovah as God. Other
         rabbis tried to simplify it further by claiming it represented God in His heavenly court. Again, all this
         is just a simple way of getting around the obvious of a plurality in the Godhead. (Emphasis his.)
        Fruchtenbaum may be correct. On the other hand, we need not necessarily insist that the Lord on Earth was
Jesus calling down fire from His Father in Heaven. Jesus can talk to Himself. We do so all the time. We do not find
it strange to find the rich man speaking to himself in deciding to build bigger barns (Lk 12:18-19). Nor should we
find it inconceivable to find the Lord speaking to Himself to call down fire. Given Barnes’ understanding of Jn 3:13,
his interpretation of Gen 19:24 might mean: “Here the Lord [Jesus] is represented as present in the skies, whence
the storm of desolation comes, and on the earth where it falls.”
        Seen from this dual perspective regarding the location of Jesus, the heavenly angels can be understood
as ascending between the Earthly Jesus and the Heavenly Jesus. While sitting on His throne in Earthly
Jerusalem, Jesus will assume an earthly form like He did on the road to Emmaus (Lk 24:13-31). While sitting
on His throne in Heavenly Jerusalem in His glorious form, He can appear on Earth in non-glorious form. He
can be the light of the City while simultaneously appearing on Earth in a non-radiant form. The proposal made by
Beasley-Murray (WBC) is intriguing when seen from this perspective:
         In Jacob’s dream a ladder is set up between earth and heaven, and angels ascend and descend on—
         ”it”? or upon Jacob? The point was discussed by later rabbis; in BerRab 70:12 the angels “were
         ascending on high and looking at his εἰκών (image), and then descending below and finding him
         sleeping” (see Burney, Aramaic Origin, 116). The natural reading of v [Jn 1:]51 is that the angels
         ascend to heaven, and descend to the Son of Man (ἐπὶ τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ ἀνθρώπον); he is the point of
         contact between heaven and earth, the focus? of the “traffic” that brings heaven’s blessings to
         mankind. (Italics his.)
       If the angels are ascending and descending to Jesus, as Beasley-Murray suggests, then the natural
understanding would be that Jesus is at the top and bottom of the ladder. Either Keith Call is correct that Jesus
is sequentially at both locations, or Lascelle is correct that Jesus is simultaneously at both locations. Given my
preference for the MT in Jn 3:13 and the deductions reached later in this book regarding the Lord’s multidimensional
replicator abilities, the latter position will be adopted herein as most probable.

      See 6D Supernalspace, 279.

       In either case, proceeding with Dolphin’s statements cited earlier, this ziggurat will not be located just

be through Israel—not merely because it was the Jewish nation that gave us Jesus but also because this is where
access to the Space City via a direct portal from Earth’s ziggurat will be available. This proposal, as it pertains to
Earth, is highly reasonable and has been largely anticipated by others as to its constituent parts. The above model
just puts the pieces of the puzzle together.

planets throughout the universe. Others have made this observation as well. What I might add is that humanity

throughout the multiverse and to the singular 4D location of the City in Paradise.301 Given the infinite spatial
capacity inside the 4D City and its infinite teleportal capacity, this proposal seems entirely plausible.
       In conjunction with the present observation regarding the association of the gates of the City with the tribes
of Israel, I propose that as the Gentile nations continue to grow in population, so will the Jewish population. This
aspect of my proposal is entirely justifiable. The speculative aspect of my conjecture is posing that wherever the
3D City is located above a capital planet, a ziggurat will be located at the northernmost part of that planet, giving
direct portal access to the 3D City above it. The land around that ziggurat will, in each case, be populated by the
Jewish people. Access to the Holy City via ziggurats will always be exclusively through the Jewish people. The
pattern established on Earth pertaining to access via the Promised Land to the Heavenly City will be replicated
throughout the eternal ages in infinite locations. The outer sphere of the City has been included in this illustration
because, in my estimation, the sphere would be a vital part of the teleportation, being dialed in, so to speak, to the
respective planetary ziggurat below it, so that the sphere and outer interface of the 3D City match the planet below.
       For example, when you teleport from the 4D City to the 3D City above Earth and exit the 3D City at that
location and walk on the mountain slopes of the City, you would see Earth down below the Space City. Likewise,
mortals on Earth would be able to see you if they were looking through a telescope at the 3D City to the north of
their planet. Immortals on Earth would be able to see you with their telescopic vision.
       If you teleported from the 4D City to the 3D City above a planet elsewhere in the multiverse, you would see
that planet when you exited the 3D City and walked on the outer slopes of the 3D City. Telescopically, those on
that planet would be able to see you walking on the slopes of the 3D City suspended above their planet. The outer
interface of the 3D City and its protective sphere surrounding it are tuned to the location of the ziggurat below that
location in 3D space.
       The ziggurat on any given planet is set by default to teleport to the 3D City above that planet. The stargate at
the top of any ziggurat could be tuned to access any 3D City above any planet, of course. They are stargate portals,
after all. Even so, the default setting would be to the 3D City directly located above that ziggurat. Such possibilities
are entirely within the standard fare of science fiction, and science fiction increasingly tends to become science fact.
One day humanity will think no more of this teleportational ability than they would think of emailing a picture on
the internet today. This teleportational technology, which is seemingly so advanced, will then be taken for granted.
       The World Wide Web (WWW) in the eternal state will be much more comprehensive than it is now. Currently,
we can take multiple pictures, for instance, and transmit them virtually instantaneously to someone on the other side
of the planet, without those pictures getting lost in all the other packets of information being sent over the internet,
even when they arrive at that same destination at the same instant. Our bodies, whether they are our physical bodies
or spiritual bodies or both, are likewise packets of information. One day we will be able to send our bodies (which
are also packets of information) to other worlds via teleportals. For that matter, overcomers will be able to teleport
their bodies without the aid of teleportals. Nevertheless, even they will prefer to use ziggurats for special occasions
to enter by the gates (portals) into the City: “Blessed are those who wash their robes, that they may have the right
to the tree of life, and may enter by the gates into the city” (Rev 22:14). We have no problem picturing millions of
overcomers coming and going via teleportation to various destinations outside the City and even back to the same
location (such as a banquet) inside the City. If overcomers, who are teleporters, can do so, then why would we have

       Certainly, Jesus will not limit Himself to entering by the gates into the City. Neither will overcomers. Both

occasions, they will enter by the gates/portals into the 3D City above their respective planets with angelic fanfare
via ziggurats. Kings of the Earth will bring their cargo into the Satellite City by means of its gates/portals: “And the
nations shall walk by its light, and the kings of the earth shall bring their glory into it in order that they may enter
it. And in the daytime (for there shall be no night there) its gates shall never be closed; and they shall bring the

Ex 24:9-11 may have been allowed special access to the lower level of the City—a City only inhabited by immortals.
After all, the gates of the City are on the lower level of the City. Mortal kings might be allowed access to this lower
level for trading purposes in exchange for the glorious cargo they bring into the City. The 3D City will be the center
for interplanetary and interdimensional trade. Lucifer was corrupted by this type of trade. But co-glorified human
immortals will be incorruptible. Yet overcomers will be very much involved in trading: ruling over cities, planets,
galaxies, and universes, necessitating a Planetary World Wide Web (PWWW) and eventually a Multiverse Wide
Web (MWW). Mortal kings will be susceptible to corruption during the millennial state, which would be a plausible
contributing factor to the rebellion at the end of the millennial. During the eternal state, however, sin will be
removed, and even mortals will no longer be subject to corruption. Business will be conducted sinlessly,
nevertheless profitably. The Lord expects us to trade and make a profit for the sake of His kingdom (Mt 25:14-30).
The present is preparation for the future.
                                                      Conclusion
        In this chapter, we have seen that the three-sectioned Jewish temple has variable typological overlaps to the
three-tiered Heavenly Jerusalem, Earthly Jerusalem, and outer darkness, depending upon the vantage point and/or
level of zoom and detail being considered. Not surprisingly, the three-decked Ark and three-tiered City and three-
section temple all have plausible typological convergences between them. Typological connections between the
earthly Mount Sinai and heavenly Mount Zion were also demonstrated. Indeed, arguable grounds for thinking that
a literal overlap may have occurred with the bottom corner of the heavenly Mount Zion with the top of the earthly
Mount Sinai were considered. This chapter also hypothesized the duality of the Heavenly City in terms of its shape
and dimensionality, postulating that the City can simultaneously be in two locations at one time, with the 3D version
operating in our 3D space while the 4D version is situated on Planet Paradise in a 4D dimension that houses our
multiverse. The 3D Pyramidal City can be used as a means of access to the 4D Cubical City just as pyramidal
stargates can be used to access the Heavenly City. The duality and typology of the Earthly Eden and Emerald Eden
were also explored, each with their respective expulsions of the sons of God. Although preference was given to the
two-garden hypothesis, the link between the Celestial City and the Terrestrial Garden was inferred to be literal, not
merely typological. The Celestial City was deemed to be accessible through a ziggurat in the Garden of Eden.
        Such ziggurats and their associated stargates were deduced to be originally designed by God and then
constructed and used by the angelic sons of God for intergalactic travel and for accessing the Heavenly City. The
Angel of the Lord, along with other angelic gods and goddesses, probably used such a ziggurat to come and go to
the Garden of Eden and converse with Adam and Eve. Jacob saw God (in the person of the Lord Jesus) standing as
the Angel of the Lord at the top of such a ziggurat in his dream. Jointly from Jesus’ statement to Nathaniel about
this incident in Jn 1:51and from His follow-up statement to Nicodemus in Jn 3:13, we can safely infer that Jesus is
capable of being in multiple places at one time. He can be in the Heavenly City, for example, while at the same time
being on Earth. The angels can be observed going back and forth to Him in both locations via the ziggurat.
Seemingly, just as Jesus can stand at the top of the ziggurat in a glorified form and simultaneously stand at
the bottom of the ziggurat in an earthly form, the City can synchronously exist on Planet Paradise in the 4D
form while existing in our universe in a 3D form and with ziggurat stargates giving access to both forms and
between both forms concurrently. As humanity spreads throughout the multiverse, the need for trade and
communication will greatly increase. If the City can be in two places at once, why not three, four, or more places
at once? The conjecture was offered that copies of the 3D New Jerusalem above Earth will be replicated above
other planets throughout the multiverse to accommodate such needs, probably with accompanying ziggurats with
attendant stargates to access those 3D Cities.

                        Chapter 6. New Jerusalem in the Future
                                                    Introduction
       The preliminary interactions with Revelation enjoined in the discussion thus far have laid a foundation for
observations to be made now as our focus on the Heavenly City turns to Revelation itself. John himself uses
preliminary texts in his opening chapters to introduce the Heavenly City as a reward before he focuses on the City
as the pinnacle of rewards in his closing chapters.
                                               Primary Preliminary
       The principle precursory texts that he uses to whet our appetite for further revelation regarding the Heavenly
City are the following:

                 •   To him who overcomes, I will grant to eat of the tree of life, which is in the Paradise of God.
                     (Rev 2:7).
                 •   He who overcomes, I will make him a pillar in the temple of My God, and he will not go out
                     from it anymore; and I will write upon him the name of My God, and the name of the city of
                     My God, the new Jerusalem, which comes down out of heaven from My God, and My new
                     name. (Rev 3:12)
                 •   He who overcomes, I will grant to him to sit down with Me on My throne, as I also overcame
                     and sat down with My Father on His throne. (Rev 3:21)

       These verses foretell spatial rewards: (1) the Paradise of God, (2) the City of God, and (3) Jesus’ throne. In
the center of these spatial promises is an explicit reference to the Heavenly City itself, New Jerusalem. This promise
regarding the City is not made in a vacuum but prepares for a climax that has been anticipated by the Jewish people
from their inception and thus for millennia regarding this Reward City. This epistle, accordingly, is addressed to
believers who would be very familiar with this tradition regarding the Jerusalem Above as an anticipated reward
for the saints. The reference to the Paradise of God would be associated with this Garden City. The reference to
sitting on a heavenly throne would likewise be anticipated to relate to this Heavenly City.
                                                Secondary Preliminary
       After making these initial references to the City, John uses a secondary intermediate text a few chapters later
to tantalize the readers of Revelation with an allusion to the Heavenly City. The veiled reference to the City should
be apparent to the astute reader since the City is where God’s throne is located and where the water of life originates:
        13
          And one of the elders answered, saying to me, “These who are clothed in the white robes, who are
        they, and from where have they come?” 14 And I said to him, “My lord, you know.” And he said to
        me, “These are the ones who come out of the great tribulation, and they have washed their robes and
        made them white in the blood of the Lamb. 15 “For this reason, they are before the throne of God;
        and they serve Him day and night in His temple; and He who sits on the throne shall spread His
        tabernacle over them. 16 “They shall hunger no more, neither thirst anymore; neither shall the sun beat
        down on them, nor any heat; 17 for the Lamb in the center of the throne shall be their shepherd, and
        shall guide them to springs of the water of life; and God shall wipe every tear from their eyes.”
        (Rev 7:13-17)

The reference to being clothed in white robes would recall the previous references made in the opening chapters:

    •        4
               But you have a few people in Sardis who have not soiled their garments; and they will walk with Me in
             white; for they are worthy. 5 He who overcomes shall thus be clothed in white garments; and I will not
             erase his name from the book of life, and I will confess his name before My Father, and before His angels.
             (Rev 3:4-5)
    •        18
                I advise you to buy from Me gold refined by fire, that you may become rich, and white garments, that
             you may clothe yourself, and that the shame of your nakedness may not be revealed; and eye salve to anoint
             your eyes, that you may see. (Rev 3:18)
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                     Page 206
The misthological nature of the Reward City and the items within the Reward City are thus indicated with a wide
variety of literary images that anticipate literal fulfillment. We will really sit on literal thrones in a literal City and
literally drink the water of life. This paradise is real.
                                                     Tree of Life
       John will go on to include several more references to the Tree of life in his climax at the end of Revelation
(22:2,14,19). The first passage associates the tree with the City. The second passage makes it clear that the tree is a
reward and associates it with the reward of entering the City by its gates. The third passage ties the tree and City
together as being forfeitable rewards:

       •    2
              In the middle of its street, the tree of life ran along on both sides of the river, bearing twelve
            kinds of fruit, yielding a different kind each month; and the leaves of the tree were for the healing
            of the nations. (Rev 22:2; TM)
       •    14
               Blessed are those who wash their robes, that they may have the right to the tree of life, and may
            enter by the gates into the city. (Rev 22:14)
       •    19
               And if anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God shall take away
            his part from the tree of life and from the holy city, which are written in this book. (Rev 22:19)

        As noted in TOD, having a portion in the Tree of Life in Rev 22:19 is a reward for faithfulness, as proven by
the background for eating from the Tree of Life in Rev 2:7. Only believers who overcome (i.e., who endure to the
end, who are faithful) will have the privilege of eating from the tree and entering the City. The reward of having a
portion in the Tree of Life means to eat from the tree and have a right to the Tree of Life (Rev 2:7; 22:2,14). The
intended application of the warning must be to believers since unbelievers do not have a part (meros) in the Tree
of Life to lose. One cannot lose something one does not have; one must at least potentially have it. Correspondently,
the reward of having a portion in the Heavenly City (Rev 22:19) should be understood similarly as having the
misthopological right to participate in and experience the City. The idea of entering the City but not being rewarded
with the City would be as foreign as the notion of being given access to the fruit and being allowed to hold and lick
it but not being allowed to eat it. Exclusion from one is best understood as exclusion from the other. Immortals who
fail to overcome will not be allowed into the City or to eat its fruit. This book of prophecy, Revelation, was addressed
to and given to believers. The warning against tampering with the message of the book is thus likewise intended for
believers. Genuine believers are in danger of losing their right to this tree; unbelievers have no right to this tree to
lose.
        According to Rev 2:7, the Tree of Life is (now—note the present tense) in the Paradise of God. The Tree of
Life is in the Holy City (Rev 22:14). A simple deduction is that the Paradise of God is in the Holy City. It is there
now and will be there in the future. Speaking of the present time period, Paul says that when he was caught up to
the third heaven, it was to Paradise (2Cor 12:2,4). Where is the third heaven? The same place you will find
Paradise—the Heavenly Jerusalem. Paul was caught up to Paradise; he did not descend down to Paradise. We may
deduce that Paradise had been transferred to the Heavenly City. This deduction is confirmed by Heb 12:22-23,
where the text explicitly confirms that the departed spirits of the righteous currently inhabit the Heavenly Jerusalem.
                                                  Pillar and Name
       As to being made a pillar in Rev 3:12, the promise must be understood as denoting both prominence and
permanence. The promise to faithful believers is that they will receive both permanence and prominence. They will
be given prominence permanently. As believers, they have eternal security soteriologically. As faithful believers,
they will have eternal security misthologically. This is simply another way of saying that rewards are eternal. These
rewards will not fade away with the passage of time. As John had noted earlier in his gospel, if anyone serves Jesus,
then God will honor him (Jn 12:26). The point being stressed in 3:12 is the permanence of that prominence.
       Rev 3:12 clearly says that only overcomers will have God’s name written upon them. This verse is
particularly interesting because it says that overcomers will be made a pillar in the temple “and not go out from it
anymore.” This appears to be a promise that the overcomers’ reward will be forevermore. It will be eternal and
thus not be obliterated at the end of the millennium. This conclusion is strongly supported by the next part of the
verse, which says that the name written on the overcomer will not only be the name of God but also “the name of
the city of My God, the New Jerusalem, which comes down out of heaven from My God, and My new name.”
This promise to the overcomers concerning the names written on them is associated with the New Jerusalem and
Chapter 6. New Jerusalem in the Future                                                                        Page 207
the eternal age, not the Heavenly Jerusalem and the millennium age. This eternal reward of having the name of God
during the eternal state is promised to overcomers, not subcomers.
                                                        Throne
       Not all believers will sit with Jesus on His throne (Rev 3:21). Only those believers who endure with Him will
rule with Him (2Tim 2:12). This rulership involves sitting on thrones. Other details also convey this ruling authority.
                        Illustration 57. Johannine Definition of Overcomer in Revelation




       Without going into all the technical details presented in TOD, summation will suffice. The parallel text in
Rev 2:26 can either be translated in the manner above or as: “I will give authority over the nations to him—the one
who overcomes and keeps My works until the end.” Kai need not necessarily be rendered epexegetically to show
that the overcomer and keeper are not two different people. The promise is made to the individual who is both an
overcomer and keeper. The keeper is not another group or person.
       Being co-seated with Christ at the right hand of the Father presently and positionally (Eph 1:20; 2:6; Col 3:1)
does not guarantee that the believer will be co-seated with Him millennially or experientially (Rev 3:21). Certain
things are true of us positionally (and potentially) that will only become true of us experientially if we overcome.
Believers do not yet rule over the nations, nor are they yet seated with Christ in the sense of ruling in this capacity.
                                              Preliminary Location
       As already noted, Jerusalem will remain cloaked in orbit above the Earth after the rapture and during the
duration of the tribulation.302 What would that mean regarding the War in Heaven that will occur during that time
period?
      7
        And there was war in heaven, Michael and his angels waging war with the dragon. And the dragon
      and his angels waged war, 8 and they were not strong enough, and there was no longer a place found
      for them in heaven. 9 And the great dragon was thrown down, the serpent of old who is called the
      devil and Satan, who deceives the whole world; he was thrown down to the earth, and his angels were
      thrown down with him. 10 And I heard a loud voice in heaven, saying, “Now the salvation, and the
      power, and the kingdom of our God and the authority of His Christ have come, for the accuser of our
      brethren has been thrown down, who accuses them before our God day and night. 11 And they
      overcame him because of the blood of the Lamb and because of the word of their testimony.”
      (Rev 12:7-11)
Future
        Commentators are divided as to when this War in Heaven took/takes place. Two popular options are to place
it in the precosmic past or in the future, midway through the tribulation.303 I am inclined to take it dually both ways:
a future replay of what occurred in the past. Wiersbe, for instance, while taking the futuristic interpretation, notes
its connection with the past:

             The next scene in this cosmic drama is a war in heaven (Rev. 12:7–12). Scripture makes it clear
      that Satan has access to heaven even today (Job 1–2). Once he was the highest of God’s angels, but he
      rebelled against God and was cast down (Isa. 14:12–15). Interestingly, as God’s church faithfully
      serves Christ and wins the lost, Satan is also cast down and defeated (Luke 10:1–2, 17–20; Matt. 16:18;

   See Illustration 7. Migration of Jerusalem, 36.

         note also 12:29)…
         …. Apparently, the devil’s hatred of Israel will spur him to make one final assault against the throne

                But perhaps there is another factor involved in this war. After the church is taken to heaven,

Linking Lucifer’s defeat and expulsion from Heaven with the future Bema is common. Tatford accordingly offers

                The reason for the conflict is not stated. Possibly Satan’s last appearance in the heavenly

       Vacendak (GNTC) concurs with the futuristic interpretation of the fall and its connection to Dan 12:1. Yet
this Danielic verse is followed by the Jacobian Bema at the end of the tribulation (Dan 12:2). The timing of Satan’s
expulsion seems to occur in conjunction with (1) a preliminary Bema (or at least sorting) for those OT saints not
yet raised from the dead during the first half of the tribulation, (2) the completion of the Bema for church age
believers who have been raised from the dead, and (3) the rapture of the 144,000.
       To summarize from a popular futuristic perspective, such as GNTC, Rev 12:1-5 covers the OT period until
the beginning of the church age. Rev 12:6 moves to the midpoint of the tribulation, with the flight of the woman
(representing the believing remnant of Israel), which will take place immediately after the Antichrist enters the
rebuilt Jewish temple and declares himself to be god at the midpoint of the tribulation. Rev 12:7-8 describes the
war in Heaven that culminates with the expulsion of Satan at this midpoint in Rev 12:9-10. Rev 12:13 continues
with Satan’s persecution of the fleeing woman now that he has been cast down to Earth.
Past
       Paige Patterson acknowledges that the futuristic interpretation of the war as the final assault is most popular,
but he believes the war took place in the past, which would make it the first assault:

                The vast majority of interpreters see this occurrence as Satan’s final assault on heaven. It
         will take place during these latter days of the tribulation, perhaps at the end. There is some reason for
         that interpretation, which is found in the general rejoicing that follows in heaven and in the greater
         fury of Satan magnified in v. 12 as well as the statement that “he knows that his time is short.”
         Furthermore, the sequential reading of the text favors such a view.
                For example, Bullinger has a protracted discussion of the futile attempts of Satan to sabotage
         God’s program of redemption through the ages. He notes that Michael initiates this final conquest,
         which is resisted unsuccessfully by Satan. Walvoord favors this view as do most premillennialists.
                However, there is another possibility. Perhaps this event is not future but past, designed to
         provide explanation not only for the present experiences of John’s readers but also for all that would
         happen in the last days. As such, its nature is like an instant video replay whereby a viewer observes
         an event that took place only minutes before or maybe even days or weeks before and later is replayed
         on the screen for the observer. My own sense of the passage is that this is still further evidence of
         the precosmic move of Satan to try to displace God, which in his plan and its failure provides the
         explanation for the upheaval experienced by earth dwellers and all the creation of God since that day.
         There was in fact a confrontation in heaven. Michael, the leading angel of God, along with his

304
      Frederick A. Tatford, The Revelation (Minneapolis: Klock and Klock Christian Publishers, 1983), 376.
Chapter 6. New Jerusalem in the Future                                                                      Page 209
      angels, fought against the dragon. While there was a legitimate conflict, Satan finds himself arrested
      and hurled to the earth. He then inaugurates his program of deceiving the whole earth, but in heaven
      there is rejoicing. (NAC)

       Likewise, in Rev 9:1, Paige Patterson looks back to the past and states: “Many commentators believe this
reference is to a precosmic confrontation referenced in Jude 6 and 2 Pet 2:4. I would also make the connection,
which few other theologians now endorse, that the fall of Satan in view here is also the background behind the
judgments on the kings of Babylon and Tyre respectively in Isaiah 14 and Ezekiel 28” (NAC). In TOD, I was
inclined to follow this line of thinking in simplistically linking Rev 9:1-2 to 12:9-12. However, unlike Patterson, at
that time, I was inclined to place them both in the future. Herein, I am not inclined to do so. Moreover, the fallen
angel of 9:1-2 is Apollyon (Rev 9:11) and need not be equated with Satan (GNTC).
Past and Future Combination
      Other interpreters split the timeframe and place the war in Rev 12:7-8 in the future but the expulsion in
Rev 12:9-10 in the past. Tony Evans is a case in point:

             12:9 Satan s expulsion from heaven is the same episode referenced in Isaiah 14:12-15 and
      Revelation 9:1, which occurred sometime before the fall of mankind (see Gen 3). At that time, Satan
      was thrown to earth, and his fallen angels with him. Since then, his chief strategy has been to act as
      the one who deceives the whole world….
             12:10 Another strategy of Satan’s is to be the accuser of believers (see Zech 3:1-7), accusing
      them before our God day and night. This indicates, first, that God has allowed Satan access to his
      divine presence. Second, it indicates Satan uses that access to level accusations against God’s people.
      He does that because he knows the Lord’s righteous character and that human sin breaks their
      fellowship with God. If Satan cannot prevent a person from being saved, he at least wants to steal the
      joy that comes from walking in fellowship with God. (TEBC, emphasis his.)

Further compounding the timeframe, even though Evans places the expulsion in the past, he links it with the future
Bema. Regardless of the timeframe, surely Satan was/is not expelled in the past or future without a fight. Evans is
on the correct track in linking the past and future.
Past and Future Duality
       Timothy Alberino poses a duality.305 His presentation at the True Legends Conference in 2019 was excellent.
Therein, he noted that “prophecy is esoteric by design” (emphasis his), “oracles are encrypted” (that require
extraction like a zipped folder on a computer), and “contain multiple layers of meanings” (often dealing with Israel
on the surface layer but with nonhuman agencies or pre-Adamic events at deeper levels). References to Edom are
often “portrayed in a cosmic context” and surreptitiously interweave descriptions of a cosmic war. The red dragon
in Rev 12:3 is directly associated with Edom. The seven-headed dragon represents Leviathan as an Edomite
confederacy. The Galactic War of Edom has a juxtaposition between its beginning and end, portrayed together in
Rev 12, with the first cosmic battle being described in Rev 12:3-4 and the last cosmic battle in Rev 12:7-9. As to
dualism, the male child is both Christ and Adam. The woman giving birth to the child is both Israel and Eve. An
intentional correlation between the past and future is intended.306
       My sense of the passage is that it is intended to depict both the first conflict and expulsion and the final
conflict and expulsion in an overlapping duality. We also find evidence of this duality in Eze 28:16-17. Langford
believes Eze 28:16, in conjunction with Is 14:12 and Rev 12:7ff, awaits future fulfillment. He interjects his
discussion of Is 14:12 and states:

       Langford proceeds to place the fulfillment of Eze 28:18 in the future also, when the Antichrist-Satan is
“destroyed by fire” yet “continues to exist in hell” (p. 173). Naturally, he places the ultimate fulfillment of Eze 28:19
in the future, when Satan is cast into the Lake of Fire forever. Such points are valid. Nevertheless, the matter is not
that simple.
       Dill quotes the NIV and NAS for Eze 28:16-17, which places it in the past. Yet he goes on to explain that the
remainder of the passage is difficult to interpret because some of it appears to be past, and some of it appears
to be future (pp. 254, 264). Yates places this event in the past (KL 904). RETs and translations are divided as to
whether Eze 28:16-17 is past or future. Commentators who take the Luciferian interpretation of the passage are
divided. McGee (TTBC) takes as future. Dyer (BKC) is ambiguous:

                 Though Ezekiel presented the fall of Satan as a single act, it actually occurred in stages. Satan’s
         initial judgment was his expulsion from the position of God’s anointed cherub before His throne. God
         expelled him from the mount of God (heaven, v. 16; cf. v. 14). Satan was cast from God’s government
         in heaven (cf. Luke 10:18) but was still allowed access to God (cf. Job 1:6–12; Zech. 3:1–2). In the
         Tribulation Satan will be cast from heaven and restricted to the earth (Rev. 12:7–13); in the Millennium
         he will be in the bottomless pit (Rev. 20:1–3); and after his brief release at the end of the Millennium
         (Rev. 20:7–9) he will be cast into the lake of fire forever (Rev. 20:10). (Bold his.)

Actually, Ezekiel is ambiguous as to singular versus multiple fulfillments. The Greek uses the aorist indicative,
indicating the past. The Hebrew uses the imperfect in v. 16, which is incomplete action and could be past or future,
but the perfect is used in v. 17, which is completed past action. Ezekiel seems to be presenting an incomplete-
completed judgment, a dual perspective. Likewise, although the Greek uses the future for Is 14:15, the Hebrew
imperfect allows past, present, or future fulfillment. Some translations (ESV, NIV) put it in the present (which
would be understood as having occurred in the past); others (NKJ, NAS) put it in the future. Translations are also
divided on whether Is 14:12 is present/past or future. Again, dual fulfillment is suggested.

                                     Illustration 58. Duality of War in Heaven




        Just as Lucifer and his fallen angels were cast out of Heavenly Jerusalem to Planet Rahab in a precosmic
battle, Satan and his fallen angels will be cast out of Heaven by the Heavenly Jerusalem to Earth. Being cast down
to Earth suggests being confined to Earth. This implication is made explicit in Rev 12:8: “There was no longer a
place found for them in heaven.” Accordingly, commentators of Revelation acknowledge this confinement to Earth.
How is it accomplished, though? Various theories are posed. One hypothesis is that fallen forces will have their
ability to shift into another dimension removed. Some liken this dimensional shift to being able to tune your radio
from AM to PM. Their radio will be busted, so to speak. Some interpreters pose that the same thing will happen to
their spaceships. Their UFOs will no longer be able to perform a dimensional shift. They will be stuck in 3D space.
Scripture indicates that fallen angels can be confined to 3D bodies that are capable of death: “You are gods, and all
of you are sons of the Most High. Nevertheless you will die like men, and fall like any one of the princes” (Ps 82:6-
7). If their bodies can be subject to 3D death, then surely their spaceships can be subject to 3D destruction.
Nevertheless, at this point in this futuristic war, their spaceships (or at least many of them) will probably not be
destroyed, only confined to Earth’s atmosphere and orbit to contribute to the Great Deception (2Thess 2:11).
Although like myself, L. A. Marzulli believes in a pretribulational rapture, he cites evidence that the first stages of
UFO official disclosure have already begun. Even so, I suspect that full disclosure will probably not occur until the
rapture. Even then, it will probably be on a comparatively small-scale basis. The widespread saturation on Earth’s
atmosphere and orbit with UFOs will probably occur seven years later at the midpoint of the tribulation when all
surviving fallen alien spacecraft are confined to Earth.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                      Page 212
                                         Illustration 59. Duality of Incarceration




       But if the past War in Heaven I (WIH-1) will be like the future War in Heaven II (WIH-2), then how could
Lucifer be confined to Earth during WIH-1? One possibility is that after the destruction of Planet Rahab, Lucifer
was thrown into a subterranean prison, perhaps Tartarus (2Pet 2:4), that could hold 4D prisoners below the waters
engulfing Earth. A second possibility is that Lucifer was limited to a 3D body and frozen in the waters that engulfed
Earth. In the latter case, after the waters from Planet Rahab engulfed Earth, the waters would have frozen in short
order, given the darkness that likewise engulfed Earth. McLaughlin describes this type of frozen incarceration:

         God tossed the fallen angels from the heavens down to planet Earth which may have existed
         for millions of years.
                Sometime afterward, He packed planet Earth with ice, thus imprisoning His rebellious
         creatures. After a holding period (perhaps millions of years), God began the act of setting up the
         courtroom and allowing the conflict to take on a course to prove that He is righteous and just.
         Mankind was then created after all was prepared and the battle lines had lines had been set upon
         planet Earth.
                It is interesting to think about Satan in a state of frozen incarceration, yelling into the darkness,
         “Let there be light!” time and time again, and of course nothing ever happened. The frustration must
         have escalated day after day, and year after year….God shut the source of light and heat off as easily
         as pulling a plug on a lamp. He peppered the earth with fire and hail stones, and for the grand finale
         our Lord froze it all over like icing on a cake. Satan and his army were probably thrown about like
         ragdolls. Completely in disarray and despair. Satan had to have felt a bitter and deep sting of utter
         helplessness.308

       Whether below water or below ice or in ice, Lucifer was incarcerated on or below Earth at the conclusion of
WIH-1. Likewise, he and his fallen forces will be thrown down to Earth again at the conclusion of WIH-2. During
the process of this war, Satan’s fallen forces will be forced to retreat to Earth. A force field in the form of an
interdimensional barrier, tuned into their fallen frequency and blocking that frequency, will probably be placed
around Earth to prevent them from leaving Earth and to prevent them from doing any dimensional shifting. They
will be stuck in our 3D dimension. Possibly, this would mean that 10 billion fallen angels will be visibly confined
to Earth at this time: some below ground, some on the ground, and some in the air. Their spaceships are pictured
on the right as locked into orbit around Earth by a force field that prevents them from leaving Earth.

Dual Hiding of the Bride
       Even though Berner (TFOT) believes the war is exclusively future, he acknowledges a typological connection
with the past throughout the context. For example, concerning the woman giving birth, he believes there is a “partial
typological past fulfillment by Mary,” but the actual literal fulfillment fitting the specifics of the passage is the
nation of Israel. As to the offspring of the woman, a “dual nature has been true ever since Eve gave birth to her
children.” “A typical interpretation is that this sign is looking back in history to the birth of Jesus Christ with the
woman being either Israel of the Virgen Mary….This is all well and good at the most superficial level, but if the
passage is typological, it cannot be limited to that level.” Berner then proceeds to demonstrate convincingly that the
raptured child in Rev 12:5 must be the Bride of Christ. The ascension of Christ after His resurrection was only a
typological foreshadowing of this rapture, at which time ‘the Bride of Christ…enters its chambers in heaven to hide
for a short time.’”309
       On the other hand, Chitwood (TOTE) notes the model posed by Berner but rejects it. After first noting that
many regard the man-child to be Christ, he also points out that some commentators believe it to be overcomers,
which is what Berner poses, but Chitwood rejects this interpretation as well:

            Then again, co-heirs with Christ have a similar connection with Israel, are given the same
      promise relative to ruling the nations, and will be caught up into heaven as well (Gal. 3:29;
      I Thess. 4:16, 17; Rev. 2:26, 27). And this has led some commentators and Bible students to associate
      the man-child with Christians being removed in what they would see as a selective rapture of Christians
      (though this would be completely out of place, for all Christians will have previously been removed
      from the earth; and, aside from this fact, selective rapture is not taught in Scripture anyway).310

Chitwood is correct to reject a partial rapture. See my book DFS for a defense of a full rapture. Still, that does not
prove that overcomers (i.e., co-heirs) are not in view. His second objection is that the overcomers of the church-age
would already have been raptured previously. Again, he is correct, but this objection is not fatal to the overcomer
thesis because the events of Rev 12 are not placed here in Revelation as a strict chronological sequence. Chitwood
believes the man-child is the 144,000 and that they are raptured immediately after the middle of the Tribulation “at
the time that the Jewish people in Jerusalem and Judaea flee for their lives” (TOTE, 317, emphasis his). Berner and
I would concur that the 144,000 are raptured at the middle of the tribulation.311 However, Chitwood has inverted
the order. In Rev 12:5-6, the woman gives birth and then flees. Since the birth proceeds the flight, Berner’s
contention that bridal overcomers are in view is still very plausible. These church-age overcomers could have been
raptured seven years prior to the woman’s flight. Even so, I suspect that the placement here at this point in
Revelation has chronological significance. My proposal is that the man-child dualistically represents both church-
age overcomers and the 144,000 Jewish overcomers of the tribulation. The text spans both and is placed here for
the chronological sequence of the latter. These Jewish overcomers are raptured immediately before the middle of
the tribulation (rather than after it, as Chitwood proposed). Note that in my chart of Revelation, I place their rapture
on the left side of the midpoint, indicating that they are raptured immediately before it. I am inclined to merge
Berner’s argument and Chitwood’s argument into one and thus adopt both.
        In addition to his splendid discussion, Berner provides excellent charts to which I am greatly indebted in the

symmetry complies with the duality of the hidden nature of the Bride and the as-above-so-below typology.
       At the time of the rapture, which commences the Bema, Satan immediately becomes fully engaged in Bema
proceedings atop the Heavenly City, which is in orbit above Earth. He is thoroughly immersed in accusing believers
so that they may not be considered worthy of taking his place and that of his fallen forces. In the case of believers
who were unfaithful to the Lord, Satan will win his case. Therefore, he will win most cases. However, the Lord
does not need to win the majority, only enough to qualify a remnant as the Bride to replace Satan and His fallen
forces as the incumbent rulers. At the conclusion of the Bema for church-age believers, the Lord announces that the
Bride (or at least this portion of the Bride) is now ready to assume the heavenly positions of authority occupied by
Satan and his fallen forces. Satan’s forces will not give up their positions without a fight, so war breaks out.
       Heaven is a big place. The war begins in the outer fringes, driving fallen forces from the outer realms
of the second heaven and perhaps even the outskirts of the third heaven to planet Earth. Satan, however,
though leading the war from afar, still has access to the Bema throne room atop the Heavenly City, which
remains in orbit above Earth. He still seeks to prosecute remaining believers from other dispensations who have
not yet been judged so that they may not be considered worthy of taking his place and that of his fallen forces. If
the Bema for church-age believers has been completed by this time, these accusations will pertain primarily to
believers living on the Earth during that time and dying during that time. Those dying during this time (i.e., the first
3 ½ years of the tribulation) will overcome his accusations by the blood of the Lamb and by their own martyr’s
blood (Rev 12:11). At the midpoint of the tribulation, Satan is cast out of the Bema throne room, away from the
Heavenly City to the Earth below. He and his forces will have completely lost the War in Heaven, the last stages of
which will have been going on for about 3 ½ years. He and his forces are now confined to Earth.
       With Satan cast out of Heaven and fully replaced by the Bride of Christ at this time, these fallen incumbent
rulers are removed because the Bride (or at least this portion of the Bride) is now ready to take Her rightful place
as Queen. She is joined by the 144,000 (who will perhaps add to the number of the Bride). These additional
overcomers are mentioned later as standing on Mount Zion in Rev 14:1-5, thus already occupying New Jerusalem
by that time. Therefore, I would concur with Chitwood that they are raptured at the midpoint of the tribulation. The
two witnesses are raptured a few days later.

        The above chart is but a small extract from my master chart. In this extract, I call primary attention to the
Bride of Christ Wedding Motif. I concur with Berner that the Bride of Christ Wedding Motif in Heaven spans the
entire 10 ½ +/- years of the Day of God’s Wrath (DOGW). In short, the Wedding Festivities last the entire 10 ½ +/-
years. However, I also call attention to the fact that the Bride’s Marriage Supper/Messianic Banquet on Earth will
last 1000 years. A mere interlude of 75 days will take place between Her Feast in Heaven and Her Banquet on Earth.
        In some of the previous models proposed in TOD and MMP1, I considered the possibility that Jesus would
intend for us to make the classical extrapolation, in terms of the parable’s applicability concerning the virgins in
Mt 25:11-12 to tribulational believers being cast out after the millennial feast starts, but I concluded that, even if
this was the case, He did not intend for us to limit ourselves to this singular perspective. One problem with such
models is that the parables seem to present the effects of the Bema as being immediately applicable. In other words,
those ejected from the wedding festivities (in the case of Mt 22:12) or rejected from the wedding feast (in the case
of Mt 25:11-12) seem to experience immediate ejection or rejection. Both the ejection and rejection are immediate.
So alternative models were considered that allowed the ejection and rejection to be immediate. Doing so is possible
if the ejection and rejection are from the Heavenly City.
        As noted in MMP1, the location could be explained as the Bema atop the Heavenly City. Still, the timing is
difficult to explain if the effects are carried out immediately rather than during the millennial kingdom. The effects
of the Bema for church-age believers would now be understood in alternate models as being carried out at the time
of the Bema. Consistency would dictate that the effects of the Jacobian Bema would also be carried out before the
Marriage Supper if one zooms in close enough through inductive extrapolation to conclude that this is the case.
Therefore, unfaithful believers would be excluded from the feast and not allowed to enter at all. In MMP1, one
alternative I considered was a Crawfordian model.

present discussion. At the time I wrote MMP1, I believed the metaphorical courtyard of Enoch and Matthew must
have been some type of literal courtyard and pictured it as such with the following illustration.

    Preliminary indications are that preliminary distinctions between the bodies of faithful and unfaithful believers
occur even before the Bema. As noted in MMP4, some eyewitness testimonies give reason to anticipate that pre-
Bema distinctions exist even during the interim state. Additionally, suppose it takes 3 1/2 years for all the raptured
believers to be judged at the Bema. The bodies of those who will be found faithful might glow in preliminary glory
even before being awarded their full misthological glory at the Bema (cp. Mt 22:10-13). Apparently, to advert
logistical problems, Salus poses that the Bema occurs during the 75-day interval between the end of the tribulation
and the start of the millennium. He also places the Marriage Supper of the Lamb during this 75-day interim time
(pp. 12, 67), thus after the seven-day Wedding Week (pp. 111-113). Salus notes that various scholars place the
Marriage Ceremony in Heaven but the Marriage Supper on Earth at the inauguration of the Millennial Kingdom
(pp. 115-117). However, he places it during the 75-day interval before the Millennial Kingdom starts because of
the logistical problems created by his supposition that the poorly dressed man attending the Marriage Supper who
is cast into the outer darkness represents an unbeliever cast into Hell. His interpretation is untenable if the Marriage
Supper is in Heaven since only believers enter Heaven. His interpretation also fails if the Marriage Supper starts on
Earth after the Millennial Kingdom commences since only believers are allowed into the Millennial Kingdom.
Thus, because Salus equates the outer darkness with Hell, he is forced to place the Marriage Supper on Earth during
the 75 days before the Millennial Kingdom. Bill Salus, The Millennium Prophecies and the New Jerusalem, Kindel
Edition (La Quinta, CA: Prophecy Depot Publishers, 2021).
       I have argued otherwise in TOD and elsewhere. The Marriage Feast is in Heaven, and the Marriage Supper
is on Earth. Salus is correct on these two matters. However, he is forcing the text into an unnatural time slot to pose
that the Marriage Supper starts before the Millennial Kingdom. The scholars he cites who pose that the Marriage
Supper inaugurates with the Millennial Kingdom are much more astute in their timing of the Marriage Supper. The
poorly dressed man is not cast out until after the Marriage Supper has started. The Marriage Supper does not start
until the Millennial Kingdom starts. Therefore, the poorly dressed man is a believer who is allowed into the
Millennial Kingdom but cast out of the place in the Millennial Kingdom where the Marriage Supper is celebrated.
       In the parable, the poorly dressed man is not cast out of the king’s kingdom. He stays in the kingdom but is
cast out of that part of the kingdom where the Marriage Supper is celebrated. Accordingly, the most natural
conclusion is that he is not cast out of the Millennial Kingdom but into a Terrestrial Outer Darkness. This darkness
is misthological, not soteriological. Salus fuses his soteriology and misthology into one, thus confusing the issues.
Other examples of his soteric-mistholic fusion-confusion include his posing that all believers are overcomers in the
sense described by Revelation and his assuming that all believers are part of the Bride as described by Revelation.
His misthology is very weak since he poses that the Bema is a mere purification process rather than a punishment
scenario (p. 228). His soteriology is poisoned since he makes Heaven conditioned on overcoming the obstacles
described by Revelation. A correct misthology has a propensity to purify one’s soteriology. Consequently, a correct
understanding of the outer darkness will help some escape Hell by understanding that the outer darkness is not Hell.

       In my opinion, faithful believers will probably not die during the millennial age. Rebellious believers will be
killed during the millennial age. All rebellious believers who live until the end of the millennial kingdom will be
involved in the rebellion when Satan is loosed at the end of the 1000 years. They will all be killed in that rebellion.
They will be summoned from the Celestial Outer Darkness for this judgment. Thus, Satan will be used, unwittingly,
to remove covertly rebellious believers from the kingdom by means of overt rebellion. God will use Satan as a
broom to sweep them into temporal destruction resulting in misthological destruction.
       The spatial scene for this judgment is described in Rev 20:11: “And I saw a great white throne and Him who
sat upon it, from whose presence earth and heaven fled away, and no place was found for them.” Aune (WBC)
says, “The location of the throne is necessarily vague, since heaven and earth have been destroyed” (emphasis his).
True, but this description does not mean that the judgment does not take place in a place, just that the place is
beyond our 3D realm and not part of the heavenly realm. Our universe is apparently destroyed. It is removed from
the multiverse. There is no need to move those being judged to the heavenly realm or another universe in the
multiverse to judge them. The notion that God is aspatial is nonsensical. This judgment will take place in a real
place, just not a place that currently exists. God could simply create a large stadium suspended in a sphere in which
to place His Great White Throne.
       This no-place, place-of-judgment is pictured as a 4D space in a self-contained 4D sphere in the illustration.
The 3D Heavenly City is not in the picture and is not a factor. In the illustration, note that the only object in the
sphere is the Great White Throne. The 3D City is probably not even in existence during this time. My theory is that
the 3D City is used as an interface with 3D reality. Since 3D reality is being wiped out and undergoing a
transformation during this time, the 3D City is unnecessary. Instead, the inhabitants of the Heavenly City are in
their 4D Heavenly City while the Great White Throne Judgement is taking place and our universe is being destroyed
with fire, in preparation for the new heavens and new Earth in the eternal state (2Pet 3:7,10-12). This judgment has
nothing to do with the Heavenly Jerusalem, either in its 3D or 4D form. Therefore, the 3D City is not pictured as
existing, and no arrow is drawn from the 4D City. The 4D Great White Throne will not be subject to the flames that
destroy our universe, and the flames will not apply to eternity future. Both these exclusions from the flames are
indicated by the illustration.

        After the first heavens and Earth have passed away in a roar of fire, 3D New Jerusalem will come out of
Heaven to the new Earth: “And I saw a new heaven and a new earth; for the first heaven and the first earth passed
away, and there is no longer any sea. And I saw the holy city, new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from
God, made ready as a bride adorned for her husband” (Rev 21:1-2, cp. 21:10). My speculation, as noted in the
illustration, is that the 3D City will serve as the space vehicle for the stationary 4D City. We will discuss the bridal
nature of the City in the next chapter. For now, though, we will consider possible objections to the proposed model.
        As noted in MMP1, regarding the parabolic imagery that Jesus uses for the second occurrence of the outer
darkness (with the possible Enochian backdrop), it must be remembered that the outer darkness is simply the outer
court (i.e., the courtyard) of the palace where the feast is being prepared. Significantly, 2 Enoch also uses this
imagery. Friends wait outside in the darkness of the courtyard while dinner is being prepared inside the palace. To
be cast into the outer darkness after dinner starts would simply picture being cast back into the place where one was
waiting before the dinner started—the courtyard outside. The added detail of being bound hand and foot means that
such outcasts would be restricted to that courtyard, which is the original location where they were waiting before
the feast started.
        In MMP5, the explanation has been modified to conclude that when unfaithful believers die, they go to be
with the Lord at Heavenly Jerusalem, but they do not reside in the Heavenly City. Rather, they reside outside the
City in the outer court, that is, the planets in the outer realm. Faithful believers are allowed preliminary residency
inside the City. Once the Bema commences, those believers found to be unfaithful will be cast back into this outer
courtyard (i.e., the Celestial Outer Darkness). I have labeled this courtyard as the outer darkness, even in the current
time period, because it is not inside the City. During the tribulation and even during the millennium, this sector will
function in both a positive and negative manner. Those believers who die during the tribulation will reside in the
courtyard until they are judged at the end of the tribulation. Those believers who die during the millennium will
reside in the courtyard until they are judged at the end of the millennium. Those believers who do poorly at their
respective judgments will be sent back to the courtyard and sentenced to live there eternally.
        Several points in favor of this model may be briefly mentioned. First, unfaithful believers are told that they
will never enter the promised rest (Ps 95:11; Heb 3:11; 4:3,5). Consequently, among other things, they are excluded
from the City of Rest. Crawford’s model had an advantage over my original classical model in TOD in that I posed
that believers are currently in the City of Rest, only to be excluded eventually and, at that point, eternally. Granted,
their works have not yet followed with them so as to qualify or disqualified them from experiencing this City as a
place of rest/rulership (Rev 14:13), so in defense of my earlier model, one might stipulate that they are in the City,
but it has not yet become the City of Rest for them. On the other hand, the typological precedence suggested by the
Exodus generation collaborates with Crawford’s model. The unfaithful children of Israel were not living in the
Promised Land before they inherited it. Rather, they were waiting outside the Promised Land, along with the faithful
believers and the children below the age of accountability, until the judgment pronounced against the carnal
believers was completed while they were still in the wilderness. Being in the wilderness could be seen easily as a
picture of being in the outer court. Whereas in Crawford’s model, they would never be allowed into the City; in my
classic model, they would have spent the last 2,000 years in the City. His model is thus superior to my original
model in that aspect. Historically also, the groom went to get the bride and bring her to his house. She was not living
in the bridal suite before being brought to his house!
        Additionally, intertestamental support can be derived from the Enochian backdrop for the outer darkness as
being the courtyard outside. Of course, in this same passage, the king comes in and finds the unworthy guest “in
here,” which most naturally, given the paradigm by Crawford and myself, would be the Reward City (Mt 22:12).
This parabolic detail, if pressed to that extent, could be seen as supporting my original model. Yet those who prefer
the Crawfordian model might suggest that being at the Bema atop the City might qualify sufficiently for this
parabolic detail. Even I would anticipate that the Wedding Feast will take place at this Bema stadium. MMP1
calculated and found that there is plenty of room for it there. And MMP4 posed that the tables are already set for
the feast. This heavenly food will not grow stale or be subject to decay in that heavenly place. Thus, unfaithful
believers will be cast out from the very place where the feast will be held with tables already set for the feast. In a
very real sense, they are at the table before being cast out from the table in Mt 8:11-12. This parabolic spatial detail
need not derail this model. Therefore, this spatial observation is made in defense of the revamped Crawfordian
model.
