                            Potential Weakness in Revamped Crawfordian Model
      In MMP1, I noted the following potential objection for the Crawfordian model:

             Against the Crawfordian model, it might be noted that in the parable of the wedding feast, Jesus
      does not depict the poorly dressed believer as being cast out of the feast until after the feast has started.
      From a classical point of view, this means that this outcast is not cast out until after the millennial
      kingdom has started. Thus, if this parabolic detail is assigned chronological significance, it would pose
      a problem for Crawford’s model. How could this parable be understood as dealing with unfaithful
      church-age believers being cast into the outer darkness before the millennial kingdom commences, if
      Jesus is indicating that they are not cast out until after the millennial kingdom has started?

I went on in MMP1 to explain, on behalf of this model, that my preference for duality would allow the ejection of
unfaithful believers after the millennial kingdom started to be applicable to tribulational believers. However, as
observed in the present study, the problem with that defense of the Crawfordian model is that the effects of the
Jacobean Bema appear to be carried out before the millennium starts, thus invaliding that added defense of his
model. Notwithstanding, the present study adds several additional arguments in favor of that aspect of the
Crawfordian model and thus for the modified model proposed herein.

•   First, the ejection of unfaithful church-age believers from the Bema atop the Heavenly City back to the outer
    realms of Heaven (i.e., to the Celestial Outer Darkness) is carried out during the Bride of Christ Wedding Motif.
    This fits very well with the parabolic detail in Mt 22:1-13. The king’s son is not the one who comes in to inspect
    the wedding guest. The prince is consummating his union with His bride. During this time, the king comes in
    and examines the dinner guests who are gathered to celebrate the feast once the consummation has been
    completed. The unworthy attendee is cast out while the king’s son is consummating this union. This would
    place it during the Bema proceedings.
•   Second, unfaithful believers dying during the tribulation (and thus during the Bride of Christ Wedding Feast)
    are sent to the Celestial Outer Darkness during the Bride of Christ’s Wedding Feast in a pre-Bema sorting.
    Thus, duality allows their exclusion to be applicable to that extent and certainly seems to fulfill the parabolic
    picture of their being left standing outside the wedding celebration in Mt 25:1-13.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 228
                                         Illustration 70. Tribulational Outer Darkness




•   Third, the 144,000 are Jewish virgins raptured halfway through the tribulation, while unfaithful believers are
    not. Unfaithful tribulational believers are left on Earth at this midpoint partial rapture and not allowed to enter
    the heavenly wedding festivities. Thus, these unfaithful tribulational believers would also fit the parabolic
    imagery of standing outside. Additionally, they are told to go and buy what they need in order to qualify to
    enter, which fits the midpoint motif. Therefore, Mt 25:1-13 would be applicable to them from this perspective
    also. Consequently, a partial rapture occurs at this juncture, but it is not the partial rapture typically postulated
    by advocates of the partial rapture position. Rather, I pose that the full rapture of church-age believers in
    1Thess 5:9-10, at the commencement of the ten years of the Day of God’s Wrath (DOGW), will be followed
    by a partial rapture at the midpoint of the seven years of tribulation for those believers who are alive during the
    tribulation. The 144,000 Jewish evangelists will begin sharing the gospel immediately after the full rapture (at
    the beginning of DOGW) but be raptured seven years later at the midpoint of the seven-year tribulation.
Chapter 6. New Jerusalem in the Future                                                                         Page 229
                                             Illustration 71. Tribulational Rapture




•   Fourth, the misthological ejection of unfaithful Jewish believers at the Jacobean Bema and unfaithful Gentile
    believers at the Sheep and Goat Judgment at the end of the tribulation occurs in the middle of the Feast-
    Banquet meal! When exactly does it occur? At the hyphen! As noted on the charts, after the Bride of Christ
    Marriage Feast, there is a pause of 75 days to judge believers before the Marriage Supper (Messianic Banquet)
    commences.
•   Fifth, for those who think this defense is too detailed, an argument could still be made that, if this microscopic
    view of the parabolic details is out of focus for the parables since the parables only intend a telescopic view,
    the ejection/rejection of unfaithful tribulational believers is presumed to be effected at the commencement of
    the millennial age.
•   Sixth, the ejection/rejection of unfaithful tribulational believers who live until the end of the tribulation will not
    be put fully into effect until the actual start of the millennial kingdom. These unfaithful believers will not be
    cast into the Terrestrial Outer Darkness (i.e., sent to live in the outer realms of the kingdom on Earth outside of
    the Promised Land) until, at a minimum, the planet is rotated so the Promised Land is at the top and the
    boundaries of the Terrestrial Outer Darkness outside the Promised Land are determined. Therefore, they are
    cast out during the Marriage Supper, which again satisfies the parabolic imagery.

                             Illustration 72. Celestial and Terrestrial Outer Darkness




To reiterate the last point, the ejection/rejection of unfaithful tribulational believers who live until the end of the
millennium cannot be put fully into effect until the actual start of the millennial kingdom. For they cannot be cast
into the Terrestrial Outer Darkness until the planet is rotated so that the Promised Land is at the top and the
boundaries of the Terrestrial Outer Darkness outside the Promised Land are determined. In that regard, they are not
cast into the outer darkness until after the Marriage Banquet has started. For unfaithful believers consigned to the
Celestial Outer Darkness, their ejection is immediate. Both details comply with parabolic expectations.
        The parabolic details provided by Mt 22:12 and Mt 25:11-12 regarding the timing and location of the
ejection/rejection of unfaithful believers are not incidental. They are beautiful ways of simplistically portraying
complex details. In effect, they are summary statements that show that those being rejected are being rejected at a
time when the focus is on misthological motifs from the vantage point of which believers are qualified to compose
the Bride. Those being judged are being judged at the time and place where, according to the parabolic vantage
point, the focus is on the believer’s worthiness to celebrate misthologically. As to the added detail of being bound
hand and foot, this binding does not mean that those cast into the Terrestrial Outer Darkness are literally bound.
Still, it is not a meaningless detail. It has literal significance. The binding means that such outcasts would be
restricted to that courtyard, not allowed to leave it and not allowed to enter the place where the celebration is being
Chapter 6. New Jerusalem in the Future                                                                          Page 231
held. Accordingly, my hypothesis is that those cast into the Terrestrial Outer Darkness will not be able to enter the
Heavenly City nor the Promised Land. Moreover, they will not be allowed to travel to other planets. They are
confined to the Terrestrial Outer Darkness of this planet. Likewise, those cast into the Celestial Outer Darkness will
not be able to enter the planetary sphere where 4D New Jerusalem is located. For that matter, they will probably
not be able to travel from one planet to another in the outer realm. They will be confined to living on one planet.
       As to the timing of Satan’s expulsion from Heaven to Earth in Rev 12:9, the casting of unfaithful believers
into the Celestial Outer Darkness as a result of judgment is at the end of the first half of the tribulation. Up until this
point in time, Satan will be busy in Heaven accusing believers day and night (Rev 12:10). His accusations are
misthological, not soteriological. As noted in TOD, this hypothesis accords well with the fact that the Bema will be
occurring in Heaven after the rapture. Also, after noting that Satan is cast out of Heaven, where he had been busy
accusing the brethren, in the very next verse John records: “They overcame him because of the blood of the Lamb
and because of the word of their testimony, and they did not love their life even to death” (Rev 12:11). One would
assume that this verse portrays how one overcomes Satan’s accusations in the previous verse.
       The courtroom scene in Heaven frequently is pictured by advocates of eternal security with Satan as the
prosecuting attorney and Jesus as the defending attorney. Satan reads the list of charges and cites the evidence
against us. Jesus counters by presenting His blood in our defense, and the Father dismisses the case as a result.
Satan loses every case against the believer. It is a wonderful picture of eternal security but probably a very shallow
presentation of what will actually occur. To be sure, I strongly affirm eternal security, and it could be that the blood
of the Lamb in 12:11 is picturing the basis of that soteriological security (cp. Rev 1:5). However, it must be noted
that the reason that these believers will successfully overcome Satan (who had been accusing them in the previous
verse) is that they are faithful even to death. It was not merely by their faith in the blood of the Lamb that they will
overcome Satan, but by their faithfulness to the blood of the Lamb. In fact, it is highly probable that the reference
to our overcoming by the blood of the Lamb is referring to our washing our own robes and making them white in
practical sanctification. This is certainly the case in Rev 7:14, which is the only other time this complete phrase is
used within Revelation.318
       Rather than thinking that Satan is merely (or even attempting) to get the Judge to send the believer to Hell (a
case Satan would lose every time), the superior supposition is that Satan actually will be dwelling on the same
subject matter that the Bema will be addressing: whether the believer is qualified to be an overcomer and thus a
millennial ruler. After all, this is the purpose of the JSC. Since the text is clear that Satan will be in Heaven accusing
believers at the time they are being judged before the JSC regarding this matter, it is reasonable to propose that he
will be making his case against us on the matter at hand. Surely, the devil will not be wasting his time on a matter
which is not even being considered and which he cannot possibly win (regarding our soteriological possession of
eternal life) when he could be investing his time in a matter where he will be able to win many cases dealing with
the loss of reward. Those believers who overcome Satan’s misthological accusations in Heaven must overcome him
by the way they live on Earth. He is our adversary, and the only way we can become rulers is to overcome this
adversary by the blood of the Lamb, the word of our testimony, and by loving the Lord more than our own lives.
This sequence of events regarding Satan’s expulsion confirms the premillennial position. I suspect that he will be
allowed to attend the judgment and function as our accuser at the JSC, but he will be excluded from the Heavenly
City when it is time for the public presentation of the Bride at the Wedding Feast, which is at the beginning of the
tribulation. A foreshadowing of what this will look like is provided by Zechariah:
         1
           Then he showed me Joshua the high priest standing before the angel of the Lord, and Satan standing
         at his right hand to accuse him. 2 And the Lord said to Satan, “The Lord rebuke you, Satan! Indeed,
         the Lord who has chosen Jerusalem rebuke you! Is this not a brand plucked from the fire?” 3 Now
         Joshua was clothed with filthy garments and standing before the angel. 4 And he spoke and said to
         those who were standing before him saying, “Remove the filthy garments from him.” Again he said to
         him, “See, I have taken your iniquity away from you and will clothe you with festal robes.” 5 Then I
         said, “Let them put a clean turban on his head.” So they put a clean turban on his head and clothed him
         with garments, while the angel of the Lord was standing by. 6 And the angel of the Lord admonished
         Joshua saying, 7 “Thus says the Lord of hosts, ‘If you will walk in My ways, and if you will perform



318
      See Rev 21:3, 242.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 232
      My service, then you will also govern My house and also have charge of My courts, and I will grant
      you free access among these who are standing here. (Zech 3:1-7)

      This foreshadowed victory before Satan will only be realized by those believers who overcome by walking
in God’s ways and performing His service. Only overcomers will be granted these festive clothes and allowed to
dine in the feast. Unfaithful believers will not be clothed in white garments and will be ejected into the outer
darkness (Mt 22:11-13).
                                                     Conclusion
       Only those believers who overcome will qualify to live in New Jerusalem. Dwelling in this City is a reward.
Hence, we can appropriately dub it the Reward City. Overcomers will be clothed in white robes and be able to eat
from the Tree of Life. Unfaithful believers, in stark contrast, will be excluded from such benefits and never be
allowed inside the City, though they may be summoned to stand trial at the Bema atop the Heavenly City before
being exiled from it permanently.
       Lucifer and his followers were cast out of the Heavenly City in their past defeat in a cosmic war that will see
him again cast from the City during the future tribulation. As a result of the first expulsion, Lucifer was incarcerated
on or below Earth. As a result of the second expulsion, Satan and his forces will be confined to Earth. During the
Bema court proceedings, Satan will be allowed to be present and level accusations against raptured believers,
seeking to disqualify them as worthy of the City. He will win the majority of the cases. Those believers found
unworthy of the City will be sent to dwell in the Celestial Outer Darkness as their eternal punishment, that is, as
their loss of reward. Those believers found worthy of the City will be able to enter it and live in it. They will
compose the Bride of Christ and be hidden in the Heavenly City until the Bema proceedings for the raptured
believers are completed. At that point, these Bridal overcomers will assume positions of authority in the City.
Cosmic war will break out, and the tribulation will start. Satan will still be allowed in the Heavenly City to bring
accusations against tribulational believers. However, he will be expelled from the City at the midpoint of the
tribulation.
       This proposal is vastly superior to some of my earlier models in which the expulsion of unfaithful believers
was delayed until the start of the millennium. The research in MMP4 has been confirmed here in MMP5 as
indicating that immediate expulsion is the superior model. Unfaithful resurrected believers found unfaithful at the
Bema will be sent to the Celestial Outer Darkness. Those believers who live until the end of the tribulation and are
judged to be unfaithful at the Jacobean Bema or Judgment of the Sheep and Goats will be sentenced to the Terrestrial
Outer Darkness, where they will remain until they die. Thereafter, they will be sent to the Celestial Outer Darkness.
The parabolic and typological courtyard to which unfaithful believers are sent can be inferred to be planets in the
outer realm of the third heaven.
       The proposal that the Heavenly City has both cubical and pyramidal features has been anticipated by others
and explained as being possible because of its multidimensionality. That proposition has been expanded in the
present chapter to postulate that the cubical dimension of the City is the principle form it has in 4D space, while the
pyramidal form of the City is the principle shape it has in 3D space. The spaceship nature of the Heavenly City has
been well attested by a variety of others. The unique proposal in the present book is that the 3D form of the City is
used as a teleportal and vehicular device used to access the 4D City. The postulation that the 4D City can
simultaneously replicate itself in its 3D form in 3D space would lead one to ponder the possibility that it might be
capable of virtually infinite reduplication in that capacity. That potentiality will be explored as a possible
practicability and perhaps even logical necessity in the next chapter.
                      Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride
                                                       Introduction
       In the concluding chapters of Revelation, at the end of the millennial kingdom and the beginning of the
eternal state, we are given a very significant detail about the Heavenly City: “And I saw the holy city, new Jerusalem,
coming down out of heaven from God, made ready as a bride adorned for her husband” (Rev 21:2). New
Jerusalem may be appropriately called the Bridal City. The residents of this City will compose the Bride of Christ.
We already have noted preliminary indications in the opening chapters of Revelation that overcomers will be the
inhabitants of this City and thus compose the Bride.319 Before we can proceed to Revelation’s discussion of the
Bride at that point in time, however, we must go back to an earlier point in time, to the end of the tribulation and
beginning of the millennium, where the Bride and the misthological invitation to the Marriage Supper was first
introduced:
         7
           “Let us rejoice and be glad and give the glory to Him, for the marriage of the Lamb has come and
         His bride has made herself ready.” 8 And it was given to her to clothe herself in fine linen, bright and
         clean; for the fine linen is the righteous acts of the saints. 9 And he said to me, “Write, ‘Blessed are
         those who are invited to the marriage supper of the Lamb.’” And he said to me, “These are true words
         of God.” (Rev 19:7-9)
                                                Three Bridal Models
      This portion of text has been covered in detail earlier in this series in MMP3 (and before that in TOD). The
present book will recap with a couple of the illustrations and abbreviated comments pertaining to them from MMP3
and then add an additional illustration to portray the options more clearly.
                                        Illustration 73. The Synecdochial Bride




319
      See Primary Preliminary, 195.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 234

        Dillow poses that the Bride is composed of all believers, but only faithful believers will be clothed in white.
He argues that those described as clothed in white are the part of the Bride referred to as clothed, not the entire
Bride. Unclothed believers would also be part of the Bride. In short, he thinks the clothed part is a synecdoche,
using this part of the Bride to include the rest of the Body of Christ as part of the Bride of Christ. However, since
the number of believers who overcome is much smaller than the total number of believers, this Dillowian
synecdochical Bride is clothed only in a synecdochic bikini.
        The impression that one gets from John’s discussion in Revelation is that only a relatively few believers will
qualify as overcomers. Only they will be clothed in misthological white garments. Only they will rule with Christ
as His consort. On such matters, Dillow and I apparently agree. The primary difference in our models is that he
would picture the Bride as composed of all believers, even the misthological naked believers. Thus, if one wishes
to picture his model, only the faithful portion of the Bride would be clothed. The unfaithful portion would be
unclothed. The bikini Bride, pictured above from MMP3, is the composite picture of the Dillowian model:
The Bride of Christ is the Body of Christ, but only part of the Bride of Christ is clothed in white, as pictured by the
bikini.
                                      Illustration 74. The Misthological Bride
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                           Page 235
        Contrastively, in my model, the Bride is fully clothed in white because only faithful believers will
compose the Bride. Whereas I would identify the Bride as only consisting of faithful believers, Dillow clarifies
that he does not believe that the action of the Bride clothing herself refers to all believers, only to faithful believers.
He posits that, although the Bride refers to all believers, not all believers clothe themselves appropriately. Thus,
part of my criticism of his position as expressed in TOD might be summarized as thinking that his position would
have to assert that all believers compose the Bride, and all bridal believers clothe themselves appropriately. His
response is that all believers compose the Bride, but not all bridal believers clothe themselves appropriately.
Therefore, he argues that one must not assume all bridal believers clothe themselves appropriately, whereas I argue
that one must not assume that all believers are bridal believers. His contention, then, is that I have assumed an all
that is not in the text. My contestation, likewise, is that he has assumed an all that is not in the text.
        In response, I ask, “Did John actually have to clarify that the Bride was not wearing a bikini for the biblical
reader to know it was not his intent to picture the Bride in a bikini?!?” No one in that culture would have pictured
a bikini Bride when John says, “‘His bride has made herself ready.’ And it was given to her to clothe herself in fine
linen, bright and clean; for the fine linen is the righteous acts of the saints” (Rev 19:7-8). Anyone in that culture
who saw a bride dressed in a bikini would have used a synecdoche to call her naked.
        John did not have to say that the entire Bride was clothed appropriately for anyone in his culture to understand
that as his intent. If John had seen a vision of a bikini-clad Bride, he would have used a synecdoche to call her
“naked,” not described her as properly clothed for a wedding! Indeed, John describes misthologically naked
believers:
       17
         Because you say, “I am rich, and have become wealthy, and have need of nothing,” and you do not
       know that you are wretched and miserable and poor and blind and naked, 18 I advise you to buy from
       Me gold refined by fire, that you may become rich, and white garments, that you may clothe yourself,
       and that the shame of your nakedness may not be revealed; and eye salve to anoint your eyes, that you
       may see. (Rev 3:17-18)

       John would have been bewildered to learn that some future expositors of his writing would have thought that
these misthological naked believers were part of his properly-clothed Bride. Instead, we should anticipate his
contrast when he goes on to describe the Bride as properly clothed for a wedding. She is clothed for a wedding, not
for a day at the beach! A synecdoche is used, but not the synecdoche Dillow imagines.
       Dillow is correct to note that many expositors mistakenly assume that the wedding garment adorns all
believers. Further, he is correct that some saints make no contribution at all to the clothing of the Bride. But this
begs the question, “Why does he assume, then, that the Bride is composed of all the saints?” Dillow certainly has a
firm grasp on the nature of these garments:

             Ezekiel also links these garments with purity. All who enter at the “gates of the inner court” shall
       be “clothed with linen garments” (Ezekiel 44:17), a symbol of purity.
             These practical, righteous acts (Revelation 15:4) do not refer to the act of the Son of God in
       declaring us righteous (justification). This garment must be put on by the believer himself. When the
       invitation went out to all in verse 10, it was indicated that in order to enter the banquet one must have
       a life of works; that is, in addition to responding in faith to the invitation, they must also be “worthy.”
       Elsewhere, Jesus said, “the laborer is worthy of his wages” (Luke 10:7, NKJV). This guest was not
       worthy of reward, and, as we shall see, he will be excluded from the banquet. (P. 771; emphasis his.)

        Correct again. But why think that those excluded from the banquet are part of the Bride? How can part of the
Bride be excluded from her own banquet?!? The consummation is very problematic in Dillow’s model. To what
text will he appeal to assert that all believers are included in the consummation? On the other hand, if all believers
are not included, then how does he propose to handle the objection that all the Bride experiences the consummation?
At the very least, how is it that Dillow has part of the Bride excluded from her own wedding celebration?!? He
clearly asserts this to be the case: “The door is shut and those unprepared are excluded from the wedding
festivities and the marriage ceremony. The Judgment Seat of Christ probably occurs at this time, and the result
is that the door to the wedding banquet is shut. Unprepared believers are not permitted to enter (Matthew 25:10,
2 Corinthians 5:10)” (Destiny, 799). The logical implication of Dillow’s argument here is that the foolish virgins,
who in his assessment are part of the Bride, are excluded from the seven-year Marriage Banquet as they experience
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 236
profound regret in the outer darkness inside New Jerusalem during that time. So, in response to such questions as,
“How can the outer darkness be inside New Jerusalem?” and “How can part of the Bride be excluded from her own
wedding?” Dillow simply responds that such questions miss the point entirely because the imagery involved is
merely metaphorical; therefore, “to raise issues about these details is to over-interpret the details of the parable”
because “this is a story, a metaphor, and there is no literal banquet, no literal table for millions of people, and no
literal marriage ceremony” (pp. 799-800).
        Interestingly, Dillow insists, on the one hand, that all believers will live in New Jerusalem while denying, on
the other hand, that New Jerusalem is a literal city. Similarly, he insists, on the one hand, that all believers will be
a part of the Bride while denying, on the other hand, that all believers will participate in the bridal preparations and
festivities. Even an appeal to non-literality does little to offset such inconsistency. The Bride is a metaphor, of
course. A metaphor for what, however? Co-rulers with Christ is the obvious answer. Yet, if that is the case, then
the most natural deduction would be that, since not all believers will be co-rulers with Christ, not all believers will
be a part of the Bride.
                                        Illustration 75. The Composite Bride
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                         Page 237

        The previous picture of the synecdochical Bride from MMP3 and TOD does not do true justice to the
injustice of Dillow’s picture of the Bride. The above picture of the composite Bride is misthologically
blasphemous, albeit, unfortunately, a better picture of the metaphorical reality being proposed by Dillow. In
Dillow’s model, the Bride of Christ and Body of Christ refer to the same entity. If that is the case, then Christ should
be pictured as the head of this singular body since Christ is the head of the church (Eph 5:23). The absurdity of this
picture, however, is apparent from Paul’s context: The husband is the head of the wife. Obviously, Paul does not
mean that we should take the husband’s head and place it on the wife’s body. Two separate bodies are posed. The
husband has his own body, and the wife has her own body. Yet Dillow’s discussion has nullified that possibility at
the metaphorical level. TOD and MMP3 used various illustrations to make it clear that the Bride of Christ must be
distinguished from the Body of Christ. Doing so was necessary to avoid this monstrosity. By denying this
distinction, Dillow’s position leads to the composite Bride pictured above.
                             Illustration 76. A Side-by-Side Comparison of the Bride




        Placing these illustrations side by side might help clarify why Dillow’s argument leads to an abhorrent
composite. In my bridal modal, as explained and illustrated in TOD, Christ is the federal and organic head
of the Body of Christ. The Bride of Christ is taken from the Body of Christ but does not cease to be part of that
body because She becomes one flesh with the Lord through matrimony. To be sure, this imagery implements
typology and metaphors, but this does not make it any less real. As explained in more detail in TOD with various
illustrations, Christ is currently the organic head of His federal body, the church (Eph 5:22-24). The church is
subject to its federal head (as in Col 1:18). As Adam was the head of his body, so Christ is the head of His body.
However, Adam was not only the head of his own personal body; he was also the head of his bridal body, Eve. The
reason is simple enough. Adam was the head of his body, and Eve did not cease to be Adam’s body. As his wife,
Eve was still one flesh (i.e., one body) with Adam. Sexually, the two of them became one flesh. Consequently,
Adam was the head of Eve’s body because he was the head of his body. Being head of his body made him head of
her body since they were one body. Matrimonially, Adam was the head of his wife, Eve. Likewise, matrimonially,
Christ is the legal head of His wife, the Bride of Christ.
        In previous discussions, I have been content to picture Dillow’s bridal model as clothed in a bikini to
focus on the fallacy of his synecdochical argument. In the present discussion, however, I will also call
attention to the second fallacy in his argument. Not only does his argument pose a synecdochical bridal body
clothed in a bikini, but it also, in terms of the typology and imagery, makes Christ the federal and organic
and matrimonial head of this singular body. Frankly, what he poses is not only misthologically abhorrent, it
is also impossible. As noted in previous discussions, you cannot marry your own body. Dillow is thus imposing
an impossibility. Basically, he is trying to pull off a hybrid in which he takes Christ’s literal body as being the
metaphorical body for the head of Christ. Yet, doing so is highly questionable, as denoted by the large question
mark in the pictorial illustration. Indeed, if you take what Paul says at face value, Dillow’s proposal is downright
objectionable. Paul identifies Christ’s body and the Church, not Christ’s literal body. The literal person of Christ
(the literal head and body of Christ) is pictured as the federal head of the Church. Consequently, we are left with a
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                Page 238
Dillowian composite that makes the literal Christ the federal and matrimonial head of a bikini Bride.
      The discussions, charts, and illustrations in TOD and MMP3 may be consulted for arguments demonstrating
the necessity of posing two bodies. For present purposes, a simple color-coded chart will suffice.

        Observations:
      1. Why is the husband the head of the wife as Christ is the head of the church (Eph 5:22)? The
         justification/explanation comes from Paul’s whole train of thought for this connection from a series of
         explanatory fors in the English text, which are building up to an apex in Eph 5:31, taking us back to the
         context of Gen 2:24.320
      2. The simile used of the Christ-Church relationship is both matrimonial (since it is compared to the husband-
         wife relationship) and typological (since it is prefigured by the Adam-Eve relationship).
      3. Adam was the head in terms of being the source of Eve and had authority over her and was to love her.
         Christ is the head of the church in the same manner.


320
   As discussed elsewhere in my writings, Eph 5:26-27 is alluding to the washing of practical sanctification and
misthological spotlessness. Bridal believers will be misthologically sinless and blameless in terms of their bridal
beauty. Because of His love for His Bride, Christ desires to maximize Her misthological beauty. Adam’s organic
body was sinless, representing our soteriological sinlessness. Eve, his bridal body, was taken from this sinless body
and presented to him as not only sinless but spotless in beauty, representing misthological sinlessness.
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                        Page 239
      4. Adam was put to sleep while his bride was formed from his side. Christ was put to sleep while His side was
         open (Jn 19:34-35), and His Bride is being formed while He is tarrying.
      5. The explanation that Paul gives for his whole argument goes back to Adam and Eve, when Eve was taken
         out of Adam’s body in Gen 2:21-24. The implication is that just as Eve was formed from Adam’s body, so
         the Church (or at least the bridal aspect of the Church) is formed from Christ’s body. Christ’s bridal body
         is composed from His body just as Adam’s bridal body was composed from his body.
      6. The great mystery (Eph 5:32) to which Paul is referring in his OT quotation of Gen 2:24 and in his allusion
         to Gen 2:23 is regarding Christ and the Church. Consequently, the OT passage must be the type and the NT
         passage the antitype. (Incidentally, the Greek word for for in v. 31 is anti.) The OT passage prefigures and
         foreshadows the creation of the bridal body of Christ.
      7. The Church is not merely the body of Christ but the derivative bridal body of Christ, just as Eve was the
         derivative bridal body of Adam.
       The typological connection between Christ and Adam is apparent. It should also be affirmed between Adam’s
bride, Eve, and the Bride of Christ. Walvoord affirms, “The very terms first Adam and last Adam and similar
expressions are applied respectively to Adam and Christ (1Cor 15:45–47). Adam as the husband of Eve is also a
type as the bridegroom in relation to the church as the bride” (emphasis his).321 Fritsch affirms the probability:
“Adam is considered a type of Christ by Paul in Romans 5:14. Probably by an extension of this idea, the Church of
Christ, which is His bride, came to be regarded as prefigured by Eve (cf. 2 Cor. 11:2, 3; Eph. 5:22 ff).”322
Köstenberger acknowledges, “A variant of the typological approach is the view that Paul finds a ‘deeper meaning’
in Gen 2:24, as if there were a hidden meaning under the surface that awaited its revelation in the ‘last days’ (sensus
plenior). Gen 2:24, though literally referring to marriage, is believed to be typologically structured so that husband
and wife function as the type of which Christ and the church are the antitypes. Paul, as an inspired NT author, is
seen to make this latent typology explicit.”323 Bruce is an example of those commentators who affirm this deeper
meaning in Eph 5:31-32:

        The hidden meaning of Gen. 2:24 now begins to appear: his people constitute his bride, united to him
        in “one body.” The formation of Eve to be Adam’s companion is seen to prefigure the creation of the
        church to be the bride of Christ. This seems to be the deep “mystery” contained in the text, which
        remains a mystery no longer to those who have received its interpretation. (NICNT)

As Bruce points out, this mystery should no longer be considered mysterious by those who observe the typological
connection in which Eve prefigures the Bride of Christ. Online sources provide numerous points of typological
contact:

        There was a very good reason that Eve was created out of Adam’s rib and then presented to him as his
        wife, and the reason is found in Ephesians 5:23-33.
        1. Just as Adam is a type of Christ, Eve is a type of the Church.
        2. Christ, the Son of God, existed independently of the Church from eternity, thus Adam existed
        independently of Eve.
        3. Adam was put to sleep in order that Eve might be taken out of his side as a rib. Christ was “put to
        sleep” in His death and burial so that the Church might be born on the Day of Pentecost.
        4. Eve was taken out of Adam’s side, just as the Church was born out of the blood and water that
        flowed out of the side of Christ.
        5. Eve was bone of Adam’s bone and flesh of his flesh, just as the Church (the Body of Christ) is bone
        of His bones and flesh of His flesh (Eph. 5:30).

                                        Misthological Contract and Canopy
Ketubah
      Having demonstrated from the above-abbreviated extracts from some of my previous typological and
exegetical discussions that the Bride is composed of faithful believers and then clarified the necessity of this
conclusion, let us return to some abbreviated extracts from MMP3 as additional background material before
proceeding in Revelation since these extracts pertain to the Heavenly City. Being a part of Christ’s Bride is
conditioned on meeting the terms of the betrothal contract, the ketubah, and goes back to Exodus, as Chumney
explains:

             At Mount Sinai, God betrothed Himself to Israel and entered into a marriage contract with her
      [cp. Jer 31:32]. In order for the marriage to be legal, both the bride and the groom must agree to the
      terms of the marriage. The terms of the marriage are stated in the marriage document known in Hebrew
      as a Ketubah. When God betrothed Himself to Israel at Mount Sinai, the Ketubah was seen as being
      the Torah. The children of Israel accepted the terms of the conditions of the marriage by saying the
      words, “I do.” In Exodus 19:8 it is written:
             “And all the people answered together, and said, All that the Lord hath spoken we will do....”
              The terms and the conditions of the marriage included the blessing for obedience and the curses
      for disobedience is [sic.] stated in Leviticus 26 and Deuteronomy 28.....
              ....During the time of the second coming of Jesus, the Bride of Christ will enter into the second
      stage of the Biblical wedding and will physically dwell with Jesus during the Messianic Age and for
      all eternity.325 (Emphasis his.)

      Although all believers are betrothed to Christ, only faithful believers will fulfill the terms of the betrothal and
consequently consummate the marriage, thus physically dwelling with Jesus in New Jerusalem during the millennial
age and eternal state. Unfaithful believers are subject to the curses rather than the blessing of the betrothal. These
curses are a typological picture of the outer darkness.
Chuppah
       Klein and Spears conclude: “All who are not part of the Bride will be outside, in the outer court, where they
will not be covered by the wedding chuppah.” Those unfaithful servants and guests who are cast into the outer
darkness are not able to attend the wedding. Those not appropriately addressed are cast out of the wedding into the
outer court of the outer darkness; therefore, they do not attend the wedding and cannot possibly be a part of the
Bride.

                                          Illustration 78. Jewish Chuppah




       On the cover of his book, Who is the Bride of Christ?, Chumney correctly pictures the bride and groom, not
their guests, standing under the chuppah (i.e., the wedding canopy under which a Jewish couple stands during their
wedding ceremony). Only the Bride and Groom will be under the bridal canopy. This canopy represents the
Heavenly City.
The Wedding Canopy of Mount Zion
       As discussed in LTPW, the Lord spreads His wedding canopy over Mount Zion (Is 4:5). The passage in
Is 25:6-9 talks about a lavish eschatological banquet on the Lord’s holy mountain—Mount Zion. The messianic
reign is compared to a feast on God’s holy mountain (Is 65:13-25). According to the OT, the wedding feast is to
occur on Mount Zion. Everyone in the kingdom will not live on this mountain:
      2
        Now it will come about that in the last days, the mountain of the house of the Lord will be established
      as the chief of the mountains, and will be raised above the hills; and all the nations will stream to it.
      3
        And many peoples will come and say, “Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house
      of the God of Jacob; that He may teach us concerning His ways, and that we may walk in His paths.”
      For the law will go forth from Zion, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem. (Is 2:2-3)

This message is expounded upon in Micah 4:1-7. Many people living in the kingdom will live outside of Mount
Zion. Thus, one cannot possibly equate merely living in the kingdom with living in Mount Zion. Moreover, a
wedding feast on Mount Zion cannot be equated with living in the kingdom, not according to the OT or the NT.
Even in OT eschatology, being present within the kingdom is not equivalent to being present at Mount Zion or at a
banquet on Mount Zion. Obviously, Mount Zion is a place within the kingdom, not the kingdom itself, and the feast
is a privilege for those who live on Mount Zion. Unfaithful Christians will be without the reward city—Mount Zion.
They will be outside the City, not inside the City.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                         Page 242
                           Illustration 79. The Bridal Canopy is the Heavenly City




       As in Rev 19:7-9, the Bride in Isaiah has prepared herself with the righteousness of godly living and
faithfulness, and she will be rewarded for doing so. The Bride has to make her own clothing. Both Is 61:10 and
Rev 19:7-9 picture the Bride of Christ. She clothes herself with the righteous deeds that her Bridegroom makes
possible. The earthly Mount Zion points to the Heavenly Mount Zion, that is, to the Reward City. The rulership
exercised by the City will be over all the Earth and spread throughout the universe.
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                      Page 243
Betrothal
      Chapter 3 of the first volume of Klein and Spears‘ book is an excellent chapter entitled Betrothal. The whole
chapter is well worth reading as an exposition upon their discussion of the ketubah mentioned above. Excerpts will
have to suffice for present purposes:

             In ancient times, the price for breaking the marriage covenant was death by hanging, stoning,
      the sword, or the fire. For us, none of these options might seem to apply. On the other hand, the eternal
      price could actually be much higher.
             ....After the ceremony came the moment of yachid, or physical unity. The parents of the bride
      would invite the guests to enjoy the feast. The music would swell, the dancing would begin, and the
      wine would flow for the first seven days.
             Meanwhile, the bride and groom would slip away to a private room, set apart from the noise
      and provided especially for them. Soon the marriage would be complete in every sense.
             On the other hand, if the groom discovered that his bride was not a virgin, (or, worse yet,
      discovered that she was already pregnant) the whole situation would immediately change....
             ...becoming part of the bride doesn’t happen automatically. This is probably the most important
      point of this whole chapter. (Emphasis theirs.)326

        Klein and Spears properly conclude that only those believers who keep themselves pure will consummate
the marriage with Christ as His Bride. Purity in terms of faithfulness to the betrothal contract is necessary for
consummation as the Bride of Christ. In other words, misthologically speaking, Christ is looking for a virgin Bride,
which is why Paul was afraid that some of his converts might not qualify: “For I am jealous for you with a godly
jealousy; for I betrothed you to one husband, that to Christ I might present you as a pure virgin. But I am afraid,
lest as the serpent deceived Eve by his craftiness, your minds should be led astray from the simplicity and purity of
devotion to Christ” (2Cor 11:23). Paul’s fears are justified. There is something to fear.
        John has an interesting verse as to the historical backdrop: “He who has the bride is the bridegroom; but the
friend of the bridegroom, who stands and hears him, rejoices greatly because of the bridegroom’s voice. And so this
joy of mine has been made full” (Jn 3:29). Lincoln (BNTC) comments: “It may well be that the talk of standing and
listening for the bridegroom’s voice has reference to the last task of the bridegroom’s friend—leading the
bridegroom to the bride and then standing watch outside the bridal chamber until the bridegroom announced the
consummation of the marriage” (emphasis his). Beasley-Murray (WBC) shares this perspective: “The ‘voice of the
bridegroom’ is thought to be ‘the triumph shout by which the bridegroom announced to his friends outside that he
had been united to a virginal bride’ (Schnackenburg, 1:416: see further Str-B 1:45–46, 500–501).” Borchert (NAC)
understands the passage likewise:

            To clarify for his disciples what he meant, therefore, the Baptizer used a typical Jewish type of
      parable, drawn from Jewish marriage customs. At that time the bridegroom normally selected one
      or two close friends to escort the bride to the bridegroom’s marriage chamber and to wait outside the
      room or tent for the bridegroom’s shout and often for receipt of tokens that the marriage had been
      consummated with his virgin bride. Such friends of the bridegroom were thus able to certify to the
      wedding guests that the consummation of the marriage had taken place and the joyous festivities could
      continue (cf. 3:29).

      The first order of business at the Bema will be to determine which believers have kept themselves pure. They,
and they alone, will be able to consummate their marriage with Christ. Jesus warned Peter, “If I do not wash you,
you have no part with Me” (Jn 13:8). Dillow correctly understands that those believers who fail to submit to this
cleansing will not have a misthological part in the inheritance. However, this foot-washing symbolizes the sandal
covenant as a prelude to the marriage. Jesus is warning Peter that he would miss out on the misthological
consummation as His Bride if he failed to submit to the necessary cleansing. If we want to be a part of the Bride,
we must submit to the necessary cleansing.

       Having now discussed the previous reference to the Bride in Rev 19:7-9, we can now resume our discussion
of the Bride in Rev 21:1-8, which is the next reference to the Bride. One must understand the Bride to appreciate
the imagery of the Bridal City. Material from TOD will be adapted for the treatment of this passage herein. See
TOD for cross-references and further explanation. The context of the passage is crucial.

                                                   Rev 21:1
      And I saw a new heaven and a new earth; for the first heaven and the first earth passed away, and there
      is no longer any sea.
       The NAS has changed the and (kai) that begins the passage in verse 1 to a then in its newer edition. The
newer translation is better since it brings out the sequence of events. This passage in ch. 21 describes what happens
after the Great White Throne Judgment in ch. 20, which in turn occurs at the conclusion of the millennial age. The
events in ch. 21 happen next in the sequence of time and refer to the eternal state. The progression of events is:
millennium, followed by Great White Throne in ch. 20, then the revelation of the new heaven, New Earth, and New
Jerusalem in ch. 21. In terms of our previous chapter, we would be looking at the last migration of New Jerusalem,
pictured in Illustration 69. Migration of New Jerusalem Part 7 (p. 225 ).

                                                Rev 21:2
      2
       And I saw the holy city, new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God, made ready as a
      bride adorned for her husband.

       City
        After describing the new heaven and New Earth, John describes the City (i.e., the New Jerusalem) as
Christ’s Bride. The verse presents two reward concepts—the City and the Bride—merged together into one Bridal
City. The Groom will wipe away the tears of His Bride who dwells in the City, which would be the faithful elect.
This identification of the Bride as being composed of only faithful believers is not very popular, but consistency
requires that the Bride be limited to those believers who have been faithful. The misthopology of the OT lays the
foundation for the misthology of the NT regarding the outer darkness. The NT doctrine of the outer darkness is a
picturesque expression of the misthopological exclusion already anticipated in the OT, particularly in Psalms and
Isaiah.

Rev 21:16). The surface area of its top is speculative, but tentative calculations have been provided in MMP1 and

of Earth in anticipation of the rapture.

       The 3D illustration of the City included here can be printed. Printing it on paper has the advantage of being

correspond to the size of the moon. So one could simply pass out copies of the above illustration to children of the
church, and they could make their own scaled models that could be compared to their basketballs and tennis balls
at home.

       I drew the City to scale for my sons’ globe and shined a flashlight on it. Since day and night will continue

the manner in which Carmical describes the outer darkness in his fictional account. His account is probably far
more literally accurate than many imagine. Although I would not restrict the Terrestrial Outer Darkness to this zone,
the worst offending believers who live through the end of the tribulation may very well be confined literally to the
darkest part of the globe at Antarctica.




329
    The circumference of the Earth is 24901.55 at the equator, which I will round off to 25000 miles. The base of
the city is 1500 miles. With these figures, one easily can compute the base of a scaled model of the city to some
scaled model of the Earth, such as a basketball or globe. The ratio of the model/city = globe/Earth. The
circumference of a basketball is 30 inches. So the model = (globe x city)/Earth. In the case of a basketball, the
computation, therefore, is: model = (30 x 1500)/25000. The base of the model is 1.8 inches. One may use this
computational procedure to calculate what the base length should be for some other globe so that one can change
the scale of the model of the city accordingly. For the twenty-nine-inch globe, which the author used for example,
it would round off to 1 ¾ inches.
