                                             Illustration 86. Golden City




       For this picture, I printed the City on a transparency with a golden hue. Jonathan is holding it above the earth.
However, the distance that the City will be above the earth is speculative. Stationary satellites, such as those used
for communications, broadcasts, and weather, are about 22,000 miles above the Earth, which is less than the
circumference of the Earth. Perhaps that would be an appropriate distance. However, the City will presumably have
a gravitational field, so the City may be further out in space, like the moon. For comparison, the moon is also
pictured by the tennis ball.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                    Page 250
                                          Illustration 87. City in Biosphere




       Apparently, the throne of God will be at the top of the City, from which the river of life proceeds and flows
down the side of the City, presumably to the New Earth by means of portals (cf. Rev 22:1). The city is called Mount
Zion in Scripture and will resemble the shape of a large mountain with rivers of life flowing down its sloped sides.
Even if the City were on Earth, as many suppose, since the low flying satellites such as space shuttles and space
stations fly at an altitude of only 100-300 miles, it is apparent that most of the surface area of the City would project
far into outer space and would be uninhabitable by creatures living in natural bodies. Nevertheless, it appears that
the entire surface area of the City is inhabitable (Is 65:25). Given that the water is not frozen solid but flows down
these slopes and that plants such as the Tree of Life grow on these slopes, it must be deduced that the City is
encapsulated in a biosphere that supports life. Posing that the living water reaches Earth by means of portals allows
the proposition that it remains in satellite position.

       Portion in the City
       Intimate association with the City is limited to overcomers since this promise by Jesus is limited to the
overcomer: “I will write upon him the name of My God, and the name of the city of My God, the new Jerusalem,
which comes down out of heaven from My God” (Rev 3:12). For these contextual reasons, one would tend to think
that portion or part (meros) in Rev 22:19 means the right to participate misthologically in: “If anyone takes away
from the words of the book of this prophecy, God will take away his right to participate misthologically in the Tree
of Life and the holy city” (Rev 22:19; CT; MT; TM). The City and tree of 22:14 are to be included in the reward of
22:12. The servants who partake of these benefits in the manner described in the passage are faithful, rewarded
servants. Subcomers will be excluded. The nations will be included to a limited extent. They might be able to enter
the City and use the leaves of the tree. Or the kings of their planet (such as the kings of the Earth, Rev 21:24) will
be able to bring gold into the City in exchange for the leaves of the tree. If my speculation is correct that the multiple
3D Cities will be found throughout the multiverse, then leaves from the trees growing on the outside walls of these
innumerable Heavenly Cities would also be a source of commerce. Yet the right to inhabit the 4D City and eat the
fruit of the tree would be limited to overcomers.

       City of Rest
       The city of Zion is part of God’s eternal rest. “For the Lord has chosen Zion; He has desired it for His
habitation. This is My resting place forever; here I will dwell” (Ps 132:13-14). The parallel to Rev 21:3a is obvious.
Zion, God’s rest in the eternal state, is the New Jerusalem. Subcomers will never enter God’s rest. Consequently,
subcomers will never enter God’s rest, which is Zion, the New Jerusalem. Tanner rightly references Is 11:10 in
associating the misthological rest we are trying to achieve in his discussion of Heb 4:1-13 with the inheritance of
the Messianic kingdom:
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                          Page 251
             God’s judgment on the wilderness generation was exclusion from His “rest” of inheriting
      Canaan (Ps 95:11)…..Yet this “land rest was typological of a greater rest to come….
             ….entering the rest in not merely being in the kingdom (which all true believers are entitled to),
      but also focuses on the inheritance and reward awaiting faithful believers and which unfaithful
      believers may very well jeopardize). Primarily, this involves a share in the dominion over God’s
      creation (recall Hebrews 2).
             ….This epistle stresses Messiah’s kingdom (cf. 1:8; 12:28), and the concept of “rest” was even
      linked in such passages as Isa 11:10 with Messiah’s kingdom” (GNTC; emphasis his).

Tanner’s full discussion is worthy of consultation. The extrapolation that needs to be added is that dominion over
the new creation in the eternal state is also at stake and, with it, inhabitation of the Heavenly City. This resting place
is contextually associated with His holy mountain (Is 11:9) and even with being an inhabitant of Zion (Is 12:6, cp.
Is 4:3-5). This reward City is the misthological mountain home of those who qualify to live there.
      6
        And the wolf will dwell with the lamb, and the leopard will lie down with the kid, and the calf and
      the young lion and the fatling together; and a little boy will lead them. 7 Also the cow and the bear
      will graze; their young will lie down together; and the lion will eat straw like the ox. 8 And the nursing
      child will play by the hole of the cobra, and the weaned child will put his hand on the viper’s den.
      9
        They will not hurt or destroy in all My holy mountain, for the earth will be full of the knowledge
      of the Lord as the waters cover the sea. 10 Then it will come about in that day that the nations will
      resort to the root of Jesse, who will stand as a signal for the peoples; and His resting place will be
      glorious. (Is 11:6-10)

       As mentioned previously herein and discussed in RAE, this background from Isaiah 11 is particularly
applicable to the Mountain City. Fishing still will take place during the millennial kingdom and/or eternal state
(Eze 47:9-10), the same time period in which the wolf lives peaceably with the lamb and the lion eats straw (Is 11:6-
8; Is 65:25). Even though the whole Earth “will be full of the knowledge of God,” this no-hurt-state-of-affairs is
explicitly said to be in God’s “holy mountain.” The earthly Mountain City (i.e., Earthly Jerusalem) will be a game
reserve: no hunting or fishing. Fish will be fair game outside of the Mountain City. Likewise, we may presume that
game will be fair game outside of the Mountain City.
       Also, as expounded upon more fully in TOD, Gleason notes that God’s resting place would be the Promised
Land and particularly Mount Zion (Ps 132:8,13-14; Is 11:10). Being able to worship God in the Promised Land and
Mount Zion are at stake for the believer.330 Or to restate Gleason’s splendid conclusions, by means of the
terminology used herein, misthological exclusion from the Promised Land and misthopological exclusion from the
City of Rest are at stake for the redeemed believer.331 The Psalmist and WH are typologically portraying the
objective nature of this reality, whereas Jesus parabolically is presenting its emotive and correlative force, picturing
it as weeping in the outer darkness. John points out that the overcomer will inherit the things associated with the
330
    Randall C. Gleason, “The Old Testament Background of Rest in Hebrews 3:7-8,” BibSac 157:627 (July, 2000):
281-303.
331
    Gleason also believes that the writer of Hebrews uses God’s rest in Gen 2:2 to include Adam’s rest in Gen 2:15,
where God caused (Hiphil) Adam to rest (nuach). Adam did not cultivate the ground until after he was expelled
from the garden (Gen 3:23). For such reasons, Gleason believes that Gen 2:15 should be translated as: God rested
Adam in the garden to worship and obey Him. Granted, worship is part of the rest in Psalms. But I would prefer to
interpret tending (abad) the garden in 2:15 as a form of ruling it (cp. Gen 1:26). Rulership is rest. Incidentally, how
and where did God rest from His works in Gen 2:2? I would suggest that He rested by sitting down (cp. Heb 1:3;
8:1; 10:12; 12:2) in His Heavenly Garden (atop the Emerald Eden) to rule. He rested from one form of activity (i.e.,
creation) to assume another (i.e., rulership). Just as God rested by ruling from Heavenly Eden, Adam was to rest by
exercising rulership in the earthly Eden—the typological counterpart to the Heavenly Eden. As an aside, note that
Adam was not driven from the Garden of Eden until after he was redeemed (via the blood of the slain animal).
Typologically, it was as a redeemed son that Adam was expelled from the garden, and, once expelled, he never was
allowed to return, being eternally barred thereafter from eating of the Tree of Life (from which he probably had
been eating until that time) and thus from living forever, that is, from qualitatively having the degree of eternal life
associated with eating from the Tree of Life (Gen 3:31-24).
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 252
Heavenly City, even in the eternal state (Rev 21:7), which is fitting since rewards (and loss of rewards) are eternal.
In association with this rich OT background regarding God’s rest as being His Mountain City, we may conclude
that unfaithful believers will be excluded from His City of Rest.

                                                    Rev 21:3
      And I heard a loud voice from the throne, saying, “Behold, the tabernacle of God is among men, and
      He shall dwell among them, and they shall be His people, and God Himself shall be among them.”

      Tabernacle
      The next verse of this context, Rev 21:3, alludes to a rewards motif previously mentioned by John as
describing God dwelling among humanity in His tabernacle. The experience was described earlier by John in
Rev 7:14-15 as a reward for those who wash their robes in practical sanctification:
      14
        These are the ones who come out of the great tribulation, and they have washed their robes and made
      them white in the blood of the Lamb. 15 For this reason, they are before the throne of God; and they
      serve Him day and night in His temple; and He who sits on the throne shall spread His tabernacle over
      them. (Rev 7:14-15)

Being with God in His tabernacle is associated with sharing His presence around His throne. Subcomers are not
included in this specific aspect of God’s dwelling among people. Unfaithful believers will dwell with God in His
kingdom, not in the tabernacle of His throne room. To be clothed with white robes, one must actively do the washing
for oneself. Just as the Bride must clothe herself with white garments (Rev 19:8), so overcomers must wash their
own clothing. The Lamb will not do the washing for them. In fact, the only other time this phrase blood of the Lamb
occurs, it is described as one of the components necessary to be an overcomer (Rev 12:11). Being clothed in white
garments is seen repeatedly as something one achieves as a result of overcoming (Rev 3:4-5,18) and is associated
with rulership (Rev 4:4). Consequently, the reason those in 7:9 are clothed in white robes is because they themselves
have made their own garments white through (dia) the blood of the Lamb in conjunction with (kai dia) their own
sacrifice. The blood of the Lamb and the blood of their own sacrificed lives are the dual instrumental means by
which they overcome (Rev 12:11). They have done their own washing in 7:14, in fulfilling the requirements
necessary to be regarded an overcomer. And 12:11 specifies that this entails cleansing their garments by the blood
of the Lamb and by the blood of their own sacrifice.

       His People
       The verse promises: “Behold, the tabernacle of God is with men, and He will dwell with them, and they shall
be His people [plural in CT and TR; singular in MT]. God Himself will be with them and be their God [not in MT]”
(Rev 21:3; NKJ). An objection to any misthological limitation will be made that God will be the God of all
people in the kingdom, not just the select few. According to some Greek texts, people is plural. In any case, Egypt
will be among the many nations who belong to the Lord as His people:

           •   Blessed is Egypt My people, and Assyria the work of My hands, and Israel My inheritance.
               (Is 19:25)
           •   And many nations shall be joined to the Lord in that day, and shall be my people: and I will dwell
               in the midst of thee, and thou shalt know that the Lord of hosts hath sent me unto thee. (Zech 2:11)
           •   Arise, O God, judge the earth: for thou shalt inherit all nations. (Ps 82:8)
           •   The earth is the LORD’s, and all it contains, the world, and those who dwell in it. (Ps 24:1)

        Aune (WBC) is representative of this sentiment: “This is almost certainly an allusion to Ezek 37:27.” “Many
nations shall join themselves to the Lord in that day, and shall be my people….It is probable that since “many
nations” are mentioned in Zech 2:11, Rev 21:3 should read λαοί, “peoples,” rather than simply λαός, “people.” “The
statement ‘I will be their God, and they shall be my people’ (Jer 31:33[LXX 38:33]) is a covenant formula, perhaps
based on the verba solemnia associated with adoption” (insert his). “This covenant language is significant because
it is applied to all people universally (nb. the term λαοί), not just to a specific group.” Thus, Aune poses inclusivity.
        Beale (NIGTC) also expresses at length why he believes this promise is universally appliable:
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                        Page 253

              The declaration of perfected communion between God and redeemed humanity is coined in the
      language of several repeated OT prophecies. These prophecies, among which Ezek. 37:27 and Lev.
      26:11–12 are foremost, predicted a final restoration in which God himself would “tabernacle in the
      midst” of Israel, and Israelites would “be to him a people,” and he would “be their God” (see below
      for further references). The same promise from Ezek. 37:26–28 to Israel is cited in Jub. 1:17 (“I will
      build my sanctuary in their midst, and I will dwell with them, and I will be their God and they will be
      my people”) and equated in Jub. 1:29 with the coming “new creation.” Already Rev. 7:15 has
      understood the prophecy of Israel’s restoration in Ezek. 37:27 to be fulfilled by Gentile as well
      as Jewish Christians. Lev. 26:11–12 and Ezek. 37:26–28 equate this final dwelling of God among
      his people with the coming latter-day tabernacle….
              ….All the OT prophecies speak of a singular “people” (λαός) among whom God will dwell.
      Rev. 21:3 changes the singular to plural “peoples” (λαοί) in order to make obvious that prophecies
      originally focusing on Israel have been fulfilled in “every tribe, tongue, people, and nation” (so 5:9;
      7:9). Zech. 2:10–11 anticipates Rev. 21:3 in its interpretation of the same prophecies concerning God’s
      final communion with his people, foreseeing an ethnic expansion of the boundaries of true Israel by
      identifying “many nations” as “my people,” a term always used elsewhere in the OT for Israel (see
      below for texts).
              Zechariah and John include Gentiles in the fulfillment of Israelite promises because that was
      the intention from the beginning when the promises about Israel were made to Abraham. God promised
      to Abraham that the nations would be blessed only through the blessing of his Israelite seed
      (Gen. 12:1–3; 17:2–8; 26:24; Sir. 44:21–23; Gal. 3:16). The formula “you will be my people, and I
      will be your God” in Jer. 11:4–5 is rooted in this Abrahamic promise and is applied to Israel (likewise
      Deut. 29:12–13). It cannot be happenstance that Ezek. 47:14 also bases Israel’s eternal
      inheritance of the land and temple on the promise to Abraham (“to your forefathers”). Ezek.
      47:22–23 affirms that the only way Gentiles can share in the promised inheritance of the new temple
      and land is to become part of Israel: Gentile “aliens … will be to you [Israel] like native born sons of
      Israel; they will be allotted an inheritance with you among the tribes of Israel.” It is certainly clear NT
      doctrine that Gentiles cannot partake of Israel’s OT promises by becoming a part of Israel’s theocratic
      society. Then how can they have access to the promises? John’s Apocalypse, like Paul (Gal. 3:16),
      reveals that the nations are able to share in true Israel’s redemptive blessing by trusting in Jesus, the
      true seed of Abraham and the only authentic Israelite, who died and rose for both Jew and Gentile.
      Everyone represented by Jesus, the ideal king and Israelite, is considered part of true Israel and
      therefore shares in the blessings that he receives (e.g., see on 1:13; 2:17–18; 3:7; 7:4–8; 12:5, 17;
      21:27).
              God’s “tabernacling” presence in Ezek. 37:27 and 43:7 would have been understood in its OT
      context and by its OT readers as being cultically separated from the majority of Israelites; only the few
      Zadokite priests who strictly kept the temple ordinances would be exposed in the fullest way to God’s
      presence within the “inner court” of the temple. But now in Rev. 21:3 the divine presence is not limited
      by the physical boundaries of an Israelite temple, since not only all believing Israelites but even all
      “peoples” experience God’s intimate tabernacling presence.

      Not so! Does adopting the plural of peoples in Rev 21:3 prove that all people universally will have this
misthological formula applied to them, as commentators assume? No. For several reasons:

      1. The background for Rev 21:3 in Eze 37:27 is from a context of covenantal formula exclusivity that gives
         special status to Israel over the Gentiles (Eze 37:28). “My dwelling place also will be with them; and
         I will be their God, and they will be My people. And the nations will know that I am the Lord who
         sanctifies Israel, when My sanctuary is in their midst forever” (Eze 37:27-28).
      2. This OT background favoring an elevated position for Israel is a dominant theme and goes back to the
         beginning: “Now then, if you will indeed obey My voice and keep My covenant, then you shall be My
         own possession among all the peoples, for all the earth is Mine” (Ex 19:5). This misthological promise
         was expanded in the NT to include faithful Gentiles in its misthological scope.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 254
      3. The supposition that John has changed the wording to the plural to show that the nations share in this
         blessing, in conjunction with Rev 5:9 and 7:9, is a reasonable conjecture by NIGTC. However, this
         destroys the very argument that NIGTC is making for universal application. Those texts in Rev 5:9 and
         7:9 are mistholic. Inclusive misthological applicability, not universal soteriological applicability, is
         being demonstrated. In other words, faithful Gentile believers are included with faithful Jews in
         the mistholic covenantal formula.
      4. The promise that all the nations would be blessed via Abraham does not mean that they will be
         blessed equally. This blessing is not merely soteriological but misthological. NIGTC is wrong to think
         that the soteriological nature of the promise nullifies the misthological scope of the promise.
      5. The very texts cited from Revelation by NIGTC prove mistholic exclusivity, not equal shares in the
         blessings.
      6. The proposal made herein truly harmonizes the passages cited by NIGTC rather than using Zech 2:11 to
         override Eze 37:27.
      7. Contrary to WBC, this covenant language is significant, not “because it is applied to all people
         universally,” but because it is applied to Gentiles with mistholic inclusivity. Both Jews and Gentiles
         will participate in misthological blessings if they qualify.

        My inclination is generally to follow the MT. Thus, I have a slight preference for singular people in Rev 21:3.
Plus, the LXX uses the singular form of people in Zech 2:11, a point which these commentators failed to point out.
Nevertheless, the point remains valid that both faithful Jews and Gentiles will compose the people(s) inhabiting
the City and are thus those for whom Rev 21:3 is intended. Misthological exclusivity (a reward that applies
exclusively to all overcomers of all ages) rather than soteriological inclusivity (a gift that applies to all
believers of all ages) is the force of the context and text. The commentators got the plurality but missed the
exclusivity. Faithful Gentile believers, as well as faithful Jewish believers of all dispensations up through the
tribulation, will inhabit the Bridal City as members of the Bride. The verse says that the tabernacle of God is
among men, not over all men. The very statement that it is among them suggests that it is not over all of them. God
will be the God of all people living in the eternal state. But He will be the God in an elevated sense of those who
dwell in His tabernacle. The nations who live on the planet below will be able to look up into the sky above their
planet and see the 3D City—the Tabernacle City. This City will be among the general populace of the planet in
terms of being in a stationary orbit above their planet. Unfaithful believers in the Celestial Outer Darkness will have
the 3D Tabernacle Cities in their midst, that is, in the multiverse, which is in the center of the heavenly outer realm,
and the 4D City in their own heavenly outer dimension. Yet they will not be able to enter either the 4D City or 3D
Cities.

                                                    Rev 21:4
      And He shall wipe away every tear from their eyes; and there shall no longer be any death; there shall
      no longer be any mourning, or crying, or pain; the first things have passed away.

       No Tears
        Peterson asks, “Does John’s vision teach the absolute banishment of death and pain? Obviously not, because
four verses later the wicked are said to go into the lake of fire (Rev. 21:8).”332 Peterson’s assessment is correct,
insofar as it goes, in refuting universalism by pointing out that this is a relative wiping limited by the context to one
group of people. Although Peterson naturally would assume from his Calvinistic premise that this applies to all
believers, the verse itself limits the promise to a particular group of believers: “He shall wipe away every tear from
their eyes.” The preceding verses in 21:1-3 leave no doubt as to the identity of the individuals who are to experience
this wonderful benefit. They are the bridal saints who inhabit the Bridal City. As Chitwood acknowledges, “The
reference to all tears being wiped away prior to the millennium in Rev. 7:17 is only for a select group of individuals
realizing an inheritance in the kingdom.”333 The proper conclusion, therefore, is that the wiping away of tears is a
reward promised to overcomers, not to subcomers.

332
    Robert A. Peterson, Hell on Trial: The Case for Eternal Punishment (Phillipsburg: Presbyterian and Reformed
Publishing Company, 1995), 176.
333
    Chitwood, Olivet, 291.
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                          Page 255
       This promise in 21:4 is composed of numerous litotes: no tears, no death, no mourning, no crying, and no
pain. No tears means supreme joy. No death means a superlative experience of life, which is used repeatedly as a
reward concept in Revelation. Like the preceding verse, verse 4 also brings back the imagery of ch. 7, which made
implicit promises to overcomers who wash their robes in practical sanctification (Rev 7:14). In addition to the
tabernacle experience around God’s throne mentioned above, overcomers are also promised that their tears will be
wiped away as a reward for washing their robes. Further, in this initial context, the wiping away of tears is also
understood as a litotes from a context of litotes (no hunger, no thirst, no hot sun—7:16). Since the wiping away of
tears was limited to overcomers previously in ch. 7, since it is associated with apparent litotes, since it may be
understood misthologically in the present context of ch. 21, since it is for the bridal inhabitants of the City, and
since it refers to more than just the removal of sorrow, the wiping away of tears should also be taken as a litotes in
21:4, promising supreme joy to its recipients.334

       No Death
       As discussed much more fully in RAE and earlier in this series in MMP2, “those who do not overcome (v. 7)”
are not going to inherit the promise of not having any death (v. 4). Verse 7 clearly states: “He who overcomes shall
inherit these things,” that is, the things just mentioned in verse 4, which promises no death of any kind. The no-
death-of-any-type promise is limited to those who overcome. Rather than repeat those detailed previous discussions,
a summary term will be introduced herein, in conjunction with the Healing of the Nations (p. 311) in Rev 22:2, to
describe a class of beings inhabiting the kingdom yet subject to a limited form of death during the eternal state.
       Smortals refer to humans in natural flesh-and-blood bodies who are sinless, semi-transformed, sexually-
reproducing, semi-mortal. Such bodies can sexually reproduce and are subject to physical death at the micro level
but not at the macro level. Adam and Eve had sinless, innocent bodies. One primary difference between the two is
that smortals are regenerate and cannot sin.335
       Immortals who do not overcome will be subject to misthological death, even during the eternal state.
Chitwood erroneously concluded that all forms of death cease during the eternal state. Therefore, he insisted that
rewards cease in the eternal state. His latter assessment is only accurate if his premise is true. However, his premise
has been demonstrated to be false and his argument refuted in RAE. Consequently, we will simply proceed with
summary statements. Death is the loss of life. Subcomers will lose their right to the crown of life and Tree of Life,
which are forms of life to which they would otherwise have been entitled. This loss of misthological life is a form
of misthological death. This litotetic outcome of no death of any type in Rev 21:4 applies only to those who
overcome; therefore, subcomers must be subject to mistholic death during the eternal state, for that is the clear
implication of the limitation and the time frame under consideration.

                                                        Rev 21:6
         And He said to me, “It is done. I am the Alpha and the Omega, the beginning and the end. I will give
         to the one who thirsts from the spring of the water of life without cost.”

       The next promise is to give the water from the springs of the water of life without cost. It thus applies to all
believers (21:6). Even so, it is one thing to be able to drink the water flowing from the spring to the outside of the
City, and it is quite another to be led personally to and have access to the spring itself inside the City, which is the
case in Rev 7:17, where Johns says, “For the Lamb in the center of the throne shall be their shepherd, and shall
guide them to springs of the water of life; and God shall wipe every tear from their eyes.” The springs are at the
throne, which in turn is at the top of the City, Mt. Zion, the New Jerusalem. Those believers who wash their robes
will have this special access to the very source of the living water and have their own watery eyes dried by God.
       This spring of water produces a river (Rev 22:1-2), so it flows through the gates in the walls to the outside of
the City, and the water of life is free outside the City walls (cf. 22:17). But how can this water of life be offered
freely to those outside the gates of this satellite City? One possibility is that teleportals may allow free access to the
water, not only to Earth but even to other planets. The water flowing from Ezekiel’s temple expands rapidly—
miraculously. Within the space of a few thousand cubits, the water expands from an ankle-deep trickle to a river
that could not be forded (Eze 17:1-5). Even one teleportal from Earth to another planet would suffice to start a chain

334
      For a thorough discussion of the tears, see TOD, MMP1, MMP2, and RAE.
335
      For a chart demonstrating similarities and differences, see Illustration 120. Adam and Eve versus Smortals, 302.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                    Page 256
of teleportals conveying living water from this planet to every inhabitable planet throughout the universe.
       After all, where does the living water flow that flows from inside the Heavenly City through twelve gates to
those outside the satellite Space City? For if the City is suspended in outer space or in the atmosphere, it has to flow
somewhere when it exits those City gates. Thus, I pose hyperspace portals.336 One of these portals could lead from
the Heavenly City to Ezekiel’s Temple, thus explaining the presence of the same water flowing from this earthly
city as from the Heavenly City. Otherwise, two independent sources of living water would have to be hypothesized.
Proposing one source seems preferable. This living water represents the Holy Spirit and flows through these portals
to Earth and to other planets as well, where, in turn, it produces rivers of living water. Just as a believer who drinks
the living water becomes a spring of living water (Jn 4:14), even to others, so those planets to which the living water
flows become the source of living water for other planets through the means of such portals.
       The water will be freely available outside the City to anyone within the kingdom. Kingdom residents may
come and drink the water at those exterior locations. Anyone within the kingdom will freely be able to drink that
spring water, but only those who are faithful will have access to the spring itself, inside the City, and thus drink the
water at its very source. The Tree of Life will be located in the City by the water (Rev 22:2). Since it is possible to
lose one’s right to the Tree of Life within the City (Rev 22:19), it is reasonable to conclude that it is equally possible
to lose one’s right to direct access to the spring itself inside the City. Since even in our day and age it is possible to
obtain exported spring water from Europe, it is reasonable to infer that spring water might also be exported (or
teleported) from the New Jerusalem as well. Just as one can drink European spring water without ever setting foot
inside Europe, it is reasonable to postulate that even those who have not visited the capital city will be able to drink
water exported from that city. After all, the leaves are evidently exported for the healing of the nations. Why not
assume that the water is likewise shared with those outside the City, especially since it freely flows outside the
City? In any case, it may be deduced that subcomers will have to drink the water of life outside the City without
being able to set foot inside the City from which the water originates during the millennial and eternal states.
       All believers will have some type of association with the Book of Life (Rev 13:8; 17:8; 20:15) and with the
water of life (Rev 21:6; 22:17; Jn 4:10). However, only overcomers will have the unique association with the Book
of Life described in Rev 3:5 and with the water of life depicted in 7:17 and 22:1-2. Both the Tree of Life and the
water of life are located in the middle of the City at the throne of God. The water of life flows forth from there
through the City, through the walls of the City, and outside into the 4D land beyond or through 3D portals to the
planet below. Those in the kingdom (but outside of the City) will have free access to the water which flows outside
the walls of the City (and presumably by portals to other locations). Yet access to the springs from which the water
originates (7:17) will be limited to overcomers. Subcomers can drink the water of life from the river of life outside
the City; overcomers can drink it directly from the springs inside the City at the throne.

                                                        Rev 21:7
         The overcomer will inherit these things, and I will be his God and he will be My son. (TM)

      Overcomers Inherit
       The very next verse in the passage explicitly states that these things are only inherited by the overcomer.
The phrase, “He who overcomes,” is a substantival participle and may be appropriately translated as “overcomer.”
Only overcomers will inherit the water of life (Rev 21:6-7). It is one thing to inherit the water and quite another
merely to drink it, which is analogous to inherit versus enter the kingdom. Subcomers will be able merely to drink
the water of life. They will drink it, but they will not be led to it. This promise of being led to the springs themselves
is limited to overcomers (7:17). Only overcomers will inherit the litotes promised in these passages. Only
overcomers are promised the litotes of having their tears wiped away. In this passage, misthological sonship is also
conditioned upon overcoming and is rewarded with the joy of a full inheritance.

       Misthological Son
       Certain things are only inherited by overcomers due to their status as mature sons. Immature children will
not inherit these things. As explained in TOD, being a son and heir of God are apparently understood dualistically
in Scripture. One can be a son at both a soteriological and misthological level. Chitwood would refer to the
soteriological sense (by an act of creation) simply being a son; the misthological sense would denote firstborn sons

336
      See Illustration 118. 3D City and Waterfalls, 299.
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                        Page 257
(by an act of adoption). Chitwood and I take different recourses to derive a similar perspective. As discussed in
MSIH, in the NT all believers are children of God (Rom 8:16; Gal 4:28), and in terms of parentage, they are also
sons of God (Gal 3:26; 4:27); nevertheless, in terms of rank, not all believers qualify as worthy to be called sons of
God (Mt 5:9; Lk 20:36; Rom 8:14,19; Heb 12:8; cp. Mt 5:44-46; Lk 6:32-35). The first two of these passages will
suffice for the present discussion:

      •   “Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God“ (Mt 5:9).
      •   And Jesus said to them, “The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage, but those who are
          considered worthy to merit that age and the resurrection from the dead, neither marry, nor are given
          in marriage; for neither can they die anymore, for they are like angels, and are sons of God, being
          sons of the resurrection.”337 (Lk 20:34-36; TM)

       One of the rewards awaiting the sons of God in the Beatitudes is inheriting the Earth (Mt 5:5). They are
rewarded with inheriting their Father’s land. A weakness in Chitwood’s argumentation is that he fails to affirm that
this elevated misthological status is eternal. Rev 21:7 affirms this differentiation in the eternal state. Because this
elevated sense of being God’s son in Rev 21:7 ties in with being His people in an elevated sense from Rev 21:3, a
further extract from MSIH is justified, though it will be abbreviated.
       According to BDAG, sons of men = humans (Mk 3:28; Eph 3:5). Thus, sonship is not limited to males. Sons
of Abraham = believers (Gal 3:7). Likewise, in that Galatian context, all believers, not just male believers, are sons
of God (Gal 3:26; 4:6-7). Furthermore, as BDAG also notes, being sons of God can refer to a special status among
devout believers and therefore is not applied to all believers indiscriminately (Mt 5:9,45; Lk 6:35; Rom 8:14,19).
However, such demarcation is not based on sexual orientation but practical sanctification. Even in the OT, being
sons of the Lord refers in a special sense to devout believers (Dt 14:1), a reference to holy people, not just males
(cp. Dt 14:2.) Being God’s sons and daughters in terms of this special status is conditioned upon personal holiness
(2Cor 6:18). As BDAG surmises, these devout believers will have “a status akin to that of angels” (Lk 20:36).
       Suffice it to say that God is endeavoring to bring His sons to experience the glory of kingdom rulership
(Heb 2:10). BDAG appropriately cites this verse in the lexical range pertaining to the special status of sonship. Not
all potential heirs of the kingdom will inherit the kingdom, as Paul notes even in Galatians (see Gal 5:21). Such
rulership is anticipated for those believers who share the status as sons of the King in the kingdom because they
have been faithful. The word sons, here, is not referring to sexuality, as such, but to status. Lexically, WH was not
referring to sexuality but to regality in such statements. Believers retaining their misthological (and thus regal)
status as sons (i.e., kingdom heirs) is contingent upon their submission to the Lord’s discipline (Heb 12:5-8).
Experiential overcomers will be God’s sons (Rev 21:7), that is, kingdom rulers. Such rulership is certainly not
limited to male believers. Huios is used inclusively regarding regality in such instances, as BDAG rightly delineates
by not putting these references in its lexical section where huios means a male.
       Notwithstanding, children is not the best translation because, although it correctly denotes generic familial
inclusiveness, it fails to convey the regal maturity necessary for this special status. Such references are best
translated as sons but interpreted as sons and daughters, with the explanation that reference to sons is being used in
the translation to point to status and maturity rather than sexuality. An exhaustive study on lexical citations is not
necessary in the current treatment since my other writings may be consulted for the misthological implications of
such texts. For present purposes, a few comments will suffice.




337
   Achieve through merit, that is, be rewarded with. “Those who are considered misthologically worthy of that
world and the resurrection out from the dead, neither marry, nor are given in marriage” (Lk 20:34; TM). See TOD
and FFG for much more detailed discussions of these passages.

                                   Illustration 88. Sons and Daughters of God




      Dillow summarizes well: “The phrase ‘I will be his God and he will be My son’ is defined elsewhere as a
statement of special honor, not of regeneration. The Davidic Covenant promised David’s son Solomon, ‘I will be
a Father to him and he will be a son to Me’ (2 Samuel 7:14). The intent of the phrase was to signify installation as
the king” (Destiny, 664-665). Commentators frequently surmise that Paul probably recalls Is 43:6, along with
several other references, in 2Cor 6:18. Regarding the NT verse, Barrett’s (BNTC) comments show that it is not just
a double entendre but a triple:

      It is significant that Paul, whose attitude to women has often been misrepresented, should modify his
      Old Testament quotation so as to include God’s daughters as well as his sons. The promise of 2
      Sam. 7:14 was originally addressed to the king; the king is Jesus, and in him men and women
      participate in his status before God.338

       As to the Corinthian context, Lenski states: “This means more than ‘children’ who are dear to me. ‘Sons’
connotes all the high rights of sonship, and ‘daughters’ does the same” (LCNT). Yet practical sanctification is of
extreme importance for believers because their status as sons and daughters of the King is contingent upon their
personal purity, being separate, being clean. In fact, Garland (NAC) uses Dt 32:16-19 as a key passage to explain
Paul’s explicit inclusion of daughters in 1Cor 6:18. In the OT context, God is angry because His sons and daughters,
whom He had begotten, were sacrificing to new demonic gods. His people had forgotten Him. As a result, God
spurned His regenerate OT sons and daughters.339 In the NT counterpart, Paul is likewise concerned that God may
do the same in regard to NT sons and daughters. Garland thus concludes: “Deuteronomy 32 is therefore clearly
associated in Paul’s mind as a source for combating the problems of idolatry. Again, the quotation from the Old
Testament derives from a context that attacks any connection with idols.” Paul’s concern for the Corinthians is in
the realm of misthology, not soteriology. Their regal status and inheritance rights were at stake, not their
regeneration. If they are unrighteous in their behavior, they will not inherit the kingdom (1Cor 6:9-10; cp. Gal 5:21;
Eph 5:5; 1Chron 28:6-9). They will enter the kingdom, of course, since they are regenerate, but to inherit the
kingdom requires personal holiness.

    Actually, these son-to-Me parallels embed a double entendre inside the triple entendre: (1) Solomon—picturing
both (a) unconditional security (2Sam 7:14-15; cp. 1Kgs 11:11-12) and (b) conditional regality (1Chron 28:6-9)—
(2) Christ (Heb 1:5), and (3) believers (2Cor 6:16-18).

    Though the people of Israel are God’s sons and daughters in the national sense in that they are born to God by

1:12-13).
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                        Page 259
        Sons (in Dt 32:20) is a summary term for sons and daughters in (Dt 32:19). Sons is a synecdoche in which a
part is used for the whole—sons and daughters. The emphasis in the synecdoche is not on sexuality but status. All
of God’s regenerate children—females included—have the potential to qualify for inheriting the kingdom if they
live in a worthy manner. Thus, Peter urges husbands to live with their wives in an understanding way and grant
them honor since their wives are co-heirs (1Pet 3:7). In terms of regeneration and thus potential misthological status,
Paul says that believers are “all sons of God through faith….there is neither male nor female….heirs according to
promise” (Gal 3:26-29).
        For brevity’s sake, since Dillow and I address soteriological and misthological sonship at length in our
writings and are in substantial agreement regarding the basics, a list of some special-status sonship passages will
suffice here:
                                     Illustration 89. Misthological Sons of God
•     Believers are to be holy people because they are sons of God (Dt 14:1-2).340
•     Believers who are peacemakers will be called sons of God (Mt 5:9).
•     Believers who love and forgive will be sons of their Father (Mt 5:44-45).
•     Believers who are led by the Spirit are sons of God (Rom 8:14).
•     Believers who suffer with Christ will be revealed in glory as sons of God (Rom 8:17-19).
•     Believers who are worthy of the out-resurrection will be like angels and be sons of God (Lk 20:35-36).
•     Believers who trust the Lord will be brought to glory as sons (Heb 2:10).
•     Believers who submit to the Lord’s discipline will be His sons rather than illegitimate children (Heb 12:5-8).
•     Believers who overcome will inherit the rewards and be God’s sons (Rev 21:7).

Since the term sons of God is an expression that denotes special status in the NT and is not intended to be limited
to male sexuality and since the NT builds upon the OT in making this association, we should infer that the same is
true of the OT. Sons of God, when used of special status, should not be limited to male sexuality. Faithful human
sons and daughters of God will replace unfaithful angelic sons and daughters of God in the divine council.
       Jesus will be King of kings. These kings are composed of believers who are “called and chosen and faithful”
(Rev 17:12). The term kings is obviously being used generically to refer to a status, not to male exclusivity. Peter
confirms that co-glorified human females are to be fellow heirs (sugkleronomos), that is, co-heirs with their
husbands: “Husbands likewise, live with your wives in an understanding way, as with a weaker vessel, since she is
a woman; and grant her honor as a fellow heir of the grace of life [which would include the crown of life], so that
your prayers may not be hindered” (1Pet 3:7). The divine plan is for couples to become overcomers and co-rulers
as god-goddess couples throughout eternity. They will live as gods and goddesses in the Heavenly City. This thesis
has been defended at length in MSIH and logistical problems addressed therein.
       Anderson stresses the importance of Christians knowing both the penalties and rewards they will receive in
accordance to how they live and gives this illustration:

               Imagine talking to your college-aged son about the importance of attending school and trying
        hard. You tell him that if he is caught skipping classes, he’ll be given consequences. These penalties
        will start small, you explain, adding that they’ll intensify the more often he skips. The penalties for
        repeating this practice in fact will escalate to the point that your son will need to move out of your
        home (remember, we’re talking about your college-aged child), forcing him to be his own financial
        provider. On the other hand, you say there is a reward for him if he works hard, applies himself with
        his best effort, maintains good attendance, and studies intently. The incentive for doing well, you tell
        him, is that when he graduates from college, you’ll pay off his student debt. 341 (Emphasis his.)

He concludes: “This beautiful city is open for any and all who will remain true and faithful to God until the end….
The Lord wants to share this city with us, and this story shows us the lengths to which He is willing to go to bring
us into this peaceful, beautiful, eternal setting with Him” (p. 175). Only faithful believers obtain this Reward City.

       As explained in MMP2, the antithetical juxtaposition in Rev 21:7-8 is between faithful believers in verse 7
and unbelievers in verse 8. The cowardly unbelievers in v. 8, who have their portion in the Lake of Fire, are not to
be interpreted as unfaithful believers. Verse 8 is a picture of the unregenerate in the eternal state. Verse 7 is a picture
of the faithful regenerate in the eternal state. Unfaithful regenerate believers are not part of the apposition.

differences, Chitwood and I can be said to agree, in terms of the bottom line, that verse 8 provides a metaphorical
picture of subcomers being hurt by the second death.

soteriological) as it pertains to unbelievers, which is its proper interpretation, and secondarily green (i.e.,
misthological) as it pertains to unfaithful believers, which is its correlative application. We both perceive a
misthological understanding of verse 8. But, in terms of this color scheme, he sees a simple yellow misthological
text; whereas, I perceive a composite green misthological text. From this perspective, I can justify a limited litotetic
reversal (LLR) for this soteric-mistholic juxtaposition of this soteric-mistholic-litotic (SML) text. Considering the
advancements in MMP4 and MMP5, the illustration from MMP2 can be updated as follows.

       In my perspective and in accordance with my principle of correlativity, verse 8 does not make this application
to unfaithful believers directly, but indirectly, not merely millennially, but emphatically eternally. Verse 8 is to be
interpreted literally, not metaphorically. Just as unbelievers are literally excluded from the City (in the Lake of Fire
outside the heavenly realm), so unfaithful believers are literally excluded from the City (in the Celestial Outer
Darkness in the outer realm of the heavenly realm). The realm of their exclusion is different, but the duration of
their exclusion is the same—forever.
       Because I derive this metaphorical application indirectly rather than directly, and secondarily to literal
interpretation, I generally prefer to refer to this secondary application as being correlative rather than metaphorical,
which helps distinguish it from other approaches, such as that by Chitwood. His direct approach has the benefit of
simplicity. But in failing to see the underlying soteric-mistholic juxtaposition, his model loses something of the
literary beauty implemented by the biblical writer. Thus, the literal separation (↔) of the noncomers from the City
(pictured on the left) finds a correlative (≅) application to the literal extraction (→) of the subcomers from the City
(pictured on the right). In other words, just as unbelievers are literally cast from their place of judgment at
the Great White Throne into the Lake of Fire, which is outside of the City, unfaithful believers are literally
cast from their place of judgment outside into the Celestial Outer Darkness, which is also outside the City.
The picture on the left describes the literal separation as pictured in Rev 21:7-8 between overcomers and noncomers
(that is, unbelievers who do not come and take the water of life freely). The picture on the right shows literal
application to subcomers.

       Terran Directions Still Apply
       When I was presenting this material to our Sunday School class, one of the participants posed a very
interesting question: If the terrestrial New Jerusalem is at the top of the planet and the celestial New Jerusalem is
above the planet, then how can the gates of the City be on the North side? Commentators are diverse in their
interpretations. Alford (AGT) relates it to the Jewish nature of the gates: “Each gate is to be imagined as used by
each tribe: the twelve tribes of Israel represent the whole people of God, and the city the encampment of Israel.”
Weymouth offers a more encompassing idiomatic opinion: “The city lies open and accessible to all quarters, and
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                     Page 262
                     342
to all quarters alike.” Exell (TBI) likewise comments: “Notice the points of the compass toward which these gates
look. They are not on one side, or on two sides, or on three sides, but on four sides. What does that mean? Why, it
means that all nationalities are included.” Constable (TCENB) offers a spatial assessment: “Evidently directions
will exist in the new creation as they do in the old suggesting that space will exist throughout eternity as well as
time (cf. 20:10)”.
        Mounce (NICNT), on the other hand, takes a completely different track and offers a conceptual, rather than
literal, suggestion:

      John chooses to list the sides of the city in the order of east, north, south, west (v. 13), although Ezekiel,
      who seems to be his model, places north before east. One suggestion is that John chooses “the most
      erratic” order to discourage any interest his readers might have in the “zodiacal cycle.” The twelve
      angels are celestial gatekeepers and may reflect the Isaianic picture of watchmen upon the walls of
      Jerusalem (Isa 62:6). They belong to the concept of an ideal city.

       When possible, literal rather than merely conceptual explanations should be preferred. John is not merely
giving us conceptual information about an ideal city but some type of spatial information about accessing a literal
city. Thus, such nonliteral approaches are secondary, and theories about discouraging zodiacal interests are actually
objectionable if the gospel has been written in the zodiacal stars. Better theories are warranted. My proposal will
combine various suggestions made by others: (1) Mounce’s observation of the celestial nature of the gatekeepers
can be enjoined with (2) Constable’s notation about space and (3) Alford’s application to Israel and (4) Weymouth
and Exell’s idiomatic extrapolation to all nations.
       My hypothesis is that John is seeing the City from outer space in relation to the planet Earth below and
indicating that this City can be approached from all conceivable spacial directions but switches the typical terrestrial
sequence to indicate that these spacial directions are not limited to the typical terrestrial four corners of the Earth.
This City is to the celestial North of the planet and is assessed from the celestial North. Some interpreters, like
Derek Gilbert, believe that reference to Mount Zion being in the far north refers to the uttermost North, the cosmic
supernatural north: “Beautiful in elevation, the joy of the whole earth, is Mount Zion in the far north, the city of
the great King” (Ps 48:2).343
       Gilbert pits Mount Zion against Mount Zaphon and believes Lucifer wanted to set up his rival throne on the
latter mountain: “You said to yourself, ‘I will climb up to the sky. Above the stars of El I will set up my throne. I
will rule on the mountain of assembly on the remote slopes of Zaphon’” (Is 14:13; NET). However, Gilbert admits
that the English translations adopting his perspective are few.344 Only three of the twenty-nine translations I
consulted render the Hebrew word tsaphon as Zaphon (a proper place) as opposed to north (direction) in this verse.
The NIB/NIV renders it as the utmost heights. The rest of the translations render it as the north/North. While
Gilbert’s view might be plausible, I do not find it probable. The same Hebrew word tsaphon is used in Ps 48:2.
NET renders that verse as: “Mount Zion resembles the peaks of Zaphon.” To its credit, NET is consistent in
rendering it the same in both verses. However, the majority opinion is also consistent in rendering it directionally:
“But you said in your heart, ‘I will ascend to heaven; I will raise my throne above the stars of God, and I will sit on
the mount of assembly in the recesses of the north” (Is 14:13). Nevertheless, to a considerable extent, I concur

      like the moon which turns the same face to the earth or the planet Venus which always turns the same
      side toward the sun.

      scientists geostationary, which will allow the satellite to match the earth’s speed of rotation. Hence,
      the heavenly city will remain stationary over earthly Jerusalem. This second possibility, by defining
      the distance involved, will mean that the city, a third of the size of the moon or larger, will be eleven
      times closer than the present moon.

during the eternal state. After all, Phillips himself concedes that Rev 21:11ff is describing Heavenly Jerusalem, not
Earthly Jerusalem. Nevertheless, I share Phillips’ perspective that Earthly Jerusalem and Heavenly Jerusalem are
linked throughout the millennial kingdom and the eternal state, with New Jerusalem being a stationary Satellite City

       Infinite Universal Terran Access to 3D Cities
       If the above explanation is deemed too technical, the visionary approach taken by Alexander Patterson in
1896 remains viable, indeed, perhaps even superior. We will examine his statement shortly.349 Taking an entirely
different approach, Patterson believes the four terrestrial directions are noted because they are intended to
denote access to the terrestrial realms scattered throughout space, throughout the entire universe! Giving all
four terrestrial directions to the Space City is intended to indicate that the Space City has access to and is
accessible from Terrans throughout the universe. Patterson suggests that it is through flights through space.
I have updated his proposal by suggesting teleportals. Nevertheless, I must credit him for the foundational
explanation. My universal teleportal explanation to provide the reason for the Terran directions of the gates
is indebted to his original suggestion.
       Putting the pieces together, I pose two basic suggestions as to why John provides the terrestrial directions to
a spacial city. The first series of explanations is focused on Earth. The second series is broadened to earth. I will
then combine the two suggestions to form a synergy in the third proposal. Finally, and fourthly, a suggestion dealing
with a remaining logistical problem will be posed.
       First, in direct association with this particular planet, Earth, John can refer to the twelve gates of the
Space City as being directed toward the four points of the compass of its earthly counterpart because the
Space City will turn at the same rate as the Earth City, and the gates of the Space City’s four sides will always
face the same direction as its counterpart on Earth. The gates to the Earth City will probably serve as
entrances to portal gates to the Space City. Because the Earth will remain slightly tilted at an angle to the sun,
the Earth City should be perceived as being at the geomagnetic north pole. Therefore, the magnetic north pole will
not be in the exact same location, so the Earth City still lies to the north of the magnetic north pole. Since the Space
City is accessed through the same gates as the Earth City, entrance through the earthly gates of the Earth
City can be taken as an entrance by its corresponding gates of the Space City. Northern Gate 1 on Earth, for
instance, will also be the corresponding name for Northern Gate 1 on the Space City. Of course, teleportals from
the Earth City to the Heavenly City will not be the only means of travel between these terrestrial and spacial cities.
Spacecraft accessing the gates of the Space City would access these northern, southern, eastern, and western gates,
as they are denoted, in accordance with their alignment and association with the northern, southern, eastern, and
western gates of the Earth City below. Additionally, the Space City would still be assessed spatially from the north

       Second, in universal association with all planets throughout the multiverse, John links terrestrial
directions that would be applicable to all planets to the Space City. Every planet has a north, south, east, and
west. John has not used the typical order associated with the millennium so as to hint at something different in
association with the Space City. Terran coordinates will still apply because the Space City is still accessible
from the earth (ground) of all inhabited planets throughout the multiverse and the Space City has access to
the earth (ground) of all inhabited planets throughout the multiverse. Even in 1896, Alexander Patterson
apparently envisioned this eventuality.
       Third, one way to accommodate Patterson’s proposal would be to have spaceships from all planets
being able to come (via teleportals, in my opinion) to the Space City above Earth. In eternity future, this
would entail trillions of spaceships trying to access this one Space City, all at one time, seemingly, a logistical
nightmare. Infinite universal 3D City access would require infinite 3D Cities. The access would have to be
unlimited in its capacity to accommodate the infinite growth of the human population. Accordingly, I propose
that the Space City will be replicated throughout space to accommodate infinite Terran 3D City access. The
3D Teleportal City could be located above every planet inhabited by a significant number of Terrans.
Moreover, the Space City would, in each case, as described above in relation to Earth, have its four sides
always face the same direction as its counterpart on the earth/ground of the planet below. Sometimes it is
hard to determine if erets/ge (the Hebrew and Greek terms respectively) should be translated as Earth or earth. In
this case, both renditions apply. The Terran kings of all earths, including this one, Earth, will bring the glory
and honor of all Terrans scattered throughout the multiverse into the Space City located above their
respective earths to gain access into the gates at the lower level of the City and do business with the heavenly
gods and goddesses therein. These gods and goddesses, in turn, have access to all the 3D Space Cities
throughout the Multiverse Wide Web (MWW) and, of course, to the Hub City, the 4D City in the heavenly
realm.
       Fourth, posing the existence of unlimited functioning replicas of the 3D City does not address the
problem of finding qualified couples to run them. As noted previously and explained in MSIH, God’s design is
for overcoming couples to rule together as gods and goddesses. For the sake of sheer illustration, suppose there are
one billion overcomers and thus half a billion overcoming couples, ignoring logistical recalibrations for the moment.
How will this finite number of gods and goddesses rule trillions of 3D Cities? They cannot, at least not
reasonably, even if they use time dilation to be in multiple Cities at seemingly the same time. The number of angels
and overcomers is finite.351 They can only be spread so thin over guarding and ruling so many 3D Cities.
Overcomers might create AIs (artificial intelligences) to act as their respective representatives in that capacity.
Alternatively, and much more likely, overcomers will employ multiple tiers of gods and goddesses to act as
subordinate deities.

       Infinite Personnel for 3D Cities
       The original design was for mankind to populate and rule the Earth and, in due time, as the population
increased and spread to other planets, to rule other earths as well. However, only overcomers will qualify as bridal
residents of the original 3D City. For logistical reasons, as noted above, I pose that the 3D City will be
essentially cloned; that is, infinite copies will be made that can function as portal cities, serving as hubs to
and from other terrestrial locations to allow infinite Terran 3D-City access. Yet the number of overcomers
qualified to rule as bridal rulers will presumably be completed at the Judgment Seat of Christ (JSC), or, if not then,

        Most, if not all, of those mortal believers who are faithful during the millennial kingdom will enter the
eternal state as smortals so that they can reproduce in the eternal state. This proposition is deductively
certain. Promises made by God to humanity and concerning humanity, as well as God’s original design, require
this conclusion (see TOD and MSIH). Notwithstanding, some smortals will be kings of the Earth and of the earths.
Each king will have his queen. Those smortals who serve faithfully as kings and queens will probably be
allowed to obtain godhood in a similar fashion as the overcomers. But it will not be the identical level of
godhood as the bridal saints. For logistical and theological reasons, I pose that faithful smortals can become gods
and goddesses, thus residences of the 3D City above the planet they are ruling, as is posed by some other writers as
well. Yet, because the overcomers who compose the Bride of Christ are co-rulers with Christ and have been
made beautiful by the trials they have faced and by the battle with sin they have overcome, these bridal
overcomers must be the highest-ranking Gods and Goddesses. These bridal overcomers will be worshipped (see
my IMOC regarding Rev 3:9). Consequently, at least two tiers of human elohim must be postulated. My hypotheses
as to how these two primary tiers operate are as follows.
        First-tier human Gods and Goddesses will compose the Bride of Christ. They will live in the 4D City
and access Earth through the 3D City above Earth. The name of this 3D City above Earth is New Jerusalem.
Functioning replicas/clones of this 3D City will be employed above other earths, but the original 3D City
above Earth will be the archetype 3D City used by and associated with these bridal Gods and Goddesses:
Earthly 3D City = New Jerusalem = 3D archetype.
        Second-tier human gods and goddesses will be composed of smortals who become immortals. Smortals
who serve the Lord with the greatest faithfulness and capableness in eternity future will eventually become
immortals. As humanity continues to increase in number and expand throughout the multiverse, the need
for additional gods and goddesses will increase. Advancement will be made available as the need arises.
Because eternity can be divided into endless ages, multiple tiers of gods and goddesses might be posed. In any
case, whether there are only two tiers or an infinite number of tiers, the number of human gods and goddesses will
infinitely increase as humanity continues to increase and expand infinitely. These human gods and goddesses will
have a lower rank and be a lower-class of divine beings than the bridal Gods and Goddesses. Allowing at least a
secondary level of human gods and goddesses is pragmatically necessary. Additionally, it has some theological
advantages. It underscores the misthological nature of the Lord. “God is a rewarder” (Heb 11:6). Plus, God is the
same “the same yesterday and today, yes and forever” (Heb 13:8). This proposal of second-tier human gods and
goddesses allows that God will still be able to award immortality to faithful humans throughout eternity, just as He
does now (Rom 2:6-7). Smortals can become immortals. Yet they cannot rise to the rank of Bridal immortals.
        The conclusion reached in DOLF is that the term elohim is extremely broad and can be used to refer to all
spiritual beings living in the spiritual realm of God’s economy and functioning at all levels of God’s bureaucracy.
Ps 45:6-15 is best taken as describing the top three tiers of these elohim participating in a royal wedding taking
place between the top two tiers of elohim.

        Your throne, O God [Elohim], is forever and ever. The scepter of Your kingdom is a scepter of

This Psalm describes a royal wedding. Four principle participants are noted, and one auxiliary group:

      1.   The Groom is referred to as: God [Elohim], King, and Lord.
      2.   The groomsmen are referred to as: His male companions, His fellows.
      3.   The Bride is referred to as: Queen, Daughter, Princess.
      4.   The bridesmaids are referred to as: daughters of kings, Her ladies of honor, Her virgin companions.
           • The wealthy are referred to in an auxiliary capacity as: people of Tyre, the richest people.

        Jesus is marrying His Bride. Like must marry like. God forbids crossbreeding. He took a very dim view of
angels mating with humans and producing demigods, or angels or humans mating with animals to produce chimeras.
The Bride is not a demigoddess. She is a Goddess. Christ is God. He cannot marry a mortal. For that matter, He
cannot marry a demigoddess. He cannot even marry a goddess. Angels are not suitable marriage companions. A
higher class of being is necessary to be a suitable marriage partner for Christ. The Bride sufficiently shares Christ’s
nature both ontologically and experientially to marry the God-Man. She alone qualifies to be His Bride. Just as God
had to form Eve from Adam’s body to be a suitable companion for him, God also had to form the Bride out of
Christ’s human body and corporate body to be a suitable companion for Him.
        High-ranking angels are attending the wedding as companions of the Groom and Bride. Yet even the highest-
ranking angels cannot qualify to be the Bride. Human bridal believers will become Gods and Goddesses: middle-
class elohim. The mixture of upper-case English and lower-case Hebrew is being used to show their middle-class
status:

      1. Jesus is the God-Man (supreme Elohim) who is represented by the Groom.
      2. Human bridal Gods and Goddesses (second-class elohim) are represented by the Bride.
      3. High-ranking angelic gods and goddesses (third-class elohim) attend as male and female companions.

       The Bride will be composed of overcomers (Gods and Goddesses) who will live with the Lord in the
Heavenly City/Palace, functioning at the very highest levels of God’s economy and bureaucracy. The NAS rightly
capitalizes King in Ps 45:15. Beirnes does one better and capitalizes both: “King’s Palace.” His translation and
capitalization are implemented above. He concludes his chapter on the Bride of Christ in Ps 45 with this
observation.352 The King’s Palace is New Jerusalem. This Heavenly City was the abode of the King and angelic
gods and goddesses from the time He first created it, but it was designed to become the abode of the Queen—the
Gods and Goddesses who would compose the Bride. When Lucifer rebelled, this Palace became a warship, which
should not be considered strange since a king’s palace may serve as a military fortress in the time of war.
Nevertheless, its primary function is its eternal function, to serve as the Palace for the King and Queen.
       Third-level elohim (angelic gods and goddesses) will retain their high-ranking status but be lower in rank,
function, and nature than these human-divine Gods and Goddesses. For simplicity’s sake, these third-tiered elohim
can simply be referred to as angels. High-ranking humans will be lower in status than the third-tiered elohim. These
high-ranking mortal humans are pictured in the Psalm as merely being wealthy in terms of earthly possessions, not
as being royalty. (These will be the Terran kings of the Earth.) Not all humanity will be higher than the angels.

       In view of the present study, the question arises as to whether second-tier human elohim would be superior
or inferior to third-tiered elohim composed of high-ranking angels. Will all human gods and goddesses outrank all
angelic gods and goddesses? We will have to reason from the known to the unknown to provide a tentative answer.
We know that not all faithful angels qualify to be on the divine council. Angels vary in rank among themselves.
God did not create all angels equal. He placed the higher order of their number, such as archangels, in positions of
authority over lower orders of their angelic counterparts. Likewise, not all bridal believers will have the same rank
relative to one another, though they will all be higher in rank than the highest-ranking angels. Consequently, we
can infer that second-tier human elohim will: (1) vary in rank relative to one another; (2) all be in a lower rank than
the lowest ranking first-tier human elohim, (3) all be in higher rank than the highest-ranking Terran king, and
(4) probably vary in rank compared to angels.
       The status of second-tier human elohim relative to angels is speculative, and I hypothesize that it is relative
rather than absolute in relation to angels. This relative-to ranking is denoted on the chart by placing these second-
tier humans to the right of angelic elohim and having them run (A) above, (B) parallel, and (C) below the angelic
spectrum. The parallel portion is colored similarly to the angelic spectrum denoting similarity in rank. Because of
the expansion and corresponding color-coding adaptation in the chart, the color-coding of the text from Ps 45:6-15
was adjusted to match.

       Rather than repeat the analysis in DOLF, I will add a few summary remarks and build upon them in
consequence of the present study. God is the supreme Elohim, the supreme Immortal (denoted by the upper case in
both cases). All other elohim are lower-ranking and lower-class immortals (denoted by the lower case of elohim
and immortals). The groomsmen and bridesmaids in the Psalm are intended by Scripture to represent male and
female angelic elohim attending the marriage celebration. They are lower-class gods and goddesses (denoted by
the lower case of gods and goddesses) in comparison to the Bride (denoted by the upper case of Gods and
Goddesses).
       Three additional groups have been added to the chart and have red text in their conclusion. The wealthy
represent the Terran kings of the Earth during the millennial kingdom who will be bringing their riches to the Bridal
City in order to enter into the lowest levels of the City. These Terran kings will be comprised primarily of mortals,
though some TZ (Twilight Zone) immortals might also be postulated. Any TZ immortals, however, do not qualify
to be classified as elohim.
       Not discussed in the passage but added by means of the chart are subsequent relatives of the Bride. These
relatives come on the scene after the millennial marriage celebration and are thus not part of the passage in
Psalms 45. Nevertheless, to retain the imagery of the passage, I will treat them as subsequent relatives of the Bride
born after the wedding. Thus, their designation as subsequent relatives on the chart is used dually to denote their
relative-of bridal relation and relative-to angelic status. Posing that smortals can become immortals who qualify
to rule from the 3D Cities provides the needed infinite number of human elohim rulers. Proportionally, these
second-class human immortals will always be much smaller in number than the vast number of smortals.
Nevertheless, these second-tier human elohim will provide enough divine rulers to run the 3D Cities throughout the
multiverse.353

them!” (KL 4667) And I would agree with him in inferring from Cabalistic literature that transformed humans will

             Rabbinic lore teaches that not only was Enoch translated into heaven, but also that he was

we might become beings more powerful than themselves” (KL 4690-4692).
        From a RET perspective, it might be objected that Lucifer fell long before the creation of Adam and Eve, so

even the highest angel. Some of the angels objected and decided to take it upon themselves to evolve into
higher-order beings themselves. Lucifer decided to evolve into a higher order of divinity, to become higher
than God. Unbeknown to them, their fall was the very catalyst that God would use to make an ADAM
superior to them!355

       Unfortunately, Hines rejects the fundamentals of the faith in favor of a Cabalistic interpretation that poses
that humanity must take the matter into its own hands and learn how to reactivate the stargates and make themselves
divine by achieving divinity: “So what is the secret knowledge that leads to God? A surface-level reading would

As a fundamentalist, I hold to the fundamentals of the faith and demonstrate in MSIH, DOLF, IMOC, and here in
MMP5 that the Spirit expects us to achieve divinity by fidelity to the Scripture. We receive a divine nature by simple
faith in Christ for eternal life. However, to become Gods and Goddesses who misthologically use the portals, we
must follow the logical implications of the text. Hines has inverted the text and put the cart before the horse in
posing that we must use the portals to become gods and goddesses. His inversion is indicative of a perversion:
             Recalling what is depicted in Genesis, mankind was not only exiled from the Garden for

Hines is toying with Gnostic thought in thinking that the God in Genesis is the bad guy. In a footnote to the above
material, he adds,
             I say that this being might not actually be “God” because it seems more like it could be the
      Angel of Yahweh (or even some other deity as the Gnostics claimed), especially since he physically
      interacts with people and the environment (e.g., Genesis 3:8). I say this because if it was really God,
      then why does he have difficulty locating Adam and Eve in the garden (Genesis 3:9–11) if God is
      supposed to be omniscient? Furthermore, this being routinely tries to preserve the ignorance of the
      human race and keep them in a subordinate position so that they will not become like the angels.
      Specifically, he drives Adam and Eve out of the garden so that they cannot eat from the Tree of Life
      (Genesis 3:22–24), and he destroys the Tower of Babel so that humans cannot reach heaven (Genesis
      11:5-9). (KL 6864-6869)

        He has misconstrued various points. For one thing, God did not drive man out because He was afraid
that humans might become as powerful as the gods. On the contrary, the Lord drove him out so that he might
experience redemption and then go on to overcome and thus become more powerful than the gods. Hines
should have been able to put these pieces together from his own statements in his own book. Just before making the
first ridiculous statement above, he correctly noted: “Jesus says, ‘Let anyone who has an ear to hear listen to what
the Spirit is saying to the churches. To everyone who conquers, I will give permission to eat from the tree of life
that is in the paradise of God.’” Long story short, the way redeemed humans become Gods and Goddesses is
by conquering/overcoming. Eating the Tree of Life is not the means to becoming Gods and Goddesses but
the result of becoming Gods and Goddesses. Hines’ inversion leads to perversion. For another thing, Jesus, as the
Angel of Yahweh, could interact with Adam and Eve in such a way as to circumscribe the exercise of His
omnipotence and omniscience. Otherwise, Adam and Eve would not have been able to look on His face and live
(Ex 33:20). Likewise, Jesus can choose not to know certain things while in this limited state. For example, while
lying in a manger as a human baby, Jesus was not, in that form, exercising His omniscience. Rather, He was taking
a form that would allow Him to learn by experience what learning by experience is like. God can exercise selective
amnesia and selective omniscience (see POV).
        For that matter, even when acting from unlimited knowledge, the Lord tests us to know what is in our hearts
(Dt 8:2), to know whether we love Him or not (Dt 13:3). His calling upon Abraham to offer up Isaac was a case in
point. After Abraham successfully overcame the trial, as the Angel of the Lord, Jesus told Abraham, “Now I know



a higher order of being just as a caterpillar can transform into a butterfly. This potential micro transformation is part

unique in this ability and capacity.

that you fear God” (Gen 22:12). “God already knew this, but now it is known by experience” (Fruchtenbaum,

       For another matter, those like Hines who want to reactivate the stargates and make themselves divine by

             “God expelled the dragon and his followers from heaven,” Michael explained. “They were cast
