        I posed something similar in TOD for believers who, for example, repent but do so too late to qualify for
living in the Heavenly City. In their case, serving the Lord faithfully, even after being rejected in terms of the gospel
of the kingdom, still counts for something rather significant. Like the prodigal son, they still might be given a robe
and ring and welcomed into the house, though not as having an inheritance. Their residency will be on Earth, but
they will be allowed to enter the Heavenly City when they bring a tribute from their territories on Earth. They bring
their tribute in order that they may enter the City (Rev 21:26; HMT; TM). They do not have free access to the City.
But as low-ranking kings, they can at least enter the City when they bring tribute. Residency in the City is, of course,
reserved for bridal overcomers who earned the right to live there and rightfully enter by the gates. These low-
ranking earthly kings, in contrast, forfeited their opportunity to dwell in the City when they made being the Bride
of Christ a common thing, having taught that all believers will compose the Bride. As a result of having defamed
and profaned the Bride when they were teachers on Earth, the most they can hope to do in the future is to bow
before her feet when they bring a tribute from their earthly territories into her city.
        If the above conjecture is correct, then raptured and resurrected believers who have been found semi-faithful
at the JSC might (1) have redeemed immortal bodies that do not glow with glory and (2) do not qualify to live in
the Heavenly City, but they nevertheless (3) are qualified to serve as low-ranking kings in the terrestrial realm
during the millennial kingdom. In the present study, I would further suggest that the faithful believers who live until
the end of the millennial kingdom might similarly be given positions of authority in smortal bodies at the beginning
of the eternal state.385 Indeed, both proposals could be enjoined to speculate that the kings of the Earth during the
eternal state will be comprised of both sets: semi-faithful immortal believers and faithful smortal believers. As the
human population continues to expand to other planets, more and more mortal kings will be necessary.
Misthological advancement does not stagnate. My theory is that (1) semi-faithful premillennial immortals,
(2) faithful millennial mortals, and (3) faithful eternal smortals might qualify for low-ranking ruling
positions in the terrestrial realm and constitute the kings of the various terrestrial planets, such as Earth,
during the eternal state.386 Thus, the Terran kings are composed of three groups. Logistical considerations have
led me further to hypothesize that the latter of these, the ruling smortals, can eventually qualify to become
second-tier ruling immortals.387 Nevertheless, these gods and goddesses will be vassal elohim to the original bridal
Gods and Goddesses.

                                                Rev 22:14
      As noted in TOD, Seymour ties Jn 14:2 together with Rev 22:14 in a manner that is highly anticipatory of
the position developed herein:

      The city is not Heaven; it is only a part of Heaven….The New Jerusalem is obviously the most glorious
      mansion of Heaven, but it is not the only one. And those who know the Lord and are obedient to
      Him will have the right to enter in through the gates of the New Jerusalem and also to eat the 12
      manner of fruit of the tree of life.388

       Seymour is on the brink of suggesting that this City is itself a reward. He certainly implies that living in this
City is a reward limited to faithful believers since he pictures it as the mansion prepared for obedient believers.
Unfaithful believers will be given other mansions (i.e., other cities) in which to live. Multiple reasons have been

provided herein for coming to a similar conclusion.
        The New Jerusalem is a City of Rest that unfaithful believers are prohibited from even entering at all
(Num 14:23; Ps 95:11; 132:13-14; Heb 3:11; 4:3,5). Special entrance by the gates is reserved for the faithful
(Is 26:1-2). Because the unfaithful are barred from any and all entrances, the special entrance of the faithful must
not be taken to mean that the unfaithful will be able to enter by some other means. Since the City is a reward
(Heb 11:14,16; 13:14), those who lose their right to this reward completely lose their right to this City. Just as we
would not picture a subcomer being allowed to borrow an overcomer’s crown, we should not picture subcomers as
being able to take subways into the City. When Jesus threatens to take away the unfaithful believer’s portion in this
City, we are left to conclude that this means that their participation in this City will be completely revoked since
they will not have access to the fruit and springs of this City (Rev 7:17; 19:7-8). This Bridal City is a reward for
bridal saints (Rev 21:2,9-10; 22:2,12, 14,19), not a gift for all believers. It is the festive City (Is 25:6-9) from which
unfaithful believers will be expelled (Mt 8:11-12). Their expulsion is the parabolic and telolic end of the
misthological story. We have no right to try to rewrite the end of the story.
        In addition to the above extraction from TOD, various possibilities about other entrances into the City apart
from the gates were discussed therein, as well as various theories about entrance via the gates. Focus herein, though,
will be limited to the thesis that bridal overcomers will be the only ones who have the right to enter by the gates
into the City. Entrance into the City via its gates by the Terran kings of the Earth will not be a right but a
purchased privilege. As discussed above in Rev 21:24-26, Terran kings will have to pay to enter by the gates by
bringing tribute from the nations. Since Terran kings may enter by the gates without having the natural misthological
right to do so, a better translation of Rev 22:14 is needed than the typical ones normally provided. The NAS, for
example, is typical: “Blessed are those who wash their robes, that they may have the right to the tree of life, and
may enter by the gates into the city.” Such translations give the impression that overcomers are the only ones who
can enter by the gates into the City. More likely, however, overcomers are the only ones who have the blood-washed
right to enter by the gates into the City. Terran kings, in contrast, who enter the City by its gates, do not have the
blood-washed right to do so. Their entrance by the gates must be obtained by some other means.
        Entrance by the gates by bridal overcomers (who have washed their robes in practical sanctification during
the course of their lives) is their misthological right. Kings of the Earth, on the other hand, may pay homage to enter
by the gates to purchase leaves from the Tree of Life, but their entrance and access to the leaves must be procured.
Their entrance is not a blood-washed right but a monetarily procured privilege for which they must repeatedly pay.
The owner of the Biltmore House, for example, does not pay to enter by its doors. Tourists, however, must pay to
do so and purchase their general admission tickets repeatedly. Likewise, overcomers enter their City by its gates as
their right. Others who enter their City by its gates must pay them an admission price each time they come into the
City.
        The context inductively leads to this conclusion, and the grammar of the verse allows it. As to the grammar,
Beale (NIGTC) says,

         The future indicative ἔσται (“will be”) is equivalent in use to a subjunctive since it follows ἵνα and is
         parallel with the following subjunctive εἰσέλθωσιν. Zerwick suggests that ἵνα could be causal
         (“because”), which would make sense, but the typical final sense (“so that”) is preferable because of
         the following subjunctive and because the causal sense is rare in the NT.

A generic rendering that helps portray Beale’s point would be:
         14
           Blessed are those who wash their robes, so that [ἵνα] they may (1) have [future indicative ἔσται] the
         right to the tree of life and may (2) enter [final subjunctive εἰσέλθωσιν] by the gates into the city. (Rev
         22:14; TM)

The hina (ἵνα) governs both the statements about the tree and gates, making them parallel so that they both have the
sense of a final subjunctive, which can be rendered as: in order that they may or so that. The parallelism Beale
seems to suggest is:
         14
              Blessed are those who wash their robes, so that [ἵνα] they may:
389
      See Rev 21:2, 234.
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                           Page 305

                    (1) have [future indicative ἔσται] the right to the tree of life and
                    (2) enter [final subjunctive εἰσέλθωσιν] by the gates into the city. (Rev 22:14; TM)

The right to the Tree of Life is parallel to the entrance by the gates. Accordingly, entrance by the gates is a right by
those who have washed their robes via the obedience of practical sanctification. Since we can infer from the context
that others will enter by the gates but from the verse that only those who wash their robes have the right to eat of
the Tree of Life, which is parallel to the entrance by the gates, a better sense of the parallelism would be:
       14
            Blessed are those who wash their robes, so that [ἵνα] they may have [ἔσται] the right to:
                    (1) the Tree of Life and
                    (2) enter [εἰσέλθωσιν] by the gates into the city. (Rev 22:14; TM)

Eating of the tree and entering through the gates are parallel rights. The leaves of the tree and general admission
through the gates must be purchased by those who do not have the blood-washed right to these privileges.
Consequently, factoring in both grammar and context, my preferred translation is:
       14
        Blessed are those who wash their robes, so that they may have the right to the Tree of Life and to
       enter by the gates into the city. (Rev 22:14; TM)
       By placing both the tree and the gated entrance in parallelism after the so that, John has grammatically
indicated that both the tree and the gated entrance are reserved as rights to those who have the blood-washed robes
of practical sanctification. Contextually, in Rev 21:24-26 discussed above, John has indicated that Terran kings
must pay to have access to the leaves and gated entrance. Put simply, Seymour was correct: Only those who know
the Lord and are obedient to Him will have the right to enter in through the gates of the New Jerusalem.
Grammatically, the right conveyed by the indicative statement regarding the tree must be applied to the subjunctive
statement regarding the gates. Only bridal overcomers have the right to enter through the City gates. Kings of the
Earth, in contrast, must pay for the privilege.
       Overcomers paid for both rights in advance, during their lives on Earth, by washing their robes in the blood
of the Lamb via practical sanctification/obedience. The most Terran kings of the Earth can hope for is for purchased
entrance by the gates, as a pay-as-you-go privilege, for which they pay throughout the course of their lives in
eternity. Terran kings bring the glory and honor of the nations into the City in order that they may enter the City
and buy leaves of the tree. They do not enter the City freely. Nor do they acquire the leaves freely. And they
cannot even obtain the fruit of the Tree of Life. The fruit of the Tree of Life is not for sale. The right to the fruit had
to be paid for in advance by blood-washed obedience. The fruit of the tree is limited to bridal overcomers.

                                                        Rev 22:1-2
       1
        Then he showed me a river of the water of life, clear as crystal, coming from the throne of God and
       of the Lamb. 2 In the middle of its street, the tree of life ran along on both sides of the river, bearing
       twelve kinds of fruit, yielding a different kind each month; and the leaves of the tree were for the
       healing of the nations. (Rev 22:1-2; TM)

       Tree of Life
       Access to the fruit of the Tree of Life, and thus to the tree itself, is limited to overcomers (Rev 2:7), that is,
to those who wash their robes in practical sanctification (Rev 22:12,14). The Tree of Life is in the City (Rev 22:2).
Subcomers will lose their inheritance rights to this tree and to the City (Rev 22:19). Loss of these rewards would
suggest loss of access to the City itself. Accessibility to the very springs themselves (from which the water of life
originates within the City) is limited to overcomers (Rev 7:17; 22:1-2). But the water of life itself (from these
springs) may be experienced freely by those outside the City.

                                           Illustration 115. The Tree of Life




       Just as the leaves of the Tree of Life, which grow inside the City, may be shared with those who live in the
nations outside the City, so the water of life may be freely accessed outside the City. For the water flows down the
middle of the streets, through the twelve gates, to the nations outside of the City. Some suggest that the Tree of Life
is a forest of trees; others believe the river is in the middle of the tree; others think that the tree is in the middle of
the river; others picture the tree along the banks of the river (cp. Eze 47:12). The mental picture the present writer
has is that of a single tree taken from the Garden of Eden thousands of years ago and transplanted at the top of the
Heavenly Jerusalem. Evidently, Alcorn shares this perspective as well:

               The same physical tree of life that was in the Garden of Eden will one day be in the New Jerusalem
         on the New Earth (Revelation 22:2). Now it is (present tense) in the intermediate Heaven. Shouldn’t
         we assume it has the same physical properties it has in the Garden of Eden and will have in the New
         Jerusalem?...

He continues in more depth subsequently:

              The river flows down the city’s main street. Likely it has countless tributaries flowing throughout

         elevation….

       This tree has now grown progressively for thousands of years. It has a massive root structure that sinks deep
into the rich soil along the banks of the river of the water of life, where the tree continues to grow and spread. It has
formed groves and parks, as well as lining the main roads. In addition to being on the outside slopes of the City
walls, the tree and the water of life probably pervade the inside of the City as well. The City would be a virtual
greenhouse. If we can have trees in our malls and waterfalls in our hotels, just imagine the creative ingenuity that
might go into channeling the river of life and growing the Tree of Life inside a City lit by the glory of God. There
could easily be lakes inside that massive city and waterfalls greater than Niagara.

       Tatford suggests that the Tree of Life is “like an immense banyan tree, sending down fibers to become huge

roots rather than aerial roots. Its aquatic roots send up fibers to become huge trunks and thus spread along the banks
of the river, reproducing itself so that this single tree has now spread by the end of the millennial age (which is the
time period in which John sees it) to run along the entire bank of the river of the water of life. In such a case, the
fruit of the tree could be seedless since the tree is propagated by its roots rather than by seeds. Possibly, a single
massive tree interconnected by a single root structure that has spread along all banks of the river is envisioned.

       The river and tree both have one point of origin—the throne of God at the top of the City, which is 1,500
miles high. The river is longer than this length, deriving its additional duration from its own curvature as a river
plus the slope of the City walls (Rev 21:16). If Lenski (LCNT) is correct, the river flows through twelve streets and
out of the City through the twelve major gates. If the tree is limited to just the dual banks of one river, and the
additional length it would have from sloped walls and curvature is ignored, then the tree line would measure 1,500
x 2 = 3,000 miles for a single branch of this river. This figure must be multiplied by the number of streets through
which it flows so that the total is 36,000 miles of tree line when all main branches of the river are taken into
consideration. This minimum figure fails to include the slope and curvature of the river.

numerous other outlets through the sloped city walls and grows inside the City (as is probable), then the figure for
the cavernous tree far exceeds the calculations above. Moreover, a tree that expansive in nature and which drinks
from the water of life could produce a tremendous amount of fruit. Its leaves are exported for the healing of the
nations outside the City (cp. Rev 22:2). These nations are composed of people who enter the eternal state in flesh
and blood bodies at the conclusion of the millennium and who then procreate subsequent generations of sinless
humanity in physical bodies. The population produced by this eternal procreation will still be subject to physical
needs. Of course, to be outside the City does not necessarily mean to be inside Hell.

       Gates of Honor and Limitation
       The above analysis raises a question about the purpose for the great and high, four-sided wall that surrounds
the City and for the angelic guard at each gate (Rev 21:12). One suggestion made by commentators is that the angels
are there as an honor guard. This is reasonable, especially in view of 22:14, which denotes entrance by the gates as
a special reward to overcomers (i.e., those who wash their robes in practical sanctification). That the angels are at
the gate to honor those who are worthy to enter the City in this manner is a reasonable conjecture. Of course, with
only three gates on each of the four sides and with each side of the wall running 1,500 miles, this computes to one
gate every 500 miles. Evidently, it is to be understood from these dimensions and from the honor afforded to those
who enter by the gates that the gates are not the only literal means of entry into such a massive City and probably
not even the major avenue of entry. A city of this size could easily accommodate aerial entry. The wall is only
seventy-two yards high (Rev 21:17), which is no obstacle to aerial entry for a city that is 1,500 miles high!
                                        Illustration 117. Outside Looking In

is limited to overcomers (Rev 22:17)? Posing that the water flows freely out the gates provides one possible answer.

flows into portals. In the case of the 4D City, the water would flow out the gate to the surrounding land. Part of it
would return to the subterranean basin; part of it would flow to other planets in the celestial realm via means of
portals. What about the 3D City, which is a Satellite City? I would pose that all of it flows into portals in that case.
Each gate could have a portal. Or each gate could create a waterfall that falls into a portal at the bottom of the
biosphere. Spaceships could dock at the City gates to access the street while the water falls to the portal(s) below.

            Thus God has said that if they will surrender their desires to him, and let their ethical behavior

       Healing of the Nations
       Smortals is the coined term introduced herein to refer principally to the people who compose these nations
in the eternal state. As noted in the opening of MSIH, Sterling has written an excellent, three-part series of articles
discussing the possibility of two modes of humanity in the eternal state.396 Mode one pertains to the possibility of
physical sex, within the confines of procreative marriage, continuing in the eternal state for those who inhabit the
kingdom during the eternal state in natural yet sinless (thus transformed to use his term but translated to use my
older term or semi-transformed to use my new term) flesh and blood bodies (cp. 1Cor. 15:50), so that procreation
can continue in the eternal state. My hypothesis in The Outer Darkness (TOD) was that those believers who live to
the end of the millennial kingdom will be allowed to enter the eternal state in sinless flesh and blood bodies and
reproduce. Procreation thereby would continue in the eternal state. For the sake of convenience, I refer to these
sinless, semi-transformed, sexually-reproducing, semi-mortals as smortals. Smortals are the necessary link
between mortals of the present and immortals of the future. Without smortals, various promises in the OT would
go unfulfilled.

      Smortals in Various Time Periods
                                  Illustration 120. Adam and Eve versus Smortals




     The S in smortals is shorthand for their sinless, semi-transformed, sexually-reproducing, semi-mortal status.
Smortals are semi-mortals because they can only experience a limited form of physical death. They need healing,

   Personal correspondence, 7/21/2021.

   Philippe R. Sterling, “The Two Modes of Humanity, Part 1: The View Delineated and Supported” JOTGES

so we can infer that they can experience cellular death in the body at the micro level. Since they are in the eternal
state, however, they cannot experience the death of the body at the macro level. In my MSIN, I referred to them as
having natural, flesh-and-blood bodies that can sexually reproduce. Adam and Eve also had sinless, innocent bodies.
Consequently, as shorthand, some say that smortals will have bodies like Adam and Eve had before they sinned,
which is true to a point. Yet some technical differences exist, especially when their spirits are included. The primary
difference is that smortals are regenerate and cannot sin. Some interpreters refer to them as having physically
glorified but spiritually unglorified bodies. In other words, smortals have physical bodies like Adam and Eve, but
they are in a physically glorified state in which sin is impossible. Other interpreters might just refer to them as
having redeemed bodies. In any case, smortals have sinless physical bodies that cannot sin.
        Another difference is that Adam and Eve were contingently subject to physical death at the macro level. Also,
Adam and Eve could die spiritually. Smortals cannot. Smortals cannot die at the macro level physically because
death at the macro level will be eliminated for humanity in the eternal state. Plus, smortals not only have innocent
bodies but a regenerate nature. The combination makes it impossible for them to sin (cp. 1Jn 3:9). The wages of sin
for humanity were immediate spiritual death and ultimately macro physical death. Smortals cannot sin and thus are
not subject to either spiritual death or macro physical death. So, smortal bodies cannot cease to function physically
to the extent of becoming deceased.
        Heretofore, propositions herein regarding smortals have been limited to the eternal state. David Pearson,
however, gives plausible reasons to infer that Jewish smortals will also exist in the tribulation and millennial
time periods.397 In concurrence and consultation with Fruchtenbaum, Pearson develops the thesis that there will be
no sinning among the Jewish remnant during the millennial kingdom.398 There will be those among the Jews and
Gentiles who enter the millennial kingdom in physical bodies, of course. But as for the Jews, Fruchtenbaum poses
that “the sin will be supernaturally controlled even though they will still have a sin nature” (6:48).399 Pearson
acknowledges this is possible but instead poses that “the sin nature will be supernaturally and miraculously
removed from the Jewish remnant” (7:6). Consequently, Jewish children born during the millennial kingdom
will have no sin nature and be born spiritually alive (regenerate). Since I share these conclusions as they apply
to smortals during the eternal state, applying them to select groups during the tribulation and millennial kingdom,
as Pearson poses, is intuitive. He proceeds to state that 1/3 of the Jews who were alive at the beginning of the
tribulation will survive and compose the remnant, some of whom will enter the millennial kingdom in their physical
bodies. Pearson takes Eze 11:17-20 to mean that they will “fully ‘walk, keep, do’ the will of God perfectly” (14:59).
However, since the text does not explicitly state that they will do so perfectly, this is an extrapolation on his part;
accordingly, he poses that either their sin nature is completely controlled (so Fruchtenbaum), or they have no sin
nature (so Pearson).
        In defense of this extrapolation, Pearson takes the one heart and new spirit in Eze 11:19 as referring to more
than just regeneration since the sequence in which this statement occurs suggests they are already regenerate and
are now being gathered at the end of the seventy-five-day interview, between the end of the tribulation and the start
of the millennial kingdom, to enter the land of Israel. Additionally, the 144,000 Jewish evangelists are the first fruits
of more to come. Even believers can have a stony/hardened heart (Heb 3:8,15; 4:7; cp. Zech 7:11-12) that needs to
be replaced with a softened heart. The replacement and removal of this stony heart (cp. Eze 36:26) indicates the
removal of their sin nature so that they will not have any tendency to sin against the Lord. Now, they will never
violate God’s will. As a people group, the Jewish remnant will have one heart, totally united in serving the Lord.
At this time, God promises to cleanse them from all their filthiness (Eze 36:25). God promises that these internal
transformations He performs will guarantee their performance: “I will put My Spirit within you and cause you to
walk in My statutes, and you will be careful to observe My ordinances” (Eze 36:27). “And the house of Israel will

perfect sanctification while they are still in their physical bodies, just as He will do for select believers at the
conclusion of the millennial kingdom. The 144,000 become smortals at the moment they are sealed. They are
the first fruits of select Jewish believers who will become smortals at the beginning of the millennium. This

and you will never again be haughty on My holy mountain” (Zeph 3:11). “The remnant of Israel will do no wrong
and tell no lies, nor will a deceitful tongue be found in their mouths” (Zeph 3:13). “He will remove ungodliness

millennial kingdom but cannot lead the Jews astray who are in the Promised Land. Instead, Satan must
invoke the nations to attack the nation of Israel (Rev 20:7-9).
        Indeed, Wilkin poses that the promise regarding Jesus saving “His people from their sins” pertains to
millennial fulfillment for the Jewish people so that “at the end of the Tribulation all surviving Jews will be believers
in fellowship with God. At that point the whole nation will be delivered from God’s wrath.”400 His discussion is
good insofar as it goes. I would add that, at the national regeneration of the Jews during the millennial kingdom, all
individual Jews who qualify to enter the Promised Land will be smortals. The scope of salvation envisioned is not
limited to individual regeneration in Mt 1:21 but anticipates a millennial Jewish nation of smortals.

       Death in the Eternal State
       An abbreviated extract from my RAE (also see MMP2) will be used to demonstrate death at the cellular level.
Human procreation will continue throughout eternity. Therefore, death, at least at the microphysical level, must
continue also. Furthermore, OECs (Old-Earth Creationists) argue that the food chain existed prior to the fall. For
example, Adam’s rulership over the fish presumably would include his ability to eat them, leading to the affirmation
of a food chain. Fishing still will take place during the millennial kingdom and/or eternal state (Eze 47:9-10), the
same time period in which the wolf lives peaceably with the lamb and lion eats straw (Is 11:6-8; Is 65:25). Even
though the whole Earth “will be full of the knowledge of God,” this no-hurt-state-of-affairs is explicitly said to be
in God’s “holy mountain.” Might death, even macrophysical death, be allowed offsite, that is, outside the perimeter
of that holy mountain as it was outside the Garden of Eden?
       Possibly, one reason God created plants and animals was so that humanity could eat them. Though Gen 9:3
is post-flood, 1Tim 4:1-5 reaches back to creation with the confirmation that eating meat is good. We know that
death entered the world through sin (Rom 5:12). As a YEC (Young-Earth Creationist), I had taken this to mean that
there was no death, in this biblical sense, before Adam and Eve sinned. Still, does this mean that there was no death
in any sense before Adam and Eve sinned? Adam and Eve certainly could suffer physical wounds involving the
deterioration and death of flesh or bone cells which must then be replaced. Animals could experience scratches or
scrapes too. Dill defends RET (Ruined-Earth Theory, aka the Gap Theory) against YEC (Young-Earth Creationism)
by explaining that death must have been in place before the fall:

      Over the years, I have seen Young-Earth creationists repeatedly try to destroy the Gap Theory by using
      a particular “biblical bombshell” that “proves” they are right. Let me defuse this “bomb.” Young-Earth
      creationists insist that the Restoration Theory is wrong because it means death reigned before Adam.
      Gap Theory creationists look at the geological strata and say that all those fossils (dead things) were

400
   Bob Wilkin, “What Did the Angel Mean, “He Will Save His People from Their Sins”? Matthew 1:21.” Accessed
1/20/2022. Available at https://faithalone.org/blog/what-did-the-angel-mean-he-will-save-his-people-from-their-
sins-matthew-121.

      formed before Adam was created. Young-Earth creationists become indignant when they hear this.
      They believe there was no death before Adam sinned. “By one man sin entered into the world, and
      death by sin,” they’ll quote. According to them, Romans 5:12 and 1 Corinthians 15:21 prove there was
      no death before Adam sinned. If you question them, however, they usually admit that some kind of
      death must have existed before Adam’s fall. Plants died when eaten. Cows didn’t carry microscopes
      to pick off the microscopic mites living on the blades of grass before they ate. These mites would have
      been killed by the cow’s digestion system. Insects, nematodes, and other soil-living creatures got
      squished as great herds of buffalo crossed the plains. Plankton-feeding whales would have digested
      microscopic animals along with microscopic plants. Once something is digested, it’s pretty good and
      dead. The outer-most layer of epithelial tissue (skin) consists of cells that are dead. If those skin cells
      were alive, we would be in excruciating pain every time something touched us, and worse than that,
      we would dehydrate within hours. The layer of dead epithelial cells acts as a fluid barrier to prevent
      desiccation. If those cells weren’t dead, we soon would be! Furthermore, those dead cells are
      constantly being rubbed off and replaced by the growing cells beneath them. Epithelial cells aren’t the
      only cells continually dying in order for animals to live. Red blood cells have a constant turnover rate.
      White blood cells do the same. Osteoclasts are cells that continually kill bone cells so that new bone
      cells can be made by osteoblasts. If this didn’t happen, bones couldn’t grow. Baby animals couldn’t
      become adult animals if living cells didn’t die. If you study embryological development, you’ll
      discover that certain embryonic cells have to die in order for further development to take place.
      Without death, animals couldn’t have multiplied according to God’s command. There had to be death
      of some kind, even in animals.401

If that is the case, then I would suppose that the Adamic atonement is not applicable to any possible pre-Adamic
humans who may have survived the Luciferian destruction of our solar system. The only beings capable of being

physically descend from them.” Adam and Eve had a spiritual dimension to them, a human spirit, that these
hominids lacked (pp. 140-141, 154). Although I appreciate his pre-Adamic hominid theory, I do not believe it
suffices to explain the extrabiblical and biblical data, which seems to favor pre-Adamic humans. To be sure, they
may be genetically different from Adamic humans. Nevertheless, they do seem to be human. My speculation is that
soteriological atonement is not available for fallen pre-Adamic humans, just as it is not available for fallen angels.
Of course, neither unfallen Pre-pre-Adamic humans nor unfallen angels would need atonement.

universe. Lucifer’s fall did not automatically result in all other types of angelic beings created in the image of God
being imputationally or ontologically implicated in Lucifer’s sin. Angels did not sin just because Lucifer sinned,
though sin had entered their domain. Likewise, we may pose that Adam’s sin did not result in all other humanoid
ETs in our universe being imputationally or ontologically implicated in Adam’s sin. They did not sin just because
Adam sinned. Even if Adam’s sin was universal in affecting our entire universe (as opposed to the multiverse) as
posed in MMP4, one might maintain that not every sentient being in our universe morally participated in Adam’s
fall or sin. Any unfallen Pre-pre-Adamic ETs (human or otherwise) living in other solar systems or galaxies within
our universe would not have fallen as a result of Adam’s fall. Sin and moral death were already present in our solar
system and galaxy as a result of Lucifer’s pre-Adamic fall. Therefore, the contamination of creation cannot be laid
solely at Adam’s feet. My objection in MMP4 that entropy and moral death would have spread throughout our
universe like a shockwave is thus offset by this alternative model. Native ETs in the present universe could be
allowed with this alternative model being posed here in MMP5.

       Leaves for Healing
       Chitwood correctly perceives that the fruit of the Tree of Life was originally only given regally to kingdom
rulers in both Genesis and Revelation. The fruit of the Tree of Life is a reward; therefore, it is not available freely
or universally to all believers. Splendid! However, he then erroneously takes away a key detail from the biblical
text in his ongoing discussion in order to derive his errant opinion that the fruit of the Tree of Life is subsequently
made available freely to all believers within the eternal state. On the one hand, the Bible says that the leaves of the
tree will be for the healing of the nations. Chitwood, contrariwise, says that the tree will be for the healing of the
nations. He has distorted the biblical message by leaving out a crucial detail. By leaving out the leaves in Rev 22:2,
he has made the unwarranted extrapolation that the fruit of the tree must no longer be a reward limited to the faithful,
as it was in Rev 2:7 since the tree is now allegedly given to nations that did not earn a right to the tree in Rev 22:2.
Never mind that the Tree of Life is still a reward a few verses later in Rev 22:14,19! Chitwood has abused both
the text and the context.405 He assumes, without any justification, that being given the leaves of the tree entails the
right to eat the fruit of the tree. But the leaves are not the fruit; moreover, the leaves could be harvested and exported
to the nations without giving the nations direct access to the Tree of Life. With such unwarranted jumps in logic,
he then proceeds to presume that all believers will eat the fruit and thus rule the Earth.
       In addition to these types of errors, Chitwood fails to notice that the leaves die after they have been gathered
from the tree to be applied to the nations. This type of death still occurs in the eternal state. The leaves of the Tree
of Life do not have eternal life in that they do not live forever. The Tree of Life does not die, but its leaves do. For
that matter, most plants probably will still be subject to death, even in the eternal state. Certainly, the plants we eat
will be subject to death. This observation, by the way, destroys Chitwood’s other argument against eternal rewards,

       Semi-transformation for Procreation
       Just as Adam and Eve could reproduce, so those who enter the eternal state in physically glorified but
spiritually unglorified bodies, to use a combination of the Evan’s and Vacendak’s terms (or my term smortals for
short), will be able to reproduce and need the leaves for healing. Vacendak says that they are transformed. Yet,
from his discussion, one can see that he does not mean a full transformation into immortal, spiritually glorified
bodies. For clarification and conciseness, as purely a matter of semantics, I am referring to these partially
transformed people as semi-transformed, thus smortals. Smortals are translated into the eternal state without
undergoing full transformation into spiritually glorified immortal bodies. Semantics aside, like Vacendak and
myself, and a variety of other writers, Becker believes:

                 Terrestrial people will continue to increase after death is abolished. Therefore, the
         administrators will have to assume greater responsibilities. Nothing will remain static because of the
         light. Therefore, those learning their ABCs will continue growing. After all, those in the heavenly city
         will have an ever-expanding universe to rule over.409

      Her statement is correct but could use some enlargement. Terrestrial people (Terrans) “will continue to
increase after death is abolished” because human procreation will continue in the eternal state after macro
death is abolished for humanity. Because this infinite growth cannot be limited to a finite universe, it must
spread beyond our universe to the multiverse. Not only will those in the Heavenly City have an increasingly
larger expanse to rule over, but Terrans whom they place in subordinate positions of rulership will have
expanding domains to oversee as earthly kings and administrators. Plus, an increasing number of upper Terran
subordinates to lower Terran subordinates will be needed. The opportunity for job advancement will be infinite to
immortals and smortals alike, except for those immortals confined to the outer darkness. Unfaithful immortals will
not be given positions of responsibility. Moreover, they will be in the outer realm, where the Terran expansion is
not applicable.
      As to the nature of the fruit and leaves, Becker’s statements are accurate insofar as they go:

               Although the fruit will provide food, the leaves will be “for the healing of the nations.” Since
         those who live in the city will have no need of healing because sorrow, crying, and pain have been
         eliminated, the healing will be for those on earth. In fact, Ezekiel tells us that these same trees will
         grow on earth and line the sides of the river flowing from the [earthly] temple.

      Tabernacles will display an open affront to God. As a result, the blessing of water (rain) will be
      withheld. Those of the Bride in charge of nations, who will also have power over the weather, will cut
      it off at a first offense. If the nations persist, however, a plague will develop in their people.
      Restoration, pictured in the leaves, will come when they repent and come back to “the way.”

       True. This situation fully applies to the millennial kingdom. However, John places his comment about the
leaves being used for the healing of the nations in the eternal state in Rev 22:2. Nor should this be surprising for
those who, like Becker, concur that the Terran population continues to increase throughout eternity. Having smortal
bodies, smortals would still be subject to microphysical injury and thus have a use for the healing leaves. McGee is
on the correct track when he affirms of this postmillennial Eternal City:

             Even the leaves of the tree are beneficial—they have a medicinal value. Why healing is needed
      in a perfect universe is a very good question and a difficult problem to solve. Perhaps it is a sort of
      first–aid kit which demonstrates the old adage, “An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.” I
      personally believe that the bodies of the earth dwellers in eternity will be different from the bodies of
      the believers in the church who are to be like Christ (that is, their bodies will be like His). The bodies
      of the earth dwellers may need renewing from time to time. This may be the reason that they come up
      to the New Jerusalem—not only to worship, but also to be renewed physically and spiritually. At least
      the prevention is there. (TTBC)

      Disease in the Eternal State
      Like McGee, Govett (GOR) basically entertains the preventative idea as one option, evidently even
suggesting that the leaves may be necessary to prevent macro death (to use my term), but also poses a second option:

              Its leaves are intended “for the healing of the nations.”
              Here a difficulty arises. It may be said—‘This conclusively proves, that the context speaks of
      millennial times: for how can there be sickncss after that?’
              I think it quite certain, that the description of the city does not belong to millennial times: and
      that this passage is reconcilable with the idea of its referring to the eternal state.
              These words do not belong to the millennium. For that is a time, not of healing the nations, but
      of bruising them with rod of iron, and dashing them in pieces like potter’s vessels, ii, 26, 27. Men are
      not all holy then: but at this period the elect only survive.
              It must indeed be allowed, that in the eternal state there is no [macro] death, nor pain, xxi, 4.
      But still there may be weakness and the painless decay of the body [thus micro death].
              The nations are still in the flesh. It is thought by some, that the tree of life, ere Adam fell, was
      designed to renovate his life from time to time, so as to prevent all necessity of death. It may be
      so now. The bodies of the nations may be invigorated by the application of the leaves of the tree
      of life. It may be that they may employ them against mechanical injuries to parts of their frame.
              The Scripture distinguishes between “infirmities,” or want of strength in various forms, and
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 320
      “diseases.” “Himself took our infirmities, and bare our diseases Matt, viii, 17. To Timothy troubled
      with infirmities Paul recommends the fruit of the vine. 1 Tim. v, 23.
             And this gives us another reason for the nations’ pilgrimage to Jerusalem; a reason which began
      to be….
             ….The leaves of the tree of life do not fall, and rot disregarded on the ground: they supply the
      need of the dwellers outside. The priests need them not. They are not in the flesh. (Emphasis his.)410

       Govett’s discussion on infirmities and diseases is interesting and speculative as applied to the eternal state;
nevertheless, his proposals are not so easily dismissed. Likewise, his proposition that the leaves may be necessary
to prevent macrophysical death is not outside the realm of possibility. In any case, his affirmation of microphysical
death—in the form of weakness, infirmity, decay, and injury—suffices for the basic point being made.
       Ryrie offers a counterpoint of view on Rev 21:9-27: “This section describes the city’s relation to the
millennial state. In other words, there seem to be two descents of the city, verses 21:1-8 being the one related to
eternity and 21:9-22:5 the one related to the Millennium” (EvBC). Then he proceeds to weaken his own analysis
when he comments on Rev 22:2-3:

      Since there is no more curse (v. 3), what is meant by healing the nations? The word “healing” also has
      the meaning of “caring for.” Thus, the phrase may well mean that the leaves of the tree enhance the
      quality of life in a positive way, not that they heal illnesses; for there will be no illnesses when there
      is no longer any curse. (EvBC)

       Ryrie is a dispensationalist. The statement that there will no longer be any curse in Rev 22:3 would be better
perceived dispensationally as applying to the eternal state rather than the millennium. Walvoord, also a
dispensationalist, notes this is the case: “In the millennial scene, there is a lifting of the curse upon the earth, but
not a total deliverance from the world’s travail brought in by sin, for in the millennium, it is still possible for a
‘sinner’ to be ‘accursed’ (Isa. 65:20) with resulting physical death. In the new heaven and earth, there will be no
curse at all.”411 Therefore, Rev 21:9-22:5 would be better understood as related to the eternal state rather than the
millennium from a simple dispensationalist perspective. Granted, from a more complex dispensationalist
perspective such as mine, it might be objected that the statement of no curse applies only to the City, not to the
Earth. Misthologically, the argument might be made that the promise of no more curse applies only to the inhabitants
of the City. To be sure, the context is describing the City. For example, Rev 22:3-5 talks about the benefits of being
God’s bond-servants who serve Him and see His face in a City that has no night because they are illuminated by
God and rule forever and ever, that is, throughout the eternal state. Indeed, Govett seems to take it for granted that
the statement of no more curse applies only to New Jerusalem when he contrasts it with the old Jerusalem and
simply says, contrastively, “Here there is ‘no more curse’” (GOR, 457). For otherwise, one would have no
explanation from his discussion how he can pose the possibility of disease and illness in the eternal state.
Notwithstanding, Walvoord’s argument still holds for the eternal state for other reasons he supplies:

              A number of considerations support the conclusion that the eternal state is in view in Revelation
      21:9 through 22:7. There is good reason for concluding that the order of Revelation beginning in
      chapter 19 is chronological; a retrogression in time would violate the structure of the last great section
      of the book. The description of the holy city as given in 21:2 is obviously identical to the description
      in 21:9. As most expositors grant that 21:2 is the eternal state, it would follow that 21:9 should be
      considered the same….The apportionment of the Holy Land and the description of the Temple as
      found in Ezekiel’s description of the millennial earth (Ezek. 40-48) are entirely different. The heavenly
      city is obviously seen as it will appear in the eternal state in the entire passage beginning with 21:1.412

       However, Walvoord (p. 318) attempts to defend this argument for the eternal state by taking the healing of
the nations to refer to health instead of healing in Rev 22:2, saying that the leaves are simply therapeutic, health-


410
    Robert Govett, Govett on Revelation, vol. 2 (Hayesville, NC: Schoettle Publishing Co., 2010), 474-476.

    John F. Walvoord, The Revelation of Jesus Christ (Moody Press: Chicago, 1966), 331.

    Walvoord, 318.
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                          Page 321
giving, promoting “the enjoyment of life in new Jerusalem, not for correcting ills which do not exist. This is of
course confirmed by the fact that there is no curse as indicated in verse 3” (p. 330). Indeed, Rev 22:2 applies to the
eternal state but not for the reason Walvoord states. Contrary to what he asserts, the leaves are not for the enjoyment
of life inside New Jerusalem but for the nations outside New Jerusalem. Nor has he proven that the curse does not
apply outside New Jerusalem. Let us consult Tatford for that argument:

                Since life flowed out in its fulness, nothing could be subject to the curse. The curse resulted
         from man’s sin (Genesis 3:14,17; Galatians 3:10), but now the curse was banished (cf. Zechariah
         14:11). Hengstenberg writes, The idea of cursing is always that of the forced consecration to God of
         those who had obstinately refused to consecrate themselves voluntarily to Him — of the manifestation
         of the divine glory in the destruction of those who, during their lifetime, would not reflect it, and
         therefore would not realize the general destination of man, the design of all creation. God sanctifies
         Himself upon all those, in whom He is not sanctified. The destruction of everything on earth, which
         will not serve Him proclaims His praise.’ In the holy city, however, there was no object for the
         penal justice of God, and in place of the curse, there was unrestrained love and life and
         blessing.413

       Once again, we find no curses inside the City. What about outside the City? No objects for the penal justice
of God exist inside the City. What about outside the City? Tatford does not address these questions. John does,
though, and very emphatically: “Outside are the dogs and the sorcerers and the immoral persons and the murderers
and the idolaters, and everyone who loves and practices lying” (Rev 22:15). We have already dealt with its twin
precursor: “But for the cowardly and unbelieving and abominable and murderers and immoral persons and sorcerers
and idolaters and all liars, their part will be in the lake that burns with fire and brimstone, which is the second death”
(Rev 21:8). Sin still exits—outside the City in the Lake of Fire. What about outside the City in the new heavens and
new Earth? No. The creation will no longer groan from the infection of sin (Rom 8:21-23). Nevertheless, the penal
effects of sin will remain in effect in the eternal kingdom. Believers misthologically banned from the City will
remain banished from the City in the eternal state: “If anyone takes away from the words of the book of this
prophecy, God shall take away his part from the tree of life and from the holy city, which are written in this book”
(Rev 22:19). Misthologically and misthopologically, they will be cursed: “If anyone does not love the Lord, let him
be accursed” (1Cor 16:22). Jesus may find believers guilty of this very thing: “I have this against you, that you have
left your first love” (Rev 2:4). The curse does not apply to those inside the City, but the affects of the curse still
apply, to the extent applicable, to those outside the City.
       Even if the curse does not apply outside New Jerusalem, however, disease and illness might. Disease and
illness are not necessarily attributable to the curse. For instance, could Adam have stumped his toe on the ground
before the earth became cursed? Surely so. Could he have cut his toe in the process? Surely so. Could his toe have
become infected as a result? Supposedly so. Since the leaves of the Tree of Life provide healing in the future, we
may infer that the leaves provided healing in the past. The nature of these leaves is to heal.
       The fruit of the tree, not the leaves, provided enjoyment (Gen 3:6). The fruit of the tree, not the leaves,
provided perpetual life (Gen 3:22-24). Adam had to eat this fruit to live forever. He had to eat the fruit perpetually
to live perpetually. Likely, he had to use the leaves to live healthily. The combination of the fruit and leaves would
allow him to live healthily perpetually. The leaves of the tree were intended for him to use for medicinal purposes,
to restore his health by healing him. Get a cut, use a leaf, not a Band-Aid. Get an infection, use a leaf, not an
antibiotic. A healthy gut contains healthy bacteria that ward off unhealthy bacteria. The leaves of the Tree of Life
are probably a natural prebiotic, probiotic, and antibiotic. A reasonable conjecture is that these leaves promote
healthy bacteria and destroy unhealthy bacteria.
       The leaves might be used to kill the microorganisms and unhealthy bacteria causing the infection and thereby
cure the infections. Microorganisms designed to be beneficial in the gut might be unhealthy when introduced into
a cut. Microorganisms designed to be beneficial when things are going as designed might be unhealthy when
introduced in a manner contrary to design. Microphysical death occurred before the curse. Therefore, posing the
use of a leaf to kill infectious microorganisms is plausible. Infectious microorganisms experienced micro death.
“Thou shalt not kill” was not a command given to Adam to keep him from killing infectious microorganisms.


413
      Tatford, Revelation, 630.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 322
       The leaves were for micro health. The fruit was for macro life, to prevent macro death. But the animals were
not eating the fruit of the Tree of Life. The animals could die. They could not only experience micro death but
macro death and were part of the food chain (see RAE and MMP2). And when they experienced macro death, their
bodies would decay. Microorganisms would assist in that decay and were part of the food chain. Bacteria and fungi
are decomposers (saprotrophs) that are beneficial in recycling dead animals and plants back into nutrients in the
soil. Could not microorganisms that were designed to assist in death and decay, when things were operating
normally, also promote micro death and decay when something went wrong, such as when Adam cut his toe?
       Sauer extrapolates from the Great White Throne to object to this type of thinking:

             “The leaves of the tree serve for healing the nations.” It would be wrong to draw from these
      words the inference that on the new earth the healing process for mankind will still continue, so that
      for those who before the great white throne might be still not completely justified there would yet
      remain a hope that, as nations on the new earth, they may at last partake of full salvation. This would
      mean that even after the great white throne there would still be a salvation for the judged, until at last
      all, without exception, would experience full redemption. Upon this Dr. F. Düsterdicck remarks: “The
      expression is just as little to be pressed to mean that a then still present sickness of the nations is
      supposed, as we are permitted to draw the inference from Rev. 21:4 that the tears which God will wipe
      away from the blessed are signs of then still present pain. It much rather means that just as the tears
      which they had shed on account of earthly suffering will be wiped away in the eternal life, so the
      healing leaves of the tree of life serve for the healing of the sickness from which the nations bad
      suffered during their earthly life, but shall never suffer again in the new earth.” (Emphasis his.)414

       Multiple weaknesses with his extrapolation are apparent in view of the present study. First, the passage is not
intended to apply the leaves to the resurrected dead outside the City in the Lake of Fire but to smortal Terrans
outside the City in the new heavens and on the new terrestrial planet(s). Second, the leaves are not to heal the
immortals inside the City but the smortals outside the City. The promise of no tears in Rev 21:4 is a litotetic-
mistholic promise limited to immortals inside the City. It does not apply to smortals outside the City. Third, the
promise of no curse could likewise be a litotetic-mistholic promise limited to immortals inside the City. Not only
will there be no curse but no effect of the curse for those ruling immortals inside the City. Fourth, Sauer’s argument
backfires if one properly extrapolates to conclude that procreation continues throughout eternity among smortals.
Smortals will continue to marry and have marital sex, that is, procreative sex. Smortal children will be born to
smortal women throughout eternity. Consequently, smortal women will continue to experience labor pains
throughout eternity as they give birth to smortal children.

        Pain in the Eternal State
        As part of the curse, God said to the woman, “I will greatly multiply your pain in childbirth” (Gen 3:16).
Pain during childbirth is natural for the woman, part of the original design, not the result of the curse. Great pain,
on the other hand, is an unnatural result of the curse. Since smortal women are to have bodies like Eve’s pre-fallen
body, we may properly extrapolate that they will have a natural degree of pain during childbirth. They will not have
great pain, just a natural degree of pain as part of the original plan. Their tears will be a mixture of joy and pain as
they give birth. Yes, they will have tears. The promise of no tears is a litotetic promise to immortals living in the
Heavenly City. It does not apply to smortals living outside the City. Naturally, smortals will continue to have tears
on occasion in response to the natural degree of physical pain as they give birth and have an injury. Misthologically,
unfaithful immortals in the heavenly outer realm will continue to have tears on occasion in response to their natural
degree of emotional pain in reaction to their misthological loss. Multiplied pain is part of the curse. It will be
removed. Unmultiplied pain is part of the original plan. It will not be removed. One of the problems with leprosy is
that it nullifies pain, making one more susceptible to injury. A natural degree of pain is necessary physically and
misthologically. In passages such as Mt 25:30, the Bible warns us about the upcoming misthological emotional pain
for believers who are unfaithful so that they can take proper action now and thereby avoid that pain altogether in
eternity.

414
   Eric Sauer, The Triumph of the Crucified: A Survey of the History of Salvation in the New Testament, trans. G.
H. Lang (Grand Rapids, MI: WM. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company, 1952), 199, n. 1.

        For such reasons, Govett’s analysis regarding the nature of the leaves is far superior, as is the rest of his
discussion of Rev 22:1-5. Since his discussion is extensive and provides background support and has been
considered at length above as it pertains to the leaves, I will only note a few highlights from the remainder of his
discussion of this passage: (1) Months and years go on in eternity, but “there is neither autumn or winter in the city.
Each month is one of bloom and fruit” (GOR, 468). (2) “The leaves are inferior to the fruit” (p. 472). (3) His servants
who serve Him refer to servants in a special sense: “It signifies the king’s more immediate attendants. This sense is
required when we find the parties, as it is here, said to be in waiting upon the throne….God at length discovers
himself to His subject-kings, as the King of kings” (p. 480; emphasis his). In other words, these servants are servant-
kings. (4) To see His face (Rev 22:4) is “the privilege of courtiers and ministers of the palace; not of the king’s
subjects in general. Thus certain nobles of Persia are distinguished by name as ‘the seven princes of Persia and
Media, which saw the king’s face, and which sat first in the Kingdom [Esther 1:14]” (p. 483; emphasis his). (5) Paul
distinguishes in 1Cor 15:40-49 “between two kinds of bodies—the earthly and the heavenly; and the distinctness
of the glory of each. These both coexist in the millennial kingdom, and are perpetuated in the eternal state” (p. 487).
(6) “Hence it is evident, that there must be a distinction of mankind into rulers and ruled. If some are kings, some
must be subjects….The nations are transferred from the old earth to the new: but they are still to be ruled” (p. 490).
In short, those in earthly bodies in the eternal state will live on Earth and be ruled over by the servant-kings who
have heavenly bodies and live in the Heavenly City. (7) “There are two kinds of kings.” The kings of the earth
(Rev 21:24) who “dwell outside the city, and are men in the flesh, who at the head of their respective nations bring
their tribute to the kings of the city. The kings of the earthy are far inferior” to kings of the City (p. 491; emphasis
his). The designation, kings of the Earth, is used to differentiate these kings from those of the kings of the City.
(8) “The citizens of the New Jerusalem reign over all others,” even during the eternal state (p. 493).

       Kings of the Earth
       As noted in TOD, both Alexander Patterson and Govett believe that the kings of the earth (terrestrial realm)
in Rev 21:24 refer to subordinate rulers in flesh and blood bodies.415 Kings who rule the terrestrial realm and walk
by the light of the City in that terrestrial realm and who bring the glory and honor of the terrestrial realm into the
City so that they may enter it are Terrans. This proposition is intuitive. Seiss acknowledges this possibility but
prefers to regard the kings of the earth as glorified saints who will live in the New Jerusalem and exercise their rule
primarily from this city.416 Baughman is undecided.417
       Among the various possibilities and mediations discussed in TOD regarding the kings of the Earth were
conjectures about the Twilight Zone. Although I acknowledged in TOD that Govett has a strong argument about
the kings of the Earth, I was more inclined in TOD to regard the kings of the Earth to be overcomers. As a result of
the present discussion, though, I am more disposed to concede to Govett’s basic position with a modification of one
of the mediations I posed in TOD. Namely, the kings of the Earth in the eternal state will include both (1) smortals
who lived until the end of the millennium and were found faithful and (2) immortals who (like the repentant prodigal
son) failed to qualify for living in the Heavenly City (HC) but who still qualify as rulers in the Twilight Zone (TZ).
As to the kings of the Earth during the millennial kingdom, they will include mortal believers who live until the
end of the tribulation and are not found faithful (or at least not faithful enough to inherit the kingdom) but who are,
nevertheless, eventually given ruling positions while in their sinful mortal bodies. Some of them and some of their
descendants will be mortal kings of the Earth during the millennial kingdom. Semi-faithful immortals may also
dwell on Earth and be counted among the kings of the Earth during the millennial kingdom. Recapping in
chronological order, dealing with the millennial kingdom followed by the eternal state, may be helpful.

       Millennial and Eternal Terran Kings
       During the millennium, the kings of the Earth will be Terrans (terrestrial Earth dwellers), comprised initially
of (1) semi-faithful premillennial immortals and (2) semi-faithful tribulational mortals and (3) subsequently of
mortals who grow up in the millennial kingdom and who are eventually given positions of earthly rulership. The
rebellion at the end of the millennium will have some of the mortal kings from the latter two categories within it.
