However, none of the semi-faithful premillennial immortals will participate in the rebellion. They cannot. As
immortals, they cannot sin. In short, TZ millennial rulers will be Terrans composed of both immortals and mortals.
       During the eternal state, the kings of the earth will be Terrans (terrestrial planet dwellers), comprised initially
of (1) semi-faithful premillennial immortals and (2) faithful millennial mortals who are semi-transformed into
smortals at the beginning of the eternal state and (3) subsequently of faithful smortals born in the eternal state.
These various groups of Terran rulers are eventually given low-ranking planetary positions of rulership in the
terrestrial realm of the various terrestrial planets, such as Earth. In short, these TZ eternal rulers will be Terrans
composed of both immortals and smortals.

       Alexander Patterson
       In TOD, I defended Alexander Patterson’s majestic twenty-two-page discussion regarding procreation in the
eternal state, originally published in 1896, and integrated it into my discussion. Patterson’s book is now available
on Kindle, where readers can now readily access it for themselves. Since his discussion remained superior to that
of his detractors and was an inspiration to my own position, sharing extended excerpts from the Kindle edition will
enable readers to appreciate the depth of his thought, though it was by no means original to him. At the same time,
I also defended J. A. Seiss’ commentary on Revelation. His book was originally published in 1900, four years after
Patterson‘s book.418 I will also interlace some of Seiss’ comments (among others) with those of Patterson in this
section. First, though, we will review some of Patterson’s comments pertaining to the Bride because these
considerations determine who inhabits the Heavenly City.

       Bride (Original and Extended)
       Patterson correctly perceives a vast difference between being the Bride of Christ and being a mere servant of
Christ who escapes Hell:

             So also a difference is intimated to exist among those being saved in the gospel age and
      commonly called The Church. There are special terms applied to some, such as, “The Bride,” “The
      first-fruits,” “The Church of the First Born.” We must not apply these indiscriminately to the
      saved. Scripture does not use terms in that loose manner. Every difference is significant of special
      meaning. There is a vast difference between being “saved as by fire,” and having “richly supplied
      unto you the entrance into the eternal kingdom of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.” Coming into
      the number of “The Church of the First-Born” is far more than escaping hell. The Bride of Christ is
      far more than a servant or a subject. There are undoubtedly differences in the constituency of these
      respective bodies.419 (Patterson, 375.)

Being saved as by fire is, of course, a reference to Paul’s statement: “If any man’s work is burned up, he shall suffer
loss; but he himself shall be saved, yet so as through fire” (1Cor 3:15). Earlier, Patterson explained: “‘Saved as by
fire’ intimates a searching personal examination. The Christian life will be gone into by Christ as we are told by the
apostles. Every secret thing not repented of and confessed, will be exposed, to the shame and mortification of the
doer” (p. 317). He then proceeds to quote Lk 12:45-47 about some of Christ’s servants being beaten with many
lashes because they beat their fellow servants:

      “Beaten with many stripes” does not mean the loss of the soul, but it does mean more than has been
      generally taught. The “stripes” are connected with the coming of Christ. The same truth is taught in
      the parables of the same talents when the unprofitable servant is cast out “into the outer darkness: there
      shall be the weeping and gnashing of teeth [Mt 25:30].” Olshausen thus comments on this:

             “The reference is not to eternal condemnation, but to exclusion from the Basilia
             [kingdom] into which the faithful enter. The Basilia is viewed as the region of light,
             which is encircled by darkness.

418
    J. A. Seiss, The Apocalypse: Lectures on the Book of Revelation (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan Publishing
House, 1975).
419
    Alexander Patterson, Greater, 376.
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                        Page 325

            “Concerning the children of light who are unfaithful to their vocation, it is said they are
            cast into the skotos (darkness): but as respecting the children of darkness, we are told
            they are consigned to the pur aionion (eternal fire) so that each one finds his own
            punishment in the opposite element.” (Pp. 317-318; emphasis his.)

       Christ does not beat His Bride! Patterson correctly perceives that being a part of the Bride of Christ is a
misthological reward limited to faithful believers. Personally, I would not place the outer darkness spatially outside
the kingdom but in the outer realm of the kingdom. In any event, we concur that those believers saved by fire will
not qualify to be part of the Bride. Seiss agrees but goes into more detail:

              Who is the Bride? Upon first blush the answer would be, the Lord’s true and faithful people,
      all who by faith and obedience were affianced to him, and continued faithful to the end. In a general
      way this answer may be accepted as the truth, but in a narrower and closer view of things it cannot be
      taken as strictly and absolutely correct.
              The 45th Psalm unmistakably refers to this subject. The qualities and doings of the King,
      come forth from the ivory palaces, arc there described with great vigour and animation. But there is
      also the Queen, the King’s Bride, standing on his right hand, in gold of Ophir, and all glorious within.
      It is said of her that “ she shall be brought unto the King in raiment of needle-work.” But, besides the
      Queen, the King’s Bride, there is another blessed company, who are also to enter with rejoicing into
      the King’s palace, and to share the light of his countenance. They are called “the virgins,” the
      “companions,” associates, and bosom friends of the Queen, but plainly distinct from the Queen herself.
      They do not go with her when she is taken, but “follow her,”—come after her,—and are “brought unto
      the King “ at a subsequent time, and in quite another capacity from that of the Queen and Bride. All
      of them belong to the general congregation of the saved. All of them arc made forever happy in their
      Lord, the King. But the Queen is one class, and “the virgins her companions that follow her,” are
      another class.
              So, too, in the Song of Solomon (6:8-9), we read of queens, concubines, and virgins, whom the
      fathers, for the most part, understood as referring to the various classes which make up the Church as
      a whole….The oldest Christian interpretation , and that which is best sustained, sees in them
      none but genuine believers, but of different degrees of honor and nearness to their Lord; in
      which case, again, not all have the Bride’s place.
              So the parable of the Ten Virgins tells of a coming Bridegroom, and of friends of the Bride
      going out, as in ancient custom, to meet and welcome him, and to go in with him to the marriage; but
      where is the Bride? Both the connection and the terms of this parable imply that she is then already
      within the Father’s house, there awaiting the coming of the Bridegroom, whilst these her friends go
      out to meet him,—not in hope of becoming his Bride, but of having the blessedness of going in with
      him to the marriage. As a matter of fact, distinctly stated, the day of the Lord has already commenced
      when the kingdom of heaven assumes the precise shape here indicated. In the verses preceding, the
      Saviour spoke of the gathering of certain eagle saints to that body on which they live, of the mysterious
      taking of some, while others are left, and of the sadness of being cut off from the high privileges and
      honours of that first class ; and it is “ then,’’ he says, only then, that matters take the shape described
      in the parable. Those who are “taken” before “then” are people of pre-eminent saintship and watchful
      preparedness. (Comp. Luke 17:33-37; 21:34-36) They correspond to the Bride, whilst the wise virgins
      come after, not being ready when the Bride was taken. Nay, it is the removal of these waiting and
      ready ones which awakens the intense adventism of those that are “left,” and serves as the means of
      bringing at least half of them in as guests and witnesses of the marriage. The “left” know now that
      Christ is presently to come as the Bridegroom, on his way to join his Bride. To be ready for that
      Bridegroom coming, that they may go in with him to the marriage, is now the one great thought. In all
      ordinary custom—to which the allusion is—the going in would be the going into the Father’s house
      where the Bride already is, arrayed and ready for her coming Lord.
              To say nothing, then, of the place and fate of the five unwise virgins, this parable, taken in
      its connections, inevitably implies that not all of those who finally get to heaven are of that class
      which actually constitutes the Bride of Christ, however related to that Bride.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 326
                 It is also the common doctrine of the Scriptures that there are great diversities in the
         portions awarded to the saints. There are some greatest and some least in the kingdom of heaven.
         There are some who shall be first and some who shall be last. There are some who get crowns,
         and there are some who get none. There are some who are assigned dominion over ten cities,
         some over five, and some who lose all reward, and are saved only “so as by fire.”…To a blessed
         degree they share the Bride’s honours. And in general terms we must include them when we
         speak of the Bride, although, in strict language, they are not all the Bride. The Bride has relations
         to the Bridegroom which belong to her alone, and it is only because of her and their association
         and companionship with her, and not because they are the Bride in actual fact, that the whole
         company of the saved Church of God is contemplated as the Lamb’s Wife.
                 Hence, also, the angel directed John to write, “Blessed they who have been called to the supper
         of the marriage of the Lamb [Rev 19:9].” It is the wider and the more general blessedness of the
         occasion that the seer was thus to attest. If all the saved were actually the Bride, it would have been
         enough, and more to the point, to say, “Blessed they that are called to be the Wife of the Lamb.” But
         there is a blessedness of being called to witness his marriage, and a blessedness of participation with
         the bridal company in the marriage banquet, as well as a more special blessedness of being the actual
         Bride of the Lamb. The call is indeed to make up the Bride. It is out of these called ones that the Bride
         is chosen. But the choosing of the Bride does not, therefore, exclude the rest of the company from the
         honours and privileges of the marriage supper, or from companionship with the Lamb and his Wife.
         The blessedness of the marriage supper is much wider than that of becoming the Bride, though the
         Bride has honour and nearness to the Lord which belong to her only. Hence the writing was to be, not
         simply “Blessed they that are called to be the Wife of the Lamb,” but “blessed they who are called to
         the supper of the marriage of the Lamb,”—called as in the parable of the marriage of the king’s son,
         which call includes the opportunity to become the Bride as well as happy guests.
                 In this sense also am I constrained to take the subsequent showing of “the Bride, the Lamb’s
         Wife,” “that great city, the holy Jerusalem, descending out of the heaven from God.” It is called
         the Bride, because it embraces the Bride, and because it is the Bride’s everlasting home and
         residence. But for the very reason that it is the home and residence of the Lamb’s Wife, it must
         include her retinue, her companions, and her attendants, who share the glory with her, but who
         are not strictly the Bride herself. In general terms the whole city, as made up of those who inhabit
         it, including all the saved up to the time of the resurrection of all saints, is the Bride, the Lamb’s
         Wife, because all that are there pertain to her company, fill out the grandeur and glory of her
         estate, and share immensely in it ; albeit, some are there who, in a narrower and more particular
         discrimination, are not actually the Bride. (Seiss, 426-428; italics his.)

        Seiss may be seen as taking a mediating position between Dillow and me. Like Dillow, he poses that all these
believers will be in the New Jerusalem. Like me, he poses that not all believers have a sufficient degree of holiness
to be the Bride. Like both of us, he acknowledges that some believers are faithful enough to be put in charge of
cities, but other believers are only saved as through fire, an obvious compilation of the Parable of the Minas in
Lk 19:12-26 with Paul’s statement in 1Cor 3:15. Yet, if compared to the sister Parable of the Talents in Mt 25:14-
30, this would place unfaithful believers in the outer darkness, a perspective Dillow and I both share. But if New
Jerusalem is a literal city and unfaithful believers live in this city, as Dillow and Seiss both believe, then this would
place the outer darkness in New Jerusalem. I have explored this possibility in both TOD and MMP1 and rejected
it. As I noted in those books, Becker had posed that unfaithful believers would be consigned to the lower third of
the City.420 Consistency, in that case, would dictate that the outer darkness is thus in the lower third of the City. Yet
this model has numerous logistical problems, as I have demonstrated in detail in those previous discussions.
        One problem concerns the location of unfaithful believers before the JSC. Were they merely in the lower
third of the City only to be sent back to the lower third of the City as a result of being cast into the outer darkness?
The ridiculousness of that proposal led me to consult Scott Crawford and adopt and adapt his suggestion into the
present model being used in this series of Misthological Models. Namely, the outer darkness is outside the Heavenly
City, even now, during the intermediate state. Consequently, the present series poses a Celestial Outer Darkness


420
      Becker, Revelation, 522-523.
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                        Page 327
                                                                      421
for unfaithful Celestials (i.e., for unfaithful immortal believers). During the millennial kingdom, unfaithful
Terrans (i.e., unfaithful mortal believers) will be in the Terrestrial Outer Darkness.
        Placing the outer darkness in New Jerusalem was so objectionable, even to Dillow, that he argued against a
literal interpretation of the New Jerusalem. Obviously, you cannot very easily place this darkness in a Celestial City
that has no darkness! Seiss, on the other hand, argues for a literal New Jerusalem. If logically consistent, his
argument, like Becker’s argument, would lead to the conclusion that the outer darkness is literally in the lower third
of the Celestial City. As noted in MMP1, Becker (p. 118) has posed that unfaithful believers will live inside the
New Jerusalem: “Those who are born again by the Spirit but fail to hear God and obey will live inside the heavenly
city but receive no reward.” Yet, in that case, what does one do with a verse like Rev 22:19: “And if anyone takes
away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God shall take away his part from the tree of life and from the
holy city, which are written in this book”? Access to both the Tree of Life and the City appears to be in jeopardy.
As noted in MMP1, Becker speculates that unfaithful believers are allowed into the lower city (pp. 522-523) but
not permitted access to the streets where the Tree of Life is located (p. 523). This argument is exceedingly strained,
however. She acknowledges, for instance, that “the whole city is like a gigantic greenhouse” because of the
pervasive presence of the Tree of Life throughout it (p. 515). She is struggling against significant logistical problems
in trying to pose that unfaithful believers are in the City. Seiss, on the other hand, has a much simpler solution: cast
unfaithful believers into the Lake of Fire for eternity. Evidently, his Lutheran background leads him to a linear view
of regeneration so that regeneration can be lost if one does not preserve in the faith, and he expands this potential
loss of salvation to warn believers, regarding Rev 22:11, that they can “be deceived and perish” (p. 517) and,
regarding Rev 22:19, that they can “forfeit salvation itself” (p. 526).
        Aside from the numerous arguments that I could make and have made in defense of unconditional security,
simply noting three inconsistencies should suffice to refute Seiss’ making soteriological salvation (and thus
retention of regeneration) contingent on perseverance in faith. First, Rev 22:11 and 22:19 are not limited to
perseverance in faith but include perseverance in faithfulness. To condition soteriology on perseverance in these
verses is to condition security on performance, thus conditioning final soteriological salvation on works, which is a
soteriological anathema, of which all forms of conditional security (even Reformed Arminianism) are guilty.
Second, Seiss acknowledges that believers can be saved soteriologically as through fire by losing all their rewards.
Rewards are always based on works/performance. Saying that believers loose their soteriological security because
of their performance is incompatible with his acknowledgment that they are saved despite a performance that is so
bad that they lose all their rewards. Third, between these two performance verses in Rev 22:11 and 22:19 is a non-
performance verse in Rev 22:17: “And the Spirit and the bride say, ‘Come.’ And let the one who hears say, ‘Come.’
And let the one who is thirsty come; let the one who wishes take the water of life without cost.” Yet Seiss adds
performance as a condition to something that is supposed to be offered freely:

             The meaning is, that the waters of life, as they flow in the New Jerusalem, which comes not till
421
   In TOD, I had to delay the expulsion of the poorly clothed friend in Mt 22:11-13 until the Wedding Banquet,
that is, until the millennial kingdom already had started. Plus, I had to place unworthy Celestials in a Terrestrial
Outer Darkness. In the present series, in contrast, I can pose an immediate expulsion from the Wedding
Feast/Festivities that take place atop the Heavenly City during the Bema with the result that unworthy Celestials
are cast into a Celestial Outer Darkness when pronounced unworthy at the Bema. The possibility of immediate
expulsion in the present study enforces the preference in TOD for a church-age vantage point. Nevertheless, even
without having the advantage of immediate expulsion, in Appendix 18 of TOD, I was able to provide multiple
vantage points for the passage and thus demonstrate both a church-age and tribulational applicability, posing that
the reason the Bride is not in the picture is because adding this detail would have limited the interpretation (and
thus the intended direct application) to one group as opposed to another. The TOD argument for a dual vantage
point remains valid. From one vantage point, such as that posed in the present study, the Bride is missing because
She is entering the Heavenly City during the Bema to consummate Her reward with Her Lord while unworthy
Celestials are being sent back to the Celestial Outer Darkness at the commencement of the Wedding Festivities.
From another vantage point, such as that posed in TOD, part of the reason Jesus presents a parable that distinguishes
appropriately clothed church-age believers from the Bride is because the Lord does not wish to limit the application
to church-age believers. Additionally, one might posit that the properly clothed wedding attendees waiting for the
Bride to come forth from Her chambers are the angelic members of the divine council attending the royal wedding
in Ps 45:1-17.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 328
      Christ comes, are to be had without money and without price: but that those who thirst for those waters
      are to join with the company and call of those who thus yearn for the blessed consummation. If
      anyone is athirst for these waters, or has a mind and appetite for them, the word is, “Let him come.”
      Come whither, come to what? Corne into fellowship with the Spirit, the Bride, and every believing
      hearer of their testimony, in yearning, and looking, and praying for the coming of the Lord to fulfil
      what he has promised, and this Book describes. Everything in grace is moving and looking to that; and
      if any are athirst for God’s living waters, or if any have a will to partake of them, this is the way to
      get them. No price is set upon them. They are free as the air to everyone who would have them. But
      the free partaking of them is by faith in Christ, by seizing hold upon his promises to his Church,
      and by joining the cry of the Spirit, the yearning of the Bride, and the soul of all right hope, in
      “looking for and hasting unto the coming of the day of God,” even the glorious Apocalypse of the
      blessed Christ. (P. 525)

Nonsense. The water of life is genuinely free to all who simply believe in Christ for eternal life. This gift is not
conditioned on Seiss’ imaginary list: joining the church, calling, yearning, fellowshipping, looking, praying, seizing,
crying, and looking. These are performance issues, matters dealing with rewards.
        Becker does better but still falls short. As pointed out in TOD, Becker entertains the idea that perseverance
in faith is a soteriological requirement to reach Heaven. In doing so, she backloads the gospel.422 Much to her credit,
nevertheless, she acknowledges that those who fall back into the world remain saved: “Are they lost then, since
they failed to continue? No, they genuinely believed; therefore, their sins remain covered by the blood of Christ.”423
With the past tense, she correctly attributes their present blood-covered status to their past faith. However, in that
case, the blood would cover the sin of failing to continue to believe. If moral apostasy is covered by the blood, then
so is theological apostasy. Becker’s soft conditional security is not only destructive; it self-destructs. Even so, she
is superior to Seiss regarding Rev 22:19. She maintains that believers’ soteriological salvation is not jeopardized by
the verse. Instead, God is warning, “in effect, ‘You don’t believe I can do what I say I will do? You are not worthy
to behold my glory at close range’” (p. 538; emphasis hers). How close of a range is permitted? Becker poses that
such believers will be in the lower section of the City. But Rev 22:19 says that they lose their part/portion in the
City. A better answer is the one posed by my books in this Misthological Models. Such believers lose their right to
participate in the City. They have no portion in the City. They never have any residence or entrance into the City.
        How did Dillow deal with the verse? He simply says that what is at stake is the loss “of the privileged
position” to be an inheritor of the kingdom: “The danger is disinheritance and not loss of salvation” (p. 676).
Basically, he reduces the City to a metaphor for the kingdom. Faithful believers inherit it. Unfaithful believers
merely enter it. Seiss and Becker are better in this regard, taking the City to be literal.
        The solution is simple. Put the outer darkness outside the literal City and locate unfaithful believers
there. Conceptually, Rev 22:19 is a warning about the misthological outer darkness. The gates of Space City
will be opened in all terrestrial directions (Rev 21:13). Terran kings from all Terran locations throughout
space will be able to bring the riches of the Terrans to the City in order to enter it. But celestial angelic guards
will still be posted as a reminder that not everyone is permitted to enter. Celestials in the outer darkness are
excluded. Terran kings can only enter if they bring the riches of the Terran provinces into it (Rev 21:24-27).
Entrance is not free. The admission price is tremendous. Tony Evans correctly deduces that the passages dealing
with the outer darkness are dealing with the loss of reward and that Rev 22:19 is also dealing with the loss of reward,
even as it pertains to the City: “Those who do so will have their heavenly rewards taken away, namely, their share
of the tree of life and the holy city” (TEBC; emphasis his). As a plus, Evans takes the City literally. Consequently,
and quite literally, unfaithful believers will have no share in the City. They will not be sharing residences, food, or
streets with those who live there.
        To be sure, logistical challenges must be addressed by the model I am posing. For instance, some arguments
made above by Seiss need to be addressed. He posed that Ps 45:1-17 unmistakably refers to the Bride of Christ. I
concur. He further notes that the Bride is distinct from her companions. Again, I agree. He then concludes that these
bridal companions in Ps 45 are genuine believers who fail to qualify to be the Bride. I disagree. The bridal

companions in Ps 45 are better seen as fellow members of the divine council. They are high-ranking angels, as
summarized herein from my discussion in LTPW. Still, that point aside, Seiss then proceeds to shoot his own
argument in the foot when he tries to make all the saints the Bride in the broad sense but not in the narrow sense.
His argument from Ps 45 refutes the notion that all saints compose the Bride in any sense. Being a bridesmaid does
not make you the Bride! Sure, a bridesmaid can be the bride at another wedding, but not at the wedding she is
attending as a bridesmaid.
       Becker uses a similar argument regarding the companions in Ps 45, taking them to be the OT saints and
tribulational saints and saying that they are not part of the Bride. Like Seiss, she believes that the virgin companions
in Ps 45:14-15 will live in the palace/City but not rule (pp. 446-448). Notwithstanding my disagreement regarding
Ps 45 and my insisting that unfaithful believers are outside the City rather than inside of it, I can appreciate the
logistical challenges these various scriptural groups present. Indeed, in TOD, my preference would have been to
regard the faithful elect of other dispensations to be distinct from the Bride. Today, I am more inclined to
regard all overcomers who live in the Bridal City as part of the Bride.424 Seiss, Becker, and I are all agreed that
the Bride is not truly composed of all believers. Even so, we disagree on some of the particulars regarding the
identity of the Bride.
                                         Illustration 121. Wife Versus Bride




        Seiss poses a distinction between being the Lamb’s Wife versus the Bride in the narrower sense. My solution
is to see the wise virgins in Mt 25:1-13 dualistically: as not being a part of the Bride dispensationally but part
of the Bride-Wife misthologically. Dispensationally, they represent faithful believers of the tribulation period who
are living on Earth and thus are not part of the Heavenly Bride. As Becker points out, they miss out on the bridal
celebration that takes place in the Heavenly City during the tribulation. Thus, in that sense, they cannot be part of
the Bride. Nonetheless, they will live in the Heavenly City, rule from the City, and participate in the Bride’s
Marriage Supper/Messianic Banquet on Earth as co-rulers with faithful OT saints and church-age saints.
Consequently, I believe Seiss is onto something to see a duality to the Bride, though I would describe it differently.
        Church-age overcomers will be the first to constitute the Bride. They are the Bride in the narrower
sense, the original sense, being the resurrected and glorified Bride during the tribulation. However, faithful
believers of other dispensations will subsequently join them as being considered part of the Bride/Wife in the
broader sense, the secondary sense, the derivative sense, and the misthological sense when they are
resurrected at the end of the tribulation and given glorified bodies before the millennium starts. These
groups, and only these groups, in my opinion, will be considered the Bride in the eternal sense. Therefore, I
concur with Seiss in seeing the Bride from two vantage points, through a narrow lens and a broad lens, so to

424
   Unfortunately, Lang simply takes the City as a metaphor for the Bride, whereas I take the City literally.
Nonetheless, I now concur with him that overcomers from other dispensations are included in the misthological
Bride. G. H. Lang, Pictures and Parables: Studies in the Parabolic Teaching of Scripture (Miami Springs, FL:
Conley & Schoettle Publishing, 1985), 376.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 330
speak. Yet, we differ on the timeframe and constituents. In the narrow sense, only the faithful of the church-age
represent the Bride. In the broad sense, the faithful of all dispensations up unto the millennial kingdom
represent the bridal Wife. Unfaithful believers are never part of the Bride in any sense. They are cast into the
darkness outside the wedding! They are not part of the wedding!
       Additionally, I would anticipate that these faithful believers from these dispensations, and only these
faithful believers, will compose the 6th-dimensional Bride. Being a member of the 6D Bride is limited to
overcomers of the church-age dispensation and other dispensations in which the battle with sin is intense.
Unfaithful believers will forever remain 4D beings, excluded not only from higher dimensions but also from the 4D
City and 3D City, and probably confined to the outer realm of the 4D Multiverse since they succumbed to sin and
were overcome by it.
       While some suggest that faithful believers of the millennial age and eternal ages might eventually be
added to the Bride, I would suggest, instead, that they are virginal companions to the Bride and join in Her
celebration in the extended sense. In a belated sense, they are invited to the marriage supper of the Lamb as
companions. The invitation of Rev 19:9 is not limited to the present dispensation or even to the next dispensation
but extends to eternal ages. “Blessed are those who are invited to the marriage supper of the Lamb,” regardless of
the dispensation in which they live. Future believers of the millennial age and the eternal ages will be able to
participate in this supper as second-tier elohim, as 4D elohim. The misthological invitation of this verse goes
forth through eternal ages. God’s misthological nature to reward does not die. What about the unfaithful
virgins? They, conversely, represent unfaithful believers who will be excluded from being a part of the Bride or
Wife forever, in either the narrow or broad sense, and are excluded from attending the bridal festivities for all
eternity.
       Seiss’ exposition of the Wedding, a few pages later, is a better assessment than his exposition of the Bride
since his Wedding exposition would exclude all unfaithful believers from being considered the Bride in any sense:

      It is Christ in the character of the Lamb, the mighty God, formally acknowledging and taking to himself
      as copartners of his throne, dominion, and glory, all those chosen ones who have been faithful to
      their betrothal, and appear at last in the spotless and shining apparel of the righteousnesses of the
      saints, thenceforward to be with him, reign with him. and share with him in all his grand inheritance,
      forever. (P. 430; emphasis his.)

       To be a bridal copartner with Christ, one must be faithful to the betrothal and thus be misthologically spotless
and wearing shining robes of misthological righteousness so that one can rule with Christ. For Seis to suggest that
the unfaithful who are not clothed in appropriate wedding garments and who lose all their rewards and fail to rule
with Christ are somehow considered the Bride in some secondary sense as His Wife is nonsense. On the other hand,
to pose that those OT saints and tribulational saints who overcome and are clothed in white and co-rule with Christ
and live with Christ in the bridal City can be considered part of the bridal company in the full 6D sense seems
sensible. Therefore, his postulation of a narrow and broad view of the Bride is adopted herein yet amended to
accommodate the more plausible inclusion of fellow overcomers of the OT and tribulational periods. The original
bridal saints compose the Bride in the narrow sense. They are first-tier human elohim. Secondary elohim added to
this number may be considered the Wife of the Lamb in a broadened sense. They will be 4D elohim. Yet, for
logistical reasons discussed herein, they must be located outside the 4D City.

      Populated Planet
      Returning now to Patterson, as part of his discussion of the nations who live on Earth, as opposed to the
immortals who live in the City, he reasonably proposes that smortals (to use my term) are already on the New Earth
before New Jerusalem descends out of heaven:

      When the New Jerusalem descends to the new earth [Rev 21:2,9], it finds people already there. It is an
      inhabited earth to which it comes. It does not bring this population with it. They are evidently not a
      part of the great body who are in the city. Indeed, the fact that the city comes to them and that this
      coming of the city and God is to them the great event, shows plainly that they are on earth. It is stated
      they are not to inhabit the city, but to live in the light of it. When we remember that the city comes
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                          Page 331
      from heaven, while this company is of the earth, there is in connection with all before said, a plain
      inference that they are different in nature also. (Pp. 386-387)

As part of his extended defense for this proposition, Patterson asserts that Rev 21:4 applies to those on Earth who
come down:

      The inhabitants of the earth to whom the city comes, and to whom God comes with it, are spoken of
      as “men” and “peoples,” and they are spoken of in connection with tears and death and mourning and
      crying and pain, all of which it is said are now to cease. The tears are to be wiped from their eyes. If
      these are resurrected persons, these allusions and declarations seem very strange. Wiping away all
      tears from the faces of risen saints is something wholly irreconcilable with their nature and state. The
      promise of banishing death from those who have gotten the victory over death by resurrection, is also
      incongruous, and so is the promise of no mourning, crying, or pain. (P. 387).

       Patterson is correct that those in New Jerusalem would have no tears to be wiped away. However, he
unnecessarily assumes that this must mean that the wiping away of tears does not apply to them. My argument in
TOD is that it applies to them litotetically. In my opinion, his application of Rev 21:4 to smortals is inferior to my
application of the verse misthologically to victorious immortals. Nevertheless, his proposal is superior to Govett,
who applies it to all immortals, thus to unfaithful and faithful alike (Revelation, 333). Not so! At least Govett
believes these immortals will rule over the smortals in the eternal state. Yet, by placing unfaithful immortals as co-
rulers in the City at the beginning of the eternal state, Govett nullifies rewards after the millennial kingdom, which
is a colossal error (see RAE). Govett is dead wrong to apply Rev 21:4 to all immortals, and Patterson unnecessarily
applies it to smortals. The solution is to apply it litotetically and thus misthologically to overcomers. Still, both
Govett and Patterson tend to be far ahead of most interpreters regarding other details. For that matter, the point
Patterson is making regarding the planet being populated before New Jerusalem comes down is plausible, as I noted
in TOD. Based on what John is describing, the inference appears to be that the inhabitants of the New Earth are
transported to the New Earth before the New Jerusalem descends to rest on it. That is, the millennial nations who
survive the millennium and who enter the eternal kingdom in their flesh and blood bodies are transported to the
New Earth before the Celestial overcomers join them on the New Earth. Restated in terms of the present discussion,
smortals will be transported to the New Earth before the City, with its faithful ruling immortals, descends out of the
heavenly realm above Earth. Like the question, “Which come first, the chicken or the egg?” we can pose the
question, “In the new heavens and New Earth, who comes back first, the smortals or immortals?” The answer,
according to Patterson, is smortals. He is probably right.

       Kings of the Earth
       Patterson immediately continues: “The further state of these [smortals] is indicated by the expression, ‘The
kings of the earth.’ The risen saints would scarcely be so spoken of either by this title or as bringing their glory into
the City where they constantly abide. It is further said, “‘They shall bring the glory and honor of the nations into
it’” (p. 387). In TOD, I was hesitant to accept this assessment. In the present discussion, I embrace it with the
modification that semi-faithful TZ immortals are probably also included. He then supplies an extended quote from
Craven:

      We should distinguish between the citizens of the city and the nations. The former are risen and
      glorified saints who constitute the Bride, the governors of the new creation. The latter are probably
      men in the flesh who ‘ walk in the light of the city,’ who ‘bring their glory and honor into it,’ and who
      are healed (or kept in health) by the leaves of the Tree of Life, i. e., who are under its instruction. . . .
      The nations will consist of men in the flesh, freed from sin and the curse, begetting a holy seed and
      dwelling in blessedness under the government of the New Jerusalem. They will not be the offspring
      of the glorified saints, who ‘ neither marry nor are given in marriage,’ but the descendants of those
      who live in the period of the millennial kingdom. . . .The same almighty power that conveyed Noah
      and his family across the waters of the first deluge, can bear other families across the fiery floods
      of the second. It may be retorted that there is no promise of such a miracle. That there is no expressed
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 332
      promise is admitted, but the divine prediction of an event ever implies the promise of a sufficient
      cause.” (Pp. 387-388; ellipses his)

Splendid! Patterson realizes that the Bride is composed of overcoming immortals. The nations are composed of
smortals who are descendants of millennial mortals. These smortals are conveyed from the millennial kingdom to
the new Earth in the eternal state in flesh-and-blood bodies that reproduce, just as Noah and his family were
conveyed across the flood to the resultant new Earth in a new dispensation in flesh-and-blood bodies that reproduce.
He further explains:

      These are then restored humanity entering the new earth. They are what Adam was before he fell,
      and therefore are fit for the presence of God, who can now resume the original fellowship of
      Eden so long interrupted. This will be the perfect restoration of humanity never before secured. It
      will be a victory not to be secured otherwise. The resurrection is victory over death, but man must die
      in order to rise. The translation of living believers saves man by lifting him above mortality into
      another sphere. The great restoration of the race gives him spirituality and immortality in his own
      sphere. It makes natural man superior to the power of death and sin. There is bestowed upon the
      restored race more than Adam enjoyed. By the death of Christ the spiritual power of sin was
      destroyed. In the millennium the social dominion of sin is removed. By the eternal edict from the
      Throne, that in man which responds to the attack of temptation, is removed. Man will be physically,
      psychically, and spiritually perfect. The first man was of the earth, earthy, but he is so no longer. By
      the edict from the Throne, he is made new. If God is to be glorified in the eternal state by material
      creatures and beauties in nature, why not by the crowning work of creation, perfected man? To lay
      man aside in the hour of final victory, would be to acknowledge a mistake in his creation or a defeat
      in his redemption. The perfection of the new earth will require the perfection of man in all his
      relationships and faculties. (P. 389).

       Smortals will be like Adam and Eve but better. They will not only be physically and psychically perfect but
also spiritually perfect. Adam and Eve were only spiritually innocent. Patterson then deals with objections:

             There are some objections to this view which we should consider here. The first is the scripture
      which says, “Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, neither doth corruption inherit
      incorruption. [1Cor 15:50]” Paul is speaking here of unregenerate man and the necessity of a
      resurrection for the admittance of such into the kingdom of God. The persons we speak of are
      regenerate, and they are not “corruption” in any sense. The body of Adam was not “corruption.” It was
      in the kingdom of God also. The place in the kingdom to which Paul refers above, however, is that of
      sovereignty in the kingdom, which is not the place of the restored race. (Pp. 389-390)

I would articulate this defense a little differently. Smortals do not inherit the kingdom. Rather than go into all the
details provided earlier in this series, such as in MMP1, suffice it to say that only immortals can inherit the kingdom.
Having a body that is even subject to micro death is not suitable for being an immortal ruler of the eternal kingdom
and living in the Heavenly City. Fully transformed bodies, not semi-transformed bodies, are necessary to reign as
Gods and Goddesses from the Heavenly Mount Olympus. Smortals are merely earthly kings, not heavenly kings.

      Procreation and Propagation on Earth
As to procreation and the expansion of the human race via smortals, Patterson responds:

              There seems at first something incongruous in the idea of there being a race of human beings
      living as now, and increasing in the eternal ages. This comes partly from preconceived opinions as to
      the future state. There is nothing in Scripture forbidding the idea of material beings in the eternal ages.
      It is the leaven of heathenism in our Christianity, which deprecates the material as inherently sinful,
      and that true holiness can only be obtained by abstraction from all this, and in a state of etherialism
      hereafter. A mystical state has come to be considered as the necessary condition for purity. Another
      reason comes from considering the fall as having consisted in, or having led to, the introduction of
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                        Page 333
      marital relations. This we have seen has no foundation in Scripture. Such relations and the propagation
      of the race were contemplated in the creation of man, as the following scripture states: “And God
      created man in his own image, in the image of God created he him; male and female created he them.
      And God blessed them; and God said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.”
      Here is express command before the fall for the propagation of the race. What was right and fitting in
      the original Eden, is also fitting in the new earth. There was here contemplated the holy increase of
      the race of man, and their gradual filling of the earth.
             There is another essential reason, however, why we must consider these to be earthly people.
      There is called for by the whole plan of God as we have seen it, and by numerous passages, the idea
      of constant increase in the numbers of the people of Christ during the ages of eternity. The Scriptures
      declare, “Of the increase of his government and of peace there shall be no end.” We cannot
      conceive of the work of God coming to a stand as to the number of his people, no matter what
      the extent of their individual advancement might be. The whole law of God in nature and in grace
      is increase. We have followed this progress from the beginning, and seen not only advance in the
      character of the individuals, and the manifestations of God’s character and grace, but the spread of the
      work of God numerically among men. It is wholly irreconcilable with the apparent plan of divine
      action, to suppose this increase will stop when the full victory of Christ over sin is gained. It
      leaves the great scheme of redemption narrowed to those gathered out of mankind who remain
      thereafter a fixed number. Christ could create new beings, but these would not be the race which
      he purchased with his blood. The same scriptures which speak of the perpetuity of the earth also
      speak of the continuance of the ordinances and people of the earth. The covenant was made for
      “perpetual generations.” (Pp. 390-392)

His argument is well stated and expanded upon in TOD. He returns to his discussion of how this applies to the kings
of the Earth:

      The same is also expressed by the plural form of the word “nations.” There is governmental life in the
      new earth. The Scripture speaks of the “kings of the earth.” This gives us the idea of self-government
      to some degree. These kings are not the saints who occupy the higher relations to the earth, but their
      own rulers in subordination to the rule of Christ and his assistants. There is diversity of gifts and place
      in the new earth. There is no such idea in the Scriptures as a common level of character or position or
      ability in the descriptions of the eternal state. Such ideas of leveling come from below and not from
      above. A state of pure communism is impossible and impracticable anywhere.
             The whole picture is that of an orderly kingdom having its capital city, and reigning king with
      his immediate family and court, and others who occupy positions of power and honor, and still a greater
      number who assist in many ways, and still larger numbers who have no such special honors, but have
      the privileges of the capital city, and a vast number of subjects, happy in being under such a king. (Pp.
      392-393)

I fully agree. My book, Is God a Communist? refutes the notion that everyone will be treated alike. Special rewards
and distinctions remain fully applicable during the eternal state. He correctly deduces that the eternal procreation
of the human race necessarily infers propagation to other planets.

      Propagation to Other Planets
      The worlds of the heavens are so great, so many, that knowing God as the God of design and life and
      purpose, we are irresistibly led to feel these great and innumerable worlds are to be the scene of
      life and activity. Further, the same arguments lead us to believe they must be intended as the spheres
      of intelligent life, of beings who can enjoy all this, and think, and reason, and glorify the Creator
      of all…. The prediction was, “Of the increase of his government there shall be no end.” Increase,
      then, is the work of Christ, and here is its sphere.
             We ask what beings will inhabit these new worlds? Christ could create races for each as he did
      man for earth. He could also repeat the work of redemption upon each. But both of these suppositions
      seem incredible. Either, as said before, would be a break in the continuity of the divine plan. It would
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                    Page 334
      be a departure from the plan as we have seen it unrolled before us, in which each age grows out of the
      preceding and leads up to another, and each advances upon a forecasted plan. Besides, if other races
      were created, sin might come to them, and other and greater falls take place. The whole outlook seems
      to comprehend extension of the work already commenced.
              Looking back to the beginning, we conceived the plan of God to be the production of a race of
      beings of a character established in holiness, whom he could trust under all circumstances, and to
      whom he could commit the carrying out of his great designs. We noted the repeated sowings and
      siftings by which such a race was. produced, the care to exclude all tares at the last great sifting. We
      are irresistibly led to believe God has some great purpose in man, aside from the peopling of this
      little world.…Earth is but a seed-bed from which God will people the heavens. This purified race
      are to be the progenitors of worlds of such holy, happy creatures. If our view of the preservation
      of a human race from the last destruction of the world, in their earthly bodies, is correct, some
      sphere for the accommodation of the increase of the race will be required. In a thousand years
      they would so increase as to fill the earth far beyond the present most crowded parts. From
      whatever point we view the future of the eternal age, we are led to see that there must be increase,
      and room for it. We can see plainly the room for the spread of the increase and the increase itself, and
      there seems to be no Scriptural or reasonable objection to this. Indeed, the Scripture tells us plainly the
      church is to be but “a kind of first-fruits of his creatures.”….
              …. It is not rhetoric. It is not hyperbole. It is actual certitude that if the worlds, innumerable as
      astronomy tells us they are, should be peopled as the earth is and will be in the time of blessedness,
      the actual number of the population of the universe would be as innumerable, on any system of human
      computation, as the sand of the sea or the dust of the earth. (Pp. 398-401)

     Space Gates to Terran Directions
     Patterson was visionary, a man so far ahead of his time that his statements about the gates are superior to
modern interpreters:

      The open gates opening to all quarters, indicate further the universal mission of the church in eternity.
      These directions, east, west, north, and south, are sidereal as well as geographical. They indicate
      universality as to other worlds as well as earth. We can conceive of the saints endowed with
      divine or angelic power of flight, going upon missions to distant worlds. We can believe their
      responsibilities will extend to these worlds. They will occupy relations of superiority as well as
      of love and mercy. Those who saw the age of sin and were combatants in that age and struggled
      and overcame, will be to these worlds as veterans are to us. Their numbers cannot be added to,
      for the story of sin will never be repeated, we feel sure. Such will occupy a position unique among
      the myriads of the universe. They may become world rulers, well trained for the great
      responsibility by their lives of struggle.

      Why would the gates of the Spacial City be said to extend in four terrestrial directions, when such
directions would not apply in space? Because they denote access to terrestrial realms scatter throughout
space, throughout the entire universe. Just as giving all four terrestrial directions on Earth to Earthly
Jerusalem would denote full access from all terrestrial directions to the Earthly Jerusalem, so making them
apply to the Heavenly City makes them apply to all terrestrial realms throughout space!

      Universes
      Patterson’s explanation about the Terran locations being associated with the Space City to denote Terran
access throughout the universe is far ahead of its time. Most interpreters have still not caught up to him. As if that
was not visionary enough, Patterson then goes on a step further and states:

      Eternity is not one long unbroken period, but is arranged in ages or periods as the time we have known,
      and we may believe that they are distinguished by peculiarities as those we have known. We have seen
      in the succession of the ages of earth and man, development. One age prepares for another, and this
      opens up into one still more advanced. One age is to another as seed to plant and this to flower and
Chapter 7. New Jerusalem as the Bride                                                                          Page 335
      this to harvest. But harvest only means a new sowing and a still greater growing and harvests
      unceasing. The same operation we have every reason to believe will continue. God’s plan is one. Great
      ages will come and go. New purposes will dawn upon the universes. (P. 406)

       One could go into a study of breaking up forever and ever into eternal ages, even eternal ages of ages, through
a study of aion to prove his point. Instead, I want to call attention to the fact that he moved from talking about God’s
purpose expanding through our universe (via an expanding human population ruled over by overcomers) to carrying
that expansion to other universes—plural! In 1896, Patterson was postulating the necessity of expanding the human
race and misthological reign to the multiverse! Astounding! Misthologically and mathematically, he is absolutely
right! Moreover, he is correct that all this extrapolation goes back to the healing of the nations. These nations must
be able to procreate to propagate God’s reign in the manner God originally designed. God never intended for
humanity to be confined to this universe, much less to this planet. Humanity was designed to rule over all the works
of God’s hands (Heb 2:6-8), not just this planet. Properly deducing that these nations are comprised of smortals
allows one to see far into the future if one will just look. Dankenbring acknowledges this possibility:

             God has called and chosen you to become one of His sons. He wants you to eventually shoulder
      the mantle of rulership over the entire Universe, along with our saviour and Elder Brother, Jesus
      Christ. God wants to glorify you, make you immortal, give you dazzling strength and power and
      radiance. He wants you to help rule His Kingdom for ever!
             But God will never give that kind of awesome power to any being whom He cannot trust. You
      must prove yourself. You must be an overcomer….
             But tomorrow, after we learn our lessons, and grow in spiritual maturity, and achieve peace with
      God through Jesus Christ, He intends for us to rule over the stars—the vast, far flung reaches of the
      Universe. We will be able to travel faster than light. We may even create new Universes, with new
      planets, and new galaxies! What an awesome, mind-boggling, incredible, astonishing destiny and
      calling! Can your mind really comprehend it?
             Today, the earth.
             Tomorrow, the stars! (BSW, italics his, 317-319)

       For starters, we can conceive of overcoming saints, being endowed with the divine power of flight and
teleportation, going on missions to distant planets in other universes. Then we can conceive of them moving galaxies
from one universe to another. Then we can conceive of them creating not only planets and galaxies but also entire
universes complete with life. Then we can conceive of them having Teleportal Cities at these distant locations
throughout the multiverse. Then we can conceive of them splitting time so as to be seemingly in multiple universes
at one time. Then we can conceive of them being able to create multiples of themselves to be semi-omnipresent. To
date, that is about as far as I can see in that direction. Still, I suppose if you can see that far, you have pretty good
misthological vision. Not bad for a Terran. But I have had a lot of help from others, such as Patterson, who have
taken a good long look at the implications before me.
       We enjoy looking back at our children’s grade school art and placing it up on the refrigerator for all to see.
Imagine looking back from eternity future with your Heavenly Father and remarking, “Hey Dad, remember when I
made my first universe?” If those like Dankenbring and I can see that as a reasonable expectation, looking at it from
this side, how much more will we be able to see when looking out into the future from the other side. I’m sure our
Dad has some surprises in store.
       To use a different analogy, suppose there are a zillion universes presently in the multiverse. Eventually, the
infinite growth of humanity will run out of space in this finite number of universes. Creating additional universes
will be necessary. Rather than create them Himself, the Lord will probably allow His Bride to get in on the family
business and create these additional universes. Doing so could be, comparatively speaking, as easy as pressing the
button on a copier. The first universes She creates might be mere copies of some of the universes He originally
made. Then He might give her a template to work with where She makes modifications to some of His original
designs to make Her own designs. Eventually, She might get to the point where she makes Her own designs from
scratch. Some women like to make cakes from scratch. This Woman might want to make a universe from scratch.
As in baking, there will be perimeters to follow. Yet I am sure the Lord will delight in our reaching our full creativity,
even to the point of our making universes from scratch if that is our desire. Some women bake cakes for their
husbands. This Woman will be able to make universes for Her Husband. Her creativity will be practically limitless.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 336
                                                       Conclusion
       This concluding chapter has surveyed New Jerusalem from the vantage point of the concluding book of the
cannon—Revelation—wherein the City is revealed as the Bride of Christ. Three bridal models were evaluated. The
synecdochical Bride presents a partially clothed hybrid Bride and is a poorly contrived model. The misthological
mode presents a fully clothed, pure Bride and is a vastly superior model. The composite model combines these two
previous models and pictures of Christ’s body as one hideous body. Unfortunately, the later model is the preferred
model of some misthologists who insist on conflating soteriology and misthology regarding the Bride. Such
preference is inexcusable since the purely misthological model preserves both the soteriological distinction of
Christ’s body from His Bridal body and the purity of the Bride.
       After surveying typological connections between the Bride and City, an exegetical examination of some of
the most crucial parts of Revelation regarding the Bride and City was then undertaken. Illustrations from TOD were
used to review principal points from two primary passages from Revelation. Nonetheless, some tweaks were
introduced to advance beyond the original discussion in TOD. Principle improvements over TOD include: (1) the
juxtaposition of a Celestial Outer Darkness for those in celestial bodies as opposed to a Terrestrial Outer Darkness
for those in terrestrial bodies; (2) scriptural affirmation that Jesus in His glorified body can be in multiple places at
one time and thus as omnipresent as He wishes to be in the fullest sense of the word; (3) inferences that the Bride
can be semi-omnipresent; (4) the plausible inference that Jesus is a 7D being with a 6D Bride; (5) the speculation
that the Heavenly City might be found in 5D, 4D, and 3D spacetime continuums with hierarchical degrees of access,
spatiality, and temporality; (6) the pragmatic suggestion that the 3D City will be replicated; (7) a proposal as to why
the gates of the replicated Celestial City correspond to terrestrial access and direction; (8) the proposition that
faithful 3D smortals can become 4D immortals who assist in the commerce of the replicated 3D Cities and serve as
assistant rulers over other smortals; (9) the broadening of smortals to include select Jews during the tribulation;
(10) the postulation that the Bride will be able to create universes; (11) spatial and temporal visualizations for the
higher degree of dimensionality for the Lord and Bride; and (12) a hypothesis for why the Satanic rebellion at the
end of the millennium is allowed.

                                                     Primary
      Genesis 1, especially the opening two verses, is the primary text for the RET (or GAP theory). The following
quotation simply provides the text and breaks the passage up into its most obvious structure in terms of days.
             1
                In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. 2 But the Earth had become formless
      and void, and darkness was over the surface of the deep; and the Spirit of God was moving over the
      surface of the waters.
              3
                Then God said, Let there be light; and there was light. 4 And God saw that the light was good;
      and God separated the light from the darkness. 5 And God called the light day, and the darkness He
      called night. And there was evening and there was morning, one day.
              6
                 Then God said, Let there be an expanse in the midst of the waters, and let it separate the
      waters from the waters. 7 And God made the expanse, and separated the waters which were below the
      expanse from the waters which were above the expanse; and it was so. 8 And God called the expanse
      heaven. And there was evening and there was morning, a second day.
              9
                Then God said, Let the waters below the heavens be gathered into one place, and let the dry
      land appear; and it was so. 10 And God called the dry land earth, and the gathering of the waters He
      called seas; and God saw that it was good. 11 Then God said, Let the earth sprout vegetation, plants
      yielding seed, and fruit trees bearing fruit after their kind, with seed in them, on the earth; and it was
      so. 12 And the earth brought forth vegetation, plants yielding seed after their kind, and trees bearing
      fruit, with seed in them, after their kind; and God saw that it was good. 13 And there was evening
      and there was morning, a third day.
              14
                 Then God said, Let there be lights in the expanse of the heavens to separate the day from the
      night, and let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days and years; 15 and let them be for lights
      in the expanse of the heavens to give light on the earth; and it was so. 16 And God made the two great
      lights, the greater light to govern the day, and the lesser light to govern the night; He made the stars
      also. 17 And God placed them in the expanse of the heavens to give light on the earth, 18 and to govern
      the day and the night, and to separate the light from the darkness; and God saw that it was good. 19 And
      there was evening and there was morning, a fourth day.
              20
                 Then God said, Let the waters teem with swarms of living creatures, and let birds fly above
      the earth in the open expanse of the heavens. 21 And God created the great sea monsters, and every
      living creature that moves, with which the waters swarmed after their kind, and every winged bird
      after its kind; and God saw that it was good. 22 And God blessed them, saying, Be fruitful and
      multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let birds multiply on the earth. 23 And there was evening
      and there was morning, a fifth day.
              24
                 Then God said, Let the earth bring forth living creatures after their kind: cattle and creeping
      things and beasts of the earth after their kind; and it was so. 25 And God made the beasts of the earth
      after their kind, and the cattle after their kind, and everything that creeps on the ground after its
      kind; and God saw that it was good. 26 Then God said, Let Us make man in Our image, according to
      Our likeness; and let them rule over the fish of the sea and over the birds of the sky and over the cattle
      and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creeps on the earth. 27 And God created man
      in His own image, in the image of gods and goddesses He created him; male and female He created
      them. 28 And God blessed them; and God said to them, Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth, and
      subdue it; and rule over the fish of the sea and over the birds of the sky, and over every living thing
      that moves on the earth. 29 Then God said, Behold, I have given you every plant yielding seed that is
      on the surface of all the earth, and every tree which has fruit yielding seed; it shall be food for you; 30
      and to every beast of the earth and to every bird of the sky and to everything that moves on the earth
      which has life, I have given every green plant for food; and it was so. 31 And God saw all that He had
      made, and behold, it was very good. And there was evening and there was morning, the sixth day.
      (Gen 1:1-31, TM)

Creation is summarized in v. 1. Destruction is summarized in v. 2. Reformation is presented in vv. 3-31.

                                              Brief Notes on Primary
        The creation in Gen 1:1 may be either be understood absolutely as an independent clause or relatively as a
dependent clause. Hamilton gives an extended discussion and takes the absolute position: “In the beginning God
created the universe” (NICOT).425 Alternatively, as he notes, it could be translated as, “When God began to create,”
as it is in the TNK, to which he objects due to a supposed contradiction:

            The larger concern is this: Does Gen. 1:1 teach an absolute beginning of creation as a direct act
      of God? Or does it affirm the existence of matter before creation of the heavens and the earth? To put
      the question differently, does Gen. 1:1 suggest that in the beginning there was one—God; or does it
      suggest that in the beginning there were two—God and preexistent chaos? The latter approach
      separates itself from the former in that it dictates the existence of chaos prior to creation. But the
      concept of the creation of chaos would be a contradiction in terms.

Hamilton’s supposition of contradiction is only substantial upon the presupposition of pagan cosmologies. One
might pose, instead, that God created the multiverse with numerous universes and then subsequently created our
universe, with the biblical account limited in focus to our universe. All universes could be well-ordered at their
point of creation. God could simply speak them into existence, creating them via the power of His word (Heb 11:3)
without using pre-existing universes to create them. Though writing at a time before multiverse theory, Unger’s
statements are compatible with it, though taking a singular universe theory: “There are cogent reasons to believe a
relative rather than an absolute beginning is envision,” so the creation of the universe is certainly “presumed by
Genesis to be before [Gen] 1:1” (UCOT, emphasis his). He proceeds to explain why he believes that the creation
being described is a re-creation of the Earth, and the chaos is attributable to Lucifer’s rebellion. Chaos was not a
part of the original creation. The GAP is between the original creation of our universe in Jn 1:1 and the relative re-
creation/making of Earth in Gen 1:1ff. 426 In BKC, Ross concurs with Unger, preferring to put the GAP before v. 1
rather than before v. 2, though in his more thorough commentary he suggests additional relative positions.427 In an
425
    Commentators commonly assert that Gen 1:1 is talking about the creation of the universe. If one believes in the
multiverse, though, this universe could be a subset of that multiverse. V. 1 need not be taken as referring to the
creation of the multiverse, however. The 3D multiverse and (or just) the 4D heavenly dimension could have been
created earlier. Gaebelein (TAB) is correct to stress God’s independence from our universe: “The ancient heathen
nations considered God and the universe one and had absolutely no knowledge of the existence of God independent
of the universe.” Still, does the rejection of Pantheism mean that God existed nowhere before He made our universe
or the multiverse? Was God spaceless, existing in no place? V. 1 does not answer such questions. Yet it does make
God distinct from what He has created. Even if we pose that God existed someplace before He created anyplace,
this does not make Him a part of that someplace or that someplace part of Him.

    Unger makes the common RET claim that the original creation is seen in Job 38:7, where the “sinless bliss that

This RET perspective should be enjoined with the observation that a GAP occurs before Job 38:8-9. This darkness
should be associated with Gen 1:2 and judgment, not with the original creation.

versus Gerhard von Rad and Bruce Waltke are grammatically distinct, they nevertheless put the fall and judgment

article, Unger supplies this translation: “In the beginning God fashioned (or formed) the heavens and the earth. For
the earth was waste and void, with darkness upon the face of the deep and with the Spirit of God moving upon the

       Whereas Unger limits the creation/re-creation of Gen 1:1ff to Earth, Martins applies it to the whole universe,

or heavenly paradise or rather the Jerusalem Above and the angels must have been created” (emphasis his, 134). On

nor necessary from my perspective. If the Earth was one of the last things created from the white hole at the center
of our universe, then the angels could have been created millions of years earlier, even in the YEC model; plus, the
angels could have rejoiced at the founding of the Earth 6,000 years ago. Even in YEC, the Earth can be only 6,000
years old while the universe is billions of years old. That said, Martin’s use of this relative-dependent interpretation
to support GAP is within bounds, yet it does not prove his point.429 Even so, pertinent to our discussion of New

       In a book dedicated to the discussion of chaos, Snodderly provides an excellent extended history of
interpretation in which she surveys and interacts with various commentators (pp. 54-66, 126-167). She develops the
view by Unger in placing a creation before Gen 1:1 (p. 65) for “a judged earth that is about to be recreated” (p. 97,
cp. 134). Beth Snodderly, Chaos Is Not God’s Will: The Origin of International Development (Pasadena, CA:
William Carey International University Press, 2014).
428
    M. F. Unger, “Rethinking the Genesis Account of Creation,” BibSac 115 (1958): 28. In Snodderly’s extended
analysis of Waltke, she finds him “inconsistent and academic” (p. 140). The hendiadys term, formless and void,
refers to something chaotic, out of order, as a result of judgment (p. 159). Snodderly poses a literary duality for
Gen 1:1 (p. 83); whereas, I pose a logical duality made grammatically possible through ambiguity. After all,
she acknowledges that since Gen 1:1 does not use an article, “the text may be intentionally ambiguous,” and
translates Gen 1:1 as, “In one of God’s new beginnings” (p. 63), “interpreting this ‘beginning’ as one among many
new beginnings” (p. 61), which would be quite compatible with my multiverse hypothesis. This verse may be
describing the creation of our universe as only one of an infinite number of universes that God creates in the
process of His time that proceeds outside of our time.

    Kidner: “Grammatically, this phrase could be translated as introducing a clause completed in verse 3 after a

    Martins makes repeated appeals to Ecc 3:11 and would probably say that the universe was created mature,
perfect, and complete. So, from his vantage point, his argument is forceful. Bryan argues similarly that a perfect
God could not make an imperfect universe that would need time to create. Betty Sue Bryan, Science and Truth by
L. Allen Higley, revised and edited by Betty Sue Bryan (n. p., 2001), 13-15. Part of her argument is dependent upon
her denial that sequence, time, or anything else existed in eternity other than God (p. 16). Such arguments are not
persuasive since the Bible indicates a sequence in the created order of our universe in Job 38:7, as she herself
acknowledges: “The angels were present when the earth was created; hence they were created before earth….the
earth was created later than the heavens” (pp. 30-31). Plus, I believe that time and space exist in eternity. I do not
believe that God exists in a timeless, spaceless eternity. See Excursus on God’s Spacetime, 365. Contrary to Bryan,
I perceive Gen 1:1 merely to be the beginning of our time or at most the beginning of created time, not the beginning
of time itself. She argues that God did not create darkness because He “is all light,” in whom is no darkness, and
“He could not create something at variance with His own attributes” (p. 25). If that is the case, then since God
created time, time cannot be at variance with His attributes. If so, uncreated time had to exist before created
time. If God can take time to make man, then God can take time to create man. One reason He did so was to
maximize His glory so that the angels could render praise as they saw Him lay the foundations of the Earth and then
create animals and humanoid life.
        The humanoid life which God had created on other planets before this time were prototypes for the humanoid
and eventual human life that He would create on Earth. This planet was to be His crowning achievement, finally
emerging from the center of the Big Bang. If one wants to picture an initial chaos or pre-creational chaos being
descriptive as what creation using a Big Bang would look like, I suggest that it be enjoined with YEC time dilation
and GAP either before Gen 1:1 or Gen 2:2. In other words, a dual chaos rather than a singular chaos might
explain why so many experts are having trouble with the chaos of Gen 1:2. Perhaps the ambiguity of the text
is intentional so that multiple perspectives have to be considered, including a dualistic perspective. Logically, I hold
a dual perspective. Exegetically, a dual perspective is plausible given the very attractive nature of competing
interpretations, some of which are mistakenly believed to be mutually exclusive. Duality encompasses them as
inclusive. In short, God spoke. The Big Bang for our universe occurred. The outer galaxies were formed out of the
chaos. Angels were created and given positions of authority on planets in these outer realms. When Earth finally
emerged from the white hole at the center of the Big Bang, God likewise formed Earth out of the chaos and
created life on it. The angels rejoiced over it. Lucifer was given charge of it. Lucifer rebelled. The Earth was thrown
back into a state of chaos. In this way, one can dualistically have one’s hermeneutical cake and eat it too, instead
of presuming chaos singularity.
        Snodderly speculates that, just as pre-incarnated Lord Jesus incarnated Himself to become human, as the pre-
existent Lord He may have taken an angelic form as the Angel of the Lord and showed His angelic friends how He
could create order in our universe, which at that point was the unformed chaos the Father had created out of nothing.
“Perhaps God deliberately chose not to use his omniscience and omnipotence to create all life form instantly, but
instead shared creation with beings who were learning as they went along” (p. 38). Such a postulation is superior
to the assumptions by Martins and Bryan of instant perfection. Snodderly poses that God placed Earth under
Lucifer’s control but told him of His plan to create humans who would have to choose of their own free will to
obey. Lucifer rebelled, resulting in a war in Heaven. “Lucifer, now Satan, the dragon, must have determined to
wreak havoc on the earth to make it unsuitable for the humans God had in mind to create” (p. 41). I would interject
