       As to our universe and planet, each of the six days of restoration begins with then God said and ends with
there was evening and there was morning. On the first day, the pre-existing sunlight is called forth in Gen 1:3 to
break through the primeval darkness surrounding Earth and shine on its surface. The light is called good; the
darkness is not. Calling the light good can be taken as calling its dark antithesis evil in this context.431 This darkness
was an expression of God’s judgment in Gen 1:2.432 The Earth was already in orbit around the Sun, which was part
of the solar system and the galaxies created in Gen 1:1. On Day 1, relative to the restoration of the Earth, God said,
“Let there be light,” that is, let this light of the sun break through the shroud of darkness in which God had
enshrouded the Earth. Subsequently, on Day 4, again relative to the restoration of the Earth, God said, “Let there
be lights,” that is, let these lights break through the now-clearing atmosphere of Earth with sufficient clarity to be
discernable and fully perform their God-given function pertaining to the vantage point of Earth’s surface.433
       Special attention has been called throughout the passage to the phrase after their kind in deference to Martins’
RET argument that this phrase refers to “restorative reproduction” (emphasis his, 156, cp. 173-180, 180-185). The
plants and animals are to reproduce the same original kind of pre-Adamic life that existed before the GAP.434 He

that if God had created humanoids as prototypes of the humans He would eventually make, then Lucifer
would have destroyed the humanoids. Since their destruction would proceed the destruction of Planet Rahab,
the lack of pre-Adamic humanoid fossils would not be surprising. In any case, Snodderly poses that “Satan and
his minions frequently killed off their own creatures through evolutionary process. Dinosaurs and other predators
made the environment ‘red in tooth and claw,’ and uninhabitable by humans” (p. 45). Evolution was Satan’s
invention, used to pervert God’s creation with adaptations to the created forms that the Lord had shown the
angels how He made them. Snodderly further poses that “pre-humans, such as Neanderthals…were a caricature
of the humanity God desired to create” (p. 46). If this is the case, then these pre-humans were not created by
God in His image, but by Satan in his image: “In using the evolutionary process, Satan must have decided to
fashion beings that would submit to his rules” (p. 45). “This evolutionary battlefield is apparently the context in
which humans were brought into being.” Humans, in contrast, were created by God in His image “so that they might
gradually vanquish this chaos” (p. 46). If these and all other pre-Adamic humanoids were created by Satan, then
they could have built the cities, which greatly weakens my argument for humanoids on other planets. However, the
postulation that all such humanoids were created by Satan seems highly improbable, thus making the existence of
humanoids created by God on other planets likely.
431
    Bryan (p. 61) thinks that in the eternal state all darkness is evil and will be done away with, “leaving no natural
light at all” (Rev 21:23-25; 22:5). Contrariwise, the fact that the City has no need of the sun and does not experience
darkness does not prove that the sun does not exist or that the Earth does not experience night. The fact that the
Tree of Life bears different leaves monthly suggests that the solar system continues to function with days and nights
(Rev 22:2). Similarly, her contention that the light of Day 1 was not natural light is not persuasive. Even she
acknowledges that the darkness of Gen 1:2 “was due to an atmospheric condition which prevented the sunlight from
reaching the surface of the earth…The darkness must have been due to a dense fog over all the earth” (p. 75).

    God creates darkness and evil in Is 45:17. As Gaebelein notes, it “does not mean moral evil. It means the punitive

    Martins has a good discussion of Day 4 and points out that Hebrew is an aspectual language rather than a tense

    Martins is advancing the argument by Bryan for after their kind. Bryan reasonably points out the expression is
not limited to reproductive kind but includes created pre-existing kind: “They were created ‘after their kind,’ yet
not commanded to reproduce after their kind” (p. 51). The passage deals with being created after their kind, not
reproducing after their kind. The bodies of creatures were made (brought forth) from the water and land of the Earth,
but their souls were created out of nothing by God (pp. 99-101, 106). Likewise, God made man’s body out of the
earth, but breathed/created his spirit (p. 108). The plants and animals were of the same kind that pre-existed before
the restoration week. This is not the case for man, however, as he was a “new order of being” created to replace
Lucifer as the ruler of Earth (p. 52). I would pose instead that man was a higher order of being than pre-Adamic

then appeals to Prov 8:22-31 to assert that v. 31 is referring to pre-Adamic men, where Wisdom is personified as

be describing the original creation, Martins’ interpretation is attractive. Even so, it is problematic. Paul says that

since those earlier men fell, what do we propose concerning their redemption?
       Martins does not address these weaknesses in his position. However, he notes that whereas “God restores
new life forms ‘after their original kind,” He instead “restores man ‘after the image and likeness of God’” (emphasis
his, 210). Therefore, the Adam and Eve created on Day 6 were not restored after their original kind. Instead,
they were created in the image of God, thus suggesting that the pre-Adamites of Prov 8:31 were not created
in the image of God, though they are sons of man (Heb. adam). Even Martins’ initial discussion provides an
implicit solution, where he said that reproduction after own’s kind means one’s similar kind (p. 156). If we take
this to mean that Adam and Eve were similar rather than identical to their previous kind, then we can posit that
replenish in Gen 1:28 contextually means to replenish with a similar kind, not an identical kind. The context
highlights the dissimilarity by not including the after their kind for Adam and Eve and, instead, noting that they
were created in the image of God. Prov 8:31 simply does not go into that degree of specificity. The pre-Adamites
were similar enough to Adam and Eve to be called sons of man (Heb. adam), thus people/human (Gr. anthropos)
but dissimilar enough to be distinguished, both implicitly and explicitly, in the more detailed account of Gen 1:24-

A weakness with my proposition, as Bryan points out, is the practical absence of such humanoid fossils (pp. 44-
46), especially in the deeper fossilized layers. If there were that many pre-Adamic humanoids, where are their
fossils? Although she is using this argument to deny that the Noahic flood was the chief source of fossilization, it
also applies to the presupposition of humanoids. A Luciferian flood and fossilization would have been expected to
fossilize millions of pre-Adamic humanoids—if they existed and if animal fossilization is primarily attributable to
the Luciferian flood. Pember recognizes this problem yet says that it “is no real obstacle” to the pre-Adamite
position (p. 59) since he poses a variety of explanations, such as suggesting that the pre-Adamites were killed in a
manner described by Zech 14:12. Indeed, both physical and literary evidence suggest this to be the case, leading
many to believe that a nuclear war wiped out humanoid life on this planet in the pre-Adamic past in the war of the
gods. The humanoids could have been destroyed by war and had sufficient time to deteriorate before the flood hit.
If the Earth was a tropical paradise and had a micro-content conducive to rapid de-skeletonization for natural deaths
(or even sin-imposed deaths), a few years might have passed between their death/murder by Lucifer and the impact
of the waters from the subsequently exploded Planet Rahab. Lucifer could have destroyed them. Alternatively,
Pember believes they followed Lucifer in rebellion and suggests that they were killed in like fashion by fire from
God (Eze 28:18, Mal 4:3) or that God simply opened the earth to swallow them (cp. Num 16:30). A combination
of such factors is plausible. If some of the pre-Adamites followed God and some followed Lucifer, which seems
likely, they would have been wiped out in mutual destruction in a civil war between the gods.
     Otherwise, if one rejects the pre-Adamite hypothesis, then one is left with Bryan’s belief that Neanderthal and
Cro-Magnon men “were completely human” (p. 110), thus not pre-Adamites. She rejects the proposition that
replenish means to repeople (Gen 1:28), posing instead that the command is to refill the planet with rulers to replace
Lucifer and his fallen angels as the planetary rulers.

suspended with Earth because Earth is the headquarters of Lucifer’s dominion, the capital planet of the
fallen forces. The war-zone nature of our solar system presently prohibits intergalactic contact, much less
intergalactic trade with Earth. Even fallen forces are currently restrained from fully revealing themselves,
though soon they will be forced to do so (Rev 12:9). For now, the rules of engagement presently prohibit
disclosure, which answers the astrotheological question posed by the Fermi Paradox, “Where is everybody?”
The aliens are presently not making contact publicly because doing so would be deadly. Any aliens making
contact now do so covertly. Doing otherwise would be like sticking your head up out of a fox hole or trench
in no man’s land only to have it shot off. Occasionally, some stick their heads up, but not for long.

            Excursus on Bride: All Saints or Some Saints?
1) Arguments that Bride is composed of only overcomers and counters
   a) The Bride clothes herself in white garments (righteous works)—Rev 19:7-8.
      i) Pro: These white garments are only worn by overcomers—Rev 3:5,18-21; 16:15 (cp. Is 61:10; Eze
           44:17; Mt 25:9-10).
      ii) Con: the prepared part of the Bride is clothed and is a synecdoche (His Bride = all the saints).
           (1) Pro: synecdoche is useful but abused, used wrongly to prove limited atonement and Lordship
               salvation.
           (2) Pro: both sides acknowledge: the saints ≠ all saints (Mt 13:3; 1Cor 4:5; 6:2; Rev 2:20; 11:18).
           (3) Pro: the proper synecdoche in Rev 19:8 is likewise: the saints ≠ all the saints.
   b) Pro: The Bride is associated intimately with the city—Rev 21:2,9-10. Only overcomers are associated
      intimately with the City—Rev 3:12 (cp. outer darkness Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30).
   c) Pro: The Bride is not excluded from the marriage feast (whereas some believers are, Mt 22:13).
      Misthopology (reward city) argues for bridal misthology.
   d) Pro: The duality argued for the Bride is common in Scripture for other dualities and strata.
   e) Pro: The Bride is ready. Foolish believers are not ready (Mt 25:10).
   f) Pro: Our bodies must be misthologically glorified to inherit the kingdom (1Cor 15:42-44,56; 2Pet 1:4).
   g) Pro: Cultural background argues for misthology:
      i) Pro: The ketubah (betrothal contract) goes back to the OT (Ex 19:8; Jer 31:32; Rev 3:20).
      ii) Pro: The chuppah (wedding canopy) covers Mount Zion, not the whole Earth (Is 4:5; 65:1,13-25).
      iii) Pro: Paul fears that some of the body may not qualify for the bridal consummation (2Cor 11:2-3; cp.
           1Jn 2:28).
2) Arguments that the Bride is composed of all believers and counters
   a) The entire church is sanctified positionally—Eph 5:25-27.
      i) Pro: Other passages collaborate the positional sanctification: 1Cor 6:11; Eph 1:4; 2Thess 2:13;
           1Pet 1:2.
      ii) Con: A number of these passages are better taken as progressive sanctification: Eph 1:4; 2Thess 2:13;
           1Pet 1:2.
      iii) Con: the sanctification in Eph 5:26 is probably progressive as well (initiated and pictured by water
           baptism)
   b) The entire church will be presented as blameless soteriologically—Eph 5:25-27.
      i) Pro: Since the future presentation is based on positional sanctification, it is soteriological.
      ii) Con: Since the sanctification is more likely progressive, the future presentation is more likely
           misthological.
      iii) Con: In Col 1:18-23, Paul again speaks in terms of Christ being the head of His body (Col 1:18), but
           the presentation is misthological (Col 1:22-23).
      iv) Con: Similarly, the future presentation is misthological (Phil 1:10; 2:14-16; 1Thess 3:12-13; 5:9-10,23;
           2Thess 2:13; 2Pet 3:14).
   c) The entire church is body and Bride of Christ—1Cor 12:13.
      i) Pro: The church is one body (Eph 4:4)
      ii) Con: In Col 2:19, Paul uses the imagery of believers forming the joints and ligaments of Christ’s body.
           Paul is also thinking in terms of this same imagery in Ephesians (1:23; 2:16; 4:4,12,16; 5:30 MT) as is
           demonstrated by his reference to believers being the ligaments of Christ’s body (4:16). Howbeit, when
           Paul reaches Eph 5:22-33, he adds an additional dimension to the manner in which we are Christ’s
           body. One cannot marry one’s own body. One cannot marry one’s hand or eye. There must be another
           dimension to Paul’s thought.
           (1) Con: One does not marry one’s own body but is one body with the body one marries (1Cor 6:15-
               16).
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                Page 346
           (2) Con: One marries a subset taken out of one’s body that becomes one’s marital body (Adam and
               Eve).
           (3) Con: The Bride is taken from her family (Rebekah and Isaac).
           (4) Con: Bridal body is a subset of His federal body (cp. heirs/co-heirs; children/sons; resurrection/out-
               resurrection; kingdom/kinship, etc.).
   d) The body has one organic head—Christ—and is thus one organic body (Eph 5:23)
      i) Pro: Unity is apparent in the OT conceptual parallel of God taking all Israel as His wife.
      ii) Con: In Eph 5:23 itself, the husband has his own organic head and yet is the federal head of the wife.
      iii) Con: In the OT, God divorces Israel and remarries the remnant. Likewise, Christ divorces the unfaithful
           betrothed and consummates with the faithful remnant.
      iv) Con: Unity with division in seen in the singular tabernacle having an inner and outer court (Heb 9:1-7)
                  Excursus on the Rebellion of the Nations
       Some interpret Ps 2:1-8 as dealing with the rebellion of the nations that culminates at the end of the
tribulation. While it probably is foreshadowed by that rebellion, the ultimate culmination of this rebellion will take
place at the end of the millennium. Concerning the crucifixion, Paul says, “We speak God’s wisdom in a mystery,
the hidden wisdom, which God predestined before the ages to our glory; the wisdom which none of the rulers of
this age has understood; for if they had understood it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory” (1Cor 2:7-
8). Barrett notes some differences of opinion as to the identity of the rulers:

      In the exposition so far the rulers have been taken to be the supernatural forces who control events in
      this age (until their overthrow by Jesus Christ). Some (e.g. Lightfoot) suppose that they are the earthly
      rulers (such as Pontius Pilate the procurator, and Caiaphas the high priest; cf. Baruch 3:16) who were
      responsible for the crucifixion. This view is possible in verse 8 but much less likely in verse 6. (BNTC)

       Actually, the opposite is more likely. While human rulers are certainly included in 1Cor 2:6 and 2:8, neither
verse is limited to human rulers. Certainly, Satan was behind the crucifixion and thus entered Judas to betray Jesus
(Lk 22:3; Jn 13:2,27). Yet, just as clearly, Satan did not understand the full scope of the plan and was probably of
a divided mind as to how to deal with the crucifixion. On the one hand, he was seeking to have Jesus killed via
crucifixion.439 On the other hand, Satan knew that Jesus had told His disciples that He was going to give His life as
a ransom for many, be crucified, and rise again (Mk 9:31-32; 10:45). But the disciples did not understand these
statements. Neither did Satan. Nevertheless, to hedge his bets, he sought to have Jesus take some other course of
action rather than go through with the crucifixion (Mk 8:31-33).
       As noted in my NBSW regarding the gospel, Augustine exhorted: “Believe so that you may understand.”
Following the same perspective, Anselm said, “I believe so that I may understand.” They made this rationalization
in order to express the relationship between faith and reason. In discussing this Augustine-Anselm perspective,
Clark explains: “In temporal sequence, faith...precedes full understanding, for one first accepts basic Christian truth
on divine authority. At the same time, in order to exercise faith, a person must understand the words that minimally
explain the gospel.”440 In other words, the sequence is: (1) minimal understanding of the saving-gospel message
(that promises eternal life to those who believe in Christ) followed by (2) saving faith (in Christ for eternal life)
allows (3) one to proceed to a full understanding of the Christian message. Faith comes first—in the latter case.
Entrance into a fuller kingdom perspective requires that one first believes the basic kingdom message.
       Accordingly, we may likewise infer that because the disciples did not believe that the Messiah would be
crucified, they did not understand Jesus’s plain statements to that effect. Likewise, because Satan did not believe
God, he was not fully able to grasp the full plan. A judicial hardening from God prevents one from accepting the
full scope of God’s statements as true when the more basic components of those statements are rejected as being
true. Satan believes that he can win in a rebellion against God because Satan is blinded by his own unbelief.441 Just
as Satan can blind the minds of the unbelieving (2Cor 4:2), so Satan’s own unbelief can be used judicially by God
to blind him. Satan reaps what he sows: He sows deception; he will be deceived. In fact, Satan has probably already
indicated just what course of action he will try to undertake in the final rebellion. In the movie Independence Day,
the impenetrable force fields of the enemy ships are taken down by a computer virus taken aboard the mothership
by a ship posing as an enemy ship. Likewise, in the Star Wars movies, the necessity of taking down the Death Star’s
shield is a common theme. Satan probably believes that he can take down Heavenly Jerusalem’s shield through

439
    Brook poses otherwise and thinks Satan was seeking to have Jesus killed by means of flogging in order to
circumvent fulfilling prophecy by having Jesus die on a cross. Linda Rios Brook, The Redeemer: Book Four of The
Reluctant Demon Diaries, Kindel Edition (Lake Mary, FL: Charisma House Book Group, 2011), 241-260.

    David K. Clark, To Know and Love God, 36.

    As Garcia points out, Satan and his forces thought that they could win the initial war, even though they only had
1/3 of the angelic forces, because they thought “it would just be a matter of choosing the right moment for launching
a surprise attack” and “catch the Most High off guard” (World, 86). Of course, such clandestine attacks by smaller
forces are often successful in military operations. By allowing Satan and his forces to make secret pacts and covertly
prepare, God allowed them to think that they would be able to catch Him off guard. Doing so would test the angels
to demonstrate where their individual allegiances lie.

some such means. The Heavenly City will certainly be accessible through various means, such as portals and
spaceships. If Satan could smuggle a zero-point energy bomb inside the City, then in theory, he could destroy the
City. Perhaps God will give him just enough sporting chance to make him think that he can pull it off. The force
shield is impregnable from the outside but probably not from the inside.
                       Excursus on Miscellaneous Writers
                                                 Introduction
      Additional material that I have consulted during this research that is not included in the main body of this
discussion will be briefly mentioned here.
                                                 Joseph Chambers
      Joseph Chambers has a very brief commentary on Revelation. He properly cites Ps 45:1-6 as dealing
misthologically with the Bride (p. 251). Yet he mistakenly believes that all believers will overcome. His Lordship
Salvation premise (p. 82) results in him inconsistently saying that the City is both a gift and a reward.442 His
Chapter 21, A City too Priceless to Value, is the most pertinent part of his book for the present discussion.
      A search on his website (www.pawcreek.org) for New Jerusalem brings up 552 articles. The first article is
basically a recap of the same material from Chapter 21 with the same inconsistencies. He claims, “This city is the
Son’s gift to His Bride.”443 He then proceeds to refute himself:

             We must understand that this city is the eternal reward of the Bride, but there is a world
      outside of this city where the saved that did not receive the reward of Brideship will live. Apostle
      Paul tried to excite us to so follow Christ that we would inherit the highest honors. He stated, “And be
      found in him, not having mine own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through the
      faith of Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith: That I may know him, and the power of his
      resurrection, and the fellowship of his sufferings, being made conformable unto his death; If by any
      means I might attain unto the resurrection of the dead.” (Philippians 3:9-11). He also spoke of being
      “saved by fire” but losing your reward. “If any man’s work abide which he hath built thereupon, he
      shall receive a reward. If any man’s work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be
      saved; yet so as by fire.” (I Corinthians 3:14-15). These great Scriptures in the Word of God make it
      absolute that the New World will be filled with the saved that failed to inherit a full reward [cp. 2Jn
      1:8]. There are no sinners that share the New World, only saints that missed the highest prize.
      This should awake the multitude that lives right and overcomes sin, but are too busy to be soul-winners
      and burden bearers in the kingdom of God.

If he were consistent, he should have concluded that the City is not a gift but a reward limited to those believers
who inherit it as their “full reward,” making 2Jn 1:8 a misthopological text. Then he should have concluded that
those believers who fail to qualify for living in the Reward City, and who thus must live on the New World instead,
do so because they are only saved by fire, making this their Terrestrial Outer Darkness.
       Subsequent articles vary in strength and consistency. For instance, he correctly states:

              The Bride of Christ will live in this city with the Bridegroom, Jesus Christ. The highest order
      of reward which a saint of God can receive is the Brideship of Christ and only a small portion of the
      Lord’s church will obtain this honor. We are saved by grace and that grace earned for us a right to
      eternal life. But rewards are not given on the merit of grace but by our devotion and surrender to a life
      of abandonment to Christ. Every expression of our rewards must be earned by every soul. (Emphasis
      his.)444

Even more astutely, he correctly observes that dwelling with the Lord forever in His house in Ps 23:6 is a reward
referring to living in New Jerusalem. He proceeds to state that the promise in Rev 3:10-13 is to the Bride.
Accordingly, his own assessment should have led him to conclude that not all believers overcome:

                         1. The promise is limited to overcomers.

      His inconsistencies are not limited to the highest tier but, by logical extension of his Lordship Salvation (LS)
premise, extend to the lowest tier of believers. In the next article, he rightly juxtaposes the possibility of living in
New Jerusalem as the highest area of reward versus outside it in the suburbs as the lowest area of reward:

      Every Blood washed saint living true to our Lord will spend eternity in the New Heaven and The New
      Earth. “And the nations of them which are saved shall walk in the light of it: and the kings of the earth
      do bring their glory and honour into it.” (Revelation 21:24) This is the least reward every saint will
      inherit. But the Highest reward will be to have a mansion in the city of “New Jerusalem”.445

He is on the right track but gives the false impression, through his LS, that being in the New Heaven and New Earth
is a reward. No, it is a gift. The least rewarded saint will live somewhere in Heaven as a gift, not as a reward. Being
saved by fire so as to be allowed to remain in the kingdom is a gift, not a reward. Being allowed to stay in the
kingdom, even though one has lost all rewards that would qualify one to inherit the kingdom or dwell in the
Heavenly City, is a gift. Those least in the kingdom (Mt 5:1) are at least in the kingdom—as a gift, not as a reward.
This clarification needs to be added to offset his LS premise.
                                                      Moses Paul
       The description of the two books by Moses Paul in his Eternity Series was promising. The positive
contributions made by the first book, Eternity in the Making, are offset by the negative aspects.446 Paul correctly
perceives that the rich entrance into the kingdom in 2Pet 1:10-11 is a reward limited to faithful believers and that
most believers will fail to achieve this entrance. Indeed, citing 1Jn 2:28, he deduces that “most Christians will spend
the first season in heaven just crying in terrible shame.” Unfortunately, he immediately appeals to Rev 21:4 to
conclude that God will wipe away their tears and “they will be full of joy and peace forever in heaven but will never
forget their first day” (p. 6). Such misthologists think that the shame and sorrow experienced by the unfaithful at
the Bema may last up to a thousand years, but God eventually wipes away their sorrow, at least by the end of the
millennium. More astute misthologists recognize that wiping away tears is a litotes limited to faithful believers.
       Like many misthologists, Paul thinks that faithful believers will shine brightly in Heaven while unfaithful
believers will be very dim in comparison (p. 8). Indeed, I used to hold much the same position. However, in my
RBVGB, I concluded that only faithful believers have glorified bodies that shine in various degrees. Unfaithful
believers will have redeemed bodies that fail to shine. This difference aside, I was pleased that Paul immediately
went on to add: “Some believers will end up spending eternity in ‘outer darkness’ if they keep resisting the will
of God!” (p. 8).
       He correctly perceives differences of rank will exist in Heaven but wrongly thinks that God may have to
discipline believers who are “on the verge of crossing to damnation” so that in the end, they at least “made it to
heaven” in last place (p. 14). Even though some FG securitists hold this position and think that God must discipline
believers to keep them saved, I maintain a stronger form of eternal security, which argues that such discipline is not
necessary to keep them saved. See my 3DUS. For example, believers are saved from Hell even if they commit
apostasy.
       Paul’s Chapter 3 Can We Sin in Heaven? provides an alternative to my model. He thinks that believers can
sin in heaven because they have free choice, but “God can only let people into heaven who he knows will never
choose to sin forever.” In other words, believers within Heaven can sin, but they will not sin because they will
choose not to sin. He argues that God “cannot sin because he has chosen never to” (p. 20). Apparently, according
to his model, since God has free will, He must have made the freewill decision never to sin. Consequently, God
does not sin temporally because of His freewill discission in eternity not to sin. Therefore, God cannot sin—now.
In contradistinction, I pose that God cannot sin because doing so would be a violation of His very nature. God was
never free to sin. Free will does not require the option to sin for those who have a nature that prevents them from

445
    “Living in New Jerusalem or Living in the Suburbs.” Available at http://www.pawcreek.org/living-in-new-
jerusalem-or-living-in-the-suburbs. Accessed 4/24/2021.
446
    Moses Paul, Eternity in the Making: Eternity Series Book 1, 2nd ed. (n.p., 2020).
Excursus on Miscellaneous Writers                                                                             Page 351
sinning. Since I have argued that point in my writings, I will not belabor it here. Suffice it to say that I concur with
Paul when he says, “Of course our bodies and souls are transformed in the resurrection but I do not think that our
spirits will be. Our spirits are already sinless, (1 John 3:9) recreated (2 Cor 5:17) but in need of growth” (p. 25).
From my perspective, when our sinless spirits are clothed with resurrected sinless bodies, we will be incapable of
sin, just as our spirits are presently incapable of sin: “Whoever has been born of God does not sin, for His seed
remains in him; and he cannot sin, because he has been born of God” (1Jn 3:9). Our regenerate spirit cannot sin
because it has been born of God and thus shares His nature. Paul was correct to argue that God gave “us something
which he has not got.” But he is wrong to think “God could have sinned many times in history” (p. 20). No. God
does not sin because He does not have the ability to do so, not because He has a nature that allows Him to sin but
chose to suppress that part of His nature by choosing not to do so. Paul’s convoluted model requires him to pose
that God can only let believers into Heaven whom He knows “will never go back to sin despite the freedom they
have in heaven to do so” (p. 24). Therefore, since we can sin in Heaven, God had “to set it up so that we never
will…God can only give what He knows we can certainly handle without compromising for a moment throughout
eternity!” (p. 27). Such arguments are a form of soft discipline-oriented security (SDOS), which I rejected in 3DUS
in favor of strong security. As noted therein:

            In contrast to those soft securitists (SDOS) who think that God’s discipline is necessary to
      prevent them from losing regeneration, strong securitists can acknowledge the realistic possibility of
      apostasy without having to commit intellectual suicide in thinking that the eternal life within them
      could die theoretically. Because securitists have eternal life and believingly know that they have it,
      they can know that they will keep this regenerate life regardless of whether they continue to believe.
      Yes, God has assumed exclusive responsibility for their safety. Yet He has not conditioned that security
      in any shape, form, or degree upon their preservation in the faith—not even upon a God-protected
      preservation in the faith in which they are completely passive.

       In his section, The Naked Bride! (pp. 62-65), Paul makes an argument similar to what I have made.
Namely, since unfaithful believers will be misthologically naked, they cannot be a part of the Bride of Christ.
The prize of marrying Christ is limited to faithful believers. Unfaithful believers will not have wedding
clothes and, as a result, be cast into the outer darkness and weep and gnash their teeth (Mt 22:2-14). I fully
concur with that aspect of his assessment. Moreover, in his next section, Weeping and Gashing of Teeth, he correctly
perceives that the expression is used soteriologically of unbelievers cast into Hell (Mt 13:41-44,13:5) and
misthologically of believers cast into the outer darkness. Though he mistakenly thinks that the latter will have their
tears wiped away, he perceptively poses:

             Why did the LORD use the same expression, weeping and gnashing of teeth? Was he
      deliberately trying to confuse us? YES! Let’s see another example of this. Jesus standing in the
      temple which all Jews marveled at, when asked to do a miraculous sign, He answered “Destroy this
      temple and I will raise it again in three days”. The ‘obvious’ interpretation of his statement was that
      he was talking about the Jerusalem stone temple in which they were all standing, not his body. He also
      purposely hid the truth when he preached in parables. In the same way there are a multitude of treasures
      of wisdom and knowledge which the LORD has deliberately buried in the scriptures. They can only
      be found with the help of the Holy Spirit as we dig. Our intellect is not enough. Neither are the laws
      of hermeneutics [how to interpret scripture] sufficient. This is so we have to rely on the LORD who
      alone is our teacher. (Insert his, 67)

Likewise, in his section, Foolish Virgins (Mt 25:1-13), he correctly deduces that they will be in Heaven but forever
miss out on being the Bride of Christ. He wisely notes the parallel between the wedding song in Ps 45:13-14 and
Queen Ester (Esther 9:29; cp. Neh 2:6). He makes the same suggestion that I did in MMP1 that faithful believers
will have a greater heavenly I.Q.

            Of course, everyone will receive new and greater wisdom und understanding in heaven.
      However, I wonder if people will grow in their understanding in heaven at different speeds, just like
      they do on earth according to how clever they are, their I.Q / intelligence level. Perhaps to the degree
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 352
      we develop our spiritual wisdom here, will determine the measure of our heavenly I.Q. and hence
      the speed at which our revelation of God will grow forever. If so, those who are wise now will quickly
      overtake the wisdom of the angels in heaven even though they have been around for thousands of years
      and reach spiritual post graduation while the foolish virgins in heaven are still struggling with first
      standard!447 (P. 73)
       In my addendum, A Matter of Necessity in 3DUS, I argued that the Lord’s self-sufficiency does not rule out
His needs for us to be His Bride and to reciprocate His loving intimacy in a manner analogous to Adam needing
Eve so that he would not be alone but have matrimonial intimacy. In his section, Intimacy with Jesus, Paul makes
a similar deduction and expresses it with a heart-touching analogy:

              More than our desire to meet with God, he wants to meet with us. God is looking for a
      companion for His Son, to marry - will you accept His proposal? Does God primarily want servants
      or friends? If He just wants to get the job done, He could use His angels or just speak the word. Why
      does He take all the trouble and patiently wait for us to co-operate? Because He is a person, with
      needs. He is all-sufficient, but in love, chooses to have a place in His heart for you. If this is not
      met, it makes God, in that area of his heart, feel like a child standing all alone lunch time without
      any friends! Worship changes His feelings, touches His heart. Share everything with Him - He is
      really interested. But doesn’t He know everything already? I was once helping to run a Sunday school.
      One of my friend’s eight-year-old son was in my class. Though I knew his family news through his
      dad, it was a delight when he ran in, jumped on my lap and excitedly shared what was going on before
      the class. I was his ‘mate’ - I enjoyed hearing it all again from this little fellow! (P. 85).

        In his section, The New Jerusalem and following, Paul correctly reasons that the City is the Bride and thus
limited to overcomers and thus composed of the faithful but disappointingly infers that this means that the City “is
not to be taken literally, but symbolically” (p. 88). However, this misthological disappointment is linked to his
soteriologically disappointing statements in his chapters on Hell. He adopts the LS fallacy that 1 John was written
to give “tests to see if we are really saved” (p. 106). No. They are tests of fellowship, not relationship. He implies
that believers who commit suicide go to Hell (p. 107). No. He should have concluded that, at most, they would go
to the outer darkness. He thinks that hating someone can disqualify you for eternal life (p. 114). Supposedly,
Eze 18:20-24 shows that if someone becomes bitter because his wife dies and turns to pornography, “he will be sent
to hell!” (p. 133) For “the people the LORD wants to live with forever are those who still obey even when all hell
is let loose” (p. 134). Aside from all my arguments for unconditional security elsewhere in my writings, note his
inconsistency. He has failed to observe that, per his own analysis, believers with the moral failures he has described
would be best seen as being cast into the outer darkness rather than into Hell. Moral failures to persevere in either
faith or faithfulness, or both, would disqualify believers from New Jerusalem, not from Heaven. Indeed, the account
which he shares to conclude his book should have led him to this conclusion:

             Praveen got saved and started coming regularly to a church where I was helping. After one year
      he was pulled back into his old worldly lifestyle and left the church and prayer. One year later his
      family was in a desperate state. His younger sister Chaitra had been attacked by an evil spirit for years.
      She was very ill, full of rage and her situation was growing critical. She had gone to many temples for
      deliverance but found none. Finally, her dad said that he could no longer stand her angry manifestation
      and was going to commit suicide. This enraged Praveen who immediately demanded that the evil spirit
      leave his sister and enter him. To his amazement the evil spirit answered him speaking through his
      sister “I can’t! You have left Jesus but he has not left you! He’s standing right behind you. Ah!” it
      screamed in terror, “There is fire coming from around”. Praveen was dumb-stuck. He wept the rest of
      the day. Even though he had lived in rebellion and disobedience to the LORD for one year despite
      knowing the truth, the LORD was still watching over him and with him to protect him: “I will never
      leave you nor forsake you.” (Heb 13:5 NKJV). (Bold his, 142-143.)

447
    Unfortunately, in this section, he also states: “Good works are essential to show real faith in salvation but eternal
life is never earned, but a gift” (p. 71). This LS statement backloads the gospel with works by making good works
necessary to reach Heaven. FG acknowledges that good works are not soteriologically essential.
Excursus on Miscellaneous Writers                                                                             Page 353

        Moses Paul’s second of his two books in his Eternity Series is better: Overcomers Win the Prize: The New
Jerusalem (2020). In this book, he appropriately focuses on a literal view of New Jerusalem. He still has some
soteriological deficiencies in that he thinks fear of Hell is only “tentatively lifted” as we journey toward Heaven in
this life, and he erroneously thinks that we gain eternal life through “true repentance” even if we forfeit our entrance
into New Jerusalem because of subsequent worldly compromises (p. 12). His misthology is better than many FG
soteriologists, but his soteriology is inferior to most FG soteriologists.
        He provides calculations that indicate that the number of sands on the seashore is equal to the number of stars
in the heavens and reasonably perceives a relationship with the promise to Abraham that his descendants would be
like both and deduces that they will fill the universe with celestial and terrestrial descendants. The overcomers will
be celestial servant kings living in New Jerusalem in resurrected bodies. Their subjects will be in natural
bodies. Very good. He also believes that trillions of Jews will be born in natural bodies during the millennial
kingdom. A more reasonable presumption would be to conclude, as I have argued at length elsewhere, that
procreation for Jews and Gentiles continues in the eternal state for those who enter it in their natural bodies.
        In any event, he improves upon his perception regarding sinlessness, acknowledging that “indeed we could
not be tempted in resurrection bodies” (p. 34). Correct. “God cannot be tempted by evil” (Jam 1:13). We share His
nature via new birth; therefore, “we cannot sin” (1Jn 3:9) in terms of our new nature, and in our resurrected bodies,
we cannot sin at all.
        Curiously, he poses that those guilty of the vice list in Rev 22:14-15 who are outside the City are
unfaithful believers who are cast into outer darkness to live on the new Earth in contradistinction to those in
Rev 21:8 who are guilty of a similar vice list but cast into the Lake of Fire because they are specified to be
unbelievers/unbelieving (pp. 48-51). His soteriology is inconsistent. On the one hand, he frontloads the gospel,
saying that salvation from the Lake of Fire is conditioned on repenting and believing (pp. 49-50). Then, on the next
page, he acknowledges: “Jesus said it is ‘just’ by believing in Him that we cross from death into life (John 5.24)
not by being sanctified…We are saved by faith alone, in Christ alone, by grace alone (Eph 2.8,9)” (p. 51). Though
he has not worked out all the bugs in his statements, his overall presentation is excellent:

              People have two extreme views about the consequences of sin for believers. There is truth in
      both sides, but not the whole truth. I think with the revelation which John received; we can have a
      more balanced view. The first extreme and harsh view is that all who sin go to hell. If a believer lies,
      even though they love God, if they don’t confess it, it can cost them their salvation. The other extreme
      view is that all believers however compromised in their lives, will enter the New Jerusalem. I believe
      the truth is found in the middle: we all know young but true believers who lie again and again. Some
      are genuinely recreated, experiencing the Lord’s love and are winning souls but have very immature
      lives. It is easy to see the saving grace of God for such people, accepted by the Lord. However, if they
      continue all their lives without dealing with this habit before God, it will cost them dearly. For the sake
      of £1000 a month extra in salary, why lie and miss out on being an emperor forever? For the sake of
      an extra £300 in business sales why use deception in your work and loose a £300,000 crown? Outside
      are the liars... In your work tell the truth, whatever the cost; it will cost much, much more if you lie.
      (Pp. 62-63)

He correctly deduces that such believers will be outside the City in the outer darkness rather than be cast
into the Lake of Fire. A life of sin does not cost them their salvation from the Lake of Fire, but it does cost
them their entrance into the Heavenly City. Such concessions greatly mitigate against his LS Arminian
conditional security, making FG unconditional security the much more consistent choice. His misthological warning
to those who reject his misthopological message provides an interesting incident:

             Once I taught about the New Jerusalem in a church where there was opposition to its challenge,
      as people were offended that they could be saved but possibly be outside the holy city. They argued
      after the end of my series, and the leader eventually stood up and said ‘don’t worry we will all be
      inside’. I felt like all the warnings I had given, and encouragement to be overcomers and holy, were in
      vain. As I arrived back to my room, my attention was drawn to a scrap of paper on the floor in the path
      outside. I picked it up and opened it out. To my amazement, it was Revelation chapter 21 and 22, the
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 354
      last 2 chapters of the bible, ripped out and on the floor. I felt God speak to me: “The church has
      removed the challenge of the Holy City, the New Jerusalem from the Bible. It must be restored. Tell
      them to stop ripping out parts of John’s Revelation”. (Pp. 87-88)

       My expectation is that such leaders who reject misthopology and insist that all believers will be in the City
will themselves be excluded from the City for having taken away from the teaching of Scripture in general and
Revelation in particular: “If anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God shall take away
his part from the tree of life and from the holy city, which are written in this book” (Rev 22:19).
       Like myself, he poses that those born during the millennial kingdom will not qualify for New Jerusalem even
if they are faithful because the training for reigning for those who compose the Bride is completed before the
commencement of the millennial kingdom (pp. 46-47). Our training is intense because our reward is immense
(p. 75). In TOD, I postulated that those believers who want to fly like angels in the future must first learn to fly like
eagles now by waiting on the Lord (Is 40:31). Since overcomers are to rule angels, surely overcomers will also rule
their angelic domains, which would include other planets. At the very least, since all believers are to be like angels
in certain ways, is it too much to deem it probable that overcomers will fly like angels (Mt 22:30; Mk 12:25)? Paul
(p. 48) likewise poses overcomers will be able to fly like supermen among the clouds (Is 60:8). In fact, like myself,
he also suggests that they will be able to move a galaxy! (p. 72). Seeing the Father’s face is a reward (pp. 94-96).
       His book has various other commendable observations, such as recognizing that ascending to the hill
of the Lord in Ps 24:3-6 is applicable to New Jerusalem (p. 99), acknowledging that suicide has the potential
to send a believer to the outer darkness outside the City rather than to Hell (p. 100), which is an improvement
over his previous book. Some of his statements I would tweak, however. For example, he properly concludes that
unfaithful believers will be excluded from New Jerusalem and thus be crying outside the City. Inconsistently, he
believes that God will wipe away their tears according to Rev 21:4 (p. 103). However, this verse is best understood
as a promise to those inside the City, not to those outside of it! He unnecessarily thinks that unfaithful believers
who are cast outside the City will be able to serve outside the City as high-ranking assistants to the kings who are
within the City (p. 115). A much more consistent proposition is that those who are born in the millennial and eternal
states and who are faithful will compose these high-ranking assistants. Those cast into the outer darkness are
pictured by Scripture as having their hands and feet tied (Mt 22:13) and their opportunities for service taken away
(Mt 25:28-30), not as being given positions of authority! All in all, though, his second book is highly recommended
as an encouraging read, despite some soteriological and misthological inconsistencies.
       Indeed, Paul makes an observation about Rev 21:1-2 that leads me to tweak my own model with an expanded
thought:

              John had a revelation about somewhere better than heaven! The last two chapters of the
      Bible are not about heaven. The climax of the Bible is about a place that comes out of heaven. God
      chose to close the canon of scripture with the description of a city coming down from heaven onto to
      the new earth. Not much is spoken about the new heaven or the new earth; but this Holy city, the
      Heavenly Jerusalem, where the Triune God is enthroned, is the focus of attention. I want to go to
      heaven, but I also want to go to a place better than heaven. It is a heavenly city but it comes down out
      of heaven (Rev 21.2) onto the new earth.
              Do you want to only go to heaven forever? Several times in the Bible it says that when the Lord
      comes, He will bring all His angels [holy ones] with Him (Zech 14.5, Mat 25:31, ITh 3:13). If all
      the angels come with Him, then none are left in heaven. So when He comes, the Lord empties
      heaven. If you want to be in heaven forever, you may be alone! We are waiting to go to heaven,
      but it seems all of heaven is waiting to come down onto the new earth! (Italics his, 5-6)

      When God brings all His holy ones with Him from Heaven to Earth, the only ones remaining in Heaven will
be unholy ones—that is, unfaithful believers who are left to live in the outer realm of the outer darkness of the
kingdom. Heaven will become a relative ghost town. The New Heavens and New Earth will be superior to the outer
heavenly realm. The New Heavens and New Earth will be buzzing with an unbelievable amount of dynamic activity,
while the outer realm becomes static by comparison. Despite my very speculative opinion that the cubical hub of
the 4D City might remain on Planet Paradise, this 4D hub of the wheel will see very little action compared to the
spokes and parameters of the wheel conveyed by the 3D versions of the City.

       During the course of this research, interaction has been provided with some of the more standard pre-Adamic
theories. Various other theories not necessarily worthy of serious contemplation might be mentioned.
                             Post-pre-Adamic Black Versus Adamic White
     Winchell begins by sharing an argument by Isaac La Peyrère. Wikipedia provides this summation of his
argument:

      “If Adam sinned in a morally meaningful sense there must have been an Adamic law according to
      which he sinned. If law began with Adam, there must have been a lawless world before Adam,
      containing people”. Thus, according to La Peyrère there must have been two creations: first the
      creation of the Gentiles and then that of Adam, who was father of the Jews. The existence of pre-
      Adamites, La Peyrère argued, explained Cain’s life after Abel’s murder which, in the Genesis account,
      involved the taking of a wife and the building of a city. This account of human origins became the
      basis for 19th century theories of polygenism and were espoused by those trying to justify racism in
      the New World. This polygenesis of the Gentiles was his method of explaining the existence of the
      Negroes, Chinese, Eskimos, American Indians, Malays and other people groups being discovered.448

       Unfortunately, such analyses do not differentiate from Post-pre-Adamites from various other forms of pre-
Adamites. In La Peyrère’s pre-Adamic theory, Genesis 1:28 deals with the pre-Adamic origin of the Gentiles.
Supposedly, Genesis chapter 2 treats the origin of Adam from whence came the Jews. But Gen 1:26-28 occurs after
Gen 1:1-2. Cain, accordingly, was an Adamite who took a wife from the older Post-pre-Adamic people in La
Peyrère’s model. La Peyrère also believes Noah’s flood was not universal but only destroyed the Adamites living
in the Mediterranean area. Winchell says that La Peyrère’s views were unjustly judged as heretical, and Winchell
then proceeds to argue along similar lines. According to this racial theory, Blacks are Post-pre-Adamites,
descendants of an earlier Black Adam. Whites are Adamites, descendants of the biblical Adam. Whites are superior
to Blacks. The Noachites were Adamites. Many of those not killed in the flood were pre-Adamites.449
       From my monogenistic, RET, and universal flood premises, such racial Post-pre-Adamic arguments are
completely untenable. For example, if the Earth were destroyed and then restored, no pre-catastrophe pre-Adamites
(Pre-pre-Adamites) would have been left on Earth at the time of Adam. Therefore, his postulation of post-
catastrophe pre-Adamites (Post-pre-Adamites) has no direct impact on this RET discussion of possible RET pre-
Adamites being destroyed in a RET war. Nonetheless, there are points of common interest. For instance, if biblical
Adam is told to replenish the Earth, this would make no sense if Earth was peopled with pre-Adamites at the time.
La Peyrère’s proposal would short circuit this objection, however, by claiming that the command to replenish in
Gen 1:28 was made to the Post-pre-Adamites. Even so, the gospel is for all humans, and all humans—Gentile and
Jew, Black and White—are made one by faith in Christ. If polygenesis is ruled out for Post-pre-Adamites, it would
be ruled out for Pre-pre-Adamites.450

                                  No Pre-Adamic Fossils on Restored Earth
      YEC criticizes RET for postulating that pre-Adamic fossils were still on Earth after God restored it. For those
who find that argument credible, one should be aware that Chitwood’s RET model adopts the same premise:

            Note that any vestiges of “sin,” which would necessitate ruin [death as well where man is
      concerned] could not have existed in connection with the material creation at the time of man’s

was made from pre-existing pre-Adamic genetic material, Christ’s death is not only retrospective to Adam
but to pre-Adamites because of their racial unity. Christ died for all humans, even pre-Adamic humans.

because he favors “monogenistic preadamitism” over “polygenistic preadamitism,” though he believes the
argument of the latter would suffice since pre-Adamic and Adamic humans are a “mutual brotherhood” created by
“a common Father” (p. 287). He bolsters his argument by pointing out that some theologians believe that Christ’s
atonement is applicable to species and planetary races God created on other planets in the past, present, or future.
They have a “moral unity” even if they do not have a “genetic unity” (296). They have a “common psychic nature”
(p. 460). Alexander Winchell, Preadamites: Or a Demonstration of the Existence of Men Before Adam Together
with a Study of Their Condition, Antiquity, Racial Affinities, and Progressive Dispersion Over the Earth (London:
Trübner, 1888). Those who find such arguments more persuasive than I do will find it much easier than I have to
accept the proposition of pre-Adamic humans. Nevertheless, I find the proposition of non-redeemable pre-
Adamic humans preferable, with redemption being limited to Adamic humans since they have Adam as their
federal head and genetic progenitor, resulting in redemption via a kinsman-redeemer. God did not send the
flood because of blacks marrying whites but because of fallen angels mating with humans, corrupting their human
genetics so that they were no longer truly human, and thereby making them unredeemable. Additionally, the
Luciferian war would have wiped out the pre-Adamic humans on this planet.

    One way around this difficulty is to pose that the Pre-pre-Adamites were a different species from the Post-pre-

that offered by Yates, which basically poses polygenesis for the human body but a monogenesis for the human

                                                 Day 6 Pre-pre-Adamites
        Garcia believes Lucifer and his angels were cast out of the third Heaven on the second day of creation to
Earth where the humanoids were, thus resulting in ancient testimonies regarding the Anunnaki. These fallen angels
were the Anunnaki rulers on the Earth, holding extraordinary reigns in the Sumerian King’s List. Though his timing
is rather peculiar, this proposition is reasonable and shared by other RETs. At the point of creation, God “formed
the earth and made it, He established it and did not create it a waste place, but formed it to be inhabited” (Is 45:18).
The angels were already created before God created the Earth (Job 38:4-7). Thus, God either had the morning stars
(pre-existing angels) inhabit the Earth (so some RETs), or God created humanoids to inhabit it (so other RETs). In
the latter RET proposal, pre-existing angels would rule over the newly formed pre-Adamic humanoids.
        Garcia holds the latter perspective, which is a reasonable RET position, perhaps even probable. However, he
enjoins it with some eccentric views. He poses that Lucifer was cast out of the third Heaven down to Earth on the
second day of creation.456 This timing is curious. He seems to make most of Gen 1 a description of what happened
during the GAP, which would make the pre-Adamites created in Gen 1:26-28 on Earth, in his model, Pre-pre-
Adamites. The fallen angels ruled as pagan gods over the Pre-pre-Adamic people of Gen 1:26-28. Yet he poses that
the fallen angels built the cities in Jer 4:23-27 because humans and humanoids did not yet exist (World, 206), though
he allows the possibility that the cities were built by pre-Adamites (World, 210). He believes “Genesis 2:5-6 is a
flashback to a bygone age where the earth had not yet been resettled in recreation as executed in Genesis 1:11-31”
(World, 205). This would seem to put this part of Gen 2 back in the GAP in his model. He places the formation of
Adam later (Gen 2:15-25) and says, “Adam was established in heaven….the land being described in these passages

existence, the loss of their former state included their forced transition into mortal embodiment” (p. 187).

       Well said. Sitchin puts biblical and extrabiblical texts in a blender and reconstructs them with his mistaken

sought to monkey with their DNA to upgrade them to be more productive workers. This basic premise seems

We differ, though, in seeking an exegetical basis through a supposed distinction between two creations:

             The first hominid referenced as being made by Elohim in ‘our image’ [in Gen 1:26-28] is an
      entirely separate hominid from that of Adam mentioned in Genesis 2:7. Likewise, in the first creation
      narrative the creature made was to inhabit the earth and was in fact, established in numerous colors
      and places upon the earth. These beings were made as several independent species of humankind and
      varying types of antediluvian hominids. They were created in breeding pairs as couples, spread abroad
      the earth, and given commandment to be fruitful, multiply, and replenish the earth as cited in Genesis
      1:26-28; which is why it specifies in several places within those verses reference to these beings as
      ‘them.’
             God had intended these beings to repopulate the earth which is why they were created together
      as a couple, male and female. The anthropological record shows that at that time there was in existence
      a wide variety of hominid species including the Neanderthal, Cro-Magnon, Denisovan, and even a
      hobbit type of hominid. (Pp. 294-295)

       I do not subscribe to the notion of two separate creations of humankind being described between Gen 1:26-
28 and 2:7. Nevertheless, I am certainly open to the possibility of the wide variety of pre-Adamic hominid species
he describes. His exegetical distinction and reconstruction seem strained. Rather than try to defend it through the
exegesis of the biblical text, I entertain it via logic and interaction with extrabiblical texts. As to logic, when God
created birds, He did not create one bird couple and tell them to go replenish the Earth. Rather, He called
forth multiple bird couples of various types and told them to replenish the Earth. Surely, He did the same
thing when He originally created the Earth. Likewise, one may propose that when God originally created
pre-Adamites, He made multiple types of hominid species. Whereas Garcia is posing various types of
antediluvian breeding couples before the Noachian flood, I would be more inclined to entertain the plausibility of
various types of antediluvian breeding couples before Lucifer’s flood. Were there multiple antediluvian breeding
couples? Yes. But the question is, Which flood is being used as a point of reference? The Luciferian flood, the
Noachian flood, or both.
       Some RETs hold to the first option. Some hold to the second. Some seem to hold to both. Indeed, I can allow
both, but I would place my pivot point at a different location than the one posed by Garcia: “I, however, interpret
and convey the subtleties of the Sumerian story of the sudden appearance of civilized man differently attributing
the dissimilarities to the Genesis 2:7 creation of an entirely new being by the Word of the Lord” (p. 309). He
reinterprets the Sumerian story’s distinction between the primitive humanoid women with whom fallen angels
mated and the subsequent humanlike women with whom they mated to be found by associating the former with
Excursus on Pre-Adamic Redemption and Reconciliation                                                      Page 361
Gen 1:26-28 and the latter with Gen 2:7. One weakness in this assumption is that the latter Eve-like woman would
start off as a singular couple. If one migrates further down the line to where multiple Eve-like women are found,
one is moving into the antediluvian era of Gen 6:1-4. Consequently, one need only entertain the plausible position
held by other RETs that, just as the fallen angels mated with humanoid women before Lucifer’s flood, fallen
angels mated with human women before Noah’s flood. Posing a distinction between the humans of Gen 1:26-28
and 2:7 is not needed. Furthermore, the acknowledgment that God created a variety of humanoid species before the
Luciferian flood allows the possibility that the pre-Adamic women whom God created at the higher end of that scale
could suffice for the basic distinction posed by the Sumerian texts without even necessarily requiring that one move
into the Gen 1:26-Gen 6:4 era at all.
                                            Exobiology—Exclusive
       This misthological series has provided limited interaction with Horn’s book, Exo-Vaticana, in MMP2 and
MMP4. Another aspect of his discussion merits further consideration in MMP5. In a video, Horn summarizes some
of the concerns raised by exobiology (astrobiology), which comprises “Section Two” of his book.458 Using that
discussion as a launching point, we can expand upon some of the questions he raises.

      1. When official disclosure of aliens—ETIs (extraterrestrial intelligences)—is made, how will it impact the
         Christian faith?
      2. Do aliens necessarily have to be angelic?
      3. Could a fake disclosure be made before the rapture?
      4. Could a genuine disclosure be made before the rapture?
      5. Could ETIs be scientifically, morally, and/or spiritually superior to humans?
      6. Should ETIs be open to our gospel, or should we be open to theirs?
      7. Does our gospel even apply to ETIs?
      8. Would Jesus become incarnate on every inhabited planet and die for the ETIs of that planet?

       Herein, in MMP5, in consideration of the material being discussed, I am adjusting my answers to some of
the above questions. For instance, if God created sentient pre-Adamites on Earth, then it stands to reason that
He did so on other planets also. Since the sentient species on this planet have had a global scientific reset at
least three times (at the Luciferian flood, Noachian flood, and Tower of Babel), it would stand to reason that
sentient species on other planets would be well ahead of us scientifically if they have not had to endure such
resets. Plus, they might have unhindered access to angelic technology. Additionally, if some of them are
unfallen, they might be ahead of us morally and spiritually.
       As Horn notes in Exo-Vaticana, some speculate that Jesus was incarnated on every planet that bears sentient
life (p. 22). Despite wishes otherwise, fallen angels and their hybrids (such as Nephilim) do not appear to have
natural-redeemable souls/spirits (pp.100-103). Bigfoot falls into this hybrid category (pp. 138-139). Exobiology is
a subdiscipline of astrobiology and deals more specifically with extraterrestrial life and whether the Copernican
Principle is true that Earth does not have “a central, preferred position in the cosmos” (p. 178) as opposed to the
anthropic principle, which asserts that “the universe appears to be designed with us in mind” (p. 188). Horn
speculates, “While we do have UFO sightings, we never see them coming from far away in space. This leads us to
suspect that they are a localized phenomenon” (p. 198). He draws upon Michael Heiser’s “Chapter 10: Panspermia:
What It Is and Why It Matters” in How to Overcome the Most Frightening Issues You Will Face This Century to
develop his exotheology (p. 204). I interacted with that material in MMP4, and, in contrast to Heiser (and Horn,
292-294), I do not find it necessary to suppose a merely functional view of man’s status as God’s unique image-

to the inference that in order to save Klingons, Jesus would have to become incarnated as a Klingon and die

million, billion, or trillion civilizations God created. Jesus would have had to become incarnate and die as

       Horn’s argument is good but not as strong as it could be. For one thing, the scope of the atonement is
not merely a question of sufficiency but also one of applicability. As noted in MMP4, Schnoebelen’s belief—
that Jesus’ death can be applied to anyone (ETs included) as long as they believe—should be amended by pointing
out that the infinite value of Jesus’ blood is given limited application; namely, it only washes away the moral
guilt of Adam and Eve and their human descendants.460 Jesus had to become incarnate as a human to save
humans through His atoning death. In turn, one has to be human to qualify for this atonement and also
savingly believe in Jesus for eternal life for His blood to be applicable. This conclusion is consistent with
Horn’s position that the atonement is not applicable to hybrids. Additionally, Heb 2:16 can be added as
supporting the contention that redemption does not extend to angels and is apparently limited to mankind
(cp. Is 53:4-12; Jn 10:15-16; 11:51-52; Rom 1:16; 4:25; 5:6-10,19; 6:5; 1Cor 15:3; 2Cor 5:21; Gal 1:4; 3:13; Eph
1:7; 5:2,25; Col 1:21-22; 2:13-14; 1Thess 5:10; Tit 2:14; 2Tim 2:11; Heb 2:6-17; 10:10-17; 13:12; 1Pet 1:18-19;
2:24; 1Jn 4:10; Rev 1:5-6; 5:9). This position is consistent with Horn’s conclusion that the atonement does not
apply to fallen angels or their hybrids and is a reasonable extrapolation regarding fallen ETIs.
       As for Col 1:20, the biblical universal reconciliation (BUR) affirmed in that text should not be confused
with unbiblical universal atonement. Reconciliation is accomplished via subjugation for those in opposition,
as Melick (NAC) notes:

                In Col 1:20 the common understanding of reconciliation must be broadened. At the most basic
         level, reconciliation means the restoring of a broken relationship. Typically in Scripture it involves
         persons because the Bible was written to transform human life. Reconciliation usually involves two
         prerequisites: Both parties must have a willingness to be reconciled, and there must be an occasion
         that brings them together. God has demonstrated his willingness and provided the occasion by taking
         the initiative to send Jesus as reconciler. The willingness is produced by the work of the Holy Spirit.
         A felt need, often prompted by circumstances of life, provides the occasion. Thus reconciliation is
         normally voluntary and volitional.
                Here, however, reconciliation involves more than a voluntary movement. The natural creation
         was subjected to sin “not by its own choice” (Rom 8:20), and its reconciliation will be of God’s
         choosing in his time. Regarding the spirits, in Col 2:15 Paul employed the language of warfare in
         stating that the spirit powers will be subdued by Christ. Their ultimate destiny was settled when
         they chose either to rebel or submit to God’s glory in eternity past. Now, God offers no possibility of
         renewal to those who rebelled, presumably because they had a full knowledge of God when they chose
         sin. Now they live in an intermediate time in which they exercise limited powers of rebellion. Some
         day, however, that will cease. The work of Christ’s death will be applied completely to them.

Simpson and Bruce (NICNT, 1957) make much the same point:


460
      William J. Schnoebelen, Space Invaders, Kindle Edition, (USA: Xlibris Corporation, 2003), KL 1505.

             Paul’s statement that Christ’s reconciling work, in accordance with the divine purpose, is to
      embrace in its scope “all things … whether things upon the earth, or things in the heavens,” has been
      taken to mean that he looked for the ultimate reconciliation to God not only of all men but of hostile
      spiritual powers as well—that, in fact, he anticipated Origen in the view that fallen angels benefit by
      the redemption accomplished by Christ. The present passage, however, has to be understood in relation
      to Paul’s general teaching on this subject; and it is very difficult to press his language to yield
      anything like universal reconciliation in the sense in which the phrase is commonly used
      nowadays [i.e., PUR—popular universal reconciliation].461 It is contrary to the whole analogy of
      Scripture (the Pauline writings included) to apply the idea of reconciliation in the ordinary sense
      to the fallen angels. And even with regard to mankind, to deduce from such a passage as this the
      conclusion that every human being, irrespective of his record or his attitude to God, will at last enjoy
      celestial bliss, is to deduce something which is contrary to recorded sayings of our Lord, not to mention
      the teaching of the NT in general.
             The peace effected by the death of Christ may be freely accepted, or it may be compulsorily
      imposed. When Paul speaks here of reconciliation on the widest scale, he includes in it what we should
      distinguish as pacification. The principalities and powers whose conquest by Christ is described in
      Ch. 2:15 are certainly not depicted there as gladly surrendering to His grace, but as submitting against
      their wills to a power which they cannot resist. Everything in the universe has been subjected to
      Christ even as everything was created for Him. By His reconciling work, “the host of the high ones
      on high” and sinful men on earth have been decisively subdued to the will of God, and can but
      subserve His purpose, whether they please or not. So in Phil. 2:11 “things in heaven and things on
      earth and things under the earth” ultimately unite to bow in the name of Jesus and to acknowledge Him
      as Lord.

       This reconciliation-via-subjugation places Jesus as the God-Man above the angels. Jesus had to die to
accomplish universal reconciliation so that mankind could be exalted above the angels. Reconciliation of subjects
with their king requires subjugation to the king’s will and restitution of any debt owed to the king. Subjects have a
relationship of subjugation to their king. Likewise, Jesus’ victorious reconciliation over His subjects puts
everything and everyone in subjection to Him. Jesus’ blood takes away the sin of the world, not the sin of
Satan. Humanity’s sin no longer stands as a legal barrier to restored fellowship with God for those fallen
humans who believe and repent. The blood does not avail to restore fellowship with God for other fallen
sentient beings. Their reconciliation will consist solely of subjugation. Reconciliation puts everything in its
proper place, like pieces on a chessboard. The proper place for sin is away from God, which is where those
who die in their sins will be located. Jesus reconciled us legally by paying our sin debt and thereby balanced
the books, removing Satan’s claim against us.
       My take is that there is no Klingon Jesus. The Lord has not incarnated Himself multiple times to die
multiple atoning deaths throughout the universe. Humanity is in a highly privileged position in that regard.
Nevertheless, the gospel impacts the entire universe. For fallen creatures, this universal gospel spells their
ultimate subjugation and destruction. For unfallen creatures, it spells their ultimate salvation. Eventually,
salvation from sin and its ravaging will spread throughout the universe when the Lord puts an end to sin in the
universe. Unfallen angels and other unfallen sentient beings will be delivered from the presence and effects of sin.
They will no longer have to fight against the forces of darkness. Their salvation will not be from personal sin but
from universal sin—sin which contaminates the entire universe without morally contaminating every sentient being
in the universe. Holy angels, for instance, remain holy although they are part of the created order affected by
Lucifer’s sin. The same would be true of other sentient beings who have not chosen to participate in Lucifer’s
rebellion. The blood of Christ will not save fallen angels. Nor will it save their hybrids, who are too genetically
modified to be considered human. Nor will it save fallen insectalins or fallen members of other alien species.
However, unfallen insectalins, if there are any, will be saved—not from personal sin, since they have none, but from
universal sin. Both immortal holy angels and mortal unfallen aliens will be saved in that sense. Our gospel is good

                                                Exobiology—Inclusive
       Despite my preference for a singular incarnation and atonement limited to mankind, a brief survey of
opposing points of view will help round out the discussion. In their book, Astrotheology, Hewlett, Moritz, Russell,
Peters, and Davies give alternate viewpoints.463 The most pertinent part of their book to our discussion is “Part 4:
Jesus Christ on Earth and Elsewhere.” Ted Peters starts that section with Chapter 16. One Incarnation of Many. He
cites the opinion held by Davies that ETIs would sink the Christian ship because they would require multiple
incarnations by a planet-hopping Christ since the Christian gospel is species-specific, being limited to
humanity. Posing that humanity has a privileged position would be nothing more than pre-Copernican
chauvinism—a geocentrism and anthropocentrism which have been refuted by Copernicus. The Copernican
Principle has proven that Earth and thus humanity are not the center of the universe but rather have a mere
marginal status.
       In surveying various theologians and options, Peters notes that some theologians believe that Jesus would
undergo multiple incarnations to save ETIs, while other theologians pose instead that a single incarnation would
suffice. Peter poses that the division in opinion is primarily due to the perception of the nature of reconciliation. If
