redemption is merely revelational, then multiple incarnations is understandable. Christ has revealed Himself
multiple times through multiple incarnations throughout the cosmos, leading to the proposition of a Cosmic Christ.
Peters points out objections by David Wilkinson to multiple incarnations, who warns against driving a wedge
between the human Jesus and cosmic Christ, adding that more is necessary for salvation than mere revelation. The
incarnation involves both salvation and revelation. Jesus did not incarnate Himself multiple times in multiple
nations on Earth to accomplish atonement because more was involved than mere proclamation. Likewise, we should
not suppose that He incarnated Himself on multiple worlds to accomplish salvation. Peters responds to Wilkinson’s
cautions by citing authors from the other camp, who pose that one incarnation suffices for the entire cosmos, being
efficacious for the whole cosmos.
       Certainly, an incarnation-for-redemption view of the incarnation can be perceived as leading to a necessity
of multiple incarnations to accomplish salvation for fallen ETIs via a planet-hopping Christ. On the other hand, an
incarnation-for-revelation view can also be supposed to require multiple incarnations via a planet-hopping Christ.
Otherwise, if one rejects the planet-hopping-Christ theory, one is left with pre-Copernican Earth chauvinism or
geocentrism. In response to these horns of a dilemma, Peters goes back to the ancient church father Irenaeus, who
posed that Jesus’s singular death was universally efficacious. More contemporary authors appeal to Jn 1:14 and
take flesh as a synecdoche to include not only all biological life (which would include exobiological life) but the
entire material universe (including plants and animals). Peters denies that this verse entails any form of centrism
because it offers divine grace to all of creation with no advanced status:

      I do not translate this into any form of centrism. What God has accomplished in this event of terrestrial
      history does not accrue to an advanced status for either the human race or for the planet on which we
      live. Nor does it preclude the existence of subjectivities on other worlds looking at our cosmos from a
      different perspective.
             If anything, what we learn from Scripture and from the teachings of Jesus is to carry ourselves
      with a demeanor of humility. When God raised up prophets in ancient Israel, God selected marginal
      individuals to speak truth to power. Jesus repeatedly warns, “the last shall be first.” If a theologian
      adopts the one-incarnation-is-enough position, I recommend he or she resist the temptation to
      justify any sort of centrism. It would fit hermeneutically, so to speak, for we earthlings to live with
      the paradox that the cosmic event of salvation took place on our marginal and humble planet. (P. 296-
      297)

       His assessment is refuted misthologically by the very passage he cites regarding the role reversal of last
versus first (Mt 19:30), plus exaltation of the humble (1Pet 5:6). Yes, we humans are presently in a humble state,
but this is not to be the eternal state of affairs. Even soteriologically among humans, believers have a special
privilege: “See how great a love the Father has bestowed upon us, that we should be called children of God;
and such we are. For this reason the world does not know us, because it did not know Him” (1Jn 3:1). And
faithful believers will have an even greater privilege. Misthological centrism is biblically apparent, making
soteriological centrism necessary as well. Thus, even if one attempts to follow Peters in taking Jn 3:16 to mean
that God so loved the cosmos, this does not mean that there are no privileged positions in the cosmos. On his opening
page, Peters provided an endnote citing Weideman’s question, “Did Jesus Die for Klingons Too?” Peters would
respond affirmatively and claim that Jesus did die for Klingons and assert that His death on our planet does not give
us a privileged position. In contrast, I concur with Weidemann in rejecting both of Peters’ propositions.
       The next chapter in Astrobiology is by Robert Russell: Chapter 17. Many Incarnations or One? Unlike Peters,
Russell argues for multiple incarnations. He believes that ETIs would, like humans, be created in the image of
God and be morally flawed. In contradistinction to the sharp distinction that Peters makes between a revelational
versus an ontological view of the incarnation, Russell argues that “the revelational view requires an ontological
incarnation, and one that can be communicated to ETI in the context of its particular history” (p. 308). He explains:

              This then is my basic argument for multiple incarnations. ETI could not be included in the
      revelational efficacy of the incarnation without an ontological incarnation on their planet, embedded
      in their own species and its histories, but from Peters’s ontological view they could be included in the
      ontological efficacy of the terrestrial incarnation without an incarnation on their planet. Since I adopt
      the revelational view, I believe there must be multiple incarnations to effect the redemption of all
      intelligent life in the universe. In sum, if Peters is correct, then from an ontological perspective a single
Excursus on Pre-Adamic Redemption and Reconciliation                                                        Page 367
      incarnation of the divine logos in Jesus of Nazareth is sufficient for the redemption of the universe. A
      unique incarnation on earth can ontologically alter the entire universe and the laws of nature which
      describe natural processes. But if I am correct, from a revelatory perspective our participation by faith
      in the Resurrection requires that this revelation be based on an ontological act of redemption by God
      and that it be known to all species needing redemption. In this perspective a single incarnation is
      insufficient for the redemption of the universe because the participation of ETI will be impossible.
      Instead multiple incarnations are required. (Emphasis his, 308)
       His argument is well reasoned to insist that the revelational aspect of the incarnation requires an
ontological basis. The revelational news of Jesus’ death for us on the cross requires the ontological death of
the God-Man to make atonement possible, but our faith in Jesus is also required to make it applicable
(Jn 3:16). For His death to be efficacious for humanity, Jesus had to be incarnated as the God-Man. The
news of God’s love for us will not save us apart from His death for us. Nevertheless, this news must be believed
in order for eternal life to be received. We could not savingly believe in Jesus for eternal life if He had not
become the God-Man and died for us to make eternal life available to us. Russell then proceeds to argue that
species-specific incarnations would be required so that ETIs throughout the universe could hear the news of the
atonement in a message they could understand. He attempts to offset the objection that this would mean that Jesus
would have to become the God-Man-Klingon-Vulcan-Romulan-etcetera by posing that flesh in Jn 1:14 encompasses
humans and ETIs: “After all we all share the same DNA” (p. 313). Apparently, although Jesus would have to
become incarnate and die as an Earthling, Klingon, Vulcan, Romulan, etc., Russell is proposing that He would not
have to assume more than one terrestrial nature in doing so. Every time Jesus becomes incarnate and dies, He does
so as the God-Terrestrial. Weaknesses in his proposal include the highly questionable presumption that all ETIs
share the same DNA and the assumption that effective communication is limited to multiple incarnations. In any
event, a fatal flaw in his argument is that the Bible states that Jesus died once for all, never to die again.
       In Chapter 18. Multiple Incarnations of the One Christ, Hess addresses the problem posed by a singular
death:
              Scholastic theologian William Vorilong (d. 1463) wondered “whether Christ by dying on this
       Earth could redeem the inhabitants of another world” and answered that this must be possible because
       Christ could not die again in another world.” In 1550 Philip Melanchthon, the great expositor of the
       Lutheran Reformation, categorically denied the existence of other worlds:
                   The Son of God is One; our master Jesus Christ was born, died, and resurrected in
            this world. Nor does He manifest Himself elsewhere, nor elsewhere has He died, or
            resurrected. Therefore it must not be imagined that there are many worlds, because it
            must not be imagined that Christ died and was resurrected more often, nor must it be
            thought that in any other world without the knowledge of the Son of God, men would be
            restored to eternal life. (Pp. 322-323)
       Vorilong is on biblically solid ground to conclude that Jesus would not die again on other worlds.
However, he moves into problematic quicksand when he assumes this means that His death would make
ETIs on other worlds redeemable by His death on this world. On the other hand, Melanchthon is on solid
ground in posing that redemption is limited to this world but overstretches in assuming that this means that
there are no ETIs on other worlds. Between these two extremes is Weidemann’s solution: Redemption is
limited to this world and not inclusive of the ETIs of other worlds. Of course, such a proposal would be
considered entirely outlandish by Hess, who even thinks that Vorilong’s view is antiquated: “The claim arguing
that Jesus’ death and resurrection are unique and universally valid for the entire universe is parochial indeed”
(pp. 324-325). Hess poses the question in a straightforward manner: “Could salvation be accomplished on other
planets without a sacrificial death?” (p. 325), but then he dances around giving a straightforward answer.
       If Jesus’ death was not a necessary outcome of the incarnation to accomplish redemption, as Hess seems to
suggest, then multiple passages demand a clear response, not a theological dance around. The answer much more
in accord with the biblical perspective would be to maintain that humanity’s redemption required Christ’s
incarnation as a human and His death for humans. The most reasonable inference, then, is that if Christ were to
redeem ETIs, He would have to do the same for them. Yet biblical indications are that He has not. Why would
Christ soteriologically single out humanity for redemption? Misthology seems to be the answer, as Hess unwittingly
acknowledges:
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 368
      Theosis or “salvation through deification,” a theme that would be central to Orthodox theology in
      succeeding centuries, succinctly expressed by Athanasius of Alexandria: “The Son of God became
      man so that we might become God.” Patristic theologian Hamilton Hess notes that Athanasius’s
      Festal Letters are “rich in soteriological teaching expressed in a great variety of motifs.” The whole
      patristic tradition is summed up by St. Thomas Aquinas: The only begotten Son of God, wishing to
      enable us to share in his divinity, assumed our nature, so that by becoming man he might make
      men gods.” (P. 321)

My assessment is that God redeemed humanity to demonstrate the glory of His grace, mercy, and love
soteriologically and to create a Bride for Christ misthologically. Ultimately, Christ died to create His Bride—
misthological Gods and Goddesses, who will more fully share God’s nature than the highest angels and rule
over the highest angels and the rest of the multiverse. Therefore, I support theological centrism. Jesus died
for humans so that He might make overcoming humans Gods and Goddesses.
                                  Illustration 122. Could ET receive eternal life?




       For the sake of illustration, suppose that ET had been present when Jesus made the evangelistic presentation
to the woman at the well. Jesus said to her, “If you knew the gift of God, and who it is who says to you, ‘Give Me
a drink,’ you would have asked Him, and He would have given you living water” (Jn 4:10). As the context shows,
this was Jesus’ way of inviting her to believe in Him for eternal life. As the Gospel of John repeatedly demonstrates,
humans receive eternal life by simply believing in Jesus for eternal life (Jn 3:16; 5:24; 6:47, etc.). If ET had been
present, he would have been excluded from the you. Why? Because Jesus did not die for ET. Jesus’ prophesied
death for humanity was the basis by which He could offer eternal life to this human woman. Although she did not
understand that His death on the cross would be the basis by which Jesus could offer this life, this does not change
the fact that the historical act of Jesus’ death is the basis by which He can offer eternal life to humans both before,
during, and after His death for them. The fact of His death for them, rather than the time of this death relative to
when they were born or their knowledge of that death relative to when they believed, is what is necessary.
Excursus on Pre-Adamic Redemption and Reconciliation                                                        Page 369
       Could ET receive eternal life as a result of Jesus’ death for humanity? No. But could ET be saved as a
result of Jesus’ death for humanity? Yes, if ET was unfallen and the salvation being considered is not
salvation from personal sin but from universal sin. Surely, angels throughout the universe were keenly interested
in the events of Jesus’ life. Perhaps they had some way of broadcasting His ministry on something akin to spiritual
television in which they and their ET subjects could watch the events unfold. If so, an untold number of ETs could
be visually present to observe the conversation of Jesus with this woman at the well even though they were not
physically present. They would understand that the offer made to this human woman was not directly
applicable to them—though they could anticipate that in some way, it would lead to their eventual
emancipation from sin and the forces of evil (Gen 3:15; Rom 8:19-22).
                                     Need for Incarnation Limited to Humanity
       Two primary presuppositions in my above position are: (1) humanity’s redemption required Christ’s
incarnation as a human and His death for humans, and (2) if Christ were to redeem ETIs, He would probably
have to do the same for them. Breeden is a pastor and speculative fiction Christian writer who explores various
possibilities and challenges the latter assessment in his book, Strangers & Aliens. Though his assessment is different
than my own, I highly recommend his book. He notes that the commentary by Peter Lombard (1392-1463) inferred
that Adam’s sin would not have been imputed to ETs, and thus ETs would not need atonement (p. 246). I agree
with that proposition. Breeden points out valid weaknesses in theological geocentrism as is posed by some (pp. 249-
251) and makes some arguments against applying Adamic Dominion Mandate beyond the range of Earth to
strengthen his case, but he seems to leave open the possibility of a Christological Dominion Misthology, which
would be conducive to my argument supporting theological geocentrism (pp. 264-274). At least eschatologically,
misthology confirms the centralism of humanity for the purpose of rulership with Christ as join-heirs. In any
case, I concur that neither anthropological nor Christological dominion is an obstacle to ETIs.
       Breeden’s assessment of Vorilong and Melanchthon is more positive than mine: “William Vorilong and
Philip Melanchthon argued that since these aliens did not spring from Adam, multiple Incarnations are unnecessary”
(255). He briefly discusses the Chronicles of Time series by a fellow speculative fiction Christian writer, J.C.
Lamont, and poses, among other things, that angels may have been created in another universe previous to ours. I
enjoy such thought-provoking reads, especially since I have inductively come to similar conclusions independently.
       Breeden begins his final chapter, Can Aliens Be Saved?, with the quote from Weidemann’s article, “Did Jesus
Die for Klingons Too?”
             The entire idea that aliens need to be saved is based on the idea that Adam’s sin affected
      the whole cosmos because he was given dominion over all creation. A king falls and his kingdom
      suffers. So far, so good. We immediately note a difference in the way animals and humans were
      affected by the Fall. The animals suffered what we might call the universal effects of the Fall
      (death, suffering, adaptations to the struggle for resources, etc.), but man also inherited a sin
      nature (what we call depravity). Depravity is like a computer virus that comes with each
      replicated program. Everyone of Adam’s bloodline is affected by it. Christ was required to
      incarnate as a human in order to be man’s kinsman-redeemer, so that His death could free us
      from the curse of sin and death and His resurrection could give us the promise of eternal life.
      Again, so far, so good. (P. 279)
       Breeden proceeds to note that amoral AIs (artificial intelligences) and ETIs (extraterrestrial intelligences)
would not need redemption. Unfallen moral ETIs would not need redemption since Adam’s sin is not imputed
to them. They would not be subject to the spiritual-soteriological-sanguine-bloodline effects of Adam’s fall
and, therefore, not need salvation through the blood sacrifice of an incarnated kinsman-redeemer. Such
statements are allowed by my first presupposition above. Breeden then poses the question about fallen ETIs who
fell by their own volition. He allows the plausibility of my second presupposition as well: Salvation would not be
available for them. Yet he allows the possibility that God might make salvation available to them through other
means. He even goes so far as to suggest that they could become part of the Bride of Christ without comprising
separate Vulcan and Klingon brides. I am very skeptical. Nevertheless, if one posed their soteriological salvation
without insisting upon their co-equal misthological salvation, such a proposition might be more difficult to disallow.
In other words, one might argue that ETIs can become gods and goddesses but not Gods and Goddesses.
       For the sake of theoretical speculation, he goes on to pose that if Adam’s sin was imputed to ETIs, then
Christ’s death would provisionally apply to them—they would only need the revelation of His incarnation and to
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                    Page 370
believe in Him for eternal life. True, hypothetically given the former, the latter seems probable. Lastly, if one grants
the former but denies the latter, then he poses that Christ would indeed become incarnate on other worlds and die
as their substitution. Therefore, for such a conclusion to even be entertainable, one would first have to pose that
Adam’s sin was imputed to such ETs and that the atoning value of Christ’s death is not applicable to them. Since
these propositions are at odds with one another, this theoretical speculation borders on being preposterous.
       Breeden’s discussion is well-reasoned, well-informed, and well-received. Indeed, I was well-pleased to read
his recommendation of other writers posing speculative possibilities regarding ETs:
                If they are not fallen, what would an encounter with them be like? Would they even want to
         contact us? This vein of thought offers some very interesting possibilities. David G.
         Johnson’s Chadash Chronicles proposes a world that is not under the effect of original sin or God’s
         election, a world set up as a sort of divine contest in the tradition of the testing of Job. Peter R Stone
         also has an interesting twist on this idea. In A Knight from Dein [AKFD], some humans were
         transported to an alien world at the dispersion of Babel (so they were dispersed quite a bit
         further than other people groups!). Their world is both fallen and unfallen (in sections) because
         God created two alien species there and set them up with a Garden of Eden type test: one fell
         and the other didn’t. There is no carnivory in the lush, unfallen lands and unsaved beings feel strong
         discomfort and conviction when they enter unfallen elven lands. Neither Johnson nor Stone’s scenarios
         negate the universal effects of the Adamic Fall; it simply notes a localized exception caused by a
         unique local phenomenon. Think of it this way: gravity isn’t negated when a rocket leaves the planet.
         (Pp. 299-300)
My previous book in this series, MMP4, contained the following statement:
         For the sake of Christian science fiction, I will pose a completely theoretical option. When God broke
         up humanity at the Tower of Babel, He could have had His angels take couples from this planet
         to galaxies throughout our universe to act as derivative Adam-and-Eve propagators in a
         panspermia dispersion of humanity. Their human dependents would be more scientifically advanced
         than we are on Earth because humanity on each of those planets would be unified through a common
         language. Through prophets that God would rise up on their planets, they could have been kept
         apprised of what happened here on the Eden Planet and of the atonement made available for
         them here. The death of Christ on the Eden Planet, namely Earth, would thus avail for them
         also, and they would hear of it through their prophets. Christ need not die on their planets
         because His death on our planet was for the whole human race (for all the descendants of the
         original Adam and Eve) and thus would apply to them also. Thus, the whole of creation groans
         from the fallen humanity dispersed throughout our universe.
        When I released MMP4 (in 2018), I was not predisposed to the probability of aliens (i.e., non-Adamic sentient
life) existing on other planets in our universe. At most, I would have allowed the possibility of unfallen sentient life
on planets in other universes in the multiverse. However, in MMP5, having now adopted the plausibility of pre-
Adamic humanoid life on other planets in our universe, and with it the probability that unfallen pre-Adamites exist
on other planets in the universe, I am open to the proposition that Peter Stone has presented through his work of
fiction. Theoretically, God could have dispersed some fallen Adamites among unfallen Pre-Adamites.
        Moreover, since every fact is to be confirmed by two or three witnesses (Dt 19:15; Mt 18:16; 2Cor 13:1;
1Tim 5:19; Heb 10:28) and since Breeden and I have born independent witness to the theoretical possibility of
Stone’s fictional scenario, the factual possibility of some such scenario might indeed be considered probable.
Attributing my discovery of Stone’s book to mere coincidence is very difficult since only 25 copies of his book
were sold, and the only way I was able to find a copy was to contact him directly. He graciously provided me with
a PDF copy. Divine providence appears to have played a hand in my discovering and obtaining a copy of A Knight
from Dien (AKFD), which is a very delightful and thought-provoking read.464 Stone fictionally portrays two species
intermingling with earthlings scattered there by God.
        To summarize his fictional scenario, in addition to the Garden of Eden that God created on Earth, God created
an Eternal Garden at about the same time, with its own Tree of Life and Tree of Knowledge, on the far-away-world
of Farwold, where He created two species: the elves and amalehqs. The elves did not eat of the forbidden Tree of

464
      Peter R. Stone, A Knight from Dein (2010).
Excursus on Pre-Adamic Redemption and Reconciliation                                                           Page 371
Knowledge which grew on their planet, but the amalehqs ate the forbidden fruit and chose to serve the Black Dragon
(Satan). At the age of twenty, elves are tested, and if found sinlessly pure, they are allowed to eat of the Tree of Life
and thus become immortal, at which time they become True Elves—sinlessly pure immortals. Shadow Elves do not
partake of the Tree of Life, either for some noble reasons or because they do not pass the test. True Elves are not
allowed to marry humans or Shadow Elves. During the Tower of Babel incident on Earth, God scattered various
races of humans from Earth to other planets, such as Farwold. These various human races have their own languages
as a result. The dwarfs were one of the human races scattered to Farwold (p. 468-474). The Seven Elven Apostles
on Farwold told the message of salvation that God accomplished on Earth. They bear witness to the redeeming
death that Jesus died on Earth to make salvation possible to all who believe in Him (pp. 99, 334). They have their
own scriptures that bear witness to this fact (pp. 266, 616). Satan, the Black Dragon, operates on both planets
(pp. 419, 546-554). Nephilim also exist on Farwold (pp. 541-542).
        In my personal correspondences with Stone in which I was seeking to obtain a copy of his book, I shared my
excerpt above from MMP4, in which I said, “The death of Christ on the Eden Planet, namely Earth, would thus
avail for them also, and they would hear of it through their prophets. Christ need not die on their planets because
His death on our planet was for the whole human race.” He pointed out that this approach was exactly what he used
in his book, except that he had “extended Christ’s death to apply to all the fallen on Farwold.” I mentioned to him
that I consider that extension improbable and prefer to limit Christ’s “incarnation and redemption to Adamites.”465
He concurred that he had subsequently come to the same conclusion, saying:
              I also agree that Christ’s redemption can only apply to Adamites, i.e., Christ had to become
      our kinsman redeemer, one of the flock, i.e., fully human, for his blood to be able to cleanse humans
      of sin. Not something I considered deeply enough when writing AKFD. One possible way around that
      in regard to the elves and amalehqs, would be that they could be baptized into the human race,
      becoming ‘human,’ before they can receive Christ’s forgiveness. Kind of like in the Old Testament
      when people of other nations, e.g., Uriah the Hittite, would be baptized into the Israelite nation,
      becoming ‘Jewish,’ so they could receive the promises of Abraham too.466
As to this possible workaround, I responded:
             I hold the angel-human hybrid view of the Nephilim. Michael Heiser’s Unseen Realm is a good
      reference work in that regard. Various writers subscribing to that school of thought believe that DNA
      corruption was a highly contributing factor to the Flood. Additionally, the mark of the beast is thought
      to involve DNA modification, making salvation impossible since the humans taking it would become
      post-human, and thus not savable since salvation is limited to humans. It would be interesting to
      speculate that the reverse might be true, that DNA modification via some form of baptism would allow
      some non-human aliens the possibility of becoming human, producing human blood, and thus
      redeemable via the kinsman redeemer. Redemption of the alien through proselytization in the OT
      might play into this theme. Sounds like the stuff of speculative Christian fiction.467
       Though I consider such speculations highly improbable, they would be interesting for speculative Christian
fiction. Most likely, given the limits of our present understanding, I continue to propose that the soteriological
benefits of Christ’s atoning incarnation and death are limited to Adamites. Redemption is limited to
humanity. I am skeptical that the testing posed by the Tree of Life and the Tree of Knowledge would have been
replicated on other planets, though I cannot see sufficient reason for completely ruling out such a possibility. If
alien species were given some such test, those who pass could become immortals or even bridal companions (i.e.,
gods and goddesses). Given my premise, ETs who fall into sin would be left without a redeemer. God did not have
to provide a redeemer for the human race. He did so by grace, not by compulsion. Therefore, one cannot insist that
God must have provided a redeemer for fallen Pre-Adamites or fallen Non-Adamites on this or other planets.
       But why would God provide such a test if He was not going to make redemption available to those who
fell the test? For the same reason, He allowed the angels to be tested even though He did not make redemption
available to them. God allowed sin so that He might be more fully known and loved by those who pass the
test and so that the redeemed who pass the test might more fully partake of His nature than they could have

otherwise. In any case, I would allow the possibility of some sort of testing, even allowing the possibility of God
scattering fallen humans among unfallen aliens and making the gospel known to these fallen humans via prophets
and/or angels. The unfallen aliens could advance themselves misthologically and become gods and goddesses by
resisting the sin posed by the presence of sinful humans on their planet. Fallen aliens, however, like fallen angels,
would be left with no hope of redemption.
                                           Reconciliation of Fallen Angels
        As a counterpoint of view, Brook’s fictional portrayal of a fallen angel features a fallen angel being redeemed
by the blood of Christ. She appeals to Col 1:19-20 in support, with this explanation to the fallen demon, “He has
heard your prayers. With His blood He has redeemed you from Satan’s bondage, just as He has all of humanity,
and reconciled you, as He has all things in creation.”468 Some go so far as to pose that all fallen angels, including
Satan, will experience harmonious universal reconciliation. I had attended a Bible conference a few years back in
which such a claim was exuberantly adopted via a mistaken translation of Rev 20:10. The speaker had translated it
as a singular age. Afterward, I pointed out to him that it refers to ages of ages. According to his own argument, this
plural-of-plural translation would be eternal torment forever and ever, not for a limited number of ages.
        Another speaker at the conference, James Hollandsworth, with leanings toward universal atonement,469 asked
that I read John Wesley Hanson’s book, Aion-Aionios: The Greek Word Translated Everlasting, Eternal in the Holy
Bible, Shown to Denote Limited Duration. I did so. Subsequently, someone else who had attended the conference
asked for my assessment. The gist of my response was that Hanson asserts that in “ages of ages, we get the idea of
long, indefinite, but limited duration, for as an age is limited, any number, however great, must be limited. The
moment we say the smoke of their torment goes up for eternities of eternities, we transform the sacred rhetoric
into jargon” (emphasis his, KL 964-975). Hanson’s argument, at least as presented in this section, misses the point.
Aion refers to age. The plural would speak of plural ages, not plural eternities. However, eternity can be broken
up into an infinite number of plural ages. This is done in Rev 20:10 with ages of ages. Even if the plural ages of
plural ages did not necessarily denote eternity regardless of the context, the context of Rev 20:10 has placed it on
the doorstep of eternity by placing it in Rev 20:10. The millennial age is completed; now those cast into the Lake
of Fire will be tormented for ages of ages. All grammatical and contextual indications are of eternal consequences.
Basically, as it seems to me, the proposal of harmonious universal reconciliation is saying that it does not matter if
you believe in Christ or live for Christ in the long run. In the end, the devil will crawl in bed with Christ and be part
of His Bride.470 Misconstruing universal reconciliation with universal redemption mars the beauty of the Bride and
should be rejected as repulsive. A picture from Face of Season 11, Episode 2 would summarize my feelings on the
matter. Can those who mar the beauty of the Bride with such abhorrent teaching realistically expect to be a part of
the Bride? Certainly, they jeopardize any such hope.

                                Excursus on Physical Angels
        Presumably, angels are intrinsically immortal because they are spiritual. However, Quarterman apparently
believes that angels initially were physically immortal beings. The fallen angels, in any case, fall into that category,
albeit inconsistently in his analysis:

                Fallen angels are eternal and therefore must reinvent themselves every generation or risk
         exposure. They operate very much as the fictional characters of the popular television series
         Highlander. The premise of the series is that the Highlanders must, every generation, disappear and
         reinvent themselves somewhere else in order not to call attention to the fact that they don’t age, for if
         it were revealed that they didn’t age, their game would be up. Thus, Lucifer and his cohorts, the fallen
         angels, have to operate similarly in order to avoid detection. (Quarterman, Angels, 23.)

                Now the serpent was in the Garden of Delight as well as the beney ‘elohim. These “sons of God”
         (beney ‘elohim) had access to the garden and were known to Adam and Eve. Adam and Eve were
         familiar with these other worldly beings known as gods, and they were spectacular creatures to behold
         in their goings and comings; the serpent used these spectacular beings to tempt Adam. These beings
         were at first called “Watchers.”
                The Watchers were humanoids, composed of a physical and spiritual nature. They are specific
         angels given charge to watch over humanity. Watchers originally were physical, but they attained
         ascension and immortally upon their home world sometime in the vast eons past and were given by
         God the ability to convert themselves to energy for interstellar travel. (Quarterman, Angels, emphasis
         his, 43-44.)

               THE CONSPIRATORS HAVE A LONG and dark history. Their history spans eons of time.
         Once they were the players upon the grand stage of the cosmos. Once they colonized worlds, traded
         among the stars, and held high and exalted places. Now they hide among us” (Quarterman, Angels,
         109).

                Angels might be humanoids, composed of a physical and spiritual nature. Perhaps before the
         creation of the world, in the eons past, they were only physical. This would mean humans and angels
         are just on different levels of ascension. (Quarterman, Angels, 125)

       Granted, some RETs take similar views. Contrastively, in my opinion, the angels and Watchers were
immortal spiritual beings who would take a physical form temporarily to rule and trade in our dimension. However,
to take a physical form capable of sexual copulation with human beings resulting in reproduction, they had to
transgress their boundaries in such a way as to take a physical form permanently that could no longer revert
spiritually. Unfallen angels could commingle socially with pre-Adamites and Adamites, including Adam and Eve.
Yet, to copulate reproductively with humanoids and/or humans, angels had to take a physical form more fully and
permanently so that they could produce sexually reproductive seed. They had to leave both their state and estate
permanently to reproduce sexually: “And angels who did not keep their original state and estate, but abandoned
their proper mode and abode, He has kept in eternal bonds under darkness for the judgment of the great day”
(Jude 1:6; TM). In doing so, they became subject to physical death (Ps 82:6), though we may suppose that they
would have exceedingly long lives and retain supernatural powers. According to Jude 1:6, they forfeited both their
proper (1) plain of existence, habitat, abode (arche) and their native (2) form of existence, natural state of existence,
mode of existence (oiketerion), when they sexually exchanged one type of body for another.471 As noted in MMP4,
Bill Schnoebelen maintains that fallen angels must drink blood to become sexually reproductive mortals. My
conjecture is that not until this point are they able to produce sexually reproductive physical seed. If Quarterman
were consistent, he would seemingly have to adopt a similar conclusion since he also acknowledges: “These fallen
angels under Samyaza conspired together to take upon themselves bodies of flesh in order to marry the daughters
of men. This they knew would be a one-way trip, knowing they would be barred from returning back into the

471
      For instance, see Fortson (Noah, 118-19), Bauckham (WBC), and Pember (Ages, 317).
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                 Page 374
spiritual realm having once disobeyed the Lord’s command” (p. 60). In the end of time, all fallen angels will be
forced to take physically mortal bodies (p. 113): “The Dark Lords will be cast out of the spiritual places into the
physical. What this means is that the spiritual, fallen angels will be forced to take physical bodies! Woe to the
inhabitants of the earth!” Per his own statements, this will not be the case until that point in time. Thus, we should
conclude that the only fallen angels currently living among us like Highlanders are those who have taken a physical
form capable of producing reproductive seed.
       Paul apparently acknowledges that presently there are gods in Heaven and on Earth: “As concerning therefore
the eating of those things that are offered in sacrifice unto idols, we know that an idol is nothing in the world, and
that there is none other God but one. For though there be that are called gods, whether in heaven or in earth, (as
there be gods many, and lords many) but to us there is but one God, the Father, of whom are all things, and we in
him; and one Lord Jesus Christ, by whom are all things, and we by him” (1Cor 8:5-6). Paul does not deny the
existence of the gods and lords associated with idols; rather, he is saying that in reality, they are fallen spirits
(1Cor 10:19-21). Taylor (NAC) affirms:

      His agreement with the “nothingness” of the so-called gods (8:5a) is not a denial of their presence in
      the world (8:5b), nor of the existence of evil spiritual powers in the worship of false gods.41 Paul’s
      point is that over against the many gods and the many lords of the heathen world stands the Christian
      acclamation of one God and one Lord (8:6).

Even allowing the popular translation of lego (called) as so-called, Ciampa (PNTC) concurs:

              That “there are many ‘so-called’ gods” and indeed “many gods and many lords” affirms the Old
      Testament’s recognition that pagan gods, while not really gods in any sense comparable to the God of
      Israel (and thus only “so-called” gods), do represent some reality. This may echo Deuteronomy 10:17,
      where, just a few chapters after the Shema, the Israelites are told, “the LORD your God, he is God of
      gods and LORD of lords.” That is the only text of the Hebrew Bible where “gods” and “lords” appear
      in the same sentence as in 1 Corinthians 8:5.

In any event, various OT passages denoting angels as gods have been noted herein (Ex 15:11; 18:11; Dt 10:17;
1Chron 16:25; 2Chron 2:5; Ps 82:1,6; 95:3; 96:4; 97:9; 135:5; 136:2). Some texts indicate that some of these gods
became mortal so that they might mate with human mortals.
                             Excursus on God’s Spacetime
                                                  Introduction
       POV provided a summation of “Five Views of Time” and my preference for the A-theory of time as opposed
to the B-theory of time, positing that—via God’s own innate knowledge (derived from His own immutable, internal,
nontemporal essence)—God was able to see (via middle knowledge) His own creative potential (via perfect self-
knowledge) for all possible worlds that He might create and decide which world He actually would make.472
                                  Illustration 124. Four Views of God and Time

                    Time                              Before               Now
      Helm                     B-theory             Not       Temporal Not Temporal
      Craig                    A-theory             Not       Temporal     Temporal
      Wolterstorff             A-theory                       Temporal     Temporal
      Padgett                  A-theory        Metaphysically Temporal     Temporal
      God’s foreknowledge and predestination occurred in His metaphysical time and therefore had a chronological
sequence in God’s time as opposed to our physical time. Helm holds the B-theory of time and believes that God is
atemporal (thus existing outside of time). Wolterstorff and Padgett hold an A-theory of time and thus agree God is
temporal (thus experiences time). Craig takes a hybrid view and poses that God is now temporal since the creation
of spacetime as we know it.473 The atemporal position is objectionable, and Craig’s partial concession to it is
inconsistent. A variation of Padgett’s view is superior. As also noted in POV, Forlines rejects the timeless eternal
now theory in favor of defining time not merely as the sequence of events but more specifically as “the possibility
of succession of events. The possibility exists whether the events are present are not…there is no reason for not
believing time to be eternal.”474
                                               A Definition of Time
       The present treatment in MMP5 expands upon that discussion from POV by noting that God exists in a
metaphysical location that corresponds to His metaphysical time. Forlines derives his statement above from James
Buswell’s definition of time as the relational possibility of durational sequence. Similarly, Buswell’s definition of
space as the conceptual possibility of dimensional relationships leads Forlines to follow Buswell’s example in also
affirming the eternality of space: “Space would be eternal. Space would not have to be created. The possibility
of having objects was eternal.”475 When God subsequently created objects in (that) space, a distance would have
been created between the objects, but the space was already there. We might say that God had to have a place to
put them, and this place was the conceptually pre-existing space. For my retrogressive analysis, I would pose that
God created a place for us within His metaphysical space. Plus, He made it while He was present in His eternal
metaphysical space. This created space was already a conceptual possibility before God chose to actualize it.
                                                 Space is Room
      Within his Systematic Theology in the section entitled, “God Acts in Space,” Buswell surmises:

             We must not leave the subject of the omnipresence of God without pointing out that as the
472
    A-theory—also referred to as the process or dynamic view: Events are in the past, present, and future. Now is
an objective state of reality. If the A-theory is true, then God is temporal and experiences change.

after). Now is a subjective state of mind. God is atemporal, so everything that happens in our time frame is an eternal
now to Him.
