      Scripture presents it, it is not a doctrine which denies that God operates in space. In Being and Knowing
      I have discussed the nature of space at some length. Space is not a container, it is simply room. It is
      not the actual relationship between physical objects, it is the abstract possibility of relationships in
      different directions and dimensions.476
                                                    Omnipresence
        As I was adding this note and reading over Buswell’s section on God’s omnipresence being expressed as
infinite in His being, my wife, Dianne, came home from getting her hair done and asked what I was working on
now. I responded that I was still working on the discussion in my book, which I summarized for her previously by
asking, “Where was God before He created anything?” Previously, she had responded, “Well, He had to be
somewhere.”477 This time, though, she immediately responded, “Everywhere, all the time.” This popular summation
that God is everywhere leads me to ask a variety of spatial questions. Is God in your cup of coffee? Is He in your
toothpaste? Is He everywhere like peanut butter spread out on a piece of bread? Is He spread out through 7D space?
Or is He localized to one place in 7D space? In my illustrations in the present book, I have pictured God as being
localized like a person, not spread out like peanut butter. God is personal and should be perceived in personal terms,
not in impersonal terms like peanut butter. Buswell rightly gives a rebuttal to the notion that God is spread out:

             The word “immensity” is used by some of the best of the theologians to describe God’s
      omnipresence. I suggest that this word should be avoided. That which is immense is relatively big, and
      partly here and partly there. The doctrine of the omnipresence of God is by no means a doctrine of His
      immensity. God is not partly with us and partly with our distant friends. God is here in His personal
      being and God is there with them in that distant place. (Emphasis his, 38.)

If God is not partly here and partly there, as Buswell insists, then God is not spread out like peanut butter. Perhaps
my analogy of peanut butter will help Buswell’s explanation and rejection of immensity stick. In any case,
Bilezikian provides powerful illustrations of his own to get the point across:

              If by omnipresence we mean that God’s energizing power permeates this whole universe
      because he makes all things hold together, we are biblically correct. But if by omnipresence we mean
      that God is actually present in all places, this is wrong. God is not present in the bottle of liquor
      that is slowly killing your neighbor. God is not present in the pornographic magazines that poison the
      minds of our children. God is not present in a sexual act that transmits AIDS or results in an abortion.
      God is not present in the empty can that I kick around, because I would be controlling him with my
      boot. Such a narrow understanding of omnipresence runs the risk of de-spiritualizing God and of
      identifying him with the material world. Because he is transcendent, God has the capacity to be
      actively present any place where he wishes to be or where he is needed and called upon. But no
      part of his creation can contain him or parts of him. The popular idea of omnipresence is too limited
      to describe adequately the magnitude of the transcendent God.478 (Italics his.)

       Bilezikian’s statement is good insofar as it goes, but it leaves questions about 7D space unanswered. For
instance, can 7D space contain God? In my model, 7D space is eternal. This metaphysical space is not a part of
God’s creation. Therefore, Bilezikian’s statement about God not being contained in part of His creation is not
directly applicable to 7D space. Granted, God cannot be contained in created space. What about uncreated space?
Buswell’s comment, that space is not a container, however, would seemingly apply to 7D space. To pursue his
thoughts in that regard, I consulted his discussion in his book, Being and Knowing. Therein, he maintains that God
is everywhere, just like Dianne said the second time, but Buswell adds a supposed clarification that seems more like
a contradiction: “If we say that God is in space, we do not mean that He is contained in anything, but that He acts
in and upon extended things and local things. This is involved in the doctrine of the omnipresence of God. God is

476
    James Oliver Buswell, Jr., A Systematic Theology of the Christian Religion, vol. 1 (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan
Publishing House, 1962), 39.
477
    See 7D Ultraspace, 282
478
    Gilbert Bilezikian, Christianity 101: Your Guide to Eight Basic Christian Beliefs (USA: Zondervan, 1993), 27-
28.
Excursus on God’s Spacetime                                                                                   Page 377
                                                                                                             479
not an extended being, partly here and partly there. God is everywhere as a total personal presence.” How is
that possible? It sounds like Buswell has God spread out like peanut butter but fully present everywhere—as if the
whole jar of peanut butter is fully located at every point on the bread. His explanation might seem plausible as long
as one is consistent with his definition of space therein as “the mere abstract possibility of dimensional
relationships” (emphasis his, 41). Yet the moment you start to think of God in personal terms, rather than as a mere
abstraction, Buswell’s explanation is called into question. I would pose instead that God, at least in the persons of
the Father and Son, are spatially extended beings, and point out that Jesus’ statement in Jn 14:23 certainly seems
counter to Buswell’s statement that God is equally present everywhere: “Jesus answered and said to him, ‘If anyone
loves Me, he will keep My word; and My Father will love him, and We will come to him, and make Our abode with
him.’” Plus, his illustrations in his Systematic Theology seem to counter his abstract definition and statement. God
does not abide equally with everyone.
       So let us return to Buswell’s discussion of omnipresence from his Systematic Theology:
              I find it helpful to express the omnipresence of God by the thought that everything in the entire
      universe is immediately in His presence. As I work at my desk, everything on the desk is immediately
      in my presence. Of course there are space relationships. I reach for my pen; I arrange my papers; but
      for all practical purposes space is no problem—it is all in my presence.
              As one speaks from the pulpit, every person and every object in the auditorium is in the
      speaker’s presence. Actually there are space relationships, but space relationships are entirely
      irrelevant to the presence of the speaker. I remember well a childhood impression as my father from
      the pulpit said, “Everyone in the world is immediately in the presence of God, just as everyone in this
      room is immediately in my presence.” I do not know that he had in mind any attempt to expound the
      doctrine of omnipresence more than to give it a practical application, but the illustration has remained
      with me. Everything in the universe is immediately in the presence of God.
              To think of God in the light of these illustrations is helpful. Space is no problem to the almighty
      personal presence of God. He hears, He sees, He acts immediately everywhere in the universe. He is
      not “a God afar off” (Jer. 23:23). He is “a God at hand.” We are immediately in His presence. (Pp. 38-
      39.)
He well states: “Everything in the universe is immediately in the presence of God.” I would add my own
observation, though: “Everything in the universe is not equally in the presence of God” (e.g., Mt 18:20;
Jn 14:23). Sticking with my peanut butter analogy, we should not picture God as spread out unevenly like peanut
butter.
                                             Omnipresence and Space
                          Illustration 125. Is God’s Omnipresence Like Peanut Butter?




479
  James Oliver Buswell, Jr., A Christian View of Being and Knowing: An Introduction to Philosophy (Grand
Rapids, MI: Zondervan Publishing House, 1960), 40.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                Page 378

      God is not like an immense jar of peanut butter that has been spread out unevenly even across space, with
more in one place than another. To expound upon Buswell’s illustration, just because everything in my study is in
my presence does not mean that all items in my study are equally in my presence. My keyboard and monitor are
much more in my presence as I type this statement than the papers in my filing cabinet. God can move in more
intimate association with some of His objects than others. This movement can occur in both His time and ours.
Indeed, our time and place are within His time and place. As noted in POV, omnipresence does not necessarily
mean that God is present everywhere but that everywhere is present to God. Therefore, I am skeptical of Forlines
making immensity the basis for omnipresence:

             Frequently, there is no distinction made between omnipresence and immensity. When a
      distinction is made, immensity refers to the infinity of God’s essence. Omnipresence speaks of God as
      being present everywhere for a relationship to His creation. It is the immensity of God that forms the
      basis for His omnipresence.
             Wherever we go, God is there (Ps. 139:7-12; Jer. 23:23; Acts 17:24-28; and others). We cannot
      run from His presence to flee His judgment. We will never find ourselves at a place where He is not
      when we need Him. He is the ever present One. (P.71).

Forlines’ explanation makes it sound like God’s essence must be spread out infinitely, like an infinite jar of peanut
butter, to make it possible for God to be present personally. Buswell’s rejection of immensity is superior, and
Bilezikian’s objections are applicable as well. In his “Introduction” to God & Time, Ganssle presents a similar
commendable perspective regarding omnipresence highlighted in yellow below, and yet moves on to make some
questionable assumptions regarding spatiality highlighted in cyan:

             It is God’s direct access to every point in space that constitutes his omnipresence. If we do
      not think of God as existing literally somewhere (that is, at some location in space) it is easier to
      think of him as standing outside space and creating it, and acting within it. Some of the reason
      that it is easy to think in this way is that we often think of space as a container—sort of like a
      box—in which all of the events of the universe happen. God created the box and stands outside
      it watching. He also interacts with the things in the box.
             Where was God when he created the box? If God “stands outside” the box, he does not do
      so in any literal way. There is no place outside of space. If all of space is in the box and came into
      being when God created the box, then God was not in any place when he created space. If God
      stands outside the box, then he does not stand at any place as he stands there. Where can we go
      from his presence? Nowhere! Everywhere we go, he is there. He is there in that he has direct knowledge
      and access to every place we could go. We do not mean that God is contained in every place in the
      universe. When we say that God is everywhere, perhaps we do not mean either that God is spread
      out throughout the physical universe or that God is wholly located at every point in the universe.
      Instead maybe we mean that God is not contained in space and that he has direct access to every
      point in space.
             Did God create time in the same way he created space? If so, is he standing outside time? What
      of God’s relation to time? God is, the psalmists affirm, “from everlasting to everlasting.” He is not
      limited by time. He did not have a beginning in time, nor will his existence end in time. But is he in
      time the way we are? Is there any sense in which he can be said to be outside time as he stands outside
      space? What is the best way to think about God’s relation to time? This is the question taken by the
      writers of this volume. (Pp. 10-11).

      In his introduction to God & Time: Four Views, Ganssle has prejudiced the discussion from the beginning
against writers who might use God’s spatiality to argue for God’s temporality. True, God is not spread out
throughout the universe because that would make Him like peanut butter. Furthermore, heaven(s) and the highest
heaven cannot contain God (1Kgs 8:27; 2Chron 2:6; 6:18). However, these statements refer to created spaces. If
7D space is uncreated and eternal, then such statements do not apply to it. To use the analogies of boxes, when God
created our spatial and temporal box, I picture Him as standing outside both our time and space in His own
Excursus on God’s Spacetime                                                                                  Page 379
metaphysical time and space. Ganssle, however, says that we are to picture Him standing outside but not standing
in any place, not literally existing somewhere. But how can God be outside the box in that case since there is no
place outside the box? Ganssle wants us to entertain the possibility that God could stand outside our created time,
in a time of His own, when He became Creator, but at the same time to picture Him as not standing outside our
created space, in a space of His own. However, doing so poses a needless inconsistency in the temporalist argument.
Although the temporalists in the book God & Time do not pursue this line of argument, they have weakened their
position in not doing so, and Ganssle has prejudiced the reader against the temporalist argument.
                                                   Immutable Nature
       In the discussion that ensues within God & Time: Four Views, Padgett (one of the four writers within it) will
argue that God changes in time and that changing is part of His perfection, but God does not change “in his basic
attributes, those essential characteristics that he holds as a divine being. God is immutable in nature” (p. 62).
I take this latter statement as an affirmation of ontological immutability. As for change being part of God’s
perfection, Wolterstorff argues similarly: “Change, and the changing experience of change, makes possible a
fullness in the totality of one’s life” (p. 73). Craig also posits: “Timeless life may not be the most perfect mode of
existence” (p. 136).
                                                       Spacetime
        Padgett further acknowledges that “space-time as we know it has a beginning—but God does not” (p. 93). “I
deny that God’s time can be measured by our space-time. Instead space-time is created by God. This implies that
God is beyond the space-time of our universe….God is beyond space-time as we know it” (p. 220). Fine, I agree.
Wolterstorff poses “a seeming paradox” in which “God is both transcendent relative to time and immanent within
time. God both transcends history…and is within history” (p. 220). True. God is transcendent to created time, but
that is our spacetime as we know it. But what about uncreated time? Is God transcendent to His own time, uncreated
time as He knows it. The inverse of Wolterstorff’s argument would be that He is not. God is not beyond His own
uncreated spacetime because His transcendence over spacetime is linked to His being Creator of that
spacetime. If He did not create it, then He is not transcendent beyond it.
        Thus, if God is temporal and exists in time as He knows it from eternity, would it make sense that He dwells
in His own spacetime? Padgett, unfortunately, does not pursue this inference. Instead, regarding the Special Theory
of Relativity, he notes that “time is not like space” and then proceeds to contrast our created spacetime with God’s
uncreated time (p. 105). Padgett’s failure to consider possible spatial implications is particularly disappointing
because his model of divine temporality would be especially conducive to divine spatiality. Since, according to
Padgett’s model, God has His own time beyond our time, the possibility ought to be considered that He might also
have His own space beyond our space.
        Wolterstorff, in his section, “Time but no Space?” outright rejects this possibility:

              Rather often it is objected to those who hold that God’s actions have temporal locations
      that, given the similarities between time and space, they must also hold that God has a spatial
      location; if one holds that God has a history, then consistency requires that God has a location.
      I hold that God does not have a spatial location; so what do I say in answer to the charge of
      inconsistency?
              In advance the charge would seem to have very little going for it. An agent has a spatial
      location on account of having a body; the location of the agent’s body being the location of the
      agent. When the agent speaks of something as here, “here” refers to the region of space in which his
      or her body happens to be located at that time. By contrast, if there’s some variation in the acts that an
      agent performs, then the agent has a history; then it is “in” time. But if one doesn’t hold that agents
      are necessarily embodied, then why shouldn’t it be the case that certain agents—God, angels,
      and so forth—have a history without occupying a place?
              In his book Eternal God? Paul Helm offers a more specific version of the objection. He insists
      that to my argument, in “God Everlasting,” that if God were timelessly eternal there would be temporal
      matters that God could never know, a precisely parallel argument can be constructed for the conclusion
      that if God has no spatial location, then there would be spatial matters that God could never know.
      God must have spatial location if God’s actions have temporal location; if one wishes to hold
      that God lacks spatial location, then one must also hold that God is timeless….
              I have a body, God does not; does that imply that there are some facts I can know that God
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 380
      cannot? I know that the kettle is now boiling here; do I thereby know some fact that God cannot know?
      Definitely not. God knows that the kettle is boiling, and knows where I am, thereby knowing what
      region of space is here for me. There’s nothing more God has to know than that the kettle is boiling
      here. (Italics his, 208-209.)

       Given his model, Wolterstorff’s rejection of God having a separate spatiality is quite understandable. Since
Wolterstorff does not believe that God transcends created time as we know it,480 he is consistent in denying that God
transcends created space. After all, since Wolterstorff does not believe that God has a separate time, one should not
expect him to think that God has a separate place. Consequently, he is inconsistent when he is content to insist “that
there is a fundamental dissimilarity between time and space” (p. 231). Of course, space and time are not one-in-the-
same; nevertheless, they do go hand-in-hand.
                                                   God has a Body
       Helm’s atemporal-aspatial linkage of space and time is much more persuasive than Wolterstorff’s
temporal-aspatial disclaimer, which poses that God can have one without the other. Wolterstorff is wrong.
Necessarily, time and space stand or fall together. Moreover, Wolterstorff’s claim that God does not have a body
is suspect as well. Such arguments tend to run along the simplistic line of reasoning that since God is spirit, He does
not have a body. Wolterstorff’s shortsighted argument that God and angels do not have bodies fails to acknowledge
that God and angels have spiritual bodies. For that matter, Jesus sets at the Father’s right hand. Both the Father and
the Son have spiritual bodies that are capable of setting on thrones in metaphysical space. Even if Jesus did not set
at the Father’s right hand until after His ascension (Heb 1:3-4), He sets there now. Jesus is not limited to 4D space
but also inhabits 7D space—in His resurrected body! By Wolterstorff’s own concession, if there is a body, then
there is space. Hence, since Jesus bodily inhabits 7D time, Jesus must inhabit 7D space. The resurrected Christ
now inhabits metaphysical 7D spacetime in a resurrected body. If He can inhabit 7D spacetime now, in His
resurrected physical body, why not admit that He could have inhabited this same 7D spacetime in His metaphysical,
spiritual body before His incarnation?
       In any case, Helm’s criticism of temporalists is that if God is aspatial (i.e., non-spatial, without space), then
He is atemporal (i.e., non-temporal, without time). For Helm, God’s spacelessness and timelessness go hand-in-
hand. If God lacks space, then God lacks time. If God lacks time, then God lacks space. Helm’s article, “God and
Spacelessness,” argues this point. Granted, I find his spaceless-timeless position repulsive and his argument in God
& Time the least persuasive of the four writers. Nevertheless, his criticism and Wolterstorff’s admission demonstrate
that temporality and spatiality are normally linked together and prove my point that Ganssle prejudiced the
discussion from the beginning against the normative temporal argument.

480
    Wolterstorff’s counter to Padgett’s temporal transcendence is weak. Padgett had acknowledged that “God really
does change in order to sustain a dynamic, changing world” (pp. 105-106). This shows that God’s time is not merely
durative but sequential. But Wolterstorff presses this point to mean that we can accordingly “measure the time
between two divine actions; and that would seem to imply that God’s time has been altered into our measured
time…God no longer has the time of pure duration but measured time” (p. 235). Wolterstorff is correct that a pure
duration view of God’s time is objectionable. But he overstates his case when he says that God’s time collapses into
our measured time. No, God’s time is relative to our time, not identical to it. Padgett rightly poses a theory of
relativity, not equitability, between God’s time and ours.
       My elastic model combines the strengths of both their models by posing that God’s time is measurable
relative to our time, yet it is capable of being both durative and sequential. For one thing, as noted in POV, God’s
time could have durative time bubbles interspersed along His sequential timeline, which is relative to, not equitable
with, our timeline. For another thing, as noted herein, God can experience time differently at different levels. For
instance, He might choose to experience time durationally for a time at one level (such as 7D) while experiencing
it sequentially at another level (such as 4D or 3D). Then again, He might simply choose to experience time
sequentially at a faster rate at one level (or in a bubble within that level) while experiencing it slower at another
level (or in a bubble within that level). Consider 2Pet 3:8, for example. One of God’s days at a 4D level or higher
(or in a Heavenly City time bubble) could be a thousand years at the 3D level. The implications are staggering. The
divine Christ in Heaven could have suffered hundreds of years in 4D time while the incarnate Christ was being
crucified for three hours on the cross in 3D time. My supposition is that in His incarnate state, Christ limited the
exercise of His deity in one place at one time. When He ascended after the resurrection, He no longer did so.
Excursus on God’s Spacetime                                                                                    Page 381
                                            Timeless Eternal Now
    The static view of God necessitated by the timeless eternal now logically pictures God frozen outside place
and time. As Forlines demonstrates, God would be stuck in the now position:

               A person has to make a choice between believing in eternal now and believing that God can
         observe human experiences as past, present, and future with equal vividness. If to God, eternity is one
         “now,” all human experiences are one “now” to Him. It is not the same as saying God sees the past
         and future as vividly as He sees the present. To Him, what to us is past and future must be viewed as
         occurring now in the eternal now view. This would be a consistent presentation of the eternal now
         view. It is only when it is consistently presented that it can rightly be spoken of as eternal now.
         (Emphasis his, 68).

The problem this poses in relation to our sins is obvious, as Forlines and Buswell proceed to demonstrate:

                If the past is not past for God as well as man, then we are yet in our sins; Christ has not
         come and never will come, for He is Deity and therefore timeless. But He is said to have come “in
         the fullness of time (chronos)” and “in due time (kairos).” If the past is not past for God, we are yet
         under the wrath and curse of a righteous Judge. Either this, or sin is merely an illusion, and we might
         as well be Eddyistic idealists and be done with the Gospel. (Buswell, Theology, 47).

God cannot put our sins behind Him because they are ever before Him since His now switch is eternally stuck—if
the timeless-eternal-now position is correct. Buswell demonstrates that Charles Hodge wavered in his affirmation
of timelessness, demonstrating that Hodge made statements that are at odds with one another. Buswell responds
with an illustration:

                Why drag in the notion that God’s consciousness is timeless? The answer is probably
         suggested in Augustine’s De Civitate Dei, Book XI, xxi. It is thought that if God is conscious of events
         as they occur in sequence, He must be continuously adding to His knowledge, and hence He cannot
         be regarded as omniscient.
                Such an inference is clearly fallacious. For example, there is a certain view across the Missouri
         River valley as one drives west on the Daniel Boone highway. I have it in my memory (imperfectly of
         course) and as I take an elderly friend for a ride, I describe to him the view which we shall see. I then
         have the view in my anticipation or in my imagination (imperfectly of course), as well as in my
         memory. As we drive westward, the view becomes an actuality in my experience.
                Now, because my memory and my anticipation or imagination are imperfect, my present
         experience may add to my knowledge; but this would not be the case if my memory and imagination
         or anticipation were perfect.
                God always knows perfectly and completely what He will know when tomorrow becomes
         yesterday. His knowledge is not increased in the slightest degree by the fact that His
         consciousness is dynamically and perfectly related to the actual ongoing of finite events.
                Somewhere in his magnum opus, The Faith of a Moralist, A. E. Taylor bluntly says, “If God
         does not know the difference between yesterday and tomorrow, He does not know as much as I do.”
         With this I agree. (Pp. 44-45).
                                         Immutable Omniscience
      In the above quote, Buswell rightly makes a critical distinction between God’s knowledge and His
consciousness, to which I will add my own clarification. God’s perfect omniscient knowledge, which is static
and timeless, should not be confused with His experiential consciousness, which is dynamic and sequential.
                               Ontological Versus Functional Immutability
     Unlike some temporalists, both Forlines and Buswell affirm that God is immutable, yet not necessarily in the
same terms.481 Buswell affirms ontological immutability, though he does not use the term, in his section,

481
      Some temporalists deny ontological immutability. Wolterstorff, for instance, rejects the prooftexts normally cited
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                 Page 382
“Unchangeable in His Being.” Ontology is the study of the nature of being. To affirm that God is unchangeable in
His being is to assert that He is ontologically immutable. Yet, even in this section, Buswell also affirms God’s
immutability in functional terms: “The immutability of God is clearly taught in the Scriptures. ‘I am the Lord. I
change not. Therefore ye sons of Jacob are not consumed’ (Mal. 3:6). By these words we are instructed that God’s
unchangeable purposes in our salvation and His unchangeable character in carrying through His purposes are our
only ground of hope” (p. 47). Buswell’s affirmation of functional immutability is consistent with his section,
“Immutability Dynamic Not Static,” in which he states: “The notion that God’s immutability is a complete
inactivity, a timeless mental and spiritual immobility, is found in the writings of some of our best theologians, but
is nowhere supported by the Scriptures” (p. 52). “The incarnation proves the immutability of God to be dynamic
rather than static” (p. 55).482 Being immutable should not be taken to mean that God is incapable—of thinking,
acting, or feeling. He experiences these activities temporally. Forlines also affirms ontological immutability: “By
the immutability of God is meant that He is unchangeable in His essence and attributes” (p. 70).483 Omniscience is
one of God’s attributes. His omniscience does not have a beginning, end, or sequence and is thus timeless.484
       Accordingly, this aspect of God’s essence is ontologically immutable. God is able to draw upon this
part of Himself, this knowledge of Himself—of His own immutable, eternal, internal, nontemporal essence—
as He thinks, makes decisions, and experiences emotions in real-time throughout eternity. Part of His eternal

for ontological immutability and affirms God’s immutability in other terms (Time, 191-193). He challenges
ontological immutability by challenging God’s supposed simplicity with complexity, posing that God is composite,
compounded (p. 212). Helm’s critical rejoinder is valid to a point:

      He [Wolterstorff] denies that God is what he calls “ontologically immutable,” immutable in his very
      being or nature, but rather immutable in his resolve. But is this sufficiently strong to ground, say, the
      modalities of Hebrews 6:13-16? Is it impossible for God to lie simply because he has resolved not to?
      Might not something come up to make him change his mind? After all, Scripture says that he does
      change his mind. (P. 214)

Although Helm’s criticism of Wolterstorff’s temporal position is valid, Wolterstorff is correct to reject divine
simplicity. For a scholarly explanation, see R. T. Mullins, “Simply Impossible: A Case against Divine Simplicity,”
Journal of Reformed Theology 7 (2013): 181-203. Available at https://philarchive.org/archive/MULSIA-2.
Accessed 11/8/2021. Mullins demonstrates that divine simplicity is incompatible with divine perfection and the
Trinity, that affirmation of the Trinity requires the affirmation of divine diversity. Accordingly, in my composite
view, I ground God’s functional immutability in His ontological immutability.
482
    Buswell, J. O., Jr. (1962). A Systematic Theology of the Christian Religion (Vol. 1, p. 55). Grand Rapids, MI:
Zondervan Publishing House.
483
    Forlines cites a useful illustration from the 1949 edition of Thiessen’s Systematic Theology: “God’s immutability
is not like that of a stone that does not respond to changes about it but like that of a column of mercury which rises
and falls accordingly as the temperature changes. His immunity consists in His always doing the right thing
and adapting” (Truth, 70). Obviously, this is a temporal-functional description of immutability. I would clarify by
suggesting that certain parts of God’s immutability are static like a stone, but other parts of His immutability are
dynamic like mercury. For example, God’s omniscience is static; His consciousness is dynamic. I had the 1979
edition of Thiessen’s Systematic Theology in which the mercury illustration has been apparently removed/gutted by
Doerksen. Supposedly, according to Doerksen’s 1979 redo, God “is free from all succession of time” (p. 78) and
thus atemporal. Yet “God is active and enters into relationships with changing men. In these relationships, it is
necessary for an unchangeable God to change” (p. 83). One is left to wonder if such inconsistencies are original
with Thiessen or added by Doerksen. So, I ordered the original 1949 edition to make that determination. It was a
combination. Doerksen subtracted and added to Theissen’s discussion, but both are guilty of inconsistency. Theissen
inconsistently states that God is immutable in His essence, attributes, consciousness, and will. Forlines leaves off
the latter two and merely affirms God is immutable in His essence and attributes (p. 70). God is not immutable in
His consciousness, and not all aspects of His will are immutable in the sense of being unchangeable.
484
    One might counter that God’s omniscience is durational and therefore sequential in relation to the changes in
His thoughts. However, since His thoughts do not have the capacity to make sequential marks on His omniscience
and since His omniscience does not have the potential to change, this objection fails to make an observable mark
on His omniscience by which time could be measured against it.
Excursus on God’s Spacetime                                                                                     Page 383
essence is timeless in that regard; part is not. God is not simply one or the other. He is composite, both
temporal and atemporal, in that respect. The incarnation proves that God’s immutability is not merely static;
it is dynamic as well.485
        As to Is 57:15, Buswell correctly refutes the notion that eternity necessarily means timeless eternity:

            The late Gerhardus Vos, the noted Calvinistic theologian of the old Princeton, in the first few
      pages of the last chapter of his Pauline Eschatology (reprinted by Eerdmans, 1952) gives effective
      suggestions against the idea of a static eternity. In a footnote on Page 291 he says, “It is usually
      believed that even the Old Testament contains the representation of Jehovah as subjectively existing
      above all progression of time, viz., in Isaiah 57:15, ‘the Lofty One that inhabits eternity.’ It is probable,
      however, that the clause should be rendered, ‘who sits enthroned forever,’ which would retain the
      time-form expression.” (P. 46).

       Eternity is not timeless! As Mullins observes in his book, The End of the Timeless God: “Jesus grants an
everlasting life, not a timeless life.”486 Eternal life is knowing God (Jn 17:3). In granting us eternal life, the Lord is
granting us His kind of life. The members of the Godhead know each other dynamically, not merely statically. They
have known each other dynamically for all eternity. Thus, this eternity is not timeless. They spend eternity knowing
each other. We get to participate in that knowledge experientially.
       God experiences change, in certain aspects, throughout eternity. To illustrate, consider 1Jn 3:9. At our
innermost regenerate core, we share God’s nature and thus cannot sin. We are sinless, not timeless, in this shared
nature. By His very nature, God cannot sin since doing so would be inconsistent with His nature. As Buswell
expounds, God is unchangeable in His holiness (p. 64). Both God and His born-again children are ontologically
immutable in that respect. Our regenerate trichotomous spirit cannot sin, but it can think, feel, and act, thus
experiencing time. It is not immutable in these respects. Yet, it can only think, feel, and act in a manner consistent
with its immutable nature. In the same way, we can deduce that God must act in a manner consistent with His
nature. In contrast to the hybrid solution posed by Craig, my hybrid hypothesis is that God is eternally and
simultaneously (a) conjointly temporal and atemporal, (b) both dynamically and statically immutable. Craig is
correct that posing both is contradictory “in the absence of some sort of model or explanation of how this can be
the case” (Time, 129). However, my model and explanation address that concern. Nor is it unique in such proposals.
Buswell, for example, seems to take a similar position to mine:

      Omniscience means that God always knows precisely and totally that He will know when
      tomorrow becomes yesterday, and He always knows what He will know when tomorrow becomes
485
    In theological terms, weak immutability is superior to strong immutability. In Eternal Now theology, God’s
knowledge of the universe is perceptual (based on His observation of the universe). All time is present to God in
His now, and this is how He knows it. But in classical theism, God’s perfect knowledge of Himself is how He
knows His creative potential. For summation, see R. T. Mullins, The End of the Timeless God (Oxford: University
Press, 2016): 77, 87. For elaboration, see his ch. 6. I am taking somewhat of a hybrid position. In his ch. 6, he will
object to four-dimensional externalism, which poses that God’s atemporal fifth dimension contains all temporal
four-dimensional spacetime. One of Mullins’ objections is that “dimensions do not contain another dimensions” (p.
131). I do not find this criticism persuasive. In my opinion, one dimension can be loosely described as contained in
a higher dimension when the lower dimension (said to be contained within it) forms an overlapping subset of part
of that higher dimension. For example, take a flatlander’s finite 2D dimension (that is like a sheet of paper) that is
contained in a 3D dimension (that is like a box). Just as the 2D paper is contained in the 3D box, so 2D spacetime
dimensional paper is contained in a 3D spacetime dimensional box. Moreover, the higher dimension would have
added dimensions not less. Thus, for the 7D spacetime continuum to contain a lower dimensional spacetime
continuum, 7D must have spacetime attributes; 7D could not be atemporal or aspatial since it contains temporal and
spatial sub-dimensions. However, I would agree with Mullins that God’s knowledge of the time in the sub-
dimensions is not derived from His atemporal observations of the time in those subsets. God is not in a timeless 7D
Eternal Now, gaining His knowledge of the past, present, and future by observing the past, present, and future
simultaneously. Rather, God’s perfect knowledge of Himself gives Him perfect knowledge of all potential and
actual futures. Plus, since God’s 7D dimension is temporal, He can relate to us in real-time.
486
    Mullins, End, xii.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 384
      yesterday. Thus to accept from the Bible a dynamic, not static, conception of God’s infinite, eternal,
      and unchangeable wisdom, is not in any sense to deny that the content of His wisdom is always
      infinite, always the same in its totality and in its every detail. (Italics his, 57)

We have heard the expression stated regarding someone who has undergone a profound change in his character or
personality, “He is not the person he used to be.” This is not true of God. Still, we need not press this to mean that
He cannot have a dynamic personality. Jesus “learned obedience from the things which He suffered. And having
been made perfect, He became to all those who obey Him the source of eternal salvation” (Heb 5:8-9). His innate
omniscient knowledge of what it would be like for Him to learn obedience while suffering was joined with
experiential knowledge when He actually underwent the suffering. His perfect innate knowledge was enjoined with
perfect experiential knowledge: “For it was fitting for Him, for whom are all things, and through whom are all
things, in bringing many sons to glory, to perfect the author of their salvation through sufferings” (Heb 2:10). But
the same writer affirms that Jesus is still the same: “Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and forever”
(Heb 13:8). Buswell does well to affirm Christ’s dynamic immutability during this process:

             When Christ “perfected” Himself, the meaning is not that He was in any sense imperfect, or that
      He in any sense changed in His character, but that in the process of time He did precisely what He had
      always purposed to do….
             In this extremely vivid description of our Lord’s suffering there is not the slightest contradiction
      of His immutability when understood in its dynamic and not in its static sense. He had purposed from
      eternity to undergo these experiences actually in time, place, and history, and so to “learn” in the actual
      experience (not to add to His information), but to make the experience actual and bring about the
      accomplishment of His eternal purpose. (Pp. 53-54)

True, but Christ had an eternal, perfect, static, innate knowledge of this temporal, perfect, dynamic knowledge that
would become His in the process of time. His static perfection became dynamic perfection without undergoing any
change in His underlying static perfection. His character remained constant because it was already informed and
formed by the suffering He would choose to endure because He had already chosen to endure it. The pre-existing
Christ innately foreknew from eternity what He would experientially acquire in time.
                                       Uncreated God-Caused Spacetime
       For a higher degree of scholastic exactitude regarding temporality, discussions by Mullins are highly
recommended. For instance, in The End of the Timeless God, Mullins clarifies that when temporalists defend
absolute time and say that God is temporal and eternally exists in time and space, this is a loose way of saying that
His existence causes time and space (pp. 17-18).487 He exists beyond created spacetime but, loosely speaking, within
caused spacetime. Thus, 7D spacetime is uncreated yet necessarily caused space and time that exists because of
God but is not created by God. It could not exist without God or be independent of God. Does this make God the
prisoner of 7D spacetime?
                                                   Absolute Time
       Mullins responds to the prisoner-of-time objection to divine temporality in his article, “Doing Hard Time.”488
Therein, he limits his discussion to the view held by the Oxford school of divine temporality, so-called because of
prominent scholars who hold this particular view of divine temporality. Instead of taking a relational view of time,
the Oxford school holds to an absolute theory of time that posits that time is the dimension of possible change and
thus can exist without change. I allow this possibility since I pose that God can pause changing if He wishes, which

487
    Mullins cites Clarke, who goes on to say, as Mullins notes, that “boundless space and time are necessary

Ariew (Indianapolis, IN: Hackett Publishing Company, 2000), 104. Since Clarke’s inclusion of boundless is based
on his argument of immensity, I do not include it as part of my perspective. All of 7D space is immediately
accessible by our infinite God via His omnipresence, but I’m not sure that this requires that 7D space to be infinite
since God is not spread out infinitely in 7D space like infinite peanut butter.

    R. T. Mullins, “Doing Hard Time: Is God the Prisoner of the Oldest Dimension?” Journal of Analytic Theology,

51122018a/231. Accessed 11/17/2021.

I picture with time bubbles with bars within it in my chart. Nevertheless, even then, because God is capable of
undergoing change, time still exists. Additionally, according to the Oxford view, God is not strongly immutable but
weakly immutable. “His essential divine nature cannot change, but He can undergo non-essential intrinsic and
extrinsic changes like becoming the Creator, Redeemer, and Lord of humanity” (emphasis his, 165). Obviously, I
hold that view as well. Such distinctions nullify the atemporalist caricatures which object that temporalism locks
God in the same plane of existence as created time. This caricature is false.
       We might think of it this way. God is the Uncaused Cause of caused time and the Creator of created time.
God was the Uncaused Cause of caused time before He became the Creator of created time. God did not have to
wait until He created time to become the Uncaused Caused. The very fact of His existence necessarily caused
something—uncreated spacetime. Absolute time is uncreated time, not uncaused time. Absolute time has a Cause—
God—but no Creator. God is not enslaved or limited by absolute time. Such time is simply concomitant with God’s
being. Indeed, Mullins will move beyond saying that “there never was a time when God was not temporal” to
arguing that “time is simply part of God’s eternal essence” (p. 172). God’s eternal essence is temporal. Again,
eternity is not timeless. Eternity is temporal, being divisible into ages. As to being a prisoner of time, it is true that
God cannot go back in created time and that His time is relative to our time. Does that make Him a prisoner of time?
No, for God would not have chosen to create a world in which He would have wanted to go back in time and undo
the changes for that particular world. Rather, He would have chosen to actualize another potential world out of all
the potential worlds He could have created. No one forced Him to create the world He freely chose to create. He is
not a prisoner to His own free choice.
       As far as going back in time, not even God can do that regardless of whether one takes a temporalist or
atemporalist position, as Mullins explains in End: “It is the case that the cosmic present marks a boundary for God
because God cannot exist at our universe’s past or future. Further, God’s eternal now and our temporal now
stand in a one-to-one correspondence. The very fact that we exist is due to the sustaining presence of God, so
we always exist in God’s eternal present” (p. 37). Plus, from a presentism perspective, “the present moment
is the only moment of time that exists” (p. 105).
                                                  Relational Time
        Although Mullins believes that “time can exist without change” (so the Oxford school of thought), he sets
aside that preference in End to adopt the relational view that “if there is a change there is time.” For the Oxford
absolute time to be true, all that is needed “is some being with duration, and a necessarily existent God fits the
bill” (p. 32). Even so, the common temporalist distinction between created time versus uncreated time and physical
time versus metaphysical time still holds regardless of one’s preference for relational versus durational definition
of time. In any event, according to Mullins, the Bible affirms time before creation:

            In fact, the Bible clearly speaks of time before creation. Psalm 90:2 says, “Before the mountains
      were brought forth, or ever you had formed the earth and the world, from everlasting to everlasting
      you are God.” The from/to formula in this passage is a common formula in scripture used to denote a
      span of time. In this instance, the Hebrew word olam—sometimes translated as eternity depending on
      context—is used twice here to refer to the span of God’s life. It quite literally means from perpetual
      duration in the indefinite past to perpetual duration in the indefinite future. This is a deeply temporal
      portrayal of God. Psalm not only portrays God in temporal terms, it also speaks of God existing alone
      before creation. One would be hard pressed to say that this is not a temporal before since the language
      employed is explicitly temporal. (P. 33)

This passage is even more interesting because it suggests relational duration: succession in the duration. Succession
is the hallmark of divine temporality. The LXE is a particularly thought-provoking translation of Ps 90:2: “Before
the mountains existed, and before the earth and the world were formed, even from age to age, Thou art.” God’s I-
AM metaphysical existence in Ex 3:14 is broken up into metaphysical AGE-To-AGE sequence by Ps 90:2 (cp.
2Pet 3:8).489 Likewise, Revelation repeatably describes God’s existence temporally: “Holy, holy, holy, is the Lord

489
   A clarification needs to be made at this juncture between my treatment and that of standard temporalist
assumptions. Mullins points out: “Metaphysical time is often associated with God’s eternal, everlasting nature. In
contrast to physical time, metaphysical time never came into existence. God resides in eternity” (End, 35). In
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                 Page 386
God, the Almighty, who was and who is and who is to come” (Rev 4:8; cp. Rev 1:4,8; 11:7). Such passages imply
that God has a past, present, and future. Mullins supplies a commendable explanation and alternate translations:

             This exposition of Revelation fits nicely with another common proof-text for divine
      timelessness—Exodus 3:14. This passage has long been, and still is, used as a proof-text for divine
      timelessness, aseity, immutability, impassibility, and simplicity. In this famous passage, God reveals
      Himself to Moses as “I AM WHO I AM.” The reason this is a common proof-text is because it is
      translated in the present tense. Atemporalists contend that the “I AM” should be read as the timeless
      present tense. This, however, is a poor interpretation of the text because the passage implies divine
      temporality. It portrays a God who will be forever divine regardless of what transpires in the future.
      As Wolfhart Pannenberg points out, most exegetes prefer to translate this passage as “I shall be who I
      shall be.” This implies that God has a future. Henri Blocher draws another important point from this
      passage. “I AM, in itself, does not exclude” ‘I was’. This implies that God has a past. (P. 202)

Personally, I am fine with the I-AM translation. It is not a timeless present tense; rather, it is a temporal
present tense, an eternal presentism in which present time is the only moment of time that presently exists so
that anything that exists only exists in God’s eternal present, as opposed to God’s past and future. God has
a past and future, but present reality is the only actualized reality. Jesus indicates the temporalism of the divine
I AM when He said, “Truly, truly, I say to you, before Abraham was born, I AM” (Jn 8:58). “But regarding the fact
that the dead rise again, have you not read in the book of Moses, in the passage about the burning bush, how God
spoke to him, saying, ‘I AM the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob’? He is not the God
of the dead, but of the living; you are greatly mistaken” (Mk 12:26-27).490 I AM can be used in relation to temporal
points in time. God’s present tense has a one-to-one correlation with our temporal present. As noted by Mullins
above, temporalists do not deny God’s eternal now but instead rightly insist that our temporal now stands in a one-
to-one correspondence with His eternal now. God’s durational eternal now is tensed, temporal, and relational. God’s
eternal now is not timeless. Rather, it runs through time. God is not timeless. Because God exists, time exists.
To speak loosely, God exists everywhere all the time because God is not without time, and time is not without God.
More precisely, time exists everywhere that exists, and everywhere that exists is accessible by God in time. Eternity
is not timeless, and God’s I-AM affirmation of now is not timeless. Biblically, the eternal now is not timeless.
                                      Before the Foundation of the World
       The fact that God has performed certain actions before the foundation of the world and that before the
foundation of the world certain actions are considered as good as performed lends support to the proposition that
God makes such decisions in a time outside of our time. Rev 13:8 is a text used by some in defense of the timeless
eternal now position. For example, a blogger asserts:



contradistinction, I believe that angels are 4D created metaphysical beings who exist in created metaphysical 4D
time. Thus, 4D spacetime is created. However, God’s 7D metaphysical time is uncreated. In my view, not all
metaphysical time is non-created, only 7D spacetime falls into that category.
490
    Some commentators say that Jesus’ argument could not be based on the present tense since the verb is unstated
in Mark even though it is stated in Mt 22:32 and the LXX. However, the sense of the verse and the presence of the
tense in Mt and in the LXX bring this objection into dispute. The tense would have been understood from the OT
passage. Tense related comments by other commentators, such as Cole (TNTC, 1989), make more sense:

      In God’s self-revelation made to Moses at the burning bush (Exod. 3:6), God describes himself as the
      God of Abraham, of Isaac and of Jacob. Now to talk of himself as being a God of the past experience
      of these men, as a western philosopher might describe him, would be nonsense to a Hebrew mind: for
      where is the experience apart from the person? Assuredly the experience is not within God; if it was
      so, God would have described himself simply as ‘I AM’, as he did elsewhere (Exod. 3:14). But to
      describe himself as Abraham’s God, Isaac’s God and Jacob’s God is obviously felt to be adding a
      further revelation. Therefore, if God can still so describe himself to Moses centuries after the death of
      these two men, their spiritual experience must still be existent. If so, these three patriarchs must still
      be in existence.
Excursus on God’s Spacetime                                                                                  Page 387
      How can an historical event, which occurred at a certain spot on earth, in the biblical reckoning be said
      to have occurred before the earth was even made? The passage does not say that the Lamb was
      foreordained to be slain before the foundation of the world, but it says He was actually slain then.
      Surely it means that the cross was an eternal event, taking place both in time and eternity. In time, it
      is long past; in eternity, it forever occurs.491

Vacendak (GNTC) expresses a similar sentiment: “The Apostle John is emphasizing that Christ’s atoning death for
man’s sin from God’s perspective actually is timeless, occurring even before the world was ever created”
       As noted in 4DF, expositors debate as to whether to apply the phrase from the foundation of the world in
Rev 13:8 to when the names were written or when the Lamb was slain, although the word order in Greek actually
puts the phrase last, after the Lamb was slain.492 At the very least, their names were written in the Book of Life

491
     See https://christianity.stackexchange.com/questions/31020/what-does-it-mean-for-christ-to-have-been-slain-
