    Aune (WBC) applies the temporal phrase “from the foundation of the world” in Rev 13:8 to the time of the
writing rather than slaying “since it is logically and theologically impossible to make sense of the statement that the
Lamb ‘was slaughtered before the foundation of the world….While it is possible to think of Christ as destined to
die for the sins of the world, it is quite another thing to say that he was slain before the creation of the world”
(emphasis his). I share his disdain for the preposterous proposition that an atemporal crucifixion would be marked
by a temporal phrase. Thus, Aune takes the simple route and applies it to the time of the writing. Walvoord (BKC)
concurs that it relates “to the time in eternity past when the names were written in the book of life, rather than to
Christ’s crucifixion, since He was not crucified when the world was created.” Regardless of whether the phrase is
alluding to the time of the writing, Walvoord is correct that we are not dealing with a timeless eternity past but with
an event or decree made at a particular point in time in eternity past. Mounce (NICNT), on the other hand, applies
the phrase to the crucifixion: “Christ was a redemptive sacrifice decreed in the counsels of eternity.” Even so, the
issue of a decree suggests a sequence, a time before the decree was made and a time after the decree was made—a
sequence in the counsel of eternity, thus a temporal eternity, an eternity marked by the passage of time rather than
a timeless eternity. Ian Paul (TNTC, 2018) is on the right track: “The reference is not to the actual timing of the
lamb’s death (as the narrative of Rev. 12 has made clear), but to the plan of redemption through the blood of the
lamb being in God’s mind from the very beginning, an idea expressed in similar terms in Matthew 25:34; Ephesians
1:4; 1 Peter 1:20.” Lange (ACHS) notes that 1Pet 1:19-20 clarifies that it is the foreordination rather than the
occurrence of His death that actually took place before the foundation of the world. Barnes (BNONT) concurs: “The
meaning here is, not that he was actually put to death ‘from the foundation of the world,’ but that the intention to
give him for a sacrifice was formed then, and that it was so certain that it might be spoken of as actually then
occurring” (emphasis his). Even so, I would suggest that the blood of the lamb was not only in God’s mind from
the very beginning of earthly time but also made possible the actual writing of our names in His book even before
the sacrifice was actually made. Just as we could be chosen in Him before His sacrifice was made because of His
sacrifice which eventually would be made, so we could be recorded in His book beforehand because of the certainty
of His sacrifice.
       Fanning (ZECNT) probably goes too far when he attributes it to “Christ’s atoning sacrifice that began in
eternity past.” Granted, if it had a beginning in eternity past, this would demand a sequence, a temporal view of
eternity, which is commendable. Still, how could it have begun back then? Via fiction, Lamont provides a scenario
that would allow one to have one’s cake and eat it too, so to speak, regarding this inquiry. Her prologue opens with
Rev 13:8 and presents a scene in which Jesus took the form of a lamb and willingly offered Himself to the Father
to be slain on a sacrificial stone table so that He could write, with His blood, a book of those to be redeemed by His
blood to be shed on the cross. The Father slew His Son, who took the form of a lamb. Jesus then presented this
finished book, written in His blood, to the Father. All this took place before the creation of the world and Lucifer’s
rebellion. Her book is very enjoyable and thought-provoking. Nevertheless, she makes a common error in attributing
the creation of time to the creation of our universe. Actually, 4D time was already occurring in the 4D universe
described in her book before our 3D universe was created with its attendant 3D time. The astute reader would have
no problem discerning this to be the case, so it is only a minor inconsistency. I found the same shortcoming in the
Reluctant Demon Diaries by Linda Rios Brook, which I was reading concurrently. She failed to note that sequence,
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 388
before the foundation of the world in anticipation of the Lamb being slain (Rev 17:8). Jesus was considered slain
from the foundation of the world. The efficacy of Christ’s death is not limited by our timeframe. Our sins were
forgiven on the layaway plan, so to speak. The payment was considered as good as done from God’s timeframe.
       If there was a point in God’s timeframe in which God considered the Lamb slain and applied the benefits of
His death beforehand to those who would eventually come to believe within their timeframe, then Christ was not
eternally slain. Vacendak and the blogger make a logical error. The benefits of His death were applied beforehand,
in God’s time, when He recorded our names. Thus, they were recorded in a one-to-one relationship between His
temporal timeframe and ours. Christ’s death and our record are tensed, temporal, and relational.
                                                     Conclusion
       This concluding excursus provides conclusive evidence for the proposition of the last chapter of this book,
namely, that God exists eternally in time and space. This book has tentatively posed that God’s spacetime continuum
might be 7D. Our spacetime continuum is a four-dimensional continuum, having three spatial coordinates and one
temporal coordinate. For simplicity’s sake, it has been simply referred to herein by its three spatial coordinates, thus
as 3D space. Likewise, the proposition of God’s ultraspace has been expressed in simple spatial terms as 7D space.
The overall rationale is rather simple. We exist in 3D space. Angels exist one spatial dimension higher than we do.
Thus, they exist in 4D space. Some mistakenly think that 4D space is timeless just because it is metaphysical, but
such thinking is obviously errant because various activities are taking place in this 4D space. Therefore, 4D space
has its own metaphysical temporal coordinates.
       Since the Bride is a higher entity than the angels, She should be perceived as being ontologically superior to
the angels. Thus, She would be at least a 5D being. Moreover, since She is like Christ, though not equal to Christ
(Phil 3:21; 1Jn 3:2), one may pose that She is semi-omnipresent. Since 4D angels are not semi-omnipresent in 3D
space, the hypothesis was proposed that the Bride is two dimensions higher than the highest dimension in which
She would be semi-omnipresent, which would lead to the conclusion that She will be a 6D being so that She can be
semi-omnipresent in 4D space or 3D space. The Lord would have to be at least one dimension higher, thus a 7D
being who resides in uncreated 7D space and time.
       This excursus defends the proposition that God does indeed reside in His own spacetime continuum. He has
the capacity to be actively present at any place or in as many places as He wishes in 5D, 4D, or 3D spacetime
continuums. God is not present in everything or present everywhere, but everything and everywhere is available to
Him. He is not spread out like an eternal mist or fog or peanut butter through His own dimension or these lower
dimensions. Rather, they are accessible to Him, and He can replicate Himself in these lower dimensions. The Bride
will also have this capacity. God may be said to reside in an eternal now, but this eternal now is not timeless. The
oxymoron is that it is a temporal eternal now. God’s 7D temporal now is eternal. Eternity can be divided up into
countless ages, not timeless ages.




and thus time, was occurring in the third heaven before Lucifer was cast out of it. To be sure, time operates
differently in the different dimensions; nevertheless, it is time, nonetheless.
                                 Excursus on the Kingdom
                                                    Introduction
       The offer of the kingdom to the Jewish people and the withdrawal of that offer is a central theme of the
Gospel of Matthew (GM). The most pivotal verse regarding its withdrawal occurs in Mt 21:43, where Jesus responds
to the Jews who have rejected Him by saying, “Therefore I say to you, the kingdom of God will be taken away from
you, and be given to a nation producing the fruit of it.” Does this mean that the Church has replaced Israel as the
recipient of the promises of God regarding the Promised Land? To hear Blomberg (NAC), you would think so:
“Jesus is not so much foreshadowing the shift of God’s activity from Jewish to Gentile realms as anticipating the
replacement of Israel by the church, which will unite both Jew and Gentile.” Of course, dispensationalism rightly
rejects the notion that the Church simply replaces Israel as the recipient of the Promised Land. Nevertheless, typical
dispensational answers are not completely satisfying either. In fact, sometimes, they are offsetting.
       Constable (TCENB) provides a churchy answer: “What God did was transfer responsibility for preparing for
the kingdom from Israel and give it to a different group, namely the church (cf. Acts 13:46; 18:5–6; Rom. 10:19;
1 Pet. 2:9)….Jesus did not mean that God would remove the kingdom from Israel forever (cf. Rom. 11:26–27).
When Jesus returns to the earth and establishes His kingdom, Israel will have the most prominent position in it
(Gen. 12; 15; 2 Sam. 7; Jer. 31).” Barbieri (BKC) rejects the churchy answer but concurs with the temporary
explanation:

      Two interpretations of this verse are often presented. One is that Jesus was saying the kingdom had
      been taken from the Jewish nation and would be given to Gentile nations who would produce the
      proper fruit of genuine faith. It is argued that since ethnei is singular, not plural, the word refers to the
      church which is called a nation in Romans 10:19 and 1 Peter 2:9–10. But the kingdom has not been
      taken completely away from Israel forever (Rom. 11:15, 25). And the church is not now inheriting the
      kingdom.
             A better interpretation is that Jesus was simply saying the kingdom was being taken away from
      the nation Israel at that time, but it would be given back to the nation in a future day when that nation
      would demonstrate true repentance and faith. In this view Jesus was using the term “nation” in the
      sense of generation (cf. Matt. 23:36). Because of their rejection, that generation of Israel would never
      be able to experience the kingdom of God (cf. comments on 21:18–22). But a future generation in
      Israel will respond in saving faith to this same Messiah (Rom. 11:26–27), and to that future generation
      the kingdom will be given.

So, some dispensationalists believe that the offer of the kingdom has been temporarily withdrawn from the Jews
and given to the Church (so also NIBC, Toussaint-Matthew). Others think that it has been temporarily withdrawn
from the Jews and will be given to the millennial generation of Jews (so also Phillips-JPCS).
                           Kingdom of God (KOG) versus Kingdom of Heaven (KOH)
Generic Contextual Considerations
       The Gospel of Matthew (GM) uses the phrase kingdom of God (KOG) in four or five verses: Mt 6:33 (MT);
12:28; 19:24; 21:31,43. The first occurrence in the CT (thus Mt 12:28) is where many commentators explain why
they believe that Matthew deviates from his much more prevalent term, kingdom of heaven (KOH), which Matthew
uses in thirty-one verses, to use KOG on these four or five rare occasions. France (NICNT) attributes the change in
phraseology to various contextual considerations: “Such departures from normal usage are ‘because the context
requires a more ‘personal’ reference to God himself rather than the more oblique language of his heavenly
authority.’” Hagner (WBC) concurs by providing a conjecture for the deviation in Mt 12:28, saying, “Here it is
preferred probably to serve as the direct opposite of the reference to the kingdom of Satan in v 26.”
Classic Dispensational Considerations
      Since the phrase kingdom of heaven (KOH) first appears in Mt 3:2, many commentators provide their primary
explanation there. Toussaint (Matthew, 65-68) surveys three different interpretations that pose soteriological,
millennial, or topological distinctions.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 390
                                    Illustration 126. Classical Dispensationalism
      (1) Soteriological—KOG is used of those who are born again (cp. Jn 3:30). KOH includes those who merely
          profess to be born again (cp. tares in Mt 13:40-42 and bad fish in Mt 13:47-50). Therefore, KOG is
          narrower in scope and is a regenerate subset of the professing believers found in KOH. Soteriologically,
          KOG ⸦ KOH.
      (2) Millennial—KOG is inwardly spiritual; KOH is earthly millennial.
      (3) Topological—KOH pertains solely to God’s rule being exercised on planet Earth, whereas the KOG is
          much broader in scope and includes the universe and three heavens. Typologically, KOH ⸦ KOG.

       Thus, depending on the perspective being adopted, the vantage point shifts as to which form of the kingdom
is the subset of the other (KOG ⸦ KOH versus KOH ⸦ KOG). Toussaint rejects the typological notion that the
KOG is broader than the KOH or that the KOH is contained within the KOG, thereby rejecting this subset notion
(p. 67). Since he asserts that KOG and KOH are simply used interchangeably (KOH = KOG), his position would
also reject the soteriological subset proposition. However, his rejection is open to question. He rejects the
soteriological interpretation because “actually the darnel and the bad fish are never said to be in the kingdom of
heavens.” Really? Then why are the tares/darnel said to be taken out of the KOH (Mt 13:41)? Mum is the word.
Toussaint glosses over answering this question on his explanation of that passage. As to the soteriological and
topological interpretations, Toussaint rejects both because both the KOG and KOH are said to be near at hand on
Earth: “The kingdom of God used in its eschatological sense is no less earthly than the kingdom of the heavens.
Christ announced the nearness of the kingdom of God in Mark 1:14-15 and Matthew 12:28” (p. 67). Thus, Toussaint
objects to any notion that the KOH can be a subset of the KOG. Even so, even he goes on to assert that Matthew
“had a special reason for employing” KOG. Toussaint claims the KOH pertains to the fulfillment of OT prophecies
(which would be millennial) while KOG “stresses the character of that kingdom.” Thus, in his opinion, both terms
refer to the same literal, earthly, millennial kingdom.
       Carson (EBC) rejects the classical dispensational view, which is the soteriological view described above:

            Classic dispensationalists (e.g., A. C. Gaebelein, John Walvoord) hold that “kingdom of God”
      is a distinctively spiritual kingdom, a narrower category embracing only true believers, whereas
      “kingdom of heaven” is the kingdom of millennial splendor, a broader category including (as in the
      parable, 13:47–50) both good and bad fish. The distinction is unfortunate. It comes perilously close to
      confusing kingdom and church (see comments at 16:17–19), fails to account for passages where the
      Matthean category is no less restrictive than “kingdom of God” in the other evangelists, and
      fundamentally misapprehends the dynamic nature of the kingdom.

       The classical dispensational view encompasses the soteriological view described by Toussaint. The KOG is
taken classically by dispensationalists, at least in certain contexts, as a soteriological subset of regenerate believers
among the professing believers of the KOH. Even though I do not hold a simplistic view of the kingdom,
conceptually at least, I am not so quick to dispense with the classical dispensation view as part of my perspective.
For example, I have used the following illustration elsewhere in my writings to depict various parts of my view. At
the point of faith, professing believers become soteriologically possessing believers. They have eternal life. They
move from being merely in the present mystery kingdom (which includes both tares and wheat) into the
soteriologically mystical kingdom as born-again believers possessing eternal life. Thus, the mystical form of the
kingdom is a soteriological subset of the mystery form of the kingdom.
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                     Page 391
                                  Illustration 127. Mystery form of the Kingdom




       The present spiritual impact of the KOG is seen in demons being cast out (Mt 12:28) and people entering the
KOG by faith (Mt 19:24; 21:31-32). These latter two passages are not without their challenges, to be sure. Still, the
major problems for the classical view occur in the first and the final occurrence of the KOG. The first occurrence
in the MT is Mt 6:33, where we are told to seek first the KOG and God’s righteousness, and all the things we
currently need will be added to us (KJV, NKJ, ESV). Why is a supposedly soteriological use of the kingdom being
used in a seemingly misthological millennial passage like this? Second, why is a supposedly soteriological KOG
taken away from the Jews and given to another nation in Mt 21:43? Let’s ask the classics.
       Scofield takes the classical soteriological view. Regarding Mt 3:2, he states

              The phrase, kingdom of heaven (lit. of the heavens), is peculiar to Matthew and signifies the
      Messianic earth rule of Jesus Christ, the Son of David. It is called the kingdom of the heavens [KOH]
      because it is the rule of the heavens over the earth (Mt. 6:10). The phrase is derived from Daniel,
      where it is defined (Dan. 2:34–36, 44; 7:23–27) as the kingdom which “the God of heaven” will set
      up after the destruction by “the stone cut out without hands” of the Gentile world-system. It is the
      kingdom covenanted to David’s seed (2 Sam. 7:7–10, refs.); described in the prophets (Zech. 12:8,
      note); and confirmed to Jesus the Christ, the Son of Mary, through the angel Gabriel (Lk. 1:32, 33).
      (Italics his.)

Regarding Mt 6:33, Scofield states:

             The kingdom of God is to be distinguished from the kingdom of heaven (Mt. 3:2, note) in
      five respects: (1) The kingdom of God is universal, including all moral intelligences willingly subject
      to the will of God, whether angels, the Church, or saints of past or future dispensations (Lk. 13:28, 29;
      Heb. 12:22, 23); while the kingdom of heaven is Messianic, mediatorial, and Davidic, and has for its
      object the establishment of the kingdom of God in the earth (Mt. 3:2, note; 1 Cor. 15:24, 25). (2) The
      kingdom of God is entered only by the new birth (John 3:3, 5–7) ; the kingdom of heaven, during this
      age, is the sphere of a profession which may be real or false (Mt. 13:3, note; 25:1, 11, 12). (3) Since
      the kingdom of heaven is the earthly sphere of the universal kingdom of God, the two have almost all
      things in common. For this reason many parables and other teachings are spoken of the kingdom of
      heaven in Matthew, and of the kingdom of God in Mark and Luke. It is the omissions which are
      significant. The parables of the wheat and tares, and of the net (Mt. 13:24–30, 36–43, 47–50) are not
      spoken of the kingdom of God. In that kingdom there are neither tares nor bad fish. But the parable of
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 392
      the leaven (Mt. 13:33) is spoken of the kingdom of God also, for, alas, even the true doctrines of the
      kingdom are leavened with the errors of which the Pharisees, Sadducees, and the Herodians were the
      representatives. (See Mt. 13:33, note.) (4) The kingdom of God “comes not with outward show”
      (Lk. 17:20), but is chiefly that which is inward and spiritual (Rom. 14:17); while the kingdom of
      heaven is organic, and is to be manifested in glory on the earth. (See “Kingdom (O.T.),” Zech. 12:8,
      note; (N.T.), Lk. 1:31–33; 1 Cor. 15:24, note; Mt. 17:2, note.) (5) The kingdom of heaven merges into
      the kingdom of God when Christ, having “put all enemies under His feet,” “shall have delivered up
      the kingdom to God, even the Father” (1 Cor. 15:24–28). Cf. Mt. 3:2, note. (Italics his.)

So, basically, the classical Scofield view includes all three of the classical dispensationalist components objected
to by Toussaint above (see Illustration 126). The classic view sees soteriological, millennial, and topological
distinctions between the KOG and KOH. As to which one is the subset of the other, it depends on what aspect is
being compared and in what timeframe. How about the classical dispensational view as presented by Gaebelein?
His discussion in TAB is very succinct:

      The phrase “Kingdom of heaven” (literally “of the heavens”) occurs here for the first time. It does
      not mean the offer of salvation, nor does it mean the church, nor the social betterment of the people,
      but it signifies the Messianic Kingdom as promised by the Prophets of God, a Kingdom which is to
      be set up on earth and over which the Son of David is to be King.

        Gaebelein’s discussion in his independent commentary provides additional information, wherein he notes
that the kingdom is rejected and thus “the kingdom of the heavens is the literal fulfillment of all the prophecies and
promises contained in the Old Testament, which the Lord gave to the seed of Abraham….It is not set aside
completely, but only postponed” (italics his).493 Wait a minute! If the KOH is the fulfillment of all the OT
prophecies, then, per WH in Heb 11:8-10, the KOH would have to include both the Promised Land (PL) and the
Promised City (PC), which was also cryptically indicated by Moses in Gen 22:17. Could Jesus cryptically be
alluding to the same thing?
        When Gaebelein gets to Mt 6:19-20, he manages to get to first base, but he fails to hit a home run. There,
Jesus exhorts us: “Do not lay up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust destroy, and where
thieves break in and steal. But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust destroy.”
Jesus is talking about heavenly rewards, not earthly rewards. The Lord is dropping a big hint that He has the
Heavenly City in mind. Gaebelein perceives that this Matthean passage is dealing with the “judgment seat of Christ,
where we shall receive the rewards” (p. 147). Okay, good. Matthew is talking about the Bema. Where exactly will
this Bema take place? There is good reason to believe that the Bema will occur atop the Reward City. Deducing
that location would have been a home run. As it is, even though Gaebelein recognizes that “the Gospel of Grace
[GOG]” is something completely different from the “Gospel of the Kingdom [GOK]” (p. 64), he does not even make
it to second base by explicitly acknowledging that the heavenly reward is associated with the Heavenly City. At
least, though, he perceives a duality to the gospel, taking the gospel of grace as soteriological and the gospel of the
kingdom as misthological.
        In his discussion of Mt 13, Gaebelein notes that these mysteries of the kingdom of the heavens follow the
rejection of Jesus as king and the rejection of His gospel of the kingdom (pp. 259-260). Jesus’ departure from
teaching in the house to teach by the seashore shows a transition to presenting the GOK in relation to the Gentile
nations (represented by the sea). What the KOH “is like” in Mt 13 can no longer be equated with what the KOH
“is.” “It can no longer mean the kingdom as it is revealed in the Old Testament” (p. 261). Gaebelein equates the
KOH in Mt 13 with “professing Christendom” (284). The tares are counterfeit professing believers during the
church age who are part of this “professing Christendom” (p. 278). They will be removed at the end of the age. As
in Mt 25:34, the righteous will inherit the kingdom at that time, which means “the Kingdom is not the heavenly
glory but the earthly Kingdom” (emphasis his, 281).494 He does not explain what it means for the KOG to be “taken
493
   A. C. Gaebelein, The Gospel of Matthew (USA: Loizeaux Brothers, 1961), 60-61.

   Rice concurs, saying that, in Mt 13:41-43, “the kingdom which is here discussed will be on earth. The angels

from” the Jews in Mt 21:43 (pp. 437-438). One is left to speculate that maybe Gaebelein thinks the responsibility
of sharing the soteriological gospel of grace with others will be taken away from Israel and given to the church.
       Turning now to Walvoord, as an additional classical dispensational representative, when commenting on
Mt 3:2, he takes the KOG as soteriologically limited to true believers (Jn 3:5) but the KOH as inclusive of professing
believers (Mt 13). He says that “all agree” that those in the KOG are also in the KOH (p. 30).495 He claims: “Only
the premillennial interpretation of the concept of the kingdom allows a literal interpretation of both the Old
Testament and the New Testament prophecies relating to the future kingdom” (p. 31). Fine. What about the literal
Promised City? There is not a peep about this in his exposition of Mt 6:19-24. As for the taking away of the KOG
in Mt 21:43 from the Jews, who had rejected it in Mt 21:31, he says, “This should not be construed as a turning
away from Israel to the Gentiles but rather a turning to any people who would bring forth fruits of real faith”
(p. 162).
Classical Dispensational Distinctions
       The classical dispensational distinctions between the KOG and the KOH surveyed above are suggestive but
generally defective, both soteriologically and misthologically. For instance, Toussaint provides a survey of
interpretations for the Sermon on the Mount in Mt 5-7. This three-chapter Sermon by Jesus has much to say about
the kingdom (Mt 5:3,10, 19-20; 6:10,13, 33; 7:21). Most, if not all, of these references appear to be dealing with
the KOH, but according to the MT, one of these passages (Mt 6:33) is the first reference to the KOG. Toussaint
rejects the soteriological approach to the Sermon since “the universal testimony is that ‘one can obtain eternal life
only by grace through faith,’ which “is indeed found to be woefully lacking” in this Sermon (pp. 86-87). Toussaint
also proceeds to reject the millennial approach held by premillennialists like Gaebelein and Chafer (p. 90), which
would be the classical dispensational view, because certain details during the time period covered by the Sermon
are incompatible with the millennial kingdom, such as the disciples being persecuted (Mt 5:11-12), praying for the
coming of the kingdom (Mt 6:10) and being warned about false prophets (Mt 7:15). So, Toussaint adopts an interim
approach because the Sermon is addressing a period in which the kingdom “is in the process of being offered to
Israel” and “looks forward to a time when people shall enter the kingdom (5:20; 7:21)” and “speaks of future
rewards (5:12,19,46; 6:1,2,4,5,6,18)” (pp. 91-92). Even so, his evaluation is flawed by faulty soteriology in that he
says that good works “are the natural evidence of a genuine faith,” which is fine, but then treats them as the
necessary evidence (p. 94). Bear good works or burn in Hell would be the bottom line for his soteriology. Then
again, the same criticism could be leveled at Gaebelein (pp. 65-66) and Walvoord (p. 58). These classical
dispensationalists and their critics show a propensity to backload the gospel of grace with works as necessary proof
of one’s salvation and thereby nullify soteriological grace.
Misthological Dispensational Distinctions
       Misthological dispensationalists tend to be much more soteriologically and misthologically consistent than
their classical counterparts. Nevertheless, some of these misthologists are very classical in their dispensational
perspective. For example, some of them do not even acknowledge that the Heavenly City is a reward.
Misthologically, in terms of the present discussion, such misthologists might be termed minimalists. Some
misthologists move further beyond the classical position by not only maintaining that the City is a reward but that
Jesus intends this affirmation by His references to KOH. For instance, Chitwood and Hollandsworth argue that the
Lord proclaims an exclusively misthological view of KOH. They thereby assign KOH a maximal misthological
perspective and might be called maximalists. However, some misthologists take a mediational perspective between
the minimalist and maximalist positions by affirming a misthopological view of KOH with a soteriological-
misthological dualism. They might be termed mediationists. I fall into this category. A brief overview of the
mediationist and maximalist views is provided below.496

own kingdom” (p. 200). Sigh, such a comment is blind to the fact that the righteous will shine like the sun in the
Heavenly City, from which they will rule over the Earth. John R. Rice, The King of the Jews: A Verse-by-Verse
Commentary on The Gospel According to Matthew (Murfreesboro, TN: Sword of the Lord Publishers, 1955).

    Various misthological combinations are possible. For instance, Lang rejects any real difference between the
KOH and the KOG (pp. 8-9). Yet he acknowledges, “The Abrahamic covenant has two planes of operations; the
heavenly seed of Abraham and his earthly seed” (cp. Gen 22:17). He adds that the heavenly portion is for the
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                Page 394
                                       Illustration 128. Cauley’s Mediation




                                            Chitwood’s Misthological KOH
       Chitwood’s book, Mysteries of the Kingdom, is devoted to the thesis that the kingdom offered to the Jews
and taken away from them is the kingdom of the heavens, not the earthly kingdom. Despite my disagreement with
a number of particulars in his book, particularly his thoroughgoing misthology, I agree with his overall
misthological thesis. He begins with the classical dispensational view that the kingdom of the heavens was offered
to the Jews in Mt 3:2 and taken away from them in Mt 21:43 and that the KOH “is a literal, existing kingdom” in
the heavenly realm associated with [rulership over] this earth (emphasis his, 3). He then migrates beyond the
classical position by saying that this offer was for a regal position in the heavenly kingdom, not an earthly kingdom
(p. 6), thereby setting the stage for his misthopology, which he will defend at the end of his book. The Jewish
participation in this misthological heavenly kingdom was conditioned on national repentance (p. 8). Chitwood
overstates his case, though, when he says, “‘Repentance” on the part of Israel was the sole condition” (emphasis
his, 8). On the contrary, Mark makes faith an added requirement: “The time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of God is
at hand; repent and believe in the gospel” (Mk 1:15). Thus, this additional call for belief adds a potentially
soteriological requirement, suggesting a possible soteriological dimension to the gospel of the kingdom, at least
when compared to Mark’s parallel GOG. Thus, Chitwood’s claim that “the message has to do with the kingdom,
not with salvation by grace through faith” is suspect (emphasis his, 35). The argument could be made that a
comparison with Mark 1:15 proves that Jesus intended a soteriological-misthological dualism.
       Without digressing too far into that discussion, two counters could be made to this dualistic objection. On
the one hand, one might argue that Mark intends for the KOG and the gospel to be understood misthologically,
even in Mark 1:15. On the other hand, a maximalist might argue that, although Mark intends to underscore the full
spectrum of Jesus’ soteriological-misthological message by including faith as a requirement for the KOG, Matthew
intends to focus exclusively on the misthological component of Jesus’ message by leaving faith out as a requirement
and using the phrase KOH instead of KOG. Then again, a mediationist might say that Matthew wishes to underscore
the misthological aspect of Jesus’ message in this passage by excluding faith as a requirement and by using the
phrase KOH instead of KOG.
       At any rate, Chitwood proceeds to say that when Jesus left the house in Mt 13:1 (after the rejection by the
Jews in Mt 12) and began teaching the mystery parables of the kingdom by the sea, His doing so represents the
KOH about to be taken away from the Jews and offered to Gentiles in Mt 21:43 (pp. 12-13). This gospel of the
kingdoms has to do with ruling Earth as co-heirs with Christ (p. 38). Chitwood’s arguments in this regard are
entirely reasonable, but he unreasonably equates the Jews who believed in Jesus in Jn 8:30 with the Jews who
opposed Jesus in Jn 8:39-44. Thus, he wrongly argues that tares were regenerate Jewish believers (pp. 54-55).
Notwithstanding this fallacy in his argument, I have entertained the plausibility of misthological tares via soteric-
mistholic duality (see MMP2), so I will not belabor this point at the moment, other than to point out that Chitwood
overstates his case yet again when he says that the parables are dealing with “entrance into or exclusion from the
kingdom” (emphasis his, 55, cp. 159). This dichotomy is not the whole truth. The parable of the tares also deals
with extraction from the kingdom (Mt 13:41). See my discussion and illustrations regarding Taren the Tare in
MMP3. Other parables in Mt 13 also appear to deal with extraction as well. Consequently, I would object to


Church, pertains to heavenly regions, and was opened to Abraham, as confirmed in Heb 11:9-10,13-16 (p. 45). This
prospect was anticipated by the account regarding Joshua the high priest (Zech 3:4-7). If Joshua was faithful in
service to God’s house on Earth, God would give him rulership in His house as a “future reward in heavenly places”
(p. 29). Although the kingdom is available as “a present spiritual experience” in the here and now (Rom 14:17; Col
1:13), the heavenly dimension is what he looked for in the hereafter (p. 22). It was this heavenly kingdom, not an
immediately earthly kingdom, that was offered to the Jews and taken away and given to the Church (pp. 14-15). G.
H. Lang, The Gospel of the Kingdom of the Kingdom: The Message of Its Five Chief Preachers: A Re-Examination
of Dispensational Teachings (Miami Springs, FL: Schoettle Publishing Co., 1988).
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                        Page 395
Chitwood’s assertion that “Scripture never pictures a mixture of saved and unsaved individuals through the use of
a metaphor such as that seen in the parable of the net” (emphasis his, 160).
        Chitwood acknowledges that Paul “had to proclaim a dual message” regarding the soteriological gospel of
the grace of God plus the misthological kingdom of God (p. 78). Paul’s gospel (good news) includes both the
soteriological grace of God and the misthological glory of Christ (pp. 105-106). I agree. Therefore, since the gospel
is soteriologically-misthologically dualistic, including both soteriological and misthological components, I question
Chitwood’s premise that the parables pertaining to the gospel of the kingdom of the heavens (GOH) are necessarily
strictly misthological (p. 130). To be sure, these parables are highly misthological, and much of Chitwood’s
exposition is very insightful. Still, he seems to have a blind spot regarding the potential soteriological components
of the gospel and the parables since he is focused on the prominent misthological theme. The fact that he equates
Mt 21:33 with the offer of the kingdom of heavens (KOH) being withdrawn from Israel (p. 153), even though the
verse actually says that the kingdom of God (KOG) was taken away from Israel, further arouses my suspicions.
Chitwood seems to differentiate the “gospel of the grace of God” as being soteriological in contradistinction to the
proclamation of the “kingdom of God,” which he takes as misthological (p. 78). Yet, if he takes both the gospel of
the kingdom of the heavens and the gospel of the kingdom of God as exclusively misthological, then this causes
grave concerns with certain passages (such as Jn 3:5), which seem to denote a soteriological entrance into the
kingdom of God. He acknowledges that “salvation by grace through faith is simply not the central subject seen
through these parables” (p. 158). Okay, but is Chitwood justified in dismissing soteriology completely from the
parables?
        In any event, he believes that the tares cast into the furnace of fire are regenerate believers/Christians being
cast into the “furnace of fire” (pp. 162-163). I disagree with the singularity of that statement. Nevertheless, I concur
that Christians being cast metaphorically in the misthological fire is certainly entailed in several of the passages that
he cites for support (Jn 15:1-6; Heb 6:7-9; 10:26-31), though his inclusion of 2Thess 1:5-10 and Jude 1:20-23 might
be called into question since they might have soteriological interpretations or at least soteriological implications.
He also takes Gehenna as being strictly misthological. I would take Gehenna dualistically as being both
soteriological and misthological, applicable metaphorically/correlatively to a Gehenna Bema (see TOD, MMP1,
MMP3). So, I can agree with his taking Gehenna misthologically as picturing “the place where the refuse from the
city was discarded, outside the city” (emphasis his, 164). Our primary difference is that I would also see
soteriological applicability, not an exclusively misthological applicability.
         Indeed, he acknowledges that the Lake of Fire is both soteriological and misthological (p. 165). Granted,
whereas he would take the misthological application of the Lake of Fire metaphorically (like Gehenna), I would
be more inclined to take it correlatively (see the principle of correlativity in TOD). That technical nuance aside,
we both agree that the soteriological application of the Lake of Fire is literal (p. 17). Regardless, since he
acknowledges a soteric-mistholic duality to the Lake of Fire and lumps it in with Gehenna, it seems that he should
be more open to duality for Gehenna and the parables, though I would concur with him that the outer darkness is
strictly misthological. My major disagreement with his discussion in Mysteries is that he argues that rewards are
limited to the millennium (pp. 166-167). I refute this temporary-rewards argument in my book RAE (Rewards Are
Eternal). Notwithstanding, I completely agree with Chitwood that “what is at stake” in the offer of the kingdom of
the heavens is “being offered positions as co-regents with Christ in His kingdom, forming the bride which will reign
with the Son as consort queen” (emphasis his, 178). We are both bridal misthologists. In a nutshell, ruling over
Earth from the Heavenly City as the Bride of Christ is the reward that was taken from the nation of Israel and
made inclusively available to Gentile believers. Thus, the Bridal City is now open to both Gentile and Jewish
overcomers. Chitwood has some excellent arguments in that regard which make his book a worthy read.
        To briefly mention some of the positive aspects of Chitwood’s arguments, his misthological distinction
between the earthly land and heavenly land and associating the latter with the Sermon on the Mount is appealing
(emphasis his, 24). He well argues that Queen Esther represents God’s wife and pertains to the Promised Land,
while Rebekah represents the Bride of Christ and pertains to the Promised City (p. 87, etc.). This is an example of
misthological wife-bridal dualism. However, I believe that some of the details are more complex than what
Chitwood has suggested. We both observe soteric-misthological dualism and misthological dualism. Nonetheless,
I tend to use more of the former than he does. Consequently, I use dualism more extensively while still coming to
much the same overall conclusion, which is that the gospel of the kingdom is focused on the Reward City, sometimes
cryptically, sometimes explicitly.
                                       Hollandsworth’s Misthological KOH
       Hollandsworth’s book Keys for Inheriting the Kingdom is excellent and, in certain ways, might be considered
a mediation between Chitwood’s position and mine. Like myself, Hollandsworth affirms that the Gospel of John
(GJ) is soteriological: “John’s Gospel is avowedly evangelistic, the focus of the Synoptics is not evangelistic. Their
primary purpose is to point national Israel to repentance” (pp. 4-5). In contradistinction to myself but in agreement
with Chitwood, Hollandsworth takes an exclusively misthological view of the synoptic parables. Unlike Chitwood,
who saves the punchline for the end of his book, that the KOH pertains to the Reward City, Hollandsworth
establishes this thesis from the beginning:
               Remarkably, we are told in v. 17 that the Old Testament prophets and patriarchs wanted to learn
        more about the kingdom of the heavens. Yet, God gave them only a tiny glimpse. For instance,
        Abraham looked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God, Heb. 11:10.
        Moses had respect unto the recompence of the reward, Heb. 11:26. But God had not revealed to them
        the fullness of the heavenly New Jerusalem. Those truths remained hidden in the Old Testament era.
        Until the time of Christ’s coming to Earth they were mysteries — the mysteries of the kingdom of
        heaven (v. 11). The mysteries have since been revealed by Christ through the medium of parables.
        (P. 10)

      Hollandsworth stresses: “Jesus offered to Israel the privilege of ruling together with Him in the heavenly
Jerusalem, the heavenly realm of the kingdom — the headquarters, if you will — and not merely in the
earthly realm” (p. 30). He reiterates this theme throughout the book. Israel still gets the earthly promise but not the
heavenly promise: “Israel will receive [an] inheritance in the earthly realm of the kingdom, for that had been
promised repeatedly in the Old Testament, but the nation will have no inheritance in the heavenly realm,
New Jerusalem, the heavenly city of reward” (p. 99). These arguments are excellent, and the present book
supports these claims. Appreciably, Hollandsworth also repeatedly affirms therein that rewards are eternal (pp. 21-
22, 35, 51, 65, 94).497
      Now for the more complex part. What does Jesus mean when He talks about being taken out of the kingdom?
            •   In Mt 21:43, the potential to qualify for the Reward City is taken away nationally from Israel and
                given to the Church (p. 42).
            •   In Mt 13:48, the bad fish are “cast away (out)” [ballo exo] into the misthological outer darkness
                (emphasis his, 47).
            •   In Mt 13:49, the angels “take out” (NAS: aphorizo) the wicked from the righteous and cast the
                wicked into the furnace of fire (Mt 13:42,50), which Hollandsworth takes as referring to the fire of
                the Bema (p. 47).
       Bema fire is Hollandsworth’s explanation for Mt 13:41, where the tares are gathered out of (sullego ek) the
kingdom and cast into the fire. He maintains that the expression the KOH is like (Mt 13:24; NKJ) means that “Jesus
is describing some aspect of the kingdom of the heavens. As in the previous parable, He doesn’t describe the
kingdom proper, in the sense of the place or the realm” (p. 19). This spatial disclaimer, if accepted, would allow
Hollandsworth to circumvent the classical argument that the tares are in some mystery form of the kingdom. His
argument is excellent, insofar as it goes. Plus, it is consistent in using the is-like argument regarding out to avoid
acknowledging the implication that the tares, bad fish, and wicked are in some form of the kingdom. This approach
allows him to sidestep acknowledging that they are currently in some mystery form of the kingdom. However, I
would counter by observing that the is-like interpretation of in is taken rather literally:

•     “The kingdom of heaven is like a man who sowed good seed in his field” (Mt 13:24, NKJ).
•     “The kingdom of heaven is like a mustard seed, which a man took and planted in his field” (Mt 13:31; NKJ).
•     “The kingdom of heaven is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in…meal” (Mt 13:33; NKJ).
•     “The kingdom of heaven is like treasure hidden in a field” (Mt 13:44; NKJ).

497
    Most regrettably, Hollandsworh subsequently abandoned the eternal view of rewards so that he could adopt
universalism. He also adopted a misthological view of GJ. See Excursus on Universalism, 438. Notwithstanding,
his material before that point is excellent.
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                      Page 397

If is-like-in means in, why does is-like-out not mean out? Hollandsworth does not completely ignore this question.
Instead, he offers some practical advice:
             We are to respond to the tares — those who refuse the word of the kingdom and perhaps criticize
      it or persecute those who hold to it — by leaving them alone. Ignore them. Let God sort them out in
      the harvest at the end of the age. It is not your duty to change them. You are called to be faithful in
      your lifestyle and to preach the truth. Beyond that, don’t single out those who oppose. Don’t criticize
      them, don’t argue with them, don’t write about them on your blog, don’t pester them. Simply leave
      them in God’s hands. He will deal with them at the Judgment Seat. (P. 28)
Hollandsworth’s words are not devoid of prudence. Jesus warns about casting your pearls before swine (Mt 7:6).
Still, Proverbs gives dualistic advice: “Do not answer a fool according to his folly, lest you also be like him. Answer
a fool as his folly deserves, lest he be wise in his own eyes” (Prov 26:4-5). Given my propensity for dualism, I have
responded briefly to some misthological tares in the present book and will continue to do so in future books—to a
limited extent. My concern is for those who may be led astray by the folly of such tares and thereby become
disqualified for entrance into the Reward City. I do not expect misthological tares to have a place in the Reward
City. I am concerned that their poisonous darnel misthology might disqualify others from attaining a reward in the
Reward City. In the parable, though, the angels are actually the ones who are told to leave them alone. I’m no angel.
        Like Hollandsworth and I, Wilson is a bridal misthologist who differentiates between the Gospel of the
Kingdom (GOK) and the Gospel of Grace (GOG).498 For instance, Wilson properly insists that the GOK in Mt 24:14
is not the GOG. The GOK pertains to the future Davidic reign of the millennial kingdom “on earth.” Accordingly,
Matthew (10:5-6) informs us that the GOK was initially to be preached only to the “lost sheep of the house of Israel”
(p. 15). This makes sense since the Promised Land was promised to the Jewish people, and the GOK pertains “to
the coming of the King and the establishment of His Kingdom [on Earth] during which He shall rule and reign for
1,000 years” (p. 118). Such statements are consistent with classical dispensationalism. Wilson approaches the
parable of the tares from the same perspective and gives the same warning: “LEAVE THEM ALONE” (emphasis
his, 120). He believes the tares are the lost (unregenerate) who hear the true gospel but reject it in favor of a false
gospel. Cultists are an example.
        Although Wilson perceives the tares to be soteriological while Hollandsworth believes them to be
misthological, they both advise leaving the tares alone. However, Paul was a fighter who opposed those who
compromised the gospel (Gal 2:11; 1Tim 1:18; 6:12; 2Tim 4:7). Paul would not pull his punches in rebuking those
who comprise either the gospel of grace or the gospel of the kingdom. Quite likely, Paul was concerned not only
about soteriological wolfish tares in Acts 20:29-30 but also with misthological wolfish tares who will arise within
the ranks of believers and draw away disciples from the GOK. Paul says that he was “preaching the kingdom”
(Acts 20:25). He adds that he was “innocent of the blood of all men” because he did not shrink from declaring to
the believers “the whole purpose of God” (Acts 20:26-27). Evidently, if he had shrunk back from declaring to the
believers the whole purpose of God, he would not have been innocent of the blood of all men. In that case, he would
have been guilty of the blood of the believers, in which case God would have required their blood from his hand
(Eze 3:18-21; 33:8-9). Misthological tares, accordingly, will be found guilty of the blood of believers on their hands.
God’s word of grace is able to build believers up so that they attain the misthological inheritance among those who
are sanctified, but it does not guarantee it (Acts 20:32). Paul warns believers about the possibility of not inheriting
the KOG (1Cor 6:9-10; Gal 5:21; Eph 5:5). FG interpreters who deny that these warnings are concerns for believers
place themselves and their listeners in danger of being considered misthological tares.
        Wilson takes an exclusively misthological view of the Sermon on the Mount. In that case, Mt 7:20-23 would
be an example of misthological tares. Like Toussaint, Wilson adopts an interim approach to the Sermon and
provides a list of reasons for rejecting the notion that the Sermon pertains to “the Laws of the Kingdom…which
will prevail during the Millennial reign of Christ…[because] the conditions which will prevail during the
Millennium are not the same conditions for which the Sermon on the Mount was written” (p. 345). However, unlike
Toussaint, Wilson offers an exclusively misthological interpretation of the Sermon (which is a position Toussaint
had not considered). Consistent with that position, Wilson takes entrance into the KOH to be misthological in the
Sermon:

498
  A. Edwin Wilson, The Selective Writings of A. Edwin Wilson, ed. Arlen L. Chitwood, third edition (Hayesville,
NC: Schoettle Publishing Co., 1996).
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                      Page 398

             The Sermon on the Mount is written to those who hope to enter into the Kingdom of the heavens
      and share the honor and glories with the Lord when He shall rule and reign for a thousand years.
             The Sermon on the Mount is, in fact, rules and regulations to be observed by all who would
      inherit the Kingdom. Matthew 6:33 the key verse….In fact, the whole of the gospel of Matthew is
      written for prospective residents of the Kingdom. (P. 346)

        Wilson equates entering the KOH with inheriting the KOH and thus with misthological ruling. He does not
equate this misthological entrance with soteriological entrance. The Sermon is strictly misthological, in his opinion.
Therefore, the entrance into the KOH described in Mt 7:21 is misthological: “Not everyone who says to Me, ‘Lord,
Lord,’ will enter the kingdom of heaven; but he who does the will of My Father who is in heaven.” This entrance
concerns “occupying a position of sovereignty” in KOH (p. 154). Ditto for Mt 5:20 (pp. 161-162). Even though
Wilson takes an exclusively misthological view of the Sermon and an overall misthological view of the Gospel of
Mattew (GM), he takes a soteriological view of the tares. Therefore, like myself, he takes a soteriological-
misthological dualist view of GM’s KOH. We differ in the degree of dualism perceived, and over the years, my
view has become increasingly dualistic; nevertheless, we fundamentally concur on taking a dualistic approach.
        Despite (or in accordance with)—hermeneutical dualism intended—my preference for dualistic vantage
points, I like to see strong, consistent FG arguments by those who take singular vantage points. In my opinion, the
stronger their offsetting singular soteric-versus-mistholic perspectives become, the stronger my case for soteric-
mistholic dualism becomes. A strong FG soteriological argument coupled with a strong FG misthological argument
makes for a good FG dualistic sandwich.
        In that spirit, I would like to offer a suggestion that might strengthen Hollandsworth’s position regarding the
is-like-out parables. Like myself in TOD,499 he argues that unfaithful believers will be on Earth, but faithful
believers will live in the Heavenly City above Earth:

             The kingdom of heaven is literally translated “the kingdom of the heavens” and is referring
      to the ruling realm of the coming kingdom, the heavenly New Jerusalem. It will be the dwelling
      place of Jesus, along with His bride, where they will rule together, as regent and co-regent, over Earth.
      The other realm of the Messianic kingdom will be on Earth and is referred to as the outer darkness, or
      the darkness outside. It is called that because the kingdom of the heavens will be intensely bright, since
      Christ is the light thereof. In contrast, the earth will be dark, relative to the heavenly realm. (Italics his,
      96).

       As misthopologists, Hollandsworth and I both agree that unfaithful believers will be cast into the outer
darkness outside the City. As I explained in TOD, ekei signifies the spatial significance: “The sons of the kingdom
shall be cast out into the outer darkness; there [ekei—spatially], there will be [eimi—experientially] weeping and
gnashing of teeth” (Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30; Lk 13:28). Or, as expressed by the NAU: “In that place [ekei] there will
be weeping and gnashing of teeth when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom
of God, but yourselves being thrown out” (Mt 8:12). This passage is not a parable. This literal, non-parabolic, spatial
affirmation of the nature of the outer darkness should inform our interpretation of the parabolic occurrences of the
outer darkness. We concur that unfaithful believers are literally cast into the relative spatial outer darkness outside
the City. If we are dealing with raptured believers at the Bema, why not allow that they were in the Kingdom City
(KC) before being cast out of it into the darkness outside? In Mt 8:11-12, those cast into the outer darkness seem to
be at the place where the supper will be celebrated in the KOH before being cast out of it. Likewise, in Mt 22:13,
they are in the place where the wedding celebration is getting ready to be held before being cast out of it. In
Mt 25:30, the place is not specified, but we can deduce that it is the Bema. So, if we know where the Bema is
located, we know where they will be before being cast out. In Lk 13:28-29, they are in the KOG, implicitly at the
table in the KOG. So, if you know where in the KOG the banquet takes place, you know where they will be when
they are cast out.



499
    Subsequently, I have concluded in this misthological series of books that unfaithful resurrected believers will be
in the Celestial Outer Darkness. Unfaithful mortal believers will be in the Terrestrial Outer Darkness on Earth.
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                      Page 399
                                       Illustration 129. Cast Out of the KOH




       My perception is that for church-age believers, the Bema is atop the Reward City. Their being cast out of the
Bema could accurately be described as cast out of and away from the Reward City. Since Hollandsworth basically
equates the KOH with the Reward City, for them to be cast out of the Bema atop the Reward City would be to be
cast out of the KOH. In other words, if Hollandsworth adopts my argument in this present book, that unfaithful
believers are cast into the Celestial Outer Darkness from the Bema atop the City, he can allow a spatial interpretation
for the is-like-out parables of Mt 13 that is consistent with our misthological understanding of the outer darkness,
even for raptured believers at the end of the church age. As indicated in Illustration 129, the KOH focuses on the
Promised City but includes Earth since the Heavenly City will rule over Earth. Therefore, in the Sermon on the
Mount, when Jesus promises the meek that they will inherit the Earth (Mt 5:5), which is part of the reward in the
KOH (Mt 5:10,12), the Lord includes the Earth as part of the misthological domain of the KOH. The promise of
inheriting the Earth would naturally entail ruling the Earth. A few equations will help with the summation.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                 Page 400
                                            Illustration 130. Equations
           KOH (Kingdom of Heaven) = PC (Promised City) + PL (Promised Land) + PE (Promised Earth)
                                                      PC > PL > PE
                                               PE = the earth of all planets

       Having a position in the Promised City (PC) is a greater position of authority than merely having a position
in the Promised Land. Having a position in the Promised Land (PL), in turn, is a superior position of authority to
merely having a position on the Promised Earth (PE). Even so, PE is no small reward. Promised Earth includes all
earth within the scope of its promise. The misthological inheritance of the “earth” in Mt 5:5 is not limited to the
Earth.
                                Illustration 131. Cast Out of the KOH Multiverse




      Jesus affirms that when He returns, He will put faithful believers in charge of all His possessions and servants
(Lk 12:42-44). According to WH, we should take Jesus very literally regarding this parabolic detail (Heb 2:6-8).
Consequently, Jesus should be understood as promising rulership over the entire terrestrial realm. In short, faithful
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                         Page 401
believers will rule the multiverse. Therefore, for the above picture, I have combined two previous illustrations to
illuminate the point. Since the realm ruled over by the KOH includes not just this Promised Earth but all earth
within the scope of its promise (as indicated by Mt 5:5,10,12), all “earth” within the 3D multiverse is inferred. In
consideration of the scope of the rulership offered to faithful believers, the exclusion of unfaithful believers spatially
from the KOH at the time of the Bema above 3D Earth would logically extend to all 3D earth throughout the
multiverse. The reasonable and possibly necessary inference is that believers found unfaithful at the Bema are
excluded from the entire terrestrial realm throughout the multiverse and thereby confined to the celestial realm.
        PE is the least in the hierarchy in terms of regality but greatest in scope in terms of realty, the amount of real
estate involved. PE is no minor reward. When Christ comes and sets up His kingdom on this planet, He apparently
will assign positions of authority to His faithful believers regarding the entire inhabited universe, placing them over
angelic rulers on other planets as well, including their terrestrial subjects. Overcomers will be intergalactic rulers
over all unfallen sentient life currently existing on other planets. Being placed over a parabolic ten cities at the time
of the Bema when Jesus returns (Lk 19:17) could very well translate into being placed into immediate rulership
over ten galaxies at the point of the Bema. Overcomers might need to be able to hit the misthological ground
running, so to speak.
        Those cast into the Celestial Outer Darkness are cast out of this KOH realm. Of course, since the KOH in
Hollandsworth’s model includes the rule of Earth from the Reward City above the planet, to be cast out of the
Jacobean Bema on Earth into the Celestial Outer Darkness would also equate to being cast out of the KOH.
Apparently, Hollandsworth can have his hermeneutical cake and eat it too. Preliminary indications are that a strong,
consistent vantage point is available for his model. Personally, I would like to see him develop it more fully in print
in the future.500 Still, for present purposes, I am comfortable enough with this proposed amendment to adopt his
position as expressed in Keys as a feasible working model, a valid vantage point intended by Matthew. Though
Hollandsworth and I agree on dualism at points, such as the soteriological-misthological dualism regarding
justification (pp. 161-162), I would be interested in seeing just how persuasive a case he can make for a singular
thoroughgoing misthological treatment of all occurrences of the kingdom in GM. Even so, even as it presently
stands, his model is an intriguing mediation between Chitwood’s model and my own model.

Jews exclusively and given to the Gentiles inclusively and, consequently, that the rulership of the Heavenly
City over the Earth is temporarily delayed. We should be able to concur on these points.
