                              Illustration 133. Cauley’s Classical View of the Gospel




       In TOD, I used this type of illustration to summarize my view of the core components of the Gospel of the
Kingdom (GOK) in relation to the Gospel of Grace (GOG) when the latter is used soteriologically.501 The GOG is
purely soteriological as it pertains to the gift of eternal life. The GOK is predominantly misthological, dealing with
rewards (as pictured by the crown), but also has the GOG as its soteriological core. Soteriologically speaking, this
is basically the classical dispensational view: GOG ⸦ GOK (KOG ⸦ KOH). That is, the Gospel of Grace (GOG)
and its corresponding Kingdom of God (KOG) are a subset (⸦) of the more comprehensive Gospel of the Kingdom
(GOK) and its corresponding Kingdom of Heaven (KOH). From this vantage point, I would take the parable of the
soils as dealing with soteriological considerations in the first soil (Mt 13:5-8; cp. Lk 8:12), but the other three soils
as dealing with misthological themes. Soteriological entrance into the KOH is by simple faith (Mt 5:20; 7:21;
21:32). Of course, misthological entrance is by faith that works. Therefore, those arguing for a misthological
interpretation can supply a misthological interpretation for such texts.

501
   The expression Gospel of Grace (GOG) occurs in Acts 20:24, but Paul uses it in conjunction with the preaching
of the kingdom (Acts 20:25) and is part of his whole message (Acts 20:27) as the “word of grace, which is able to”
build believers up and grant them a misthological inheritance via practical sanctification (Acts 20:32). Therefore,
in TOD, I pictured GOG as a subcomponent of GOK. In my “Appendix 4. Gospel Stratum” in MCMC, I used a
three-sphere diagram that uses the Gospel of Jesus (cp. Mk 1:1) as the outermost, most comprehensive sphere. One
could also use the Gospel of God (Mk 1:14). The MT rendition of Mk 1:14 makes it clear that the SG Gospel of
God includes the Gospel of the Kingdom: “Now after John was put in prison, Jesus came to Galilee, preaching the
gospel of the kingdom of God, and saying, ‘The time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of God is at hand. Repent, and
believe in the gospel’” (Mk 1:14-15; MT; NKJ; cp. Mt 4:23; 9:35; Lk 4:43; 16:16).
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                       Page 403
                                   Illustration 134. Kingdom Within a Kingdom




       Even so, in my discussion and illustrations for Taren the Tare in MMP3, I used the reverse vantage point and
pictured the misthological kingdom within the soteriological kingdom (KOH ⸦ KOG), even though I was taking a
soteriological vantage point of the tares. So, I am not dogmatic about which vantage point is taken as long as the
discussion is consistent. I am dualistic in my vantage points. In MMP3, I asserted that a common vantage point
found within Scripture occurs in which one sphere of reality finds its deeper, more fulfilling aspect of that same
reality conceived of as a self-contained subsphere of that same reality, in this case, a kingdom within a kingdom, or
in Greek, a basileia within a basileia. Blue is basic, thus soteric. This type of entrance is the one described by Jesus
in Jn 3:3-5 and Paul in Col 1:13. At the point of new birth, we are transformed irreversibly into a new creature and
transferred irreversibly into a new kingdom, the kingdom of God, a new soteriological reality unconditionally
guaranteed for all believers. The yellow sphere is used to represent the subsphere. When used in this manner, yellow
represents golden rewards (cp. 2Tim 2:20-21). Because blue and yellow combine to make green, the green person
in the inner sphere is used in this type of illustration to represent believers who qualify for such rewards.
       Two corresponding representative believers were introduced for this purpose, one called Lester (representing
least) and the other called Gregory (representing great). So, we have Lester the Least and Gregory the Great.
Lester, represented in red, is saved by the blood of the Lamb. Lester will be in the kingdom but fail to enter the
kingdom. How can that be? The riddle is easily answered by the illustration: All believers will be in the outer
kingdom, but only faithful believers will enter the inner kingdom. Thus, Lester is standing inside the blue sphere
but outside the yellow sphere because unfaithful believers will not enter the inner kingdom. Lester will only make
it into the outer part of the kingdom, that is, the outer darkness. Gregory (or Greg for short), pictured in green,
represents faithful believers. They will be great rulers in the kingdom of Heaven and live in the Reward City. In
short, Greg will rule; Lester will not.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 404
                       Illustration 135. Hollandsworth’s Misthological View of the Gospel




       Since Hollandsworth is taking an exclusively misthological view of the GOK, his position might be perceived
as being the inverse of the classical soteriological position, so that: GOK ⸦ GOG (KOH ⸦ KOG). The kingdom of
heaven (KOH) is a subset (⸦) of the kingdom of God (KOG). One must believe the soteriological GOG in order to
be in the running to qualify for the KOH.502 The GOK is the deeper, meatier teaching. One must breach the outer
shell by soteric faith before one can get into the heart and meat of the gospel, which is the GOK, by mistholic faith.
Most people never get past the milk to the meat. So, picturing the GOK as purely misthological is very attractive.
The beauty of this model is its seeming consistency and simplicity. Nonetheless, like any model, problems need to
be addressed. Hollandsworth answers several potential objections, but others remain, especially regarding GM’s
use of the KOG.
       For instance, Jesus seems to equate the KOH with the KOG in Mt 19:23-24. Thus, insisting on a distinction
between the KOG and the KOH is questionable. Plus, if Mt 21:28-32 is talking about the publicans and harlots
believing the GOK, then why does Jesus associate it with entrance into the KOG rather than the KOH? Would not
the KOH be the expected phraseology for misthology? Furthermore, when Jesus says that the Kingdom of God
(KOG) is being taken away from Israel in Mt 28:43, why does Hollandsworth instead refer to it as the Kingdom of
Heaven (KOH) that is being taken off the table and given to the church? If Hollandsworth has no room for a
soteriological understanding of the KOG in Matthew, then an explanation should be provided as to why Matthew
uses the expression KOG on occasion. Hollandsworth acknowledges, “Charles Stanley correctly says, ‘To be in the
‘outer darkness’ is to be in the kingdom of God but outside the circle of men and women whose faithfulness on this

502
   Lee takes this position. Witness Lee, A Brief Definition of the Kingdom of the Heavens (Anaheim, CA: Living
Stream Ministry, 1986), 12-13. However, Hollandsworth’s argument is an advance over Lee’s argument in various
particulars, not the least of which is that Hollandsworth affirms that rewards are eternal. Regrettably, though,
Hollandsworth has subsequently abandoned viewing rewards as eternal in order to embrace universalism. Lee,
unfortunately, thinks that all the redeemed will inhabit New Jerusalem after the time for millennial rewards is
completed. If taken to its logical conclusion, Lee’s position of limiting misthopological distinctions to the millennial
age would lead to Hollandsworth’s new position—universalism. See Excursus on Universalism, 439.
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                    Page 405
earth earned them a special rank or position of authority.’” Stanley is taking a soteriological view of the KOG with
this statement, in contradistinction to the Matthean misthological term outer darkness. So, is the KOG soteriological
in Matthew after all? Acknowledging that possibility would be counter intuitive to Hollandsworth’s thoroughly
misthological view of Matthew. Granted, Hollandsworth probably did not intend that degree of exactitude in
affirming the correctness of Stanley’s statement. Still, the enigma must be explained. If Matthew wishes to affirm
that those cast into the outer darkness are still in some form of the kingdom (which certainly seems to be the case),
then what form of the kingdom is intended? Would Matthew not mean that they are still in the KOG? Yet, if so, the
KOG has soteriological ramifications even in GM despite its usage in misthological contexts, in which case the
classical soteriological position seems correct: GOG ⸦ GOK.

                                   Illustration 136. Duality for GOG and GOK
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                Page 406

       Rather than choose between one perspective or the other, one may dualistically affirm both. The classical
argument has its strengths and weaknesses. The same is true of Hollandsworth’s misthological argument. Matthew
may have purposefully used his terms in such a way so as to make a thoroughly singular vantage point implausible
if not impossible. In certain texts, my perception is that Matthew intends the classical vantage point to be more
prevalent. In other texts, he intends for the misthological vantage point to be more prevalent. His complexity makes
his gospel shine like a multifaceted diamond—for those who have eyes to see it. In doing so, Matthew is being true
to Jesus, who said,
      11
        And He answered and said to them, “To you it has been granted to know the mysteries of the
      kingdom of heaven, but to them it has not been granted. 12 "For whoever has, to him shall more be
      given, and he shall have an abundance; but whoever does not have, even what he has shall be taken
      away from him. 13 "Therefore I speak to them in parables; because while seeing they do not see, and
      while hearing they do not hear, nor do they understand. (Mt 13:11-13)

       Jesus presented His parables in such a way to conceal and reveal. They are dualistic in their intent. They are
not intended to be tare proof or leaven proof, as is proven by the parables themselves. Complexity makes the
parables much more difficult to understand and, therefore, easier to misrepresent. Complexity also makes them
meatier. Not everyone can handle the meat, though (1Cor 3:2; Heb 5:12-13). Still, meat is necessary for maturity.
The Lord wants a mature Bride. The same gospel that makes infiltration by tares possible also makes Bridal maturity
achievable. Sowing wheat in a field that is susceptible to having tares sown in it by an enemy is necessary to make
this type of wheat—tare resistant wheat. Pain is necessary to make the pearl. Just as sin was necessary to produce
the Bride, tares are necessary to produce this type of wheat. The wheat that survives and thrives until the
misthological harvest and that bears much misthological fruit will be wheat that has survived birds, stony ground,
thorns, and tares. Sin was necessary to produce the Bride. Accordingly, tares, leaven, and bad fish are necessary to
produce bridal wheat, pearls, and good fish. Complexity is just part of the adversity that Bridal believers face on
their road to maturity.
                                      Illustration 137. Lion-Lamb Dualism
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                     Page 407
       Adapting a lion-lamb illustration from James J. Choi above, do we really expect thoroughgoing singular
simplicity from a Deity who revels in duality, even to the point of being seen simultaneously as a Lion and Lamb?
Is the claim that Jesus would necessarily only intend one vantage point at a time regarding the kingdom really
credible?
       That said, I would further like to strengthen Hollandsworth’s misthological vantage point by offering some
suggestions as to how to reconcile Matthew’s use of KOG with the KOH. As already noted, I pose that when
Matthew says that the KOG is taken away from the Jews in Mt 21:43, a dualism is intended. Temporally, as noted
by classical dispensationalists, the setting up of the millennial kingdom on Earth, with its associated Jewish
prominence, is being delayed temporarily (cp. Rom 11:22-28). Eschatologically, as noted by Hollandsworth,
rulership from the Heavenly City is being permanently withdrawn from Israel and given inclusively to overcomers
of the church age. Therefore, the KOG is more comprehensive than KOH in that the KOG deals with both temporal
and eschatological benefits, but KOH deals exclusively with eschatological benefits.
       In Mt 6:33, believers are to seek first the eschatological KOG and are promised that their temporal needs will
be supplied. Again, the KOG pertains to both temporal and eternal benefits. In Mt 12:28, the KOG has temporally
come near in the casting out of demons, but it remains eschatologically unrealized in that it has not yet arrived. In
Mt 19:23-24, the entrance into the KOH seems to be equated with entrance into the KOG, but the context
immediately goes on to note that both temporal and eternal benefits are entailed: “Everyone who has left houses or
brothers or sisters or father or mother or children or farms for My name’s sake, shall receive many times as much
[now], and shall inherit eternal life [then].” (Mt 19:29). Mark makes this temporal-eschatological dualism explicit:
“He shall receive a hundred times as much now in the present age, houses and brothers and sisters and mothers and
children and farms, along with persecutions; and in the age to come, eternal life” (Mk 10:30). Both temporal and
eschatological rewards are promised.
       In Mt 21:31, a discrepancy is found among the translations. NAS portrays it as future: “The tax-gatherers
and harlots will get into the kingdom of God before you.” Other translations portray it as present entrance: “go into”
(KJV), “enter” (NKJ), “are entering” (NIV). The verb in question (proago) is in the present active indicative, thus
favoring the latter. Even so, the meaning is not conclusive. As discussed in TOD, translations generally handle this
present tense verb in one of three ways, translating it as (1) go/enter (ambiguous/punctiliar action), (2) are
going/entering (present linear action), or (3) will go/enter (future punctiliar action).
       Having presented a defense for the neoclassical dualistic model for this text in TOD, I will not repeat that
argument here. Instead, I will modify a soteric-mistholic illustration from TOD and use the modification to offer a
suggestion to strengthen Hollandsworth’s mistholic model. Indeed, for present purposes, I will pose a strictly
misthological dualism for his model. First, though, I will take issue with a statement that Hollandsworth made in
defense of his exclusively misthological model. He presumes proago signifies precession: “Jesus assumes that both
groups — the scribes and Pharisees and the publicans and harlots — will be in the kingdom, but the repentant
publicans and harlots will go before (precede) the unrepentant Pharisees, signifying a greater status in the kingdom
for those who are repentant” (emphasis his, 75). As noted in TOD, however, commentators are divided as to whether
the comparison signifies exclusion (cp. Mt 23:13) versus precession. Jesus purposefully may have used ambiguity
that would allow a dualism in which exclusion would signify soteric entrance, but precession would denote
mistholic entrance. One need not necessarily suppose that the Pharisees were simply “self-righteous saints” (thus
believers), as Hollandsworth does (p. 101), in order to adopt his overall misthological perspective. Contrary to
Hollandsworth’s premise, the Pharisees may also have been lacking soteriological righteousness. Saints are not the
only ones who can be self-righteous. Unbelievers can be self-righteous also. That said, presumably, some of the
Pharisees were believers (cp. Lk 13:31; Jn 12:42-43), and Jesus’s statement would apply to them in the manner
described by Hollandsworth. Believers can be experientially self-righteous.

                                              Misthological Entrance
       As misthopologists, we know that all believers will be in Heaven. We may not agree that this necessarily
means that they will be in the kingdom. For myself, though, I am generally content with the tripartite paradigm that
poses the universal kingdom versus the soteriological kingdom versus the misthological kingdom. However, trying
to determine which aspect is intended (or intended foremost) in a particular passage is a matter of debate at times.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                 Page 408
                             Illustration 138. Temporal and Eschatological Entrance




       Misthopologists agree that there is a misthological entrance into the kingdom. In some passages, this is a no-
brainer (e.g., 2Pet 1:11). Other passages are much more challenging in determining the nature and time of the
entrance. For instance, Matthew may have used the present tense of proago in Mt 21:31 to signify a present
mistholic entry into the KOG and thus into the kingdom way of life that leads to rulership in the City (KOH). Dillow
offers this type of explanation in a variety of places, including this passage (Destiny, 691). Wilkin gives a critical
rejoinder.503 However, Wilkin’s counter assumes that “entrance into the kingdom is future.” Yet, if that is the case,
why did Matthew use the present tense in Mt 21:31? Of course, rejoinders are possible, and the NAS translates it

503
    Bob Wilkin, “What Did the Lord Jesus Mean When He Spoke of Entering the Kingdom?” (May 1, 2014).

entering-the-kingdom/. Accessed 2/16/2022. Wilkin stresses that believers do not presently enter the kingdom,
either when they believe or when they die and go to Heaven. The kingdom of Heaven, in his explanation, is the
kingdom that comes from Heaven. So, Heaven is the source of the kingdom, but the kingdom will be on Millennial
Earth, and the New Earth. Bob Wilkin, “Does Matthew 3 Support That Eternal Salvation Could Be Received As a

says that the KOH does not merely mean from Heaven but in Heaven, referring to the Heavenly City (End, 85).
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                     Page 409
as the future. I suspect that the truth dualistically lies somewhere in-between, making various vantage points valid.
Dillow has a valid vantage point. Wilkin has a valid vantage point. Hollandsworth has a valid vantage point. For
present purposes, it suffices to note that the present tense is not incompatible with the present proposal in support
of Hollandsworth’s strictly misthological model, even though Hollandsworth insists on strictly future entry.
Interestingly, both Hollandsworth and Wilkin insist that the entry is future, but they are divided on whether it is
soteriological or misthological. Dualism would accommodate both vantage points.

                                            Mize’s Misthological KOH

      Three Kingdom Spheres
      I had just finished the above analysis when I received a prepublication copy of The Open Door by Lyn Mize
from my friend, Jim Harman, who is the editor of the book. Like myself, both Harman and Mize are misthopologists.
The heart of Mize’s position that is most applicable to the present discussion comes about halfway through the book
when he says:

      A common error among prophetic scholars is the failure to see the Church in the book of Matthew and,
      especially, in the Olivet Discourse. It is routinely stated that the Olivet Discourse is all Jewish mid
      does not pertain to the Church. This very serious exegetical error conveniently applies all the promises
      to the Church and all the threats in the Jews….
              The Gospel of Matthew does portray Jesus Christ as King of the Jews, and it also speaks much
      about “the kingdom of heaven.” Many theologians also err in this respect by setting aside “the kingdom
      of heaven” as being Jewish or earthly only. The kingdom of heaven has two compartments with
      one being earthly and one being heavenly. The Jews were promised an earthly Jerusalem, and
      Christians were promised a new heavenly Jerusalem.
              The Son of Man as the ladder of Jacob [Jn 1:51] unites the earthly aspect with the heavenly
      aspect. Jesus as the Son of God is the point of the ladder that touches heaven while Jesus as King
      of the Jews is the foot of the ladder that touches the earth. Thus, the Church is found in the Gospel
      of Matthew and even in the Olivet discourse, contrary to the traditional teaching by seminaries.
              The Olivet Discourse actually addresses all three classes of people who are part of God’s overall
      plan. Every human being belongs to one of these three classes of Jews, Christians, or Gentiles. The
      Jews and the Gentiles who are God’s people (i.e., they were saved outside of the Church age) are
      attached to the earthly portion of the kingdom while the Church belongs to the heavenly portion.
              It is important for the reader to first understand the term kingdom of heaven before the Olivet
      Discourse is explained. The kingdom of God and the kingdom of heaven are sometimes
      synonymous in Scripture but not always. The Scriptures teach us that the kingdom of God has
      three different aspects that correspond with the Trinity of God.
              The first aspect is the kingdom of God the Father, and it is the [universal] rule of God over
      all creation. This means everything created including planets, angels, animals, lost men, saved men,
      and even the insects. Every molecule in the universe comes under God’s dominion in this aspect of
      His kingdom. Daniel 4:34-35 refers to this aspect of the kingdom. When a person is born physically
      he enters the Kingdom of God the Father.
              The second aspect is the kingdom of God the Holy Spirit, and it rules over the believer’s
      heart and life but only by permission from the believer. This kingdom is entered by faith in the Lord
      Jesus Christ. Romans 14:17-19 refers to this [present, spiritual, soteriological] aspect of the kingdom.
      The spiritually reborn person after entering this aspect of the kingdom has two ways that he can live
      his life. If he allows his depraved flesh nature to dominate, then this aspect of the kingdom will not be
      operating within the believer. This believer is referred to as a carnal Christian.
              However, if the believer allows the Holy Spirit to dominate, this kingdom will be in operation,
      and He will experience righteousness, peace and joy in the Holy Spirit while being a faithful servant
      to Christ and acceptable to God the Father. This Christian is called the spiritual Christian, and he will
      qualify to enter the third aspect of the kingdom that is described next.
              The kingdom of God the Son is a visible, literal, corporal, and future kingdom that has
      boundaries of time and space. The Old Testament calls it the “messianic kingdom,” while the New
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                 Page 410
         Testament refers to it as the millennium or the kingdom of heaven. This kingdom is still future, and it
         is the one that Jesus Christ commanded his disciples to pray for when he instructed them to pray, “Thy
         kingdom come.” This kingdom is entered by works, and numerous Christians will fail to enter because
         of sin, disobedience and a love of this world. Numerous Scriptures refer to this kingdom in the New
         Testament. It is commonly believed that all Christians will enter this kingdom, but this is not
         true….only a relatively few Christians will enter this kingdom.504 (Pp. 117-118.)

                In summary, the three aspects of the kingdom of God operate in different spheres. The first
         is entered by creation or physical birth. The second is entered by the new creation or the new birth.
         The third must be entered by re-creation by the washing of water by the Word. This is through
         confession of sin and growing in knowledge and thus earning rewards. (P. 120.)

Mize’s threefold model of the kingdom is basically the same perspective I portrayed in MMP3 for Taren the Tare,
in which I added the third sphere to my previous two spheres to accommodate a soteriological view of the tares and
to explain their expulsion from the kingdom, as pictured below.
                                     Illustration 139. Taken Out of the Kingdom




504
      Lyn Mize, The Open Door, prepublication edition (Maitland, FL: Prophecy Countdown Publications, 2022).
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                          Page 411

       Taren the Tare was pictured in black. In MMP3, I stated that Taren looks like a believer on the outside, but
if you look at his inner nature, it is transparent that he had never received the gift of eternal life. Taren gives many
expositors a fit, even to the point that some deny that he is in the kingdom. Yet Jesus says that he is taken out of the
kingdom, and, of course, he cannot be taken out of it unless he was first in it (Mt 13:41). Therefore, some interpreters
inversely insist that he is regenerate (cf. Jn 3:3-5). Notwithstanding, his entry into the kingdom is attributed to Satan
(cp. Mt 7:15-20; 2Cor 11:13-15), not to God, thus not readily suitable to being interpreted as a picture of
regeneration. He never entered the inner regenerate sphere of the kingdom. The only form of the kingdom he entered
was the external form of professing Christendom.
       In this above explanation from MMP3, I was being consistent with the soteriological vantage point I was
adopting for Jn 3:3-5 at the time, which would take Nicodemus, the Pharisee to whom Jesus’ was speaking, as
unregenerate and therefore soteriologically excluded from the kingdom. Mize, conversely, takes a misthological
view of entering the kingdom in Jn 3:3-5 (pp. 61, 108). Correspondingly, he asserts:

                 The Scribes and Pharisees were regenerate Jews who had fallen into pride and sin, and
         they had become barren. This is why Jesus’ message to them was not, “Believe and be saved,”
         but, “Repent for the Kingdom is at hand.” They had no fruit in their lives and had stopped watching
         for the coming Messiah. The carnality of the Jews caused them to reject Jesus as the Messiah
         prophesied in the Old Testament. It was because of this rejection that the offer of the kingdom of
         heaven was taken away from the nation of Israel and offered to a new nation that would bring forth
         fruit (Mat. 21:43). This new nation was the Church, and the criterion for receiving the kingdom was
         still the bearing of fruit. It was not automatic upon salvation. (P. 120.)

This is the type of statement I would expect from someone like Chitwood. Accordingly, Chitwood believes that the
tares are regenerate. However, like myself, Mize prefers a soteriological interpretation of the tares:

                 A tare is someone who has heard the true gospel and rejected it. He has seen and heard and
         rejected the testimony of Christians. Tares look like Christians, act like Christians, and talk like
         Christians. Many tares are people who can not accept salvation by faith only. They insist on working
         for it.
                 It is only at harvest time that they can be distinguished from true Christians. Jesus said to leave
         them alone, but many Christians do not take this advice.505

So, how is it that unregenerate tares are presently in the kingdom? Mize provides the same type of answer that I and
other similarly minded dispensationalists have proposed: “Christendom is the mystery aspect of the kingdom of
heaven” (p. 150). Tares are removed from the mystery form of KOH. Yet, Mize gives an extended quote from
Hollandsworth (p. 141) and shares his same premise that what was offered and taken away from the Jews was the
offer of the Heavenly City, a thesis which I also defend at length in the present book. Obviously, the complexities
are such that uniformity has been elusive, even among misthopologists, regarding various details. Rather than be
dogmatic about one vantage point versus the other, I generally prefer to allow both possibilities dualistically if
strong arguments can be made for both and consistency can be maintained for both.

       Seeing Versus Entering the Kingdom of God
       Some misthologists pose a difference between seeing and entering the kingdom of God in Jn 3:3-5. In TOD,
I discussed this possibility and the dangers of doing so, warning that we should not undermine the clarity of the
soteriology of the Gospel of John (GJ) in general or especially in this passage, even by implementing duality. We
do not want to confuse unbelievers or immature believers by unwittingly giving them the mistaken impression that
soteriological entrance into Heaven is both costly and free, an anathema frequently committed by LS.
Notwithstanding, in NBSW, I introduced some charts that would allow one to pose duality without sacrificing
clarity. I also followed up that perspective in this series (MMP2, MMP3). Rather than repeat the extended discussion
from MMP2 here, I will simply call attention to the heart of the analysis and then further strengthen the

505
      Ibid., 146.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 412
misthological vantage point.
        First and foremost, as argued in MMP2, Jn 3:5 is definitely a go-to-heaven-when-I-die type of passage: “Jesus
answered, ‘Truly, truly, I say to you, unless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of
God.’” Soteriological entrance into the kingdom is conditioned on the new birth. This soteriological perspective
must not be confused or compromised by additional vantage points. As a further safeguard against compromising
the soteriological integrity of this text, a misthologist who feels compelled to allow a secondary vantage point to
Jn 3:5 might acknowledge that, although John lays the framework for allowing a potential misthological lens over
this soteriological text in the broader context of GJ, he does not develop that vantage point within this narrow
context of ch. 3. Rather, he makes that vantage point contingent upon a broader context, probably requiring at least
the Synoptic Gospels (SG) for its justification.
     If so, my argument in MMP2 was that within the limited context of GJ, Jn 3:5 might be interpreted differently
than when interpreted in the broader context of the New Testament (NT). In the limited context of GJ, a
misthological understanding of Jn 3:5 is probably lacking sufficient justification even for a second orientation. In
the broader NT context, however, where other passages are able to assist in generating a secondary misthological
lens over the passage, one is potentially justified in entertaining both experiential and misthological dimensions.
Without the soteriological-misthological discussions found in the broader context of the NT, however, or at least
without the Synoptic Gospels (SG), Jn 3:5 should be interpreted solely soteriologically.
     In deference to that earlier analysis in MMP2, I point out that the word kingdom only occurs in three verses in
GJ (Jn 3:3,5; 18:36). In the later passage, Jesus told Pilate, “My kingdom is not of this world. If My kingdom were
of this world, then My servants would be fighting, that I might not be delivered up to the Jews; but as it is, My
kingdom is not of this realm.” The impression conveyed is that Jesus is talking about a heavenly kingdom, an
otherworldly realm, a spiritual kingdom. Therefore, the uninformed reader of GJ could rightly suppose that Jesus is
also simply talking about entering this spiritual kingdom in Jn 3:3,5 by means of spiritual new birth. Blum, a
dispensationalist commentator, concurs:

      His kingdom is not like that. It is not of this world; it is from another place, that is, heaven. Therefore
      it comes not by rebellion but by submission to God. Its source was not from men’s acts of violence but
      from a new birth from heaven which transferred a person out of Satan’s kingdom into God’s kingdom
      (cf. Col. 1:13; John 3:3). (Emphasis his.)

   On the other hand, Wilkin, likewise a dispensationalist, takes an exclusively futuristic view of the kingdom and
adopts a different type of translation that interjects a now:

      “My kingdom is not of this world … now My kingdom is not from here.” This implies (especially
      the word now) that His being “delivered to [the will of] the Jews” is a necessary step toward His
      future rule as King of the Jews.
             One day Jesus’ kingdom will be on earth. However, that will be a revitalized world. It will not
      be “this world,” a world whose god is Satan. In addition, Jesus will reign forever on the new earth
      (Revelation 21–22). (Bold and italics his.)


       Surprisingly, translations are pretty evenly split between the now and no-now renditions of Jn 18:36, despite
the fact that the now (nun) occurs in both the CT and MT:

           •   NOW: ASV, DBY, DRA, ERV, GNV, KJV, MRD, NIB, NIV, NKJ, PNT, RWB, TNT, WEB, YLT.
           •   No NOW: BBE, CJB, CSB, ESV, GWN, NAB, NAS, NAU, NET, NJB, NLT, NLT, RSV.

Commentators frequently ignore the now (nun), failing to comment on its possible presence, or they gloss over it
as if it has no eschatological significance. Leon Morris (NICNT, 1995) is an example of the latter approach, merely
remarking, “But now, as things are, it is plain to all that he looks for no kingdom from this world.” On the other
hand, Constable, a dispensationalist, does not mention it but interprets the passage as if it were there with an
eschatological significance: “This should be clear from Jesus’ other references to His kingdom as being an earthly
kingdom. His point was that He and His kingdom were not a threat to Rome (cf. 18:10–11). The reason was that
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                       Page 413
God had postponed the messianic kingdom due to Israel’s unbelief, though Jesus did not explain this to Pilate.”
        The problem with Constable’s explanation is that John has apparently taken pains to avoid any of Jesus’
references to an earthly kingdom. Readers of SG must observe that in GJ, John has removed all of Jesus’ other
references to His kingdom as being an earthly kingdom found in SG. John’s description of the kingdom in Jn 3:3,5
certainly seems to be spiritual, heavenly, rather than earthly (cp. Jn 3:6-8,12). Similarly, Wilkin interprets the
passage from a dispensational framework, but it is by no means apparent that John is limiting GJ to that more widely
informed SG perspective. John seems to be writing for the guy on the street, so to speak, including the Greeks, who
may not know about a dispensational framework and who would need someone to explain it to him before he would
be able to see the passage from that perspective, much like the Ethiopian eunuch who did not understand what he
was reading and needed Philip to step up into his chariot and explain the Scripture to him (Acts 8:27-31). Therefore,
despite the plausible misthological and eschatological inferences that could be drawn from SG texts regarding
entrance into the kingdom, I held to an exclusively soteriological view for GJ in TOD.
     Part of the rationale I provided in TOD was that the mutual perspective shared by both Tucker and Crawford is
that entrance into the kingdom in Mt 5:20 and 7:21 is a misthological entrance. For Crawford, this would be an
entrance into kingdom rulership. Obviously, I was not conceptually opposed to such a possibility in that I adopt this
perspective for Acts 14:22: “Through many tribulations we must enter the kingdom of God.” To enter means to
inherit in this context. Moreover, basileia may be taken to denote kingship. “Through many tribulations we must
enter the kingship of God.” An experience within the Messianic kingdom on Earth during the millennial era is in
view. Misthologically, an experiential exclusion is in view. Thus, in TOD, the position I held was that spatial
exclusion from that kingdom is not a consideration. All believers will be in the millennial kingdom, but not
all believers will enter/inherit the kingdom/kingship. So, in TOD, I concluded that the outer darkness does not refer
to exclusion from the kingdom but to exclusion from the rulership of the kingdom. On such particulars, I was in
agreement with Tucker on this particular passage in Acts. The question is, “How far do we proceed with applying
this perspective to other NT texts?”
       As I continued to explain in TOD, Tucker apparently would apply this perspective to the entire NT. In
Tucker’s estimation, new birth in Jn 3:3-5 is a precondition rather than a condition to enter the kingdom. On the
other hand, I regarded punctiliar faith to be the singular condition for kingdom entrance in that context and thus
argued for soteric rather than mistholic entrance therein. As Tucker and I would both agree, the reason John does
not use the word repent(ance) in GJ is because he is not presenting the gospel of the kingdom. In contrast to SG,
John does not present the kingdom of God as being at hand. In further contradistinction to the synoptic writers,
John avoids the use of the word gospel in order to clarify that he is not presenting the same message as that presented
by the synoptic writers. Astute misthologists are aware of such matters.506 SG explicitly uses the word reward in a
variety of passages; GJ does not. GJ focuses on the reception of eternal life by simple faith (e.g., Jn 4:10; 20:30-
31); SG does not. GJ stresses eternal security. SG does not.507 Also, in comparison to the synoptic writers, John has
very little to say about the kingdom, other than that faith is requisite and that Jesus’ kingdom is not of this world
(Jn 18:36). Whereas I would tend to see a spiritual dimension to that kingdom that is presently entered by faith
(Col 1:13) [like Blum], in contrast, Tucker [like Wilkin] would insist that this kingdom is not presently otherworldly
at all but entered into futuristically during the millennium by those who have met the prerequisite of faith, though
Tucker would add repentance as subsequent requisite since he advocates a misthological entrance. In effect, Jesus
was telling Nicodemus that he could not skip first base (new birth by faith) if he wanted to reach home base (i.e.,
have a part in kingdom rulership). Therefore, what is at stake for a believer (i.e., for someone who has rounded first
base) is failing to reach home base (in terms of kingdom rulership). According to Tucker, entrance into the kingdom

ch. 9 of Robert N. Wilkin, “The Ten Most Misunderstood Words in the Bible (USA: Grace Evangelical Society,
2012). See my “Appendix 4. Gospel Stratum” in MCMC.

    This is not to say that such concepts are completely absent in SG or GJ. Take Lk 19:26-17, for instance. The
unfaithful slave is stripped of his mina, but the enemies lose their lives, which suggests a soteriological-
misthological contrast in which unfaithful believers are eternally secure and cast into the outer darkness rather than
into the Lake of Fire. Similarly, GJ has its misthological passages (e.g., Jn 5:29; 13:8; 14:2-3; 15:6, etc.) and places
where an invitation to repentance might be inferred (Jn 3:20-21)
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 414
                                                                      508
is strictly a misthological theme (Mt 5:20; 7:13,21; 18:3; 19:23-30).
        Returning now from TOD to the present discussion in MMP5, my subsequent studies have expanded my
hermeneutical options. In TOD, I was not able to entertain a misthological spatial exclusion because I erroneously
equated Heaven with the Heavenly City. Plus, I was engaging with millennial exclusionists who would place
unfaithful believers in Gehenna for 1000 years if unfaithful believers were excluded from the millennial kingdom.
In contradistinction, I insisted that all believers would be in the millennial kingdom. However, during the course of
this present series of misthological books, I have demonstrated the fallacy of limiting Heaven to the Heavenly City.
Consequently, rethinking a spatial millennial exclusion for the kingdom is possible.
        As to the translation of Jn 18:36, I accept the now implication. My rendition is: “If My kingdom were of this
world, then My servants would be fighting, so that I might not be delivered over to the Jews; but as it is presently,
My kingdom is not of this realm” (TM). I agree with Wilkin in that respect. Further, I agree that John intends a not-
yet understanding for the more fully informed reader of GJ. However, like Blum, I would perceive John as endorsing
an already soteriological apprehension for the uninformed reader reading the text from its primarily soteriological
vantage point. The primary vantage point being provided by John is not dispensational but simply soteriological
(cp. Jn 20:30-31), telling the reader how to receive eternal life and spiritual birth by faith and thereby qualify for
Heaven. John does not superimpose this vantage point on Jesus, however. The Lord Himself, by the use of ambiguity
and duality, allows Nicodemus to embrace this possibility. However, as Constable points out, Jesus’ perspective
would not be limited to this simplistic vantage point. Jesus would have intended an additional deeper meaning for
those who have the depth to perceive it. John has not stripped that fuller meaning from the text but allows it to
remain hidden in its depths so that he might focus on soteriology. The tell-tale signs of misthology are not missing,
though.
        First, as noted, in the remote context, John does not remove the nun from Jn 18:36. He leaves it there for
those who are perceptive enough to recognize its import from SG. This inclusion is important since this text is the
only other explanation provided for the kingdom in GJ. Second, in the immediate context of Jn 3:3-5, John records
Jesus as not only inviting Nicodemus to believe and thereby receive the gift of eternal life but also, having done so,
to openly confess his faith (cp. Jn 3:19-21), which, as John goes on to indicate, would have misthological
implications (cp. Jn 12:42-43). Furthermore, in the immediate context, John records Jesus’ statement regarding Him
being the link between Heaven and Earth (cp. Jn 3:13), suggesting the link of His kingdom with Earth.509 Third, the
link was already suggested in the preceding context (Jn 1:51).510 Fourth, John will go on in the remote context to
associate the heavenly place Jesus is preparing with the Reward City (Jn 14:2-3,23).511 Consequently, we have
several reasons to think that just as Moses lifting up the serpent in the wilderness and placing it on a pole is a sign
suitable in Jn 3:14 for soteriological typology, Moses himself being lifted up and placed on Mount Nebo where he
could see the kingdom but not be allowed to enter it in Dt 32:49-52 is a sign suitable for misthological typology
and possibly intended by John and Jesus at a deeper implicit level in Jn 3:3-5.
        In the literary context, John has focused our attention on the present spiritual and soteriological aspects of
Jn 3:3-5. However, he has not stripped Jesus’ statement of its historical context. John knew that better-informed
readers would realize that Jesus was talking to a well-informed Jew who knew the OT promises of the coming,
future, millennial kingdom and who had heard John preaching, “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand”
(Mt 3:2). From this vantage point, the better-informed readers could be expected to perceive the greater implications
of Jesus’ invitation to Nicodemus. Indeed, Nicodemus probably would have as well. Wilkin says that Jesus is talking
about the future millennial kingdom in Jn 3:3-5. As a well-informed Jew familiar with OT promises of the coming
kingdom, Nicodemus would have included this messianic Promised-Land perspective within the scope of Jesus’
meaning. Like Jesus, John is conveying the message at two different depths. John’s GJ is the kiddy pool in which
the theologian can dive into its depths. Uninformed readers can safely trust in the surface soteriological nature of
the invitation to believe in Jesus for eternal life and thereby be assured of going to Heaven. Both John and Jesus
wish to convey this message. Likewise, they both intend to supply a deeper misthological invitation for the more
mature reader. With this said, let’s take a dive.

                              Illustration 140. Seeing Versus Entering the Kingdom




    Conceptually, the dive is not that difficult because the foregoing discussion has prepared for the plunge. At this
deeper level, seeing the kingdom can be quite easily distinguished spatially from entering the kingdom. Unfaithful
believers will be in the Celestial Heaven from which they can see God’s Kingdom—the Kingdom of Heaven. NDEs
give reports of being able to see Earth from Heaven. One may reasonably pose that unfaithful believers confined to
Heaven during the millennial age and eternal state will likewise be able to observe the events happening throughout
the kingdom in the multiverse. I have never been out of the USA. Nevertheless, I have seen movies and live news
feeds of other countries. Presumably, those in Heaven will likewise be able to watch movies and live feeds of events
taking place throughout the kingdom. They will not be able to visit those places, but they will be able to see them
remotely. Occasionally, they may shed tears as they watch since they will realize that they could have been visiting
those locations and participating in those activities if they had lived faithfully during their time on Earth. Even so,
they will still appreciate the fact that they can view those locations and activities remotely.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 416
    Mize provides an explanation shared by others of this see-versus-enter persuasion:
             Even though the Church as an entity received the kingdom of the heavens, there will be many
      Christians who will lose this inheritance just like Israel did because of unfaithfulness and disobedience.
      Scripture distinguishes between Christians who are able to “see the kingdom of heaven” and Christians
      who will “enter the kingdom of heaven.” “Enter the kingdom” literally means to enter into the King’s
      dominion and refers to being assigned a responsible position in our Lord’s kingdom.
             “See the kingdom” means to be physically present in the coming millennial kingdom but having
      no position of authority. All Christians will “see the kingdom” but not all Christians will “enter the
      kingdom.”
             The failure of Bible students to see this difference has resulted in the rapid growth of the false
      doctrine of Lordship Salvation. Numerous (Christians equate “enter the kingdom” with salvation in
      the evangelical sense, but it is actually related to the ongoing present aspect of our salvation as
      described earlier in the chapter. (Bold his, 61).
       This is the type of misthological distinction that I also have considered in the past. Basically, it poses a
dynamic understanding of the kingdom as exercising kingship. Unfaithful believers will be excluded from the
kingship. This interpretation is valid insofar as it goes, of course. However, a believable spatial distinction would
even be better. Mize goes on to pose that all believers get “into heaven,” but faithful believers get “into the kingdom
of heaven” (p. 95). He seems to intend the first phrase to be taken spatially but the second phrase dynamically.
Again, this perspective is good insofar as it goes, but we could go further. He basically takes the same position I
did in TOD when he goes on to say, “All believers will be in the millennial kingdom, but like the disciples, some
Christians will be closer and more intimate with Christ. The twelve disciples represent those who will ‘enter the
kingdom,’ or more specifically those who will reign and rule with Jesus Christ” (p. 109). Enter is equal to reign, a
dynamic entrance into the kingship, which is limited to the faithful; nevertheless, all believers will spatially enter
the millennial kingdom. As I argued in TOD, this proposition is certainly better than that provided by misthologists
who pose that unfaithful believers will be spatially excluded from the millennial kingdom and be in Gehenna during
that time. Contrariwise, the present misthological series has demonstrated that unfaithful believers can be spatially
excluded from the millennial kingdom by being confined to Heaven. In this way, they are not only excluded from
the Promised Land during the millennial kingdom but from the Earth\earth as well. This explanation allows Mize’s
subsequent statement to be taken at face value: “All Christians will enter heaven and see the kingdom. All Christians
will not enter the kingdom” (p. 115). As a dualist, I will opt to adopt this vantage point as the deeper perspective
and take it literally at face value from that vantage point.
                                            Invalid Vantage Points
      Not every vantage point is valid, however. At best, some are just plain dumb. Others require investigation.
A few examples will suffice to demonstrate the need for discretion when implementing duality.
Soteriological Invalidity
       A soteriological interpretation of Mt 5:12, for instance, is ludicrous and easy to spot. A standard translation
is: “Rejoice, and be glad, for your reward [misthos] in heaven is great, for so they persecuted the prophets who were
before you.” Yet some interpreters and translators act as if Jesus said gift (doron). Leon Morris (PNTC) wrongly
suggests that this reward is unmerited: “This does not mean that the pious have merited a heavenly reward.” Lenski
(LCNT) is blatant: “This μισθός is ‘pay,’ but never in the sense of something earned by works or sufferings of ours
but as something unearned and freely bestowed by grace by the generous hand of God.” UBSH makes the gift-
equals-reward stupidly complete:

              The concept of a reward may be difficult for many readers. The main idea is that of a
      compensation which is valuable and special. If the idea of a reward sounds strange, one should realize
      that it is a reward of God’s grace, that is, a reward not merited but which God wills to give to those
      who serve him faithfully. It is not a compensation for work done, but rather a gift which far exceeds
      any service rendered….
              Some translations will use “gift” for reward, or even “great (or, valuable) gift.” This is kept in
      heaven, which means that it is God who will give it, as we pointed out. Thus the translation can be
      “God is keeping a valuable reward for you in heaven,” “God will reward you greatly in heaven,” or
      “the gift God is keeping for you in heaven is great.” (Emphasis theirs.)
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                     Page 417
                            Illustration 141. Commentators Say the Dumbest Things




       I have dealt with various forms of misthological merit in MCMC and thus will not need to do so here. Nor is
there a need. In this very passage, the reward (misthos) is contextually given for enduring persecution for Jesus’
sake. To say that the reward is unmerited is incredulous. To say that this reward is a gift is not only erroneous but
also poisonous. Mistaking the reward for a gift has the propensity to poison the gospel of grace, turning GOG into
a false gospel that leads to eternal damnation—a soteriological gospel of the tares. Just as Satan counterfeits the
gospel of grace by making it a reward, he counterfeits the gospel of the kingdom by making it a gift. Of course,
Satan uses legalists to make the gift a reward, while he uses antinomians to make the reward a gift. Notwithstanding,
this does not mean that the above commentators are antinomians in their approach to the commands of Scripture.
On the contrary, they might be something far worse—camouflaged legalists. Some legalists call the reward a gift
and then proceed to say that all the works necessary to attain the gift do not detract from it being a gift. They make
you work very hard to receive or retain their so-called gift of eternal life.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                               Page 418
                               Illustration 142. Soteriological Gospel of the Tares




      The frontloading and/or backloading of the soteriological gospel of grace with works, as is so often done in
Lordship Salvation, is also another form of the soteriological gospel of the tares. By teaching that good works are
necessary to reach Heaven, LS makes the gift of eternal life a reward at the point of reception and thereby prevents
regeneration.

                                  Illustration 144. Normative Bases for Regality




       In DOLF, I used a baseball illustration to explain that the rules of the race for winning misthological regality
normally require us to round all three bases properly in order to reach home base. We need sound theology in terms
of soteriology, nikology, and misthology to reach co-glorification. Even so, typology suggests that there are
exceptions to this rule. The carnal believers below the age of twenty did not die in the wilderness but were allowed
to enter the Promised Land, fight, and win an inheritance. A misthological age of accountability is thus suggested.
Accordingly, we might postulate that those believers who have not had time to move from immaturity to maturity
in this life might have the opportunity to participate in co-glorification to whatever degree might be possible for
immature saints. But for those who have had opportunities to mature, much more will be required (Lk 12:48).
       Soteriologists who never progress to nikology or who flunk misthology could be excluded from the Reward
City and, thereby, be considered examples of misthological tares. Presumptively, they are presently qualified to
inherit the City, but eventually, when resurrected or raptured to stand before the Lord at the Bema, they will be
expelled from the City to dwell in the outermost regions of the kingdom, the Celestial Outer Darkness.
       Nikologists who fail to mature misthologically might not be suitable candidates for composing a
misthologically mature Bride either, especially if they are without excuse, having had ample time and opportunity
to mature in this area. Some potential instances have been noted herein. By asserting that misthologists who teach
negative rewards are necessarily legalists, some nikologists place themselves in potential danger of being considered
misthological tares. By unjustly criticizing such misthologists as legalists and giving the potential impression that
rewards do not really matter, they place themselves in danger of being considered the “evil slave” in Mt 24:48-49
who “beat his fellow slaves.” Furthermore, their undermining of misthology might lead to antinomianism in some
cases and might thereby be associated with the type of behavior described by the rest of the verse. I have no need
for “passing judgment before the time” on them (1Cor 4:5). The Lord will judge if this is the case. I merely sound
a warning lest their blood should be on my hands otherwise.
       Misthologists do not get a free pass from the danger of being considered misthological tares. Indeed, even
some champions of the misthological-tare interpretation could themselves turn out to be misthological tares in the
end. Mature misthology is third base, not home base. Just because one reaches mature misthology does not ensure

so, they undermine soteriology and place themselves in danger of becoming misthological tares. Again, I have no

disagreement and point out the potential danger of an excessively misthological position. On the other hand, because
of their fascination with aionios and trying to limit it to a finite (number of) age(s), some misthologists can become
susceptible to teaching a popular form of universal reconciliation that leads to universalism, which, in turn, can
undermine both soteriology and misthology. Some of those hearing this popular form of universal reconciliation
might conclude that witnessing and living holy are not really worth the sacrifice because even the devil will be
saved in the end. So, my concern is that not only are those teaching an unbiblical universal reconciliation dividing
the word of truth wrongly, which would be a serious enough error, they are propagating a proposition that might
disqualify both themselves and their listeners from attaining the misthological kingdom because they are providing
a misthological stumbling block to others, and the Lord has some very negative things to say about stumbling
blocks. Such tares are gathered out of the kingdom (Mt 13:41). More often, though, these misthologists may not go
that far and only insist that rewards are limited to one thousand years. Yet, here again, some of those hearing this
limitation might reason that since rewards are only temporary, rewards are not really worth the effort. The
misthological blood of such listeners might be on the hands of those misthologists who give the impression that
rewards do not really matter because rewards are only temporary in their opinion. A thousand years of rewards is
practically nothing in terms of eternity.514
Eschatological Invalidity
       Duality cannot be posed for all suggested soteriological and misthological models. Neither can it be
maintained for all eschatological models. The premillennial interpretation is either right or wrong. Duality might
be posed for various dispensational particulars. Still, fundamentally, one is going to opt for premillennialism,
postmillennialism, or amillennialism. The same is pretty much true for the rapture. The rapture is going to be either
pretribulational, midtribulational, prewrath, or posttribulational. Here, however, an additional qualifier must be
added because some advocate a partial rapture, and the first part could be said to be pretribulational, with the latter
part occurring later, at one of the other popular options just mentioned. Yet, only one of these positions will be
found to correspond to objective reality. Therefore, duality is not a logical possibility. Jesus will come back in the
manner broadly described by only one of these models.
       In TOD, I dealt with these various positions regarding the rapture and advocated a full pretribulational
rapture. Later, in DFS, I strengthened that argument by expounding on 1Thess 5:9-10 (in conjunction with
1Thess 1:10). In a nutshell, God has not destined believers for the wrath of the Day of the Lord (DOL) but for
earning misthological salvation. Even if believers are morally asleep at the time of the rapture, they will be spared
from the wrath of the DOL. I dealt with Govett’s argument for a partial rapture in DFS and noted his deficiencies.
As discussed more fully therein, Govett does not balk when he reaches 1Thess 5:10. He correctly acknowledges

the Jews, a mixture of regenerate and unregenerate, wanted to learn what they had to do to get to home base.

instructions regarding home base because Matthew was writing for believers; John focused more on Jesus’

soteriology complement one another.

concludes, instead, by affirming that being with the Lord is a gift rather than a reward, as even Govett, in all
exegetical honesty, has conceded.
        My contention is that 1Thess 5:9-10 falsifies the partial rapture model advocated by Govett. He does not even
deal with the passage in his 357-page book devoted to this topic: The Saints Rapture to the Presence of the Lord
Jesus. Lang (Firstfruits, 83) criticizes Govett and those adopting Govett’s model of the rapture; Lang offers his own
model instead. Yet Lang does not address 1Thess 5:9-10 in Firstfruit, which is his book devoted to this topic,
thereby losing any real credibility for his model of the partial rapture. Nevertheless, he makes noteworthy
contributions to the overall discussion by arguing, for instance, that believers undergo a pre-Bema judgment
immediately after death (cp. Heb 9:27; etc.). Briefly, he poses that the 144,000 of Rev 14:1-3 is a nonliteral number
that refers to firstfruit overcomers raptured in a pretribulational rapture that occurs before the Great Tribulation, at
the midpoint of the general tribulation, and are distinct from the 144,000 of the godly Jewish Remnant described in
Rev 7:4-8 who are on Earth during the general tribulation (pp. 46-47). The firstfruits are the first group raptured.
At the time of the Harvest (rapture), they receive the rewards associated with New Jerusalem (e.g., Rev 3:12) and
thus do not have to wait until the Bema to receive their white robes (pp. 48, 64). They have already attained
misthological adjudication for their crowns but have to wait until the Bema for the actual “bestowment of the crown
already won and allotted” (pp. 84-87). I agree with that part of his argument, but the thesis I have developed in this
misthological series is that all believers who die or are raptured before the end of the tribulation experience a pre-
Bema assessment and sorting. Thus, unfaithful believers are not allowed into the Heavenly City in their postmortem
state, whereas faithful believers are allowed in even now, as confirmed by exegetical considerations and NDEs (see
MMP4). I do not take the 144,000 as being two different groups but believe that the Jewish remnant chosen at the
beginning of the DOL to proclaim the GOK composes the firstfruits of the DOL who are raptured at the middle of
the seven-year tribulation.
        Mize likewise holds the partial rapture or what would be better described as a two-phased rapture. He places
the Firstfruits Rapture on the Day of Pentecost for mature believers in Rev 4:1 and locates it at the beginning of the
seven-year tribulation. Immature believers are left behind and raptured at the Feast of Trumpets at the Main Harvest
Rapture, thus going through the first 3 ½ years of the tribulation and hopefully maturing during those 3 ½ years,
and consequently composing the great multitude in Rev 7:9-17.515 This main part of the rapture will occur at the
beginning of the Great Tribulation, which is the midpoint of the seven-year tribulation.516

        Three things I like about Mize’s approach are: (1) It provides a two-phased model that correctly recognizes

        Nevertheless, I do not adopt his model because I believe that the DOL will commence ten years before the
millennial kingdom.517 Plus, I anticipate that Mize’s model has some logistical issues that need to be addressed,
such as explaining why God gives living believers a second chance but does not dead believers a second chance.
Still, whereas I usually would give a two-phased rapture a probability of zero, at least Mize’s model allows me to
contemplate the theoretical possibility that his model might at least have some low-level credibility since it cannot
be dismissed as easily as the partial rapture models proposed by others, such as Govett and Lang. Accordingly, for
the sake of theoretical discussion, let us suppose that the probability of the rapture happening on any day of the year
is 10%. Thus, Jesus can come any day, though the likelihood is low. Even so, some pretribulationalists believe the
Lord is most likely to come on Pentecost or the Feast of Trumpets, so the probability is higher on those days. I
prefer the Feast of Trumpets as more probable.
        Notwithstanding, Pentecost would be my second choice, so I must allow some increased probability for a
rapture on Pentecost. So, in deference to pretribulationalists who prefer the Pentecost timeframe, suppose we allow
that Pentecost adds another 10% to the 10% already proposed for any given day. This increased probability would
mean that the likelihood of Jesus coming any day is 10%. In comparison, the probability of His coming on Pentecost
is 20% (10% + 10%), leaving the remaining 80% (100% - 20%) for the Feast of Trumpets. Yet, following that
rationale, if I cannot entirely dismiss Mize’s model, I must allow it at least some low-level degree of probability.
For the sake of theoretical calculations, let us grant it a 10% probability of being correct. Accordingly, in this
theoretical computation, the likelihood that Jesus will return any day remains 10%, but the probability for Pentecost
now rises to 30% (20% + 10%), leaving 70% (100% - 30%) for the Feast of Trumpets. As a result, I now have two
days of the year, rather than only one, when my hope of the Lord’s return is substantially increased, which I take as
a plus. My eagerness for the Lord’s return leads me to wish those adopting this model well in their working out
logistical problems within their model. The bottom line, of course, is that we want to be ready for the Bema anytime,
regardless of which day the rapture occurs. Therefore, comparatively speaking, a sound misthology is much more
important than nailing down the time of the rapture. Duality will not allow me to embrace both the single-phased
model and a two-phased model as correct for the rapture. Only one model will prove to correspond to reality. More
importantly, though, both models can encourage us to be ready and give us occasion during the year to be especially
hopeful of His imminent return.
                                                         Conclusion
        At the very least, a triple dualism is found in the gospel. Depending on the context, it can be (1) soteriological-
misthological. The misthological component of the gospel can be (2) terrestrial-celestial. Yet the gospel can also be
(3) temporal-eschatological. Every text will have its context to determine if the word gospel is used singularly or
dualistically on that particular occasion. Importing the full semantic range into a single occurrence would have to
be justified by the context. One must not commit the well-known fallacy of illegitimate totality transfer by importing
its full semantic range from multiple contexts into any given context unless ample justification can be demonstrated
that this is the biblical author’s intention. At the opposite end of the spectrum, one must not attempt to strip the term
gospel down to only one aspect. This latter error is prevalent in those who adopt a one-size-fits-all mentality so that
they can push their particular favorite perspective. Some misthologists are prone to try to make every occurrence a
misthological text. Conversely, some soteriologists try to make the gospel a soteriological message.518 Some

also the beginning of the DOGW, thereby nullifying Mize’s argument. See my “Revelation Banner Chart.”

                                  Illustration 145. Triple Dualism of the Gospel




       The expression kingdom of Heaven (KOH) is unique to the Gospel of Mattew (GM) and appears to accentuate
the eschatological-misthological component of the more comprehensive term kingdom of God (KOG), the latter of
which might include temporal or soteriological themes. Depending on the vantage point taken overall or in a specific
context, KOH might be seen as the subset of the KOG, or the KOG might be seen as the subset of the KOH. The
present discussion focuses on the former vantage point, which limits the KOH to a misthological vantage point that
encompasses three primary regions so that the KOH includes the Promised Earth (PE), the Promised Land (PL),
and Promised City (PC), with a focus on the latter. Thus, the Matthean GOK is foremost terrestrial-celestial,
secondarily eschatological-misthological, and debatably temporal-eschatological or soteriological-misthological at
times.
       When Jesus said that the KOG was taken away from the Jewish people and given to another nation, He could
not be referring to the permanent removal of PL from the Jewish people. Classical dispensationalists are correct to
insist upon a temporary removal, which underscores the temporal component of the KOG. On the other hand,
misthopological dispensationalists are correct to assert that the offer of the PC was permanently taken away from
the Jewish people and inclusively given to overcomers of the church age. The church does not replace Israel as the


Stegall’s The Gospel of the Christ.” Available at https://faithalone.org/journal-articles/a-review-of-thomas-stegalls-
the-gospel-of-the-christ. Accessed 3/12/2022.
Excursus on the Kingdom                                                                                     Page 425
recipient of the PL, but the church does open the door to overcomers of other dispensations regarding the PC.
        The Gospel of Grace (GOG) and the Gospel of the Kingdom (GOK) should not be equated. The former is
(primarily) soteriological, and the latter is (prominently) misthological, with the parenthetical notations being
dependent on which one is pictured as the core of the other. The GOK pertains to the KOH and thus concerns much
meatier matters than simple soteriology. From one vantage point, the tares in the KOH might be said to be
unregenerate. From another vantage point, they might be said to be regenerate. The present discussion supports both
vantage points but focuses on the latter.
        The KOH encompasses three primary components in the following hierarchy from greater to least in terms
of authority: PC (Promised City), PL (Promised Land), and (PE) Promised Earth. Therefore, for a believer to be
cast out of the KOH need not be equated with being cast out of the KOG. The withdrawal of the KOG from the
Jewish people would include the temporal postponement of the PL for the Jews and the eternal withdrawal of the
PC from Jewish exclusivity.
        Classical dispensational considerations and distinctions were posed and then juxtaposed against
misthological dispensational options. Chitwood’s thoroughgoing misthological position regarding the gospels was
rejected. Even the Matthean parables seem to have soteriological dimensions at times. Nevertheless, I concur with
Chitwood that the removal of the offer of the KOH from the Jewish people was for the purpose of misthologically
opening the gates of the Reward City to Gentiles directly. Hollandsworth was found to be superior to Chitwood in
that Hollandsworth affirmed the soteriological nature of the Gospel of John (GJ).519 Furthermore, Hollandsworth
clarifies from the beginning of his book that the Reward City is what was at stake in the offer of the KOH.
Hollandsworth’s discussion, though excellent, had a perceivable weakness in that it failed to provide a satisfactory
answer as to what misthological extraction means in several Matthean parables. For instance, what does it mean for
misthological tares to be taken out of the KOH? If the KOH pertains to the Reward City, what are misthological
tares doing in the Reward City? One solution developed herein, and used to strengthen Hollandsworth’s argument,
is to pose that the tares are extracted from the Bema atop the Reward City and cast into the Celestial Outer Darkness.
Extraction to the Celestial Outer Darkness rather than the Terrestrial Outer Darkness is the more satisfying proposal
because the KOH encompasses the PC (Promised City), PL (Promised Land), and PE (Promised Earth). Moreover,
the PE (Promised Earth) includes the promised earth of all planets. Therefore, extraction from the realm of the KOH
necessitates extraction to the outer realm of the universal kingdom, with the result that misthological tares are
confined to Heaven and removed from the multiverse.
        The present book strengthened Hollandsworth’s exclusively misthological view of KOH so that this vantage
point might be entertained as a valid option for a dualistic vantage point that perceives both soteriological and
misthological authorial intentions regarding KOH. My duality appreciates an exclusively misthological argument
when appropriate but does not find itself restricted solely to this model. However, not everyone will be able to
appreciate the beauty of dualistic complexity and may need to limit themselves to the simplicity of singularity. This
limitation may be especially helpful for those who do not have the maturity to see the duality. Even mature scholars,
however, might wish to invoke Occam’s razor to insist upon such singularity and then proceed to argue that their
vantage point is the superior one. I wish them well. The stronger they make their opposing cases, the stronger they
make my case.
        Pursuant to the goal of making the misthological position as strong as possible, I interacted with the see
versus enter motifs in Jn 3:3-5 that are popular in certain misthological circles and was occasioned in the present
study by the prepublication copy I received of Lyn Mize’s book The Open Door. I strengthened Mize’s position so
that it could move from experiential exclusion from the kingdom to spatial exclusion from the kingdom, in harmony
with the conclusions already obtained in the present work. All believers will be in the universal kingdom. Only
faithful believers will be in the millennial kingdom when the latter is defined as a misthological subsphere of
Heaven, a subsphere that encompasses the entire 3D multiverse, nevertheless. Duality poses that there is a sense in
which unfaithful believers will be spatially in the kingdom in one aspect but extracted from the kingdom in a
different aspect.
        Notwithstanding the versatility of duality, duality has its limitations. Not all vantage points can be deemed
valid. Examples of soteriological, misthological, and eschatological invalidity were provided. To say that a gift is a
reward, for instance, is a telltale sign of invalidity. The same thing cannot be both a gift and a reward in the same
way at the same time. Correspondence with reality would break down. Arguably, unregenerate tares will be removed
519
    Unfortunately, Hollandsworth no longer holds this position and has followed Chitwood in erroneously
interpreting GJ primarily as misthological. See Excursus on Universalism, 438.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 426
from one form of the kingdom, having rejected the gift of eternal life, while regenerate tares will be removed from
another form of the kingdom, having failed to obtain the reward of eternal life. Even so, eternal life cannot be both
a gift and a reward in the same way at the same time any more than a tare can be both regenerate and unregenerate
in the same way at the same time.
        Under normal circumstances, regality was demonstrated to be conditioned on maturity in soteriology,
nikology, and misthology, with exceptions being allowed for those who fail to reach the misthological age of
accountability. Severe defection in any one of these areas can suffice for disqualification for the misthopological
realization of one’s presumptive reward. Duality cannot be used to avoid this conclusion. Eschatological invalidity
was also discussed regarding the full pretribulational rapture versus a selective rapture. Duality cannot make both
true. Only one can be right in terms of correspondence to reality.
        A point not pursued herein, though, is that the Lord may have used ambiguity in a passage like Rev 3:10 to
allow the perception of duality. One can certainly see how the verse could be used to argue a selective rapture.
Could it be that the Lord allowed this mistaken impression because the misthological immaturity of some people is
such that they would be better served by this mistaken impression than they would be by the correct interpretation,
which is much more complex? I prefer the complex route, as demonstrated in my writings regarding this verse. Yet,
for those who cannot handle that degree of complexity, would they be better served by wondering if the selective
rapture is true? They might think that being left behind to go through the tribulation would be worse than being
saved from the tribulation via the rapture. They cannot comprehend the fact that if they were raptured to stand
before the Bema unprepared, they would wish they were still on Earth and allowed to endure the tribulation so that
they might have further opportunities to prepare. Could it be that the Lord was not forthright about what He meant
because some immature believers could be better served, at least at certain points in their lives, by an ambiguity
that would motivate them to keep ready for the rapture just in case they missed it; whereas, the more mature believers
would realize that it is better to get ready for the Bema just in case they do not miss the rapture? Could the Lord not
use the beauty of complexity in such a way to help those who are not adept at complexity? Apparently, judging
from the testimony of Scripture and a NDEr, we can answer affirmatively.520
