          Excursus on Abraham, Moses, and John the Baptist
                                                    Introduction
       Misthologists who take the Heavenly City nonliterally are certainly at a disadvantage for perceiving the KOH
as having dual misthological implications: one for the Promised Land, the other for the Promised City. Misthologists
who take a soteriological view of the Heavenly City have blinded themselves to this misthological land-city dualism.
                                       Abraham Saw the GOK and KOH
      The contention herein, of course, has been that Abraham was looking for a literal Heavenly City as his reward.
The conceptual juxtaposition that WH supplies between Abraham and Moses confirms this conclusion:

          •   8
                By faith Abraham, when he was called, obeyed by going out to a place which he was to receive
              for an inheritance; and he went out, not knowing where he was going. 9 By faith he lived as an
              alien in the land of promise, as in a foreign land, dwelling in tents with Isaac and Jacob, fellow
              heirs of the same promise; 10 for he was looking for the city which has foundations, whose
              architect and builder is God. (Heb 11:8-10)
          •   24
                 By faith Moses, when he had grown up, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter;
              25
                 choosing rather to endure ill-treatment with the people of God, than to enjoy the passing
              pleasures of sin; 26 considering the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt;
              for he was looking to the reward. (Heb 11:24-26)

                                         Moses Saw the GOK and the KOH
       The articular nature of the City was discussed earlier. Abraham was not looking for a city but the City.521
Similarly, Moses was not looking for a reward, but the Reward. Speaking somewhat generically, Lane (WBC)
associates this with the future reward promised by God (cp. Heb 11:6). However, in doing so, Lane overlooks the
contextual specificity of the City. The reward is not merely eschatological; it is misthopological. Cockerill (NICNT,
2012) is much more perceptive: “Like Abraham, he [Moses] ‘saw’ God’s promised City (v. 13). He had his
parents’ vision into the things of God (v. 23). He firmly believed in a God who was the ‘rewarder’ of the faithful
(v. 6).” Moreover, Cockerill rightfully asserts that Moses knowingly bore this reproach in association with the
promised Christ:

         Thus, there is no need to assume that the pastor thinks Moses received some special vision apart from
         Scripture. Moses knew that by his sufferings he identified with “the Christ” who was to come. His
         hearers are fully aware of who that Christ is. Thus, the pastor would have them imitate Moses’ value
         judgment and joyfully embrace “the reproach of Christ.”

       True, Moses knew the oral traditions that he would later record as Scripture, which included the Lord as the
Angel of the Lord making the sand-sea promise to Abraham (Gen 22:17). Yet we must not forget that Moses’
knowledge was not limited to the oral knowledge that we later find him recording as Scripture. Dyer reminds us
that the oral knowledge possessed in the OT was far greater than those oral traditions which we now have. In other
words, OT saints knew a lot more than we tend to acknowledge:

                It must be remembered, however, that the organic development of revelation refers to
         inscripturated revelation. Believers who lived before the incarnation undoubtedly possessed revelation
         that was transmitted orally. There is evidence in the New Testament that believers before the
         incarnation had a more comprehensive knowledge of the gospel than is indicated in the Old Testament.
         Take for example Jude’s statement about Enoch in vv 14 and 15 of his epistle. Here Jude quotes Enoch
         saying, “Behold, the Lord comes with ten thousands of His saints, to execute judgment on all, to
         convict all who are ungodly among them of all their ungodly deeds which they have committed in an
         ungodly way, and of all the harsh things which ungodly sinners have spoken against Him.” Since
         Enoch knew about the second coming of Christ and prophesied concerning it, is it not logical to

      See A City Versus the City, 19.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                    Page 428
      conclude that Enoch also knew about His first coming? Even though believers were not called
      Christians until they were given that name in Antioch, is it really an anachronism to say that the name
      appropriately belongs to Enoch? Consider also the statement made by the author of Hebrews in 11:26
      where he states that Moses esteemed “the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures in Egypt.”
      This statement shows that Moses possessed a fuller knowledge of the gospel than is indicated in the
      Pentateuch. Even though we do not know the exact content of the oral Bible used by the Israelites, we
      know that it was more comprehensive than is indicated in the Old Testament Scriptures.522

       Other commentators, who allow that Moses knew of Christ, suggest a special vision as a possibility. For
instance, Attridge (HERM) provides this as one of the plausible potentialities: “As such a prophetic seer, Moses
could have been understood to be aware of the ultimate perfecter of the faith, the one who would bring God’s
promises to reality. Sustained by that awareness, he accepted the reproach that accompanied his association with
Christ and Christ’s people.”
       In any event, one way or the other, or through multiple means, Moses knew of the Promised Redeemer and
the Promised City. Moses chose to bear the reproach of the former to gain the reward of the latter. If Moses could
deduce such inferences from Scripture about Christ, are we to think that Christ could not draw the same conclusions?
Of course not! WH makes it clear, in the very opening of the next chapter, that Christ was motivated by the same
prospect, as WH transitions to Christ and affirms of Christ that “for the joy set before Him endured the cross,
despising the shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God” (Heb 12:2). Where? In the Heavenly
City, of course. WH apparently uses the in Heb 11:26 as an article of the previous reference to the City of Heb 11:10.
Jesus says that Moses wrote of Him (Jn 5:46). Did Moses not know that he wrote of the Christ?523 Did Moses not
know of whom he was writing? Some commentators give that impression. Other commentators, such as Lenski
(LCNT), are much more believable:

      As for Moses’ knowing about the Christ, in John 5:46 Jesus says that Moses wrote about him, and not
      merely in a sentence or two as in Deut. 18:15–19 (Acts 3:21–23; 7:37), but in all his writing. Even at
      the time when he made his decision Moses knew all about the reproach of the Christ and its heavenly
      value. His was the faith of Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Joseph. Note v. 22 and what he did with Joseph’s
      bones.

       MacArthur (MNTC) draws a sensible inference: “We do not know how much Moses knew about God’s
future great Deliverer. But he had considerably more light than Abraham, and Jesus tells us plainly that Abraham
looked forward to Jesus’ day and rejoiced (John 8:56). In the same way, Moses looked forward to Jesus.” Bryant
also affirms: “Living 1,500 years before Jesus came, he [Moses] not only believed in Christ, he also understood
God’s truth concerning discipleship and rewards. Moses even wrote about Christ. As Jesus said to the Jews, ‘For if
you believed Moses, you would believe Me; for he wrote about Me’ (John 5:46).”524 Basically, the chain of logic

       Abraham, along with many other OT saints, such as Moses, was looking forward to the Reward City. Was
Jesus ignorant of this fact? Surely not! So, what did Jesus mean when He said, “Your father Abraham rejoiced to
see My day, and he saw it and was glad” (Jn 8:56)? Wilkin explains that most commentators think that Jesus was
talking about His coming as the Promised Messiah or the Messianic Age. Wilkin then comes right up to the threshold
of making a brilliant observation:

               I do not think it is accurate to say that Abraham rejoiced “about the forgiveness of sins
         and eternal life that Christ would bring.” That would suggest that forgiveness and everlasting life
         was future to Abraham’s day. But Abraham knew that he was forgiven, justified, and regenerate
         (Gen 15:6). A better way to understand this statement is that Abraham knew that he was eternally
         secure and that he would be in Messiah’s kingdom. That knowledge caused him to rejoice. Compare
         Heb 11:10.525 (Italics his.)

Unfortunately, having cited the misthological passage from Heb 11:10 regarding the Reward City, Wilkin proceeds
to provide a soteriological explanation instead:

                 Jesus’ listeners were angry with Him over this statement about Abraham. Why? The rabbis had
         long taught that Abraham had a vision during his lifetime of the coming Messiah and His kingdom. It
         is therefore unlikely that they would have been angry had Jesus said, “Abraham rejoiced to
         see Messiah’s day.” Carson puts it this way: “The point of tension arose because of the way Jesus
         phrases this: not ‘Your father Abraham rejoiced to see the messianic age’, but ‘Your father Abraham
         rejoiced to see my day’. The ‘day’ or the ‘day of the Lord’ becomes Jesus’ day” (Carson, John, p.
         357). Jesus was using Abraham to support His claim that He is the Messiah who guarantees everlasting
         life to all who believe in Him.526 (Emphasis his.)

       Although Wilkin is correct that Jesus is associating what Abraham was looking forward to with Himself,
Wilkin is wrong to reduce it to a soteriological claim of merely providing the gift of eternal life to all those who
would believe in Him. As Wilkin acknowledges, Abraham knew that he was soteriologically secure.527 Abraham
was not looking forward to soteriological security. Abraham already had it. Rather, he was looking forward to the
misthological realization of the Reward City, as is proven by the very passage Wilkin cites in Heb 11:10. Abraham
was not merely looking forward to being in the Messiah’s kingdom but to being in the Messiah’s City. Are we to
think, as some commentators would seemingly have us believe, that Abraham was looking forward to the Messianic
Age but failed to realize that it would entail the Messianic City? Jesus was not only proclaiming a soteriological
gospel of grace but also the misthological gospel of the kingdom, and the gospel of the kingdom implicitly had to
include the gospel of the City.
       Even during his sojourn on Earth, Abraham was looking forward to Jesus proclaiming the GOK and its related
KOH. Jesus’ doing so would mean that the realization of the KOH was contingently near. If Abraham’s Jewish
descendants would just receive Jesus’ message, then Abraham would be able to enter the Reward City. During his
lifetime, Abraham anticipated this future proclamation of the KOH by Jesus as the Messiah. To be sure, Abraham

    This specification addresses the short-sighted tense objections raised by various commentators. For instance,

             But when did Abraham see Christ? Consider first, that in John 1:18 the apostle explains that

      the verses in Genesis that tell of the LORD’s appearing to Abraham refer to the appearance of the Son
      of God (15:1; 17:1; 18:1). For example, in Gen 18:1, Moses specifically says that “the LORD appeared
      to him.” Also, in Gen 15:1, Moses tells us that the LORD appeared to the patriarch in a vision. Thus,
      when Gen 15:6 declares that Abraham believed God and He counted it to him for righteousness, the
      object of Abraham’s faith was undoubtedly the Son of God, the preincarnate Christ. Is it not
      appropriate therefore to say that Abraham was a Christian?

looked ahead in time and believed in the coming Christ for eternal life. Therefore, he was saved by faith alone in
Excursus on Abraham and Moses and John the Baptist                                                        Page 431
of the Lord, He had made this promise to Abraham? No! Had Jesus failed to remember that Abraham was looking
forward to the Reward City? No! Any thought that Jesus did not intend for the Reward City to be a primary part of
the GOK or the KOH is to bank on Jesus’ ignorance of what He had promised Abraham and the misthological goal
of His mission. Not a safe bet! Do commentators really expect us to believe that, in this Johannie context, in which
Jesus knew that He was God (Jn 8:58), Jesus did not know that Abraham was looking forward to a Heavenly City
during his time on Earth when Abraham was wandering around in the Promise Land?
Govett
      Having pointed out the futility of some commentators above, in their erroneously equating a gift with a
reward, and observing that some of them say the dumbest things,531 it is fitting to note that some commentators say
the smartest things. I did not consult the commentators on Jn 8:56 until I had first provided my own analysis above.
Then, I checked to see if any commentators might have come close to anything approaching the same conclusion.
To my surprise, Govett explicitly seems to have put all the pieces together:

             The promises of God to Abraham suppose his resurrection before the earth is destroyed. Then
      restored to his body, his soul will no longer be left in hades [no longer in Subterranean Paradise],
      but will possess the land of promise [terranean Promised Land]….
             …Abraham looked to Christ as the Great Redeemer and fulfiller of all the hopes to Abraham;
      the Jehovah, indeed, who by His power would bring in the resurrection of the dead. Abraham knew
      that he was to die, and be buried, and that hundreds of years should pass ere his hopes were fulfilled.
      But he trusted in One whose power would bring in resurrection….
             ‘My day.’… Some endeavor to make the words, ‘He saw and rejoiced’ refer to some discovery
      of Christ made to Abraham after his death, and at that time of His (Christ’s) appearing on earth. But
      the words will not bear any such thought. They would then have been, He saw and rejoices,’ or ‘He
      sees and rejoices.’ As they stand the words intimate that both this site and the joy were past, because
      both refer to the time of Abraham’s life in the flesh [proper duction from tenses]….
      ….Abraham was waiting for the time when his Seed should put forth His power against His foes, and
      on behalf of Abraham himself and of his two seeds after the flesh and spirit [thus sand and star
      seeds of Gen 22:17]. ‘My day,’ signifies chiefly ‘My day of glory, and of the millennial
      Kingdom…. Such would be the day in which the Son of Man would show Himself in glory and the
      heaven, then taking the Kingdom over all the works of God (Ps. viii.).
             The promises then to Abraham assure to him a place in that day of the millennial kingdom of
      heaven. He is then to arise, and enjoy the land of Palestine [thus the Promised Land], yea, the
      whole earth [thus Promised Earth]. He is then to enter also on the better and heavenly country,
      and to enjoy the mansions of the city which God had built [thus the celestial Promised City]…
      And he perceived that God’s promises to him implied, that he should have a part in that day of
      glory. (Emphasis his).

       As Govett perceives, Abraham was looking forward to the millennial kingdom when Christ would reveal
Himself in glory and that Abraham in his resurrected body would be freed from the Subterranean Paradise to
participate in the terranean Promised Earth and terranean Promised Land and celestial Promised City. The only
tweak that I perceived myself as having added to Govett’s argument was to propose that Abraham would have
known that participation in these millennial blessings would have necessitated that Jesus would first proclaim the
GOK and offer the KOH as contingently near. Upon a second reading, however, I observed that Govett’s extended
argument leads to this very conclusion:

            We may say that Abraham saw Christ, both (1) in the promises of the coming millennial day,
      and (2) also in the typical events which befell our Lord during his life.... Abraham, in some of the
      scenes of his life which are written for us, saw, by the teaching of God, types of that come kingdom


Christ alone.” Yes, the OT believers were saved by looking ahead to the Promised Redeemer. Yet, in the case of
some OT saints, they were able to believe in the Promised Redeemer who stood right in front of them at the time,
as the Angel of the Lord, and trust in the promised redemption He would accomplish for them in the future.
531
    See Invalid Vantage Points, 417.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 432
      of glory.
             1. He beheld then in type of Isaac raised (in a figure) from the dead, that the promises
      were to come to him through his Individual Heir after His being slain, and raised. It was over
      the risen Isaac that the Angel-Jehovah uttered his oath never to be recalled. When the promises
      (Gen. xxii. [22]) are fulfilled, Messiah’s day of glory will have come.

        WH credits Abraham with deducing that God would have to raise Isaac from the dead if Abraham was
required to sacrifice Isaac: “He considered that God is able to raise men even from the dead; from which he also
received him back as a type” (Heb 11:19). Paul credits Abraham with knowing and believing the soteriological
gospel: “And the Scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, preached the gospel beforehand
to Abraham, saying, ‘All the nations shall be blessed in you.’ So then those who are of faith are blessed with
Abraham, the believer” (Gal 3:8-9). Are we really to believe Paul and yet doubt that Abraham was unable to
perceive that everyone who, like Abraham, believed in the Promised Messiah, whom Abraham knew would come
through his lineage as the Promised Seed (Gen 3:15; Gal 3:19), would become Abraham’s spiritual seed—children
of promise? Could Abraham not anticipate the very proclamation that Paul makes in Gal 4:8: “And you brethren,
like Isaac, are children of promise”? Govett credits Abraham with being able to deduce that the Messiah would
fulfill the type regarding Isaac by being slain and raised. When would this occur? When the Messiah came and
preached the GOK, of course. Abraham foreknew that Jesus would be slain and raised when He preached the GOK
and that this would be a necessary precursor to Abraham being able to enter the KOH’s Heavenly City, for which
he was sojourning. Abraham saw a lot when he saw Jesus’ coming day.
        Govett also notes that the sons of Abraham’s flesh, as sons of the kingdom, are cast out into the outer darkness
(Mt 8:12). Naturally, that passage deals with the KOH (Mt 8:11). A question might be supposed at this point: Did
Abraham foresee the outer darkness? More reasonably, one might pose: How could he not? Certainly, he would at
least know that the Reward City was not Gift City! As a reward, the City would be limited to his faithful believing
children—whether they be physical or spiritual. Spatially, the basic definition of the outer darkness is exclusion
from the Reward City.532 At the very least, Abraham would have perceived that exclusion from the Reward City
would be at stake. Fittingly, in Mt 8:11-12, Jesus links His first teaching regarding the outer darkness with reclining
at the table with Abraham, the kingdom of heaven, and the sons of the kingdom. While Abraham’s physical
descendants would automatically be excluded from the KOH if they did not believe the GOG, both his physical and
spiritual descendants would be excluded if they did not believe the GOH. Such elementary deductions would not
have been lost on astute Abraham.
Supporting Commentators
     Some commentators can be cited in support of Govett’s more thorough explanation. The summation by Lange
(ACHS) is pregnant with possible implications:

            The expression of all the immeasurable hopes of Abraham united in their central point of aim.
      The hope for the heir—for the heirs—for the inheritance (Heb. 11) was a hope whose aim and centre
      appeared on the day of the Divine Heir who embraces all other heirs and the whole inheritance. The
      day of Christ is therefore also the whole time of the New Testament, as it reaches beyond the last
      day into the eternal day of His glory. (Emphasis his).

      True. In a very condensed nutshell, this is what Govett claims. The full inheritance of Heb 11, which includes
the Promised Land and Promised City, were in Abraham’s preview, and Abraham saw everything from the death
and resurrection of Christ to the glorification of Christ, including His proclaiming the GOK and establishing the
KOH. If Lange really means to affirm all these latent implications by his comprehensive statement, then he has
done well.
      Barnes (BNONT), on the other hand, does not leave the matter so implicit and, in fact, rivals Govett to a
considerable extent in his explicitness:


532
   Dillow acknowledges: “Marty Cauley’s work on the Darkness Outside [TOD] may be the most extensive and

             “He saw it. See He. 11:13: “These all died in faith, not having received (obtained the

       Wilkin cites Heb 11:10 as indicating what Abraham saw pertaining to Jesus’ day; Barnes cites Heb 11:13.
Excellent! If Jesus is affirming that what Abraham saw coming to fruition is what Jewish sources and WH confirms
to be true of Abraham (which certainly seems to be the case), then Jesus is implicitly acknowledging that Abraham
foresaw the GOK and the KOH (thus the PE, PL, and PC). Similarly, Wiersbe (BC) corroborates:

             How did Abraham “see” our Lord’s day, that is, His life and ministry on earth? The same
      way he saw the future city: by faith (Heb. 11:10, 13–16). God did not give Abraham some special
      vision of our Lord’s life and ministry, but He did give him the spiritual perception to “see” these future
      events. Certainly Abraham saw the birth of the Messiah in the miraculous birth of his own son,
      Isaac. He certainly saw Calvary when he offered Isaac to God (Gen. 22). In the priestly ministry
      of Melchizedek (Gen. 14:17–24), Abraham could see the heavenly priesthood of the Lord. In the
      marriage of Isaac, Abraham could see a picture of the marriage of the Lamb (Gen. 24).

Mattew Henry (MHCWB) likewise states:

      It is more commonly understood of some sight he had of Christ’s day in this world. They that
      received not the promises, yet saw them afar off, Heb. 11:13. Balaam saw Christ, but not now, not
      nigh. There is room to conjecture that Abraham had some vision of Christ and his day, for his own
      private satisfaction, which is not, nor must be, recorded in his story, like that of Daniel’s, which must
      be shut up, and sealed unto the time of the end, Dan. 12:4. Christ knew what Abraham saw better than
      Moses did. But there are divers things recorded in which Abraham saw more of that which he longed
      to see than he did when the promise was first made to him. He saw in Melchizedek one made like unto
      the Son of God, and a priest for ever; he saw an appearance of Jehovah, attended with two angels, in
      the plains of Mamre. In the prevalency of his intercession for Sodom he saw a specimen of Christ’s
      intercession; in the casting out of Ishmael, and the establishment of the covenant with Isaac, he saw a
      figure of the gospel day, which is Christ’s day; for these things were an allegory. In offering Isaac,
      and the ram instead of Isaac, he saw a double type of the great sacrifice; and his calling the place
      Jehovah-jireh—It shall be seen, intimates that he saw something more in it than others did, which time
      would produce; and in making his servant put his hand under his thigh, when he swore, he had a regard
      to the Messiah533

       In an article, Dimmick stresses the heavenly nature of the promise made to Abraham and confirms that he,
along with the other patriarchs, was looking forward to the Heavenly City in the heavenly kingdom of Christ (later
to be called the kingdom of heaven by Christ):
533
   Matthew Henry, Matthew Henry’s Commentary on the Whole Bible: Complete and Unabridged in One Volume

             There is, indeed, a sense, and that a very important sense, in which the covenant with Abraham
      was strictly an eternal covenant, and the blessing promised,—not the earthly Canaan, but that which
      the earthly Canaan prefigured,—an eternal inheritance. The blessing included, and was designed more
      and more to unfold into, a spiritual good, that should continue, not only through the duration of earth,
      but through the duration of heaven itself. It was a blessing in Christ, and including Christ and his grace,
      and the fruits of his grace, while eternity shall endure. So the apostle interprets it. “To Abraham and
      his seed were promises made. He saith not, And to seeds, as of many; but as of one, And to thy seed,
      which is Christ,” (Gal. 3:16). Christ was the leading blessing, even in the covenant with Abraham,—
      Christ, and the eternal heaven which he has prepared for his people. Hence it is written: “If ye be
      Christ’s, then are ye Abraham’s seed, and heirs according to the promise” (Gal. 3:29); heirs of heaven
      according to that very promise which God made to Abraham. So Abraham himself understood

      kingdom. “He looked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God;” and,
      with his fellow-sojourners in Canaan, through faith, “desired a better country, that is, an heavenly,”
      (Heb. 11:10, 15). This was the vision that filled the believing eye of the father of the faithful, and
      the other patriarchs who embraced the promises. The earthly Canaan,—a blessing, indeed, in
      itself,—was yet but a shadow of richer blessings seen through it, the kingdom of Christ, and the
      glory of heaven.534

Such interpreters do well in crediting Abraham with far-reaching soteriological, misthological, and misthopological
insights and in perceiving Jesus as including this whole range in His affirmation of what Abraham saw.535
                                      Jesus Preached the GOK and the KOH
       Abraham and Moses saw the GOK and the KOH that Jesus would eventually preach. In particular, Jesus was
offering the Promised City that Abraham and Moses had anticipated. Indeed, we learn that the Promised City was
also the Prepared City. The conclusion that Jesus was talking inclusively about the promise of the Promised City
in His affirmation about what Abraham saw about the proclamation of the KOH in Jesus’ day is virtually demanded
by the exclusivity of Jesus’ reference to the Promised City (PC) as the Prepared Place (PP) in Jn 14:2-3: “In My
Father’s house are many dwelling places; if it were not so, I would have told you; for I go to prepare [hetoimazo]
a place [topos] for you. And if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again, and receive you to Myself; that
where I am, there you may be also.” Jesus is talking spatially about a Prepared Place, namely, the Prepared City, as
is indicated by WH: “But as it is, they desire a better country, that is a heavenly one. Therefore God is not ashamed
to be called their God; for He has prepared [hetoimazo] a city for them” (Heb 11:16). Jesus was speaking cryptically.
Consequently, the disciples did not understand and honestly confessed their obtuseness during this discourse: “Lord,
we do not know where You are going” (Jn 14:5). “We do not know what He is talking about” (Jn 16:18).
Nevertheless, Jesus promised them subsequent insight: “But the Helper, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send
in My name, He will teach you all things, and bring to your remembrance all that I said to you” (Jn 14:26). Jesus
knew what He was talking about, the Promised Place—the Promised City.536 The disciples eventually came to know
what He was talking about. Matthew, for example, had figured it out by the time he wrote his gospel. He could not
spell it out in his written account of Jesus’ ministry because Jesus did not spell it out during the course of His
ministry, but the Lord did drop some big hints. As a follower of Jesus, Mathew follows Jesus’ example by dropping
a big hint himself, cryptically referring to the Heavenly Promised Place/City with the expression Kingdom of

Heaven (KOH). Indeed, various prepared places in this Prepared Place/City are anticipated by Jesus’ earlier words

“Come, you who are blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom prepared [hetoimazo] for you from the foundation
of the world” (Mt 25:34). The Heavenly City is the Prepared Kingdom (PK). The faithful sheep are to receive places
in this Prepared City/Kingdom at the beginning of the millennial kingdom (MK), to be sure, but the kingdom cannot
be simply equated with either the Promise Land (PL) of the millennial kingdom or even more comprehensively with
the millennial kingdom itself because the Prepared Kingdom has been prepared (perfect passive participle denoting
completed action and resulting state) since “the foundation of the world.” Hence, the present study has demonstrated
the prehistory of the Heavenly City. Paul refers to this Prepared Kingdom City (PKC) as a “hidden wisdom” that
has been prepared [hetoimazo] “for those who love” God and which is discerned by the Spirit of God as being
“predestined before the ages to our glory” (1Cor 2:6-10). Like Jesus and Mattew, Paul is cryptic. Yet he is not
obtuse. He knows what he is talking about in his writings, the PKC, and he drops a lot of big hints of his own. Some
of the NT hints are so big that various writers and commentators pick up on them in various places. This passage in
Jn 14:2-3 is one of those places.
        Whereas most commentators are obtuse and think that Jesus is just speaking generically of Heaven or God’s
presence in Jn 14:2-3,537 some commentators who are more astute and realize that Jesus is talking, at least inclusively
if not exclusively, about the Heavenly City. Beasley-Murray (WBC) weighs in with his scholarly discussion,
appropriately adding 2Cor 5:1 as a Pauline passage associated with the Heavenly City, making an exclusive
association with the Heavenly City:

      The Father’s “house” with its many dwellings is most plausibly a pictorial representation of the
      transcendent dwelling of God, such as is depicted under the figure of “the city of the living God,
      the heavenly Jerusalem” in Heb 12:22, a symbol which is greatly elaborated in the apocalyptic vision
      of the City of God in Rev 21:9–22:5. Naturally the figure in John 14:2–3 is wholly unapocalyptic;
      rather it is eschatological, as the related comparison of tent and house in 2 Cor 5:1…. The departure
      of Jesus is for the purpose of preparing a place for the disciples within that “home”; the latter is viewed

they are taken to the Heavenly City, where they will live with God forever. Woychuk makes a comprehensive

       N. A. Woychuk, “Is Heaven A Place?,” BibSac 109 (1952): 75. He correctly perceives that Jesus is talking
inclusively of the City, but he wrongly equates the Heavenly City with Heaven. I held the same mistaken notion in
TOD; even so, even there, I correctly stated: “Those who inherit the land will be the ones who possess the city.
Overcomers (i.e. bridal saints) will possess dwelling places in the bridal city (Jn 14:2-3). Subcomers will not.” Even
in TOD, I knew that nonovercomers would be excluded from the Reward City. However, I mistakenly thought that
it would only happen eventually, at the beginning of the millennial kingdom, since I equated Heaven with the
Heavenly City. Now, as a result of the present series (e.g., MMP1, MMP4), I know better. The Heavenly City is a
part of Heaven, not equal to Heaven. Unfaithful believers are excluded from being inside the Reward City, both
presently and eschatologically. They are presently and forever will be in other parts of Heaven. In this passage,
Jesus is talking about the rapture of faithful believers to the Heavenly City. While partial rapturists will take this
interpretation as proof of a partial rapture, I do not. Other passages talk more comprehensively and inclusively about
the broader scope of the rapture (e.g., 1Thess 4:13-5:10).

      as existing already, but by his death and exaltation the Lord is to make it possible for his own to be
      there with him. (Emphasis his.)

Wilkin (GNTC) splits the difference, sees both spatial possibilities, and takes an inclusive approach:
             “My Father’s house” refers to heaven or to the whole universe. Many commentators suggest
      that heaven and some vague sort of heavenly dwellings are in view. This is highly unlikely because
      the eternal abode of believers is the new earth, not heaven (Rev 21:1–27). The dwellings (mansions)
      refer to literal homes or apartments which someday will come down with the New Jerusalem out of
      the new heavens onto the new earth. Revelation 21:2, which refers to the descending New Jerusalem
      as a bride prepared for her husband, probably parallels John 14:2, which speaks of Jesus preparing a
      place for His disciples. The New Jerusalem with its golden buildings is prepared by Jesus both for His
      disciples’ joy, and for His own. (Emphasis his.)

Since, as a result of the present study, I am inclined to believe that God has many inhabited planets throughout the
whole universe, I concur with Wilkin’s inclusion of the whole universe (as being presently dwelt in) as being a
plausible part of the scope of the reference. Indeed, I agree with McGee (TTBC):

      I do not think that God has a vacancy sign hanging out anyplace in this vast universe. I don’t mean
      that human beings are living on other planets. One is enough of little mankind—we are the ones who
      are in rebellion against God. However, I think this vast universe is filled with created intelligences
      who are looking at this little earth. This is where they see something unique in the universe.538

Though McGee equates the KOH with “the reign of God over this earth,” he immediately goes on to add that the
Prepared Place is the Prepared City:
              The disciples are startled when Jesus reveals that He is going to take a people—beginning with
      the apostles—off this earth to be with Christ in the place that He is preparing for them. This is
      the first time it is mentioned, but it is not the last time. Paul talked about it, saying in 1
      Thessalonians 4 that the Lord Himself would descend from heaven with a shout. His voice will be like
      a trumpet and like the sound of an archangel. He is coming to call His own. The dead in Christ will
      rise first, and then those believers who are still alive will be caught up together to meet the Lord in the
      air. So shall we ever be with the Lord in that place that He has prepared. John, in Revelation 21, tells
      us that the city, the new Jerusalem, will come down from God out of heaven. It will be a new city, a
      new concept in urban dwelling, my friend, and that is where believers, from the apostles on, will dwell
      throughout eternity.

       Following the example of Wilkin and McGee, a dualistic approach might be allowed. Let us consider that
vantage point first. Broadly speaking, the Father’s house presently might be the inhabited heavens of the whole
universe (with various sentient beings living on numerous planets ruled over by angelic overlords who are watching
to see what happens on Earth). Eschatologically and misthologically speaking, though, which is the focus of the
context, Jesus is referring to the Heavenly City. Indeed, temporally and eschatologically (thus dualistically), a few
verses later: “Jesus answered and said to him, ‘If anyone loves Me, he will keep My word; and My Father will love
him, and We will come to him, and make Our abode with him” (Jn 14:23). Presently, Jesus and the Father come to
the obedient believer in the form of spiritual fellowship. Eschatologically and misthologically, Jesus and the Father
will come to have their abode (mone) with the obedient believer inside the Heavenly Abode—City.
       The only other occurrence of mone in the Bible is in Jn 14:2, which is translated as rooms, mansions, dwelling
places, etc. God’s dwelling place with the obedient believer during both the millennial kingdom and the eternal
state will be the Heavenly City. In both Jn 14:2 and 14:23, Jesus is at least talking inclusively about New Jerusalem
as the misthopological dwelling place (mone) of God and the obedient believer. Wilkin is in the general ballpark
when he goes on to add, regarding Jn 14:23, “The implication of this link between vv 2 and 23 is that the present
dwelling of God within believers is a foretaste of the eternal kingdom when God will dwell with them on the new
538
   Barnes (BNONT) also applies the passage to the universe. In a more contemporary fashion, I would apply it to
the multiverse.
Excursus on Abraham and Moses and John the Baptist                                                              Page 437
earth.” More precisely, since v. 23 includes the Father and since the Father will not dwell on the New Earth but in
New Jerusalem, Jesus is referring specifically to New Jerusalem, not generically to the New Earth. As noted in
LTPW, even David provides this misthopological implication when he says, “I will dwell in the house of the Lord
forever” (Ps 23:6). Though David will rule on Earth in the PL during the millennial kingdom, he will also have a
dwelling place in the PC as well. He knew this would be the case. Planet Earth will be a footstool for David’s feet
when he plants them on earth, just as Jesus spoke of Earth as the footstool of God’s feet and Jerusalem as “the city
of the great King” (Mt 5:34). This earth-footstool-city-Jerusalem relationship foreshadows the Earth-footstool-City-
Jerusalem relationship that overcomers will share with God in relationship to the New Earth and New Jerusalem.
        Certainly, the double dualistic approach for Jn 14:2-3 is very attractive. Both temporal-eschatological
dualism and universal-misthopological dualism might both be intended. Nonetheless, even though I would like to
adopt the universal-misthopological dualism so that I could use Jn 14:2 as a prooftext for my deduction herein that
life currently exists on other planets, I will have to pass. Conceptually, I agree with Wilkin and McGree.
Exegetically, though, I am skeptical that Jn 14:2 is talking about the whole universe as the Father’s house.
        First, the context is limiting the Father’s dwelling to faithful believers in Jn 14:23. Presumably, the same
would be true in Jn 14:2. Second, the OT Davidic background associates participation in God’s house with reward
and Mt Zion, not the universe (see LTPW). Third, being Christ’s house is a reward: “Christ was faithful as a Son
over His house whose house we are, if we hold fast our confidence and the boast of our hope firm until the end”
(Heb 3:6).
        As discussed more thoroughly in FFG, the contingency in Heb 3:6 runs parallel to the perfective state and is
necessary to maintain that state. Continuing to hold fast is necessary if one is to remain in the state of being qualified
for participation in Christ’s ruling house (Heb 3:6). Temporally, the Lord rules in the faithful believer as His house
(cp. Jn 14:23). Misthologically, the faithful believer remains qualified to be a member of the ruling body of His
house. Instead of being members of the House of Representatives, such believers will be members of the House of
Christ: co-rulers with Christ. Just as house refers to the ruling family in 2Sam 7:16, so it refers to ruling priests in
Heb 3:6. Currently, believers function as Christ’s representatives on Earth merely as priests, but the full realization
of that role will involve their functioning as ruling priests. They will be a ruling household of priests. In order to
function in that capacity and therefore be a part of that house, we must hold fast. Moreover, just as the priestly role
carried out in the tabernacle prefigures the priestly function that is to be carried out in its heavenly counterpart
(Heb 8-9), so those believers who wish to serve as a member of that household in the Heavenly City (the capital of
the kingdom) must be faithful. The political House of Representatives is nothing but a pale illustration of this
priestly House of Representatives.
        In short, the priestly role, the tabernacle typology, and the house imagery point to New Jerusalem, not the
whole universe, as Christ’s house, which in the context of Hebrews is associated with God’s rest (Heb 3:11; etc.)—
Rest City (cp. Heb 11:10; etc.). Therefore, in Jn 14:2-3 and Heb 3:6, I am content with temporal-eschatological
dualism and will pass on universal-misthopological dualism. Accordingly, in this text, both the temporal and
eschatological aspects are strictly rewards, thus misthological, rather than universal or soteriological.
        The objection might be raised that the present tense is used in Jn 14:2. Jesus says, “In My Father’s house are
many dwelling places,” not, “in my Father’s house will be many dwelling places.” Valid point. A juxtaposition is
posed between the dwelling places (mone) already in existence and the place (topos) that Jesus was going to prepare.
I propose that the distinction is simply temporal rather than inclusively spatial. The McGee-Wilkin proposal would
suppose a spatial distinction: the whole universe versus the Heavenly City. By Jesus’ death, Jesus would open up
the Heavenly City to postmortem inhabitants. This interpretation is extremely attractive and is certainly true
conceptually, as has been deduced in my writings, including the present book. Still, a strictly temporal explanation
is possible. Jesus’ statement in Mt 20:23 is very suggestive: “He said to them, ‘My cup you shall drink; but to sit
on My right and on My left, this is not Mine to give, but it is for those for whom it has been prepared by My
Father.’” Note the preparer in Jesus’s statement. Why does Christ not have the right to determine who will sit on
His right and His left in His own house? Would it not seem strange if you went to have dinner with a friend in his
house, and he told you that he had no right to determine who sits beside him since the right to make that choice was
reserved for his father? Would you not think that your friend’s father was some type of control freak? Rather than
adopt some freakish type of interpretation, the postulation might be posed that the reason the Father determines who
will sit beside Christ is that it is the Father’s house. In that case, one can certainly understand why the Father would
reserve the right to determine who would set where. A dichotomy between Christ’s house and the Father’s house
need not be supposed. After all, both the Father and the Son live in New Jerusalem!
        Even so, the objection might be pressed that the present tense proves that the Father’s house had many
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 438
dwelling places already in use, so it could not possibly be the Heavenly City before Christ led captivity captive to
the City. Again, a valid consideration. Nonetheless, observe the tense of Jesus’ statement: “It is for those for whom
it has been prepared [hetoimazo] by my Father” (Mt 20:23). On the one hand, the completed preparation of this
place matches the completed preparation of the kingdom in Mt 25:34, as noted by Hagner (WBC), which was before
the foundation of the world. So, Lange concludes: “The place which each of us is to hold in the eternal kingdom, is
the result of our eternal destination, and intimately connected with the state of our minds and hearts.—For whom
it is prepared, οἶς ἡτοίμασται.—That question has been decided before the foundation of the world” (emphasis
his). Likewise, Phillips (JPCS) rightly observes: “But the right to that place is not His to give. It has to be earned.
Although God gives unmerited salvation, He never gives unmerited rewards. That reality ought to grip our souls.”
McGee likewise elaborates:
      You are saved by faith in Christ through His marvelous grace. However, my friend, your position,
      your reward in heaven is determined by what you do down here on earth. That is very important, and
      Christians seem to have lost sight of it. What kind of a place are you preparing for yourself? Personally,
      I have no ambition for the places on Christ’s right or left hand—I’m sure I have missed those—but I
      am working for a place. All of us should be doing this.

       Very good. We should all be working for a place in the City even if the top positions within it might already
have been won by saints of old, such as Enoch, Abraham, Moses, David, or Daniel. Yet the question remains, since
the Father has handed all judgment over to the Son (Jn 5:22), why does the Father determine who sits where at this
most prestigious level? Barnes (BNONT) provides a thoughtful answer:

      Is not mine to give, &c. The translation of this place evidently does not express the sense of the original.
      The translation expresses the idea that Jesus has nothing to do in bestowing rewards on his followers.
      This is at variance with the uniform testimony of the Scriptures, Mat. 25:31–40; Jn. 5:22–30. The
      correct translation of the passage would be, “To sit on my right hand and on my left is not mine to
      give, except to those for whom it is prepared by my Father.” The passage thus declares that Christ
      would give rewards to his followers, but only to such as should be entitled to them according to
      the purpose of his Father. Much as he might be attached to these two disciples, yet he could not
      bestow any such signal favours on them out of the regular course of things. Rewards were
      prepared for his followers, and in due time they should be bestowed. He would bestow them
      according as they had been provided from eternity by God the Father, Mat. 25:34. (Italics his.)

       In short, the eschatological realization of this pre-temporal, presumptively prepared reward is contingent on
their temporal performance and bestowed by Christ at the Bema, in accord with the Father’s pre-temporal
misthological election. The Father already had presumptively prepared this kingdom (Mt 25:34). This
Presumptively Prepared Kingdom (PPK) came complete with a Promised Kingdom City (PKC), which, in turn, was
complete with plural individual dwelling places (mone) in the Father’s House/City. Jesus, in contrast, was going to
prepare this singular promised place (topos) City for His faithful followers. By His death, Jesus would open the
doors of the Prepared Place City (PPC) to His overcomers so that they could take their abodes and seats at the
individual dwelling places (IDP) already allotted to them by the Father within the PPC. In shorthand, the Father’s
preparation of the PPK (which contains the PKC) and the IDP (contained within the PKC) would rely on Christ’s
preparation of the PKC.
                           Melchizedekian Priests Preached the GOK and the KOH
John the Baptist
       The preaching of Jesus regarding the GOK and the KOH was preceded by that of John the Baptist (JB). As
part of his preparing the way of the Messiah, JB was preaching, “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand”
(Mt 3:2). John knew that the Messiah would be offering the KOH. JB also knew that Jesus existed before him even
though Jesus was born after him. Thus, he bore witness of Jesus, saying, “‘This was He of whom I said, ‘He who
comes after me has a higher rank than I, for He existed before me.’” (Jn 1:15). Wilkin (GNTC) affirms: “The
preexistence of the Word is confirmed by the testimony of John the Baptist.” Barnes (BNONT) confirms: “This can
refer to nothing but his pre-existence, and can be explained only on the supposition that he existed before John, or,
as the evangelist had before shown, from the beginning.” In the same manner, NIBC states, “John the Baptist said
Excursus on Abraham and Moses and John the Baptist                                                           Page 439
Jesus was before him, meaning that Jesus’ existence is from eternity past (v. 30) .” Lenski (LCNT) is emphatic:

              The objection has been raised that the knowledge of the pre-existence of Christ was beyond the
      experience of the Baptist. The evangelist is charged with putting his own ideas into the mouth of the
      Baptist. The same is done with regard to many of the great utterances of Christ himself. The very
      strangeness of the Baptist’s utterance is unique. It is couched in a form that the Jews liked and because
      of its very form is easily remembered. The stress which the evangelist puts upon this testimony of the
      Baptist, both here and in v. 29–33, shows that this remarkable testimony is genuine. The Baptist uttered
      not only this testimony but all his preaching by revelation as one who was sent and commissioned by
      God.

       Furthermore, JB knew that Jesus was the Lamb of God who would take away the world’s sin (Jn 1:29). Thus,
even from this scant biblical data, we have reason to believe that JB knew that Jesus was God incarnate who would
die to take away our sins.
Essenes
       Extrabiblical data gives us further confirmation and perhaps even much more. In his book, The Ancient
Mysteries of the Essenes, which is really a compilation of three of his books into one, Ken Johnson retraces the
extrabiblical data regarding prophetic information passed down through the Essenes whose writings had been
preserved in the Qumran community, of which Johnson deduces that JB was a leader.539 Johnson provides a
fascinating reconstruction of the historical events and textual evidence.

                                                 Essene Calendar
       Part One of his book is entitled, “The Ancient Dead Sea Scroll Calendar and the Prophecies it Reveals.”
Johnson begins with the Essene history. Following the biblical mandate in Ex 12:2, the Essenes used “a completely
solar calendar that started with the spring equinox” (p. 11). The Sadducees were Jews who believed they should
follow the high priest no matter what. The Pharisees were dissenters who believed that they should follow the
Mosaic law instead (p. 16). Since the Essenes held their calendar so sacred and believed that the Pharisees corrupted
the calendar by going on moon phases, they made numerous comments about all the things the Pharisees did wrong
on their calendar, repeatedly calling them sons of darkness for following a lunar calendar” (p. 23). Johnson cites
the Dead Sea Scroll 11QMelchizedek as affirming that the Messiah would be a Melchizedekian priest who would
come to Earth and die for our sins in AD 32 (pp. 76-77).

                                        Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs
       Part Two of his book is entitled “The Ancient Testaments of the Patriarchs: Autobiographies from the Dead
Sea Scrolls.” Johnson acknowledges that the history of the scrolls is very complex but says, “We know that the
Essenes kept an ancient library in Qumran” and that “in AD 70, the Essenes sealed the scrolls of their library in jars
for future generations” (p. 111). He calls particular attention to one such set of scrolls called the Testaments of the
Twelve Patriarchs (T12P). In 1995, I wrote a research paper on T12P for a class that I was taking at the time. I have
posted this paper online for the purpose of the present study.540 Our particular interest in the present book for the
T12P is occasioned by the explicit mention of “New Jerusalem” in the Testament of Dan (TDan). Johnson gives a
simplified version of the history of the T12P and then proceeds with a discussion of other similar patriarchal
testaments:

      These were supposedly the writings of the twelve sons of Jacob: Ruben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar,
      Zebulun, Dan, Naphtali, Gad, Asher, Joseph, and Benjamin. They were their last words to their
      children dealing mainly with morality; but also containing references to ancient prophecy.
             Scholars had two major problems with these testaments. First, the prophecies were very focused
      on the Messiah and agreed wholeheartedly with Christian doctrine. Second, the story was that the

    Ken Johnson, Ancient Mysteries of the Essenes: The Ken Johnson Collection (USA: Defender Publishing, 2021).

Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 440
      original Hebrew version was in the hands of a private collector and only the retranslated Greek was
      available for scholars to study. With no original Hebrew scrolls and messianic prophecies being too
      Christian-like, the Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs were dubbed to be Christian fiction. They are
      still part of volume eight of the Ante-Nicene Fathers (ten volume set) that was produced in the late
      1800 s. All that changed with the official discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls.
              Between AD 1948 to 2016, twelve caves were found in Qumran containing many ancient scrolls
      that are pre-Christian. A forty-volume set of the Dead Sea Scrolls was produced entitled Discoveries
      in the Judean Desert. This set contains every photo, description, and translation of these scrolls.
      Fragments of five of the twelve sons of Jacob were found in the Dead Sea Scrolls: Levi, Judah,
      Naphtali, Joseph, and Benjamin. In this book, the portions of the twelve that were found in the Dead
      Sea Scrolls are underlined, so that you can see how much remains from the original Hebrew.

                                             The Other Testaments
             The legend found in the Talmud of the orthodox Jews and in the Essene community is that all
      of the patriarchs from Adam to Aaron (thirty-seven or more) were prophets and all wrote testaments
      for their posterity. (Emphasis his, 111-112)

       Johnson proceeds to give a very positive reconstruction of the prophetic contributions derived from the
existing fragments of these testimonies. Even so, my predisposition is to be much more pessimistic as to the
historical credibility of these testimonies as being unadulterated prophecies, at least in the form we currently have
them. Granted, I believe such testimonies were written. Yet uncritically accepting what we have in its current form
as being completely authentic is very questionable. Moreover, Johnson’s lack of interaction with critical scholarship
prevents me from uncritically adopting his reconstruction, though doing so would strongly support my position. In
short, Johnson takes these testimonies as authentic. I am skeptical, even though taking them as authentic would
prove that the OT patriarchs knew about New Jerusalem. Therefore, I have made this deduction regarding their
knowledge of New Jerusalem through other means during the course of this book. I cannot cite Johnson’s
reconstruction in favor of my position without issuing this disclaimer regarding my skepticism, at least regarding
the authenticity of the final state of the written material he has presented.
       My skepticism goes back to the class I took in 1995. As part of that class, I wrote a paper providing a critical
analysis of the Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs (T12P). As I discussed within that paper, when T12P was first
translated by Robert Grosseteste, the T12P was thought by the church leaders of the West to contain reliable and
genuine prophecies that had originated with the patriarchs concerning Christ. They believed that the Jews had kept
T12 hidden because it clearly pointed to the fact that Jesus is the Christ.
       This initial positive assessment was challenged by Grabe at the close of the 16th century, who thought that it
was a Hebrew document with subsequent material added by Christians. However, the responding consensus was
that T12P was written by a Christian in Greek and that the interpolations, if there were any, were added by other
Christians. In other words, they viewed it as being originally a Christian document with possible Christian
interpolations. However, beginning with Schnapp in 1884, the consensus switched back to thinking that the
document was originally a Jewish document, but now the specific prophecies were considered Christian
interpolations. The Qumran discoveries led to a very popular hypothesis that the authorship was Jewish.
       Dupont-Sommer and his student Philonenko argued that T12P was produced by Essenes at Qumran
and had little to do with Christ or Christianity. In 1953, M. de Jonge readvanced the argument that the author of
T12P was a Christian “compilator, not an interpolator.”541 The Qumran position has few advocates today. The
prevailing opinion has returned to viewing the T12P as originally a (non-Essene) Jewish document versus a
Christian document. Even Kee and Charlesworth, advocates of the Jewish theory, admit that M. de Jonge has
demonstrated that there are Christian redactions in T12P rather than mere interpolations.542 Kee claims that there
are only twelve Christian interpolations in the T12P at the very most and that these interpolations can be easily

identified! However, in Kee’s text and textual notes, he identifies many more interpolations. One would probably
conclude that the rest are redactions. The old debate continues about whether the T12P is a Jewish or a Christian
document. Although both sides talk today of redactions, in practice, the Jewish side of the argument still thinks
primarily in terms of interpolations. It should be remembered that both sides believe the final form of the document
by the end of the second century AD was a Christian document.
       Since my paper was a little dated, I checked a more current resource for the purposes of the present book.
Evidently, my paper is still current since Park gives basically the same position in a 2016 publication:

       TESTAMENTS OF THE TWELVE PATRIARCHS A nonbiblical text that contains pseudonymous
      farewell discourses of the 12 sons of Jacob, preserved primarily in Greek manuscripts, but with some
      fragments in Hebrew and Aramaic.
            Scholars are divided over whether it is a primarily Jewish work with Christian interpolations,
      or a Christian work based on Jewish traditions….
            ….(For a minority view that identifies Qumran as the origin of the T. 12 Patr., see Dupont-
      Sommer, The Jewish Sect).544 (Emphasis his.)

        Apparently, Johnson has given a reconstruction that adopts the primary component of the Dupont-Sommer
argument in taking T12P as an Essene document, which is a minority view. Accordingly, I will only grant the
particulars of Johnson’s reconstruction as providing minor support for my position. That said, the broad strokes of
Johnson’s thesis are entirely justifiable, as argued herein. Namely, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob were certainly aware
of the Promised Redeemer and the Promised City and passed this information on to their descendants. Posing that
each of Jacob’s twelve sons passed this information on to their descendants via written testimonies is a sensible
proposition and is confirmed by Jewish tradition and the Dead Sea scrolls. Maintaining that this information reached
us unadulterated by Christian redaction and interpolation is implausible, however. Therefore, when I read Johnson’s
citation of the testimony of Jacob’s Son, Dan, pertaining to New Jerusalem, my kneejerk reaction was to suspect
Christian redaction. Nevertheless, I would be remiss not to mention the possibility that it adds further credibility to
my position. So, dealing with it briefly herein is prudent. T12P and TDan can be found easily online. TDan 5:12-
13 is translated by H. C. Kee as follows:
      12
         And the saints shall refresh themselves in Eden;
      the righteous shall rejoice in the New Jerusalem,
      which shall be eternally for the glorification of God.
      13
         And Jerusalem shall no longer undergo desolation,
      nor shall Israel be led into captivity,
      because the Lord will be in her midst [living among human beings].
      The Holy One of Israel will rule over them in humility and poverty,
      and he who trusts in him shall reign in truth in the heavens. (Brackets his.)545

       Kee marks the bracketed phrase, living among human beings, as a probable Christian interpolation. Does this
mean that we can assume that the statements about the righteous believers rejoicing in New Jerusalem and reigning
in the heavens are genuine? Perhaps not. They could be Christian redactions of the pre-existing material. A Christian
could have clarified what the original text meant by using the phrase New Jerusalem. Yet Johnson accepts all these
statements at face value (p. 18) without mentioning the possibility of Christian interpolations or redactions.
       Notwithstanding my skepticism of Johnson’s taking such statements at face value, the 1-2-3 punch provided
by his three-books-in-one prevents me from discounting his approach completely. I would highly recommend
reading his entire book for the plausible connection of such texts with an Essene library, going back to the earliest
times, and associated with John the Baptist. Additionally, since T12P is highly dependent upon the prophecies of

    James H. Charlesworth, ed., The Old Testament Pseudepigrapha, 2 vols. (New York: Doubleday, 1983), 777.

Enoch, reading Johnson’s Ancient Book of Enoch in conjunction with his The Ancient Mysteries of the Essenes is
recommended.
       A variety of passages in Enoch are conceptually suggestive of New Jerusalem. The high mountain that has
the fragrant tree that is given to the righteous and humble with food for the elect in the north holy place, which is
the temple of the Lord (1En 25:1-7), certainly sounds like the Tree of Life being reserved as a reward in New
Jerusalem. Indeed, Heiser states: “In chapters 24–25 [of 1Enoch] the seer is once again at the mountain throne of
God. The description of 18:6–9 has been augmented by reference to God’s final visitation of the earth, mention of
the tree of life, and a description of the blessings that the righteous will experience in the new Jerusalem.”546
Thus, Enoch is describing New Jerusalem, though he does not use that term. Lumpkin likewise cites Rev 22:1-3 as
an NT parallel to this Enochian text.547
       The mansions (dwelling places) of the elect and holy in the heavens and kingdom in 1En 41:1-2 certainly
sounds like Jn 14:2-3. Lumpkin (p. 62) cites this NT counterpart in association with this Enochian passage. Yet we
cannot be sure, as Heiser explains: “Mansions of the elect and the mansions of the holy—N, CW: ‘dwelling
place(s).’ To the English reader’s ear, the wording sounds like John 14:1–2. First Enoch 41 does not exist in Greek,
so comparison with the Greek wording of that New Testament passage cannot be made.”548 Even so, the Enochian
context associates it with the “hope of those who inherit eternal life” (1En 40:9). So, one has to wonder if these
mansions are not associated with the misthological theme of inheriting eternal life in the NT (cp. Mt 19:29).
       Other texts in 1Enoch are also suggestive of New Jerusalem. Enoch’s rapture to God’s crystal house in the
heavens of heavens where innumerable angels dwell (1En 71:5-9) sounds like a trip to New Jerusalem. Thus,
Lumpkin (p.94) cites Rev 21:10-11 as a parallel. The extended description of God’s “new and larger house”
(1En 90:28-36) might be too extensive to be limited to the millennial temple, thus entailing New Jerusalem.
Accordingly, Lumpkin (p. 130) cites Heb 13:14 in associating with looking for the Heavenly City for this Enochian
passage and cites the House that the righteous acquire because of their righteousness in association with the House
built for the Great King in glory in 1En 91:12-13 as being a future House (thus a New House) in the new heaven
and earth (p. 132). In summary, although the exact phrase New Jerusalem is not textually present in 1Enoch,
conceptually, the Heavenly City is arguably present.
       In conjunction with the Enochian background, one might pose that the term New Jerusalem in TDan 5:12
might not be a Christian redaction after all but a natural juxtaposition of the pre-existing heavenly misthological
Enochian concept with the affirmation that “Jerusalem shall no longer undergo desolation” in TDan 5:13. The
Heavenly Jerusalem was anticipated to become the New Jerusalem when it becomes the new home of the righteous
believers and is naturally called New Jerusalem in contradiction to the old earthly Jerusalem, which was susceptible
to desolation. If so, one might even pose that Jesus (Rev 3:12) and John (Rev 21:2) got the term New Jerusalem
from Jewish traditions going all the way back to the early patriarchs, as evidenced by TDan 5:13. In this case, both
Jesus and John were using a term that would have been understood by their listeners as having a rich history.
       Johnson concludes the second part of his book by noting that the Sadducees supported forced conversion to
Judaism and forced observance of the priestly code by non-priests. The Pharisees rightly opposed both forms of
coercion but wrongly placed their Oral Torah (i.e., Midrashic oral interpretation of the Torah) on par with the written
Torah. The Essenes arose as a new denomination and agreed with the Pharisees in opposing both forms of coercion
but rightly believed that the “written Torah and the written histories of the forefathers” were the superior authority
(pp. 225-226). This sets the stage for the third part of his book, which deals with the presence of these written
histories by the Essenes.

                                            Melchizedekian Order of Priests
       Part Three of his book is entitled: “Ancient Order of Melchizedek.” Beginning with Adam, God created king-
priest-prophets called Melchizedekian priests (p. 233). They made a successive lineage of prophet-priest-kings—
Kings of Righteousness. Adam was the first of these king-priest-prophets, and we still have fragments of the
