Testament of Adam in the Dead Sea Scrolls. Each of the Melchizedekian priests wrote Testaments. “God gave
Enoch a prophecy that the Messiah would come seventy generations from his time. See Ancient Book of Enoch 10.
Luke 3:23-38 verifies that Jesus Christ is the seventieth generation from Enoch” (p. 241).
       Noah was the fifth Melchizedekian priest, and at the time of the Flood, Noah took all the patriarchal
testaments of the four preceding Melchizedekian priests with him on the Ark. After the Flood, God made what is
commonly known as the Rainbow Covenant with him, “but it is more properly called the Noahide Covenant….God
then instructed Noah to teach his sons to observe what became known as the Seven Noahide Laws….Blasphemy
was defined as not believing everything the prophets said about sin, salvation, and the coming Messiah” (p. 246).
The Testament of Noah contains a dream in which God warned Noah of a coming apostasy. Noah ordained his son
Shem to be the next Melchizedekian King of Righteousness. “Shem and Eber kept the ancient records of their
fathers that Noah had brought aboard the Ark and they wrote the historical records of their time” (p. 248). Shem
was thus the Melchizedekian King who anointed Abraham as the next Melchizedekian priest (Gen 14:18; Heb 7:1-
2).549 As to this biblical text, Johnson explains:

             The Hebrew word “melek” means “king” and the Hebrew word “zedek” means “righteous.”
      Melchizedek is properly translated as “King of Righteousness.” The word Melchizedek can also be
      translated as “King of the Zadok priests.” The priests who lived in Qumran were direct descendants of
      the Jewish high priest Zadok. They were priests of righteousness. They were waiting for the Teacher
      of Righteousness to come. This righteous teacher, or Zadok teacher, was the Messiah….
             ….Jesus became a priest after the order of Melchizedek. [Heb 6:20]
             ….What modern Rabbis teach about Melchizedek comes from the Talmud, which is also called
      the “oral law.” Jesus called this the “tradition of the elders.” This teaching says there was no “Order
      of Melchizedek.” Melchizedek was the name of a man who happened to be a priest of the Most High
      God. On the contrary, the Dead Sea Scrolls teach there never was a man named Melchizedek.
      Melchizedek was an order of priests. The Levitical and Aaronic priests were just priests. The apostle
      Paul teaches that any kind of priest is a human picked to intercede with God on behalf of other people.
      The Melchizedekian priests were a combination of priest, king, and prophet. (Pp. 235-236)

       Returning now to the narrative of events, “Abraham recognized Isaac was ordained by God, so he sent him
to learn the ways of God and how to be a priest of the Most High God” (p. 253). In turn, Isaac’s son, Jacob “was a
‘man of the tents,’ meaning he loved to study the prophecies” (p. 254). Isaac sent Jacob “to the house of Shem and
Eber” (Jasher 28:18) to study for the priesthood (p. 255).

             Jacob studied with Shem and Eber at the School of the Prophets until the death of Shem in 2158
      AM. Eber continued the school, but copies of all of the records were given to Levi for safe keeping.
      Eber died in 2187 AM, just twenty-nine years after his father, Shem, died. Shortly thereafter the area
      was overrun by the Amorites. They seized control of the area, took the records as their own, and even
      took the title of Adonizedek (the Lord of Righteousness) as their own. (P. 256)

      In preparation for his successor, “Jacob sent Levi to learn the priesthood from Isaac his father. God had
revealed to Jacob that the Melchizedekian priesthood was to be broken up until the coming of the Messiah” (p. 258).
This broken Melchizedekian order prophet-priest-kings could only be restored by the Messiah:

             The prophecies stated that the Messiah would be born a direct descendant of Judah. He would
      be born as King. Afterwards, Messiah would have to be ordained into the priesthood by a priest of that
      order. This was the only way for Him to become a real priest. He would also have to be filled with the
      Holy Spirit to become a prophet. Only with these three offices uniting into one man could the
549
   Commenting on Gen 14:18, Fruchtenbaum (ABC) presents Shem as the most reasonable candidate: “While many
have taught that Melchizedek was a preincarnate Christ, this simply cannot be. This was not a theophany, because
theophanies came and went; they appeared, gave their proclamation, message, or commandment and then
disappeared. Theophanies never held an office here on earth. Here, Melchizedek holds two offices: that of king and
that of priest. The only other reference to Melchizedek in the Old Testament is Psalm 110:4. In rabbinic tradition,
Melchizedek was the same person as Shem, the son of Noah” (emphasis his).
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                              Page 444
      Melchizedekian priesthood be recreated. (P. 258)

The Melchizedekian priesthood was broken up by Jacob into three parts among three of his descendants. The office
of high priest went to his son Levi, who passed it down to his son Kohath, who passed the records on to Amran,
and he to Aaron:

             Kohath turned the priesthood over to his son Amram, with the instructions and records.
      According to the Testament of Amram, he left his wife and family in Egypt to go built the sepulchers
      of his fathers in the cave of Machpelah in Canaan. While there, a war broke out and because of it, he
      was trapped and could not get back to his family for forty-one years! When Amram was finally able
      to be reunited with his family, Moses had already been banished from Egypt. Amram turned over the
      priesthood and records to Aaron his firstborn, Moses’ brother. They waited for the fulfillment of the
      prophecy God gave to Abraham. (P. 259)

Through a series of historical events explained by Johnson, the kingly line and priestly lines were subsequently
narrowed down:

              Legitimate Israeli kings could only come through the line of Judah, but later this lineage was
      narrowed to the line of David, a descendant of Judah. In the same way, a high priest had to be of the
      lineage of Levi, but in time it was narrowed to the lineage of Aaron, a descendant of Levi, and finally
      narrowed again to a descendant of Aaron, namely Zadok….
              The Zadok priests knew of the apostasy that was to come, and under inspiration of the Holy
      Spirit, took the temple library to Qumran. There the Lord protected them, and they prepared the hearts
      of the people for the coming of the Messiah. They did this as best as they could in the midst of a
      growing apostasy in the Sanhedrin, and in the Pharisee and Sadducee parties. The Dead Sea Scrolls
      found in Qumran and its surrounding caves are the legacy of the Zadok priests with a complete history
      from their point of view. (Pp. 260-261)

      Through the Ante-Nicene Fathers, Johnson traces “the prophetic line that ran the School of the Prophets from
Moses to John the Baptist” (p. 263). The “head of the School of the Prophets in Qumran” eventually fell to John
the Baptist (pp. 265-266).

      Josephus records that there were two groups of Essenes, the Qumran Essenes (godly Jews who kept
      the scrolls and studied the prophecies) and the Egyptian Essenes (who despised prophecy, and instead
      practiced a system of magic which was forbidden to Jews in Israel). Much like today, Christian
      denominations and cults both claim the name of “Christian.” (P. 266)

             John the Baptist was baptizing in the Jordan river just eight miles from where Qumran was at
      that time. There is a Dead Sea Scroll called the Community Rule which records not only how to
      become an Essene, but how they started. The Community Rule says when the apostasy hit, the Holy
      Spirit spoke to their leaders, the Zadok priests, instructing them to move out of Jerusalem into the
      wilderness taking the temple library with them. They said that the Holy Spirit told them one of their
      order would fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah which says, “The voice of him that crieth in the wilderness,
      Prepare ye the way of the LORD, make straight in the desert a highway for our God. (P. 268)

       JB was not only an Essene and the fulfillment of this Essene prophecy but their leader of the School of the
Prophets. He baptized the sinless Jesus into the priesthood, thereby fulling all righteousness (Mk 3:15), that is,
recreating the Melchizedekian priestly order (Heb 7:17), making Jesus the ultimate Prophet-Priest-King of
Righteousness, who would usher in the Age of Grace, for which the Essene order had long been waiting (pp. 268-
270). I highly recommend Johnson’s Ancient Order of Melchizedek for further details and implications. Herein, I
have only taken a few pages to provide highlights from his discussion leading up to the ministry of JB in order to
establish the fact that JB was preaching the same GOK and KOH as was Jesus. JB was not ignorant of such
prophecies!
       The details Johnson provides for the ancient clash between the Essenes and Pharisees is also helpful:
Excursus on Abraham and Moses and John the Baptist                                                         Page 445

             The Essenes taught that the ancient patriarchs, Adam through Aaron, wrote testaments for their
      children. These testaments contain moral wisdom and Messianic prophecy. The Pharisees agreed
      that these patriarchal texts did exist, but said they were lost long ago. Nothing is ever lost except
      that which you choose to throw away because it does not fit your doctrine. The Essenes rejected the
      Pharisee’s Oral Torah because of what is taught in the Testaments of the Patriarchs. The Pharisees
      reject the Essene testaments because of what their Oral Torah says. Jesus said the Pharisees’
      “Traditions of the Elders,” their Oral Torah, makes void the Word of God. (P. 301)

This clash raises some interesting questions. JB certainly clashed with the Sadducees and Pharisees: “When he saw
many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming for baptism, he said to them, ‘You brood of vipers, who warned you
to flee from the wrath to come?’” (Mt 3:7). In Jesus’ encounter with the Pharisees, Jesus likewise responded, “You
brood of vipers, how can you, being evil, speak what is good? For the mouth speaks out of that which fills the heart”
(Mt 12:34). Could Johnson be correct that part of the reason JB and Jesus were rejected was that they were preaching
a message that had been preserved by the Essenes but rejected by the Pharisees and Sadducees? Granted, the Essenes
represented a minority opinion. But could the tendency of modern scholarship to write off the Essenes as a sect or
to reject the prophetic elements of their writings be guilty of showing a modern-day Pharisaical spirit and bias?
       For Johnson to be fully persuasive in such speculations, however, he needs to interact with scholastic
counterpoints, such as those raised by Elwell and Barry:

             From time to time there have been attempts to show that Jesus and the early Christians
      were Essenes. A full treatment of the discussion can be found in J.B. Lightfoot, St. Paul’s Epistles to
      the Colossians and to Philemon (London: Macmillan, 1875), pp. 82–95, 114–179. There is nothing
      to be gained in reopening this discussion, unless, of course, we substitute the Qumran materials
      for what Philo, Josephus, and Pliny have told us about the Essenes, a methodology that would be highly
      objectionable.550 (Italics theirs.)

       By and large, Johnson has endeavored to perform this very substitution, using the Qumran materials to show
that John the Baptist was an Essene:

      We will look at the history, theology, and prophecy of the Melchizedekian priests from many sources.
      These will include books of the Bible (Genesis and the Psalms), Jewish history books (the Ancient
      Book of Jasher and Josephus), Dead Sea Scroll Testaments (authored by Noah, Levi, Kohath, Amram,
      Aaron, and others), other Dead Sea Scrolls (Enoch, Jubilees, 4QMelchizedek, and others), and
      documents from Elijah’s School of the Prophets. We will also look at what the early church fathers
      taught about the Melchizedekian priesthood. (P. 233)

                                         T12P Background for Revelation
       Without critical interaction with the standard conclusions drawn by academia from Philo, Josephus, Pliny,
wide acceptance of Johnson’s reconstruction is highly unlikely. That said, I would be interested to see where such
interaction might lead by someone who undertakes it. The undertaking might not be quite as daunting as one might
suppose, though. Some scholars have already provided a foothold to such an argument from their comments on
Jn 1:29, where at the very beginning, JB said of Jesus, “Behold, the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the
world!” Commenting on this Johannie text, Beasley-Murray (WBC) appeals to texts from T12P as providing pre-
Christian illumination!

             Such a figure appears in the Testament of Joseph 19:8 f., where a lion and a lamb appear
      together, the former the Messiah from Judah, the latter the Messiah from Aaron (so reads the present
      text; J. C. O’Neill has suggested that the original text spoke of one animal only: “a lamb … like a
      lion,” The Lamb of God, 5). It is said, “And all the beasts rushed against him (the lamb), and the lamb
      overcame them, and destroyed them, and trod them underfoot. And because of him the angels and men

  Walter A. Elwell and Barry J. Beitzel, “Essenes,” Baker Encyclopedia of the Bible (Grand Rapids, MI: Baker
Book House, 1988), 721.
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                 Page 446
      and all the earth rejoiced.… His kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, which shall not pass away.” A
      further reference to the lamb of God occurs in the Testament of Benjamin 3; O’Neill has given strong
      reasons for believing both references to be pre-Christian (1–27). (Italics his.)

      The Testament of Joseph and the Testament of Benjamin are both T12P documents. So, here we have NT
scholarship arguing that these T12P texts are pre-Christian documents used to express Christian doctrine.
Leon Morris (NICNT, 1995) opens the door wide open to the Qumran scrolls being usable as a source to inform
our understanding of the NT backdrop:

             The Qumran scrolls have made acceptance of the saying “not so impossible as it once
      seemed,” as Brownlee puts it. He points out that the scrolls link suffering, and specifically the
      Suffering Servant, with messiahship, and he discovers “important Essene conceptions in John’s
      messianic expectation.” They have not been taken over unaltered, but the point is that the
      Qumran evidence indicates that a saying like this on the part of a man like John no longer looks
      improbable. In the third place, if it is not authentic it is difficult to ascertain where the saying comes
      from. It possesses none of the characteristic marks of a Johannine construction.

      If my proposal that TDan 5:12-13 (from T12P) might have been the background for the use of the term New
Jerusalem by Jesus (Rev 3:12) and John (Rev 21:2) seems too radical, then consider that Kruse (TNTC, 2017)
suggests that TJos (from T12P) was the background for the warrior lamb motif in Revelation:

             John may have been identifying Jesus as the apocalyptic warrior lamb referred to in
      Jewish writings (e.g. 1 Enoch 90:9–12; T. Jos. 19:8–9), as did the author of the book of Revelation
      (Rev. 5:5–10; 17:14), though the latter fused the idea of the powerful lamb/lion of Judah with the
      sacrificial lamb.

Ditto for Carson (PNTC), who adds TBen as another T12P pre-Christian probability:

             If we credit the Evangelist with making an historical statement about the witness of John the
      Baptist, however, then perhaps some such reconstruction as the following involves fewest
      difficulties. When the Baptist identified Jesus as the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world,
      he probably had in mind the apocalyptic lamb, the warrior lamb, found in some Jewish texts (1
      Enoch 90:9–12; Testament of Joseph 19:8; Testament of Benjamin 3:8—the latter passages
      probably, but not certainly, pre-Christian) and picked up in the Apocalypse (Rev. 5:6, 12; 7:17;
      13:8; 17:14; 19:7, 9; 21:22–23; 22:1–3).

If Carson can pose such a reconstruction from T12P, then why can Johnson not pose a similar reconstruction from
T12P? Is Johnson just being more consistent? In any case, in commenting on Rev 21:2, Aune (WBC) acknowledges:
“Apart from T. Dan 5:12, the phrase “New Jerusalem” does not occur in the OT or early Jewish literature.” So
which text had it first, the Testament of Dan or Revelation? Evans (BKBC) seems skeptical of the Qumran
contribution:

             A set of so-called “New Jerusalem” texts were discovered at Qumran. These documents provide
      descriptions, written in Aramaic, of an anticipated heavenly city which paralleled Ezekiel 40–43 and
      John’s description here in Revelation. Scholars conjecture that a surveyor of the era was a visionary
      in ancient Judea who provided a detailed picture of the entire city’s dimensions.

However, these are not so-called New Jerusalem texts in that one of them is the only other reference to New
Jerusalem! Watson says that the idea of an earthly Jerusalem being superseded by a Heavenly Jerusalem was a later
Jewish expectation:

            In later Jewish literature the expectation of Jerusalem restored was replaced by Jerusalem
      supernaturally transformed by God (Tob 13:8–18; T. Dan. 5:12–13; Sib. Or. 5.420–27; 1 Enoch 90:28–
      29) or a Jerusalem from heaven which would replace the earthly Jerusalem altogether (2 Esdr 7:26;
Excursus on Abraham and Moses and John the Baptist                                                         Page 447
                                           551
      10:25–28; 13:36; 2 Bar. 4; 32:1–4).

       Later! Really? How can that be since Abraham, the father of the Jewish people, was looking for this Heavenly
Jerusalem? Are we sure that it was later? Could the Essenes have preserved accounts that went back earlier, even
to Abraham? How else did WH know that Abraham was looking for a Heavenly City? Why else could WH assume
that his Jewish readership would share his understanding that Abraham was looking for this City? Even if
TDan 5:12-13 was later, how much later was it? Was the use of the term in TDan 5:12-13 at least prior to the use
of the term in Revelation? Watson cites the Sibylline Oracles 5.420-7 above as being part of this later expectation.
Fine. However, Barclay (NDSB) puts this expectation as being intertestamental and thus pre-Christian:

             The writers between the Testaments had their dreams.
             The city which God loved he made more radiant than the stars and the sun and the moon; and
      he set it as the jewel of the world and made a Temple exceeding fair in its sanctuary, and fashioned it
      in size of many furlongs, with a giant tower, touching the very clouds, and seen of all, so that all the
      faithful and the righteous may see the glory of the invisible God, the vision of delight. (Sibylline
      Oracles 5:420–7).

       So the intertestamental literature beat Jesus and John to the punch line. Now the questions are, How and by
how much? Did it do so by some so-called visionary surveyor of the era, as Evans would have us believe, or by
retaining prophetic documents preserved by the Essenes that went back to the patriarchs, as Johnson would have us
believe? I am warming up to the latter possibility. With a number of scholars already caught with their hands in the
proverbial cookie jar concerning Jn 1:29, it may not be long before we find the same thing true in Rev 21:2. Indeed,
some scholars appear to have taken the lid off the cookie jar for that text also. Affirming the basic authenticity of
these writings is starting to look appealing.
Melchizedekian Abraham?
       Johnson argues that Abraham became a Melchizedekian priestly king. But how could this be if Shem outlived
Abraham? Normally, one would think that the priesthood was not passed on until the death of the previous
Melchizedekian. Johnson ignores this problem. Blondino makes a positive case for Shem being a Melchizedekian
but then tries to posit that Abraham became a Melchizedekian when Shem died:

              It is very interesting that the term “Hebrew” or “of Eber” would be first used in Abram's
      generation. At the time of Abram three men in the patrilineal line from Noah remained alive (after
      Terah's death). Shem, Eber, and Abram. Eber would live into Isaac’s life but Shem would die, leaving
      all of the priestly accounts, genealogies, with the new bearer of the covenant... Abraham.552 (Ellipses
      his.)

However, Blondino’s argument is flawed since Shem clearly outlived Abraham! Taking a different approach,
Berner uses ancient rabbinical and extrabiblical material to argue that Shem was the Melchizedekian referred to in
Gen 14:18. For instance, Berner appeals to the positive identification in the Ancient Book of Jasher, mentioned in
the Bible (Josh 10:13; 2Sam 1:18).553 Modern scholarship is, of course, well aware of such claims but dismisses
them, denying that the book of Jasher we have today is the original one referenced in the Bible and, in some cases,
ascribing rabbinical attributions to Shem as an anti-Christian polemic against taking Melchizedek as a typological
reference to Christ, even though modern scholarship frequently acknowledges that Melchizedek was not a

theophany of Christ. Notwithstanding, as I acknowledged in DSAS, although the Jasher we currently have is no

If Shem was Melchizedek, then the statement that he was without father or mother or genealogy in Heb 7:3 is
speaking typologically, based on the details (and lack thereof) in the narrative. A typological understanding of
Melchizedek is common among commentators (GNTC, LCHS, NIBC, NICNT, WBC). The OT details do not
provide the background for Melchizedek. We can only derive the conclusion that Shem was Melchizedek from
logical inference and extrabiblical material. This lack of explicit OT background for Melchizedek’s origin is useful
for typology and allows WH to use Melchizedek legitimately as a type.
       Writing at a scholastic level, Horton documents that Jewish Rabbis from a very early time identified
Melchizedek with Shem. Horton speculates that they may have done so because (1) Shem was alive during the time
of Abraham and outlived him by 35 years; (2) Noah’s blessing of Shem in Gen 9:26 has some similarities with
Melchizedek’s blessing of Abraham in Gen 14:18-20; and (3) between these two texts “there is no other passage in
which Yahweh is said to be the God of anyone other than Shem” (pp. 114-118). Horton also documents that later
Jewish midrash went on to assume that Melchizedek passed the priesthood on to Abraham (pp. 119-124). Although
Horton offers possible textual and theological reasons as to why Melchizedek was identified as Shem, he concludes
his book-length discussion as a Melchizedekian agnostic: “We are no closer than when we begin to knowing
anything of real substance about the historical figure named Melchizedek. The only solid connection between this
figure and the priesthood are preserved for us only in later tradition, and we have no reason to try to push this
tradition back beyond the first century B.C.”556
       Contrariwise, Hahn cites Horton’s positive contributions regarding scriptural implications for identifying
Shem as Melchizedek; however, Hahn progresses rather than retreats from that trajectory: “The blessing that links
Abraham to Shem and Noah suggests that the identity of Melchizedek can be inferred from the narrative itself.
Indeed, many ancient Jewish and Christian interpretive traditions ‘naturally’ (i.e., on the basis of the logical flow
of the Genesis narrative) identify Melchizedek with Shem” (p. 132). Hahn proceeds to surmise that Shem’s
outliving Abraham by 35 years and the identification of Salem as Jerusalem are “convergent lines of narrative
evidence which identify Melchizedek as Shem” (p. 133). “Also his status as Noah’s firstborn son qualifies Shem
for the priesthood. Ancient Jewish and Christian interpreters generally recognized that a pre-Levitical natural
priesthood belonged to the firstborn in the patriarchal narratives” (p. 133). Hahn expands upon the latter concept
subsequently (pp. 298-299). Like Berner, he uses scripture and logic to identify the Melchizedekians with the family
line in which Shem was the Melchizedekian priest who blessed Abraham.557
       In contradistinction to Hahn, Berner contends:

             As is often the case in God’s dealings with man, the actual firstborn son is not always the one
      to carry the promise....The firstborn son tended to characterize the natural man or earthly man as
      opposed to the spiritual man. The earthly preceded the spiritual in time, but the spiritual had
      preeminence with God. This trend is also true of Noah’s sons. Shem is listed first of three sons in
      Gen 5:32 and Gen 6:10 because he is the one that God favored to carry the promised seed, but Shem
      was not the oldest son.”558

This assessment is part of Berner’s section, “24 Elders on Earth” (pp. 234-241). Berner posits that Shem was one
of the 24 Elders and provides a chart of the proposed elders. Nevertheless, Berner’s argument would also apply to
Shem’s sonship status to Noah in regards to Melchizedek. Berner juxtaposes the natural sequence with the actual
sequence. Certainly, this was the case with Esau and Jacob. In any case, this differentiation between Hahn and

Berner demonstrates that scholarly identification of Shem as Melchizedek is not limited to one line of reasoning.
Divergent courses of argument can converge to identify Shem as a member of the Melchizedekian order.
        Although I retain a degree of skepticism regarding the degree of authenticity of some of the material used to
support the identification of Shem as Melchizedek, I adopt the Shem-Melchizedek proposition as being most
reasonable, partially in deference to the superior logic of Berner’s inferences in Fullness and Hahn’s lines of
reasoning in Kinship. For example, Berner argues that the order of Melchizedek refers to an order of priestly kings,
just as the title Pharoah is used for Egyptian kings. In the same manner, Melchizedek is not a personal name but a
title implying a sequential order of priestly kings. I highly recommend Berner’s discussion for further scriptural
inferences. Unlike Johnson, Berner’s argument is not solely reliant upon extrabiblical arguments. Hahn points the
way toward combining both approaches in a manner that might be palatable for critical scholarship.
        Berner (Fulness, 415) also provides a detailed chart of his estimated sequence of the Melchizedekians.
Berner’s Melchizedekian sequence offers a competing model to Johnson’s sequence. I have adapted my chart of
Abraham’s Genealogy and Abbreviated Timeline from DSAS to illustrate the Melchizedekians up until the time of
Joseph using Berner’s logic.
                                   Illustration 146. Berner’s Melchizedekians
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                      Page 450

       The line of Melchizedekians was suspended until Christ, who was the ultimate and final Melchizedek, as
noted by Berner on his chart. On my chart, the Melchizedekians are highlighted in blue on the left, and the gap of
time from the preceding Melchizedek to the subsequent Melchizedek is highlighted in red on the right, with the
name of the Melchizedek denoted in red font. The Melchizedekian baton, so to speak, was not passed on to the next
Melchizedek until the time of death of the preceding Melchizedek. In both of our charts, Abraham is not considered
a Melchizedek because he would have died before the previous Melchizedek. Thus, Abraham did not have an
opportunity to receive the Melchizedekian baton, though he would have been well acquainted with the
Melchizedekian literature. Accordingly, counting Jesus, there were fourteen Melchizedekians in this model. I
inquired of Berner what his take was on Johnson’s proposal of Abraham as a Melchizedek. Berner responded:
                 It is more logical to me that the [Melchizedekian] appointment would be for life (rather than
         retirement at age 50 as in the Levitical system) considering the longevity of their lifespans and the
         nature of the position - King/High Priest/Prophet. If so, the progression would be to the next in line
         for the position at the time or very near the time of death of the current High Priest. I still lean towards
         my interpretation that Abraham did not fill that specific role. I am not being absolutely adamant about
         it, but I am not convinced that Johnson has proved that Abraham was [a Melchizedekian]. Shem clearly
         outlived Abraham. The Bible never refers to Abraham in the context of his fulfilling all three roles.
         We never see Abraham acting as king over Salem or being the head of the school that he attended as
         a youth under Noah and Shem. Instead, he sends Isaac to attend that school, and Isaac would have
         studied under Shem. I simply am not convinced that the incident where Shem received the tithes from
         Abraham’s spoils of war and Shem blessed Abraham equates to his making Abraham the High
         Priest/King of the Most High God.559
       Johnson, on the other hand, following the Dead Sea Scrolls, only has ten Melchizedekians, including Jesus
(p. 236). He notes that Adam’s son Seth and Seth’s son Enos were godly, but Johnson believes they were passed
over as being chosen as Melchizedek successors. According to Jasher, God used Cainan to lead a revival, and in
687 AM, Adam made Cainan the second ruler over the whole Earth (Jasher 2:11-13). Cainan had Mahalaleel, who
had Jared, who had Enoch. Johnson says that in 687 AM, Enoch was made a Melchizedek because Jasher says that
Enoch was the ruler over men for 243 years (Jasher 3:12). Enoch had Methuselah. Because Enoch was raptured, he
did not anoint a successor, so all the kings of Earth anointed Methuselah as their ruler. Methuselah had Lamech,
but Lamech was not very godly, so understandably, he was not a Melchizedek. Lamech had Noah. Methuselah was
inspired by the Holy Spirit to conclude that his grandson Noah would be the next Melchizedekian king and thus
taught Noah. As a result, Noah received all the patriarchal writings dating back to Adam (and took them with him
on the Ark). Noah ordained his son Shem as the next Melchizedek. (So, in Johnson's discussion, an unspecified
length of time laps in which Shem and Noah were both living after Noah ordained Shem). Johnson strangely skips
over Eber as being the next Melchizedek. By Johnson’s own assessment, though, Eber seemed like a good choice:

         Eber was born in 1723 AM, sixty-seven years after the Flood. His heart was perfect before the Lord
         his God. Was he to be the next King of Righteousness? Shem should wait until he could be sure. If
         God told Shem directly to anoint Eber as the next King of Righteousness he would, or if he witnessed
         Eber fulfilling the prophecy by destroying the apostasy, then he could be sure. But the growing
         apostasy was not yet full.
               Shem and Eber kept the ancient records of their fathers that Noah had brought aboard the Ark
         and they wrote the historical records of their time. In time Eber was given a vision that a series of
         earthquakes would occur to further separate the nations. (Pp. 247-248)

                Shem passed away at the age of six hundred, in 2158 AM. Eber then took full control of the
         School of the Prophets and continued their work teaching the whole council of God and recording
         history. (Pp. 252)

     In any case, Johnson states that Abraham was the seventh Melchizedekian (p. 252) and claims, “Eventually
God did speak to Abram. God changed his name to Abraham and made the covenant with him. He was to be the

Johnson seems to make this inference on his own since he does not cite any text that explicitly states this to be the
case. He assumes that the blessing of Abraham by the Melchizedekian priest, described by Gen 14:18 and Jasher
16:10-12, confers this Melchizedekian ordination, but that is an assumption. Yet, given Johnson’s model, in which
the next Melchizedekian assumes his position while the previous Melchizedekian is still living, one cannot charge
Johnson with being inconsistent in making this inference. He forgets to mention who the eighth and ninth
Melchizedekians are in his assessment, but we can infer that they are Isaac and Jacob. This would make Jesus the
tenth. In Johnson’s reconstruction, Joseph would not have been a Melchizedekian because the kingship was given
to Judah and the priestly role to Levi, leaving Joseph with only the prophetic role. These three offices would not be
united again until the Melchizedekian office was resumed and retained by the tenth Melchizedekian—Jesus.
                                   Illustration 147. Johnson’s Melchizedekians
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                               Page 452

       For comparison purposes, I have superimposed Johnson’s nine patriarchal Melchizedekians (denoted in
brown font) over Berner’s thirteen Melchizedekians (denoted in the red font). Where Berner and Johnson concur,
I have used a combination of a red-brown font. The major variant is that Johnson follows extrabiblical texts
(particularly Jasher) more closely in determining when one Melchizedekian ordained his successor. This presents
an anomaly regarding Shem and Abraham. Since Shem outlived his successor, who ordained Isaac? Did Shem
ordain him also? A minor variant is that Berner includes Joseph in his chart of Melchizedekians, whereas Johnson
apparently excludes Joseph. Much more importantly, in comparing Johnson with Berner, we have two competing
scholarly models by which to make a reasonable inference that the patriarchs were well acquainted with writings
going all the way back to the very beginning regarding the Promised Redeemer and Promised City.
       I shared this comparative analysis with Berner, who, true to form, responded with an argument that shows
sound reasoning from the Scripture:

             There is a [valid] point regarding the division of roles King, High Priest, and Prophet among
      Jacob’s (Israel) sons: Judah, Levi, and Joseph.
             However, when did that division become effective? Levi did not receive the priesthood, and
      Aaron the High Priestly position until the Exodus, well after the time of Joseph. Judah had the kingly
      line, but when did he begin to function as a king? Certainly not before or during the time of Joseph.
      Judah could not reign until after the death of Israel. Joseph was the one functioning as King and
      Prophet. Who was functioning as High Priest between the time of Israel and Joseph until the time of
      the Exodus? It seems to me that the divisions of labor really came into being after the time of Joseph
      and would not necessarily have excluded Joseph from the High Priest / King position of the Order of
      Melchizedek.560

Berner has the better biblical argument. Johnson has the better extrabiblical argument. Taken together, their
competing models coalesce to give considerable justification for not only believing that Shem was the historical
Melchizedekian referenced in Gen 14:18 but that he was part of a historical order of Melchizedekians who, to a
considerable extent, faithfully preserved patriarchal information spanning back to the beginning of time, a minority
report that would have been known by the populace in the days of Jesus and John the Baptist and adopted and
adapted by these two prophets in their proclamations of the kingdom.561

   Personal correspondence, 3/20/2022.

    Berner’s biblical arguments and Johnson’s extrabiblical arguments may not agree on all particulars, such as
whether Abraham was a Melchizedekian, but they do reinforce each other in regarding Shem as part of a
Melchizedekian order of priests. As noted, like Berner, Hahn gives a strong case for logically deducing from
Scripture that Shem was a Melchizedekian. However, like Johnson, Hahn also supports his position from T12P. In
his 2009 publication of Kinship, regarding Shem being Noah’s firstborn and thus the “Melchizedek-as-
Shem…prototype of Christ, God’s firstborn Son who eternally reigns as priest-king in the heavenly Jerusalem” (p.
303), Hahn gives a lengthy endnote in which he quotes a variety of passages from T12P with bracketed statements
by J. H. Charles, marking “suspected Christian interpolations.” Hahn, however, seems to suspect that such suspected
interpolations might not be interpolations after all. Even if they are, he makes an intriguing comment:

             It is significant that canonical figures like Adam, Shem, Melchizedek, and Abraham (along with
      his “seed”) all figure in the messianic hope and speculations of these intertestamental sources, as they
      share a similar place in Hebrews….If any or all of these are interpolations, their significance as
      parallels would not be weakened, but in fact strengthened, for in that case their proximity to Hebrews
      would be confirmed” (P. 475n67.)

      Hahn suspends judgment on whether Charles is correct to suspect any of the strong Christological statements
of T12P as being interpolations, even the prophetic statement about the Jews impaling the Messiah, and is content
to point out that the allegation of interpolation is itself an admission of interconnection between T12P and WH.
Again, we have a chicken-egg quandary. If the Christians got the Christological-Melchizedekian association from
WH, from where did WH get such a strong association? Did he pull it out of thin air? Hardly! Did he get it from
Excursus on Abraham and Moses and John the Baptist                                                          Page 453
                                                       Conclusion
       Abraham was looking for the City. Moses was looking for the reward. By combining these articular
affirmations in the same context, WH gives the distinct impression that Abraham and Moses were looking for the
same thing—the Reward City. Additional scriptural implications reinforce this inference, as do oral traditions as
well as implications by Jesus.
       Abraham and Moses foresaw Jesus preaching the GOK and offering the Reward City as the pinnacle of the
KOH. Abraham was looking forward to this Reward City. He could anticipate that any of his physical or spiritual
descendants who failed to qualify for this reward would be misthologically excluded from the City. Jesus referred
to exclusion from the City as being cast into the outer darkness, thus excluded misthologically from the KOH but
not soteriologically from the KOG. Surprisingly, some commentators have anticipated the thrust of this conclusion
and have correctly argued that Jesus confirms it as well.
       In all likelihood, the biblical information we have regarding Abraham and Moses is only the tip of the iceberg.
They probably had access to information going all the way back to Adam that had been preserved by faithful
Melchizedekian priests. The Pharisees said that these testaments were lost. The Essenes said that they were
preserved. Current scholarship is divided over just how much of the information we currently have is authentic.
Nonetheless, a plausible argument can be made that information was preserved to a considerable extent until the
days of John the Baptist. Fragments of this information have even reached us today. A plausible reconstruction of
some of that information is possible, even though potential redaction and interpolations might not be ruled out
completely. Nevertheless, enough documentation survives to postulate that there has always been a faithful remnant
who preserved genuine faith in the Promised Redeemer and Promised City. WH gives us confirmation that the
Melchizedekian order of prophet-priest-kings found its final completion in the reestablishment of this order in
Prophet-Priest-King Jesus.




T12P? Did he get it from a shared intertestamental understanding preserved in the Essene community? Did he derive
the implications for himself from the OT? If he got it from OT implications, what was to prevent the Rabbis or
Essenes from doing the same. And if they could do so, why could OT prophets not do so also? And if they could
do so, why could OT patriarchs not do so also? The textual evidence indicates the association was already in
circulation during the intertestamental period, and logical inference suggests that it probably had a long history,
making Johnson’s reconstruction all the more credible.

                                                     Introduction
       As I was finishing this book, I notified James Hollandsworth via email that I had gone back to listen to his
sermons on Ephesians in order to expand upon that section in my book. He responded that he had preached that
series back in 2018 and was not sure that he still believed everything he said back then. He informed me that he had
been doing a lengthy sermon series on the Life of Christ and planned to convert it into a series of books. He further
added that he had come to conclude that rewards are not eternal, particularly the negative rewards.
Furthermore, he had come to believe that the wiping away of tears in Rev 21:4 refers to the Perfect Age (PA)
of the New Heavens (NH) and New Earth (NE) rather than referring exclusively to New Jerusalem (NJ).
Consequently, he now believes that all believers as having a part in the NH-NE age so that, in that era, NJ
will connect with Earth, and God will dwell with men, while NJ will apparently hover over Earth in the
Millennium. He concluded by stating that he was not trying to argue his position via our email discussion.
                                              Preliminary Exchange
      My first response was:

            I was not aware that [you] had moved away from the eternal-rewards view. However, I’m not
      surprised since it is incompatible with the universal reconciliation to which you were leaning. As
      you note, email correspondences are not a suitable medium for debating our differences in this regard.
      Those discussions would be book-length and thus must be deferred to our books. Will you be dealing
      with both of these in your proposed volumes? Curious, though, did you retain a primarily soteriological
      view of the Gospel of John, or did you migrate to a misthological view?562

Years before, Hollandsworth and I had attended a Bible conference together, at which he was one of the speakers.
In a sermon at the conference, he had given a very brief and subtle indication of his openness to the popular form
of universal reconciliation (UR).563 We discussed it on our drive back, and I expressed my opposition to this form
of UR and stated that I would be taking the opposing point of view. He said that to respond appropriately, I would
need to read a number of books advocating the position he was considering. I ordered the books and read one. Other
writing projects, however, prevented me from pursuing that investigation further, though, in the present book, I
noted his UR inclination.564
       His explanation was:

             In my first book, The End of the Pilgrimage, p. 63, I indicated that I was leaning toward the
      position that rewards are eternal. But I did not discuss it in that book. In my third book, Keys for
      Inheriting the Kingdom, p. 51, I explained that there are two positions on rewards, and briefly described
      the two positions, but I did not take a position. I have since landed on the position that rewards are
      NOT eternal and, yes, that is largely because I hold to universal reconciliation and define eternal
      as “age-during,” not unending.
             In my upcoming book I don’t specifically address the RAE [rewards-are-eternal] issue,
      because to me it is a moot point, but I do tackle the definition of eternal, laying the groundwork for
      future books. Not to mention, I also paint a picture of the Gospels as being entirely about the millennial
      kingdom, thus rewards are millennial in scope.
             In this book I essentially take the position that John’s Gospel is misthological, not soteriological
      (along with the Synoptics, of course), including the John 3 Nicodemus passage. The content of this
      first book spans Christ’s baptism through his early Galilean ministry, but lays a very important
      foundation for the rest of my writings on the Gospels. I explain concepts such as repentance, the gospel
      of the kingdom, John's baptism, rewards and inheritance, kingdom of heaven and kingdom of God, the

       He responded by giving me his definition of eternal life and asked if I thought it would be consistent with his
misthological view of the four gospels and his UR position. He provided me with a few points to outline his
anticipated UR scenario. I responded by noting a few of the questions I would have about his position and that there
were too many unanswered questions at that point for me to guess the consistency of his model. That evaluation
will probably have to await our book-length interactions. However, I will expand upon some of the questions I
presented to him for consideration so that they might be addressed more fully in his forthcoming books.

                                               Preliminary Questions
      In order to properly understand his new model, a number of questions will need to be addressed. The few
questions I posed in the email will need to be expanded, of course, if we have the opportunity to pursue this line of
inquiry in the future via further responses within our books. We will need to evaluate the logical consistency of his
new model, the logistics of his new model, and the biblical accuracy of his new model. Preliminary questions that
come presently to mind would include the following.
      As to logical consistency, his email seems to be lacking it. Back to back, he states: “I have since landed on
the position that rewards are NOT eternal and, yes, that is largely because I hold to universal reconciliation
and define eternal as ‘age-during,’ not unending. In my upcoming book I don’t specifically address the RAE
[rewards-are-eternal] issue, because to me it is a moot point” (emphasis his).
      His statement was in response to my having said that I was not aware that he had moved away from the
eternal-rewards view but that I was not surprised since it is incompatible with the universal reconciliation to
which he was leaning. Apparently, he has acknowledged the accuracy of my assessment. The chain of logic would
basically run like this.

         1. If negative rewards are not eternal, then positive rewards are not eternal either, so rewards are not eternal.
         2. If rewards are not eternal, then punishment in Hell, which is a negative reward, is not eternal.

Of course, this chain can be abbreviated to a one-line deduction:

             •   If negative rewards are not eternal, then punishment in Hell, which is a negative reward, is not eternal.

565
      Personal correspondence, 3/4/2022.
Excursus on Universalism                                                                                         Page 457

If this line of reasoning is correct, then how can Hollandsworth say that whether rewards are eternal “is a moot
point” for his position. On the contrary, it is the backbone of his position. In brief, the logical connection would be:

           •   Denying eternal rewards leads to universalism.
           •   Affirming universalism leads to denying eternal rewards.

This relationship is logical. If A then B is true, then the contrapositive is true: if not-B then not-A. In other words, if
denying eternal rewards leads to universalism, then denying universalism leads to affirming eternal rewards.
Consequently, when Hollandsworth said that affirming universalism had led him to deny eternal rewards, I was
not surprised. Hollandsworth is a sharp thinker, and he was just following the extrapolation of his position to its
logical conclusion. If he can maintain logical consistency within his model, then discussion of his model in the
years to come might be worth the effort. Over the years, I have sought to perform logical extrapolations on my own
models to see where such extrapolations would lead. This book is evidence of my doing so. I have also performed
logical extrapolations on other models also. If a model collapses under the weight of its own extrapolations, it is
not worthy of sustained consideration.
       Given the above considerations, kingdom teachers who deny eternal rewards will need to provide rebuttal as
to why their denial does not lead to universalism. Hollandsworth has seemingly followed Chitwood’s argument to
its logical conclusion. Chitwood’s denial of eternal rewards leads to universalism. If this assessment is not true,
then Chitwood will need to explain why this conclusion is false. If I am wrong, prove it. Otherwise, the argument
can be made that, by denying that rewards are eternal, Chitwood is leading others into universalism, even if he does
not follow the logic of his own position to its own conclusion. The same would be true of other kingdom teachers
who reject the eternality of rewards.
       As to my equating Hollandsworth’s UR with universalism, the logic seems straightforward enough. A
Wikipedia article makes the connection in its opening sentence: “In Christian theology, universal reconciliation
(also called universal salvation, Christian universalism, or in context simply universalism) is the doctrine that
all sinful and alienated human souls—because of divine love and mercy—will ultimately be reconciled to God”
(emphasis original).566 Stated somewhat more fully, from the previous discussion herein, the version of universal
reconciliation popular today confuses it with universal redemption.567 The popular form of UR goes like this:

           •   UR = universal reconciliation = universal redemption = universalism.

Hollandsworth’s brand of universalism is more logically consistent, it would seem, than the form provided by
Wikipedia in that he apparently includes Satan and fallen angels and demons. He does not limit UR to sinful and
alienated humans but poses that all of the fallen creation will be restored. He was leaning in this direction in our
conversation driving back from the Bible conference, and in our email exchange, I explicitly asked about fallen
angels, asking if bridal distinctions will disappear and if fallen and unfallen angels and all humans have equally
glorious bodies. That simple question, however, is a loaded one that Hollandsworth will need to explain in-depth
since he takes the affirmative position. Conversely, if someone does not take an affirmative position, they need to
demonstrate why logical consistency with their premise does not require it.
       In my books, I have followed the logical extrapolations of my model to propose that the primary reason God
allowed sin was to produce the Bride and to maximize the beauty of the Bride. If my arguments are valid, then
Hollandsworth’s argument is invalid. Since my arguments are explained in detail, he will have to match them with
an equally detailed rebuttal. Various questions will have to be considered in doing so. Why did God allow sin? He
did not have to allow it, of course, as I have demonstrated in my corresponding discussions. God did not have to
allow sin in order to allow free will or love, which are the typical shortsighted answers given as to why God allowed
sin. Instead, God uses fiery trials to produce godliness in our character with profound ontological ramifications.
       Like an oyster that must undergo pain over time and respond appropriately to produce a pearl, we need to
respond appropriately to the Holy Spirit so that He can produce the desired results in us. Hollandsworth will have

to provide explanations that are logically consistent with his new model. Does God just snap His fingers and give
unfaithful beings the same godly character that was achieved over time through the obedience of the faithful via the
Holy Spirit working in their lives? If not, and yet God gives the unfaithful or unbelieving the same degree of glory
as the believing faithful, does God really care about the godly character of the faithful? On the other hand, if God
can somehow give the same godly character to unbelievers or the unfaithful regardless of their unfaithfulness, then
why did God require the faithful to undergo trials in dependency on the Holy Spirit to develop such character?
When God takes fallen entities out of the Lake of Fire, does He eliminate their sin? If so, how? Does He regenerate
them? Does He give them eternal life? Does He give them a choice? If the beauty of the Bride was gained by her
struggles against sin, how would fallen angels and fallen humans gain an equally glorious nature without any
struggle against sin? If the elimination of sin is all that is needed for a glorious nature and glorious bodies, then why
did Christ make His Bride suffer? Did He make her suffer needlessly? Making someone sinless does not necessarily
make one glorious. Sinless believers will not necessarily be glorious believers. Does this change in eternity future?
       Will God make everyone love Him equally in Hollandsworth’s UR? Will He give them a choice as to whether
they love Him? Does He even care if they love Him? Will He become indifferent to their previous freewill responses
to Him? Is He indifferent to their previous freewill love for Him? If He becomes indifferent to their previous freewill
obedience to Him, will He become indifferent to their previous freewill love for Him? Is God’s internal attitude
toward those who previously loved Him and served Him no different than His attitude toward those who did not?
Previously, pleasing God required that one believed in His existence and believed that He is a rewarder. Why does
God cease to be a rewarder? Does His nature change?
       Hollandsworth still affirms a literal New Jerusalem (NJ) since he places it above the New Earth. How many
people and angels will live in NJ? Will some live outside of NJ? What determines who gets to live in NJ? If NJ was
a reward before the Perfect Age, does it become a gift in the Perfect Age? Will there still be people in physical
bodies during the Perfect Age? Will their bodies be less glorious than those in celestial bodies? If there is no longer
any variation in celestial degrees of glory among those beings in celestial bodies, will there be differences in the
degree of physical glory for those in physical bodies?
       If God is not a misthological communist during the millennial age, does He become a communist during the
Perfect Age? Do rewards really matter in the millennial age if they are only temporary? In comparison to the eternal
age, would millennial rewards not be practically meaningless? Does it really matter if we witness for Christ or live
for Christ if we are all going to be treated the same in the end anyway?
       Examples raised by others such as Yates will also need to be addressed, such as the eternal kingdom not
seeming to be limited to a millennial kingdom in 2Pet 3:10-13, which goes directly to the new Heavens and Earth.
Imperishable treasure and crowns seem to be eternal (Mt 6:20; 1Cor 9:25). The kingly ranking in Rev 21:24 seems
applicable to the eternal state. The white robes are rewards in the eternal state for keeping God’s commandments
(Rev 22:14; MT). Will some angels still be archangels during the eternal state? If ruling angels still exist, then ruling
believers surely will as well.568
       Of course, other questions based on analogy could be added as well. Paul reasons from analogy to heavenly
glory when he says, “There is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars;
for star differs from star in glory. So also is the resurrection of the dead” (1Cor 15:41-42a). Does the analogy break
down in the eternal state? Will all stars be equally bright in the eternal state? Will the moon be as bright as the sun
in the eternal state? Does the God of variety become a God of uniformity in the eternal state? Paul also says, “All
flesh is not the same flesh, but there is one flesh of men, and another flesh of beasts, and another flesh of birds, and
another of fish. There are also heavenly bodies and earthly bodies, but the glory of the heavenly is one, and the
glory of the earthly is another” (1Cor 15:39-40). Will there be degrees of glory for humans versus animals versus
fish in the eternal state? Will a tadpole be as glorious as a human in the eternal state? Will humans be as glorious
as Jesus in the eternal state? Will the creation be as glorious as the Creator in the eternal state? Paul had a very
negative view of those who “exchanged the glory of the incorruptible God for an image in the form of corruptible
man and of birds and four-footed animals and crawling creatures” (Rom 1:23). If Hollandsworth denies degrees of
glory, does he make the glory of God interchangeable with that of men and animals? If Hollandsworth affirms a
differentiation between the divine glory of the Creator versus that of creation, what happens to the divine glory that
the Lord shares with His Bride?

                                               Preliminary Assessment
       Inquiring minds will want to know the answers to such questions, and Hollandsworth will need to provide
answers in a manner that is logically consistent with his model. Doing so will allow us to compare and contrast our
models. I generally find that interacting with competing models allows me to refine and strengthen my own models.
My model has been refined by the fire many times through that process. Interacting with his model will provide yet
another opportunity. Until that point, to be consistent with my own arguments made in TOD, my preliminary
assessment is that those adopting Hollandsworth’s model will be committing misthological apostasy and placing
themselves in danger of being considered misthological tares.
       Apostasy comes in many forms and degrees. Switching from being a believer to being an atheist is an extreme
form of soteriological apostasy. Falling from grace into legalism, though less extreme, is nevertheless another form
of apostasy. Similarly, switching from affirming rewards to denying rewards is an extreme form of misthological
apostasy. Some do so by making rewards gifts or by making rewards a soteriological matter rather than a
misthological matter or by claiming that the Bema is merely an educational experience. Lesser degrees of apostasy
include denying that rewards have a negative dimension or denying that rewards are eternal. Most of those who say
that rewards are eternal do not follow through on the logical implications of their position to its logical conclusions.
Ironically, the argument could be made that their logical inconsistency spares them from being considered
misthological apostates. It would seem that the more one undermines misthology, the more one places himself or
herself in danger of being considered a misthological apostate at the Bema.
       My initial email to Hollandsworth, in which I mentioned that I had listened to his sermons on Ephesians, was
occasioned by our both having received a joint email regarding a prepublication copy of The Open Door by Mize
for our review. Like any book, it has its strengths and weaknesses. A weakness within it to which I take strong
exception is one that I find in various other kingdom teachers. It denies that rewards are eternal. Mize states: “The
loss of the soul is not eternal condemnation but the loss of rewards, position and honor in the millennial kingdom”
(p. 49). Rather than affirming that the loss of one’s soul is an eternal misthological loss, Mize implies that it is only
a millennial misthological loss. Having acknowledged that New Jerusalem is initially a misthological reward, he
then seems to indicate that it will eventually be a gift, the home of the entire Church simply because their sin nature
is soteriologically removed: “The home of the church will be the New Jerusalem. All church members will be totally
cleansed by the Lord Jesus Christ, and the sin nature that plagues Christians in this age will be eradicated in the
coming age (i.e., the millennium)” (p. 107). Like so many others, Mize implies that the loss of rewards is limited to
the millennial kingdom because Rev 21:4 supposedly erases all such distinctions at that time:

             The unfaithful servant, a believer, was called wicked and slothful, and his talent was taken away
      from him. In addition, he received no sovereign authority in the coming kingdom. He was called an
      unprofitable servant, and he was cast into “outer darkness” where there will be weeping and gnashing
      of teeth. “Outer darkness” is a position outside the sovereign dominion of Jesus Christ in the upcoming
      millennial kingdom. Outer darkness is not hell. The phrase comes from an ancient oriental idiom that
      means “to receive the displeasure of the master.” There will be much weeping and gnashing of teeth
      by Christians when they are not allowed to enter into the kingdom of Jesus Christ. This does not mean
      exclusion from heaven but exclusion from being a sovereign or ruler in the one thousand year
      kingdom of Jesus Christ. God the Father promises to wipe away all the tears at the end of the
      Millennium (Rev. 21:4). (P. 138).
       I expressed my counterargument in TOD, taking the promise as a litotes limited to overcomers in NJ. If Mize
intends to wipe away rewards with the wiping away of tears, then he has committed a major misthological fallacy.
Hollandsworth will challenge my assessment in his model, for he stated in his email: “I view Rev. 21:4 as referring
to the NH/NE era, not as exclusively referring to NJ.” Apparently, in Hollandsworth’s opinion, the wiping
away of tears in Rev 21:4 does, in fact, indicate the wiping away of eternal rewards.
  •   The universal wiping away of tears indicates universal wiping away of rewards and leads to universalism.
       Certainly, Hollandsworth will address this argument more fully in his writings. We can debate it more fully
then. Until then, let those kingdom teachers who refuse to adopt my misthological interpretation of Rev 21:4, which
limits it to faithful believers, and who yet wish to disassociate themselves with universalism, explain why their view
of universal wiping for all believers does not undermine the doctrine of rewards and thereby implicitly imply full-
blown universalism. For now, I simply call attention to the fact that when Chitwood indicated that the wiping away
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                  Page 460
of tears in Rev 21:4 leads to a wiping away of rewards in the eternal state, I provided an extended rebuttal in RAE.
As noted therein, The backbone of Chitwood’s argument is that because Rev 21:4 rules out all forms of death within
the eternal state, it must rule out eternal rewards as well.569 In RAE, I summarized his argument syllogistically.
                   Illustration 148. A Syllogistic Summation of Chitwood’s Primary Argument
1. Major Premise: Rewards necessarily entail misthological death (Rom 8:13).
2. Minor Premise: All forms of death are removed for everyone in the kingdom during the eternal state (Rev 21:4).
3. Therefore, rewards must cease at the beginning of the eternal state.
Chitwood argues:
             Scripture deals with millennial rewards and/or loss, never with eternal rewards and/or loss. This
      should be easy enough for anyone to understand, for if rewards are eternal, so is loss of rewards. And
      loss of rewards involves an association with death (Rom. 8:13), something which Scripture clearly
      reveals will be done away with at the beginning of the eternal ages beyond the Millennium
      (I Cor. 15:26; Rev. 21:4).570 (Emphasis his.)

Chitwood’s argument deductively amounts to this:

      1.   “If rewards are eternal, so is loss of rewards.”
      2.   “Loss of rewards involves an association with death.”
      3.   Death “will be done away with at the beginning of the eternal ages.”
      4.   Therefore, rewards are not eternal.

        If Chitwood is correct, then his argument necessitates a denial of eternal rewards.571 Chitwood believes that
the misthological death is only millennial, obliterated at the end of the millennial kingdom by Rev 21:4 because all
forms of death supposedly are ended at that point. I objected in RAE, however, because the evidence within
Revelation indicates that Rev 21:4 is a litotetic promise limited to faithful believers, in harmony with the OT
background, concerning both the tears and the City. His argument actually backfires. The logical conclusion of his
argument is that no misthological death continues at that point, so rewards cease. Contrariwise, as demonstrated in
RAE, the context of Rev 21:4 limits this no-death promise to overcomers. Therefore, in accord with Chitwood’s
own rationale, misthological death, and hence rewards, must extend into the eternal state.
        Hollandsworth is aware of such arguments, of course. So, it will be intriguing to see Hollandsworth’s
interaction. Seemingly, in adopting a universal wiping away of tears in Rev 21:4 as leading to a wiping away of
eternal rewards and as a result leading to universalism, Hollandsworth is just a more consistent version of Chitwood.
It will also be interesting to see if Chitwood ignores the implications of his own writings as leading to universalism.
Hollandsworth followed the trail Chitwood blazed by proceeding into universalism. Will Chitwood be able to
counter the argument that his position leads to universalism? Will he just ignore the extrapolations of his position?
Or will he adopt universalism?
        Chitwood was more logically consistent than the average misthologist in perceiving that adopting a universal
no-death view of Rev 21:4 for all believers leads to a no-eternal-rewards interpretation for the eternal state for all
believers. Apparently, Hollandsworth is even more logically consistent than Chitwood in recognizing that a
Chitwoodian affirmation of a universal no-death view of Rev 21:4 intertwines with his universal no-tears view of
Rev 21:4 to teach a universal universalism. In other words, the Chitwood-Hollandsworth interpretation of Rev 21:4
leads to a no-death-no-tears-no-rewards view of the eternal state that extrapolates to affirm a universalism that
embraces Satan and his fallen forces in universal harmonious reconciliation. I object most strenuously, of course.
But I have a model that allows me to do so. Can the same be said of others who object to universalism?
