Excursus on Universalism                                                                                        Page 461
                                       Illustration 149. Misthological Apostasy




        My perception is that there is room for variation among those who are misthologically qualified to inherit
the kingdom. Those who qualify to inherit the kingdom will not have agreed on every point. We might disagree,
let’s say, about the time and nature of the rapture. Is it pretribulational or midtribulational? Is it full or partial? My
postulation is that as long as one has reached soteriological, nikological, and misthological maturity, allowable
variations among those who are qualified for bridal glory are to be expected and will determine their degree of
bridal glory, not disqualify them from receiving bridal glory.
        Disagreement among those who are misthologically disqualified from inheriting the kingdom will likewise
exist. Not everyone will be disqualified for the same reason. In a passage well-known to misthologists, Paul says,
      23
         And I do all things for the sake of the gospel, that I may become a fellow partaker of it. 24 Do you
      not know that those who run in a race all run, but only one receives the prize? Run in such a way that
      you may win. 25 And everyone who competes in the games exercises self-control in all things. They
      then do it to receive a perishable wreath, but we an imperishable. 26 Therefore I run in such a way, as
      not without aim; I box in such a way, as not beating the air; 27 but I buffet my body and make it my
      slave, lest possibly, after I have preached to others, I myself should be disqualified. (1Cor 9:23-17)

Some believers will be qualified for the prize; some will be disqualified. Obviously, one can be disqualified from
winning the prize by a variety of means. Moral apostasy would be one means; theological apostasy would be another
means. Even theological apostasy can take various forms. Misthological apostasy is one of them. Flat out denying
the significance of rewards would disqualify one for rewards since believers who displease the Lord will not qualify
for rewards, and believing that God is a rewarder is a ground-level necessity to please God misthologically
(Heb 11:6). A related means of denying that the Lord is a rewarder is to claim that the Bema is merely educational,
thus asserting that God is a mere educator rather than a rewarder. In this approach, no real misthological distinctions
are made between the qualified and disqualified. Quite possibly, this might be taken by the Lord as a form of
misthological apostasy that is extreme enough to disqualify anyone teaching it from inheriting the kingdom. Such
teachers might be extracted from the KOH at the Bema and given a real educational experience by being sent to the
celestial darkness for eternity.
       In between these two groups, of the totally qualified versus the unquestionably disqualified, is an intermediate
misthologically                    range where errors committed in one’s misthological position can have such a
significant negative impact on one’s misthological evaluation at the Bema to be considered possible grounds for
disqualification. This endangered group is in danger of being disqualified at the Bema because those within it have
embraced a significantly undermining view of the Bema.
       In my opinion, claiming that everyone will have their tears wiped away is one of the first steps often taken
on the slippery slope of misthological apostasy. Does this mean that everyone who teaches that everyone will have
their tears wiped away has committed a form of misthological apostasy that automatically disqualifies them from
the KOH? Not by a long shot! Nevertheless, they have taken a step that, if followed through to its logical conclusion,
could arguably lead to full-fledged misthological apostasy. To their benefit, since this deduction is a rather extended
Misthological Models Part 5                                                                                   Page 462
extrapolation, most people taking the universal-wipe-away-tears argument are not logically consistent enough to
perceive that it leads to universalism. Nevertheless, even the un-extrapolated version of the universal-wipe-away-
tears argument undermines misthology to a considerable extent and can be expected to have negative implications
at the Bema. Too many people think, What difference does disappointment at the Bema really make since all my
tears will be wiped away anyway? Those teaching that all tears are wiped away will be accountable for teaching a
false doctrine that leads some to draw this false conclusion. Bad misthology is a stumbling block to proper thinking.
       On the other hand, a misthologically astute teacher like Hollandsworth, who is more logically consistent than
the typical misthologist, might have deduced that making the wiping away of tears universal makes the wiping away
of rewards universal. Would he be correct in that assessment? In my opinion, yes. It would be interesting to see if
he can prove this point in defense of his position. I would think he should be able to do so. Naturally, if he does, I
will challenge his premise. His conclusion stands if, and only if, the premise is granted. If the wiping away of tears
is universal, then the most reasonable inference is that universalism is true. The slope is really that slippery, but
most people will probably not have the audacity or capacity to admit it. As a result, those committing this
                                       fallacy are normally at the upper part of the endangered range and therefore are
not necessarily disqualified from inheriting the kingdom.
        At the lower end of the spectrum would be teachers who have taught a form of misthological apostasy that
has a much higher probability of disqualifying them from inheriting the kingdom. Those at the lower end of the
slope would include the                                  group and the                                     group. Even
further down the slope would be the                                                                         group.
       Not everyone teaching these positions is necessarily automatically disqualified from inheriting the kingdom.
Various factors need to be taken into consideration, thereby yielding a variable threshold on the sliding scale,
making it fuzzy as to where the black-and-white dividing line is, pictured in the illustration as indicating that one is
no longer qualified to inherit the kingdom because of erroneous kingdom teaching. For example, some of those who
are teaching that rewards are not eternal only do so very implicitly. By no means do they stress the fact that, in their
opinion, rewards are not eternal. Instead, they do everything they can, within the limited parameters of their model,
to stress the importance of rewards. The Lord will weigh their positive stress on the importance of the rewards in
their favor, weighing most heavily what they have stressed. On the other hand, Chitwood had extrapolated his
rewards-are-not-eternal implications to the very threshold of deducing that rewards are not eternal. Then the force
of his argument carried him over the threshold. Thus, in my assessment, he has placed himself in a much more
tenuous position. The Lord might decide that he has undermined misthology sufficiently to be disqualified from
inheriting the kingdom. Chitwood might have become a misthological tare, the very thing he warns against. Maybe,
maybe not. The Lord will judge if this is the case. I am only warning about the potential danger. Hollandsworth has
extrapolated the rewards-are-not-eternal-position even further to reach its logical conclusion. It leads to
universalism. If I am correct that rewards are eternal and that universalism is therefore false, then Hollandsworth
has placed himself in an even worse predicament than Chitwood in that Hollandsworth is further down the slope.
Yet, rather than automatically assume that Hollandsworth is necessarily disqualified from inheriting the kingdom,
I anticipate that the Lord will weigh most heavily the stress Hollandsworth places on the importance of rewards. In
theory, Hollandsworth’s positive stress on the importance of rewards might sufficiently outweigh the negative
impact his universalism has on rewards to yield a sufficiently positive result so that he might nevertheless inherit
the kingdom.
       Admittedly, to someone like myself, with a mathematical background, Hollandsworth’s stress on the
importance of rewards sounds hollow. His positive stress is like water off a duck’s back to me. A thousand years of
rewards compared to, and thus divided by, an infinite number of years of no rewards makes rewards practically
insignificant. In my mind, anyone truly extrapolating Hollandsworth’s position to its ultimate conclusion will
concede that rewards do not really matter. Since the Lord will surely judge us for the extrapolations of our teaching,
Hollandsworth’s affirmation of universalism would still be a significant negative at the Bema and perhaps even
outweigh the positive and thereby disqualify him from inheriting the kingdom.
       Since I am inclined to believe in the irrevocability of apostasy when committed by mature believers, I do not
know that Hollandsworth can be won back to his previous position. Perhaps not. Misthological tares may not be
able to change back into wheat. Chitwood, Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig might be in the same boat and are now
destined to go down with the ship they have built. Yet pointing out the possible irrevocable nature of their mature
misthological apostasy might prove helpful for someone considering the possibility of adopting their positions. If
you are making such contemplations, consider the possibility that you might end up taking a one-way trip down a
Excursus on Universalism                                                                                      Page 463
slippery slope that ends in misthological disqualification. You might cross the line, the point of no return. Where is
the line? Only the Lord knows since it varies according to your individual factors.
       As to Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig, I do not assume they are necessarily excluded from the positive reward of
inheriting the kingdom just because they do not believe in negative rewards. However, since they have written a
book denying that rewards can be negative, they have increased the probability of their being disqualified.
Moreover, since they have wrongly given the impression that anyone teaching negative rewards is a legalist, they
have further increased the probability of their being disqualified from regality, possibly digging themselves into a
deeper hole from which they cannot escape.
        Fundamentally, the difference between Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig versus Chitwood or even Hollandsworth
is a matter of logical consistency. The denial of negative rewards leads to universalism. The same is true of the
denial of eternal rewards. Hollandsworth is being more logically consistent in following his premise to its logical
end. If Rokser, Stegall, Witzig, or Chitwood disagree that their position logically leads to universalism, let them
prove that to be the case. Conversely, perhaps Hollandsworth will demonstrate that the positions held by Rokser,
Stegall, Witzig, and Chitwood necessarily lead to universalism.
                                                       Conclusion
        Let’s end by playing the what-if game. Even at this preliminary stage of evaluation, a misthological
application of Pascal’s wager seems appropriate. In terms of PA, what do Hollandsworth and I have to lose? Suppose
that Hollandsworth is right and I am wrong. What do I have to lose? Evidently nothing. Suppose that I am right,
and Hollandsworth is wrong. What does he have to lose? Everything, misthologically speaking. Potentially, he
could fail to inherit the kingdom and be excluded from NJ during PA.
        The same is true of Rokser, Stegall, and Witzig. If they are right and I am wrong, then, according to them, I
will live in New Jerusalem, eat of the Tree of Life, wear white garments, and rule with Christ over the nations.
Scarry, right? Not hardly! That is their point. Don’t fear the outer darkness or the logical implications that would
be entailed regarding it. Rather, take all the overcomer promises in Revelation as applying unconditionally to you
simply because you are a believer. Conversely, if I am right and they are wrong, they are in danger of losing out on
all these rewards because they will have wrongly turned these rewards into gifts.
        Likewise, for Chitwood, if he is right and I am wrong, then, after the thousand years of the millennial age, it
will not matter. Alternatively, if I am right and he is wrong, then he stands the reasonable possibility of regretting
it for infinite ages.
        If Rokser, Stegall, Witzig, Chitwood, and Hollandsworth are right and I am wrong, then I will live in New
Jerusalem throughout the eternal ages and enjoy all the benefits that go with it. If I am right and they are wrong,
then they are in considerable danger of being excluded from New Jerusalem throughout the eternal ages and losing
all the benefits that go with it. Of course, this observation does not prove that I am right or that they are wrong.
Still, one should consider the logical implications of the models being considered. Jesus did say to count the cost
(ESV) for the position you are deliberating and the path you are weighing (Lk 14:28). Here and on many occasions
elsewhere, Jesus seems to advocate taking the most prudent course of action as the one that pays off in the long run.
If this is the Lord’s intent, then He has left us an implicit clue as to which of the above positions is misthologically
sound. Mathematically, I have counted the cost, and I am quite content with the bottom line. Choose wisely.
